site_title: Macron roils French sense of equality with pension reform
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron's proposed pension reform has sparked nationwide strikes and protests, with opponents arguing the changes disproportionately affect low-income workers and are part of a broader economic model favoring the wealthy. The reform would raise the retirement age to 64 and increase the number of years of work required for a full pension. Critics, including left-wing politicians and trade unions, claim Macron is prioritizing the interests of the rich and middle class, while the poorest will bear the burden of the reform.

images.alt_text: Demonstrators gather in Place de la Bastille during a rally called by French trade unions in Paris, France on Jan 19, 2023.

Passengers a platform during a strike by Paris transport network workers at Saint-Lazare metro station in Paris on Tuesday (Jan 31).  Opinion polls show that most French people oppose the retirement-age reform, but President Emmanuel Macron and his government intend to stand their ground.

site_title: Orchard Bel Air relaunched for en bloc sale at unchanged S$587.5m guide price
summary: Orchard Bel Air, a 99-year-old condominium in District 10, Singapore, has been relaunched for collective sale with a guide price of S$587.5 million. The site, located next to the Orchard Boulevard MRT station, has a land area of 93,126 sq ft and can be redeveloped up to 276,298 sq ft at a gross plot ratio of 2.96. Marketing agent Knight Frank expects strong demand for luxury residences in the area, citing positive sales momentum at nearby projects.

images.alt_text: Orchard Bel Air's 99-year leasehold tenure started in Aug 1980, and it has a land area of about 93,126 square feet.
Built in 1984, Orchard Bel Air comprises 71 residential units across 25 storeys.

site_title: Taiwan exports fall for the fourth straight month; uncertainty darkens outlook
summary: Taiwan's export orders contracted for the fourth consecutive month in December, falling 23.2% from a year ago to $52.17 billion. Weaker Chinese demand and slower global consumer spending due to inflation and interest-rate hikes contributed to the decline. Orders for telecommunications products plummeted 24.1%, while electronic product orders fell 20.9%, but were partially offset by demand for chips for high-performance computing and cars. The ministry expects export orders to be lower than in January 2022, citing uncertainties from global economic downturns and the war in Ukraine.

images.alt_text: Gross domestic product is forecast to have expanded 2.9 per cent in 2022 from a year earlier.
While Taiwan’s assisted local chipmakers in the past with infrastructure construction and other measures, the island is now stepping up its efforts.
Taiwan’s export orders are a leading indicator of demand for hi-tech gadgets and Asian exports, and typically lead actual exports by two to three months.

site_title: Canada’s economy grew 0.1% in November, likely was flat in December
summary: Canada's economy grew 0.1% in November, matching forecasts, but likely remained flat in December. The Bank of Canada raised its key interest rate at a record pace to cool the economy and bring inflation down. Annualized GDP in the fourth quarter was likely 1.6%, exceeding the bank's forecast of 1.3%. The Canadian dollar traded at 1.3430 to the US dollar, while the service-producing sector grew 0.2% in November, driven by transportation and warehousing gains.

site_title: Malaysia’s ex-PMs Mahathir, Muhyiddin sued for cancelling high-speed rail project with Singapore
summary: Former Malaysian Prime Ministers Mahathir Mohamad and Muhyiddin Yassin have been sued for allegedly cancelling the High-Speed Rail project with Singapore, resulting in significant financial losses for the country. A Malaysian man, Mohd Hatta Sanuri, is seeking RM1 million in damages and compensation for every Malaysian citizen, claiming negligence and tort of misfeasance in public office by the defendants. The project was cancelled in 2020, with Malaysia paying over RM320 million in compensation to Singapore. The lawsuit seeks to revive the project and demand compensation for the public.

site_title: Keppel DC Reit’s H2 DPU up 4.8% to S$0.05165
summary: Keppel DC Reit reported a 4.8% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.05165 for the second half of FY2022, driven by the accretive acquisition of London Data Centre, Guangdong Data Centres, and investments in bonds issued by M1 Network. Gross revenue and net property income (NPI) also grew 4.3% and 4% respectively. The Reit's portfolio occupancy remained stable at 98.5% with a long portfolio weighted average lease expiry of 8.4 years. Despite rising interest rates, the manager remains cautiously optimistic about growth opportunities.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
Jude Chan

0620 Yy / Media Release: Keppel DC REIT strengthens portfolio with two data centres in Guangdong, China
/ 20 June 2022, Singapore – Keppel DC REIT has entered into agreements with Guangdong Bluesea Data Development Co. Ltd. (Bluesea) and its parent company, Guangdong Bluesea Mobile Development Co. Ltd., to acquire two data centre facilities, on a fully-fitted basis, in Jiangmen, Guangdong Province, for RMB 1,380.6 million (approximately S$297.1 million).
Yeo Siew Eng is currently a director in Transit Link and in mainboard-listed companies Venture Corporation and Nam Lee Pressed Metal Industries.

site_title: German unemployment rate remains stable at 5.5% in January
summary: Germany's unemployment rate remained stable at 5.5% in January, according to the Federal Labour Office. The number of unemployed people fell by 15,000 in seasonally adjusted terms, reaching a five-month low of 2.5 million. This is partly reversing the jump since June 2022, driven by Ukrainian refugees becoming eligible for jobless benefits. Despite this, analysts predict a small increase in the unemployment rate over the coming months due to the German economy shrinking and tightening lending conditions.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Employment Office "Amt fuer Arbeit" designed by Bauhaus architect Walter Gropius, one of UNESCO world heritage sites of the eastern German city of Dessau, is pictured in Dessau, Germany, March 5, 2022. Picture taken March 5, 2022. REUTERS/Wolfgang Rattay/File Photo

site_title: PayPal to cut 2,000 jobs in push to trim costs
summary: PayPal Holdings plans to cut 2,000 jobs, about 7% of its workforce, to trim costs amid a macroeconomic slowdown that has weighed on the company's business. The cuts will take place in the coming weeks, following a year of efforts to reduce expenses and improve operating leverage. Despite the job cuts, PayPal's stock has risen 14% this year, outpacing the S&P 500 Information Technology Index. The company aims to achieve US$1.3 billion in cost savings this year.

images.alt_text: The PayPal controversy was also seized upon by conservative politicians and social media personalities, who called on users to delete their PayPal accounts.

site_title: IMF sees Singapore growth slowing to 1.5% in 2023 as global headwinds offset China boost
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has lowered its 2023 growth forecast for Singapore to 1.5% due to slowing global growth outweighing the positive impact from China's economic reopening. This is slower than the 3.7% growth achieved in 2022. The IMF also raised its 2023 forecast for global growth to 2.9% from 2.7% in October. The US economy is expected to grow at 1.4% and the euro area at 0.7%, while Singapore is expected to experience elevated inflation.

images.alt_text: A general view shows the city skyline in Singapore on December 1, 2022. (Photo by Roslan RAHMAN / AFP)

site_title: Bursa Malaysia net profit down 36% in 2022 due to lower revenue and higher expenses
summary: Bursa Malaysia's net profit declined 36% in 2022 to RM226.6 million due to lower revenue and higher expenses. The exchange's overall trading revenue decreased 31% to RM377.1 million, while operating expenses increased 1.4% to RM292.7 million. Despite the decline, Bursa Malaysia's chairman Abdul Wahid Omar remains confident that the exchange can improve its performance this year through continuous investments in new business.

images.alt_text: Bursa Malaysia CEO Muhamad Umar Swift at the launch of the first Shariah-compliant carbon exchange in the world on Dec 9, 2022 in Kuala Lumpur.

site_title: UK retail giant Tesco to axe more than 2,000 jobs
summary: Tesco, the UK's largest supermarket group, plans to cut 2,100 jobs, including 1,750 management roles, due to rising costs. The company will offer alternative roles to some affected employees and create 1,800 new shift leader positions. The job cuts come as Tesco passes on rising costs to consumers, despite posting a bumper revenue during the Christmas season. The move is part of the company's efforts to maintain profitability amid a cost-of-living crisis.

images.alt_text: A shopper holds bags outside a Tesco Plc supermarket in Guildford, UK, on Tuesday, Jan. 10, 2023. Tesco are due to release a trading update on Thursday. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg

site_title: Economists see uneven employment growth in Singapore in 2023
summary: Singapore's employment growth is expected to become more uneven in 2023, following a record expansion in 2022. Total employment grew 231,700 in 2022, driven by growth in non-resident employment in construction and manufacturing sectors. Resident employment also grew, but at a slower pace. Economists, including OCBC chief economist Selena Ling, note that while the manufacturing sector appears downcast, pockets of growth segments will still be hiring. This uneven growth may indicate a shift in the job market.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
Resident unemployment was the same as the previous month at 2.8 per cent, according to the latest figures from the Ministry of Manpower.
Office workers walking at Raffles Place Park within the heart of Singapore's financial centre in the CBD area on Nov 1, 2022.

site_title: Malaysia bags RM13 billion in foreign direct investment from three investors after Singapore mission
summary: Malaysia secured an additional RM13 billion (S$4 billion) in foreign direct investment from three investors - Sea Ltd, Yondr Group, and Inseact - during a mission to Singapore. The investments, expected to be operational within three years, will create over 2,000 jobs and contribute to Malaysia's economic growth. The investments reflect the long-standing relationship between Malaysia and Singapore in trade and investment, with Malaysia aiming to strengthen this partnership and pursue high-quality, strategic investments.

images.alt_text: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said he and Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim had had a fruitful discussion, including on how to make progress on “outstanding bilateral issues” during the latter's first official visit to the Republic.

site_title: After three pandemic-hit years, the world must be better prepared to deal with next health crisis
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has warned that the world is "dangerously unprepared" for the next health crisis, citing the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic as a sobering reminder. Over 752 million confirmed cases and 6.8 million deaths have occurred since the pandemic began, with a recent surge of over 170,000 deaths per week. The WHO urges governments and citizens to learn from the pandemic experience and take steps to prepare for future crises, emphasizing the need for strong political will and action to mitigate the impact of potential disasters.

images.alt_text: The end to both federal emergency declarations will see funds used to subsidise Covid-19 medicines, medical insurance and other types of government aid related to the pandemic come to an end.

WHO chief Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus says he agrees with the advice offered by the committee regarding the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic and that the event continues to constitute a public health emergency of international concern.

site_title: Financial stability in the spotlight as central banks gear up to hike rates again
summary: Central banks are expected to hike interest rates again this week, with the US, EU, and UK set to announce rate hikes. Analysts are divided on the impact, with some predicting a recession and financial crash, while others expect a peak in rates later this year followed by a decline. The US Federal Reserve is predicted to raise rates by 25 basis points, while the European Central Bank is expected to raise rates by half-a-percentage point to 3%. The Bank of England is also expected to raise rates to combat high inflation.

images.alt_text: The IMF lifted its outlook for global inflation on Tuesday and now predicts it will slow from 8.8 per cent in 2022 to 6.6 per cent this year and 4.3 per cent in 2024.
A recent Fed survey hinted at strategies banks may be using to recoup lost cash as funding pressures increase.

Powell is expected to balance this week’s likely 25 basis-point increase in rates with a stern message that the step-down from the past six hikes doesn’t diminish his commitment to reducing inflation to 2 per cent.
The Singapore dollar has been a safe haven for the past few years, so why the change?

site_title: US Justice Dept investigating Tesla self-driving features
summary: The US Department of Justice has launched an investigation into Tesla's driver-assistance features, including Autopilot and Full Self-Driving (FSD) capabilities. The investigation follows an ongoing review by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA). The Securities and Exchange Commission has requested documents related to Tesla's Autopilot and FSD features. This development comes amid concerns over the safety and reliability of Tesla's advanced driver-assistance systems.

images.alt_text: Tesla has cut about US$9.5 billion of debt since its peak in Jun 30, 2020.
The regulator’s Autopilot review directly touches on a business priority that Musk has singled out as crucial to Tesla’s future.

site_title: GuocoLand’s Midtown office tower 80% pre-committed at TOP stage
summary: GuocoLand's 30-storey Guoco Midtown office tower in Singapore has reached 80% pre-commitment of its 709,000 square feet space, with major tenants including Pacific International Lines, BASF, and NetEase Interactive Entertainment. The mixed-use development offers premium office spaces, recreational facilities, and retail clusters. When completed, the project is expected to attract over 10,000 people daily, boosting GuocoLand's portfolio and recurring income.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei
Guoco Tower Urban Park
GuocoLand, whose projects include Midtown Modern (pictured in artist's impression), benefitted from a strong property market and tourism revival.
Work and play get a green boost

site_title: Eurozone yields edge down after weak data from France, Germany
summary: Eurozone yields fell 3.5 basis points to 2.3% on Tuesday, January 31, after weak economic data from France and Germany revived fears of a slowdown. France reported meagre growth in the final quarter of 2022, while German retail sales unexpectedly fell. The European Central Bank is expected to consider a 50-basis point rate hike at its upcoming meeting, further exacerbating the economic concerns.

images.alt_text: At a recent Riksbank gathering, European Central Bank (ECB) executive board member Isabel Schnabel spoke about how the ECB is aligning policy with Paris Agreement objectives, including steps to actively decarbonise its balance sheet.
The IMF lifted its outlook for global inflation on Tuesday and now predicts it will slow from 8.8 per cent in 2022 to 6.6 per cent this year and 4.3 per cent in 2024.
Stronger-than-expected Spanish inflation data  prompted eurozone bond yields to rise sharply.

site_title: Oil prices settle steady on higher US demand, weaker dollar
summary: Oil prices settled steady on Tuesday, influenced by a weakening US dollar and higher demand for US crude and petroleum products in November. The second-month Brent contract settled at $85.46 a barrel, up 1%, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures settled at $78.87 a barrel, up 1.3%. A weaker US dollar made dollar-denominated crude cheaper for foreign buyers, while a report showed US demand rose 178,000 barrels per day in November, the highest since August.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Exxon Mobil logo and stock graph are seen through a magnifier displayed in this illustration taken September 4, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Hong Kong regulator to regulate stablecoins as crypto risks mount
summary: Hong Kong's de facto central bank, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA), plans to regulate stablecoins to address the risks they pose to financial stability. The proposals aim to implement a regulatory framework by the end of this year and the next, covering areas such as user-protection, audit, and anti-money laundering. Following a consultation, respondents "generally indicated their support" for regulating stablecoins, and the HKMA will regulate stablecoins referencing the Hong Kong dollar, with entities needing to apply for a licence to conduct regulated activities.

site_title: Sembmarine to hold EGM for Keppel O&M merger on Feb 16; IFA in favour of deal
summary: Sembmarine will hold an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) on Feb 16 to vote on its proposed merger with Keppel O&M. Independent directors recommend shareholders vote in favor of the deal, which has already received backing from Keppel shareholders. The merger, first announced in April 2022, will result in Keppel O&M becoming a wholly-owned subsidiary of a combined entity, with Sembmarine shareholders owning 46% and Keppel retaining 54%.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Keppel sky sign taken at Ocean Financial Centre.
Sembmarine is poised to become a much bigger and more competitive entity with a sharp renewables focus post merger
Sembcorp Marine's net order book stands at S$7.1 billion as at the end of its third quarter, of which S$6.7 billion comprises new contracts acquired in the year to date.

site_title: GM profit rises in Q4 2022; expects strong earnings in 2023
summary: General Motors (GM) reported a higher quarterly net profit of $2 billion in Q4 2022, up from $1.7 billion in the same period the year before. The company forecast stronger earnings in 2023, with estimated full-year net income between $8.7 billion and $10.1 billion. GM's adjusted earnings before interest and taxes (Ebit) of $14.5 billion was a record, and the company expects its core auto operations to perform at a consistently strong level in 2023.

site_title: Adani share sale fully subscribed after last-minute jump in bids
summary: Indian billionaire Gautam Adani's $2.5 billion equity sale was fully subscribed on its final day, aided by a last-minute surge in demand, after allegations of fraud by short-seller Hindenburg Research. The offering was India's largest follow-on share sale and removed one overhang for the country's $3.2 trillion stock market. However, retail investors bid for only 10% of the shares, undermining Adani's goal of broadening the investor base. The sale was seen as a victory for Adani, but investor concerns about corporate governance remain.

images.alt_text: An Adani Enterprises Limited board of director arrives to attend a news conference to announce the company's forthcoming Follow-on Public Offering (FPO), in Mumbai on January 19, 2023. - Indian industrialist Gautam Adani on January 19 launched the country's biggest follow-on share sale, offering investors incentives and discounts in a bid to lower debt and fuel rapid expansion at his conglomerate. (Photo by Punit PARANJPE / AFP)

site_title: US labour costs trail forecasts, adding to slower inflation signs
summary: US employment costs rose 1% in the fourth quarter of 2022, slightly slower than forecast, but still consistent with inflationary pressures. This data supports the Federal Reserve's decision to raise interest rates further and keep them higher for longer to curb inflation. Wage growth is slowing, but still not enough to alleviate concerns, with policymakers indicating their work is far from over. The Fed is expected to slow the pace of rate hikes to a quarter point during its upcoming policy meeting.

site_title: Singapore stocks up 3% in January on expectations of peaking interest rates
summary: Singapore stocks rose 3% in January, driven by optimism over smaller interest rate hikes by central banks, particularly in the Reits and technology manufacturing sectors. Reits and technology manufacturers gained 6.3% and 2.8% respectively, with four of the top five performers on the Straits Times Index being Reits. Analysts expect strong results from banks and sectors like tourism, hospitality, and retail Reits in February, despite ongoing risks including decelerating growth and persistent inflation.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
Singapore Exchange (SGX).

site_title: US house price inflation slows further in November
summary: US single-family home prices increased 9.2% year-over-year in November, slowing further from October's 10.7% growth. The Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes have driven the housing market into recession, but declining mortgage rates and slowing price growth have raised hopes for stabilization. The 30-year fixed mortgage rate fell to 6.13% last week, its lowest level since mid-September. Economists predict a relatively tame year for housing in 2023, with prices potentially flatlining.

images.alt_text: Crossing the 50 per cent occupancy threshold is a milestone sure to be cheered by business leaders on Wall Street and elsewhere who have pushed for more in-office attendance.

site_title: Mobile phone, PC shipments to fall again in 2023
summary: Mobile phone and PC shipments are expected to fall for the second consecutive year in 2023, with mobile phone shipments projected to decline 4% to 1.34 billion units. This marks a decade low, with shipments in 2021 reaching 1.43 billion units. The decline is attributed to consumers holding onto their phones longer and moving away from fixed contracts, as well as rising global interest rates and cost of living. Personal computer shipments are also expected to slide 6.8% this year, following a 16% decline in 2022.

site_title: US consumer confidence ebbs in January; inflation expectations rise
summary: US consumer confidence fell to 107.1 in January, down from 109.0 in December, as households worry about the economy's prospects. Consumer inflation expectations rose to 6.8% from 6.6% last month. The present situation index increased to 150.9, but the expectations index dropped to 77.8, below the 80 threshold associated with recession. This decline in consumer confidence and rising inflation expectations may signal a slowdown in the US economy.

site_title: France hit by second nationwide strike against pension reform
summary: France experienced a second nationwide strike against the government's pension reform plan, disrupting electricity production, public transport, and schools. The strike, which involved over 1 million people, was in response to the government's plan to raise the retirement age to 64 from 62. The strikes were called by unions, who argue that the reform is unfair and brutal, and that alternative solutions, such as taxing the super-rich, could achieve the same goal. Despite the opposition, President Emmanuel Macron's government intends to stand its ground, citing the need to ensure the pension system's financial stability.

images.alt_text: Public transport operator RATP says that most metro and suburban rail services in Paris will be severely restricted on Tuesday.
Demonstrators gather in Place de la Bastille during a rally called by French trade unions in Paris, France on Jan 19, 2023.
In France, more than a million people took to the streets on Thursday (Jan 19) to protest President Emmanuel Macron's pension-reform plan.
Hundreds of thousands took part in rallies across the country to protest against government plans to raise the retirement age by two years to 64.

site_title: Shipping’s forgotten crisis could get worse
summary: A new report by the NGO hotline Alarm Phone reveals an increase in migrant crossings and distress alerts in the Mediterranean Sea in 2022, with 105,000 people arriving in Europe through the central Mediterranean route. The report notes that 673 boats were in distress, up from 27 in 2018, and at least 30 people have died crossing the Mediterranean so far this year. The Italian government's new decree requires civilian rescue ships to immediately head to Italy after each rescue, delaying further lifesaving operations, and NGOs argue this will make the central Mediterranean, one of the world's deadliest migration routes, even more dangerous.

images.alt_text: The intention behind cold ironing is to cut pollution by stopping ships using their onboard diesel generators while in ports.

site_title: Falling property values create US$55b funding shortfall in Europe
summary: Europe's commercial property market is experiencing a funding shortfall of €51 billion ($72.6 billion), with a decline in property values causing a gap between owed debt and available refinancing credit. This is partly due to rising interest costs and tightening credit standards. The region's property boom is over, with real estate distress levels at their highest since 2012. Lenders will need to be more proactive about restructuring loans, and the cyclical adjustment may be quicker this time around, according to research by AEW Europe.

images.alt_text: Residential properties stand on the hill leading to Saint George's hilltop castle near Martim Moniz square where Chinese buyers have targeted real estate at auction in Lisbon, Portugal, on Saturday, Nov. 1, 2014. Portugal is the latest target for Chinese property investors, who have been snapping up assets abroad to counter a slump in China's real estate sector. Photographer: Mario Proenca/Bloomberg

site_title: SMEs upbeat about 2023 prospects; GST hike, energy prices and inflation still top concerns: poll
summary: Most small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in Singapore are optimistic about 2023, with 59% expecting economic conditions to improve. Despite this, concerns over the goods and services tax (GST) hike, rising energy prices, and inflation remain top priorities. 55% of SMEs reported an increase in overall business sales in 2022, with 58% expecting further growth in 2023. Most SMEs are preparing for increased expenditure, with 47% expecting to spend more on capital and 42% planning to hire more staff.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
Linus Goh, OCBC's head of global commercial banking, believes there is a chance that SMEs will still remain in expansionary territory for the first quarter of 2023.

site_title: Property auctions, mortgagee sales seen surging in 2023 on rising bankruptcies
summary: Bankruptcy petitions are rising in Singapore amid interest rate hikes, inflationary pressures, and the expiry of pandemic support measures for borrowers. This is expected to lead to a surge in property auctions, with up to 40-50% more listings in 2023. Experts predict more private homeowners will sell their properties at reduced prices due to increased mortgage payments. The commercial and industrial sectors may also see an increase in listings as small and medium-sized enterprises struggle financially. Total listings are expected to reach around 600 in 2023, up from 420 in 2022.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim
Even without acquisition growth, Singapore-listed Reits merit serious consideration if organic growth drivers deliver.
Owner sale listings almost doubled to 91 listings in Q3 2022, from the previous quarter's 62. It also comprised more than two thirds of the sale listings this quarter, which totalled at 131.
Owner sale listings more than doubled to 62 properties last quarter, up 121.4 per cent from Q1’s 28.

site_title: Sri Lanka’s key inflation rate eases to 54.2% in January
summary: Sri Lanka's key inflation rate eased to 54.2% in January, down from 57.2% in December, according to the country's statistics department. Food prices rose 60.1% and non-food prices climbed 51% from a year earlier. The central bank held interest rates steady for a third consecutive meeting, citing the need to tame high inflation and restore economic stability. However, a US$2.9 billion bailout plan with the IMF is contingent on securing financing assurances from China and Japan.

site_title: ComfortDelGro’s venture arm may need fuller autonomy if it is to live up to its potential
summary: ComfortDelGro's venture arm, CDG Ventures, has made its first investment in nearly four years with a US$4 million investment in teleoperation company Ottopia. The slow pace of investments may be due to a lack of autonomy, as CDG Ventures is part of Comfort's corporate strategy team, unlike peers such as Singtel's Innov8 and ST Engineering Ventures. With a US$100 million fund size, CDG Ventures has the potential to make more investments, but its current structure may be hindering its ability to reach its full potential.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
The investment in Shift4Good was made through ComfortDelGro’s US$100 million venture capital fund.
ComfortDelGro is making a US$4m investment in an Israeli company that develops teleoperation software for autonomous vehicles.

site_title: Mapletree Pan Asia Commercial Trust keeps Q3 DPU unchanged at S$0.0242 due to higher finance costs
summary: Mapletree Pan Asia Commercial Trust (MPACT) maintained its Q3 distribution per unit (DPU) at S$0.0242, unchanged from the previous year, due to higher finance costs. The trust's gross revenue and net property income (NPI) grew 84% and 76.8% respectively, driven by higher earnings from its Singapore portfolio, including shopping mall VivoCity. Finance costs, however, offset the growth, resulting in no change in DPU.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
VivoCity saw a 49.4 per cent y-o-y surge in shopper traffic in H1, while tenants’ sales jumped 48.4 per cent to surpass pre-Covid levels.

site_title: IMF approves US$4.7 billion Bangladesh support package
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has approved a $4.7 billion support loan package for Bangladesh to help it cope with soaring energy and food costs. The package, which includes $476 million in immediate funding, aims to address the country's economic challenges, including a high inflation rate and a significant decline in foreign exchange reserves. The IMF urges the government to accelerate its reform agenda to achieve a more resilient, inclusive, and sustainable growth. The loan package also includes measures to address bad loans in the banking sector and tax hikes.

images.alt_text: The benchmark repurchase rate was increased to 6 per cent from 5.75 per cent effective from Monday (Jan 16), Bangladesh Bank said in a statement on Sunday.

site_title: Beijing has hit 'temporary herd immunity': official
summary: Beijing has reportedly reached "temporary herd immunity" and its Covid outbreak is nearing an end, according to a city health official. The city's Covid deaths nationwide have fallen by nearly 80% since the start of January, with the number of daily cases and hospitalizations also decreasing. The city's Centre for Disease Control and Prevention plans to survey thousands of residents in February and March to assess the city's coronavirus infection rate and inform future resource allocation. This development suggests China's unprecedented virus wave is waning.

images.alt_text: epa10070599 Medical personnel takes Coronavirus mandatory PCR test from citizens while cooling off with an ice block and a fan behind them, in Shanghai, China, 14 July 2022. Shanghai city reported five locally transmitted COVID-19 cases and 42 local asymptomatic infections, according to the Shanghai Health Commission report. Due to the virus' spread, more communities are in lockdown again. Shanghai issued its third red heat alert this week while the record 40.9 degrees Celsius on 13 July was tied with the hottest day record from 2017.  EPA-EFE/ALEX PLAVEVSKI

site_title: Adani drops off list of world’s top 10 richest people
summary: Gautam Adani has fallen from fourth place to 11th on the Bloomberg Billionaires Index, with a personal wealth wipeout of $34 billion in three trading days. His conglomerate's shares have plummeted, erasing $68 billion of market value, following a report alleging "brazen stock manipulation and accounting fraud." Adani now sits just one spot above rival Mukesh Ambani, whose net worth is $82.2 billion.

site_title: UK mortgage approvals at lowest since pandemic as rate rises bite
summary: UK mortgage approvals fell to 35,612 in December, the lowest level in 2.5 years, as higher borrowing costs took their toll on the property market. The effective mortgage rate rose 32 basis points to 3.67% last month. Weakening demand is expected to lead to a 5-8% drop in house prices this year, according to Nationwide and Halifax. The interest-rate hikes from the Bank of England have increased the cost of mortgages, affecting consumer spending on unsecured credit and credit-card debt.

site_title: UBS profit beats estimates as rates offset trading slowdown
summary: UBS reported a net income of $1.65 billion for the fourth quarter, beating estimates, as rising interest rates offset a slowdown in trading fees and transaction income in its wealth-management business. The bank plans to buy back over $5 billion of shares this year. Revenue at the investment bank fell 24% while wealth management fees declined 5%. Despite this, UBS remains confident in its ability to avoid large-scale job cuts, citing a surge in interest income and significant inflows into its Asian wealth-management business.

images.alt_text: UBS remains tactically cautious on credit spreads at current levels.
UBS chief executive Ralph Hamers says the bank's growth strategy focuses on two key regions, the US and Asia.

site_title: Indonesia finance minister Sri Mulyani among candidates for top central bank job: sources
summary: Indonesia's Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati is among candidates being considered for the top central bank job, replacing current Governor Perry Warjiyo whose term ends in May. Mulyani, a former World Bank managing director, has won plaudits for reforming the taxation system and steering the country's economy through the pandemic. Other potential candidates include the head of the Indonesia Deposit Insurance Corporation and BI's senior deputy governor. A short-listing process is underway, with the president's office expected to submit at least one name to parliament by February.

images.alt_text: The 10 sites include working areas in Natuna D Alpha, which are giant gas fields in the South China Sea.

site_title: US: Stocks rally on eve of Federal Reserve decision
summary: US stocks rose 1.1% on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average reaching 34,086.04, ahead of the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision. Solid earnings from companies like ExxonMobil, General Motors, and UPS offset a downcast consumer confidence report. Despite a survey showing greater unease about the short-term outlook, the rally was driven by positive earnings news, setting a bullish tone for the market.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 86.47 points, or 0.26 per cent, at the open to 33,803.56.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as data eases inflation concerns
summary: US stocks opened higher on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 86.47 points, or 0.26%, to 33,803.56, amid wage growth data easing inflation concerns ahead of the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained, with the S&P 500 rising 3.08 points, or 0.08%, to 4,020.85, and the Nasdaq Composite gaining 4.76 points, or 0.04%, to 11,398.58.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the trading floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., January 27, 2023. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly

site_title: US stops granting export licences for sale to  Huawei
summary: The US government has stopped granting export licenses to US companies for sale to Huawei, citing national security concerns. The restrictions apply to most items, including equipment below 5G level, artificial intelligence, and high-performance computing. This move follows previous export restrictions and marks a significant escalation in US-China tensions. The US Department of Commerce had previously granted licenses to some American firms to sell certain goods to Huawei, but this new policy change effectively blocks all exports to the Chinese company.

images.alt_text: (FILES) This file photo taken on July 8, 2022 shows the Huawei headquarters in Shenzhen, China's southern Guangdong province. - Revenue at Chinese telecom giant Huawei fell by 2.2 percent in the first three quarters of 2022, company data showed October 27, 2022, as Covid-19 and US sanctions dragged down sales. (Photo by Jade GAO / AFP)

site_title: UK budget watchdog says it’s often too optimstic on economy
summary: The UK's fiscal watchdog, the Office for Budget Responsibility, has admitted to having an "optimism bias" that overestimated GDP growth by 0.5 percentage points, leading to a review of its assumptions. This admission suggests gloomy budget forecasts are expected, with weak productivity and labor supply problems expected to limit potential growth. The Office for Budget Responsibility has previously overestimated GDP growth and underestimated borrowing, leading to market turmoil. New forecasts are expected to be delivered on March 15, with limited room for tax cuts or spending increases.

images.alt_text: People walk along Regent Street during the second day of Boxing Day sales, in London, Britain, December 27, 2022. REUTERS/Henry Nicholls

site_title: Moody’s downgrades Vietnam’s banks to ‘stable’ on real estate headwinds
summary: Moody's downgraded Vietnam's banking system to "stable" from "positive" due to growing asset risks from real estate stress and deteriorating profitability. Despite strong economic conditions, banks face challenges, including rising non-performing loans and declining net interest margins. However, the central bank has set a cap on credit growth and allows banks with good liquidity and low interest rates to increase their credit growth. Moody's still expects Vietnam's GDP to grow between 6-6.5% in 2023.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting

An electric vehicle from VinFast, a Vietnamese automaker producing electric cars and SUV on display at a showroom in California. Last December, VinFast filed for a US listing, which was once reported to help the company raise about US$2 billion.
Maybank analysts noted that property prices in Vietnam have skyrocketed in recent years and become increasingly unaffordable, particularly since the pandemic

site_title: Cindy Williams, star of Laverne & Shirley, dies at 75
summary: Actress Cindy Williams, best known for her role as Shirley Feeney on the 1970s sitcom Laverne & Shirley, has died at 75. She passed away on January 25 following a brief illness, and her death was confirmed by her assistant. Williams appeared in over 150 episodes of Laverne & Shirley, which ran for eight seasons and was a spinoff of Happy Days. She also had roles in films such as American Graffiti and The Conversation, and was a guest star on several TV shows.

images.alt_text: Italian actress Gina Lollobrigida in this file photo taken in Sept 1978.

site_title: Libraries offer novel 'warm space' for hard-up Britons
summary: UK public libraries are providing "warm spaces" for vulnerable individuals to access free food and stay safe during the cost-of-living crisis. Many libraries, including Chantry Library in Ipswich, eastern England, are offering free hot drinks, soup, and food, as well as clothing and sanitary products. The move is a response to the government's limited support, with charities and local councils working together to fill the gap. Libraries aim to provide a safe and welcoming space for those in need, while also acknowledging the strain on their own resources.

images.alt_text: Renters, who are facing the fastest rent increases in a decade, are at the sharp end of the crisis.

site_title: Thai economy continued recovery in December, central bank says
summary: Thailand's economy continued to recover in December 2022, driven by increased tourism and domestic consumption. The Bank of Thailand reported a current account surplus of $1.1 billion and projected 25.5 million foreign tourist arrivals in 2023, up from previous estimates. Exports fell 12.9% year-over-year, but the country's tourism sector is expected to gain momentum, particularly with China's reopening. The central bank will monitor global economic trends and costs to ensure steady economic improvement.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Bank of Thailand logo is pictured in Bangkok, Thailand, August 5, 2016. Picture taken August 5, 2016.  To match Interview THAILAND-ECONOMY/CENBANK    REUTERS/Chaiwat Subprasom/File Photo

site_title: China's BYD dreams big in auto powerhouse Japan
summary: China's BYD unveiled its first dealership in Japan on January 31, aiming to open over 100 dealerships by 2025. The company faces a tough task in a country where 90% of cars sold annually are built by domestic firms like Toyota. BYD is showcasing its ATTO 3 electric sports utility vehicle, which has a 485km cruising distance and costs $33,744. Despite initial interest, convincing the broader population could be an uphill battle, with some customers preferring domestically made cars. BYD's success in Japan will depend on winning over loyal customers.

images.alt_text: BYD sold 1.86 million new energy vehicles last year, more than the previous four years combined.

site_title: Brokers’ take: Analysts lift targets for Genting Singapore as China reopens
summary: Analysts have upgraded their target prices for Genting Singapore, predicting a faster-than-expected recovery in 2023 following China's reopening. Morgan Stanley has raised its target to S$1.15, while Maybank Securities has increased its target to S$0.94. Genting Singapore is expected to benefit from the influx of Chinese tourists, with analysts predicting a 10% increase in Ebitda for the fourth quarter of FY2022. However, concerns over competition from regional casino operators remain, with Maybank Securities warning that the threat of Thai integrated resorts could draw Chinese gamblers away from Singapore.

images.alt_text: Singapore Exchange (SGX).
Children walk away with a Christmas gift of autographed mini football from Mikael Silvestre.
Genting Singapore's gaming revenue rose 96 per cent on-year to S$382 million, while non-gaming revenue climbed to S$137.3 million from S$56.2 million in the year-ago period.

site_title: New Zealand unemployment climbs, wage inflation accelerates
summary: New Zealand's unemployment rate unexpectedly rose to 3.4% in the fourth quarter, despite wage inflation accelerating to 4.3%. Employment growth missed estimates, and the jobless rate was higher than expected. The acute labour shortage is fueling price pressures, with employers offering sign-on bonuses to retain workers and lift pay rates. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand predicts the economy will enter a recession this year, which may soften the labour market.

images.alt_text: The survey’s headline measure showed a net 52 per cent of respondents expected New Zealand's economy to deteriorate over the year ahead.

site_title: World Bank approves US$600 million loan to support Philippines’ recovery, financial sector
summary: The World Bank has approved a US$600 million loan to support the Philippines' economic recovery and financial sector development. The loan aims to strengthen financial sector stability, expand financial inclusion, and improve disaster risk finance, particularly in developing a catastrophe insurance market to prevent poverty following natural disasters. Only half of Filipinos aged 15 and above have a transaction account, and the Philippine central bank aims for 70% of adults to be bank account holders by this year.

images.alt_text: A woman takes videos at a Christmas light show in Makati City, Metro Manila, Philippines, December 13, 2022. REUTERS/Lisa Marie David

site_title: China tells Dutch it wants open supply chains amid US chip curbs
summary: China expressed its desire for open supply chains and trade, amid US efforts to restrict exports of advanced chipmaking machinery to the country. In a phone call with the Dutch Foreign Minister, China's Foreign Minister Qin Gang stated that Beijing aims to jointly safeguard international industrial and supply chains and promote an open, orderly trade environment. China hopes to maintain ties with the Netherlands defined by openness and pragmatism, seeking to find room to maneuver amidst US pressure.

images.alt_text: The White House continued to press allies to pass restrictions limiting the sales of semiconductor manufacturing equipment by firms such as Dutch company ASML or Tokyo Electron in Japan.

site_title: Russian tech giant Yandex says code leaked in cybersecurity incident
summary: Russian tech giant Yandex reported a cybersecurity incident in which fragments of its program code were leaked online. A preliminary investigation found violations of internal policies, but no user personal information was compromised. The leaked code contained contact details of some partners. Yandex's Dutch holding company stated that the company is taking the matter seriously and has initiated a thorough investigation into the cause, content, and implications of the leak.

site_title: Australian Open sets Grand Slam attendance record
summary: The Australian Open set a Grand Slam attendance record with 839,192 fans attending from January 16-29, surpassing the previous mark of 812,174 in 2020. The tournament, missing big-name players, broke its single-day attendance mark with 94,854 fans on January 21, and total attendance including qualifying events reached 902,312. Tennis Australia chief executive Craig Tiley attributes the record attendance to people wanting to be entertained, and he aims to breach the one-million mark next year. Novak Djokovic won his 10th Australian Open crown, drawing level with Rafael Nadal on 22 majors.

images.alt_text: Rafael Nadal of Spain bends over injured during his match against Mackenzie McDonald of the USA during the 2023 Australian Open tennis tournament at Melbourne Park in Melbourne.
South Korean Ko Jin-young will return to Singapore in March to defend the HSBC Women’s World Championship at Sentosa Golf Club’s Tanjong Course.

site_title: Planting seeds for inflection points in 2023
summary: Investors are optimistic about the market despite looming recession in the US and Europe. Three key inflection points - inflation, policy rates, and economic growth - are on the horizon, with inflation already turning and policy rates and economic growth expected to turn by mid-to-end of 2023. To cope with volatility, investors are focusing on protection via defensives and value stocks, uncorrelated hedge fund strategies, and early cyclical assets such as China, the Australian dollar, and semiconductor manufacturers.

images.alt_text: The IMF said global growth would still fall to 2.9 per cent in 2023 from 3.4 per cent in 2022, but its latest World Economic Outlook forecasts mark an improvement over an October prediction of 2.7 per cent growth this year.

site_title: Buyers beware: China’s economic recovery may be painful and perilous
summary: China's economic recovery may be painful and perilous, despite a recent surge in equities. A bigger Covid-19 wave is expected to spread to rural areas, causing short-term shocks to labor supply and potentially disrupting businesses. The country's reopening is ill-timed, as the rest of the world is slowing down, and exports are likely to face headwinds. Consumer spending may disappoint due to lingering fears of Covid-19, a confidence crisis in the property market, and high youth unemployment. The government's shift towards a top-down state-controlled economic growth model and increasing control over the private sector also pose long-term structural risks.

images.alt_text: The IMF said global growth would still fall to 2.9 per cent in 2023 from 3.4 per cent in 2022, but its latest World Economic Outlook forecasts mark an improvement over an October prediction of 2.7 per cent growth this year.
Shoppers in the Guanqian Street shopping area in Suzhou. China's growth pro

site_title: Airbus and Qatar Airways edge towards agreement in A350 dispute: sources
summary: Airbus and Qatar Airways are nearing an agreement to settle their dispute over grounded A350 jets, two people familiar with the matter said. The companies have been fighting over the safety impact of flaking paint and corrosion issues on the aircraft. The feud has led to the cancellation of large-scale orders and extra business for Boeing. Diplomatic efforts, including a meeting between French President Emmanuel Macron and Qatari Emir Sheikh Tamim bin Hamad al-Thani, have accelerated negotiations, with one source stating that an agreement is likely.

images.alt_text: The design could trim fuel consumption and emissions by around 30 per cent over Boeing’s 737 Max and Airbus’s A320neo family.
FILE PHOTO: The Boeing logo is seen on the side of a Boeing 737 MAX at the Farnborough International Airshow, in Farnborough, Britain, July 20, 2022.  REUTERS/Peter Cziborra/File Photo

site_title: Australia retail sales post first fall of 2022; yields drop
summary: Australian retail sales declined by 3.9% in December, the first fall in 2022, indicating slowing consumer demand. The drop was larger than forecast, with sales tumbling to their biggest fall since August 2020. The result suggests that cost of living pressures are biting, but may not be enough to prompt the Reserve Bank of Australia to pause interest rate hikes.

images.alt_text: Australia's consumer price index climbed 1.9 per cent in the December quarter, outpacing market forecasts of 1.6 per cent.

site_title: Cnooc’s US$3 billion UK portfolio sale has stalled on valuation gap
summary: CNOOC has paused a planned US$3 billion sale of its UK North Sea portfolio due to a valuation gap. The Chinese oil giant initially received offers that fell short of its expectations. The deal, which includes stakes in several high-producing fields, has been put on hold but may resume once conditions improve. This comes as Chinese companies reassess their overseas holdings amid tightening financing conditions and national security concerns.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Men wearing face masks walk past a sign of China National Offshore Oil Corp (CNOOC) outside its headquarters in Beijing, China March 8, 2021. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang/File Photo

site_title: Indian central bank partially relaxes restrictions on SBM Bank India
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) partially relaxed restrictions on SBM Bank India until March 15, allowing ATM and point-of-sale transactions on internationally active debit cards. The decision followed SBM Bank's submission and efforts to address "supervisory concerns". The RBI cited "material supervisory concerns" as the reason for the initial restrictions, but the relaxation aims to provide relief to affected customers.

site_title: Western Digital to get US$900 million investment from Apollo, Elliott
summary: Western Digital has received a $900 million investment from Apollo Global Management and Elliott Investment Management. The funds will provide financial firepower at a challenging time for the memory industry, which is experiencing consolidation. A potential merger with Kioxia Holdings is still in talks, with Western Digital's hard-drive business expected to remain separate. The investment and merger discussions are expected to help Western Digital advance its strategic review and create value for shareholders.

images.alt_text: In June, Western Digital announced a review of strategic alternatives following discussions with activist investor Elliott Investment Management.

site_title: Singapore manufacturers’ sentiment worsens; services sector mood moderates: surveys
summary: Singapore manufacturers' sentiment worsened for the third consecutive quarter, with a net weighted balance of 25% expecting a less favorable business situation from January to June 2023, down from 20% previously. In contrast, services sector optimism moderated, with a net weighted balance of 3% down from 9% previously. The current downcycle in the global semiconductor industry continues to weigh on electronics manufacturers' expectations.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
SK Hynix Solid State Drives (SSD) modules. Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg

site_title: The alternative, optimistic story of population decline
summary: China has reported its first population decline in six decades, with the country's population expected to drop to around 700 million by the end of the century, according to UN projections. This trend is expected to be irreversible, with China potentially overtaken by India. A shrinking global population poses unprecedented challenges, with median UN projections pointing to a global population peaking in the mid-2080s. This decline is attributed to greater longevity and freedom, rather than labor shortages and pension support, offering a more optimistic perspective on the issue.

images.alt_text: Members of a family laugh after taking a selfie as they visit a business street during the Chinese Lunar New Year in Beijing on January 25, 2023. (Photo by WANG Zhao / AFP)

site_title: Singapore shares track Wall Street losses to close 0.4% lower
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.4% to 3,365.67, following Wall Street losses. Losers outnumbered gainers 297 to 241 after 1.3 billion securities worth S$1.2 billion changed hands. The decline may be attributed to a possible higher-for-longer Fed funds rate regime, which put pressure on markets. Despite positive regional developments, recession risks in the US remain a major concern, posing significant risks to the global cyclical picture.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Losers outnumbered gainers 64 to 32 after 48.2 million securities worth S$48.0 million changed hands this morning.

site_title: IMF slashes UK growth outlook, adding pressure on finance minister Hunt
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has downgraded the UK's economic growth outlook for 2023, predicting a 0.6% contraction, a sharp downgrade from its previous forecast of 0.3% growth. This is the only G7 nation to have suffered a cut to its growth outlook, adding pressure on finance minister Jeremy Hunt to come up with a growth plan. The IMF attributes the downgrade to factors such as higher taxes, a surge in gas prices, a shortage of workers, and the Bank of England's interest rate hikes.

images.alt_text: The budget deficit underscore risks to the UK economy as Prime Minister Rishi Sunak struggles to contain inflation near a four-decade high and strikes crippling the public services.
British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak said in a statement that the UK had “forged a path as an independent nation with confidence” and “that momentum hasn’t slowed”.

The IMF said global growth would still fall to 2.9 per cent in 2023 from 3.4 per cent in 2022, but its latest World Economic Outlook forecasts mark an improvement over an October prediction of 2.7 per cent growth this year.

site_title: Russia’s inflation risks set to rise in 2023, says central bank
summary: Russia's central bank expects inflation risks to rise in 2023, primarily due to the labor market, budget, and balance of payments. The Bank of Russia is expected to keep its key interest rate at 7.5% in its first meeting of the year, despite inflation gradually slowing but still above the 4% target. Household inflation expectations stood at 11.6% in January. The bank warns of pro-inflationary risks from the rouble's weakness and potential decrease in trade surplus.

images.alt_text: Moscow has intensified efforts to reduce exposure to the US dollar and other so-called “unfriendly” currencies.
Once a niche group of buyers in Dubai, Russians’ interest in real estate there surged after the war in Ukraine.
G7, Australia and the European Union  placed a US$60 per barrel limit on sea-borne Russian crude oil sales late last year.

site_title: Europe: Shares end lower but log biggest January gain in eight years
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index closed 0.2% lower on Tuesday, despite recording its largest January percentage gain since 2015, at 6.7%. Investors awaited interest rate hikes from top central banks, but the index's resilience on better-than-expected corporate earnings and economic signs lifted it.

site_title: AMD shares climb as server market helps sales forecast
summary: AMD has beaten its sales forecast for the first quarter, with revenue reaching up to $5.6 billion, exceeding analyst predictions. The company's server market gains helped offset a decline in demand for PC chips, marking the first year-over-year quarterly sales decline since 2019. AMD's data-centre business saw a 42% sales increase, while its client division saw a 51% drop. The company's shares rose 3.7% in New York trading, following a 4.6% increase in extended trading.

images.alt_text: Genoa launches at a time when rival Intel’s latest data centre chip, code named Sapphire Rapids, has struggled with delays.

site_title: Straits Trading prices S$370 million secured exchangeable bonds at 3.25%
summary: Straits Trading Company priced S$370 million worth of secured exchangeable bonds maturing Feb 13, 2028, at 3.25% interest. The net proceeds will be used for refinancing existing borrowings, working capital, and capital expenditure. Bondholders will receive a pro rata share of 67,738.6364 ESR Group shares for each S$250,000 principal amount of bonds. The bonds will be redeemed at 100% of their principal amount on maturity, along with accrued interest.

images.alt_text: Straits Developments’ chief executive Eric Teng says the group is careful about where it makes investments. In particular, the company looks at factors such as the cash flow of the assets, as well as opportunities for asset enhancement.

site_title: US Fed starts policy meeting with smaller rate hike likely
summary: US Federal Reserve officials are expected to announce a smaller, 25 basis point interest rate hike during their two-day policy meeting, signaling a slowdown in the pace of rate hikes as inflation begins to fade. The Fed has raised rates seven times last year to combat inflation, but indicators suggest a decrease in costs and a cooling of consumer inflation and wage growth. A smaller hike would mark a further step down from December's half-point hike, taking the rate to 4.50-4.75%.

images.alt_text: The Fed and other major central banks are intent on fighting inflation

site_title: McDonald’s slips as operating margin misses estimates
summary: McDonald's shares fell 1.7% after the company's fourth-quarter operating margin and 2023 operating margin projection missed analyst estimates. The company reported 12.6% comparable sales growth, exceeding expectations, but predicted $100-150 million in costs to support franchisees in Europe due to inflation. McDonald's expects macro-related pressures to continue weighing on the business, and is focusing on location growth in the US and international markets.

site_title: EU studying whether Big Tech should pay network costs: EU document
summary: The European Union is consulting tech giants and telecoms providers on whether they should pay network costs, citing the six largest content providers account for over half of internet data traffic. Telecoms providers, including Deutsche Telekom and Orange, argue that these providers should contribute their fair share. Tech giants, including Google and Meta, argue that this would be an internet traffic tax interfering with net neutrality rules. The EU executive will gather feedback before proposing legislation to address the issue.

site_title: Philippine nickel-mining group rejects proposed tax on ore exports
summary: The Philippine government is considering taxing nickel-ore exports to encourage local processing, but the industry's head, Dante Bravo, warns that a 10% tax could force local producers to close. The Philippines is the world's second-largest nickel-ore supplier, and a tax could lead to higher costs for China, the world's top nickel consumer. The proposed tax is part of a larger plan to boost government revenue and follow Indonesia's policy of taxing nickel-ore exports to attract investments in processing plants.

images.alt_text: As a resource-rich country, Indonesia has been trying to capitalise on its abundant nickel reserves to develop battery and electric vehicle industries at home.

Miners are increasingly reliant on computing heft to manage tasks such as automated truck fleets, and using artificial intelligence to delve into reams of data and discover the next big deposit, said BHP chief technology officer Laura Tyler.

site_title: China will keep yuan basically stable, Premier Li says
summary: China will maintain a stable yuan currency, according to Premier Li Keqiang, ensuring economic and financial stability. The yuan rebounded in January after a 7.9% drop against the US dollar in 2022. China's foreign exchange reserves rose to $3.1 trillion, reflecting international confidence. The International Monetary Fund has lifted China's 2023 growth outlook to 5.2%, a sharp rise from 4.4% in October. Li emphasized the importance of maintaining financial stability, a challenging task, to support the country's economic growth.

images.alt_text: The deficit has left local governments in an increasingly poor fiscal position, and the central government could become reluctant to support the economy with fiscal spending after last year’s growth slump.
China’s economy will likely improve significantly from 2022’s 3 per cent expansion.

site_title: Food giant Wilmar vows to stand by its venture with Adani Group
summary: Food giant Wilmar International will continue to support its joint venture with India's Adani Group, despite a report from Hindenburg Research accusing the conglomerate of corporate malfeasance. The venture, Adani Wilmar, operates independently with its own management team and board, and has undergone a full public offering process. Wilmar contributes expertise in commodity and consumer-food products, while Adani provides local logistical support. Shares in Adani Wilmar dropped 20% in the past four sessions, but Wilmar remains committed to the partnership.

site_title: Five days for the future
summary: The January effect, a historical indicator of the US stock market's direction, has a 83% accuracy rate, predicting a market trend that is generally up for the year if the market rises in the first five days of January. However, this pattern fails 17% of the time.

images.alt_text: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - JANUARY 26: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) during morning trading on January 26, 2023 in New York City. The stock market opened slightly higher this morning as investors awaited the release of fourth-quarter Gross Domestic Product (GDP) report. The report showed that the economy grew at an annual rate of 2.9 percent in the fourth-quarter with the rate decreasing slightly from a 3.2 percent growth rate in the third quarter.   Michael M. Santiago/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by Michael M. Santiago / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: Malaysian trade minister Zafrul guns for Umno supreme council seat
summary: Malaysia's newly-appointed Minister of International Trade and Industry, Tengku Zafrul Aziz, has announced his intention to run for a supreme council seat in Umno at its upcoming party election, marking a significant move in his political ambitions. Zafrul, who is currently Umno's Kota Raja division committee member and treasurer, aims to "play the long game" and secure a strong position within the party. His goal is to contest as head of his division or at the supreme council level, depending on Umno's approval.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel
Malaysia's Minister of International Trade and Industry Zafrul Aziz

site_title: Exxon beats estimates, posts record US$56b 2022 profit
summary: ExxonMobil reported a record US$55.7 billion full-year profit, exceeding its prior record of US$45.2 billion in 2008. The adjusted fourth-quarter profit of US$3.40 a share surpassed analyst estimates. This marks Exxon's ninth consecutive quarter of beating profit expectations. In contrast, Chevron posted a surprise earnings miss last week, while announcing a US$75 billion share-buyback program. Exxon's strong performance is a significant departure from its US rival Chevron.

images.alt_text: Adjusted 2022 earnings more than doubled to US$36.5 billion from a year earlier, while oil and natural gas output from the company’s US fields climbed almost 4 per cent to the equivalent of 1.181 million barrels a day.

site_title: Pfizer 2023 outlook disappoints as Covid business drops off
summary: Pfizer's 2023 outlook fell short of analyst expectations due to declining demand for its Covid-19 vaccines and Paxlovid treatment. The company predicted adjusted earnings between $3.25 and $3.45 per share, below the $4.31 average estimate. Revenue is expected to be between $67 billion and $71 billion, down from $71.7 billion forecast by analysts. Covid vaccine sales are expected to decline 64% to $13.5 billion and Paxlovid sales are expected to fall 58% to $8 billion. Despite this, Pfizer expects its Covid business to grow again in 2024.

images.alt_text: Pfizer and BioNTech agreed to supply the European Union with 900 million Covid-19 vaccine doses by the end of 2023, though that amount might change due to a supply glut.

site_title: Norway’s wealth fund posts record US$164b loss
summary: Norway's sovereign wealth fund reported a record loss of 1.64 trillion kronor (S$207.2 billion) in 2022, ending a three-year streak of soaring profits. The loss was attributed to market impacts from war in Europe, high inflation, and rising interest rates. The fund's return on investment in 2022 stood at minus 14.1%, with losses in equities and fixed-income investments. Despite this, the fund still outperformed its benchmark index by 0.88 percentage points.

images.alt_text: Norges Bank will push for companies to reach the goal via “credible” interim targets and plans to reduce their scope 1, scope 2 and material scope 3 emissions.
The transaction is part of Iberdola’s plan to sell minority stakes in renewable developments to finance its climate action plan.

site_title: Job switching rates in Singapore reach 6-year high: MOM
summary: The job switching rate in Singapore reached a six-year high in 2022, with 16.8% of employed residents changing jobs over the last two years. This increase was largely due to the tight labour market and economic recovery, prompting dissatisfied workers to quit and seek new opportunities. The unemployment rate for workers under 30 rose to 4.3%, while the long-term unemployment rate remained steady at 0.3%. The share of employees with a job tenure of less than one year remained unchanged, while those with 10 years or more tenure reached a decade-long high at 31.1%.

images.alt_text: Office workers walking at Raffles Place Park within the heart of Singapore's financial centre in the CBD area on Nov 1, 2022.
The unemployment rate for PMETs dips to 2.6 per cent, down from 3.4 per cent a year ago, according to the MOM report.
The newly-launched Progressive Wage Mark scheme aims to encourage consumers to support lower-wage workers by purchasing from accredited firms.

site_title: Celsius’ business model different from that advertised: US bankruptcy examiner
summary: A US court-ordered examiner report revealed that Celsius Network's business model differed from its advertised promises. The firm, which froze customer withdrawals, did not deliver on its promises surrounding its native CEL token and other business activities. Celsius's stablecoin deficit between May 2021 and its bankruptcy filing last year was approximately $1 billion, resulting from its use of customer deposits to acquire stablecoins. The company filed for Chapter 11 protection in July 2022 with a $1.19 billion deficit on its balance sheet.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Celsius Network logo and representations of cryptocurrencies are seen in this illustration taken, June 13, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Samsung sees phone market shrinking again after 2022 woes
summary: Samsung Electronics expects the smartphone market to contract in 2023 due to ongoing economic challenges and consumer spending slowdown. The company's biggest profit drop in over a decade was attributed to deteriorating business environment. Despite China's gradual reopening, Samsung's outlook suggests the smartphone market won't return to growth in the near term, with mass market shipments expected to decline.

site_title: Myanmar junta prepares for poll, raising fears of more bloodshed
summary: Myanmar's military junta is planning elections, despite opposition and allegations of voter fraud in the last election, which led to the coup in 2021. Analysts warn that the polls cannot be free and fair under the current circumstances, and may be a "performance" to justify the military's hold on power. The junta is expected to hold the election later this year, but resistance from the hilly jungles and plains of the country means that voting will likely be impossible in many areas, and those who do vote may face reprisals. The international community remains divided on how to respond to the junta's move.

images.alt_text: The meeting came a day after the UN Security Council adopted its first resolution on Myanmar in 74 years, demanding an end to violence and for the junta to free all political detainees.

(FILES) in this file photo taken on January 17, 2020, Myanmar's State Counsellor Aung San Suu Kyi poses for pictures during a welcoming ceremony for China's President Xi Jinping at the Presidential Palace in Naypyidaw. - Myanmar junta court jails Suu Kyi for six years on August 15, 2022, for corruption. (Photo by AFP)
Asean held up valiantly in 2022 as the COVID-19 pandemic lingered and the Russia-Ukraine conflict led to a supply shock

site_title: White House says US Covid-19 emergency status to end on May 11
summary: The US White House announced that the national and public health emergencies declared in January 2020 due to the Covid-19 pandemic will officially end on May 11. This will lead to the end of government aid programs, including subsidies for Covid-19 medicines and medical insurance. The White House warned that abrupt cancellations would cause "chaos and uncertainty" in the healthcare system, particularly for hospitals and nursing homes. The decision also affects immigration, as the rule allowing swift expulsion of undocumented migrants, known as Title 42, will expire.

images.alt_text: WHO chief Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus says he agrees with the advice offered by the committee regarding the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic and that the event continues to constitute a public health emergency of international concern.

epa10070599 Medical personnel takes Coronavirus mandatory PCR test from citizens while cooling off with an ice block and a fan behind them, in Shanghai, China, 14 July 2022. Shanghai city reported five locally transmitted COVID-19 cases and 42 local asymptomatic infections, according to the Shanghai Health Commission report. Due to the virus' spread, more communities are in lockdown again. Shanghai issued its third red heat alert this week while the record 40.9 degrees Celsius on 13 July was tied with the hottest day record from 2017.  EPA-EFE/ALEX PLAVEVSKI
Crossing the 50 per cent occupancy threshold is a milestone sure to be cheered by business leaders on Wall Street and elsewhere who have pushed for more in-office attendance.

site_title: China’s economic activity rebounds sharply after reopening
summary: China's economy rebounded sharply in January after reopening from Covid Zero, with manufacturing and services expanding for the first time in four months. The manufacturing purchasing managers' index rose to 50.1, and the non-manufacturing gauge increased to 54.4, surpassing expectations. The recovery is expected to continue, with China's GDP growth likely to improve significantly from 2022's 3% expansion, and policymakers poised to announce more stimulus to support growth at the National People's Congress in March.

site_title: Central banks told to keep rate hiking until inflation all-clear
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has lowered its global inflation forecast, predicting it will slow from 8.8% in 2022 to 6.6% this year and 4.3% in 2024. However, IMF official Tobias Adrian advises central banks to continue raising interest rates until inflation is "durably retreating" to avoid the risk of not doing enough. The IMF also warns that markets are overly optimistic about inflation, and economists expect a quarter-point hike in US interest rates and half-point steps in the UK and eurozone.

images.alt_text: Britain’s flagging economy now looks set to shrink by 0.6 per cent this year, a sharp downgrade from previously expected growth of 0.3 per cent in the IMF’s last forecast in October.

The IMF said global growth would still fall to 2.9 per cent in 2023 from 3.4 per cent in 2022, but its latest World Economic Outlook forecasts mark an improvement over an October prediction of 2.7 per cent growth this year.

site_title: China electric-car upstart Xpeng pushes back profit goal after horror year
summary: Xpeng, a Chinese electric vehicle (EV) maker, has pushed back its profit goal to 2025 due to a horror year marked by a 80% decline in shares and underperforming sales. The company aims to turn an operating profit in 2025 by focusing on full self-driving technology and expanding its market share to 20% of the "all-intelligent vehicle" market. Xpeng is restructuring its management team, simplifying its product offering, and reducing suppliers to achieve this goal. Despite challenges, CEO He Xiaopeng remains optimistic, citing rapid technology developments that will see the market grow to 5 million vehicles a year in five years.

images.alt_text: BYD sold 1.86 million new energy vehicles last year, more than the previous four years combined.

site_title: Australia is boosting hydrogen exports to EU as part of green push
summary: Australia aims to boost hydrogen exports to the European Union (EU) as the bloc seeks to cut emissions. The EU has set a goal to produce 10 million tons of hydrogen by 2030 using renewable technologies like wind and solar, and will also need to import the same amount from abroad. Australia's climate and energy minister Chris Bowen stated the country is committed to supporting Europe's transition to green energy, citing Australia's potential to become a renewable energy export superpower.

images.alt_text: Retail sales have been seasonally weak in December in recent times, suggesting further evidence of slowing demand is needed before the RBA pauses tightening.

site_title: China's JD.com to shut e-commerce sites in Indonesia, Thailand
summary: JD.com, a Chinese e-commerce company, will shut its e-commerce sites in Indonesia and Thailand by the end of March, citing a competitive e-commerce landscape in the region. The move follows a year of struggles for China's retail and technology sectors. Despite posting an 11.4% revenue rise in the third quarter, JD.com's chief executive described the second quarter as the most difficult since listing in 2014. The company will continue to serve global markets through its supply chain infrastructure.

images.alt_text: Baidu has spent billions of dollars researching AI in a years-long effort to transition from online marketing to deeper technology.

site_title: UK PM hails Brexit as ‘huge opportunity’, three years on
summary: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak hailed Brexit as a "huge opportunity" three years after the UK formally left the EU, citing significant achievements in tackling generational challenges. Sunak defended the decision, stating that the UK has "forged a path as an independent nation with confidence" and "momentum hasn't slowed." Despite the UK's economic struggles, Sunak remains optimistic about Brexit's impact, emphasizing its potential to deliver on his priorities of growth, employment, and social mobility.

images.alt_text: Britain's Labour leader Keir Starmer speaks to the media at an event celebrating the results of the 2022 local elections in Carlisle, Britain May 6, 2022. REUTERS/Scott Heppell
With the latest inflation data, some economists are starting to talk about an end to the Bank of England's tightening cycle, which has delivered the fastest rate rises in three decades.
Nurses and ambulance workers are due to stand side-by-side on picket lines for the first time on Feb 6, in an escalation of their campaign against below-inflation raises.

site_title: Climate tech investments, positioning Singapore as ESG arbitration centre: PwC’s Budget 2023 wishlist
summary: PwC's Budget 2023 wishlist suggests Singapore position itself as a climate tech innovation hub and ESG arbitration centre to resolve environmental disputes. The firm proposes incentives for climate tech investments, refining capital risk charges, and removing traders of digital payment tokens from input tax restrictions. Additionally, PwC recommends expanding grant schemes for multinational enterprises, setting production standards for CBAM, and investing in upskilling programs for employees to address the talent crunch.

images.alt_text: Sharon See

EY’s Singapore head of tax Soh Pui Ming said: "While the pandemic is behind us, Singapore continues to face a highly volatile and uncertain global environment. Hence, we should stay focused as a nation and prime ourselves for any potential challenges and upcoming opportunities."
KMPG also called for targeted grants for some GST-registered businesses to address concerns over higher costs from complying with the rate hikes.
Deloitte said it would not be in Singapore’s best interest to be the first mover in enacting Pillar Two rules, and waiting for international consensus on implementation options is “more prudent”.

site_title: Changi Airport traffic strongest in December, near pre-Covid levels
summary: Changi Airport saw its strongest traffic in December 2022, handling 4.6 million passengers, reaching 72% of pre-pandemic levels in 2019. The airport handled 32.2 million passengers in 2022, about half of the traffic in 2019. Other regions, including South-east Asia and South Korea, also registered strong recovery in passenger traffic. The airport will welcome more flights in the coming months, with new routes and airlines established in 2022. Despite a decline in airfreight and cargo flows, Changi Airport remains confident in restoring its connectivity and traffic to pre-Covid levels.

images.alt_text: Despite the uptick, the airport is well-equipped to handle the higher volume, says Transport Minister S Iswaran, citing the reopenings of Terminal 4, on Sept 13, and the southern wing of Terminal 2, on Oct 11.

site_title: Cromwell E-Reit reports 1.6% portfolio valuation decline for FY2022
