summary: Cromwell E-Reit reported a 1.6% portfolio valuation decline for FY2022, reaching 2.5 billion euros. The decline is attributed to valuation decreases in the Netherlands and UK portfolios, while valuation increases in Italy and the Czech Republic offset some losses. CEO Simon Garing attributes the decline to "good or very good macro or micro" locations experiencing market rent growth with limited competitive supply.

images.alt_text: The Reit’s gross revenue gains 10.4 per cent to 55.9 million euros from 50.7 million euros, while net property income grows 4.1 per cent to 34.5 million euros from 33.1 million euros.

site_title: Australian dollar sideswiped by dire data, still up on month
summary: The Australian dollar dropped 0.1% to US$0.7050, despite being up 3.5% for the month, amid a broad-based bout of risk aversion. The decline was attributed to dire data showing a shock tumble in retail spending in December, which likely dragged on economic growth and trimmed expectations for future interest rate hikes.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An Australia Dollar note is seen in this illustration photo June 1, 2017. REUTERS/Thomas White/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Adani share sale fate hangs in balance as rout hits US$75b
summary: The Adani Group's US$2.5 billion equity sale hangs in balance as the rout in its shares enters its fourth session, wiping out about US$75 billion in market value. Despite a 20% overall subscription rate, the sale's fundraising goal may be at risk, complicating plans to refinance debt and fund expansion. A vote of confidence from Abu Dhabi's International Holding, which will invest US$400 million, has lent some tactical support, but markets await more clarity on allegations made by Hindenburg Research.

images.alt_text: Hindenburg Research's accusation of stock manipulation by Adani Group will not, on its own, be enough to convince investors who are deciding what to do with their Adani holdings.

site_title: Central bankers can’t save the planet – nor should they be mandated to do so
summary: Central banks are being urged to expand their roles beyond price stability to tackle challenges like debt sustainability and climate change. However, experts argue that this should be left to governments, citing fiscal policy's effectiveness in addressing climate change and the need for accountability to the public. Central banks should focus on their core objectives of maintaining price stability and financial stability, rather than attempting to lead the green transition. This week's policy statements are likely to underscore the central bank's primary focus on inflation control, with rate hikes expected in the US, ECB, and Bank of England.

images.alt_text: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell said we should not wander off "to pursue perceived social benefits that are not tightly linked to our statutory goals and authorities.”
Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell could still have a sobering effect on markets if he says the hikes must stop because of an oncoming recession.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's employment levels improved significantly in 2022, with a total of 231,700 non-resident workers added to the workforce. This growth was driven by a rebound in foreign workers as border restrictions were lifted and employers backfilled positions. Resident employment also grew, albeit at a slower pace than the previous year. The Ministry of Manpower reported this data, indicating a positive trend in the country's employment market.

site_title: Sony slashes PlayStation VR2 headset output after pre-orders disappoint
summary: Sony has reduced its PlayStation VR2 headset production to around 1.5 million units due to disappointing pre-orders, halving its initial forecast of 2 million units for the launch quarter. The company had expected strong demand for the headset, but its high price of $549 and incompatibility with other consoles may have limited consumer appetite. Analysts predict the headset will remain in a niche market, with some speculating that virtual reality may not be the next growth frontier for computing hardware and services.

images.alt_text: Sony Honda Mobility plans a global roll-out that includes Europe, parts of Asia and the Middle East.

site_title: Spotify’s user growth beats estimates, expects 500 million listeners next quarter
summary: Spotify reported fourth-quarter results beating expectations, with 489 million monthly active users and 205 million premium subscribers, a 14% increase. The company forecasts 500 million listeners next quarter and expects revenue of 3.1 billion euros. Premium subscribers are expected to reach 207 million, surpassing estimates of 202 million. Spotify's growth is driven by marketing campaigns and increased sign-ups in countries like India and Indonesia, which will help the company reach its goal of 1 billion users by 2030 and $100 billion revenue annually.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Earphones are seen on top of a smart phone with a Spotify logo on it in this February 20, 2014 photo illustration. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo                        GLOBAL BUSINESS WEEK AHEAD

site_title: Is there life on Mars? Maybe, and it could have dropped its teddy
summary: Scientists analyzing data from the HiRISE camera on Mars have discovered a face-like feature on the planet's surface. The "face" appears to be a 2,000-meter-wide hill with a V-shaped collapse structure, two craters, and a circular fracture pattern. Possible explanations include volcanic or mud vents, lava flows, or settling deposits. The discovery was made using the Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter's powerful camera, which captured the image last month. The finding highlights the Martian surface's activity and suggests it may have been shaped by geological processes.

images.alt_text: The historic Russov House in the Ukrainian city of Odessa.  Unesco has added the historic centre of Ukraine's port city of Odessa to its World Heritage List despite opposition from Russia.

site_title: How the ‘Madoffs of Manhattan’ can unravel Gautam Adani’s empire
summary: Hindenburg Research has accused Indian billionaire Gautam Adani's Adani Group of stock manipulation, claiming insiders own over 75% of four publicly traded subsidiaries through offshore shell entities, potentially triggering delisting. In response, Adani Group called Hindenburg "the Madoffs of Manhattan," labeling the report a "calculated attack" on India's growth story. Despite Adani's rebuttal, Hindenburg's report may focus on Adani's ability to refinance debt, as the company holds over $10 billion in foreign currency-denominated bonds, which could be affected by global market concerns about Adani's creditworthiness.

images.alt_text: While Gautam Adaninet's net worth took a beating in the days after Hindenburg’s report emerged, he was still comfortably in the top 10 in the Bloomberg Billionaires Index as at late January.

The selloff is fast eroding the wealth of Adani, Asia’s richest man, after his stocks were some of the best performers last year not just in the local market, but also on the broader MSCI Asia Pacific Index.

site_title: AI voice tool ‘misused’ as deepfakes flood web forum
summary: A British AI firm, Eleven Labs, is rethinking its safeguards after its audio tool was used to clone celebrity voices and spread racist and homophobic slurs on the internet forum 4chan. The tool, released just days earlier, was used to create deepfakes of celebrities, including the stars of the Harry Potter films and film directors Quentin Tarantino and George Lucas. Eleven Labs admitted to finding "an increasing number of voice cloning misuse cases" and is considering additional safeguards, including manually verifying each cloning request.

site_title: UniCredit pledges payout of 5.3 billion euros after posting record profit
summary: UniCredit, a European bank, has pledged to return 5.3 billion euros (S$7.48 billion) to investors after posting a record profit for the fourth quarter of 2022. The bank's quarterly profit of 2.5 billion euros exceeded analyst forecasts, driven by a 38% increase in core lending income. UniCredit aims to pay out more than 16 billion euros in dividends and buybacks by 2024, with CEO Andrea Orcel confident of receiving approval from the European Central Bank for share buybacks.

images.alt_text: At a recent Riksbank gathering, European Central Bank (ECB) executive board member Isabel Schnabel spoke about how the ECB is aligning policy with Paris Agreement objectives, including steps to actively decarbonise its balance sheet.
While global investors agree that things should quieten down for the euro, European policymakers continue to push back against this market positioning.

(FILES) In this file photo taken on October 21, 2020 people wearing face masks walk in front of the euro sign at the former ECB headquarters in the city center of Frankfurt am Main, western Germany. - The European Central Bank is expected Thursday to unleash more stimulus to help shore up a eurozone economy devastated by the coronavirus pandemic, analysts said, in a move eagerly awaited by financial markets.

The Frankfurt institution already has a 1.35-trillion-euro ($1.6-trillion) emergency bond-buying programme in place, but ECB chief Christine Lagarde all but promised in October that extra support was on the way. (Photo by Yann Schreiber / AFP)

site_title: Singapore stocks fall at Tuesday’s open; STI down 0.3%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.3% at the opening on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) dropping 8.74 points to 3,369.55. Losers outnumbered gainers 64 to 32, with media company The Place Holdings and Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust being among the most actively traded counters. The decline follows losses in US and European markets, where the Dow Jones fell 0.8% and the pan-European Stoxx 600 dropped 0.2%.

images.alt_text: The property player is in talks for the proposed acquisition of the St Katharine Docks (SKD) development in London, United Kingdom.

site_title: EU warns of ‘unfair’  Chinese subsidies in Green Deal plan: draft
summary: The European Commission is set to warn of "unfair" Chinese subsidies in its Green Deal Industrial Plan, which aims to maintain Europe's position as a manufacturing hub for green products. The plan, due to be published on Wednesday, will emphasize the need for fair trade and competition in net-zero industries, citing China's subsidies as a major concern. The EU will seek to increase free trade agreements, build partnerships for critical raw materials, and deploy trade defense measures to counter China's $280 billion subsidy program and ensure a level playing field.

images.alt_text: While green subsidies could encourage more investment, they could also entrench inefficient incumbents.
Greening the entire economy is said to be key to Singapore's transition to a sustainable economic model - and blended finance will play a crucial role. PHOTO: ST

site_title: IMF lifts 2023 growth forecast on China reopening, strength in US, Europe
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has raised its 2023 global growth forecast to 2.9% due to "surprisingly resilient" demand in the US and Europe, as well as China's reopening after strict COVID-19 restrictions. The IMF now expects US GDP growth of 1.4% and euro zone growth of 0.7%. However, recession risks remain, and the IMF warns that the world could easily tip into recession. For 2024, the IMF predicts global growth will accelerate slightly to 3.1%.

images.alt_text: The deficit has left local governments in an increasingly poor fiscal position, and the central government could become reluctant to support the economy with fiscal spending after last year’s growth slump.

Powell is expected to balance this week’s likely 25 basis-point increase in rates with a stern message that the step-down from the past six hikes doesn’t diminish his commitment to reducing inflation to 2 per cent.

site_title: Pay up on 1MDB settlement, Anwar tells Goldman
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim urged Goldman Sachs to settle its $6.5 billion settlement with the government over its role in the 1MDB scandal. Anwar stated that Goldman Sachs' financial strength should not be used to dictate terms, and that the Wall Street firm should "come out clean" and settle with Malaysia. The 1MDB scandal involved the misuse of a sovereign state fund, partly due to the complicity of institutions like Goldman Sachs, Anwar claimed.

images.alt_text: Anwar told Bloomberg TV he has a huge issue of having to introduce taxation policies or new initiatives when it affects the plight of the low-income group.
Since October Goldman has made a U-turn on its plan to build a big consumer bank; booked one of its worst quarterly results for a decade; and attracted a probe by the Federal Reserve.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CDL, Keppel Infra Trust, ESR-Logos Reit, OUE C-Reit, Straits Trading
summary: CDL is in talks to acquire the £400 million (S$650.9 million) St Katharine Docks development in London. The acquisition is a significant development for the company. Meanwhile, Keppel Infrastructure Trust (KIT) posted a lower distribution per unit (DPU) of S$0.0191 for the second half ended December 2022, but its distributable income rose 47.4% to S$134.9 million.

images.alt_text: Generic pictures of SGX

site_title: Thailand among Apac economies to watch as Chinese tourists return: Fitch
summary: Fitch Ratings expects Thailand's tourism recovery to be particularly important due to its weakened credit metrics from weak tourism activity. China's easing of zero-Covid policy is expected to boost tourism in Thailand and other Asian-Pacific economies, including Malaysia, Hong Kong, and Macao. However, the recovery remains vulnerable to risks such as lower-than-forecasted economic growth, eroded consumer purchasing power, and high energy costs. A slow recovery for air travel and tourism sectors is also anticipated, with limited upside risks for government ratings in the near term.

images.alt_text: China was the world’s largest outbound tourism market before the pandemic.
Chinese tourists will no longer need to quarantine on return home starting Jan 8.

The US$280 billion force that is Chinese tourism may not reemerge for months, thanks to lingering infections, restrictions for new arrivals and surging costs tied to a breakdown of the global travel infrastructure.

site_title: Non-resident labour bumps up Singapore employment by ‘unprecedented’ 231,700 workers in 2022
summary: Singapore's employment levels grew by an unprecedented 231,700 in 2022, driven mainly by a rebound in non-resident foreign workers in the construction and manufacturing sectors. Resident employment also increased, but at a slower pace than the previous year. Growth was observed across most sectors, particularly in financial services and community services. This improvement in employment levels is attributed to the lifting of border restrictions and employers backfilling positions.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
Resident unemployment was the same as the previous month at 2.8 per cent, according to the latest figures from the Ministry of Manpower.

A Microsoft office in New York, US, on Friday, Jan. 20, 2023. US technology stocks are about to hit their next hurdle when earnings season for the most influential segment of the S&P 500 Index gets underway in the coming week: vanishing profits. Photographer: Victor J. Blue/Bloomberg

site_title: Hong Kong seeks to revive crypto sector wrecked by FTX debacle
summary: Hong Kong is pushing forward with its plan to revive its crypto sector, despite the industry's tarnished reputation following the FTX debacle. The city aims to create a fresh regulatory framework to protect investors and encourage growth, with a mandatory exchange licensing regime set to launch in June. Firms like Matrixport Technologies are assessing Hong Kong's evolving rulebook, with some considering setting up operations in the city. Regulators are also exploring the possibility of allowing retail trading and permitting exchange-traded funds (ETFs) investing in Bitcoin and Ether futures.

images.alt_text: For the fourth quarter, investment income amounted to HK$76.4 billion, compared to HK$48.2 billion in the same period of 2021.

site_title: Japan’s Dec factory output inches down, retail sales beat forecasts
summary: Japan's industrial output fell 0.1% in December from the previous month, marking a slight decrease in the final quarter of 2022. Despite this, retail sales rose more than expected, beating forecasts. The drop in factory output is attributed to stalling global demand and rising costs, which may impact companies' ability to hike wages and sustain Japan's post-pandemic recovery. Manufacturers expect output to remain flat in January and increase 4.1% in February.

images.alt_text: A worker, wearing head-to-toe white dust suit, on the automatic timepiece movement assembly line at the Yamagata Casio factory in Higashine, Japan, Nov. 21, 2022. Employees on the assembly line enter a clean room through an airlock. (Niroko Hayashi/The New York Times)

site_title: Gold prices flat as investors await Fed rate decision
summary: Gold prices remained flat on Tuesday as investors awaited the US Federal Reserve's rate decision. Spot gold held steady at $1,922.26 per ounce, while US gold futures fell 0.1%. Traders expect the Fed to scale back rate hikes to 25 basis points, reducing the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion. The US central bank's policy meeting concludes on Wednesday, with the Bank of England and European Central Bank also holding meetings this week.

site_title: Hong Kong spends HK$26 billion on temporary homes to ease crisis
summary: Hong Kong plans to spend HK$26 billion on temporary apartments to reduce wait times for public housing, aiming to cut the waiting period to 4.5 years from 5.6 years. The initiative will feature modular construction and include 30,000 units of light public housing over five years. The government hopes to provide an affordable option for those priced out of decent housing in the city's expensive property market. The proposal has raised concerns about cost-effectiveness and potential impact on the public housing application process.

images.alt_text: Matrixport Technologies, a crypto lender with about 300 staff, is among the firms assessing Hong Kong’s evolving rulebook.

site_title: HSBC Asset says Fed to cut rates by full point as growth expected to falter
summary: HSBC Asset Management predicts the US Federal Reserve will cut interest rates by a full percentage point before the end of 2023, as signs of a US economic recession emerge. The firm's global chief strategist, Joe Little, expects the Fed to deliver 100 basis points of cuts in 2023 and 200 basis points in 2024, contradicting economists who forecast a recession-free year. This move would reverse the Fed's current tightening campaign, which has lifted borrowing costs by 425 basis points in less than a year.

images.alt_text: Powell is expected to balance this week’s likely 25 basis-point increase in rates with a stern message that the step-down from the past six hikes doesn’t diminish his commitment to reducing inflation to 2 per cent.

site_title: NFTs coming to Bitcoin sparks handwringing about crypto purists
summary: Bitcoin's introduction of non-fungible tokens (NFTs) has sparked debate among crypto purists, with some seeing it as a fresh use case and others concerned about deviating from the network's origins. The NFTs, made possible by the Taproot upgrade in November 2021, allow users to mint and trade digital assets on the Bitcoin blockchain. While miners welcome the boost to fees, critics fear it may crowd out other transactions. The introduction of Bitcoin-native NFTs has the potential to improve mining economics and increase transaction volume.

images.alt_text: “Since exploding onto the scene with Bored Ape Yacht Club in 2021, Yuga Labs has quickly made a name for itself through a powerful combination of storytelling and community-building,” new CEO Daniel Alegre said.

site_title: BlockFi approved to set up auction for crypto mining business
summary: BlockFi has received bankruptcy court approval to set up an auction for its digital coin mining business. The company aims to sell computer equipment used for mining digital coins at a time when the crypto mining business is on the upswing. Bids for the mining assets are due on Feb 20, with an auction to follow about a week later. BlockFi, which filed for bankruptcy in November, plans to either sell or reorganize its business to repay creditors.

images.alt_text: BlockFi said in a bankruptcy filing that its substantial exposure to FTX created a liquidity crisis.

site_title: World’s next inflation surprise is looming in China
summary: China's reopening is expected to boost global growth, offsetting Europe's weakness and a US recession, but may also lead to higher inflation. Bloomberg Economics forecasts China's GDP to accelerate from 3% in 2022 to 5.8% in 2023, potentially lifting consumer prices by 0.9-2.0 percentage points. This could frustrate expectations for the US Federal Reserve to halt interest rate hikes at its May meeting. China's growth is seen as a positive factor for global commodity markets, with copper prices rising above $9,000 a tonne and Chinese oil consumption forecast to hit a record this year.

images.alt_text: Shoppers in the Guanqian Street shopping area in Suzhou, Jiangsu province, China, on Wednesday, Jan. 25, 2023. China's Lunar New Year travel and box office showed signs of recovery as people took advantage of a holiday free of strict restraints on movement following Beijing's pivot away from its Covid Zero policy. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

site_title: AIG fires interim CFO Mark Lyons for confidentiality breach
summary: AIG has terminated interim CFO Mark Lyons for violating the company's confidentiality obligations, unrelated to financial statements. Lyons will receive a $7.5 million settlement and will be replaced by Sabra Purtill, who previously served as chief investment officer of Corebridge Financial. Lyons has also been terminated as executive vice-president, global chief actuary, and head of portfolio management.

site_title: US offices reach 50% occupancy for first time since pandemic hit
summary: US offices have reached 50% occupancy for the first time since the pandemic, according to a security firm's index of building occupancies in 10 major metro areas. The index increased to 50.4% in the week ended Jan. 25, with most cities, including New York, seeing occupancy hold steady or rise. Austin had the highest level at almost 68%, while the San Jose area had the lowest at 41%. This milestone comes later than expected due to health concerns and workers' reluctance to give up flexibility.

images.alt_text: A view of the New York City skyline of Manhattan and the Hudson River during the outbreak of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) in New York City, as seen from Weehawken, New Jersey, U.S. April 18, 2020. REUTERS/Jeenah Moon

site_title: Green players eyeing government boosts for blended finance, carbon tax and SME support
summary: Singapore's Budget 2023 is expected to focus on drivers to bring about rapid decarbonization and infrastructural change, with key initiatives including blended finance, carbon taxation, and SME support. Thought leaders and executives hope for a more systematic and coordinated approach to mainstream blended finance, with increased funding for green technologies and infrastructure. Carbon taxation is also expected to be more aggressive, with a focus on driving action in the economy. Additionally, there is a call for greater support for SMEs, particularly in adopting innovative technology and energy-efficient solutions, as well as the development of green talent and a mindset shift within corporate Singapore.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

A worker watering plants outside Singapore's ArtScience Museum on a sweltering day in July. The National Climate Change Secretariat (NCCS) says the public can give their views on the 2050 timeline and the possibility of an updated 2030 target via government feedback portal Reach. The public consultation exercise opened on Monday and closes on Sept 26.
Countries typically take a “production-based” accounting approach in quantifying their greenhouse gas emissions.
There is a need for fiscal consolidation on the government’s part, after a “substantial” amount of fiscal bullets were used during the pandemic, said DBS senior economist Irvin Seah.

site_title: US: Stocks begin newsy week on downcast note
summary: US stocks began the week on a downcast note, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 0.8% to 33,717.09, the S&P 500 dropping 1.3% to 4,017.77, and the Nasdaq Composite Index sinking 2.0% to 11,393.81. Analysts attributed the decline to profit taking, particularly in the tech sector, ahead of key central bank announcements and corporate earnings. The Federal Reserve's rate decision and European Central Bank meeting are expected to be closely watched, while US jobs data for January will also be released later this week.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 68.87 points, or 0.20 per cent, at the open to 33,909.21.

site_title: A mindset shift to unlock the value of cash and bridge liquidity gap in the new normal
summary: Standard Chartered Bank's Peter Wong emphasizes the need for a mindset shift in cash management to unlock the value of cash and bridge the liquidity gap in the new normal. Amid predictions of recession and rising borrowing costs, Asian companies maintain high cash reserves, with sectors like hospitality and energy holding more cash buffers. To ensure growth and success, treasurers must adopt a new perspective and put their cash to use, leveraging opportunities in the region. A mindset shift is crucial for smarter decisions and future growth.

images.alt_text: The power of compounding over decades can grow a small investment into a sizable amount.

site_title: Foreigners scoop up China shares with January inflow at record
summary: Foreign investors have poured into China's stock market in January, adding a record 131.1 billion yuan (S$25.5 billion) worth of shares through trading links with Hong Kong. This is nearly 50% above the previous monthly record. The CSI 300 Index has gained nearly 20% over the past three months, driven by Beijing's Covid policy pivot and support for growth. Analysts expect foreign buying to propel mainland shares to outperform overseas Chinese stocks in the coming months, driven by solid holiday spending data and forecast upgrades for China's economy.

images.alt_text: The deficit has left local governments in an increasingly poor fiscal position, and the central government could become reluctant to support the economy with fiscal spending after last year’s growth slump.

site_title: Condo and HDB lease volumes rebound in December on fear of further rent hikes; rents continue climb: SRX, 99.co
summary: Residential leasing volumes rebounded in December, driven by lease renewals from expats and tenants anticipating higher rents in 2023. Condo rental volumes surged 26.6% from the previous month, breaking a four-month decline streak, with 6,345 units rented in December. Rents rose 3% from the previous month and 34.4% from the year before, with condo rents being 13.4% lower but 2.8% higher than the five-year average for the month.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Condominiums and HDB flats as viewed from CapitaSpring on Feb 9, 2022.
Private properties along Paterson Road
In the HDB rental market, prices are up 1.6 per cent from October 2022 and 27.8 per cent on a year-on-year basis.
HDB rents for October increased by 1.8 per cent from the previous month, with mature and non-mature estate rents rising by 1.6 per cent and 2.1 per cent respectively.

site_title: BP cuts oil demand outlook on Ukraine war
summary: British energy giant BP forecasts worldwide energy consumption to drop 2.3% by 2035 due to the Ukraine-Russia war, accelerating the transition away from fossil fuels. Oil demand is expected to continue playing a major role for 15-20 years, but carbon dioxide emissions could peak this decade and drop 30% by 2050. Climate campaigner Philip Evans welcomed the report, but emphasized the need for greater government intervention and investment to meet the Paris Agreement's targets.

images.alt_text: Chevron says it would triple its spending on share repurchases to US$75 billion over five years at current guidance.
BP is aiming to rapidly grow the company’s renewables business and slash oil and gas output by 2030.
The 10 sites include working areas in Natuna D Alpha, which are giant gas fields in the South China Sea.

site_title: Europe doubles down on support for Ukraine
summary: European countries have reaffirmed their support for Ukraine, with the European Union set to impose new sanctions on Russia ahead of the one-year anniversary of its invasion. The EU and US have also agreed to deliver tanks to Ukraine, including US-made M1 Abrams and German-made Leopards. However, analysts suggest that Ukraine's chances of removing all Russian forces from occupied territories in 2023 are low, with a stalemate or ceasefire possible. The European Council on Foreign Relations research found that only 11 nations believe Ukraine can regain all its territory, while others expect Russia to control chunks of Ukrainian territory.

images.alt_text: Pressure has been building for weeks on German Chancellor Olaf Scholz’s government to send the tanks and allow other Nato allies to do the same.

site_title: Europe: Stocks slip as hot Spanish inflation data fans rate hike concerns
summary: European stocks slipped 0.2% on Monday as hotter-than-expected Spanish inflation data fueled concerns about interest rate hikes from the European Central Bank and the Bank of England later this week. The US Federal Reserve is set to raise its policy rate by 25 basis points on Wednesday. Eurozone bond yields climbed after Spain's consumer prices rose 5.8% year-on-year in January, with investors bracing for aggressive rate hikes to combat inflation.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.8 per cent lower at 33,717.09 on Monday.

site_title: Ford cuts price of electric Mustang Mach-E in response to Tesla
summary: Ford cuts the starting price of its electric Mustang Mach-E by US$900 to US$45,995, following Tesla's recent price cuts. The move aims to boost sales and offset declining margins, with production set to increase by 67% to 130,000 models this year. The price cuts also bring the Mach-E in line with new federal tax credit caps of up to US$7,500 under the Inflation Reduction Act.

images.alt_text: Ford said it has reports of 17 minor crashes relating to the recall issue and more than 2,100 warranty reports but no reports of injuries.

GM, the No 1 US automaker by sales in 2022, said higher prices added US$2.1 billion to pre-tax profits in the third quarter compared to the same quarter in 2021 – equivalent to nearly half of pre-tax profits for the period overall.

site_title: CSE Global acquires US radio communication group for US$11 million
summary: CSE Global acquired US radio communication group Radio One Group for US$11 million. The acquisition is expected to be earnings accretive and a strategic fit for CSE Global's current business. Radio One Group recorded net profit before tax of US$3.5 million for the 12 months ended Dec 31, 2022. The deal will fund CSE Global using proceeds from its rights issue and bank borrowings, with pro-forma earnings per share expected to rise to 3.38 Singapore cents.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
satellite, technology, spark

site_title: India plans measures to curb Chinese imports as trade gap concerns mount
summary: India is considering tariffs and non-tariff measures to curb Chinese imports, amid a 28% widening of the trade gap with China from 2021 to 2022. The government aims to reduce imports of non-essential consumer and electronic goods, with China accounting for nearly a third of India's trade deficit. India plans to intensify checks on imported goods and introduce safeguards such as anti-dumping duties if unfair practices are found, with possible measures to be detailed in the February budget.

site_title: Sanofi to retrench 800 staff at vaccine plants in India
summary: Sanofi is planning to retrench approximately 800 employees at two vaccine-making facilities in India, offering a voluntary retirement scheme to affected staff. The move comes after the company failed to secure a Unicef contract for its Shan-5 vaccine, which has faced regulatory scrutiny over quality issues. Sanofi will continue to fulfill its current supply commitments to the Indian government, but will transfer insulin packaging to another site and evaluate which facility will support this operation.

images.alt_text: Sanofi's vaccine production facility to strengthen Singapore's future pandemic readiness

site_title: Labour wants to fix Brexit. Good luck with that
summary: Labour leader Keir Starmer's party is unlikely to rejoin the single market and customs union, despite London Mayor Sadiq Khan's call for discussion on the issue. Instead, Labour will focus on marginal changes to the current Brexit deal, aiming to "fix" the Northern Ireland Protocol and reduce trade frictions. Despite Prime Minister Rishi Sunak's efforts to make progress on the Protocol, concessions come at a cost, and the government faces challenges in negotiating external trade deals. A study by the Centre for Economic Reform found UK GDP is 5.5% lower than it would have been if Brexit had not happened, resulting in £40 billion in lost tax revenue.

images.alt_text: But higher net migration may do little to fill labour shortages in industries that rely heavily on workers from the EU.
British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak said in a statement that the UK had “forged a path as an independent nation with confidence” and “that momentum hasn’t slowed”.

site_title: BYD’s 2022 net income jumps over 400% to as high as 17 billion yuan
summary: Chinese electric vehicle giant BYD reported a 458% increase in net income to 17 billion yuan in 2022, exceeding analysts' forecasts. The company sold 1.86 million new energy vehicles last year, a record high. Revenue is expected to almost double to 400 billion yuan. BYD attributed its strong financial performance to surge in new energy vehicle sales and its ability to produce key components, avoiding supply-chain disruptions. The company's shares dipped 2.7% on Monday, trimming this year's gains to around 24%.

images.alt_text: BYD was the world’s biggest seller of BEVs and plug-in hybrids in 2022 with a total of 1.86 million sales.

site_title: ESR-Logos Reit H2 DPU rises 7.5% to S$0.0154 on higher earnings
summary: ESR-Logos Reit reported a 7.5% increase in its second-half distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.0154, driven by a 61% rise in gross revenue to S$195.6 million. The Reit's net property income (NPI) grew 64% to S$141.5 million, mainly attributed to contributions from the merger with Ara Logos Logistics Trust. Despite higher electricity rates, the Reit delivered stable growth, with a retention rate of 69.3% and positive rental reversions across all sub-sectors.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
ESR-Reit's general industrial property at 120 Pioneer Road.

site_title: Gucci’s challenge: reigniting heat while boosting timeless appeal
summary: Gucci appoints new creative director Sabato De Sarno to revive its fortunes, which have lagged behind rivals such as Hermes and Louis Vuitton. De Sarno, a senior fashion designer from Valentino, will focus on both timeless appeal and generating buzz with new styles. Analysts say Gucci needs to strike a balance between these two approaches to drive customer loyalty. De Sarno's first collection is set to debut in September in Milan, and the brand is under pressure to quickly recover from recent Chinese market decline amid Covid-19 lockdowns.

images.alt_text: A selection of designer sunglasses owned by André Leon Talley are among the items to be auctioned by Christie’s.
Luxury retailers look forward to Chinese tourists returning to Milan in large numbers.

site_title: Even on US$100k, more Americans are living pay cheque to pay cheque
summary: A new study by Pymnts.com and LendingClub found that 64% of US consumers, equivalent to 166 million people, were living pay cheque to pay cheque at the end of 2022, up 3 percentage points from the previous year. This increase was largely driven by higher earners, with 8 million people earning over $100,000 a year, and over half of them living pay cheque to pay cheque. The study suggests that consumers face growing financial strain due to rising costs, stagnant wages, and decreased savings, with many expecting their incomes to not keep pace with inflation.

images.alt_text: poverty, black and white, emotion

site_title: Chip Eng Seng subsidiaries win S$562m Cross-Island Line-Punggol Extension contract
summary: Chip Eng Seng's subsidiaries, CES_SDC and Chip Eng Seng Contractors, have been awarded a S$562 million contract by the Land Transport Authority (LTA) to design and construct the Elias station and tunnels under the Cross Island Line-Punggol Extension. Construction works are expected to start in Q2 2023, with passenger service targeting 2032. The station will be an underground station with five entrances, built at a depth of about 40m. This contract completes the appointment of contractors for all four Cross Island Line-Punggol Extension stations.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
LTA says it will continue to engage stakeholders, including nature groups, when construction  beneath the Central Catchment Nature Reserve is under way.

Announcing the alignment for phase 2 on Tuesday (Sep 25), Transport Minister S Iswaran said it will provide greater public transport access to areas in the west such as Jurong Lake District and West Coast, and improve connectivity between the eastern, western and north-eastern parts of Singapore.

The offer of S$0.75 per share represented a steep 43.9 per cent discount to CES’s revalued net asset value (RNAV) per share.
But the IFA, Xandar Capital, deemed the offer to be “fair and reasonable” – and recommended shareholders accept it.

site_title: Fed funds borrowing leaps to new high as banks scramble for cash
summary: US federal funds borrowing reached a new high of $120 billion on January 27, exceeding the highest level in at least seven years. The surge in borrowing indicates increasing pressure on the banking system due to the Federal Reserve's tightening policies. As cash becomes scarce, banks are turning to alternative sources to fund themselves, with depositors shifting into higher-yielding alternatives such as money-market funds.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An eagle tops the U.S. Federal Reserve building's facade in Washington, July 31, 2013. REUTERS/Jonathan Ernst/File Photo
HSBC Asset Management says policymakers may cut rates by a full percentage point before the end of the year, as signs of a US economic recession emerge.

site_title: Samsung profit plunges as memory chip crash eats into earnings
summary: Samsung Electronics' quarterly profit plummeted due to a sharp drop in demand for semiconductors, with the chip segment's profit declining over 90% to 270 billion won. Operating income fell short of estimates, but net income exceeded expectations at 23.5 trillion won. The decline is attributed to consumers cutting back on gadget purchases amid soaring interest rates and inflation.

images.alt_text: Crypto exchange-traded products rocketed in popularity during 2021’s boom in token prices.

site_title: Will Americans even notice an improving economy?
summary: The US economy is experiencing a positive outlook, with a 6.7% real gross domestic product growth and 4.5 million job gains in 2022. However, a majority of Americans rate their own financial situation positively, despite 75% describing the economy as poor. This disconnect between public perceptions and economic reality is attributed to partisan biases, negative media coverage, and the influence of personal experience. Experts predict a potential growth hiccup in the next quarter, but it remains uncertain whether Americans will notice the improving economy.

images.alt_text: Shoppers in the SoHo neighborhood of New York, US, on Saturday, Jan. 21, 2023. The Bureau of Economic Analysis is scheduled to release personal spending figures on January 27. Photographer: Jordana Bermudez/Bloomberg

Powell is expected to balance this week’s likely 25 basis-point increase in rates with a stern message that the step-down from the past six hikes doesn’t diminish his commitment to reducing inflation to 2 per cent.
Gross domestic product (GDP) increased at a 2.9 per cent annualised rate last quarter, the Commerce Department said in its advance fourth-quarter GDP growth estimate on Thursday (Jan 26).

site_title: Golden Energy’s proposed break-up, delisting looking more miserly after Stanmore’s big run
summary: Golden Energy and Resources (Gear) has pushed back its long-stop date for the proposed break-up and delisting to August 9, following a 3.9% decline in the market price of shares in its Indonesian-listed thermal coal producer, Golden Energy Mines (Gems). The deal's terms now look more miserly, with the exit offer price of S$0.16 per share undervaluing Gear's remaining assets, including a 64% stake in Stanmore Resources. Analysts say the offer is 52% below the value of Gear's stake in Stanmore, sparking concerns that minority investors are being unfairly disadvantaged.

images.alt_text: Ben Paul
Golden Energy and Resources had on Nov 9 sounded its intention to give shareholders an option of cash, or a combination of cash and shares, to delist from SGX.
The series of proposals come as Gear seeks to reduce its exposure to energy coal by shifting away from its existing energy coal business currently conducted by Gems through the proposed distribution.
Gear has rationalised its break-up and privatisation with an ESG narrative

site_title: Micro-Mechanics Q2 net profit falls 58% to S$1.9 million amid global chip market slowdown
summary: Micro-Mechanics' Q2 net profit fell 58% to S$1.9 million due to a global semiconductor industry slowdown and "difficult conditions" in China. Revenue dropped 17.9% to S$16.7 million, with earnings per share declining 58.4%. The company attributed the decline to softer demand and higher chip inventories, particularly in personal computers and smartphone applications.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
Christopher R Borch, CEO, Micro-Mechanics Holdings.
Micro-Mechanics posted a 14.6 decline in net profit, marking the end of four consecutive quarters of growth.

site_title: US court rejects J&J bankruptcy strategy for thousands of talc lawsuits
summary: A US appeals court has rejected Johnson & Johnson's attempt to offload thousands of talc lawsuits into bankruptcy court, allowing the company to face the potentially massive liability. The court ruled that J&J's subsidiary filed for bankruptcy without financial distress, allowing over 38,000 lawsuits to revive. The decision reverses J&J's strategy, known as the "Texas two-step," which was used by the company and others to avoid lawsuits. The ruling could set a precedent, forcing companies to consider the risks of the strategy. J&J shares fell 3.7% after the decision, with the company stating it would challenge the ruling and that its talc products are safe.

images.alt_text: J&J to end global sales of talc-based baby powder

site_title: Israeli PM invokes Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan in economic defence
summary: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu invoked Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan to refute warnings of a market backlash against his government's plans to reshape the judiciary. Despite protests and criticism, investment banks JPMorgan and Goldman Sachs say the proposed changes won't deter investors. Economist Tadas Gedminas warned that negative scenarios could take years to materialize, and the shekel declined 1.7% on Monday. The government is expected to moderate aspects of the reform to appease critics and investors.

site_title: Sunak says UK can’t raise taxes to end dispute with nurses
summary: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak said he cannot raise taxes to fund pay rises for NHS workers, citing a historical high in government spending on the healthcare service. He is grappling with the ongoing strike by nurses and ambulance workers, who are due to stand side-by-side on picket lines on February 6. Sunak's administration is trying to overhaul the crisis-hit NHS, while also keeping a firm grip on the nation's finances and shielding Britons from the biggest cost of living squeeze in decades.

images.alt_text: The walkout has piled further pressure on the National Health Service, at a time of peak demand due to winter illnesses and lengthening waiting lists for treatment caused by Covid cancellations and understaffing.

site_title: Facebook seeks to block £3 billion UK mass action over market dominance
summary: Meta Platforms, the parent company of Facebook, is facing a £3 billion lawsuit in the UK over allegations it abused its dominant position to monetize users' personal data. The lawsuit, brought on behalf of 45 million Facebook users in Britain, claims users were not properly compensated for the value of their personal data. Meta has said the lawsuit is "entirely without merit" and that the claimed losses ignore the economic value Facebook provides. The case will be heard by a London tribunal, with a decision on certification of collective proceedings expected.

site_title: France braces for new strikes against Macron pension reform
summary: France is bracing for another day of mass protests and strikes on Tuesday over proposed pension reforms championed by President Emmanuel Macron. The strikes, which began on January 19, have grown to the largest demonstrations since 2010, with around 1.1 million people participating in the first strike day. Security forces expect similarly sized crowds in 240 demonstrations across the country, with disruptions to transport, education, and other services. The government has signaled wiggle room on some measures, but the minimum retirement age of 64 remains non-negotiable, with public transport operator RATP severely restricting services in Paris.

images.alt_text: Demonstrators gather in Place de la Bastille during a rally called by French trade unions in Paris, France on Jan 19, 2023.

site_title: EC World Reit extends long stop date for divestment of two Chinese logistics assets
summary: EC World Reit has extended the long stop date for the proposed divestment of two Chinese logistics assets to February 28, from January 31, due to purchasers being unable to complete the transaction by the initial deadline. The divestment, worth 2.03 billion yuan (S$392.7 million), aims to repay outstanding loans and is part of a repayment plan agreed upon by the Reit's manager and lenders. The extension is a temporary measure, and the Reit's manager remains confident in the divestment's completion.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
EC World Asset Management noted that the proceeds of the proposed divestment of some assets will be sufficient to make the mandatory repayment.
EC World Reit's manager said lenders are in the process of obtaining the relevant internal approval for the repayment plan.

site_title: Goldman Sachs restructures Russian business
summary: Goldman Sachs has restructured its Russian business, selling assets including minority stakes in recruitment firm Headhunter and real estate database Cian to local management. This move, which includes a 9% reduction in credit exposure to Russia, brings the US bank closer to exiting the country. The restructuring comes after Goldman Sachs reduced its exposure to Russia by 9% to US$205 million in the third quarter. The sale is a response to US banks cutting exposure to Russia since Russia's invasion of Ukraine last year.

site_title: Indonesia domestic cooking oil allocation to rise ahead of Ramadan
summary: Indonesia's Trade Minister Zulkifli Hasan announced a 50% increase in domestic cooking oil supply to 450,000 tonnes per month for three months ahead of Ramadan and Eid al-Fitr. The current allocation of 300,000 tonnes per month is insufficient, with traditional market merchants facing difficulties in securing supply and prices surpassing the capped price. The increase aims to meet rising demand and alleviate supply chain issues.

site_title: Indonesia to offer 10 oil and gas sites in 2023
summary: Indonesia plans to auction 10 oil and gas working areas, including a block in the South China Sea, in May 2023 to boost energy production. The sites include giant gas fields in Natuna D Alpha. The move aims to revive stalled projects, including the Indonesia Deepwater Development (IDD) and Masela projects, which missed targets last year. Indonesia aims to increase crude oil lifting to 1 million barrels per day and gas lifting to 12,000 million standard cubic feet per day by 2030. Oil giant Chevron is close to a deal to transfer its stake in IDD to an investor.

images.alt_text: Profit taking ahead of the weekend may  have driven prices lower.

Nat Vanitchyangkul, the Asia chief executive officer for sustainability consultancy ERM, said energy companies are trying to wrest control over the supply of green feedstock, like sugarcane or crude palm oil, as they look at building their biorefinery arsenal worldwide.
The Philippine Coast Guard personnel aboard the BRP Cabra patrol ship monitoring Chinese vessels anchored at Sabina Shoal, in the disputed South China Sea on 27 April 2021.

site_title: Abu Dhabi’s IHC plans to invest 1.4 billion dirhams in Adani Enterprises
summary: Abu Dhabi's International Holding Company (IHC) plans to invest 1.4 billion dirhams (approximately $500 million) in Adani Enterprises' follow-on public offer. The investment comes amid Adani Group's ongoing crisis, which has seen losses of $65 billion in market value following a short-seller's criticism. IHC CEO Syed Basar Shueb expressed confidence in Adani Enterprises' fundamentals and growth potential. The investment is part of IHC's strategy to boost global acquisitions by 70% this year, focusing on clean energy and food processing sectors.

images.alt_text: The selloff is fast eroding the wealth of Adani, Asia’s richest man, after his stocks were some of the best performers last year not just in the local market, but also on the broader MSCI Asia Pacific Index.
Opposition lawmakers will raise ties between Gautam Adani, Asia’s richest man, and Prime Minister Narendra Modi at the coming budget session.
Adani Group’s response comes as its flagship company, Adani Enterprises, pushes ahead with a US$2.5 billion share sale.

site_title: LIV Golf tour announces full schedule for 2023
summary: The LIV Golf tour has announced its full 2023 schedule, featuring 14 events at 12 venues worldwide. The tour will return to five venues from last year's inaugural series, including Centurion Club, Trump National Golf Club Bedminster, and Trump National Doral Golf Club. The season will start on February 24 in Mexico, with a record $405 million in prize money. The tour includes individual and team elements, with 12 franchises competing. LIV Golf has signed big-name players like Cameron Smith, Dustin Johnson, and Phil Mickelson, and has secured a broadcast deal with The CW Network in the US.

site_title: CDL in talks to acquire St Katharine Docks development in London
summary: City Developments Ltd (CDL) is in talks to acquire the St Katharine Docks development in London, subject to satisfactory due diligence and negotiation on terms. CDL has signed an exclusivity agreement with asset manager Blackstone, which is reportedly considering selling the marina for around £400 million (S$650.9 million). The acquisition is one of CDL's opportunities to improve shareholder value, and the company will provide further updates if material developments occur. CDL shares rose 0.1% on the news.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
City Developments Limited (CDL) headquarters along Robinson Road.

site_title: Tech industry group calls for support for digital trust, talent, sustainability in Budget 2023
summary: Singapore's Budget 2023 is being urged to support the tech industry by developing digital trust capabilities, adopting skills-based assessments to hire and train tech talent, and promoting sustainability. SGTech, a technology trade association, has submitted nine recommendations to the Ministry of Finance, including offering grants and subsidies to incentivize cyber hygiene among SMEs, piloting digital trust workforce schemes, and promoting cross-border data flows. The government is also encouraged to form an advisory group to catalyze the uptake of cross-border privacy rules among Asian enterprises.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
Members of Parliament Liang Eng Hwa (left), and Don Wee co-chaired the panel discussion.

Despite the potential advantages of various government measures to boost foreign investment, if put into action, industry observers expect the government to hold off on providing details at Budget 2023.
Any unemployment support measures will likely be for vulnerable workers, such as those who are older, have lower-income, or are less educated, one economist told The Business Times.

site_title: Metro, Boustead Projects and independent third party to jointly acquire high-spec industrial property
summary: Metro Holdings and Boustead Projects, along with an independent third party, have jointly acquired the eight-storey high-spec industrial property J’Forte Building in Singapore for S$98.8 million via the Boustead Industrial Fund (BIF). The acquisition marks BIF's first in the open market and brings the total number of properties under BIF's portfolio to 16. The trust's total assets under management will increase to approximately S$749 million, with a high committed average occupancy rate of 98 per cent and a long weighted average lease expiry of approximately 6.1 years.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
Boustead Projects' net profit for the 6-months ended Sep 30, 2022, rose to S$7.7 million from S$5.9 million in the year ago period.

Metro’s retail division saw a 33.9 per cent year-on-year jump in revenue due to the lower base last year, when department stores had shorter operating hours as Singapore went through a “heightened alert” owing an increase in Covid-19 cases.

site_title: China posts record deficit in 2022 on Covid Zero, property slump
summary: China's budget deficit reached a record 8.96 trillion yuan ($1.7 trillion) in 2022 due to the costly implementation and offsetting of its "zero-Covid" policy, which severely damaged economic activity. The deficit was 51% higher than in 2021 and 7.4% of China's nominal GDP, leaving local governments in a poor fiscal position. The central government may become reluctant to support the economy with fiscal spending after last year's growth slump, which slowed to 3% due to a property slump and weakening global demand.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People walk out of a subway station during morning rush hour in Wuchang district, after the government gradually loosened restrictions on coronavirus disease (COVID-19) control, in Wuhan, Hubei province, China December 9, 2022. REUTERS/Martin Pollard/File Photo

epa10070599 Medical personnel takes Coronavirus mandatory PCR test from citizens while cooling off with an ice block and a fan behind them, in Shanghai, China, 14 July 2022. Shanghai city reported five locally transmitted COVID-19 cases and 42 local asymptomatic infections, according to the Shanghai Health Commission report. Due to the virus' spread, more communities are in lockdown again. Shanghai issued its third red heat alert this week while the record 40.9 degrees Celsius on 13 July was tied with the hottest day record from 2017.  EPA-EFE/ALEX PLAVEVSKI

Travelers in the departure hall at the Hongqiao Railway Station in Shanghai, China, on Thursday, Jan. 19, 2023. With China's 296 million migrant workers on the move this year, factories and local governments are bracing for disruptions during a longer-than-usual holiday period. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg
China's housing market faces the prospect of slower recovery than consumption or broad domestic demand.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower ahead of Fed rate decision
summary: US stocks began the week lower, with the Dow Jones falling 0.20% to 33,909.21, and the Nasdaq Composite dropping 0.94% to 11,512.34. The decline comes ahead of the Federal Reserve's rate decision and the start of the earnings season. The S&P 500 also opened lower, falling 0.52% to 4,049.27. The lower opening marks the start of a busy week for markets.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the trading floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., January 27, 2023. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly

site_title: OUE C-Reit H2 DPU falls 24.1% to S$0.0104 despite higher revenue
summary: OUE Commercial Reit reported a 24.1% year-on-year decline in distribution per unit (DPU) for the second half of 2022, falling to S$0.0104 despite an 8% increase in revenue to S$125.7 million. Net property income rose 8.6% to S$103.3 million, driven by lower rental rebates and higher property expenses. The Reit's amount available for distribution fell 19.1% to S$52.1 million, largely due to lower income support and higher interest expenses.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
Hospitality S-Reits such as CapitaLand Ascott Trust are expected to ride on the tailwinds of the return of Chinese tourists.
Net property income in Q3 rose to S$48.3 million, due mainly to lower property expenses, while revenue increased 1.7 per cent to S$59.5 million, OUE C-Reit's manager said in an exchange filing.

site_title: Euro rises on Spanish data, US dollar slips towards 8-month low
summary: The euro rose 0.2% to $1.0891 after Spain's consumer prices increased 5.8% in January, exceeding expectations and raising hopes for a 50 basis point interest rate hike by the ECB on Wednesday. Meanwhile, the US dollar slipped towards an eight-month low due to expectations of a 25 basis point rate hike by the Fed and hawkish rhetoric from ECB policymakers. The euro is on track for a near 1.7% monthly gain, while the yen fell 0.3% to $1.30, and the Australian dollar rose 0.5% to $0.7071 despite a 33-year high inflation rate.

site_title: The future of fashion grows in a pond
summary: A new generation of sustainable fashion startups is emerging, focusing on materials like algae, hemp, and fungus to create clothing that is not only eco-friendly but also desirable. Companies like Algaeing, Vollebak, and others are developing algae-based dyes, yarns, and textiles that are biodegradable, non-toxic, and require less water and energy than traditional materials. With growing demand from environmentally-conscious consumers, these startups aim to revolutionize the fashion industry, which is responsible for up to 10% of humanity's carbon emissions.

site_title: Fed’s Wall Street clash sets stage for Powell’s hawkish message
summary: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell is expected to balance a likely 25 basis-point interest rate hike with a hawkish message, cautioning that the step-down from past hikes doesn't diminish his commitment to reducing inflation to 2%. Despite financial conditions being the loosest since February, Powell is likely to push back on market expectations of rate cuts later this year, citing the need for tighter financial conditions to achieve price stability. This could lead to a roiling of the markets, as investors bet on fading inflation and subsequent rate cuts.

images.alt_text: Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell could still have a sobering effect on markets if he says the hikes must stop because of an oncoming recession.

site_title: Issuers’ ESG strategy more important to investors than the label of their bonds: Barclays
summary: Barclays reports that investors in Asia are focusing more on a bond issuer's environmental, social, and governance (ESG) strategies rather than the label of their bonds in 2023. This trend contrasts with Barclays' expectations of an expanding green premium in European credit markets due to upcoming regulations. In Asia, green premiums narrowed to 15 basis points, and the volume of new ESG bond issuances among corporates is expected to decline structurally in 2023, with total bond supply expected to be between $150 billion and $180 billion.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
Globally, ESG bond proceeds fell 52.9 per cent to US$133.3 billion in Q4 2022, compared to the US$203.8 billion in the same quarter in 2021.
ESG bond volumes swelled over the past few years but dropped by 22 per cent in 2022 amid a broader slowdown in corporate bond issues.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure Trust H2 DPU slips 0.5% to S$0.0191
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust (KIT) reported a 0.5% drop in second-half distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.0191, despite a 47.4% increase in distributable income to S$134.9 million. Full-year DPU rose 1% to S$0.0382, and distributable income increased 15.8% to S$222.5 million. The trust's energy transition segment contributed to the largest increase in full-year distributable income. KIT's net gearing was 39.8% and it had "comfortable debt headroom for growth."

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
Jopy Chiang assumed the role of chief executive at KIT’s trustee-manager just over a year ago.

site_title: TikTok’s CEO to testify before Congress in March
summary: TikTok CEO Shou Zi Chew will testify before the US Energy and Commerce Committee on March 23, marking his first appearance before a Congressional committee. The hearing comes amid concerns over national security, data security, and online harms. Lawmakers, particularly Republicans, have demanded more information from TikTok on its impact on young users and the platform's safety measures. TikTok has previously stated it limits features by age and is focused on the safety of younger users, but some lawmakers remain skeptical about the app's practices.

images.alt_text: TikTok has been seeking to assure Washington that the personal data of US citizens cannot be accessed.

site_title: WHO says Covid-19 still an international emergency
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has reaffirmed that the Covid-19 pandemic remains a public health emergency of international concern, 3 years after initially declaring it. The declaration comes after a 14th meeting of the WHO's emergency committee, citing rising deaths and a transition point in the pandemic. WHO chief Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus acknowledged the need for a careful transition and mitigation of negative consequences, despite progress in managing the crisis.

images.alt_text: Measures that could be taken include genomic surveillance, and targeting passengers from other countries as long as it does not divert resources from domestic surveillance systems.

site_title: Deutsche Bank hires Credit Suisse’s Indonesia wealth chief
summary: Deutsche Bank has appointed Johanes Oeni as head of international private bank for South-east Asia, marking the second senior hire from Credit Suisse in Singapore in recent months. Oeni will start at the German bank in April, replacing Young Jin Yee, who left Credit Suisse as the Swiss bank's No 2 for wealth management in the region. The move comes as Credit Suisse undertakes a sweeping overhaul of its business following years of scandals and management missteps.

images.alt_text: The Swiss lender has been reducing headcount across its divisions after announcing plans last year to eliminate 9,000 roles globally by 2025.

site_title: Why are markets shorting the Singapore dollar?
summary: Analysts from Goldman Sachs, Societe Generale, and OCBC have made short calls on the Singapore dollar, citing reasons such as cooling inflation, lower demand for exports, and a potential weakening of the currency against other currencies. Despite the Singapore dollar's past performance as a safe-haven currency, experts expect it to continue strengthening in 2023, but the outlook may not be as bullish as previously thought.

images.alt_text: Jeanette Tan
Momentum indicators show the Singapore dollar’s gains have taken it into overbought territory, according to slow stochastics, suggesting that some sort of pullback is likely in the near term.
From a top-down perspective, analysts say things are generally seen as changing for the better in 2023 for most EM currencies after a difficult year in 2022.
The baht may get an early boost to start the year if December inflation numbers due Thursday show CPI is starting to rise again, as economists forecast.

site_title: Budget hongbao should be for those who need it
summary: Singapore's Budget hongbao, traditionally given to those in need, should remain targeted, rather than being a blanket handout. The government's paternalism and the evolution of societal attitudes suggest that the practice should adapt to changing needs. Some argue that those in the top income tax bracket or with sufficient earning power should not receive hongbao, as it implies they don't need the money. A more calibrated approach, prioritizing lower-income and vulnerable groups, is seen as a more prudent fiscal strategy, especially considering the government's recent financial outlays.

images.alt_text: The government is looking at additional measures in this year’s budget to help Singaporeans cope with rising prices and inflation, said DPM Lawrence Wong.
CDC Vouchers are one possible form of additional cost-of-living support in Budget 2023, say observers.

site_title: China finds no new variants despite massive New Year migration
summary: China found no new Covid-19 variants during the recent New Year holiday migration, despite concerns about the virus spreading globally. The country's most populous country tested 1,421 viral sequences and found older strains like BA.5.2 and BF.7, which have been driving the outbreak for weeks. The testing also captured a small amount of the XBB and BQ.1 subvariants, but no new variants were detected. China's outbreak has been waning since its peak in late December, with a significant decline in severe patients and deaths.

site_title: Luxury Valentine’s Day gifts for a big wow
summary: Luxury Valentine's Day gifts are showcased in this article, focusing on unique and elegant presents for loved ones. Options include the Dinh Van Paris Double Coeurs R27 pendant necklace ($10,670), Louis Vuitton LV x YK LV Trainer Sneaker ($1,360), Winston Flowers One & Only Flowers ($750), Bulgari Serpenti Tubogas Infinity ($85,500), Cartier Tank Française ($3,550), and Oura Ring ($299). Other gifts include Cadar Endless Hoop Earrings ($2,900), Fendi Baguette Bag ($4,300), Berluti Silk and Cotton Track Pants ($1,180), and The Beauty Sleeper & Silk Pillowcase ($200-$160).

site_title: China says Covid situation at 'low level' after holiday
summary: China reported a "low level" of Covid-19 cases, with fever clinic visits dropping 40% during the new year's holiday period. The country's sudden relaxation of Covid restrictions led to a sharp rise in domestic and international travel, with 892 million passenger trips recorded between Jan 7 and Jan 29. Despite concerns about a potential rebound in cases, the China Center for Disease Control and Prevention reported no significant increase in cases, and a decline in severe Covid cases and deaths. The country's reported data on Covid-related deaths may be undercounted.

images.alt_text: More trips are being made out of and into China after the country stopped requiring inbound travellers to quarantine upon arrival.

site_title: Singapore shares down 0.5% on Monday amid cautious trading
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.5% to close at 3,378.29 on Monday, as cautious trading ahead of key events including the US jobs report and China's purchasing managers' index led to a higher number of losers (350) than gainers (234) in 1.3 billion securities worth S$1.6 billion.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
On the Singapore Exchange, gainers outnumbered losers 94 to 39.

site_title: Adani rout hits more than US$70 billion as fight with Hindenburg intensifies
summary: Adani Group, Asia's richest man Gautam Adani, is facing a severe selloff worth over $70 billion as the fight with Hindenburg Research intensifies. Despite Adani's 413-page rebuttal to allegations of fraud, shares of most Adani Group firms have slumped, and US dollar bonds have fallen to fresh lows. The conglomerate's corporate governance is under scrutiny, threatening to weaken investor confidence in India and accelerate a shift towards a reopening China.

images.alt_text: Opposition lawmakers will raise ties between Gautam Adani, Asia’s richest man, and Prime Minister Narendra Modi at the coming budget session.

site_title: Huawei spinoff is lone winner in dire year for China smartphones
summary: Honor, a spinoff from Huawei, was the only major phone manufacturer to grow shipments in China in 2022, despite a decade-low market. The company's shipments increased by 34.4% as peers like Oppo and Vivo declined by over 25%. Honor's 18.1% market share was just behind Vivo, which led the market. The growth was attributed to the COVID-19 lockdowns and restrictions in early 2022, which impacted consumer demand. Honor is preparing for an initial public offering and has been consistently growing since its separation from Huawei in 2020.

site_title: Iron ore extends rally on China demand optimism
summary: Iron ore prices rose 3% to a contract high on Monday, driven by optimism about demand from top steel producer China. The May iron ore contract on China's Dalian Commodity Exchange ended 2% higher at 873.50 yuan (S$169.90) per tonne. Market sentiment was boosted by a surge in Chinese New Year holiday trips and central bank support for targeted sectors of the economy.

images.alt_text: The most active rebar contract on the Shanghai Futures Exchange has edged 0.2 per cent higher.

(FILES) This file photo taken on May 1, 2018 shows a worker handling steel cable at a steel factory in Lianyungang in China's eastern Jiangsu province.
China opened trade in iron ore futures to foreign investors on May 4, 2018 on the market of the north-eastern city of Dalian, aiming to boost its pricing clout for one of its top imports, in one additional signal of opening up amidst a trade row with the US. / AFP PHOTO / - / China OUT

site_title: Indonesia sees record coal exports of more than 500 million tonnes in 2023
summary: Indonesia plans to produce 695 million tonnes of coal in 2023 and expects exports of 518 million tonnes, a record level. The country's domestic coal consumption is estimated at 177 million tonnes, down from 193 million tonnes in 2022. Energy Minister Arifin Tasrif attributes the decline to efficiency programs to reduce carbon emissions. Indonesia aims to cut emissions by 31.9% by 2030 and reach net-zero emissions by 2060, with coal prices expected to remain elevated due to global supply and demand imbalances.

images.alt_text: Surging domestic prices forced the government to suspend palm oil exports temporarily last April, causing turmoil on global and local markets, something Jakarta would not want to repeat.
Indonesia allows direct carbon trading among emitters and authorities plan to launch a carbon exchange this year.

site_title: Anwar vows gradual debt reduction to ensure stability
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim has vowed to gradually lower the nation's debt and narrow the budget gap without raising taxes that would hurt the poor. The country's actual debt is at 61% of GDP, and Anwar aims to reduce the debt ratio to win a higher credit score from Fitch Ratings. He will table the revised 2023 budget on Feb 24 and has been preaching fiscal prudence, prioritizing protecting low- and middle-income groups from rising prices. Anwar acknowledged the need for taxation policies but wants to avoid measures that affect the low-income group.

images.alt_text: Like the party's name (Harapan means hope in Malay), Malaysian has high hopes on the new government for a change that could improve the country.

site_title: Housing market will weigh on China’s recovery
summary: China's housing market is expected to experience a slower recovery than consumption or broad domestic demand, a reversal of its usual role. The country's transition to "living with Covid-19" is progressing faster than anticipated, leading to a recovery phase as early as March. China's focus on domestic demand expansion, including consumption, aims to boost GDP to around 5% this year, potentially lifting global growth but with significant inflationary effects. The housing market's recovery will be driven by policy support, particularly for high-quality developers, but will likely be slower due to buyer reluctance to invest in a market with uncertain lockdown prospects.

images.alt_text: This aerial photo taken on December 3, 2022 shows a housing complex by Chinese property developer Evergrande in Huaian, in China's eastern Jiangsu province. (Photo by AFP) / China OUT

Cities are eligible to maintain, lower or remove minimum interest rates on loans for first home purchases, according to a statement from the China central bank and banking regulator on Thursday (Jan 5) evening.

site_title: German economy unexpectedly shrinks in Q4 2022
summary: Germany's economy unexpectedly contracted 0.2% in Q4 2022, according to the German Federal Statistical Office, in a sign that the country may be entering a recession. This is despite analysts' forecast of stagnation. The contraction increases the likelihood of a recession, which is defined as two successive quarters of contraction. The German government revised its economic forecast for 2023 upwards, now predicting a 0.2% growth, up from an earlier forecast of a 0.4% decline.

site_title: Singapore hotels’ average room rates up in Dec from previous month; other measures down slightly
summary: Singapore hotels saw a 27.7% increase in average room rates (ARR) to S$285.84 in December 2022, a 14-year high, driven by "revenge" travel and luxury demand. Average occupancy rate rose 4.8% to 79.1%, while overall room revenues increased by almost two times on the year to S$377.9 million. However, revenue per available room (RevPAR) dropped 3% sequentially and 6.3% from November. Analysts predict moderate ARR growth in 2023, with raised inbound arrival projections, especially with China's re-opening.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
Marquee international events returned to Singapore in 2022 as MICE tourism recovered with easing Covid restrictions.
November’s lower figures came as tourist arrivals fell marginally to 816,254 for the month, breaking a nine-month growth streak.

site_title: BOJ should make 2% inflation target a long-term goal, panel says
summary: A panel of academics and business executives has urged the Bank of Japan (BOJ) to set a 2% inflation target as a long-term goal, rather than a short-term objective, to make monetary policy more flexible. The panel, comprising 100 members, also recommended interest rate hikes in line with economic fundamentals and normalizing Japan's bond market function. This comes amid rising inflation and criticism of the BOJ's ultra-loose policy, which has led to distortions in the yield curve and a dysfunctional bond market. The BOJ's Governor Haruhiko Kuroda has expressed support for maintaining the current policy, but there is growing pressure to revise it.

images.alt_text: A pedestrian walks in front of the Bank of Japan (BoJ) head office building in Tokyo on April 27, 2022. (Photo by Kazuhiro NOGI / AFP)
The announcement underscores the central bank’s resolve to prevent simmering market speculation of a near-term interest rate hike from pushing up bond yields too much.

site_title: Maybank says no financial impact from subscription to Adani's share offering
summary: Malaysia's Maybank stated it faces no financial impact from its subscription to Adani Enterprises' $2.45 billion share offering. The subscription was client-funded and fully covered by client funds, according to Maybank. The move comes despite a short-seller report criticizing Adani Group's use of offshore tax havens and high debt, which was also reported on the same day. Adani Enterprises plans to use the proceeds to fund capital expenditure and pay off debt.

images.alt_text: For this year, Maybank said it is focused on driving loans growth in key business segments across its home markets within a rising rate environment.

site_title: Eurozone bond yields jump after hot Spanish inflation data
summary: Eurozone bond yields jumped after stronger-than-expected Spanish inflation data, which rose to 5.8% year-over-year in January, exceeding analysts' expectations of 4.7%. This led to a sharp rise in bond yields, with Germany's 10-year yield increasing by 4 basis points to 2.287%, and Italy's 10-year yield jumping 10 basis points to 4.292%. The European Central Bank is set to raise interest rates by 50 basis points on Thursday, sparking anticipation for further rate hikes in the coming weeks.

images.alt_text:
(FILES) In this file photo taken on October 21, 2020 people wearing face masks walk in front of the euro sign at the former ECB headquarters in the city center of Frankfurt am Main, western Germany. - The European Central Bank is expected Thursday to unleash more stimulus to help shore up a eurozone economy devastated by the coronavirus pandemic, analysts said, in a move eagerly awaited by financial markets.

The Frankfurt institution already has a 1.35-trillion-euro ($1.6-trillion) emergency bond-buying programme in place, but ECB chief Christine Lagarde all but promised in October that extra support was on the way. (Photo by Yann Schreiber / AFP)

site_title: Tax hike for top earners did not hurt spending, while handouts boosted consumption: Singapore study
summary: A 2015 Singapore personal income tax hike for top earners did not significantly reduce spending among those affected, while redistribution programs boosted consumption among lower-income groups. Data from DBS and an international credit card company showed that high-income earners increased their credit card spending by 0.8 cents per extra tax dollar after the announcement, while low-income earners increased their spending by S$15 to S$28 per month after Budget 2015. The study found that the tax hike had a positive redistribution effect, directly raising lower-income groups' consumption, accounting for 60% of the additional taxes raised from high-income earners.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
CDC Vouchers are one possible form of additional cost-of-living support in Budget 2023, say observers.
A man shopping for groceries at the Fairprice at City Square Mall on 15 February 2022.
Burden of GST hike falls on better-off, will not change effective rate at the bottom: Wong

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong met with Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim, discussing bilateral issues. The two countries signed three agreements on digital economy, green economy, and cybersecurity. A new study found that a personal income tax hike for top earners did not reduce overall spending, while redistribution programs boosted consumption by lower-income groups.
