Meanwhile, Singapore hotel average room rates reached a 14-year high in December, and Keppel Offshore & Marine made full payment of fines to Brazilian authorities.

site_title: China 2022 lithium production jumps on strong demand, soaring prices
summary: China's lithium production surged 32.5% in 2022 to 395,000 tonnes of lithium carbonate, driven by strong demand from the new energy sector and soaring prices. Lithium hydroxide production also increased 29.5% to 246,400 tonnes. The significant increase is attributed to China's growing role in the global lithium market, with the country now the largest producer of lithium. This boost is expected to support China's transition to a low-carbon economy.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Workers are seen at a production line of copper foils used for lithium batteries, at a Tongling Nonferrous Metals Group plant in Tongling, Anhui province, China November 30, 2018. Picture taken November 30, 2018. REUTERS/Stringer  ATTENTION EDITORS - THIS IMAGE WAS PROVIDED BY A THIRD PARTY. CHINA OUT./File Photo
The agreement with a consortium including CATL could help finally unlock Bolivia’s huge potential as a supplier of lithium for batteries needed to power the global shift to electric vehicle.

site_title: Risky Manila currency move tells a big global story
summary: The Philippines peso has strengthened to around 54 per US dollar, defying conventional wisdom that publicly setting a line in the sand would lead to market volatility. The move is attributed to the global shift in interest rates, with the US Federal Reserve preparing to slow down rate hikes and possibly even cut rates this year. The peso's strength is also linked to the decline of the dollar, which has been on a downtrend since Fed vice chair Lael Brainard's speech in September, signaling a change in the Fed's approach to inflation.

images.alt_text: The peso’s drop of more than 13 per cent is one of the steepest declines among major Asian currencies.
The peso has rebounded 3 per cent to 57.21 from the record-low 59 per dollar it touched in late September.

site_title: Updates on fair employment guidelines to ensure employees are not forced to support, attend events unrelated to work
summary: Singapore's Tripartite Guidelines on Fair Employment Practices will be updated in mid-February to require employers to be sensitive to employees' diverse cultures, values, and beliefs when organizing non-work-related events. Employees should not be pressured or penalized for not participating, and support for causes should not lead to bullying or harassment. Employers are expected to provide a safe environment for employees to raise concerns and demonstrate the importance of an inclusive workplace. Failure to abide by the guidelines may result in curtailed work pass privileges.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
Section 377A has caused some LGBTQ individuals to fear their work prospects, with some worrying that they might be denied promotions, said Sengkang MP Louis Chua.
Some have expressed concern that they will be pressured into supporting diversity efforts at work following the repeal of Section 377A, said several Members of Parliament.

site_title: UK accounting watchdog tightens scrutiny of ESG in company audits
summary: The UK's Financial Reporting Council (FRC) has announced it will intensify scrutiny of ESG reporting in company audits, focusing on the use of ESG data and its link to investors. The watchdog aims to prevent 'greenwashing' and ensure auditors are making spot checks on compliance with environmental, social, and governance reporting requirements. The FRC will also introduce requirements for actuaries to consider climate and ESG-related risks in their work, and revise the UK Corporate Governance Code to recognize the growing importance of ESG reporting.

images.alt_text: Cotton fabric labelled as "100% recycled fabric". Britain's Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) is concerned that shoppers are being misled and potentially even paying a premium for products that aren’t what they seem.

site_title: Philips to cut 6,000 more jobs as product recall costs mount
summary: Royal Philips is cutting an additional 6,000 jobs, or 8% of its workforce, amid costly product recalls and supply-chain turmoil. This follows 4,000 job cuts announced last year, expected to result in 300 million euros in costs. CEO Roy Jakobs says the cuts are necessary to address rising costs and make the company more agile. The company is also increasing provisions for potential charges related to its sleep-therapy devices, which were linked to cancer and respiratory issues.

images.alt_text: Philips announced in October plans to reduce its workforce by 5 per cent, or 4,000, after a recall of respiration devices that has knocked 70 per cent off its share price since mid-2021.
“We can state that the whole product complies with safety norms. That is very encouraging news,” Philips chief executive Roy Jakobs said.

site_title: Renault agrees to lower Nissan stake in historic rebalancing
summary: Renault and Nissan agree to rebalance their alliance, lowering Renault's stake in the Japanese automaker to 15% with a French trust holding the remainder. The partners will retain a 15% cross-shareholding and collaborate on specific projects, including electric vehicles and software. Nissan will invest in Renault's Ampere business and become a strategic shareholder. The deal aims to address a power imbalance and allow Renault CEO Luca de Meo to implement his strategy. Final approval is required from the companies' boards.

site_title: Peru protests threaten production at China-owned copper mine
summary: Peru's nationwide protests threaten production at the Las Bambas copper mine, owned by China's MMG. The mine will stop production if transport disruptions persist, citing a shortage of critical supplies due to road blockages. This could impact about 30% of Peru's copper production, which is a significant source of the metal. The protests, sparked by the impeachment of former president Pedro Castillo, have also disrupted shipments and raised concerns about copper supply risks in neighboring Chile.

images.alt_text: People near a mine operated by MMG Las Bambas, in a region where locals claim mining activity has negatively affected crop yields and killed livestock, outside of Cusco, Peru October 14, 2021.
Brazil's former president and presidential candidate Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva at an election night gathering on the day of the country's presidential election run-off, in Sao Paulo, Oct 30, 2022.

site_title: Foxconn hires ex-Nidec CEO to steer its fledgling EV arm
summary: Foxconn has hired Jun Seki, former Nidec CEO, as chief strategy officer for its electric-vehicle (EV) venture, bolstering efforts to secure new revenue. The 61-year-old Seki will help drive the EV business, which is expected to contribute meaningful revenue this year and target a 5% market share by 2025. This is Foxconn's first high-profile hire for its EV arm, following a year of accelerated push into the auto industry.

site_title: Parliament to debate public housing affordability next Monday
summary: Singapore's Parliament will debate public housing affordability next Monday, focusing on debunking "spurious claims" and hearing constructive views on fulfilling home ownership aspirations. Senior Minister of State Sim Ann stated that the debate will provide details on the government's approach to public housing, differing from a motion filed by Progress Singapore Party (PSP) Non-Constituency Member of Parliament Leong Mun Wai. HDB prices rose 2.3% in the fourth quarter of 2022, with a 10.4% growth for the whole year, and transaction volumes of resale flats dipped 12.6% quarter-on-quarter.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim
While new HDB homes are priced to ensure they are affordable, some concerns over housing affordability in Singapore persist, possibly for valid reasons.

The Housing and Development Board noted that median resident employed household income has kept pace with the increase in average selling prices of built-to-order flats in both mature and non-mature estates.
The Pinnacle@Duxton on 7 April 2021.

site_title: Avatar sequel now ranks fourth all-time in global sales
summary: Avatar: The Way of Water ranks fourth globally all-time in sales with an estimated US$2.117 billion, surpassing Avengers: Endgame. The film dominated the box-office charts for 7 consecutive weeks, a feat since the original Avatar in 2009. James Cameron's film now holds three of the top four highest-grossing films, including Titanic and The Way of Water.

site_title: Making property groups disclose revalued net asset value would benefit investors
summary: Property groups in Singapore typically trade at huge discounts to book values, which don't capture upside from property development projects. The net asset value (NAV) often understates the true value of a business, which is better captured by the revalued NAV (RNAV). Mandatory disclosure of RNAV could benefit investors, as it would provide a more accurate estimate of a company's value. This could lead to more informed investment decisions, as investors could compare discounts to NAV and RNAV to determine which companies are undervalued.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee

The offer of S$0.75 per share represented a steep 43.9 per cent discount to CES’s revalued net asset value (RNAV) per share.
But the IFA, Xandar Capital, deemed the offer to be “fair and reasonable” – and recommended shareholders accept it.
Celine Tang, managing director of listed developer SingHaiyi Group

site_title: Bitcoin barrels towards historic January as crypto market jumps by US$280 billion
summary: Bitcoin is on track for its best January since 2013, with a 40% gain since the start of the year, surpassing only two previous instances of first-month growth in its infancy. This surge is attributed to bets that monetary tightening and the crypto sector crisis are easing, with central banks potentially slowing interest rate hikes and cutting borrowing costs later this year. The US$280 billion January increase in digital assets overall has seen smaller coins like Solana, Axie Infinity, and Decentraland double in value, contributing to the market's revival in risk appetite.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Bitcoin are seen in this illustration picture taken September 27, 2017.  REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/File Photo
The company is among a slew of publicly traded crypto-mining businesses struggling to stay afloat after a plunge in Bitcoin’s price plus soaring energy costs.

site_title: Serangoon Road commercial building for sale at S$20m
summary: A commercial building on 466 Serangoon Road in Singapore is for sale with an indicative guide price of S$20 million, or S$2,250 per square foot. The 4-storey building, spanning 2,236 sq ft, is 250m from Farrer Park MRT station and within a 10-minute drive to the city centre. Potential uses include F&B, co-living, and clinics, subject to approval. The sale is part of a growing interest in the area, with shophouse sales in District 8 increasing by 40% in 2022.

images.alt_text: 466 Serangoon Road building which sits on a land plot spanning about 2,236 square feet (sq ft) has been put up for sale with an indicative guide price of S$20 million.
GSM Building at 141 Middle Road.
The shophouses in District 8 can be potentially redeveloped into a six storey commercial building with a gross floor area of 27,125 square foot, PropNex said.
City Developments Limited (CDL) and MCL Land has launched its 407-unit condominium Piccadilly Grand, with previews starting Saturday (Apr 23) and sales booking scheduled for 2 weeks later on May 7.

site_title: Brokers’ take: CGS-CIMB downgrades Starhill Global Reit to ‘hold’ on strong price performance
summary: CGS-CIMB analysts downgraded Starhill Global Reit to 'hold' from 'add' due to strong unit price performance, which is expected to cap upside. The Reit's unit price grew 16% over the past three months, with a target price raised to S$0.62 from S$0.58. Despite this, CGS-CIMB recommends accumulating the Reit in case of price weakness. The downgrade reflects the analysts' belief that the Reit's backfilling and asset enhancement initiatives are paying off.

images.alt_text: Hospitality S-Reits such as CapitaLand Ascott Trust are expected to ride on the tailwinds of the return of Chinese tourists.
The property – a three-storey retail and office building – is located in the Ebisu district in the Shibuya ward, and has a net lettable area of 8,087 square feet.

Starhill Global Reit's manager says that the increase in its NPI for the first half of FY22/23 is mainly due to the completion of asset enhancement works at The Starhill, lower rental assistance and higher rental contribution from Singapore office, partially offset by lower rental contribution from its retail Wisma Atria property and net movement in foreign currencies.

site_title: Hong Kong’s Exchange Fund records HK$202.4 billion 2022 investment loss, outlook uncertain
summary: Hong Kong's Exchange Fund reported a record investment loss of HK$202.4 billion (S$33.9 billion) in 2022, the worst ever on record. The fund's investment income decreased to HK$76.4 billion in the fourth quarter, down from HK$48.2 billion in 2021. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority's chief executive, Eddie Yue, attributed the losses to significant uncertainties and volatile asset prices, with monetary policies of major central banks dominating the investment outlook. Despite this, Yue noted that the mainland economy may rebound strongly this year due to relaxed Covid measures and economic stimulus.

site_title: UOL, Pan Pacific Hotels Group partner ComLink to support children living in rental housing
summary: UOL Group and Pan Pacific Hotels Group (PPHG) launched the UOL-PPHG Community Uplift Programme, supporting children living in rental housing through learning opportunities and enrichment activities. The programme, in collaboration with Community Link, aims to promote stability, self-reliance, and social mobility. Over the next three years, UOL will contribute S$150,000 and encourage retail tenants to provide activities for the children. The programme's goal is to improve academic outcomes and family bonding, with plans to roll out more activities and promote learning outside the classroom.

images.alt_text: UOB chief executive officer Wee Ee Cheong (centre) with winning bidders Kelvin Lim (second from left) and Neo Kah Kiat (second from right), as well as UOB head of group commercial banking Eric Lian (extreme left) and head of group wholesale banking and markets Frederick Chin at the Lunar New Year fundraising gala dinner.
The festive bags, or fu dais, are packed by more than 1,300 volunteers over two days.

site_title: China’s factory activity likely contracted more slowly in January: poll
summary: China's factory activity likely contracted more slowly in January than in December, with production hindered by ongoing worker illnesses after the government lifted its "zero-Covid" regime. The official manufacturing PMI improved to 49.8, reversing a downward trend, but still fell short of breaking into expansion territory. The economy continues to face external headwinds, with shrinking export orders and a global recession looming. China's cabinet pledged to boost consumption to drive recovery, with consumption increasing 12.2% during the Chinese New Year holiday.

images.alt_text: Chinese policymakers have sought to boost infrastructure spending to shore up the Covid-ravaged economy.

site_title: A subsidy war without winners
summary: The US and EU are embroiled in a "subsidy war" over green investments, with the US passing the Inflation Reduction Act (IRA) offering $369 billion in subsidies for green technologies. In response, the EU's Ursula von der Leyen promised to loosen state aid rules, sparking concerns about inefficiency and retaliation. While green subsidies aim to address climate change, a subsidy war could lead to economic harm, including higher costs, reduced global emission reductions, and fiscal waste. Policymakers should instead work together to encourage green investments, prioritizing cooperation over competition.

images.alt_text: Sources say that the US is likely to want to focus only on extraction and processing critical minerals used in the vehicles, while the EU wants any arrangement to also include recycled materials.

A solar panel installation at a house in Madrid, Spain, on May 24, 2022. EU countries must use the green energy transition as an opportunity to set a fair minimum wage that provides a decent standard of living.
President Joe Biden discusses American Rescue Plan investments in regional and community economic strategies at the White House in Washington on Sept 2, 2022.

site_title: Investment trends for 2023
summary: Investors can position themselves for 2023 by focusing on sectors expected to recover, such as travel, airlines, and hospitality, following China's easing of zero-Covid measures. Despite cyclical challenges, the US Federal Reserve's policy tightening cycle is nearing its end, with inflation expected to peak and rates slowing. Services inflation will remain sticky, but the Fed may keep policy on hold. Asia is also driving dollar asset diversification, and retail investors are expected to drive growth in the ETF market.

images.alt_text: In early equity trade, Hong Kong, Shanghai, Tokyo, Sydney, Singapore, Wellington, Manila and Jakarta were all on the rise, though Seoul dipped on Wednesday.

site_title: Email layoffs show what employers really think of their workers
summary: Google's parent company, Alphabet, announced a 6% workforce reduction of 12,000 jobs, mostly via email to affected employees. This trend of mass layoffs via email is becoming increasingly common in tech and digital media companies, with many arguing that it's a way to avoid personal human contact and potential criticism from employees. Critics, including the author, believe that treating employees as disposable units can damage a company's reputation and lead to increased unionization, as employees feel undervalued and mistreated.

images.alt_text: Google Headquarters in Manhattan on Tuesday, Jan. 24, 2023. GoogleÕs parent company, Alphabet, said last week it planned to cut 12,000 jobs, or about 6 percent of its total staff. (John Taggart/The New York Times)

site_title: Gold steady, spotlight on Fed rate-hike meeting outcome
summary: Gold prices remained steady at $1,928.32 per ounce, awaiting the US Federal Reserve's rate-hike verdict due this week. Investors expect the Fed to scale back rate hikes to 25 basis points from 50 bps announced in December, which could benefit gold prices. Meanwhile, physical gold dealers in India offered discounts to lure customers, while inflation data showed US consumer spending fell in December and inflation continued to subside.

images.alt_text: Lower interest rates tend to be beneficial for bullion, decreasing the opportunity cost of holding the non-yielding asset.

site_title: ‘Keep no traces’: Guidebook to secret billions exposed in ruling
summary: A Quebec Superior Court judge has exposed a guidebook to secret billions hidden by rich French families through Canadian trusts. The trusts, managed by asset managers and lawyers, were used to avoid paying France's wealth tax for years. The group used tactics such as destroying computers, referring to clients with acronyms or nicknames, and sending faxes to avoid digital fingerprints. The judge found that the system ensured secrecy, but ultimately led to the group being caught by Canadian courts in 2021. The ruling highlights the use of Canadian trusts to evade taxes and raises questions about whether Canada is a tax haven.

images.alt_text: The company is among a slew of publicly traded crypto-mining businesses struggling to stay afloat after a plunge in Bitcoin’s price plus soaring energy costs.

site_title: Singapore, Malaysia discuss how to progress on ‘outstanding bilateral issues’ during Anwar’s visit
summary: Singapore and Malaysia discussed "outstanding bilateral issues" during Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim's first official visit, resulting in the signing of three agreements on digital economy, green economy, and cybersecurity cooperation. The meeting was described as "fruitful" by Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, with both leaders vowing to work together to enhance relations and address contentious issues.

images.alt_text: Sharon See

ST20230130-202306525416-Lim Yaohui-Chin Soo Fang-sfanwar30/

Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim attending delegation meeting at Istana on Jan 30, 2023. 

Mr Anwar Ibrahim, Prime Minister of Malaysia, will be in Singapore for an official visit on Jan 30, 2023. Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim will be calling on President Halimah Yacob and meet with Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong at the Istana, following which they will witness a MOU signing ceremony.

(ST PHOTO: LIM YAOHUI)

site_title: UK business optimism at six-month high despite recession risk
summary: UK business confidence reached a six-month high in January, boosted by hopes of a brighter economic outlook and cooling price pressures. Despite forecasts warning of a recession in the first half of 2023, optimism is fueled by evidence that inflation has peaked. A separate survey showed private-sector activity declined due to strikes, staff shortages, and the cost-of-living crisis. Lloyds Banking Group's business barometer rose five points to 22%, with firms' expectations for prices moderating. However, high energy bills remain a concern for businesses.

images.alt_text: The central bank has expected the UK to be in recession already, but the economy has proved resilient so far, growing slightly in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Boeing’s 747, the original jumbo jet, prepares for final send-off
summary: The Boeing 747, the world's first twin-aisle wide body jetliner, is set to make its final commercial delivery to Atlas Air on January 31, marking the end of its nearly 53-year reign as the "Queen of the Skies". Designed in the late 1960s to meet demand for mass travel, the 747 revolutionized air travel with its luxurious upper deck and transformed the industry with its massive capacity. Although more efficient twinjet planes have since replaced it, the 747's legacy continues, and its production plant in Everett, Washington, may be under-used in the future.

images.alt_text: The design could trim fuel consumption and emissions by around 30 per cent over Boeing’s 737 Max and Airbus’s A320neo family.

site_title: Adani Group’s fight with US short-seller may dominate budget session
summary: Opposition lawmakers in India plan to raise the Adani Group's dispute with a US short-seller during the upcoming budget session, highlighting ties between the conglomerate's CEO, Gautam Adani, and Prime Minister Narendra Modi. The Adani Group has portrayed the allegations as an attack on India, while Hindenburg Research claims the conglomerate failed to answer its questions and instead stoked a nationalist narrative. The issue may overshadow parliament's budget session, which is set to unveil the government's last full-year budget before Modi seeks a third term in office.

images.alt_text: Adani Group’s response comes as its flagship company, Adani Enterprises, pushes ahead with a US$2.5 billion share sale.

site_title: How investors can counter biodiversity loss
summary: Investors can help counter biodiversity loss by increasing financing and disclosure. Funding biodiversity is an investment, not a cost, maintaining critical ecosystem services and yielding financial returns. The Global Biodiversity Framework calls for companies and financial institutions to disclose their biodiversity risks and impacts, driving greater transparency and action. Investors can support conservation efforts by leveraging private finance, promoting blended finance, and investing in impact funds. A $200 billion annual target for conservation is set, with a 30x30 target to protect 30% of nature by 2030, which has been found to have a five-to-one financial benefit.

images.alt_text: Countries that signed the landmark Kunming-Montreal Global Biodiversity Framework at the COP15 summit will have to submit their national biodiversity plans in 2024.

site_title: Historic crash for memory chips threatens to wipe out earnings
summary: The global memory chip industry is experiencing a historic downturn, with a US$160 billion industry suffering its worst rout ever due to a combination of pandemic sales surge, inflation, and rising interest rates. Companies such as Samsung, SK Hynix, and Micron are struggling with inventory gluts, reduced demand, and plummeting prices, leading to significant losses and potential mergers. The industry's ability to recover will depend on how quickly companies scale back production and adapt to the changing market, with some analysts predicting a recovery in the second half of the year.

images.alt_text: The White House continued to press allies to pass restrictions limiting the sales of semiconductor manufacturing equipment by firms such as Dutch company ASML or Tokyo Electron in Japan.
Getting the Netherlands and Japan to impose tighter export controls on China would be a major diplomatic win for President Joe Biden’s administration.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed as traders await rate decisions
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Monday as traders awaited rate decisions from the Federal Reserve, European Central Bank, and Bank of England. Despite a strong performance on Wall Street, Shanghai rallied, while Tokyo, Taipei, Jakarta, and Wellington also rose. However, Hong Kong, Sydney, Seoul, Singapore, and Manila slipped. The mixed sentiment was partly due to concerns about a potential recession and mixed earnings season, with US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen expressing caution about the economic outlook.

images.alt_text: China is keen to attract foreign capital to its US$10 trillion market, but also wary of its impact.

site_title: Lincotrade secures S$35 million asset enhancement contract for integrated development
summary: Lincotrade & Associates Holdings has secured a S$35 million asset enhancement initiative contract for an integrated development in Singapore, its largest single contract to date. The project includes interior fit-out and refurbishment works expected to be completed by June 2024. The contract is not expected to impact earnings per share and net tangible assets per share for the current financial year. The company's order book is strengthened to about S$78 million for the next two years, with another large showflat project expected to be completed in the current financial year.

images.alt_text: Lincotrade & Associates managing director Jimmy Tan Jit Meng (left), and executive director, Jackie Soh are co-founders of the company.

site_title: Brokers’ take: DBS downgrades Grab to ‘fully valued’ on fintech losses
summary: DBS Group Research has downgraded its call on Grab to "fully valued" from "hold" due to expected significant losses in the financial services segment. Analyst Sachin Mittal predicts losses will narrow gradually, with the company aiming to break even in the second half of 2024. Despite this, DBS maintains a target price of US$2.93, based on a 12% adjusted Ebitda margin in FY2027. Grab's mobility and delivery segments are expected to deliver higher Ebitda, but with lower margins due to the instant delivery nature of their businesses.

images.alt_text: The logo of Grab at their main office in Midview City at Sin Ming Lane on 23 June 2017.
The growth of South-east Asia's food delivery gross merchandise value has been muted in 2022 as profitability becomes front of mind.
An illustration on the Grab website shows that a S$1,500 cash advance, payable over one year, would be charged a S$120 admin fee

site_title: Boris Johnson: Putin threatened to lob missile at me
summary: Former UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson claims that Russian President Vladimir Putin threatened to personally target him with a missile attack just before ordering Russian forces into Ukraine on February 24, according to a new BBC documentary. Johnson had been trying to deter a Russian attack and warned Putin that any invasion would mean "more Nato, not less Nato" on Russia's borders. Johnson also recalled a phone call where Putin seemed to be "playing along" with his attempts to negotiate, despite the apparent threat.

images.alt_text: Zelenskiy calls on IOC President Thomas Bach to visit the war-torn city of Bakhmut in eastern Ukraine.
BP is aiming to rapidly grow the company’s renewables business and slash oil and gas output by 2030.

site_title: Chinese search giant Baidu to launch ChatGPT-style bot
summary: Chinese search giant Baidu plans to launch a ChatGPT-style AI chatbot service in March, embedding it into its main search services. The tool, built on Baidu's Ernie system, will provide conversation-style search results. The company's shares rose 5.8% after the report, marking its largest intraday gain in almost four weeks. Baidu aims to transition from online marketing to deeper technology, following in the footsteps of OpenAI's ChatGPT, which has attracted billions of dollars in investment and sparked debate about AI's role in various industries.

images.alt_text: Baidu's Apollo programme, which allows customers to hail and ride a fully autonomous robotaxi, has racked up more than 1.4 million public journeys, and is expanding a network that already covers dozens of square miles across 10 key cities that also include Wuhan and Chongqing.

site_title: Indian industry turns to biomass as capital bans coal in pollution fight
summary: India's capital, New Delhi, has enforced a ban on coal burning from this month, forcing industries to shift to biomass. About half of the 1,695 units in a cluster of small industries around the city have adopted biomass, up from fewer than 15% in 2020. The shift is aimed at reducing pollution. Biomass use can be identified by the color of steam and the smell in the air. This move is part of India's efforts to combat pollution and move towards a cleaner energy source.

images.alt_text: India projects US$10 trillion to US$15 trillion in investment is needed to achieve net-zero carbon emissions by 2070

A geothermal power plant in the Philippines. As part of the research initiative, CNCS researchers will work with other universities, government agencies and corporations to establish monitoring plots at various natural habitats across South-east Asia.

site_title: Investors call for more tools to hedge China market risks
summary: Investors are calling for more tools to hedge China market risks, citing limited futures and securities lending options. China's $10 trillion market is keen to attract foreign capital but is wary of its impact, with officials monitoring fast money that can create large swings. Expanding hedging tools, including securities lending, could attract more active managers and add liquidity to the market, according to experts. The MSCI has listed four conditions to deepen inclusion of Chinese shares, with some met, but progress is still uncertain, relying on regulators in Beijing.

images.alt_text: Chinese policymakers have sought to boost infrastructure spending to shore up the Covid-ravaged economy.

site_title: Condo resale volumes drop 14% in December, prices continue to rise: SRX, 99.co
summary: Condo resale volumes in Singapore dropped 14% in December to 661 units, the third consecutive month of decline. Prices rose 0.8% for the month, while year-on-year, resale prices increased 9.7%. A mismatch in price expectations between buyers and sellers, as well as cooling measures, are cited as factors contributing to the decline. Analysts predict condo resale volumes will decline further in 2023 due to rising interest rates and tighter budgets.

images.alt_text: Private properties along Paterson Road
In the HDB rental market, prices are up 1.6 per cent from October 2022 and 27.8 per cent on a year-on-year basis.
Resale prices continue to trend upwards in November, show flash figures from SRX and 99.co.
Resale volumes rise for the second straight month, advancing 4.8 per cent.
HDB rents for October increased by 1.8 per cent from the previous month, with mature and non-mature estate rents rising by 1.6 per cent and 2.1 per cent respectively.

site_title: French PM says pension age hike ‘non-negotiable’ as strikes loom
summary: French Prime Minister says raising the retirement age to 64 is 'non-negotiable' amid mass protests against the reform, which aims to ensure the future financing of France's pensions system. The plan, pushed by President Emmanuel Macron, has sparked widespread strikes, with over a million people participating in protests on January 19. The government has shown flexibility on some measures, but the prime minister's stance on the pension age hike suggests no major concessions are likely.

images.alt_text: Hundreds of thousands took part in rallies across the country to protest against government plans to raise the retirement age by two years to 64.
In France, more than a million people took to the streets on Thursday (Jan 19) to protest President Emmanuel Macron's pension-reform plan.

site_title: Oil climbs after drone attack in Iran, China’s pledge to promote consumption
summary: Oil prices rose 0.6% to $87.20 a barrel, driven by tensions in the Middle East following a drone attack in Iran and China's pledge to promote consumption, which could support fuel demand. Brent crude futures rose 54 cents, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose 54 cents. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec+) is unlikely to adjust its oil output policy when meeting virtually on February 1. China's cabinet also announced plans to boost imports and promote a consumption recovery, driven by the country's major driver of the economy.

images.alt_text: Profit taking ahead of the weekend may  have driven prices lower.

site_title: China resumes issuing visas for Japanese citizens
summary: China has resumed issuing visas to Japanese citizens, ending a retaliatory step against Japan's COVID-19 testing requirements for travelers from mainland China. The move follows China's suspension of visa issuance to Japanese nationals from January 10. Japan still requires travelers from the mainland to test before and upon arrival, with proof of negative test results needed. This decision aims to address the spread of infections in China, with Beijing calling Tokyo's move "discriminatory."

images.alt_text: The White House continued to press allies to pass restrictions limiting the sales of semiconductor manufacturing equipment by firms such as Dutch company ASML or Tokyo Electron in Japan.

site_title: Profit warnings issued by UK firms surge 50% on higher costs: EY
summary: UK-listed companies issued 305 profit warnings in 2022, a 50% increase from the previous year, due to higher costs. Retailers and travel and leisure sectors were most affected. The number of profit warnings was similar to that during the 2008 global financial crisis. Credit conditions are expected to tighten further, with the Bank of England potentially raising interest rates to tame inflation.

images.alt_text: The City of London financial district can be seen as people walk along the south side of the River Thames, amid the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) outbreak in London, Britain, March 19, 2021. REUTERS/Henry Nicholls/File Photo

site_title: Top Republican to meet Biden on avoiding US debt default
summary: US Republican Kevin McCarthy is set to meet with President Joe Biden on Wednesday to discuss avoiding a US debt default, with McCarthy warning that Biden must consider spending cuts in exchange for raising the borrowing limit. McCarthy has threatened to block the usual increase in the national debt limit, which could trigger a "global financial crisis." The meeting comes as the Treasury Department has taken "extraordinary measures" to temporarily reduce outstanding debt and avoid a default, which could occur as early as June.

images.alt_text: The US Treasury is now using extraordinary measures to pay the country's bills and service its debt, as in previous years.
“So the Senate is going to have to recognise the fact that we’re not going to budge until we see meaningful reform with respect to spending.” House Oversight Committee chairman James Comer said.
US consumers expect inflation to rise 2.9% over the next five to 10 years.

site_title: Toyota retains status as world’s top-selling automaker in 2022
summary: Toyota retained its title as the world's top-selling automaker for a third consecutive year in 2022, with 10.5 million vehicles sold globally. Despite a 0.1% decrease in global sales, Toyota's overseas sales of 8.6 million helped offset a 9.6% drop in domestic sales. This marks Toyota's third straight year as the top-selling automaker, while Volkswagen Group reported its lowest sales in over a decade due to Covid-19 lockdowns and the war in Ukraine.

site_title: Sabana Reit H2 DPU falls 7% to S$0.0146 on higher interest expenses
summary: Sabana Industrial Reit reported a 7% decline in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.46 Singapore cents for the half-year ended Dec 31, 2022, due to higher interest expenses. The Reit's portfolio valuation increased 2.3% to S$885.7 million, driven by higher gross revenue of 16.9% to S$50.1 million.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Suntec Reit reported 24 per cent year-on-year growth in net property income, which in turn saw distributable income grow 3.4 per cent on a full year basis.
Volare says it is launching the partial offer to diversify its business away from fossil fuels and build up its real estate portfolio.
Sabana I

151 Lorong Chuan, a 6-storey industrial building, is the largest property of Sabana Industrial REIT by gross floor area.

site_title: CapitaLand Ascott Trust H2 DPS rises 47% to S$0.0333; managers eye greater traction from China reopening
summary: CapitaLand Ascott Trust reported a 47% increase in distribution per stapled security (DPS) to S$0.0333 for the half year ended Dec 31, 2022, driven by higher portfolio revenue per available unit growth and accretive acquisitions. Revenue rose 69% to S$353.8 million, and total distributable income increased 54% to S$113.2 million. The trust expects to benefit from China's reopening and rising travel demand, with forward bookings for its properties showing positive signs.

images.alt_text: Net proceeds arising from the issue of the notes will be used for refinancing the existing borrowings of CapitaLand Ascott Reit and its subsidiaries.
While CapitaLand Investment navigates choppy waters, there is room for the group to surprise shareholders by distributing units of listed trusts that it owns.

site_title: UK gives homebuilders six weeks to pledge payment for cladding
summary: The UK government has given homebuilders six weeks to sign a contract committing them to pay for upgrades of cladding in homes and apartment blocks deemed a fire risk following the Grenfell Tower fire in 2017. Hundreds of thousands of people live in such buildings, with leaseholders previously unable to sell their homes due to the costs of upgrades. Failure to sign the contract may result in builders being barred from future construction projects, according to Cabinet Minister Michael Gove.

site_title: Uniqlo brings skateboarding streetwear vibe to T-shirt sub-brand
summary: Uniqlo is expanding its streetwear presence with its T-shirt sub-brand UT, led by creative director Kosuke Kawamura. Kawamura, who previously collaborated with Adidas and Katsuhiro Otomo, has introduced bold graphics and colours to the brand. UT has previously featured collaborations with artists like KAWS and Demon Slayer creators, but this marks a shift towards in-house designs. Kawamura aims to establish UT as a solid brand and sell well, rather than relying on licensing.

site_title: Top bankers in Asia see pay cuts of 50% after drought in deals
summary: Top bankers in Asia, excluding Japan, are facing pay cuts of 40-50% due to a decline in deals, according to sources. Managing directors at Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley, and Bank of America have seen their total compensation drop by 40-50%, with some senior MDs seeing payouts of $800,000-$1.5 million. Non-performers are seeing reductions of 60-70%, with some being left out of the bonus pool. The cuts are part of a broader trend to reduce headcount and costs at global investment banks, which have been hit by a regulatory crackdown in China and a decline in investment-banking revenue.

images.alt_text: Even in Japan, whose central bank wants stronger wage gains to take hold, Governor Haruhiko Kuroda is practising restraint.

site_title: Zilingo board confirms winding up; appoints provisional liquidators
summary: Singapore-based fashion startup Zilingo's board confirmed the company's liquidation, appointing provisional liquidators Aaron Loh Cheng Lee and Ee Meng Yen Angela from EY Corporate Advisors. The move comes after the company cited its inability to continue business due to liabilities. Zilingo, which received funding from prominent venture capitalists, faced a crisis following alleged financial irregularities and the dismissal of its co-founder and CEO, Ankiti Bose in May 2022. Meetings with creditors will take place within a month.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

site_title: Keppel says O&M unit has fully paid its fines to Brazilian authorities
summary: Keppel O&M, a unit of Keppel Corporation, has fully paid its fines and damages worth 343.6 million reais (S$88.2 million) to Brazilian authorities under a leniency agreement. This follows confirmation from Singapore's Attorney-General's Chambers and the Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau that Keppel O&M may seek crediting of up to US$52.8 million in fines payable to the Brazilian authorities. The company is working towards a merger with Sembcorp Marine, which received approval in-principle from the Singapore Exchange Securities Trading (SGX-ST) for the deal, pending further conditions.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
Terms of the proposed deal to merge Sembmarine and Keppel O&M were revised in October.
Six former senior management staff of Keppel Corporation’s Offshore & Marine unit are being issued stern warnings for bribery-related offences.

site_title: Manpower moves to watch in Budget 2023
summary: Singapore's Budget 2023 may include expansions to the Progressive Wage Model to cover skilled non-degree holders and low to middle-income sectors, with economist Kelvin Seah suggesting targeted support for these groups to mitigate stagnating incomes. The budget is also expected to focus on supporting local workers, with increased training support for employers and improvements to the Central Provident Fund framework. Additionally, the Jobs Growth Incentive may be extended, and Workfare Income Supplement and Silver Support Scheme payouts could be increased due to high inflation.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
Any unemployment support measures will likely be for vulnerable workers, such as those who are older, have lower-income, or are less educated, one economist told The Business Times.
The newly-launched Progressive Wage Mark scheme aims to encourage consumers to support lower-wage workers by purchasing from accredited firms.

site_title: Malaysian PM Anwar in Singapore for official visit on Jan 30
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim will visit Singapore on January 30 for an official visit, marking his first visit since taking office in November. During the visit, he will attend a welcome ceremony, meet with Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, and witness the signing of three agreements on cooperation in the digital economy, green economy, and personal data protection. The visit aims to strengthen bilateral relations and explore opportunities for investments and partnerships between the two countries.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim will be visiting Singapore by end-January, this will be his first visit to the Republic since he took office in November last year.
Singapore Foreign Minister Vivian Balakrishnan (right) calling on Malaysian PM Anwar Ibrahim on Jan 17, 2023.

site_title: Bed Bath & Beyond customers confront empty shelves ahead of looming bankruptcy
summary: Bed Bath & Beyond is on the verge of bankruptcy, with empty shelves and dated merchandise at its US locations. The company has warned it can't pay lenders and stalled efforts to find a buyer may lead to liquidation, potentially benefiting competitors like Target and Walmart. If Bed Bath & Beyond closes, Target could gain 20% of its business, adding $1.11 billion in sales and 28 cents a share in earnings. The chain's decline is a stark contrast to its heyday, when it was a staple of back-to-school shopping lists and wedding registries.

images.alt_text: The notice is the latest sign that one of the largest sellers of home goods in the US is likely to seek bankruptcy protection in short order after years of falling revenue.

site_title: CDL Hospitality Trusts’ H2 DPS up 17.3% to S$0.0359 on continued global travel recovery
summary: CDL Hospitality Trusts reported a 17.3% increase in its half-year distribution per stapled security (DPS) to S$0.0359, driven by a 48.1% rise in net property income to S$72.8 million. The trust attributed the growth to continued global travel recovery, with positive momentum in rate growth across its portfolio markets. Gross revenue also rose 42.9% to S$130.7 million.

images.alt_text: W Singapore under CDL Hospitality Trusts. The stapled group's distribution per stapled security saw positive momentum in rate growth across all the portfolio markets.
Hospitality S-Reits such as CapitaLand Ascott Trust are expected to ride on the tailwinds of the return of Chinese tourists.
CDL Hospitality Trusts, whose portfolio includes W Singapore at Sentosa Cove, was the top performing S-Reit in 2022.

site_title: Ukraine war to accelerate shift to clean energy: BP
summary: The Russia-Ukraine war is expected to accelerate the shift to clean energy as countries boost domestic energy supplies, according to BP's 2023 Energy Outlook. Global energy demand is forecast to peak between the late 2020s and 2035, with oil demand declining rapidly after 2030. BP expects primary energy consumption in 2035 to be 2% lower than last year's outlook, with half due to energy efficiency gains and half due to lower economic activity. The company aims to rapidly grow its renewables business and slash oil and gas output by 2030.

images.alt_text: Adjusted 2022 earnings more than doubled to US$36.5 billion from a year earlier, while oil and natural gas output from the company’s US fields climbed almost 4 per cent to the equivalent of 1.181 million barrels a day.
Chevron says it would triple its spending on share repurchases to US$75 billion over five years at current guidance.

site_title: With mortgage rates staying high in 2023, should you pay down your home loan?
summary: Singapore homeowners considering prepaying their mortgages due to high interest rates should weigh the opportunity costs. Three scenarios to consider: using other people's money (leverage), CPF savings, or it might be harder to increase the loan later. Prepaying with cash may not be the best use of funds, especially if interest rates drop in the future. Using CPF to prepay could also limit future growth and increase the risk of having to pay accrued interest when selling the property. Homeowners should consider their individual financial situations and goals before making a decision.

images.alt_text: The pace of property price increases in the last quarter has moderated amid a drop in sales volume, says Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat.

MAS expects Singapore companies, households and banks to remain resilient in the face of potential global macro-financial shocks next year, but flagged pockets of risks among highly leveraged households and smaller businesses.
DBS continues to have a home loan specially for home owners of public housing flats at 2.6 per cent a year – similar to the current HDB concessionary interest rate.

Minister for National Development Desmond Lee said in parliament that the number of HDB resale flat buyers who also own private residential properties doubled in 2021 and the first three quarters of 2022, as compared to 2019 and 2020.

site_title: Hyphens Pharma to expand footprint in South-east Asia: CEO
summary: Hyphens Pharma, a Singapore-based specialty pharmaceutical and consumer healthcare company, plans to expand its presence in South-east Asia beyond its current five markets. Chairman and CEO Lim See Wah aims to set up offices in countries without a presence to tap into the region's growing demand. The company's revenue jumped 47% to S$42.8 million in the third quarter, driven by growth in all business segments. Hyphens Pharma has secured agreements for exclusive rights to develop and sell new products, including Winlevi for acne treatment, and is seeking acquisition opportunities to fuel growth.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan
FILE PHOTO: The logo for AstraZeneca is seen outside its North America headquarters in Wilmington, Delaware, U.S., March 22, 2021.  REUTERS/Rachel Wisniewski/File Photo
Pfizer has also separately agreed over the past year to supply millions of doses of its Covid-19 oral treatment drug Paxlovid to low- and middle-income countries.

site_title: India’s Adani hits back at Hindenburg, insists made full disclosure
summary: Adani Group has responded to a Hindenburg Research report that sparked a $48 billion rout in its stocks, denying claims of debt levels and tax haven use. The conglomerate, led by billionaire Gautam Adani, said it complies with Indian laws and made necessary regulatory disclosures. Adani Group's flagship company, Adani Enterprises, is pushing ahead with a $2.5 billion share sale, overshadowed by the Hindenburg report, which flagged concerns about debt and valuations. The group has accused Hindenburg of making "misleading claims" without evidence and seeking to book gains at the cost of investors.

images.alt_text: While Gautam Adaninet's net worth took a beating in the days after Hindenburg’s report emerged, he was still comfortably in the top 10 in the Bloomberg Billionaires Index as at late January.

site_title: Thaksin’s daughter confident of landslide Thailand election win for her party
summary: Thailand's Pheu Thai opposition party, led by 36-year-old Paetongtarn Shinawatra, is confident of a landslide victory in the upcoming general election, citing better policies to ease the burden of voters. Paetongtarn, daughter of fugitive former premier Thaksin Shinawatra, has been leading the party's outreach program and promises to raise minimum wages by 70%, increase crop prices, and slash energy costs. The party is seen as the most popular choice for prime minister, with opinion polls showing it is likely to win the most seats.

images.alt_text: Prawit Wongsuwon, an adept political dealmaker in Thailand’s conservative establishment and current deputy prime minister, will likely go against the Pheu Thai Party’s Paetongtarn Shinawatra, the daughter of self-exiled former premier, Thaksin Shinawatra, who has declared her readiness for the top job.
The Thai currency is forecast to average 32.50 to a US dollar this year, stronger than the 36.68 the ministry predicted in October.
FILE PHOTO: Thailand's central bank is seen at the Bank of Thailand in Bangkok, Thailand April 26, 2016. REUTERS/Jorge Silva/File Photo

site_title: Will Volare supplant Quarz as Sabana Reit’s key minority unitholder after its partial offer?
summary: Sabana Reit, a Singaporean industrial real estate investment trust, has received a partial offer from Volare Group for 10% of its units at S$0.465 per unit, a 9.4% premium to its closing price. The offer could have implications for the trust's future direction and whether it is sold or merged with ESR-Logos Reit. Unitholders who voted against the merger in 2020 may be pleased with the offer, which has delivered a 49.2% total return since then, outperforming the iEdge S-Reit Index.

images.alt_text: Ben Paul
Volare says it is launching the partial offer to diversify its business away from fossil fuels and build up its real estate portfolio.

site_title: Thai bourse expects busy year with more big listings
summary: The Stock Exchange of Thailand (SET) is expected to have a busy year in 2023, following a successful 2022 with 42 IPOs raising 127.8 billion baht (S$5.1 billion). The SET was the region's top issuer of IPOs in 2022 and aims to match the numbers in 2022. Major listings are expected, including SCG Chemicals, a subsidiary of Siam Cement Group, which could raise 98.8 billion baht. Provincial business groups are also expected to go public, with the SET targeting these companies to attract more listings.

images.alt_text: Paetongtarn Shinawatra, the 36-year-old daughter of fugitive former premier Thaksin Shinawatra, is widely seen as the Pheu Thai opposition party’s top potential candidate to become Thailand's next prime minister.
Thailand’s economic recovery has lagged that of other South-east Asian nations, with the crucial tourism sector just starting to pick up last year with 11.15 million foreign arrivals.
FILE PHOTO: Thailand's central bank is seen at the Bank of Thailand in Bangkok, Thailand April 26, 2016. REUTERS/Jorge Silva/File Photo

site_title: With a fresh rate hike likely this week, US Federal Reserve may disappoint the bulls again
summary: The US Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates by 25 basis points on February 1, potentially disappointing stock bulls who are betting on a reprieve from rate hikes. Despite inflation moderating, the Fed may not stop raising rates due to ongoing economic concerns, including a darkening economic picture and potential layoffs. The Fed chairman, Jerome Powell, may hint at slowing down rate hikes, but his words could still have a sobering effect on markets if he indicates that hikes must stop due to an oncoming recession.

images.alt_text: Even in Japan, whose central bank wants stronger wage gains to take hold, Governor Haruhiko Kuroda is practising restraint.
The Federal Reserve's second-in-command, Lael Brainard, is viewed as someone who could successfully implement the Inflation Reduction Act and the semiconductor funding in the Chips and Science Act.
Economic data since the US central bank’s last meeting in December have showed inflation continuing to wane, with consumer and producer prices, profits, and wages all growing more slowly.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Monday; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.2% on Monday, driven by gains in US and European markets. Gainers outnumbered losers 94 to 39, with Singtel, CapitaLand Ascott Trust, and Keppel Reit among the top traded counters. Local banks UOB and OCBC saw gains, while DBS declined. The move follows similar gains in the US and European markets, where the Dow Jones, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite rose on Friday.

images.alt_text: Singapore Exchange (SGX).

site_title: Bet you didn’t know you needed a sleep coach
summary: The sleep-tech industry is booming, with device makers and startups offering high-end gadgets and personalized coaching to improve sleep quality. Devices such as Oura's ring, Garmin's watches, and Eight Sleep's smart mattress track sleep patterns and provide scores, but the accuracy of these devices is disputed. Sleep coaches and apps offer generic recommendations, and some companies, like Eight Sleep, use gimmicky marketing tactics to promote their products. Despite the trend, experts warn that the key to improving sleep lies in individualized, actionable advice, rather than relying solely on data and scores.

images.alt_text: Each device defines “stress” differently, although many use heart rate variability as an indicator. However, this capability could be a double-edged sword.

Workers who shifted to 32-hour workweeks logged 7.58 hours per night of sleep, nearly a full hour more than when they were keeping 40-hour workweeks, according to lead researcher Juliet Schor, a sociologist and economist at Boston College who is tracking over 180 organisations globally as they shift to truncated schedules through six-month pilot programs.

site_title: How BT is using e-mail newsletters to diversify its content offerings
summary: BT, a Singaporean news outlet, is diversifying its content offerings through email newsletters, providing exclusive, high-quality content to existing subscribers. The company has launched three new newsletters: Property Insights, ESG Insights, and Thrive, covering topics such as property development, sustainability, and career advice. While the newsletter boom poses challenges, BT aims to engage with its audience, gather feedback, and improve its newsletters' user experience and discoverability. By offering curated content, BT seeks to build deeper relationships with its subscribers and provide them with a digital substitute for traditional news sources.

images.alt_text: Dhany Osman

To cultivate these talents, media and journalism programmes in schools will need to make a culture shift towards developing audience-centric, product thinking mindsets and digital product management capabilities in students.
Sign-up page for the Thrive newsletter, which will provide weekly advice on career, money and life. Find out more at bt.sg/thrive.
Being a trusted news source is not enough. So what makes journalism worth paying for?

site_title: China local government special bond issuance slows in December
summary: China's local governments issued 9.8 billion yuan in special bonds in December, a sharp slowdown from 45.5 billion yuan in November. This marks a significant decrease from the 4.04 trillion yuan issued in 2022. The move is part of efforts to boost infrastructure spending and shore up the Covid-affected economy. Local governments were allowed to sell more debt to fund infrastructure projects, with a goal of selling over 500 billion yuan in special bonds.

images.alt_text: Shoppers in the Guanqian Street shopping area in Suzhou, Jiangsu province, China, on Wednesday, Jan. 25, 2023. China's Lunar New Year travel and box office showed signs of recovery as people took advantage of a holiday free of strict restraints on movement following Beijing's pivot away from its Covid Zero policy. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

site_title: India’s budget to test Modi’s fiscal resolve ahead of 2024 vote
summary: India is set to unveil its budget on February 1, testing Prime Minister Narendra Modi's fiscal resolve ahead of the 2024 elections. Modi aims to sustain fiscal consolidation, reducing the deficit to 6.4% of GDP, despite potential populist measures. The budget is seen as crucial for India's long-term growth, freeing up funds for infrastructure development and job creation. Economists expect the budget to focus on strengthening manufacturing and creating jobs, with a focus on fiscal prudence over handouts.

images.alt_text: Narendra Modi Photographer: T. Narayan/Bloomberg

site_title: Gulf royals own £1 billion UK property via tax havens: Guardian
summary: The Guardian reports that nearly 200 UK properties, including hotels, mansions, and country estates, worth over £1 billion are owned by Middle Eastern royal families via offshore tax havens. The properties include a £150 million estate in Surrey and a £185 million London manor in Regent's Park. The royal families of Saudi Arabia, the UAE, and Qatar are among the owners, with individuals such as Sheikh Mansour and Abdullah bin Khalid Al Saud holding significant assets through offshore entities.

images.alt_text: Almost a quarter of London homes were sold off-market in the final three months of last year, according to broker Hamptons International.

site_title: S&P 500 expected to ride on bullish momentum for another breakout
summary: The S&P 500 is expected to continue its bullish momentum as the earnings season progresses, despite potential volatility. The index has broken out to fresh monthly highs, driven by positive data such as a 3.5% unemployment rate and a 6.5% year-on-year Consumer Price Index, indicating a soft landing. However, a short-term key resistance level at 4,100 is expected, and a lack of traction could lead to a reversal in momentum. A golden cross signal, where the 50-day SMA crosses over the 200-day SMA, is also needed for a more confirmatory turnaround signal.

images.alt_text: The outlook for the S&P 500 in Q1-Q3 2023 is expected to be bearish as the US enters a mild recession and corporate earnings see a significant decline.  PHOTO:  EPA-EFE

site_title: Danone puts lagging US brands including Wallaby up for sale
summary: Danone, a French dairy giant, is putting its US yogurt brands Wallaby and Horizon Organic under strategic review as part of its turnaround plan. The move comes amid slower sales growth and lower profitability for the brands, which represent 3% of Danone's global revenue. The review is part of new CEO Antoine de Saint-Affrique's plan to sell or buy lines representing a tenth of the portfolio. The announcement follows sanctions over the war in Ukraine, which made it difficult to turn around Danone's business in Russia.

images.alt_text: CEO Mark Schneider said the company was implementing price increases in a "responsible manner" to help it manage "significant and unprecedented cost inflation".
Consumer companies like Danone make many versions of the same product - from big and small tubs of the same yogurt to different flavours and value packs.

site_title: China’s 2022 smartphone shipments the lowest in 10 years: research firm
summary: China's smartphone sales plummeted 13% year-on-year in 2022, the largest decline in a decade, with total shipments reaching 286 million, the lowest since 2013. Android maker Vivo topped the market with 18.6% market share, while Apple's sales fell 4.4% year-on-year, outperforming the market. Strict Covid-19 controls in China weighed heavily on the economy, which saw a slump in growth. This decline in smartphone sales reflects the sector's global performance, with global shipments hitting 1.2 billion, the lowest since 2013.

images.alt_text: Apple saw lower demand for its latest generation of iPhones than it had projected earlier this year.

site_title: UK PM fires Conservative chairman after tax probe
summary: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak fired Conservative Party Chairman Nadhim Zahawi from government after an investigation into his tax affairs found a serious breach of the ministerial code. Zahawi was briefly finance minister during a period of political turmoil last year. He was deemed "careless" with his declarations, but not deliberately trying to pay less tax. The investigation found Zahawi misled the public and failed to correct a false statement, showing "insufficient regard" for transparency and honesty. Sunak removed Zahawi from his position in the government following the findings.

images.alt_text: Britain's Prime Minister Rishi Sunak delivers a speech at the leaders summit of the COP27 climate conference at the Sharm el-Sheikh International Convention Centre, in Egypt's Red Sea resort city of the same name, on November 7, 2022. (Photo by AHMAD GHARABLI / AFP)

site_title: Energy players hungry for control over green feedstock supply in S-E Asia
summary: Energy companies are seeking control over green feedstock supply in Southeast Asia to build biorefineries worldwide. This is driven by the need to decarbonize supply chains and limit crude oil use. Companies are acquiring, partnering, or establishing joint ventures with agribusiness companies to secure biomass supplies. However, this poses challenges such as human rights, food security, and deforestation. Energy companies must balance these tradeoffs and navigate complex issues like the transition to electric vehicles and cleaner fuels. The growing interest in biodiversity is driving companies to understand the link between climate and nature, with business participation at COP15 being "unprecedented".

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting
Wilmar’s chief financial officer Charles Loo said sustainable financing remains part of its holistic approach to integrate sustainability principles into every aspect of the business operations.
Peter Vyncke, CEO, Vyncke
Dr Langen says waste-to-energy (WTE) strategies save primary resources by substituting coal, crude oil or natural gas.

A geothermal power plant in the Philippines. As part of the research initiative, CNCS researchers will work with other universities, government agencies and corporations to establish monitoring plots at various natural habitats across South-east Asia.
Indonesia needs to retire more coal power plants earlier and reduce the operational levels of the remaining ones.
