Container ship operator Samskip is installing carbon capture systems of two of its ships.

Trees’ ability to absorb climate-damaging carbon dioxide and emit oxygen is central to the world’s efforts to rein in global warming, yet the rate of deforestation continues apace and hit a fresh record high in the Amazon last year.

site_title: Singapore could introduce unemployment support as early as Budget 2023
summary: Singapore's Budget 2023 may include unemployment support for vulnerable workers, such as those older, lower-income, or less educated. The proposed scheme, which was first recommended in 2021, could provide a fixed period of benefits with conditions, and may not be available to all unemployed workers. The government is "looking very carefully" at structuring the scheme, with Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong suggesting it should focus on re-employment support rather than unemployment support. The exact timing and policy details are still being ironed out, but economists expect the scheme to be limited in duration and may require workers to actively seek employment or training.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
One group that could benefit from an expansion of the PWM is skilled non-degree holders, said one economist.
CDC Vouchers are one possible form of additional cost-of-living support in Budget 2023, say observers.

Despite the potential advantages of various government measures to boost foreign investment, if put into action, industry observers expect the government to hold off on providing details at Budget 2023.

The PME taskforce has made progress on eight of the nine recommendations it put forth to the government last year aimed at improving job security and fair employment practices, the taskforce said on Wednesday.

site_title: It’s time for Singapore companies to start investing in coaching
summary: Singapore companies should consider investing in coaching to address high employee churn rates. Career coaching can help both employees and management improve performance, boost confidence, and overcome challenges. Executive coaching, a process involving goal-setting, action planning, and execution, can be tailored to individuals, groups, or teams and can be conducted remotely or in-person. Coaching can be beneficial for high-performing achievers, and employers can save on training costs by not having to replace burnt-out or demotivated employees.

images.alt_text: Jeanette Tan

Staff can feel comfortable having candid conversations about their current state of wellbeing and workplace struggles, or arrange for one-on-one meetings with managers for professional guidance. When done right, coaching provides greater intrinsic motivation.
Amanda Clayman, a financial therapist, at her home in Los Angeles on Aug 3, 2022. She became a licensed clinical social worker in 2006.

site_title: UK wage inflation points to another big rate hike this week
summary: The UK central bank, the Bank of England, is expected to raise interest rates by half a point to 4% this week, marking the highest rate since 2008. The move is driven by soaring wage inflation, which reached a 41-year high in 2022, and a tight labor market that is contributing to inflation. Policymakers are concerned about a wage-price spiral and will publish forecasts showing a shallower recession and falling inflation this year. The decision is expected to deliver more pain for households struggling with the cost-of-living squeeze.

images.alt_text: Input prices paid by factories fell by 1.1 per cent in month-on-month terms, also the biggest drop since April 2020.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for January 10, 2025, highlights the turbulent tanker and dry bulk market. The Capesize market experienced softness initially but rebounded by Thursday, closing on a positive trajectory. The Pacific market remained under pressure due to oversupply, while the South Brazil and West Africa markets gained strength. The North Atlantic market saw a shift in sentiment, with rates climbing on the transatlantic and fronthaul routes. The Panamax market declined, with limited demand and ample tonnage. The Ultramax/Supramax market also saw limited activity, with fresh enquiries remaining limited.

images.alt_text: lA roundup of the week’s tanker and dry bulk market (Dec 20, 2024).

site_title: China central bank to roll over lending tools to spur growth
summary: China's central bank will extend three lending tools to support targeted sectors until the end of 2024, including a carbon emission reduction tool to 2024, a clean coal use tool to 2023, and a transport and logistics tool to June 2023. The move aims to increase support for green development and other areas. The tools, which include relending and rediscount facilities, will be available to some foreign financial institutions. The central bank's actions are part of its efforts to implement prudent monetary policy and address economic challenges.

images.alt_text: The move also comes amid expectations that Chinese authorities will do more to stimulate the country’s Covid-ravaged economy.
FILE PHOTO: Headquarters of the People's Bank of China (PBOC), the central bank, is pictured in Beijing, China September 28, 2018. REUTERS/Jason Lee/File Photo

site_title: Dollar clings to gains after US data; traders eye upcoming Fed meetings
summary: The US dollar maintained modest gains against the euro after data showed falling consumer spending and cooling inflation. Consumer spending dropped 0.2% last month, and the personal consumption expenditures (PCE) price index rose 0.1%. Investors await central bank meetings, including the Federal Reserve's upcoming decision, which may influence future rate decisions.

images.alt_text: The Federal Reserve, European Central Bank and Bank of England are all due to make rate decisions next week.

site_title: Vietnam walks tightrope between meeting net-zero targets and pursuing economic growth
summary: Vietnam's energy transition faces challenges as the country aims to meet net-zero targets while pursuing economic growth. Despite having the highest installed solar and wind energy capacity in South-east Asia, many farms are unable to operate at full capacity due to outdated grid and transmission infrastructure. The country's eighth Power Development Plan (PDP8) has been delayed, reflecting the difficulty in reaching a consensus on the mix of renewable and conventional energy. The Just Energy Transition Partnership (JETP) with G7 countries provides $15.5 billion in financing to support the transition, with Vietnam required to peak greenhouse gas emissions by 2030 and ramp up renewable energy sources to 47% of power supply.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
Vietnam, which has the highest solar power generation capacity in the region, is facing setbacks in its clean energy transition due to inadequate grids and regulations.

Vietnam, which is among the world’s top 20 coal users, was initially slated to sign up for the so-called “Just Energy Transition Partnership” with G7 nations at the global COP27 climate summit in November, but high-level talks stalled before the meeting.

site_title: French court orders return of Nazi-looted painting
summary: A French court ordered Christie's auction house to return a 17th-century painting, "The Penitent Magdalene," to the heirs of its owner, Lionel Hauser, a cousin of writer Marcel Proust. The painting was stolen by Nazi forces in 1942 and sold at auction in 2005 for £60,000. After researching the painting's provenance, Christie's agreed to return it and pay Hauser's heirs 10,000 euros. The court also ordered Christie's to reveal the painting's current owner and whereabouts, as well as its sales record, in a case aimed at restoring artworks looted by the Nazis to their rightful owners.

images.alt_text: A Rolex sold at auction in New York was worn by a British prisoner during the real-life "Great Escape" from the Nazi Stalag Luft III concentration camp in 1944.

site_title: Veteran fund manager lists global macro hedge fund Asia Genesis on ADDX
summary: Veteran fund manager Chua Soon Hock has listed a global macro hedge fund, Asia Genesis Macro, on private market exchange ADDX, seeking to achieve investors' goals of capital preservation and positive annual compounding. The fund, with US$173 million in AUM as of Dec 2022, aims for consistent, positive, and uncorrelated returns with low downside volatility. Chua believes the current market climate will be characterized by a multi-year range market decade with more frequent bear phases, and his understanding of market psychology should give a strong edge.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
Bottles of vintage wine in the Provenance Treasures portfolio. Both carry "Grand Cru'' appellations.

Choo Oi Yee, chief executive of ADDX, said Innoven’s loss rate of under 1 per cent after US$218 million in loans made out can be attributed to its ability to be “highly selective in deploying capital”.

site_title: Netherlands and Japan said to join US in curbing chip technology sent to China
summary: The US has successfully pressured the Netherlands and Japan to join in curbing chip technology sent to China. The agreement, announced on January 27, restricts the sale of advanced semiconductor manufacturing equipment to China, following a similar unilateral restriction imposed by the US in October. The move aims to prevent China from acquiring technology that could be used for military purposes, and puts the technology industries in the countries on a more even footing with US firms.

images.alt_text: Beijing filed a dispute with the World Trade Organization in December aimed at overturning the US-imposed export controls.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CDLHT, Sabana Reit, CapitaLand Ascott Trust, Keppel Corp, Keppel Reit
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article content:

Stocks to watch include CDLHT, Sabana Reit, and Keppel Corp. CDLHT's distribution per stapled security rose 17.3% to S$0.0359 for the second half of 2022, driven by positive momentum in rate growth across its portfolio markets. Sabana Reit's distribution per unit fell 7% to 1.46 Singapore cents due to higher interest expenses. Keppel Corp made a full payment of fines to Brazil under a leniency agreement, while Keppel Reit reported a 23.4% positive rental reversion in Q4 2022 for its office assets in Singapore's Central Business District. Other Reits, including Parkway Life Reit and Starhill Global Reit, also reported positive earnings.

images.alt_text: W Singapore at Sentosa Cove is one of the properties under CDL Hospitality Trusts.

site_title: Philippines to offer value-added tax refund to foreign tourists by 2024
summary: The Philippines plans to introduce a value-added tax (VAT) refund program for foreign tourists by 2024, aiming to attract more visitors. The program will allow foreigners to receive a VAT refund on items taken out of the country. President Ferdinand Marcos Jr has also approved an online visa for Chinese, Indian, South Korean, and Japanese tourists. The country recorded 2.65 million international visitors last year, generating an estimated $3.68 billion in revenue, and aims to increase visitor arrivals to 4.8 million this year.

images.alt_text: For the full year, GDP expanded 7.6 per cent in 2022, surpassing the 7.4 per cent survey median and clocking in among Asia’s fastest expansions.

site_title: Nato’s Stoltenberg arrives in S Korea to deepen alliance’s ties in Asia
summary: NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg arrived in Seoul, South Korea, to strengthen ties with US allies in the region amid the war in Ukraine and rising competition with China. Stoltenberg will meet with South Korean officials, including President Yoon Suk-yeol, and Japanese officials, including Prime Minister Fumio Kishida, to discuss security cooperation and global threats. He emphasized the interconnected nature of security issues worldwide, saying NATO's focus on Europe and North America does not preclude cooperation with Asian partners. This visit aims to deepen NATO's ties with South Korea and Japan.

images.alt_text: Finland – which shares a 1,300 km border with Russia – and Sweden applied to join Nato last year after Moscow’s invasion of Ukraine, ending decades-long policies of military non-alignment.

site_title: S-Reits’ upcoming 2022 report cards
summary: Suntec Reit reported 24% year-on-year growth in net property income, resulting in 3.4% growth in distributable income for the full year. Five S-Reits have released their financial results, with Sabana Industrial Reit postponing its release due to a conditional cash offer, and Paragon Reit changing its financial year-end to Dec 31. The Reits' upcoming reports are expected to be released in the coming weeks, with Paragon Reit's release date yet to be confirmed.

site_title: China kicks off 2023 leading global peers in equity fundraising
summary: China's companies are leading global peers in equity fundraising, raising $8.1 billion via follow-on share sales and IPOs since the start of 2023, surpassing US and European firms. Beijing's supportive monetary policy and policy adjustments, including easing COVID-19 restrictions and a tech crackdown, have provided a cushion for Chinese assets. This trend is expected to continue, with Chinese firms poised to be the first to emerge from last year's global slump in share sales.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong equities have risen 26 per cent since Nov 18, when Hong turned bullish ahead of China’s abrupt end to its years-long Covid-Zero policy.

site_title: Brazilians are choking in debt with a third of their salaries going to repay loans
summary: Brazilian households are struggling with high levels of debt, with 28.2% of monthly wages spent on credit payments in November, the highest figure since 2005. Outstanding debt reached 49.5% of total income, and default rates rose, with 44.7% of revolving loans not paid in full and 13.4% of overdrafts defaulted. Despite central bankers warning of "high" levels of household debt, interest rates are expected to remain steady at 13.75% due to concerns about the government's fiscal outlook and inflation targets.

site_title: 'Drought' has New Yorkers asking: 'Where's the snow?'
summary: New York City is experiencing its longest drought without measurable snow, surpassing a 50-year record for the latest first snowfall of the season. The city is forecast to surpass a 50-year record for the latest first snowfall of the season, with Sunday expected to mark the longest wait since records began in 1869. Residents, who typically welcome snow, are puzzled by the lack of winter weather, with some expressing a mix of sadness and nostalgia for the white stuff.

images.alt_text: More rain is forecast to fall on Saturday.

site_title: UK raises migration projection in potential boost for economy
summary: The UK is expected to take in 245,000 foreign nationals per year from 2026, up from the previous estimate of 205,000, providing a potential economic boost. This increase in net migration may not address labor shortages in industries reliant on EU workers, as many have left the UK due to post-Brexit immigration rules. The revised figures may help offset a downgrade to productivity expectations and support Chancellor Jeremy Hunt's budget.

images.alt_text: Jeremy Hunt, UK Chancellor of the Exchequer, focused on growth industries, including digital technology and the shift to new, high value industries in a speech at Bloomberg in London.

site_title: What’s passive income? It’s not what influencers say it is
summary: Passive income is often misunderstood, with many people claiming it's effortless money-making. However, experts say it's not as easy as it seems. While 20% of American households earn passive income, the median amount is just $4,200 per year. In reality, creating passive income often requires significant upfront work, such as developing products, managing websites, and marketing. Compound interest can also contribute to passive income, but it's not a guarantee. Many people mistakenly confuse leveraged income with passive income, and investing in assets like real estate or stocks can be a better way to build long-term wealth.

images.alt_text: The power of compounding over decades can grow a small investment into a sizable amount.
As almost 90 per cent of resident households own their homes, one's home is a key asset for many people.
Be aware that prepaying down your mortgage does come with opportunity costs or “reduced capacity”.

site_title: Top UK officials on charm offensive to woo foreign investment to Britain
summary: Top UK officials, including International Trade Secretary Kemi Badenoch and former foreign secretary William Hague, are on a charm offensive to woo foreign investment to Britain amid recession concerns. The UK government aims to make Britain the most attractive place to invest in Europe, with inward foreign direct investment (FDI) in 2021 and 2022 creating almost 85,000 jobs. Despite Brexit, FDI in the UK has risen by £969 billion over the past five years, with the US and European Union being major investors. Labour Party leaders also seek to demonstrate their commitment to investing in the UK, with a plan to implement growth and investment incentive strategies.

images.alt_text: But higher net migration may do little to fill labour shortages in industries that rely heavily on workers from the EU.
Renters, who are facing the fastest rent increases in a decade, are at the sharp end of the crisis.
Jeremy Hunt, UK Chancellor of the Exchequer, focused on growth industries, including digital technology and the shift to new, high value industries in a speech at Bloomberg in London.

site_title: Visa, Mastercard pin hopes on China reopening as travel boom fades
summary: Visa and Mastercard expect growth in 2023 to be slower than the previous year, driven by declining travel spending. The companies are relying on China's reopening to boost travel spending, as the country lifted its Covid-19 control measures in early January. With consumers cutting back on discretionary expenses due to rising interest rates and recession fears, the travel recovery in China is seen as a key growth driver for the payments processors.

site_title: White House blasts Big Oil stock buybacks again as Chevron profits double
summary: The White House has criticized US oil companies for using profits to buy back shares instead of increasing production, after Chevron reported a record $36.5 billion profit for 2022. Chevron plans to triple its share repurchases to $75 billion over five years. The White House accused companies of prioritizing shareholder payouts over boosting supply, despite record profits and thousands of approved permits. The administration's criticism comes as Chevron and Exxon Mobil are expected to post record annual profits, with combined earnings forecasted at nearly $100 billion.

images.alt_text: Adjusted 2022 earnings more than doubled to US$36.5 billion from a year earlier, while oil and natural gas output from the company’s US fields climbed almost 4 per cent to the equivalent of 1.181 million barrels a day.

Britain’s government is looking to boost domestic hydrocarbon output as Europe weans itself off Russian fuel, but climate activists have criticised the licensing round and Greenpeace is working on a legal challenge.

site_title: Jet fuel prices up as demand jumps, refinery outages limit supply
summary: Jet fuel prices have surged due to increased demand from China's lifting of Covid-19 travel restrictions and US refinery outages. Jet fuel demand has more than tripled since early December, reaching an average of 10,700 flights per day. Prices have risen in Asia, Europe, and the US, with Singapore jet fuel trading at $122.30 per barrel and New York spot prices at $2.45 above ultra-low sulphur diesel. US East Coast supplies are expected to remain scarce until mid-February, driving up prices and fueling concerns about the impact on air travel.

images.alt_text: The design could trim fuel consumption and emissions by around 30 per cent over Boeing’s 737 Max and Airbus’s A320neo family.

site_title: Rapidly cooling housing market helps to quell Canadian inflation
summary: Canada's inflation rate is expected to lose momentum due to base effects and a cooling housing market. The country's unique method of capturing housing costs in inflation metrics, influenced by mortgage rates and home prices, is contributing to this decline. While inflation remains 6.3% in December, economists predict a sharp drop in shelter component CPI to 3.5% by June and 1.5% by December. The Bank of Canada's pause in interest rate hikes may also contribute to a faster-than-expected decline in inflation, with energy, food, and goods prices also expected to fall.

images.alt_text: Canada’s housing crisis is becoming more acute as its longstanding home shortage is met with record levels of immigration.

site_title: A-Sonic and Singapore Shipping directors continue with their acquisitions
summary: A-Sonic and Singapore Shipping directors have continued their share acquisitions, with A-Sonic CEO Janet LC Tan acquiring 63,000 shares and Singapore Shipping Corporation executive chairman Ow Chio Kiat buying 75,800 shares. Meanwhile, institutions were net sellers of Singapore stocks, with S$157 million of net outflow, while Mapletree Logistics Trust, Singapore Technologies Engineering, and others led the net institutional inflow. The Straits Times Index gained 3.1% over the three trading sessions, with eight primary-listed companies conducting share buybacks totaling S$1.9 million.

images.alt_text: SGX RegCo on Tuesday said its actions apply to IPO and RTO submissions for which UOBKH had agreed to act as issue manager or full sponsor under any agreement entered into after Aug 31.
Shares on the Singapore bourse rose on Tuesday amid a mixed showing by regional peers

site_title: Amazon beats claim that warehouse quotas are biased against older workers
summary: Amazon has won a bid to dismiss a class action lawsuit claiming its strict production quotas in warehouses discriminate against older workers. US Magistrate Judge Kandis Westmore ruled the lawsuit too vague and failed to identify specific discriminatory policies. The lawsuit alleged older workers were more susceptible to injuries due to repetitive motions, but Westmore said age alone doesn't mean older workers are more likely to get injured. Amazon maintains it invests hundreds of millions of dollars annually to ensure worker safety and doesn't require employees to meet specific productivity speeds or targets.

images.alt_text: Amazon’s decision to sell the property underscores the risks of a new real estate strategy the company has embraced in recent years.
A few hundred workers at a warehouse in Coventry, central England, have walked out over a pay increase worth five per cent.

site_title: Who is Gautam Adani and what is Hindenburg Research?
summary: Gautam Adani, India's 60-year-old billionaire founder of the Adani Group, is facing pressure after New York-based investor Hindenburg Research issued a report alleging stock manipulation and accounting fraud against the conglomerate. Adani's net worth took a hit, but he remains in the top 10 on the Bloomberg Billionaires Index. The Adani Group, which includes companies in energy, transportation, and infrastructure development, has denied the allegations and is exploring legal action. Adani's close ties to Prime Minister Narendra Modi and his company's business dealings have raised concerns about the tycoon's influence in Indian politics and economy.

images.alt_text: Seven listed companies of the Adani conglomerate – controlled by one of the world’s richest men Gautam Adani (above) – have lost a combined US$48 billion in market capitalisation since Wednesday.

site_title: Half of Britons struggle with soaring cost of running households
summary: Half of Britons are struggling with the soaring cost of running their households due to the fastest rent increases in a decade. A report by the Resolution Foundation found that 44% of working-age households were falling behind on rent and mortgage payments in November 2022, up from 26% in January 2021. The cost-of-living crisis has intensified pressures sparked by the Covid-19 pandemic, affecting renters who are facing the sharp end of the crisis.

images.alt_text: Jeremy Hunt, UK Chancellor of the Exchequer, focused on growth industries, including digital technology and the shift to new, high value industries in a speech at Bloomberg in London.

The Confederation of British Industry’s (CBI) sales balance, which included a couple of days of the Christmas trading period, fell to -23 from +11 in December’s report, meaning more store chains reported a drop in retail sales than a rise.

site_title: Goldman Sachs slashes CEO Solomon’s pay about 30% to US$25m
summary: Goldman Sachs has cut CEO David Solomon's pay by about 30% to $25 million for 2022, down from $35 million the previous year. The firm faced a challenging operating environment, including a failed consumer bank effort and a slowdown in dealmaking. Solomon's new compensation package includes a $2 million base salary and $23 million in variable compensation. The decision reflects the industry-wide trend of reducing executive pay amid cost-cutting efforts.

images.alt_text: Since October Goldman has made a U-turn on its plan to build a big consumer bank; booked one of its worst quarterly results for a decade; and attracted a probe by the Federal Reserve.

Julian Salisbury, chief investment officer of asset and wealth management at Goldman Sachs, says the Wall Street giant plans to divest its positions over the next few years and replace some of those funds on its balance sheet with outside capital.

site_title: US secures deal with Netherlands, Japan on China chip export limit
summary: The US has secured a deal with the Netherlands and Japan to restrict exports of advanced chipmaking machinery to China, a major diplomatic win for President Joe Biden's administration. The agreement, which was reached in talks led by White House national security adviser Jake Sullivan, extends some export controls adopted in October by the US to companies based in the two allied nations. The move aims to slow China's technological and military advances in the semiconductor industry.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. chipmaker Intel Corp's logo is seen on their "smart building" in Petah Tikva, near Tel Aviv, Israel. December 15, 2019.  REUTERS/Amir Cohen/File Photo

site_title: Ronaldo’s Saudi Arabia switch another symbol of Chinese football’s decline
summary: Cristiano Ronaldo's move to Saudi Arabian club Al-Nassr has highlighted a shift in Asian football, as the Chinese Super League's decline continues to impact the sport. The CSL, once a destination for top players and coaches, has seen several clubs close due to financial issues, including Tianjin Quanjian and Wuhan Yangtze. The downturn in Chinese football has spared few, with talent draining to the Saudi Pro League, where Al-Nassr's high pay deal has attracted Ronaldo. The decline of Chinese football has significant implications for the sport, with Saudi Arabia now poised to host major international tournaments.

images.alt_text: Fifa has long managed a loan portfolio, targeting short-term bonds predominantly in government or public debt.
English clubs’ spending “reached a record high of almost US$2.2 billion”, the report said, with six of the 10 biggest international transfers involving moves to Premier League sides.

Chelsea FC's Marc Cucurella (right) in action against Everton's Alexander Iwobi in Liverpool last August. Everton  is in danger of dropping out of the lucrative Premier League. It now ranks second-to-last in the standings, with three teams set for demotion at the end of the season in May.

epa10407306 Son Heung-Min (R) of Tottenham in action against Aaron Ramsdale of Arsenal during the English Premier League soccer match between Tottenham Hotspur and Arsenal London in London, Britain, 15 January 2023. site_title: Bull market beckons China stock traders as consumption revs up
summary: China's stock market is poised for a bull run as a rebound in consumption fuels optimism about the economy's resilience. The CSI 300 Index is expected to extend its 19% rise from an October low, with hotel operators and travel firms set to benefit. The rally is driven by easing US inflation, a potential pause in Federal Reserve tightening, and a better-than-expected European economy. Analysts expect sustained gains throughout 2023, with some cautioning that a new wave of virus cases may impact the outlook.

images.alt_text:
weechina21 - Stock information is displayed on an electronic board at a securities brokerage in Shanghai, China, on Friday, Oct. 13, 2017. A number of economic indicators show "stabilized and stronger growth" and the momentum of a 6.9 percent expansion in the first six months of 2017 "may continue in the second half," People’s Bank of China Governor Zhou Xiaochuan said. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

site_title: UK airline Flybe ceases trading, cancels all flights
summary: UK airline Flybe has ceased trading and cancelled all flights, citing it has been placed into administration. The UK Civil Aviation Authority advises passengers booked with Flybe not to go to the airport. Flybe's flights from and to the UK are cancelled and will not be rescheduled.

images.alt_text: A bird flies over a logo of Air India airlines at the corporate headquarters in Mumbai, India, October 19, 2021. REUTERS/Francis Mascarenhas
American Airlines expects an adjusted profit of US$2.50 and US$3.50 per share for 2023, up from 50 cents per share a year earlier.

site_title: Holiday trips within China surge after lifting of Covid curbs
summary: China saw a 74% surge in domestic trips during the Lunar New Year holiday, with an estimated 226 million trips made, compared to 130 million last year. The increase comes after authorities lifted Covid-19 curbs, allowing travel to resume after three years. The surge in travel has boosted the tourism industry, with many people heading to their hometowns and villages for family reunions.

images.alt_text: Local economies are ramping up efforts to revive the Covid-hit services sector as frequent and stringent lockdowns and restrictions kept shoppers at home and disrupted consumption activity.
Passengers prepare to board a train bound for Jilin province at the Beijing railway station, Beijing, China, Jan 14, 2023.

site_title: Tempers flaring over onions show Marcos faces risk on prices
summary: The Philippines is facing a severe onion shortage, with prices briefly exceeding those of meat, sparking concerns over food security. Despite the country producing a record-high onion crop last year, the shortage is attributed to greedy traders hoarding the commodity, selling it at inflated prices to cold storage facilities, and then reselling it at exorbitant rates. The government has ordered permits to import onions and is buying sugar from overseas, but critics argue that inadequate infrastructure and lack of access to subsidies and cold storage facilities hinder domestic production.

images.alt_text:
(FILES) This file handout photo taken and released by the Presidential Photo Division (PPD) on March 1, 2018 shows President Rodrigo Duterte (R) firing a few rounds with a sniper rifle during the opening ceremony of the National Special Weapons and Tactics (SWAT) Challenge in Davao City on the southern Philippine island of Mindanao. - Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte has been accused of rights abuses in a drug war that has killed thousands of people. But analysts say he is unlikely to face charges after he steps down on June 30, 2022. (Photo by ROBINSON NIÑAL / PRESIDENTIAL PHOTO DIVISION / AFP) / TO GO WITH Philippine-politics-crime-Duterte,FOCUS by Allison Jackson

site_title: Musk faces SEC probe for role in Tesla self-driving claims
summary: US regulators are investigating Elon Musk's role in Tesla's self-driving car claims as part of an ongoing Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) probe. The review, which touches on a key business priority for Tesla, aims to scrutinize the accuracy of the company's statements about its Autopilot driver-assistance system. As CEO, Musk's comments carry significant weight under SEC rules, but he and his attorney declined to comment on the matter. The SEC declined to comment on the investigation, which is the latest effort to scrutinize Musk's actions.

images.alt_text: Tesla has cut about US$9.5 billion of debt since its peak in Jun 30, 2020.
Elon Musk sees the toughest competition for Tesla in China, home of the company he expects “most likely to be second” in electric vehicles.

site_title: US seeks tighter bail for FTX founder Bankman-Fried to prevent tampering
summary: US prosecutors asked a Manhattan judge to impose stricter bail conditions on Sam Bankman-Fried, the 30-year-old founder of FTX, citing concerns he may tamper with witnesses or destroy evidence. Bankman-Fried, who has been free on a $250 million bond, is required to live with his parents and is barred from contacting FTX employees or using encrypted call and messaging applications. Prosecutors also want him to communicate only through lawyers or family members.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Former FTX chief executive Sam Bankman-Fried, who faces fraud charges over the collapse of the bankrupt cryptocurrency exchange, leaving the court on Jan 3.
Former FTX chief executive Sam Bankman-Fried is currently on bail after signing a US$250 million package that effectively placed him under house arrest at his parents’ home in California.

site_title: Global central banks preaching on pay are enforcing squeeze too
summary: Global central banks are enforcing pay freezes or modest increases to prevent wage-price spirals, amid surging consumer prices. Despite wanting stronger wage gains, Japan's Bank of Japan governor Haruhiko Kuroda is practicing restraint, and the US Federal Reserve has set a maximum 5.1% pay increase for staff. In the eurozone, European Central Bank staff received a 4% salary increase, while the Bank of France and Bundesbank have also implemented modest pay increases. Central banks are under pressure to maintain budgetary discipline while addressing cost-of-living pressures, with the risk of criticism and inflation if they fail to do so.

images.alt_text: The personal consumption expenditures core price index, which excludes food and energy, rose 4.4 per cent in December from a year earlier.

With inflation soaring to double digit territory late last year, the ECB hiked rates by an unprecedented 2.5 percentage points in just six months, hoping to cool demand and prevent longer term inflation expectations from moving higher.

site_title: Summer storm lashes New Zealand, killing two and halting flights
summary: A summer storm in Auckland, New Zealand, caused widespread flooding, killing two people and prompting flight cancellations. The storm dumped 153mm of rain in three hours, a record for the city, and flooded homes and roads. International and domestic flights were halted, with 1,000 travelers stranded. The storm is attributed to climate change and La Nina, and more rain is forecast for Saturday.

images.alt_text: The survey’s headline measure showed a net 52 per cent of respondents expected New Zealand's economy to deteriorate over the year ahead.

site_title: The hottest property in the job market right now is the CFO
summary: Finance chiefs are in high demand as companies face liquidity crises amid high inflation and recession prospects. The average age of a CFO in the UK's FTSE-100 stock index is 52, and few have dealt with such challenging conditions. CFOs are no longer just number-crunchers, but are expected to be leaders and transformation officers. Assignments for CFO appointments are up by almost a third, and companies are seeking finance directors who can navigate crises. As interest rates rise, CFOs will need to prove their mettle, with banks becoming more demanding on loan conditions and credit becoming more expensive.

images.alt_text: Investment, money, growth, wealth, finance, business. Copyright: Pixabay

site_title: Elon Musk, White House discuss electric vehicles
summary: Elon Musk met with White House officials, including Mitch Landrieu and John Podesta, on January 27 to discuss growing the electric vehicle market. The meeting focused on "electrification" and how the bipartisan infrastructure law and Inflation Reduction Act can advance electric vehicles and increase broader electrification. Musk, known for his prickly relations with President Joe Biden, had previously tangled with the administration. The discussion aims to advance EVs and clean energy, aligning with the Biden administration's push to bolster the market.

images.alt_text: The regulator’s Autopilot review directly touches on a business priority that Musk has singled out as crucial to Tesla’s future.

site_title: Proportion of delayed BTO projects down from 90% to 40%, HDB to clear backlog in two years
summary: The proportion of delayed Build-To-Order (BTO) projects in Singapore has decreased from 90% in 2021 to 40% as of 2023, according to the Housing and Development Board (HDB). Despite the initial 90% delay rate, HDB has completed 55% of delayed projects in the past two years, with the first project completed without delays since the pandemic beginning expected to be ready by Q1 2023. HDB aims to clear its backlog in about two years and plans to launch more BTO flats with shorter waiting times, including 11,000 flats launched since 2018 with waiting times under three years.

images.alt_text: Resale prices rose 2.3 per cent quarter on quarter, making for the slowest growth in 2022.
The pace of property price increases in the last quarter has moderated amid a drop in sales volume, says Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat.

site_title: Parkway Life Reit FY2022 DPU up 2.1% to S$0.1438
summary: Parkway Life Reit reported a 2.1% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 14.38 Singapore cents for FY2022, with gross revenue rising 7.7% to S$130 million and net property income increasing 9.6% to S$121.9 million. The Reit's healthcare real estate portfolio in Japan contributed 39.2% of gross revenue, and the company completed two nursing home acquisitions in Japan. The Reit's gearing remains optimal at 36.4%, and its manager expressed confidence in the company's diversified portfolio and strong financial standing.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
First REIT now has 14 out of its 32 Asian healthcare assets in Japan nursing homes.
Gross revenue is down 1.3 per cent to S$89 million in the same period.

site_title: Charge a US$75m painting on your AmEx card? CEO says you could
summary: American Express (AmEx) CEO Steve Squeri revealed that the company can approve high-value transactions, such as charging a $75 million painting, due to its underwriting standards. AmEx evaluates customers' riskiness with every purchase, unlike most credit cards with pre-defined limits. As the company prepares for a weaker economy, AmEx has begun tightening underwriting standards for new accounts and prunes existing limits to minimize losses. The company's stock surged after forecasting revenue and profits would rise this year.

images.alt_text: The typically strong holiday season saw AmEx’s largely wealthy customers shrug off inflationary pressures to splurge on gifts, travel, and entertainment, helping sustain card member spending volumes.

site_title: Eurozone lending growth tumbles as higher rates bite
summary: Eurozone lending growth tumbled in December, with lending to businesses expanding by 6.3% and household credit growth slowing to 3.8% from 4.1% a month earlier. This decline is attributed to the European Central Bank's unprecedented 2.5 percentage point rate hike in six months, aiming to cool demand and prevent inflation expectations from rising. The sharp decline in private sector borrowing is seen as a recessionary sign, with rate hikes expected to peak around 2.45% mid-year, further impacting the economy.

site_title: China stocks veteran Hao Hong sees Hong Kong surge to 2021 highs
summary: Hong Kong's benchmark Hang Seng Index may reach 30,000 points, its highest level since 2021, according to veteran market analyst Hao Hong. The index has risen 26% since November 18, driven by stronger-than-expected holiday spending data, including a 23% increase in domestic tourism trips and a 130% year-over-year surge in sales of travel agencies. Hong is cautious about fundamentals, but expects a bullish market sentiment, with no immediate changes to his forecasts for Hong Kong and Chinese shares.

images.alt_text: The Hong Kong dollar may stay near the weaker-half of its trading band and USD/HKD is more likely to stay above 7.80 in the near term given the fairly negative Hibor-Libor spreads.

site_title: Bitcoin miner Argo hit with lawsuit over ‘misleading’ US IPO
summary: A class-action lawsuit has been filed against Argo Blockchain, a British Bitcoin miner, alleging the company made false or misleading statements during its US IPO in 2021. Argo is accused of failing to disclose significant capital constraints, electricity costs, and network issues, which hampered its ability to mine Bitcoin and operate its business. The lawsuit claims the company's business and financial prospects were overstated, and its American depositary shares have tumbled nearly 90% since the last Bitcoin bull run.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A representation of bitcoin is seen in an illustration picture taken on June 23, 2017. REUTERS/Benoit Tessier/File Photo

site_title: US consumer spending ends 2022 on weaker footing; inflation slowing
summary: US consumer spending declined 0.2% in December, its second consecutive drop, amid higher borrowing costs and lower gasoline prices. Inflation, however, continued to slow, which may give the Federal Reserve room to ease interest rate hikes next week. The decline in spending was largely driven by the goods sector, while services outlays remained stable. The drop in spending puts the economy on a lower growth path heading into 2023, raising recession risks, but also reduces the need for an overly aggressive monetary policy stance.

images.alt_text: The personal consumption expenditures core price index, which excludes food and energy, rose 4.4 per cent in December from a year earlier.
Over the year as a whole, as measured from the fourth quarter a year earlier, US GDP grew 1 per cent, down sharply from 5.7 per cent growth in 2021.

site_title: US inflation expectations extend retreat, buoy consumers’ mood
summary: US consumers expect inflation to rise 2.9% over the next 5-10 years, down slightly from the preliminary reading, according to the University of Michigan's survey. Short-term inflation expectations fell to 3.9% over the next year, the lowest since April 2021, boosting consumer sentiment. The sentiment index climbed to 64.9, the highest in nine months, despite two-thirds of consumers expecting a downturn in the coming year due to the debt ceiling debate.

images.alt_text: Over the year as a whole, as measured from the fourth quarter a year earlier, US GDP grew 1 per cent, down sharply from 5.7 per cent growth in 2021.
Gross domestic product (GDP) increased at a 2.9 per cent annualised rate last quarter, the Commerce Department said in its advance fourth-quarter GDP growth estimate on Thursday (Jan 26).

site_title: Zelenskiy vows campaign to prevent Russia from competing in Olympics
summary: Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelenskiy has vowed a campaign to prevent Russian athletes from competing in the Paris 2024 Olympics, calling for the International Olympic Committee (IOC) to take a stance against Russia's participation. Zelenskiy has also invited IOC President Thomas Bach to visit the war-torn city of Bakhmut in eastern Ukraine, criticizing the idea of neutral Russian athletes at the Olympics. Ukraine may consider boycotting the Games if Russian and Belarusian athletes are allowed to compete, with Sports Minister Vadim Guttsait stating the country would not rule out a boycott.

images.alt_text: “All athletes, regardless of their nationality or the passport they hold, should be able to compete in sports competitions,” the OCA said in a statement.
President Volodymyr Zelensky's decision to stay in Kyiv and rally Ukraine through the ongoing war is "fateful", says Time magazine's editor-in-chief.

site_title: Biden picks Jeff Zients as next chief of staff
summary: US President Joe Biden has chosen Jeff Zients, his former Covid-19 policy coordinator, as the next White House chief of staff. Zients previously worked on the American Recovery Act during the Obama administration and led the Covid-19 response under Biden. He will replace Ron Klain, who has been chief of staff since January 2021. The move is seen as a strategic choice to address healthcare and economic issues, citing Zients' expertise in these areas.

site_title: Oil prices settle lower on stronger supply outlook
summary: Oil prices settled lower on Friday, making their weekly finish flat to lower, due to stronger Russian oil supply and profit taking ahead of the weekend. Brent futures fell 0.9% to $86.66 per barrel, while US crude fell 1.6% to $79.68 per barrel. Strong Russian oil loadings and hopes for a rapid recovery in Chinese demand offset better-than-expected US economic growth data.

images.alt_text: Brent futures rose US$1.35, or 1.6 per cent, to settle at US$87.47 a barrel on Thursday.

site_title: WHO panel in talks on Covid emergency status
summary: The World Health Organization's emergency committee is meeting to discuss whether the Covid-19 pandemic still warrants the highest level of global alert. WHO chief Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus expressed concern over the rising number of deaths and inadequate vaccination rates. The committee, which meets every three months, will consider the global response to the pandemic and the availability of health tools, including antivirals. The outcome of the meeting is expected to be announced in the following days.

images.alt_text: The Chinese Center for Disease Control and Prevention says that daily fatalities dipped to 896 on Monday, from a high of 4,273 on Jan 4.

site_title: DOJ probing Visa on US debit card practices, competition
summary: The US Department of Justice is investigating Visa's US debit card practices and competition with other payment networks, following reports of anticompetitive practices. The probe, initiated in 2021, seeks documents and information about Visa's US debit card practices. This comes after Visa faced increasing scrutiny for its dominance in the credit card market, including a 2019 settlement with the European Union over card fees. The investigation is part of a broader probe into the credit card payments industry, with Mastercard also facing similar scrutiny.

site_title: Goodyear to cut 500 jobs amid ‘significantly weaker’ demand
summary: Goodyear Tire & Rubber will cut approximately 500 salaried jobs, about 5% of total salaried positions, due to weak demand and rising inflation. The layoffs are expected to be completed by mid-year, resulting in pretax charges of around $55 million. The company's fourth-quarter results were disappointing, with a 12% decline in tire demand in the Europe, Middle East, and Africa region, leading to an operating loss of around $80 million.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower on Intel warning, inflation data limits fall
summary: Wall Street's main indexes opened lower on Friday after Intel's bleak outlook dragged chipmakers down, despite data showing easing inflation. The S&P 500 dropped 0.17% to 4,053.72, while the Nasdaq Composite fell 0.36% to 11,470.47. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.01% to 33,952.93. The market's losses were limited by hopes of a policy shift from the Federal Reserve, which could ease inflation pressures.

images.alt_text: A trader works on the trading floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., January 26, 2023. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly

site_title: Climate change and the future of globalisation
summary: Companies will play a key role in combating climate change as a fundamental global value, with ambitious targets and transparency from top suppliers driving action along entire value chains. To ensure verified compliance, companies can require suppliers to establish sustainability scores and goals, with those that refuse facing consequences. The private sector's problem-solving capabilities and continuous improvement mindset can prove valuable, but governments must also facilitate efforts by reducing emissions and efficiently using resources. Achieving Scope 3 net-zero emissions, which account for emissions from suppliers and customers, is crucial, with technologies developed or under development offering potential for 86% emissions reductions.

images.alt_text: Pressure mounts on companies to critically focus on their suppliers and actively assist them in reducing their carbon footprint as it would ultimately add to their “own” emissions.

Solutions can take on issues in carbon credits projects from a demand or supply perspective. For example, Fairatmos, a carbon technology platform  enables communities as project developers to develop carbon sequestration projects and companies that want to offset their carbon footprint.

site_title: Rental reversions for Keppel Reit’s Singapore CBD offices hit 23.4% in Q4
summary: Keppel Reit reported a 1.7% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.0592 for FY2022, driven by a 2% rise in net property income (NPI) due to contributions from Keppel Bay Tower and higher NPI from other assets. The Reit secured positive rental reversions of 23.4% for its Singapore CBD offices in Q4, bringing its full-year reversions to 10%. Management expects reversions in the "mid to higher single digits" for leases expiring in 2023.

images.alt_text: Hospitality S-Reits such as CapitaLand Ascott Trust are expected to ride on the tailwinds of the return of Chinese tourists.
Mapletree Pan Asia Commercial Trust’s (MPACT) Mapletree Business City (MBC) recorded yoy growth in both gross revenue and NPI in H1FY23.

site_title: Europe: Shares end higher as focus shifts to central bank meetings
summary: European shares ended higher for the second consecutive day, with the Stoxx 600 climbing 0.2% and posting weekly gains. Mixed earnings from the region and easing US inflation bolstered sentiment ahead of central bank meetings. Luxury firms such as Compagnie Financiere Richemont and Moncler rose, while fashion retailer H&M fell 4% after reporting lower-than-expected operating profit. The upcoming week features monetary policy decisions from the Federal Reserve and European Central Bank, with traders betting on a possible 25-basis-point rate hike from the Fed next week.

images.alt_text: The pan-European Stoxx 600 rose 0.4 per cent on Thursday after two consecutive days of declines.

site_title: Crypto billionaire Wu cuts jobs at one firm, loses CEO at other
summary: Crypto billionaire Jihan Wu is reshuffling the leadership of his asset manager Matrix Asset Management, following a 10% staff reduction at his digital-currency lending firm, Matrixport. CEO Damien Loh and head of business development and investor relations I Z Wong have left the company, amid regulatory uncertainty. Wu attributed the staff cuts to a shift in the regulatory climate and vowed to continue hiring in compliance, legal, and product development areas. The company handles $5 billion in trades monthly and has $10 billion in assets under management.

images.alt_text: Wu Jihan, co-founder of Bitmain Technologies Ltd., poses for a photograph in Hong Kong, China, on Friday, May 18, 2018. Photographer: Anthony Kwan/Bloomberg

site_title: Want to create a billion-dollar company? Just S$16 will do
summary: A group of South-east Asian tech founders and executives created a shell company with S$4 in paid-up capital and 250 million shares, raising S$16 through investments. By using Employee Stock Option Plan (ESOP) math, they declared the company worth S$1 billion, illustrating how fuzzy tech valuations can be. This experiment aimed to educate tech workers on how ESOPs work, as inflated valuations have become a concern during the tech boom. The "S$16 unicorn" experiment highlights the need for reality check as the tech bubble has deflated, with companies like Grab and GoTo Group experiencing valuation cuts.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
Esop fables: A cautionary tale for those joining startups
ESOP platforms gain ground amid S-E Asia's tech talent war
Bait or boon: The good, the bad and the ugly of startup employee stock option schemes

site_title: Russian-born quant trader named UK’s biggest taxpayer
summary: Russian-born quantitative trader Alex Gerko has become the UK's biggest taxpayer, contributing £487.4 million (S$792 million) to Britain's public finances over the past year. Gerko, founder of London-based XTX Markets, has earned a billionaire status through his firm's daily volume of nearly $300 billion across various markets. XTX paid a £1.3 billion dividend in March 2022, further boosting Gerko's tax contributions.

images.alt_text: Alex Gerko, founder and co-chief executive of XTX Markets.

site_title: US pending home sales post first gain in seven months in December
summary: US pending home sales rose 2.5% in December, the first increase in seven months, driven by declining mortgage rates. The National Association of Realtors reported 76.9 pending home sales, exceeding economists' forecasts of a 0.9% decline. This marks a low point in home sales activity, with Lawrence Yun, NAR's chief economist, stating that the recent decline is likely over. Falling mortgage rates have raised hopes for a stabilizing housing market, despite the Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes.

images.alt_text: US consumers expect inflation to rise 2.9% over the next five to 10 years.
New home sales increased 2.3 per cent to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 616,000 units last month, the Commerce Department said on Thursday (Jan 26).
Over the year as a whole, as measured from the fourth quarter a year earlier, US GDP grew 1 per cent, down sharply from 5.7 per cent growth in 2021.
Gross domestic product (GDP) increased at a 2.9 per cent annualised rate last quarter, the Commerce Department said in its advance fourth-quarter GDP growth estimate on Thursday (Jan 26).

site_title: Ex-CEO of A-Smart charged with breaching disclosure obligations
summary: Former Xpress Holdings CEO Fong Kah Kuen has been charged with 15 counts of breaching disclosure obligations under the Securities and Futures Act. He allegedly failed to give timely notice of changes in his direct and deemed interest in Xpress shares on 11 occasions between 2014 and 2015. If convicted, Fong faces up to two years' imprisonment and a fine of up to S$250,000. This breach also involved A-Smart Holdings breaking listing rules in July 2014, failing to disclose creditors' winding-up applications in a timely manner.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher

site_title: Ford recalls 462,000 vehicles for rear camera display failure
summary: Ford Motor is recalling 462,000 vehicles worldwide due to a rear camera display failure. The recall affects 2020-2023 Explorer, Lincoln Aviator, and 2020-2022 Lincoln Corsair models. Reports of 17 minor crashes and over 2,100 warranty claims have been made, but no injuries have been reported. The recall expands a 2021 recall and includes updating software on image processing modules. Ford has issued other rear camera-related recalls in recent years, and an ongoing NHTSA investigation reviews the company's recall procedures.

site_title: US: Wall Street ends higher, notches weekly gains as Fed meeting looms
summary: US stocks closed higher on Friday, marking the end of a week with mixed signals on demand and economic resilience ahead of the Federal Reserve meeting. The Nasdaq led gains, driven by mega-cap momentum stocks, while the S&P and Dow posted their third weekly gains in four. The tech-laden Nasdaq achieved its fourth straight weekly advance.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange during opening bell in New York City on January 18, 2023. - Wall Street stocks climbed early on January 18, 2023, on easing worries about further Federal Reserve moves to aggressively counter inflation following the latest US economic data. (Photo by ANGELA WEISS / AFP)

site_title: Chevron posts record profit, bolstering US$75b buyback plan
summary: Chevron posted a record profit of US$36.5 billion in 2022, driven by surging commodity prices and domestic oil production. The company's adjusted earnings more than doubled from the previous year, while oil and natural gas output from US fields climbed 4% to 1.181 million barrels a day. Chevron's US$75 billion share-buyback plan has been met with criticism from the White House, which argues that the cash could be better spent increasing energy supplies to lower pump prices.

images.alt_text: The company last year announced that capital spending for 2023 will be at the top end of its guidance range at US$17 billion.

site_title: ChatGPT ‘arms race’ adds US$4.6 billion to Nvidia founder’s fortune
summary: Nvidia co-founder Jensen Huang's fortune has surged 33% to $18.4 billion, surpassing other US billionaires. His company's growth is attributed to its dominance in powering artificial intelligence applications, including ChatGPT. The tool's popularity has sparked an "arms race," with Nvidia expected to generate $3 billion to $11 billion in sales over the next 12 months. Huang has expressed concerns about AI's potential harm, but also sees its benefits. The company's market value has jumped 35% since the start of 2023.

images.alt_text: Taiwan-based Foxconn makes electric vehicles for Lordstown Motors and has a contract to make Fisker’s second car model, Pear.

site_title: Israeli justice reforms spark tech investor flight fears
summary: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's proposed judicial reforms have sparked widespread concern among tech investors, with some major investors expressing concerns about the potential politicization of the judiciary and compromise of its independence. Tens of thousands have taken to the streets in Tel Aviv and other cities, while business and economy experts have warned of a "danger to Israel's economy". Some top tech executives, including those from Nice and Papaya Global, have announced plans to consider relocating their businesses abroad due to the uncertainty surrounding the reforms. The reforms have created palpable alarm in the tech industry, which accounts for a significant portion of Israel's economy.

images.alt_text: Foreign Minister Penny Wong said the city’s status should be decided by Israeli-Palestinian peace talks.
Can Silicon Valley, birthplace of high-tech, still dominate global innovation?

site_title: US dollar ticks up ahead of central bank meetings
summary: The US dollar rose on Friday ahead of major central bank meetings next week, as investors anticipated potential rate decisions from the Federal Reserve, European Central Bank, and Bank of England. The meetings aim to combat inflation against a tough global economic backdrop. Despite this, currency analysts do not expect significant moves, with a key US jobs report scheduled for the following week. The US dollar has been trending away from multi-month lows against the euro and sterling.

images.alt_text: A gloomy US corporate earnings season has stoked recession fears in the world’s largest economy, sending the dollar index to its lowest level since the end of May.

site_title: European mortgages tumble 70% to lowest since Covid on rate jump
summary: European mortgage lending has plummeted 70% to its lowest level since the Covid-19 pandemic, as interest rates surge and financing costs skyrocket. This decline has affected home prices, with Germany experiencing its first drop in residential home valuations in over a decade. The drop in demand has made home purchases unaffordable for many consumers, with mortgage rates tripling over the past 12 months. The European Central Bank reported a 5 billion euro decline in loans for house purchases in December, a significant contraction in the market for residential real estate.

site_title: Japan to drop mask guidance, relax Covid strategy
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida announced plans to drop mask guidance and downgrade Covid-19's medical classification, moving towards "life with corona." The changes, effective May 8, will classify Covid-19 on par with the flu, allowing patients and close contacts to no longer isolate. The move comes as South Korea and China also ease their strict Covid-19 policies.

site_title: Grab’s cash-advance scheme for drivers stirs debate, draws calls for more clarity
summary: Grab's cash-advance scheme for drivers has sparked debate over its benefits and risks. The scheme, launched in December 2022, offers cash advances of S$1,000 to S$10,000 with a one-time admin fee charged upfront. Critics argue the 9% admin fee is excessively high, while others worry drivers may become deeply entrenched with Grab if they borrow from the platform. Experts suggest more clarity on regulation is needed, given Grab's dominant position and the fact that its workers are technically not employees.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
Platforms like Grab could do more to support drivers amid strong cost pressures.

site_title: GM, Ford must convince investors they can profit as prices fall
summary: GM and Ford, the US's top automakers by sales in 2022, must convince investors that their profit model can continue despite rising EV battery costs, high interest rates, and Tesla's price cuts. The Detroit rivals are scaling back spending, with GM shelving plans for a new EV battery plant and Ford considering thousands of job cuts and selling a German plant. Both companies rely on sales of pickup trucks and SUVs for most of their profits, but plan to increase electric vehicle sales, which could be impacted by a potential US recession.

site_title: Hollywood has become ‘completely dysfunctional’: Shyamalan
summary: Director M Night Shyamalan calls the current state of Hollywood "completely dysfunctional," citing the emphasis on franchise films and commercial success over artistic integrity. He attributes this shift to the major studios, which now rely on pre-existing franchises and superhero characters. Shyamalan, who has maintained his creative freedom by producing outside the studio system, believes the industry has lost its focus on storytelling for the widest audience. He continues to produce original, risk-taking films, such as his upcoming apocalyptic horror tale "Knock at the Cabin."

images.alt_text: US director Steven Spielberg (centre) poses with the awards for Best Director - Motion Picture and Best Picture - Drama for "The Fabelmans" alongside Seth Rogen (2nd left), Michelle Williams (3rd right) and US actor Paul Dano (right) at the 80th annual Golden Globe Awards in Beverly Hills, California, on Jan 10, 2023.

Malaysian actress Michelle Yeoh poses with the award for Best Actress - Motion Picture - Musical/Comedy for "Everything Everywhere All at Once" in the press room during the 80th annual Golden Globe Awards at The Beverly Hilton hotel in Beverly Hills, California, on January 10, 2023.

site_title: Fifa’s US$2b loan deals to Swiss capital gets pushback
summary: Swiss city Bern is pushing back against borrowing $2.6 billion from FIFA, citing concerns over the football governing body's past corruption scandals. Councillors have tabled a motion to establish governance rules on borrowing from FIFA, which has offered short-term financing to Swiss municipalities since 2017. FIFA justifies the deals as part of its prudent money-market management strategy, but critics argue that the city should be cautious about borrowing from an organization with a history of corruption.

images.alt_text: Argentina won their first World Cup trophy since 1986 by beating France in a penalty shootout in the final in Qatar on Dec 18, 2022.

Following the approval of changes agreed at a Fifa Council meeting in Doha, agents can take a maximum 3 per cent commission for any transfer above US$200,000 and 5 per cent for deals under US$200,000.

site_title: AmEx misses profit estimate as loan-loss provisions weigh
summary: American Express (AmEx) reported a fourth-quarter profit that missed market estimates, citing increased loan-loss provisions to prepare for a worsening economy. The credit card giant's largely wealthy customers helped sustain card member spending volumes during the holiday season, but the looming recession and inflation concerns have led to a rise in debt defaults. AmEx stockpiled more rainy-day funds to address the potential economic downturn, wrapping up a turbulent quarter for major US card companies.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: Credit card is seen in front of displayed American Express logo in this illustration taken, July 15, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: EU may pay more for Pfizer Covid vaccines in return for lower volume
summary: The European Union is discussing with Pfizer and BioNTech the possibility of reducing the 500 million Covid-19 vaccine doses committed to buy this year in exchange for a higher price due to a global glut of vaccines. The talks also consider an extension of the delivery deadline to the second half of 2024. The EU's drug regulator reported disappointing uptake of booster doses, and EU member states complain of strained budgets, prompting the negotiations. A tiered-pricing approach is being considered, with prices varying by volume and national income tiers.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: A medical worker fills a syringe with a dose of the Pfizer-BioNTech coronavirus disease (COVID-19) vaccine as Japan launches its inoculation campaign, at Tokyo Medical Center in Tokyo, Japan February 17, 2021. Behrouz Mehri/Pool via REUTERS/File Photo/File Photo

Moderna said it was filing these lawsuits to protect the innovative mRNA technology platform that it pioneered, invested billions of dollars in creating, and patented during the decade preceding the Covid-19 pandemic.
Vials of the Pfizer-BioNTech Comirnaty Covid-19 vaccine. BioNTech and partner Pfizer Inc are counting on an Omicron-adapted vaccine to reinvigorate sales for the rest of the year.
The vaccine partners earlier got formal approval for their Covid-19 vaccine for teens 16 and older.
Novavax slumped 20 per cent on Friday (Jun 4) after US regulators raised concerns over the biotech’s much-anticipated Covid-19 vaccine.
PFIZER and partner BioNTech have completed the filing with the US drugs regulator seeking authorization for their Covid-19 vaccine in children under 5 years of age.
Pfizer and BioNTech are currently testing other versions of the vaccine targeted at the Omicron variant of the coronavirus.

site_title: Starhill Global Reit posts 2.2% rise in H1 FY22/23 DPU
summary: Starhill Global Reit reported a 2.2% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) for the first half of FY2022/2023, reaching S$0.0182, due to asset enhancement works, lower rental assistance, and higher rental contributions from its Singapore office. Gross revenue rose 4.1% to S$94.7 million, while net property income (NPI) increased 6.7% to S$74.3 million. The Reit maintained a stable portfolio occupancy of 97.1% and continues to upgrade existing assets.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
Wisma Atria Taxi Stand.

site_title: German web hosting firm Ionos targets IPO value of up to US$3.4b
summary: German web hosting firm Ionos is targeting an initial public offering (IPO) valuation of up to €3.15 billion, with an expected market capitalization of €4.5 billion. The IPO is expected to run from January 30 to February 7, with a price range of €18.50 to €22.50 per share. If successful, Ionos will have a free float of 17.3% and will debut on the Frankfurt bourse the following day. The company aims to strengthen its growth trajectory with the IPO, which was influenced by a reference point of US peer GoDaddy.

images.alt_text: SoftBank shouldered big writedowns on investments in some of the world’s most high-flying startups, resulting in deep losses last year.
The baht’s recent rally is unnerving Thai exporters, manufacturers and some companies that complain the currency’s rapid gain is eroding their competitiveness and the nation’s economic recovery.

site_title: Prada appoints former Luxottica chief Guerra as new CEO
summary: Prada appointed Andrea Guerra, 57, as its new CEO, succeeding Patrizio Bertelli and Miuccia Prada. Guerra will receive a monthly remuneration of around 151,000 euros, including a director's fee of 50,000 euros per annum. The move eases a transition to the next generation of the founding family, as announced in December.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Italian luxury fashion house Prada's logo is seen at a store in Zurich, Switzerland October 26, 2016.   REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann/File Photo

site_title: India's Vedanta profit plummets 41% on soft metal prices
summary: Vedanta, an Indian metals-to-oil conglomerate, reported a 41% drop in third-quarter profit to 24.64 billion rupees due to a 15% fall in zinc and aluminium prices, despite a 17% surge in total expenses. The company's earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortisation fell 35.1% year-on-year, while aluminium production and refined metal production dropped 2%. Vedanta's results continue to be impacted by the Indian government's windfall tax on crude oil.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: A man walks past the logo of Vedanta outside its headquarters in Mumbai, India January 31, 2018. REUTERS/Danish Siddiqui/File Photo

site_title: Chip stocks extend gains in Asia, defying Intel’s sales warning
summary: Asian semiconductor stocks rose 0.6% on Friday, defying Intel's sales warning, as investors look for a potential recovery in the sector. Intel's weak forecast was due to sluggish PC demand, but demand from industries such as cars and cloud computing is strong. Asian chip stocks have climbed this month, with Samsung shares continuing to rise despite its worst profit drop in a decade. Analysts see potential for a V-shaped recovery, but some are sceptical about the prospects.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong continued its new year rally, while Tokyo, Sydney, Seoul, Singapore, Wellington, Manila and Jakarta were also on the rise.
The chipmaker also has been cutting costs to cope with the slowdown.

site_title: China domestic tourism picks up over New Year holiday as Covid curbs end
summary: China's domestic tourism rebounded over the Chinese New Year holiday, with 308 million trips made, a 23.1% increase from last year and 88.6% of pre-pandemic levels. Revenue from domestic tourism reached 375.84 billion yuan (S$72.8 billion), 73.1% of 2019 figures. The end of Covid-19 curbs allowed for more trips out of and into China, with 2.39 million trips made in the first six days of the holiday, a 123.9% increase from last year. International travel has yet to recover to pre-Covid levels.

images.alt_text: The government’s target of drawing 25 million overseas holidaymakers in 2023 stands to gain momentum now that China has abandoned its Covid-Zero policy and reopened its borders.
Luxury retailers look forward to Chinese tourists returning to Milan in large numbers.
Louis Vuitton owner LVMH has experienced solid growth despite soaring inflation and slowing economies, making the French luxury group a darling among investors.
Thailand is estimated to have welcomed at least 11.5 million foreign travellers last year, surpassing the initial 10 million estimate.
Malaysia's tourism industry players observed that there are increasing number of Chinese tourists choose to travel in smaller groups and more outdoor activities due to health safety concerns.

site_title: Hong Kong dollar pessimists stage a comeback
summary: Hong Kong dollar pessimists are gaining traction as borrowing costs remain low, making it lucrative for traders to borrow the currency cheaply and sell it against the US dollar. The Hong Kong dollar has fallen nearly 1% from its 18-month high in December due to the widening gap with the US equivalent, with the benchmark one-month Hong Kong Interbank Offered Rate now 160 basis points below the London Interbank Offered Rate. Experts predict the Hong Kong dollar may stay near the weaker half of its trading band, with USD/HKD likely to stay above 7.80 in the near term.

site_title: The Philippines won't cooperate with ICC investigation
summary: The International Criminal Court (ICC) plans to reopen an investigation into the Philippines' 'war on drugs' and other human rights abuses during former President Rodrigo Duterte's term. The Philippines' justice secretary, Jesus Crispin Remulla, has refused to cooperate, calling the ICC's move "irritant" and saying the court has no jurisdiction over the country. Remulla stated the ICC should not impose on the Philippines, which is no longer a signatory to the international tribunal. The ICC's decision has been criticized by human rights groups, who say it's the only credible path to justice for victims and their families.

images.alt_text: Rights groups say Duterte created a climate of impunity that led to an estimated tens of thousands of deaths at the hands of police, hitmen and vigilantes, even without proof that victims were involved in drugs.

site_title: India's Adani slammed by US$48 billion stock rout, clouding record share sale
summary: India's Adani Group, controlled by billionaire Gautam Adani, has faced a significant stock rout, with seven listed companies losing a combined $48 billion in market capitalization since Wednesday. A scathing report by US short seller Hindenburg Research has raised concerns about Adani's debt levels and use of tax havens. The report has cast doubts on Adani's record $2.45 billion secondary share sale, which started on Friday. The conglomerate's shares have plummeted, with Adani Enterprises' stock falling 20% and US dollar-denominated bonds issued by Adani Green Energy extending their falls to their lowest since November.

images.alt_text: Chairperson of Indian conglomerate Adani Group, Gautam Adani, speaks at the World Congress of Accountants in Mumbai on November 19, 2022. (Photo by INDRANIL MUKHERJEE / AFP)
Adani Enterprises aims to use the share sale proceeds for capital expenditure and to pay debt.
FILE PHOTO: The logo of the Adani Group is seen on the facade of one of its buildings on the outskirts of Ahmedabad, India, April 13, 2021. REUTERS/Amit Dave/File Photo
Hindenburg vs Adani: The short seller taking on Asia’s richest person

Gautam Adani, who chairs Indian conglomerate Adani Group. Adani Enterprises last week set the floor price for India’s largest follow-on public offer (FPO) at 3,112 rupees per share, with a price cap of 3,276 rupees apiece.

site_title: Londoners are selling homes on WhatsApp in booming private sales market
summary: Almost a quarter of London homes were sold off-market in the final three months of last year, according to Hamptons International, with £1 million-plus homes accounting for a record share of off-market sales. The trend is driven by luxury buyers and sellers seeking privacy, with WhatsApp becoming the preferred platform for negotiations. High-end buyers and sellers value discretion, and strong off-market sales are expected to continue through 2023, with some sellers opting to start off-market before deciding to market their homes more widely.

images.alt_text: UK home buyers seek energy-efficient properties as prices tumble
The average cost of a home fell to £295,000 in November, down by £1,000 from the month before but £28,000 more than a year ago, the Office for National Statistics (ONS) said on Wednesday (Jan 18).
A person on a bicycle rides past houses on a street early in the morning in Islington, London, Britain, June 22, 2020. REUTERS/Simon Newman/

site_title: Russian banks’ profits slumped around 90% in 2022: Central bank
summary: Russian banks' profits plummeted around 90% in 2022 to 203 billion roubles (S$3.8 billion), due to Western sanctions and outflows of depositors. The sanctions blocked access to the Swift international payments system, forcing several key banks to shut operations in Europe. Despite a first-half loss of 1.5 trillion roubles, banks managed to offset it by year-end, but 104 unprofitable banks were reported, down from 130 in the middle of the year. Moscow has intensified efforts to reduce exposure to US dollars and other "unfriendly" currencies.

images.alt_text: Russia’s budget is increasingly squeezed as President Vladimir Putin’s invasion heads for its second year and the economy contracts under sweeping US and European sanctions.
The outlook for rates has become so murky that central bank governor Elvira Nabiullina wouldn’t rule out that the central bank’s next move may be a hike, a scenario that doesn’t look likely for now.

site_title: Reits lead Singapore stocks higher on Friday; STI notches 4-day winning streak
summary: Singapore stocks rose for a fourth consecutive day, with the Straits Times Index (STI) gaining 0.5% or 17.02 points to close at 3,394.21. Real estate investment trusts (Reits) led the gains, with Keppel DC Reit and other Reits rising between 1.6% and 3%. The broader market saw 335 gainers outnumbering 222 losers, with 1.6 billion securities worth S$1.4 billion traded.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
Hong Kong continued its new year rally, while Tokyo, Sydney, Seoul, Singapore, Wellington, Manila and Jakarta were also on the rise.

site_title: UK's Hunt pledges to boost growth but won't budge on tax hikes
summary: UK Finance Minister Jeremy Hunt vowed to boost growth through post-Brexit reforms, but refused to budge on tax hikes. Hunt focused on growth industries like digital technology and renewable power, calling for a competitive tax regime. He acknowledged Britain's poor productivity and vowed to tackle it, but emphasized the need for public spending restraint. Hunt's comments come ahead of a budget statement in March, which is expected to outline a plan for long-term prosperity. The UK's economy has grown more than France and Germany since 2010, but remains the only G7 economy to fail to recover its pre-pandemic size.

images.alt_text: With the latest inflation data, some economists are starting to talk about an end to the Bank of England's tightening cycle, which has delivered the fastest rate rises in three decades.

site_title: UOB raises S$2.4 million for charity in annual CNY celebrations
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) raised S$2.4 million for charity in its annual Chinese New Year celebrations, with funds going towards supporting charitable causes and innovation efforts by small and medium-sized enterprises. The event included art workshops and a gala dinner with 1,500 clients, featuring an auction of two festive-themed art pieces that raised S$483,888. The funds will support charitable causes such as arts, children, and education, as well as innovation efforts by enterprises.

images.alt_text: As of January 2023, LAMOAH has recruited 14 persons with disabilities, with the help of grant support provided by SGUnited Jobs & Skills Schemes for Persons with Disabilities from SG Enable.
The festive bags, or fu dais, are packed by more than 1,300 volunteers over two days.
