site_title: Burning trees in the Amazon could melt snow in the Himalayas
summary: Scientists have discovered a previously unknown atmospheric pathway originating in the Amazon rainforest, stretching 20,000 km to Central Asia, and potentially influencing climate systems worldwide. The connection suggests that Amazonian warming can lead to melting glaciers in the Himalayas and Antarctica, highlighting the interconnectedness of distant ecosystems. This discovery raises concerns about tipping points, where the collapse of one ecosystem could destabilize others, leading to severe climate consequences.

images.alt_text: Aerial view showing the Essequibo River running in a section of the Amazon rainforest in the Potaro-Siparuni region of Guyana.

Buying carbon credits by financing projects to protect rainforests has become a popular way for companies to claim they are carbon neutral, even though their activities generate gases that cause global warming.

site_title: Founders’ dispute: Court finds Incomlend co-founder breached shareholders’ deed
summary: A High Court in Singapore ruled that a co-founder of fintech startup Incomlend breached a shareholders' deed, after his two co-founders brought a case against him for failing to leave his full-time job at HSBC. The court did not find a forced sale of the founder's shares justified, as the sale occurred under an invalid mechanism. Instead, the court found that the co-founders could have lawfully obtained the shares for free under a different mechanism, forcing the founder to become a full-time employee of the company.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
Stripe and other tech firms have seen valuations drop as the growth in online spending slowed in the aftermath of the pandemic.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's non-landed property prices rose 0.3% in Q4 2022, a decrease from the 4.4% increase in the previous quarter. This marks a 0.4% increase from the 3.8% rise in the previous quarter. Overall, 2022 saw a 8.6% increase in non-landed property prices.

site_title: Apple’s iPhone dominated China last quarter despite disruptions
summary: Apple dominated China's smartphone market last quarter, securing nearly 24% of sales despite disruptions, including COVID lockdowns and worker protests. The company saw lower demand for its latest iPhone generation, but shipments from domestic rivals were also impacted by economic slowdowns. Apple's iPhone Pro models remained in high demand, but deliveries were challenged. This marks the company's second-biggest seller in China on an annualized basis.

site_title: Latest Singapore Savings Bond undersubscribed; 10-year average return at 2.97%
summary: Singapore's latest Savings Bonds (SSBs) tranche received S$477.1 million in applications, below the S$700 million allotment. The 10-year average return fell to 2.97%, lower than previous issuances. The February tranche offers a 2.84% first-year interest rate. The auction for a 10-year Singapore Government Securities (SGS) bond also closed with a cut-off yield of 2.86%, drawing S$5.8 billion in applications. This marks a test of demand for lower yield levels, with the US Federal Reserve profile expected to be dovish in 2023.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
MONEY - CURRENCY - SINGAPORE DOLLAR - SGD

site_title: Djokovic’s father to skip Australian Open semis after Russian flag fallout
summary: Novak Djokovic's father, Srdjan Djokovic, will not attend his son's Australian Open semi-final match due to controversy surrounding a group of pro-Russia fans he was filmed with after his quarter-final win. Srdjan Djokovic denied intentionally joining the group, stating he was merely celebrating his son's victory and taking photos with fans. Tennis Australia reiterated its ban on Russian and Belarusian flags at the event, and removed protest instigators from the venue. The decision comes amid pressure from figures like Ukrainian tennis player Alexandr Dolgopolov and Ukraine's ambassador to Australia.

site_title: Demand for luxury goods rebounding from year-end slowdown, says LVMH
summary: LVMH, the owner of Louis Vuitton, reported solid growth despite soaring inflation and slowing economies, driven by a rebound in luxury demand in China. The company's performance in China "recovered very significantly" in January, with key fashion and leather goods sales rising 10% in the final three months of 2022. LVMH's shares have risen 17% so far this year, with billionaire Bernard Arnault confident of the company's performance in 2023, but remaining vigilant about current uncertainties.

images.alt_text: Bernard Arnault, chairman and CEO of LVMH, speaks during a news conference on the company's 2022 annual results in Paris, France, Jan 26, 2023.

Bernard Arnault, chairman of LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton, attends the LVMH Innovation Award ceremony at the Viva Technology conference dedicated to innovation and startups at the Porte de Versailles exhibition center in Paris, France June 16, 2022. REUTERS/Benoit Tessier
“We are running out of stock” for some top champagnes, chief executive Philippe Schaus said in an interview at the New Economy Forum in Singapore

site_title: India’s Tata Motors up 8.2% after posting shock Q4 profit
summary: Tata Motors reported its first quarterly profit in two years, with a surprise profit of 29.6 billion rupees (S$476.6 million) in Q4 2022, beating analysts' expectations of a 185.6 million loss. The company's luxury car unit, Jaguar Land Rover, turned profitable due to improving semiconductor supplies and rising demand. Shares rose 8.2% to a four-month high, with the stock trading up 5.2% at 440 rupees.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Tata Motors logos are pictured outside their flagship showroom in Mumbai May 28, 2013. Picture taken May 28, 2013. REUTERS/Vivek Prakash/File Photo
A man charges an electric vehicle in Gurugram. India, one of the world’s fastest growing oil markets, has lagged major economic peers in Europe and Asia in the adoption of EVs.
A bird flies over a logo of Air India airlines at the corporate headquarters in Mumbai, India, October 19, 2021. REUTERS/Francis Mascarenhas

site_title: Housing market has slowed, government to monitor  prices and borrowing: DPM Heng
summary: Singapore's housing market has slowed, with property prices increasing 8.6% in 2022, down from 10.6% in 2021. The government will continue to monitor prices and borrowing, with Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasizing the need to ensure affordability and prevent a destabilizing correction. Despite global uncertainties and increased supply, property prices remain buoyant, with demand for owner-occupied homes remaining strong. Mortgage interest rates have also increased, with the Singapore Overnight Rate Average rising to 3% in the past year.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei
Redas seeks longer project sales period for land acquired before latest cooling measures
Tan is also the chairman of Keppel Reit Management and senior managing director of urban development at Keppel Corporation.

site_title: India market regulator increases scrutiny of Adani group: sources
summary: India's Securities and Exchange Board of India (Sebi) has increased scrutiny of Adani Group's transactions over the past year, examining transactions in the listed space and studying a report by short-seller Hindenburg Research. The report accused Adani Group of improper use of offshore tax havens and high debt, leading to a massive sell-off of India-listed shares. Sebi has been asking for disclosures it ordinarily does not, and the regulator has examined an offshore special purpose vehicle used for the Adani Group's acquisition of Holcim's stake in Ambuja Cements and ACC.

images.alt_text: Chairperson of Indian conglomerate Adani Group, Gautam Adani, speaks at the World Congress of Accountants in Mumbai on November 19, 2022. (Photo by INDRANIL MUKHERJEE / AFP)

site_title: South Korea pension fund will deplete faster than expected
summary: South Korea's National Pension Service (NPS) will deplete its funds two years earlier than expected, by 2055, due to a shrinking population and low economic growth. The NPS had 915 trillion won (S$974.1 billion) of funds as of October 2022, equivalent to 42% of that year's estimated annual GDP. The pension system, launched in 1988, will start to shrink after 2040, prompting President Yoon Suk-yeol to promise sweeping reforms to make it more sustainable.

site_title: India plans to classify clean activities, technologies under a new policy
summary: India is developing a policy to classify economic activities and technologies into sustainable and non-sustainable categories to attract green investment. The proposal, similar to the EU's Green Taxonomy, aims to certify sustainable activities, giving investors extra comfort. The renewable energy and finance ministries are working on the draft policy, which is the first step in identifying sustainable projects and phasing out non-sustainable ones. India aims to attract $10-$15 trillion in investment to achieve net-zero carbon emissions by 2070, with a focus on hydrogen fuel, electric cars, and solar panels.

site_title: Philips plans reorganisation and job cuts
summary: Philips plans to reorganize and cut 1,000 jobs in the Netherlands, in addition to its previously announced 4,000 job cuts, as part of a broader restructuring effort. The move comes after a 70% decline in its share price since mid-2021 due to a recall of respiration devices. New CEO Roy Jakobs will outline his strategic plan during the company's earnings report on Monday. Analysts expect a fourth-quarter net profit of 140 million euros, down from 507 million euros in the same period in 2021.

site_title: BOJ deploys funds-supply tool again as yields creep up
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) extended its funds-supply operation for the second time, offering five-year loans to financial institutions to defend its yield control policy. The move aims to prevent rising bond yields from exceeding the central bank's 0.5% cap. The BOJ will conduct the operation starting from February 1, with the amount of loans to be offered announced on the same day. The move comes after the 10-year Japanese government bond yield crept up near the cap due to data showing a near 42-year high in core consumer inflation.

images.alt_text: Finance Minister Shunichi Suzuki notes that Japan’s public finances have increased in severity to an unprecedented degree due to supplementary budgets to respond to the coronavirus and similar issues.

site_title: Inside the over-the-top hotel opening beside Buckingham Palace
summary: The Peninsula London, a new luxury hotel beside Buckingham Palace, is set to open later this year. Designed by architect Peter Marino, the 190-room property features extravagant amenities, including state-of-the-art phones and a "valet box" for discreet guest service. The hotel's rooftop restaurant, Brooklands, will be led by Michelin-starred chef Claude Bosi, and its ground-floor restaurant, Canton Blue, will offer Chinese specialties. The hotel also houses 25 apartments, with some already sold to high-profile buyers, including a £100 million penthouse purchased by Citadel Securities' CEO Ken Griffin.

images.alt_text: People shop at the Sanya International Duty-Free Shopping Complex in Sanya, Hainan province, China. Nov 25, 2020.
Dubai's new Atlantis The Royal in the background, with views of villas on the waterside of the Palm Jumeirah.

site_title: FCT cements position as heartland mall king with Nex acquisition: analysts
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) has acquired a 50% stake in suburban mall Nex, jointly with Frasers Property, for S$652.5 million. The joint acquisition makes FCT the "largest suburban retail landlord" in Singapore, according to analysts. This move is seen as an "accretive and sizeable acquisition" that diversifies FCT's portfolio and solidifies its position as the "suburban king" in Singapore. Analysts predict further growth potential for the trust post-acquisition.

images.alt_text: Frasers Centrepoint and sponsor Frasers Property has acquired a 50 per cent stake in NEX for S$652.5 million
Hong Kong-listed Link Reit won the race to acquire Jurong Point and Swing By @ Thomson Plaza for S$2.16 billion.
Tenant sales in at 313@Somerset exceeds pre-Covid levels in Q3.

site_title: Thailand’s ruling party picks veteran kingmaker Prawit as PM candidate
summary: Thailand's ruling Palang Pracharat party has chosen veteran kingmaker Prawit Wongsuwon as its prime minister candidate, setting him up as a likely opponent to Paetongtarn Shinawatra, daughter of self-exiled former premier Thaksin Shinawatra. Prawit, 77, is a skilled political dealmaker and current deputy prime minister, while Paetongtarn, 44, has declared her readiness for the top job. The move is seen as a strategic bid to ensure the party's grip on power, with Prawit potentially teaming up with incumbent prime minister Prayut Chan-o-cha, a former army chief.

images.alt_text: “We want the party to win the election by a landslide so the promises we made to the people can be realised,”  Paetongtarn Shinawatra said.

site_title: 2023 BMW X1: A BMW for every bunny
summary: The 2023 BMW X1 is a family car first and Sport Utility Vehicle (SUV) second, making it suitable for those who need a roomy interior and versatile boot, despite its lack of powerful engine. The X1's 1.5-liter engine, which produces 122 horsepower, qualifies for a Category A COE, making it an affordable option for those in Singapore. The car's elevated ride height and rugged stance make it suitable for daily driving, but its true purpose is as a family vehicle, not a high-performance SUV.

site_title: Irish real estate returns drop amid higher interest rates
summary: Ireland's real estate market experienced a 4% drop in returns for the final three months of 2022, with the market value of property assets decreasing from 7.01 billion euros to 6.72 billion euros. This decline is attributed to rising interest rates, persistent inflationary pressures, and economic uncertainty. Irish banks, however, are exposed to commercial real estate markets in other EU countries, and the sector's stress may be mitigated by reduced transmission risk to the broader economy.

images.alt_text: Canada’s housing crisis is becoming more acute as its longstanding home shortage is met with record levels of immigration.

site_title: Thai Finance Ministry sees sustained baht gains on tourism boom
summary: The Thai Finance Ministry forecasts the baht to average 32.50 to a US dollar this year, stronger than the previously predicted 36.68. This is due to a tourism boom, with an estimated 27.5 million travelers expected to generate 1.2 trillion baht in tourism revenue. This is significantly higher than the 360 billion baht in receipts from 11.2 million visitors last year. The stronger currency is expected to propel Thailand's growth to its highest in five years.

images.alt_text: Thailand’s economic recovery has lagged that of other South-east Asian nations, with the crucial tourism sector just starting to pick up last year with 11.15 million foreign arrivals.

site_title: BT Market Focus: Enthusiastic hop into the Rabbit year (Ep 29)
summary: Investors in Singapore and the region remained enthusiastic despite a short trading week. According to Market Focus, a weekly podcast by The Business Times, the market's positive sentiment can be attributed to several factors, including a rebound in the US dollar and a decline in global inflation expectations. Additionally, the US Federal Reserve's decision to keep interest rates steady was seen as a positive sign. Claressa Monteiro, the host of Market Focus, analyzed these market movements and provided insights into the drivers behind the investors' enthusiasm.

images.alt_text: Christopher Lim
Find out why tepid sentiment challenged markets this week.
What caused the optimism which drove markets this week?

site_title: Adani rout deepens to more than US$50b, pressuring Asia’s richest man
summary: Billionaire Gautam Adani, Asia's richest man, faces pressure as shares of his Adani Group companies have lost over US$50 billion in market value in less than two sessions. A scathing report by US short seller Hindenburg Research sparked a selloff, eroding Adani's net worth and threatening investor sentiment for his upcoming US$2.5 billion share sale. Some group stocks, including Adani Green Energy and Adani Total Gas, tumbled 20% each on Friday, while Adani Enterprises lost 9.7%.

images.alt_text: Chairperson of Indian conglomerate Adani Group, Gautam Adani, speaks at the World Congress of Accountants in Mumbai on November 19, 2022. (Photo by INDRANIL MUKHERJEE / AFP)
Adani Enterprises aims to use the share sale proceeds for capital expenditure and to pay debt.

site_title: Japan, Netherlands to join US in chip controls on China
summary: US, Netherlands, and Japan are set to limit China's access to advanced semiconductor machinery, aiming to undercut Beijing's ambitions to build domestic chip capabilities. The US-imposed export controls, expanded upon by the Netherlands and Japan, will restrict ASML Holding and Nikon, crucial for making advanced chips. China has filed a dispute with the World Trade Organization in response, while ASML's CEO warns that the US campaign could push Beijing to develop its own technology. The joint effort aims to curb China's military and artificial intelligence advancements.

images.alt_text: Republicans who control the House intend to use the debt-ceiling deadline as leverage to extract deep spending cuts from the White House and congressional Democrats.

site_title: ECB seen delivering two half-point rate hikes on way to may peak
summary: The European Central Bank is expected to deliver two half-point rate hikes in the coming months, with borrowing costs potentially reaching 3.75% by May. Economists predict the deposit rate will be held at 3.25% for about a year, followed by a series of quarter-point cuts starting in June 2024. Despite 250 basis points of rate rises, many analysts believe officials are still behind the curve in tackling inflation, which remains above the 2% target. The ECB is also set to shrink its bond portfolio and reduce its holdings of public and corporate bonds.

images.alt_text: While global investors agree that things should quieten down for the euro, European policymakers continue to push back against this market positioning.

site_title: Economists finally have a good excuse for being wrong
summary: Economists' predictions have proven wrong again, as the US may avoid a recession despite tightened monetary policy. Contrary to predictions, the US economy may experience a "soft landing" rather than a hard landing. This challenges the underlying aggregate demand model and highlights the limitations of macroeconomic forecasting. The article cites examples of past economists, including Larry Summers, who have been correct in their warnings but later proven wrong. The uncertainty surrounding economic models and the inability to accurately predict outcomes is emphasized, suggesting that economists should be cautious in their predictions and not overconfident in their models.

images.alt_text: The full impact of rate hikes can take a year or more to show up in economies.
Key economic indicators appear to have turned up of late, yet the world economy is weaker than at any point since the lockdowns of 2020.
Some 18 per cent considered a world recession “extremely likely” in World Economic Forum (WEF) survey, more than twice as many as in the previous survey conducted in September 2022.

site_title: Adani begins big share sale as short seller triggers US$37b rout
summary: India's Adani Group began a $2.45 billion secondary share sale for retail investors on January 27, amid a heavy selloff in Adani companies after a US-based short seller flagged concerns over debt levels and tax havens. Seven Adani-listed companies have lost $36.5 billion in market value since Wednesday, with bonds and shares of Adani firms also falling. The company aims to use the sale proceeds for capital expenditure and debt repayment, dismissing the report as baseless.

images.alt_text: Adani New Industries, Adani Airport Holdings, Adani Road Transport, AdaniConnex and the group’s metals and mining units will become independent units.

site_title: Hong Kong home prices drop 15.6% in 2022, snap 13 years of gain
summary: Hong Kong's private home prices dropped 15.6% in 2022, marking the first annual decline since 2008. This followed seven consecutive months of decline, with prices falling 2.0% in December to their lowest since April 2017. Weakened economic outlook and rising mortgage costs contributed to the decline. Real estate consultancies predict home prices to remain soft in 2023, stabilizing in the second half after an expected peak in interest rates.

site_title: IMF urges Sweden to boost capacity to deal with property risks
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has urged Sweden to boost its capacity to deal with property risks, citing a funding squeeze facing property companies due to plummeting house prices over the last nine months. The IMF recommends that Sweden require banks to hold more capital and increase funding for its financial regulator to mitigate potential risks to financial stability. Despite having strong capital and liquidity positions, Sweden needs to be vigilant about risks to its financial stability, particularly in the property sector.

images.alt_text: The old town of Gamla Stan in Stockholm. Swedish public housing is carefully conceptualised to be spacious and have leisure spaces such as playgrounds.

site_title: Brokers’ take: OCBC lifts fair value estimate for CapitaLand Investment on more expected divestments
summary: OCBC Investment Research has lifted its fair value estimate for CapitaLand Investment (CLI) to S$4.05, citing expected divestments and a potential beneficiary of China's faster-than-expected reopening. The brokerage rates CLI at "hold" but views the index counter as a potential beneficiary. CLI is expected to target more divestments of assets held on its balance sheet in 2023, which would increase its funds under management. The loosening of Covid restrictions in China is expected to drive CLI's recovery efforts, particularly in its retail and lodging management businesses.

site_title: US wants WTO dispute system fixed by 2024
summary: The US is leading consultations with over 70 countries to reform the World Trade Organization's (WTO) trade dispute arbitration system, aiming for it to be fully functioning by the end of 2024. Deputy US Trade Representative Maria Pagan said the US is committed to reforms, including alternatives like mediation, and has discussed 12 reform themes with countries. The WTO's appeals bench has been mothballed for over two years due to blockages of adjudicator appointments, and 24 cases are stuck in legal purgatory.

images.alt_text: Participants of the JSI have committed to intensifying negotiations.

site_title: Japan PM says can’t rule out return of deflation despite price spike
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida said that a return of deflation in Japan's economy cannot be ruled out due to weak domestic demand, despite a 42-year high in Tokyo's consumer inflation in January. Kishida attributed inflation to high global raw material prices and a weak yen, not strong domestic demand. The Bank of Japan's recent decision to allow 10-year bond yields to move in a slightly wider range has sparked speculation about a gradual exit from its super-loose policy, but Kishida described the move as an operational tweak.

images.alt_text: Reflecting snowballing debt, interest payments would nearly double from 8.6 trillion yen for fiscal 2023 to 17.1 trillion yen by the end of the forecast period, the draft government estimate shows.
With inflation risks tilted to the upside and price expectations rising, wages now hold the key to whether price growth will be able to stay above Tokyo's 2 per cent target.

The increase in Tokyo's core consumer prices, which was driven mostly by food and fuel bills but spread to a broader range of goods, will likely keep the Bank of Japan under pressure to phase out its massive stimulus programme, analysts say.

site_title: Consumer inflation in Japan’s capital exceeds BOJ goal for 8th month
summary: Japan's consumer inflation in Tokyo exceeded the Bank of Japan's 2% target for the 8th consecutive month, with core consumer prices rising 4.3% in January from a year earlier. The increase, driven by food and fuel bills, puts pressure on the BOJ to phase out its stimulus program. The Tokyo core consumer price index rose 3.0% in January, marking the fastest year-on-year increase since 1981. Analysts expect the BOJ to keep monetary policy loose until wages rise more, changing the recent cost-push inflation into inflation driven by domestic demand.

site_title: Tata’s Air India to seal half of jumbo plane order: sources
summary: Air India is set to seal half of its order for 495 jets with Boeing and engine suppliers, worth billions of dollars, as its new owner seeks to revive the airline and compete with larger rivals. The order includes 190 Boeing 737 Max, 20 Boeing 787s, and 10 Boeing 777X planes. The second half of the order, including 235 Airbus single-aisle jets and 40 Airbus A350 widebody aircraft, is expected to be finalized over the coming days. The deal aims to put Air India in the league of large global airlines and make it an influential customer for planemakers and suppliers.

images.alt_text: Vistara will receive its pending order for 17 aircraft by mid-2024, taking its total fleet to 70 planes.

site_title: The US debt ceiling: A slow burn, not a big bang
summary: The US debt ceiling is set to be reached, prompting the Treasury to use extraordinary measures to pay bills and service debt. A default is unlikely, but a temporary fiscal hit is expected, with the Treasury prioritizing interest payments and delaying spending. The impact on the economy will be a slow burn, building to a bigger problem if the debt ceiling is not raised by early June. A potential sequestration deal could mitigate the effects, but lasting spending cuts could have a material impact on economic growth. Market reaction will likely be measured, with a risk-off sentiment and potential sell-off in equities, but a buyer's strike on US Treasuries is unlikely.

images.alt_text: A board at a bus stop in Washington showing the US national debt figure after the US government hit its US$31.4 trillion borrowing limit on Jan 19 amid a standoff between the Republican-controlled House of Representatives, President Joe Biden and Democratic legislators that could lead to a fiscal crisis in a few months.
Unfortunately, allowing the GOP to drive the US economy off a cliff may be President Joe Biden’s best option right now.
A default on the US debt could ignite a global financial crisis and force the fragile American economy into a full-blown recession.

site_title: Thai finance ministry maintains 2023 GDP growth outlook, sees more tourists
summary: Thailand's finance ministry maintained its 2023 GDP growth outlook at 3.8% due to a rebound in tourism and domestic demand, despite exports expected to slow down. The country's economic recovery lags behind other South-east Asian nations. In 2022, Thailand's economy expanded 3.0% compared to a previous forecast of 3.4%, with exports, public investment, and private consumption slowing down.

site_title: Wells Fargo CEO Scharf’s 2022 pay unchanged at US$24.5m
summary: Wells Fargo CEO Charles Scharf's total compensation for 2022 remained unchanged at US$24.5 million. The bank reported a 50% decline in fourth-quarter profit due to costs related to a fake accounts scandal and potential economic slowdown. This comes as other major banks, including JPMorgan Chase & Co, have increased their CEOs' pay in 2022.

site_title: The stand-up way to lay off
summary: Researchers at Singapore's business schools say layoffs can be carried out in a respectful and humane way. Senior leadership, particularly the CEO, should be visible in the announcement and provide a clear explanation of why the layoffs are necessary and the options considered before resorting to retrenchment. This approach helps maintain trust and respect among employees.

images.alt_text: Layoffs are already painful for workers who are being let go, so why make it worse than it has to be? Yet the recent wave of tech layoffs have unveiled what organisational behaviour researchers and human capital consultants see as corporate callousness reaching new depths.
Rapid interest rate hikes, weak consumer demand and an economic slowdown in China have forced firms such as Amazon, Walt Disney, Facebook-owner Meta and American banks to trim their workforce.
Don't neglect thinking about how to communicate your departure to your colleagues and teams.
The recent spate of widespread layoffs by tech behemoths such as Twitter and Meta marks a  drastic shift away from the rapid and aggressive hiring in the tech sector during the pandemic.

site_title: Gold little changed as traders focus on US inflation data
summary: Gold prices remained unchanged in early Asian hours on January 26, awaiting US inflation data for guidance on the Federal Reserve's rate-hike stance. Spot gold rose 0.1% to $1,931.95 per ounce, while investors await US PCE data for clues on inflation. The US economy maintained a strong pace of growth in the fourth quarter, but momentum appears to have slowed. Market participants expect the Fed to raise interest rates by 25 basis points at its upcoming policy meeting.

images.alt_text: Most investors are expecting the Fed to raise rates by 25 basis points (bps) at its Jan 31-Feb 1 policy meeting.

site_title: Amazon to sell Bay Area office complex as sales growth cools
summary: Amazon is selling a 12-hectare office complex in Milpitas, California, for an undisclosed price, marking the company's latest effort to unwind a pandemic-era expansion that left it with a surplus of warehouses and employees. The decision comes as the company slows its real estate strategy, citing sluggish online sales growth and new municipal regulations in the Bay Area that have stalled development plans. Amazon had paid $123 million for the property in October 2021, but is now expected to take a loss on the sale.

images.alt_text: Amazon is trying to sell unused space in its cargo jets, as it adjusts to a post-pandemic slowdown that has forced it to cut 12,000 employees, or about 6 per cent of its workforce.

site_title: Audi’s new concept car turns from electric SUV into truck
summary: Audi's Activesphere concept vehicle combines the features of an SUV and a truck, with a sliding glass panel to reveal a spacious pickup bed. The vehicle is roughly the same height as the Audi Q4 SUV and features 22-inch knobby tires, a greenhouse-style cabin, and augmented reality headsets for control. The Activesphere runs on electric power with 800-volt charging capability and a range of over 372 miles. While Audi has no plans to send the Activesphere into production, the concept is part of a growing trend of luxury automakers creating off-road capable vehicles to capitalize on the current craze for adventure driving.

images.alt_text: Under the landmark deal, Renault is expected to reduce its 43 per cent stake in Nissan to 15 per cent through an orderly disposal of stock over time.

site_title: India’s EV dawn fans expectations fuel demand may peak early
summary: India's rapid adoption of electric vehicles (EVs) is prompting a shift away from oil production, with petrol consumption expected to peak in the mid-2030s, earlier than previously thought. This growth is driven by investments in new autos and energy infrastructure, and is expected to lead to a significant increase in petrochemical manufacturing. Indian refiners are investing billions of dollars to raise petrochemical capacity, and the country aims to increase EV sales to 30% of new car sales by 2030. Despite challenges, such as limited charging infrastructure and high EV battery costs, the growth of EVs is expected to have a significant impact on India's fuel needs.

images.alt_text: CATL’s 1.8-billion-euro German factory, its first in Europe, sent its first sample battery cells to clients in December 2022.
Hyundai and Kia, its affiliate, rank as the world's third-largest carmaker.
Tesla has cut about US$9.5 billion of debt since its peak in Jun 30, 2020.

site_title: HSBC shares become most overbought since 1986 after 50% rally
summary: HSBC shares have surged 50% to a 11-month high, making them the most overbought in over three decades, with a 14-day relative strength index (RSI) of 90. The rally is driven by China's reopening, expected to unlock up to $750 million in wealth revenues for HSBC. Analysts predict a modest 13% gain over the next 12 months, but note that the strategy of using RSI to trade HSBC hasn't always been promising, with investors who shorted the stock at RSI 70 losing 60% over the past five years.

images.alt_text: The European Commission, the bloc’s executive body, ruled in 2016 that HSBC and six other banks had tried to distort Euribor (euro interbank offered rate), a benchmark for rates on financial products, fining the lender 33.6 million euros.

site_title: Tech layoffs’ missing humanity
summary: Tech layoffs have unveiled corporate callousness, with some companies letting go of workers without addressing them by name or providing personal support. Experts say this is a sign of organisational behavior gone wrong, with workers feeling like just numbers. The practice is seen as a result of the current economic downturn, where companies are cutting costs and prioritizing profits over people. Business school experts emphasize that companies can do better, letting go of workers with empathy and support.

images.alt_text: Senior leadership must be visible in a retrenchment exercise, with the CEO taking on the role of the leading spokesperson for the announcement, said Singapore Management University associate professor Kenneth Tai.

Hung Truong, who remembers feeling relieved after sharing online about his layoff from Lyft at the start of the pandemic, at his home in Seattle on Nov 8, 2022. As Twitter, Meta and other companies that helped create a culture of more workplace transparency slash their work forces, some laid off employees are very publicly using those social media platforms to critique their former employers.
Offices for Twitter in San Francisco, on Oct. 6, 2022.
Microsoft most recently shrank its workforce in October and July, and has eliminated open positions and paused hiring in various groups.
The latest round, scheduled to commence Wednesday, will mostly affect the retail division and human resources.
Microsoft plans to reduce its workforce by 5 per cent.

site_title: Asia: Markets build on rally on hopes US will avoid recession
summary: Asia markets rose on Friday, fueled by US economic data showing growth in 2022, alleviating recession fears. Hong Kong continued its new year rally, while Tokyo, Sydney, and other cities also saw gains. Investors await inflation data and the Federal Reserve's policy decision next week, with hopes for a 25-basis-point interest rate hike. The broadly upbeat tone suggests a positive year for markets, with analysts setting a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for the MSCI global equity index.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks jumped more than 1.0 per cent on Thursday – having already piled on more than 10 per cent in 2023.

site_title: Who wants to live forever?
summary: Countries and companies are facing an aging crisis due to the increasing life expectancy of populations in wealthy nations, with over half of today's 5-year-olds expected to live to at least 100. France's attempt to reform pension rules sparked nationwide strikes and protests, while China's shrinking population poses a threat to economic growth. Experts warn of a "global aging crisis" unless policymakers and business leaders take action to adapt to an older workforce and address rising pension costs. Governments and companies are exploring strategies such as upskilling, reskilling, and multi-generational workplaces to mitigate the impact of aging populations.

images.alt_text: In Japan, the decling birth rate is particularly acute because it has the world’s second-highest proportion of people aged 65 and over.
Children playing in the village square after school in Xiasha village in Shenzhen, China, Nov 16, 2022. Deaths outnumbered births last year in China for the first time in six decades.
An elderly Ukrainian villager on a road on the outskirts of Dibrova on July 23, 2022. The relative balance of risks between demography and climate is changing.

site_title: Biden hammers Republican ‘chaos’ in economic speech
summary: President Joe Biden vowed to veto any Republican legislation threatening the US economy, describing it as "chaos" and "pain" that would harm the world's number one economy. He criticized Republican plans to block the nation's borrowing limit and replace the income tax with a 30% sales tax, labeling the latter as "almost unbelievable." Biden's economic speech, which touted his promise of a US manufacturing rebirth, comes ahead of his expected 2024 re-election bid, which is seen as gaining momentum despite his low popularity.

images.alt_text: The US Treasury is now using extraordinary measures to pay the country's bills and service its debt, as in previous years.
Former US secretary of state Mike Pompeo said that US diplomats convinced both India and Pakistan that neither was preparing to use nuclear weapons against each other in 2019.

Meta announced it would, in the coming weeks, "end the suspension" of Donald Trump's Facebook and Instagram accounts, two years after the former US president was banned following the assault on Capitol Hill.

site_title: Indonesia wants palm oil exporters to trade on local exchanges
summary: Indonesia is studying rules requiring palm oil exporters to trade at least some of their oil on local exchanges before shipping it overseas to improve control and data transparency. The goal is to establish a reference price for a specific palm oil product, helping to ensure the local market is well supplied and increase government tax revenue. This plan echoes Indonesia's earlier one for tin exports, which require trading on a domestic exchange before shipping. The regulatory agency aims to provide incentives for sellers and buyers to trade on local bourses.

images.alt_text: Edible-oil buyers, including price-sensitive consumers in South Asia and Africa, will bear the brunt of the supply-side constraints.

site_title: New Zealand business confidence improves, still weak: ANZ survey
summary: New Zealand's business confidence improved in January, with a net 52% of respondents expecting the economy to deteriorate over the year ahead, down from 70.2% in December. This marks a slight recovery from the November Monetary Policy statement shock. Meanwhile, a net 15.8% of respondents expected their own businesses to shrink in the next 12 months, down from 25.5% last month. The improvement in confidence suggests the economy is showing signs of stabilization.

site_title: Retail sector in better shape than a year ago, say market watchers
summary: Retail sector in Singapore is in a better shape than a year ago, despite a 1.1% drop in central region rents in Q4 2022, according to market watchers. This decline is attributed to the easing of pandemic restrictions allowing retailers to gear up operations with pre-pandemic normalcy. Net take-up of retail space increased by 710,417 sq ft in Q4 2022, taking the full-year 2022 tally to positive 990,279 sq ft. Experts expect occupier demand to remain firm, pushing overall vacancy rates down and supporting rent growth of prime floor space.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala
Prices of retail space in the central region falls by 3.2 per cent in Q3 after it dipped 1.2 per cent in Q2.
Retail spaces in the Orchard Road area grew by 7.4 per cent to S$39.20 per square foot per month in Q4, noted Edmund Tie in a Thursday report.

site_title: Why passive investing makes less sense in the current environment
summary: Investors now face a more complex environment, shifting away from the fixed-menu approach of passive investing, which was attractive in a world of low correlations and artificially low interest rates. With rising inflation, growth risks, and structural shifts, investors need to be more selective and dynamic in their asset allocation. Greater individual stock pick selection and a better understanding of local market conditions are crucial for generating high risk-adjusted returns. Passive strategies, while still attractive, are no longer the only option, and investors must adapt to the changing market landscape.

images.alt_text: While sticking with the familiar, such as Singapore-listed stocks, is sensible, it can be good to become knowledgeable about other markets.
An angel investor are likely to be a male aged between 41 to 55 years-old who invests out of their net worth according to a report by AngelCentral.

site_title: HDB resale price growth slows to 10.4% for 2022 as prices flatten, sales fall in Q4
summary: HDB resale prices rose 10.4% in 2022, the slowest growth in the past year, with a 2.3% quarterly increase in Q4. Sales volumes also declined 12.6% in Q4 to 6,597 units, a 16.9% drop year-over-year. Analysts attribute the slowdown to the cooling measures and seasonal lull, with some towns experiencing median price decreases. The HDB town with the highest median price was Punggol at S$451,000, and the lowest at Geylang at S$335,000. Demand for resale flats is expected to soften in 2023, leading to a slowdown in price growth and market stabilization.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim
As almost 90 per cent of resident households own their homes, one's home is a key asset for many people.

The number of complaints against property agents who are suspected of helping their clients to break the Minimum Occupation Period rules have surged in the past two years, from three cases per year to 20 cases per case.
HDB flats as viewed from Block 79D Toa Payoh Central on March 17, 2022.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Frasers Centrepoint Trust, Frasers Property, Mapletree Industrial Trust
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust and Frasers Property are jointly acquiring a 50% stake in suburban mall Nex for S$652.5 million. Frasers Centrepoint Trust reported a 0.9% increase in shopper traffic and tenant sales for the first quarter of FY2023. Mapletree Industrial Trust's distribution per unit fell 2.9% year-over-year to 3.39 Singapore cents for the third quarter of FY2022/2023.

site_title: Malaysia says Luxembourg court sets aside request to enforce US$15b arbitration award
summary: Malaysia's law minister Azalina Othman Said announced that the District Court of Luxembourg has set aside a request for an "attachment order" made by the Sulu heirs, who won a US$15 billion arbitration award against Malaysia. The award was related to a colonial-era land deal, and Malaysia maintains the process is illegal. The ruling remains enforceable outside France under a United Nations treaty on international arbitration.

images.alt_text: Ms Azalina othman Said, Minister in the Prime Minister’s Department in Malaysia, speaking to the media.

site_title: Royal mail resumes more services after cyber incident
summary: Royal Mail has resumed its International Tracked and Signed, and International Signed services to all destinations for business account customers and online customers starting January 26, two weeks after a cyber incident disrupted its operations.

site_title: This column may, or may not, cause an allergic reaction
summary: Olive Garden added sesame flour to its breadsticks to comply with FDA regulations requiring labels for foods containing sesame, despite concerns it may not be the safest business decision. The FDA's current labelling practices rely on companies to judge the risk of allergens, but experts suggest a better approach grounded in science and risk assessment. The Allergen Bureau of Australia and New Zealand has developed a voluntary industry consortium, Voluntary Incidental Trace Allergen Labelling (VITAL), which publishes thresholds and advisory statements to help companies label foods reflecting actual risks. The US can be a leader in the shift by establishing its own thresholds and risk assessments, benefiting consumers and industry.

images.alt_text: Cotton fabric labelled as "100% recycled fabric". Britain's Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) is concerned that shoppers are being misled and potentially even paying a premium for products that aren’t what they seem.

site_title: Hasbro to cut 1,000 full-time jobs globally in 2023
summary: Hasbro to cut 1,000 full-time jobs globally in 2023, representing about 15% of its full-time workforce. The toymaker estimated fourth-quarter revenue of about US$1.68 billion, down 17% from the previous year. The company also announced the exit of President and Chief Operating Officer Eric Nyman and plans to reduce costs in a tough macroeconomic backdrop. Shares fell 4% to US$61.30 in after-hours trading.

site_title: ‘We need pleasure to survive’
summary: Academic researchers argue that excessive concern over health and wellness can lead to a loss of pleasure and social connection. "We need pleasure to survive," says Morten Kringelbach, a professor of neuroscience. Studies suggest that moderate consumption of substances like alcohol can facilitate social connection and lower social anxiety, while also providing bursts of positive emotion. Experts emphasize the importance of finding balance and moderation, rather than strict abstinence, to achieve a full and meaningful life.

images.alt_text: Oh, for the kind of boredom that can create space for reflection, creativity and a renewed sense of enjoyment and motivation.
Great writing can transport us and delight us, yes, but it can also open our hearts.

site_title: US economy showed momentum at year’s end, defying recession fears
summary: The US economy showed resilience in the final quarter of 2022, with GDP growth at an annual rate of 2.9% when adjusted for inflation. This marked a solid end to a year that saw the economy contract in the first six months before rebounding in the second half. Despite this, inflation remains a concern, and the Federal Reserve is expected to continue increasing interest rates to bring prices under control. A repeat performance in 2023 is uncertain, and the economy's momentum may be tested by ongoing inflation and potential recession fears.

images.alt_text: WASHINGTON, DC - JANUARY 19: The U.S. Capitol Building is seen on January 19, 2023 in Washington, DC. U.S. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen warned Republican and Democratic leaders that the federal government will reach its limit on the amount of money it is able to borrow, and that further action by lawmakers is needed by June 5th when the U.S. could go into economic default.   Anna Moneymaker/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by Anna Moneymaker / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: US shuts down major global ransomware group Hive
summary: The US Justice Department has shut down the Hive ransomware operation, which had extorted over $100 million from more than 1,500 victims worldwide. US authorities, working with German and Dutch law enforcement, infiltrated Hive's website and servers for nearly seven months, helping hundreds of companies avoid paying $130 million in ransom demands. The operation was shut down after US officials obtained digital keys to unlock victims' frozen data, preventing them from having to pay millions of dollars in ransom.

images.alt_text: The cryptocurrency market floundered in 2022, as risk appetite diminished and various crypto firms collapsed.
Identity-based attacks leading to data breaches will continue to be the leading attack vector in Singapore, the writer says.

site_title: US apartment rents rise at slowest annual pace since mid-2021
summary: US apartment rents rose 4.7% in December from a year earlier, the slowest pace since July 2021, according to Rent.com data. The national median apartment price dropped to $1,978, with rental prices falling 1.4% from the previous month. Experts predict rents may decline on a year-over-year basis by late summer, potentially helping to lower US inflation this year.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at Friday’s open; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.1% at the open on Friday, driven by a rise in Q4 private home prices and a decline in retail rents. The Straits Times Index (STI) reached 3,381.02. Gainers outnumbered losers 74 to 42, with Sembcorp Marine and Sinjia Land being among the most actively traded securities. Local banks DBS and OCBC traded mixed, while Yangzijiang Shipbuilding rose 0.8%. The rise follows gains on Wall Street, where investors await the Federal Reserve's monetary policy meeting next week.

images.alt_text: Singapore Exchange (SGX).

site_title: Renault-Nissan alliance reboot will kick off with five projects
summary: Renault and Nissan are rebooting their 20-year alliance with a plan to rebalance capital ties and pursue five industrial projects, known as "reloaded". Renault will reduce its 43% stake in Nissan to 15% through orderly stock disposal, and the companies will equalize their cross-shareholdings. The partnership will also focus on electric vehicles, software, and commercial vehicles. Renault CEO Luca de Meo plans to split the company into five separate businesses, including Ampere, an electric vehicle and software unit.

images.alt_text: Renault is in the middle of a complex split of its business into five different units.

site_title: Intel tumbles after forecast suggests comeback is far off
summary: Intel slumped in late trading after issuing a dire forecast, predicting a revenue range of $10.5-$11.5 billion for the first quarter, down from an analyst estimate of $14 billion. The chipmaker expects to lose 15 cents per share and sees its revenue at its lowest level since 2010. Intel's struggles reflect the challenges in the personal computer chip market, where it faces sinking demand and tough competition from rivals.

images.alt_text: Intel’s data centre business has been treading water as the industry has exploded.

site_title: Shell says reviewing home energy business in UK, Germany, Netherlands
summary: Shell is conducting a strategic review of its home energy retail business in the UK, Netherlands, and Germany due to "tough market conditions." The review, which could affect its 2,000-strong UK workforce, is expected to take several months. Shell Energy supplies energy to around 1.4 million homes and broadband to half a million customers in these countries. The assessment is part of a longer-term strategy to explore options, with no decisions made yet.

images.alt_text: A liquefied natural gas (LNG) tanker. For a shipment to be declared carbon neutral, companies must show transparent emissions data, reduce emissions at its operations and use offsets for any remaining emissions for the cargo’s lifecycle or those generated when the fuel is consumed.
Shell also expects to pay about US$2 billion in additional 2022 taxes related to the European Union and British windfall taxes imposed on the energy sector.

site_title: Mobileye expects strong 2023 as customers lap up autonomous driving tech
summary: Mobileye, majority owned by Intel, forecasts strong 2023 with revenue between $2.19 billion and $2.28 billion, beating analysts' projections. The company's fourth-quarter revenue jumped 59% to $565 million, with adjusted earnings per share of 27 cents. Mobileye's core advanced driver-assistance systems (Adas) products have a $17 billion revenue pipeline through 2030, and shares rose 6.5% to $36.17 in premarket trading.

site_title: South Korea tech industry’s confidence sours to seven-year low
summary: South Korea's tech industry confidence has plummeted to a seven-year low, with a gauge of 61 for February, down from a pandemic-era low of 58. The industry, driven by semiconductor and display manufacturers, is now more pessimistic about consumer demand. The decline is attributed to waning demand for semiconductors and a slowdown in exports, with the government expecting a chip exports recovery only in the second half. The outlook suggests a recession risk, with global interest rates still rising and inflationary pressure not abating.

site_title: Decentralised finance fading as next crypto frontier as returns disappoint
summary: Decentralised finance (DeFi) is losing interest due to disappointing returns and security concerns. Despite previous performance, DeFi trading volume has more than halved and the total value of crypto tokens locked in DeFi protocols remains flat. Investors are becoming less willing to look past regulatory uncertainty, and solutions to these problems are still years away. As a result, some DeFi projects may not survive the downturn, casting doubt on its potential as the next crypto frontier.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Representations of the Ripple, Bitcoin, Etherum and Litecoin virtual currencies are seen on a PC motherboard in this illustration picture, February 14, 2018. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/File Photo

site_title: Rents in Canada grow at record pace as housing shortage stings
summary: Canada's housing crisis worsened in 2022 as record immigration levels and a housing shortage led to a 5.6% increase in average rent for a two-bedroom apartment. The vacancy rate dropped to 1.9%, the lowest in 21 years, with condominium rentals seeing a 0.2% decrease. Housing prices fell due to high borrowing costs, while the Bank of Canada raised interest rates to 4.5%, the highest in 15 years. The CMHC reports Canada needs to build 3.5 million homes by 2030 to restore affordability, but faces labor and material costs, as well as restrictive zoning rules.

images.alt_text: The housing slump so far has largely been driven by a pullback among buyers who’ve been priced out due to higher interest rates.

site_title: Strong central region office rent growth figures in Q4, full-year 2022 belie signs of caution in market
summary: Singapore's office market experienced a 5.1% quarter-on-quarter growth in Q4 2022, driven by a decline in vacancy rate to 11.3% and a 3.7% increase in rental prices. However, signs of caution are emerging, with some observers attributing the growth to tight supply rather than strong demand. The tech sector drove demand in the first half of 2022, but leasing activity slowed in the latter half of the year. Experts expect a subdued market in 2023, with forecasters predicting a 1% increase in monthly gross effective rents, down from 9.4% in 2022.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

Skyline of the Central Business District (CBD) along the Singapore River on Oct 29, 2022.
Can be used for stories on money, job, manpower, tourist, tourism, property, land, commercial, office, finance, financial, and CBD.
(ST PHOTO: LIM YAOHUI)   Singapore Skyline at night

site_title: US: Wall Street gains as solid GDP data offsets signs of economic weakness
summary: US stocks rose on Thursday as solid GDP data offset signs of economic weakness, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 87.4 points, or 0.26%, to 33,831.24. The data showed a tighter labor market, but also signs of weakening demand, leading investors to weigh the possibility of the Federal Reserve keeping interest rates high. Despite mixed corporate earnings, megacap momentum stocks like Tesla led gains, with the Nasdaq Composite up 1.08%.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 27.82 points, or 0.08 per cent, at the open to 33,771.66.

site_title: French luxury group LVMH posts record sales, net profit for 2022
summary: LVMH, the world's top luxury group, posted record sales and net profit of 79 billion euros and 14 billion euros, respectively, in 2022, driven by strong demand in Europe and the US. The company's sales and net profit both surpassed previous records, with Europe, the US, and Japan experiencing significant growth. LVMH's market capitalization soared to 400 billion euros, making it Europe's most valuable company. Chairman and CEO Bernard Arnault attributes the growth to strong demand from local customers and the recovery of international travel, despite an uncertain geopolitical and economic environment.

images.alt_text: China has been a main driver of an explosion in demand for Swiss watches, jewellery and accessories in recent years.
TAG Heuer Monza Flyback Chronometer.

site_title: Private home prices up 0.4% in Q4 for full-year gain of 8.6%, but future increases expected to slow
summary: Singapore's private home prices rose 0.4% in Q4 2022, with a full-year gain of 8.6%, driven by landed properties, which increased 0.6% in Q4. Non-landed properties grew 0.3% in Q4, with prices rising 8.1% for the year. Experts expect prices to slow to 3-8% growth in 2023, with luxury demand from Chinese buyers and low unsold inventory supporting prices. The rental market remained strong, with rents growing 7.4% in Q4, and 29.7% for the year. Unsold stock remains low, with 16,152 private homes unsold as of Q4 2022, and 19,291 new private homes slated for completion in 2023.

images.alt_text: Private home price rise slows to 0.2% in Q4 as suburban prices drop; 2022 chalks up increase of 8.4%
While new HDB homes are priced to ensure they are affordable, some concerns over housing affordability in Singapore persist, possibly for valid reasons.
The 14 residential projects will supply some 5,300 private homes in Q1 2023, said Huttons senior research director Lee Sze Teck.
Real estate consultancy Knight Frank noted that the scant inventory of landed and non-landed homes on the market will continue to shrink in 2023.

site_title: American Airlines forecasts higher profit on buoyant travel demand
summary: American Airlines forecasted higher profit for 2023, expecting an adjusted profit of $2.50 and $3.50 per share, up from 50 cents per share in 2022. The airline beat quarterly earnings estimates with an adjusted profit of $827 million. Strong demand for air travel, despite a potential recession, has allowed the industry to raise air fares and offset rising expenses. Industry executives see no signs of slowing demand, with packed planes providing room to increase fares.

images.alt_text: Southwest, which also reported a loss in the fourth quarter, said it expects a revenue hit of between US$300 million and US$350 million in the first quarter.

site_title: Europe: Earnings optimism helps shares snap two-day dip
summary: European shares rose 0.4% on Thursday, snapping a two-day decline, as upbeat corporate earnings results eased concerns about profit impacts from higher borrowing costs. The pan-European Stoxx 600 rose, driven by gains in retailers, financial services, and technology sectors. Earnings optimism and data showing the US economy grew faster than expected in the fourth quarter, but with momentum slowing, boosted market sentiment. However, the European Central Bank is expected to hike interest rates by 50 basis points next week, which may impact market performance.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 87.4 points, or 0.26 per cent, to 33,831.24 on Thursday.

site_title: US new home sales post third straight monthly gain
summary: US new home sales increased 2.3% to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 616,000 units in December, marking the third straight monthly gain. This rise in sales, despite a 26.6% year-on-year drop, is attributed to declining mortgage rates, which have fallen to 6.15% - the lowest level since mid-September. Economists had forecast a decline in sales, but the housing market appears to be stabilizing at depressed levels.

images.alt_text: Gross domestic product (GDP) increased at a 2.9 per cent annualised rate last quarter, the Commerce Department said in its advance fourth-quarter GDP growth estimate on Thursday (Jan 26).

site_title: FAA cracks down on contractor linked to US flight groundings this month
summary: The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has revoked access to a contractor linked to the recent US air-traffic error that grounded thousands of flights. Spatial Front Inc., a small government contractor, had its personnel's access to the FAA's computer system revoked after an employee inadvertently deleted a data file, causing the system to fail on January 11. The FAA identified the contractor for the first time, citing the incident as a contributing factor to the massive air-traffic error.

images.alt_text: The Notice to Air Missions system provides pilots, flight crews and other users of US airspace with critical safety notices.
US airlines expect normal operations to resume a day after a system outage grounded flights nationwide.
Some international airlines have privately expressed reluctance to install filters absent a legal requirement from the FAA, officials told Reuters.

site_title: Time for Singapore’s biggest investors to lay out their own ultimatums for companies
summary: Singapore's largest investors, including GIC and Temasek, can demonstrate leadership by putting in writing their voting positions, similar to Norges Bank Investment Management, which criticizes boards for high executive pay, carbon footprints, and diversity. Despite Singapore's CEOs not being as greedy as their US counterparts, the country performs poorly on governance metrics, such as boardroom diversity and director aging. Norges' approach could be emulated by Singapore's largest investors, potentially leading to improvements in corporate governance.

images.alt_text: Joan Ng
Norges Bank Investment Management is voting down poorly structured pay packages, said CEO Nicolai Tangen.
Singapore has a longstanding issue with independent directors who simply would not leave.

site_title: Oil settles up 2% on strong US data, China reopening
summary: Oil prices rose 2% on Thursday, with Brent futures increasing $1.35 to $87.47 a barrel, and US West Texas Intermediate crude rising 86 cents to $81.01. The rise was driven by strong US economic data and China's reopening of its economy, with analysts expecting global demand to strengthen. Despite US crude inventories edging up, the market is optimistic about the outlook, with the Opec+ ministerial panel meeting on Feb 1 likely to endorse current output levels.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled at US$86.12 a barrel on Wednesay, down a cent.
The company last year announced that capital spending for 2023 will be at the top end of its guidance range at US$17 billion.

site_title: Bed Bath & Beyond says it received default notice from JPMorgan
summary: Bed Bath & Beyond received a default notice from JPMorgan Chase, its loan agent, due to a breach of terms in its revolving credit line. The company listed around $2.1 billion in obligations, but warned it doesn't have enough funds to make payments. This is the latest sign that Bed Bath & Beyond is likely to seek bankruptcy protection, which is expected within the next 30 days. The company is exploring all strategic alternatives, including restructuring its debt under the US Bankruptcy Code, and has begun speaking with potential lenders for bankruptcy funding.

images.alt_text: Bed Bath & Beyond’s suppliers have become increasingly cautious in recent months, worried about getting paid for the products they are selling to the home goods store chain.

site_title: NYSE mayhem traced to staffer who left a backup system running
summary: A human error by an NYSE staffer led to chaos on January 24, affecting over 250 companies, including Wells Fargo, McDonald's, and Morgan Stanley, with stock prices swinging by 25 percentage points in minutes. The mistake occurred when the employee failed to properly shut down the backup data center in Chicago, which was supposed to safeguard US markets. The incident highlighted a lack of attention to detail and raised concerns about the reliability of the NYSE's disaster-recovery system.

images.alt_text: The amount of stock traded at away-from-market prices was just a tiny fraction of the usual volume in stocks that normally see millions of shares change hands each day.
More than 1,300 trades and some 84 stocks were impacted and marked as “aberrant”, NYSE said in an updated statement on its website.

site_title: When the boss asks you to do something illegal
summary: A former CFO of Agritrade International, Lulu Lim, was sentenced to 20 years in prison for making false representations and submitting fictitious documents to 16 financial institutions. Lim deceived them into believing Agritrade's financial statements were audited when they were not. An approach called "principled rebellion" suggests eight steps for employees to say no to their bosses, including systematically and sequentially saying no to illegal requests. This case highlights the importance of employees standing up against unethical behavior and seeking alternative approaches to challenging their employers.

images.alt_text: While serving as the chief financial officer of Agritrade, Lim instructed her subordinates to submit financial statements which were unaudited and false to the financial institutions.
John Soh and Quah Su-Ling were found guilty for their involvement in the October 2013 penny stock crash that wiped S$8 billion in market capitalisation from penny stocks on the Singapore Exchange.

epa09969055 A worker loads freshly harvested palm fruits on a truck at a palm oil plantation in Deli Serdang, North Sumatra, Indonesia, 23 May 2022. Indonesia has lifted the ban on palm oil exports after it had been imposed for weeks to control cooking oil prices in the domestic market.  EPA-EFE/DEDI SINUHAJI

site_title: Visa, Mastercard see card spending to slow as inflation persists
summary: Visa and Mastercard reported slower-than-expected card spending in the final quarter of 2022, with Visa's spending up 1.7% to $3.01 trillion and Mastercard's spending jumping 11% to $1.73 trillion. Despite inflation providing a tailwind for the companies, investors remain concerned that higher prices will curb consumer spending, which could impact revenue. Both companies attributed the shift in spending to lower-cost items and generic brands, but noted a slowdown in cross-border transactions. Mastercard's net revenue for the year is expected to grow in the "low teens", while operating expenses are expected to fall in the "mid single digits".

images.alt_text: Mastercard would have to start providing competing payment networks with the customer account information they need to process payments.

A sign advertising payment services by Visa Inc. and Mastercard Inc. in the window of a store inside the GUM luxury department store in Moscow, Russia, on Wednesday, Feb. 23, 2022. U.S. President Joe Biden's debut set of sanctions on Russia for its actions over disputed Ukrainian territory hit markets with a whimper and were quickly criticized as limited in scope. site_title: How to live better, according to philosophers
summary: Philosophy professors Dean Rickles and Kieran Setiya have written two new books offering advice on living a meaningful life. "Life Is Short: An Appropriately Brief Guide To Making It More Meaningful" by Rickles focuses on teaching readers how to live better within the finite time they have on earth, while "Life Is Hard: How Philosophy Can Help Us Find Our Way" by Setiya explores how to lead a more meaningful life amid life's challenges and tragedies. Both books draw from the wisdom of ages to help readers cherish life more and find purpose in their existence.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
Self-care continues to be a priority in 2023.
Book cover of Red Blossom In Snow by Jeannie Lin.

site_title: Borrowing to drive Japan’s debt over 1,100 trillion yen for first time
summary: Japan's government debt is expected to surpass 1,100 trillion yen for the first time by March 2027, driven by heavy borrowing and growing interest payments. The debt-to-GDP ratio is forecast to worsen further, with interest payments nearly doubling from 8.6 trillion yen to 17.1 trillion yen by the end of the forecast period. The International Monetary Fund urges the government to raise taxes and reduce spending to get its fiscal house in order, citing Japan's elevated debt level. The government will present the estimate to parliament as a reference for budget debates.

site_title: A rejuvenated Alibaba takes off, but with Beijing in tow
summary: Alibaba shares have surged over 30% since the start of the year, reaching around $120, as analysts give the Chinese e-commerce giant a "strong buy" rating. Meme-stock investor Ryan Cohen has taken a stake in Alibaba, pushing for the company to buy back more shares. This is a rare case of activism targeting a prominent Chinese firm. The company's shares have doubled in price compared to last October, reflecting a rebound from its sidelining in 2020 after founder Jack Ma fell out of favor with Chinese President Xi Jinping.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan
An arm of the Cyberspace Administration of China took 1 per cent of an Alibaba digital media subsidiary in Guangzhou on Jan 4, according to corporate database Qichacha.
While Jack Ma’s relinquishing of control could clear the way for Ant Group to revive its IPO, it won’t happen within this year due to listing regulations, market observers said.
Jack Ma has since late 2022 gradually resumed the globe-trotting that once defined China’s best-known entrepreneur.

site_title: Mapletree Industrial Trust posts 2.9% fall in Q3 DPU to 3.39 Singapore cents
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust reported a 2.9% drop in third-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 3.39 Singapore cents, despite strong operating metrics and a 5% increase in gross revenue to S$170.4 million. The decline was attributed to higher operating expenses and borrowing costs. The trust's average portfolio occupancy rose to 95.7%, with positive rental revisions across most property segments in Singapore. The trust's manager expects to reach another milestone in its portfolio rejuvenation efforts with the completion of its Kallang Way high-tech industrial redevelopment project.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
Mapletree Industrial Trust in 2021 acquired a portfolio of 29 data centres in the US - including 250 Williams Street in Atlanta (pictured) - for S$1.8 billion.
Across the broader market, gainers outnumbered losers 265 to 143 after 975.2 million securities worth S$1.5 billion were traded.

site_title: China’s net gold imports via Hong Kong more than double in December
summary: China's net gold imports via Hong Kong surged 109% to 43.622 tonnes in December, the highest monthly increase since June, marking a four-month high. This follows a 150% jump from November, with total gold imports reaching 43.622 tonnes. The significant increase is attributed to re-exports and reflects China's ongoing demand for gold, solidifying its position as the world's top gold consumer.

site_title: US dollar just off eight-month low ahead of US GDP data
summary: The US dollar index has fallen to an eight-month low ahead of US GDP data, driven by recession fears fueled by a gloomy corporate earnings season. Investors expect the Federal Reserve to slow down monetary tightening in response to economic downturn concerns. The dollar index recovered some ground, trading up 0.2% at 101.76, as investors await US economic data and potential interest rate adjustments.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. Dollar and Euro banknotes are seen in this illustration taken July 17, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration//File Photo

site_title: Snap’s stock investors risk more pain on advertising woes
summary: Snap Inc.'s shares are trading near their cheapest valuation on record due to concerns over the state of online advertising, which is expected to be revealed in the company's fourth-quarter results on January 31. Investors are doubtful about a sustainable recovery ahead, citing intense competition from TikTok, Alphabet's YouTube Shorts, and Meta's Reels. Despite being relatively cheap, Snap's shares have fallen 81% in 2022 and face near-term and long-term issues with competition, leading analysts to predict a significant drop in earnings and revenue.

images.alt_text: Snap said in August it would lay off 20 per cent of all staff and shut down projects to cut costs amid a deteriorating economy.
FILE PHOTO: TikTok app logo is seen in this illustration taken, August 22, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Championing an inclusive workforce
summary: A Singaporean old age home, Lee Ah Mooi, has championed an inclusive workforce by hiring 14 people with disabilities, including those with autism. The home's efforts in disability-inclusive hiring have led to a resident becoming more cooperative after witnessing an employee's diligence. The home collaborates with SG Enable and other agencies to provide support and training to employees with disabilities. Ensign InfoSecurity, a cybersecurity firm, has also recognized the value of hiring individuals with autism, resulting in a successful employment program. SG Enable aims to create more opportunities for persons with disabilities in the workforce, particularly in healthcare and IT sectors.

images.alt_text: To help persons with disabilities navigate their new responsibilities, Lee Ah Mooi Old Age Home collaborates with social service agencies and retains in­house job coaches
Liew Dong En (left) with a resident of Lee Ah Mooi Old Age Home.
Daryl Loh (second from right) with his neurodiverse colleagues undergoing training with the guidance of Tan Shao Kai (standing, in black).

site_title: US economy grows strongly in fourth quarter; weekly jobless claims fall
summary: The US economy grew at a 2.9% annualized rate in the fourth quarter, driven by strong consumer spending, but momentum is expected to slow as interest rates continue to erode demand. Economists forecast a recession by the second half of the year, with some expecting a rolling downturn rather than an outright recession. Despite this, the labor market remains strong, and the housing market may be stabilizing.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher on soft landing hopes, Tesla boost
summary: US stocks opened higher on Thursday, January 26, driven by a resilient labor market and better-than-expected economic growth. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 27.82 points, or 0.08%, to 33,771.66, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained. Tesla's bullish outlook added to the cheer, easing recession worries.

images.alt_text: A trader works on the trading floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., January 26, 2023. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly

site_title: Climate startup aims to narrow gap in flood protection with data
summary: Climate startup Floodbase launched a global flood-risk data service to help narrow the "protection gap" in flood insurance. The near-real-time monitoring tool combines satellite imagery, water gauge data, and machine learning to track water levels before, during, and after floods. The data will enable insurers to automatically pay out when policyholders experience flooding beyond a defined level. Floodbase aims to support poor nations recover from climate-related losses and damages, with a US$12 million Series A fundraise led by Lowercarbon Capital.

site_title: Bank of Canada’s surprise on interest rates is test of soft-landing bets
summary: The Bank of Canada, led by Governor Tiff Macklem, raised its overnight lending rate to 4.5%, a 15-year high, to combat inflation. Macklem said the rate increase is a test of bets on a "soft landing," where the economy slows down without a recession. The Bank of Canada now expects inflation to fall to 3% by mid-year, with a mild economic contraction at worst, and will hold interest rates until it sees how the economy responds.

site_title: Toyota names Lexus chief its new CEO as car industry faces historic shift
summary: Toyota has appointed Lexus president Koji Sato as its new CEO, replacing Akio Toyoda, who will become chairperson. The move comes as the car industry faces a historic shift towards electrification and automation. Sato, 53, takes leadership at a watershed moment for Toyota, which has faced criticism for its reluctance to invest in electric vehicles. Toyoda, who has been CEO for over a decade, will step down on April 1, and his appointment as chairperson signals a broader view of management.

images.alt_text: Morizo, the alter ego of Toyota President Akio Toyota, greets the crowd before the start of the Idemitsu 1500 at the Chang International Circuit in Buriram, Thailand.

site_title: Anwar’s official visit to Singapore may bring several pressing issues to the fore
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim will visit Singapore by end-January, marking his first visit since taking office in November last year. The trip is expected to focus on pressing issues such as boosting connectivity, growing the digital economy, and resolving the Pedra Branca dispute. This visit comes after a period of uncertainty following the constant changing of the guard in Malaysia and the coronavirus pandemic, which slowed progress on bilateral issues with Singapore. The meeting with Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong is seen as an opportunity for both countries to move forward and strengthen their ties.

images.alt_text: Singapore Foreign Minister Vivian Balakrishnan (right) calling on Malaysian PM Anwar Ibrahim on Jan 17, 2023.
When the 4km rail shuttle service is ready, it will take five minutes to travel from Woodlands to Johor Bahru and vice versa.

site_title: Elevator-maker Kone to slash 1,000 jobs, sees recovery in Asia
summary: Elevator-maker Kone plans to slash 1,000 jobs globally to save 100 million euros annually, with 150 job losses in Finland. The cuts represent 1.6% of Kone's workforce. Despite this, the company expects demand to recover in Asia, particularly in China, with markets expected to start recovering by the end of the first half of the year. Kone's fourth-quarter core earnings beat expectations, with an adjusted operating profit of 365 million euros. The company's shares rose 1.8% following the earnings report.

site_title: Blackstone misses target to manage US$1t by end-2022
summary: Blackstone, the world's largest alternative asset manager, missed its target of reaching $1 trillion in assets under management by the end of 2022. The firm currently has $975 billion, down from $951 billion in the prior quarter. Despite this, CEO Jon Gray expressed confidence in investors entrusting more money if the firm delivers strong performance. The company's distributable earnings fell 41% to $1.3 billion, and its quarterly earnings report highlighted the impact of higher interest rates and investor caution on its valuations and sales.

images.alt_text: Breit’s institutional class shareholders received an 8.4 per cent total return in 2022 when most real estate funds lost money and stocks and bonds declined.
Blackstone currently owns 24 per cent of the Embassy Reit, which has a market capitalisation of nearly US$4 billion.

Blackstone bought the Stuyvesant Town-Peter Cooper Village apartment complex in 2015 for about US$5.4 billion in a deal that was praised by local politicians because of promises that nearly half the 11,200 units would remain affordable to middle-class families
