The US$68 billion Blackstone Real Estate Income Trust (Breit) has been grappling with an increase in investors pulling money, particularly from Asia

site_title: UK retail sales volumes slide at fastest rate since April
summary: UK retail sales volumes slid at the fastest rate since April last year, with the Confederation of British Industry's sales balance falling to -23 from +11 in December's report. This indicates more store chains reported a drop in sales than a rise. The weak state of the consumer economy, combined with strong inflation, is highlighted as a major concern. The survey also points to a potential drop in retail sales next month, further weakening the UK economy.

site_title: Hong Kong stocks end at over 10-month high as Chinese New Year cheers
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged 522.13 points, or 2.37%, to close at 22,566.78, marking the highest since March 2022. The gains were driven by optimism over mainland Chinese tourism, with companies like China Tourism Group Duty Free and Prada jumping on consumption expectations. The Hang Seng TECH Index jumped 4.3%, while the IT sector surged 3.2%. Xiaomi led the gains, rising 12.48%, while Orient Overseas (International) was the biggest loser, falling 2.63%.

site_title: Greenwashing on food, drink, toiletry labels to be scrutinised in UK
summary: Britain's Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) is investigating greenwashing on food, drink, and toiletry labels, scrutinizing companies for misleading claims about sustainability. The probe aims to protect consumers who may be paying a premium for products that don't meet their eco-friendly claims. The CMA will review big and small companies, including major players like Unilever and Procter & Gamble, and may take enforcement action or open investigations if necessary. The regulator believes consumers are being misled and potentially paying extra for products that aren't sustainable.

images.alt_text: acgreen17-ol - Cotton fabric with label saying '100% recycled fabric'

site_title: Record Premier League spending fuels transfer market recovery: Fifa
summary: English Premier League clubs spent a record US$2.2 billion on transfers in 2022, fueling a recovery in the international transfer market, which saw a total outlay of US$6.5 billion. This represents an increase from the previous two years, although still below the pre-pandemic level of US$7.35 billion in 2019. Six of the 10 biggest international transfers involved Premier League sides, marking a significant presence of the league in the transfer market.

site_title: Nokia says it’s gaining market share, sees 2023 growth
summary: Nokia reported a beat on quarterly operating profit expectations and forecast higher 2023 sales, citing gains in market share driven by 5G roll-out in countries like India. CEO Pekka Lundmark attributed the growth to a broad-based expansion and a more optimistic view on the Indian market. Nokia's fourth-quarter comparable operating profit rose to 1.15 billion euros, beating forecasts, and the company expects 2-8% growth in constant currency for 2023. This contrasts with Ericsson's lower-than-expected fourth-quarter core earnings and forecasted decline in margin.

site_title: Asian Olympic chiefs say Russians can take part in Asian Games
summary: Asian Olympic chiefs have announced that Russian and Belarusian athletes will be allowed to compete in this year's Asian Games, despite the invasion of Ukraine. The Olympic Council of Asia (OCA) stated that all athletes, regardless of nationality or passport, should be able to participate in sports competitions. This decision comes after the International Olympic Committee (IOC) expressed interest in exploring a pathway for Russian and Belarusian athletes to compete at the 2024 Paris Games.

site_title: Yew Kee Duck Rice, Chicha San Chen franchise operator to raise S$16.6m in Catalist IPO
summary: Yew Kee Duck Rice and Chicha San Chen franchise operator YKGI is raising S$16.6 million through a Catalist IPO in Singapore. The IPO will see 82.8 million shares sold at S$0.20 each, with the funds primarily used for expansion across the brands, including entering new markets for Yew Kee Duck Rice and Chicha San Chen. The company aims to strengthen its supply chain capabilities, expand franchising and sub-franchising operations, and accelerate growth through strategic acquisitions and joint venture partnerships.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
The food group has a licence to operate Chicha San Chen in Singapore for ten years, starting from 2019.

site_title: China’s CATL German plant targets six battery cell production lines by end-2023
summary: CATL, China's largest battery maker, plans to install six battery cell production lines by the end of 2023 at its German factory, with a capacity of 24 gigawatt-hours. The plant, which began construction in 2019, has already sent its first sample battery cells to clients in December 2022. CATL aims to power around 350,000 electric cars annually with its initial production capacity of 14 GWh. A second European plant, targeting 100 GWh capacity, is in the planning phase, with construction expected to start in the second half of the year.

site_title: Kuwait Airways annual revenue up 115% from 2021, says chairman
summary: Kuwait Airways saw a 115% surge in annual revenue from 2021, reaching 10% above pre-pandemic levels in 2019. Despite this, the airline posted a net loss of 55 million dinars ($236.33 million) in 2022. The carrier expects to break even by the end of 2024, with plans to introduce new routes to several European and Middle Eastern cities in 2023.

images.alt_text: Kuwait Airways, Airbus A310.

site_title: FCT, Frasers Property team up to acquire 50% stake in Nex
summary: Frasers Property Limited (FPL) and Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) have jointly acquired a 50% stake in suburban mall Nex for SGD 652.5 million. The stake was bought from Mercatus Co-operative, which had put it on the auction block in June 2022. The acquisition is expected to be accretive to FCT's distributions per unit, with a projected increase of 0.5%. The mall, located at Serangoon Central, has a total net lettable area of 634,631 sq ft and a committed occupancy of 99.9%.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
Hong Kong-listed Link Reit won the race to acquire Jurong Point and Swing By @ Thomson Plaza for S$2.16 billion.
Hospitality S-Reits such as CapitaLand Ascott Trust are expected to ride on the tailwinds of the return of Chinese tourists.
CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust reported 21.3 per cent y-o-y growth in tenant sales and 21.9 per cent y-o-y growth in shopper traffic for 9M 2022.

site_title: Strong demand for tech talent in Singapore despite global Big Tech layoffs: Josephine Teo
summary: Singapore remains committed to developing its tech talent despite global tech layoffs, with Minister for Communications and Information Josephine Teo citing strong demand for tech workers in non-tech industries. The government has launched a tech talent training program, including the Step IT Up initiative, to reskill and upskill Singaporeans for tech roles. With over 13,000 individuals trained and placed in tech roles since 2016, Teo believes investing in tech talent is essential for the country's growth and future opportunities.

images.alt_text: Google says it will eliminate about 12,000 jobs, becoming the latest tech giant to retrench after years of abundant growth and hiring.
Rapid interest rate hikes, weak consumer demand and an economic slowdown in China have forced firms such as Amazon, Walt Disney, Facebook-owner Meta and American banks to trim their workforce.

site_title: Southwest Airlines forecasts first-quarter loss on cancellations impact
summary: Southwest Airlines forecasts a first-quarter loss due to the impact of cancellations following a tech meltdown during the Christmas and New Year's holidays. The airline expects a revenue hit of $300-350 million. This is the second consecutive quarter that Southwest reported a loss, following a loss in the fourth quarter. The cancellations, totaling over 16,700, disrupted holiday plans for tens of thousands of passengers and have drawn regulatory scrutiny.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Southwest Airlines jetliner lands at Chicago Midway International Airport in Chicago, Illinois, U.S., December 27, 2022.  REUTERS/Kamil Krzaczynski//File Photo

site_title: Dutch central bank fines cryptocurrency exchange Coinbase 3.3 million euros
summary: The Dutch central bank, DNB, has fined US cryptocurrency exchange Coinbase 3.3 million euros for failing to register as a money transmitter in the Netherlands before offering services. Coinbase had been out of compliance from November 2020 to August 2022, potentially allowing unusual transactions to go unnoticed. The fine mirrors one handed to Coinbase rival Binance in July. Coinbase has until March 2 to appeal the decision, which it claims "includes no criticism of our actual services".

images.alt_text: Customers will have until Feb 16 to withdraw their fiat and crypto holdings, Coinbase said in a blog post on Wednesday (Jan 18).

site_title: Pushing boundaries in art
summary: Three art exhibitions in Singapore challenge perceptions of the world. Joo Choon Lin's solo presentation at the Singapore Art Museum features bizarre sculptures and live performances, exploring industrial materials and technology. Her installation "I Only Make Friends With Money" critiques capitalism and the art market. Meanwhile, Jane Lee's solo show at Primz Gallery showcases her deconstructed paintings, while "Altered State: Painting Myanmar in a Time of Transition" at De Suantio Gallery features works by Myanmar artists expressing their views on the country's political turmoil. These exhibitions offer unique perspectives on the world, encouraging viewers to engage with the art on multiple levels.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
National Gallery Singapore's Light To Night festival will feature live performances, large-scale installations, a market and other attractions.

site_title: European chipmaker STMicro posts Q4 sales rise on strong consumer demand
summary: STMicroelectronics, a European chipmaker, reported a 2% increase in net revenue to US$4.42 billion in the fourth quarter, beating expectations. The company attributed the growth to strong consumer demand, particularly from automotive and industrial customers. Net income rose 12% to US$1.25 billion, and the company hit its full-year revenue target of US$16.1 billion. CEO Jean-Marc Chery expects full-year revenue to be between US$16.8 billion and US$17.8 billion, with plans to increase manufacturing capacity and raise capital expenditure.

images.alt_text: STMicroelectronics, whose top clients include iPhone maker Apple and electric carmaker Tesla, strongly benefits from a surge in power-management semiconductors as the auto industry moves to low-emission vehicles, and from automation in multiple industries.
STMicro's mid-term sales target represents about a 30 per cent increase from the top range of its expectations for this year, at US$15.3 billion.
Limiting gains on Germany’s DAX index, Symrise falls 5.5 per cent after the German flavour and fragrance maker reports a lower-than-expected Ebitda margin for 2022.

site_title: US Treasury, financial watchdogs, companies among FTX creditors, filing shows
summary: The US Treasury's Financial Crimes Enforcement Network and US Internal Revenue Service are among creditors of bankrupt cryptocurrency exchange FTX, along with companies like Airbnb and Binance. A court filing showed 116 creditors, including financial watchdogs from the US, Japan, and Switzerland. FTX filed for bankruptcy in November, leaving an estimated one million customers and investors with total losses in the billions. The exchange owed its 50 biggest creditors nearly $3.1 billion, with FTX founder Sam Bankman-Fried facing fraud charges over the collapse.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Former FTX Chief Executive Sam Bankman-Fried, who faces fraud charges over the collapse of the bankrupt cryptocurrency exchange, departs from his court hearing at a federal court in New York City's Manhattan, U.S. January 3, 2023. REUTERS/David Dee Delgado/File Photo

site_title: Singapore stocks rise for third consecutive day; STI up 0.7%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.7% to 3,377.19, marking its third consecutive day of gains. The benchmark index saw 413 gainers out of 189 losers, with Sats leading the gains. Other top gainers included ST Engineering and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding. Despite mixed regional markets, investors are optimistic about global growth accelerating in the second half of 2023, according to Stephen Innes of SPI Asset Management.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
Singtel is the most actively traded on Thursday morning with 2.7 million changing hands at the open.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What happened today
summary: Singapore's factory output expanded 0.3% year on year in January, reversing a 5.8% contraction in November, excluding the volatile biomedical manufacturing cluster. This marks a reversal of the three-month decline in factory output, which had been dragged down by a deepening contraction in biomedical manufacturing.

images.alt_text: Core inflation holds steady at 5.1 per cent in December, as smaller price increases for retail and other goods, and electricity and gas were offset by higher inflation for food and services.
The single most important input in the production of food is water, says Marcos Troyjo, president of New Development Bank.
Analysts say rising interest rates could result in higher margins and a revival of wealth management income for local lenders, which will lift their overall earnings.

site_title: Dow misses Q4 profit estimates, to cut 2,000 jobs
summary: Dow Inc. plans to cut 2,000 jobs as part of a US$1 billion cost-saving plan following its Q4 2022 profits missing Wall Street estimates. The company cited higher energy costs, supply chain disruptions, and a slowing economy in Europe. Dow will reduce raw material purchases, cut logistics and utilities costs, and take a US$550-725 million charge. The move adds to a growing wave of corporate job cuts, with SAP also planning to cut 3,000 jobs this year. Dow shares fell 7.3% in premarket trading.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: The Dow logo is seen on a building in downtown Midland, Michigan, in this May 14, 2015 file photograph.  Picture taken May 14, 2015. REUTERS/Rebecca Cook/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Brokers’ take: DBS upgrades Paragon Reit to ‘buy’ as China’s borders reopen
summary: DBS Group Research has upgraded Paragon Real Estate Investment Trust (Reit) to "buy" due to expectations of a rebound in tourist arrivals, particularly from China, and a recovery in tenant sales. The analysts forecast a 5.6% yield and higher sales efficiency at Paragon Mall, driven by luxury spending. The Reit's one-time price-to-book value ratio is deemed attractive, and DBS expects it to be a prime beneficiary of China's reopening and Orchard Road's recovery, with a potential takeover unlocking value.

images.alt_text: DBS Research Group raises Paragon Reit's target price to S$1.10 from S$0.96.

SPH Reit's portfolio includes its anchor asset, Paragon, along with The Clementi Mall and The Rail Mall. 
It has two more such facilities in Australia.
Major office and retail property landlords need to carefully balance filling up space with anchor tenants on sweet deals, with signing up smaller tenants on better terms.

site_title: Hyundai unveils 10.5 trillion won spending plan as EVs rise
summary: Hyundai Motor Company has unveiled a 10.5 trillion won spending plan for 2023, aiming to electrify its fleet and meet rising consumer demand for greener cars. The company targets a revenue growth of 11.5% and plans to sell 4.3 million cars globally, with its affiliate Kia also targeting a 10% growth for 2023. Hyundai's operating profit for the fourth quarter more than doubled to 3.4 trillion won, beating analyst estimates. The company also raised its cash dividend, citing a strong demand for its electric vehicles.

images.alt_text: Like many other automakers, Hyundai benefited from the tight supply of new vehicles last year which have kept retail prices high.

juev19 - Andy Kang, VP of Sales and Innovation, Hyundai Motor Group Innovation Center Singapore, with the Hyundai Ioniq 5 First 100 edition at the Singapore Motorshow



source/copyright/credit: Big Fish Publishing Pte Ltd
Total sales across all car brands for 2022 likely fell below 14 million units, the lowest since 2011, when the US was still recovering from the 2008-2009 financial crisis.
Hyundai and its affiliate Kia say they will target global sales of 7.5 million vehicles this year.
Hyundai’s global presence is rooted in the company’s strong manufacturing base in South Korea.
Hyundai and SK On aim to begin operations in 2025, with the venture expected to  create more than 3,500 new jobs through approximately US$4-5 billion of investment.
Last year, Hyundai Motor Group and LG Energy Solution said they would set up a US$1.1 billion EV battery joint venture in Indonesia.

site_title: Private equity deal activity in Apac hits 5-year low in 2022: S&P
summary: Private equity deal activity in the Asia-Pacific region declined in 2022, reaching its lowest level in five years. There were 208 transactions valued at US$35.4 billion, down from 347 deals valued at US$74.1 billion in 2021. The decline was attributed to a sharp fall in investment, primarily driven by a pullback of US institutional investors in China. However, investors are increasingly focusing on India and South-east Asia technology companies, with mergers and acquisitions activity rising to US$204 billion in Q4 2022.

images.alt_text: The Apac region leads global deal making at US$25.7 billion across 407 transactions.

site_title: Japan needs 3% wage growth for inflation goal, IMF’s Gopinath says
summary: Japan needs a 3% increase in nominal wages to anchor inflation above the central bank's 2% target, according to IMF's Gita Gopinath. With inflation risks tilting to the upside, wages now hold the key to maintaining price growth above the target. The IMF recommends the Bank of Japan to allow more movement in long-term yields and clear communication on monetary policy conditions. Achieving the target remains uncertain, with the IMF's current projections expecting inflation to decelerate below 2% by the end of 2024.

images.alt_text: Many of the central bank's board members agree on the need to retain ultra-loose monetary policy to support the economy and help companies raise wages.

Finance Minister Shunichi Suzuki notes that Japan’s public finances have increased in severity to an unprecedented degree due to supplementary budgets to respond to the coronavirus and similar issues.

site_title: Johnnie Walker maker Diageo beats first-half sales estimates, but  key US market sales weaken
summary: Diageo, the world's largest spirits maker, reported a 9.4% organic net sales growth in the first half of 2023, beating analyst forecasts. The company's premium-plus brands drove 65% of the growth, while organic operating profit rose 10%. However, sales in the US weakened, with a 3% organic growth rate in North America, missing estimates, and Diageo shares fell 6.1%. The company remains confident in its medium-term guidance of 5-7% organic net sales growth and 6-9% sustainable organic operating profit growth.

images.alt_text: Diageo will sell 32 of its liquor brands in India to Inbrew Beverages for 8.2 billion rupees (S$144 million) as the alcoholic beverage maker seeks sustainable long-term profitable growth by pruning some of its low-margin products.
Guinness launches scheme for an environmentally friendly pint

site_title: Does ChatGPT spell AI for good or bad?
summary: ChatGPT, a text-based AI bot, has raised concerns about the impact of AI-generated content tools on cybersecurity, with experts warning of the potential for AI-powered exploits to democratize cybercrime. Researchers have demonstrated how AI can craft more effective phishing emails, while the makers of ChatGPT have suggested that the system has in-built guardrails to prevent malicious activities. However, with a few tweaks, the AI-generated phishing email sounded "weirdly human," highlighting the need for the cybersecurity industry to be prepared to fight AI-powered exploits and for businesses and governments to develop intelligent responses to neutralize evolving threats.

images.alt_text: Do AI-generated works infringe copyright?

site_title: US investment firm eyes stake in Premier League’s Everton FC
summary: US investment firm MSP Sports Capital is considering buying a stake in Premier League's Everton FC, which is in danger of dropping out of the league due to poor form. The team, controlled by Farhad Moshiri, has not won a major trophy since 1995 and has been struggling financially. MSP has a history of investing in sports teams, including McLaren Racing and several European football clubs. The potential deal is at an early stage, and there is no certainty it will lead to a transaction, with other investors also potentially interested in the club.

images.alt_text: Everton's goalkeeper Jordan Pickford makes a save from Chelsea's Cesar Azpilicueta during the English Premier League soccer match between Everton FC and Chelsea FC in Liverpool, Britain.
Erling Braut Haaland in action for Norway in the UEFA Nations League earlier this month. The 21-year-old striker will play for Manchester City in the English Premier League.

site_title: Tesla gets US$5b credit line in sign it’s nearing investment-grade status
summary: Tesla has secured a US$5 billion revolving credit facility with banks, a sign that the company is nearing investment-grade status. The electric vehicle seller has cut US$9.5 billion of debt since 2020 and has seen its creditworthiness improve with upgrades from Moody's and S&P. The company's current high-yield rating and cash generation capabilities are contributing to its investment-grade status, which could lead to a one-time upgrade from another major credit grader in the next 12-18 months.

images.alt_text: Tesla reported fourth-quarter profits of US$3.7 billion, up 59 per cent from the year-ago period as revenues jumped 37 per cent to US$24.3 billion.

site_title: Morgan Stanley fines its bankers over messaging breaches
summary: Morgan Stanley has fined its bankers over US$1 million each for using unapproved messaging platforms to conduct business, following an industry-wide probe. The bank is requiring individual staff to bear the burden of the investigation, which has resulted in record penalties for monitoring lapses. The penalties will be docked from bonuses or clawed back from previous pay. Morgan Stanley joins a dozen other banks, including Barclays and Goldman Sachs, which have paid similar levies totaling US$2 billion. The probe has prompted wider changes, including training on official platforms and message retrieval on company phones.

site_title: A ‘terrace’ flat shows off flexible open-plan living
summary: Architect Melvin Keng renovated his 40-year-old HDB corner unit into a unique, open-plan living space inspired by his childhood home. The design features a wedge-shaped "patio" area with lush plants, a central cabinet concealing the bed for privacy, and a quirky guest bathroom entrance. Keng incorporated sustainable elements, such as cement render and minimal finishing materials, and drew inspiration from architects Mies Van Der Rohe and Le Corbusier. The space includes a 3m-long dining island with a built-in planter and custom-designed furniture, showcasing Keng's passion for his hobbies and life collections.

images.alt_text: Yang is on a mission to preserve South Korean heritage in modern architectural design..

site_title: Hindenburg vs Adani: The short seller taking on Asia’s richest person
summary: Activist short seller Hindenburg Research, led by Nathan Anderson, has launched a two-year investigation into Indian industrialist Gautam Adani's conglomerate, Adani Group, accusing it of stock manipulation and accounting fraud. The report, which Hindenburg calls "The Largest Con in Corporate History," has already wiped $12 billion of market value. Adani Group has dismissed the allegations as "malicious misinformation." Anderson, who has previously targeted electric-vehicle makers Nikola and Lordstown Motors, is seeking to expose Adani's business empire, which spans energy, agribusiness, real estate, and defense.

images.alt_text: Gautam Adani, who chairs Indian conglomerate Adani Group. Adani Enterprises last week set the floor price for India’s largest follow-on public offer (FPO) at 3,112 rupees per share, with a price cap of 3,276 rupees apiece.

site_title: Marina Bay Sands delivers record mass gaming, retail revenue in Q4
summary: Marina Bay Sands reported record mass gaming and retail revenue in Q4 2022, with net revenue contribution nearly doubling to US$682 million. The casino segment saw a surge in contributions, with rolling chip volume growing to US$7.1 billion. Hotel occupancy and average daily rate also increased, with 98.3% occupancy and US$550 per room. This contrasts with most of Las Vegas Sands' Macau casinos, which remained in the red. The group's adjusted property earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization (Ebitda) for Marina Bay Sands was US$273 million.

images.alt_text: Marina Bay Sands hotel, Central Business District and Marina Bay Financial Centre from the rooftop deck of Supertree Observatory at Gardens by the Bay on Oct 11, 2021.
Marquee international events returned to Singapore in 2022 as MICE tourism recovered with easing Covid restrictions.

site_title: The shape of watches to come
summary: Watchmakers are expected to showcase unconventional watch cases at the upcoming Watches & Wonders show. Hermès' H08 features a cushion-shaped case with gold accents, while Cartier's Tank Francaise boasts a square case with a modern design. Richard Mille's RM 66 Flying Tourbillon incorporates the "horns" hand sign, a symbol of rebellion, into its design. These watches demonstrate a shift towards non-traditional case shapes and designs, marking a departure from the traditional round-case timepieces.

images.alt_text: TAG Heuer Monza Flyback Chronometer.

site_title: Musk says China rivals ‘work hardest, smartest’
summary: Elon Musk has stated that China's car companies are the toughest competition for Tesla, citing their hard work and intelligence. China is Tesla's second-largest market, accounting for two-thirds of global electric vehicle sales in 2022. Musk expects China to be the most likely company to surpass Tesla in electric vehicle sales, with companies like Xpeng, Nio, and BYD competing aggressively on style and price. Despite this, Musk expressed respect for Chinese automakers and praised their talent and work ethic.

images.alt_text: Elon Musk ended three days on the stand defending against claims that he defrauded investors by tweeting on Aug 7, 2018, that he had “funding secured” to take Tesla private.
The move suggests Tesla is finally committing to large-scale production of the Semi, which was initially supposed to begin rolling out of factory doors in 2019.
Tesla reported fourth-quarter profits of US$3.7 billion, up 59 per cent from the year-ago period as revenues jumped 37 per cent to US$24.3 billion.

site_title: US$1 trillion green investment matches fossil fuels for first time
summary: Global investments in the clean energy transition reached US$1.1 trillion in 2022, surpassing fossil fuel production for the first time. Solar and wind power accounted for US$495 billion, while electric vehicles came in second with US$466 billion. The US and China were the top investors, with the US spending US$141 billion and China US$546 billion. To achieve net-zero emissions by 2050, annual investments in the transition must triple, according to BloombergNEF.

site_title: Singapore’s latest one-year Treasury bill offers 3.87% yield
summary: Singapore's one-year Treasury bill auction closed with a cut-off yield of 3.87%, surpassing the previous 3.72% yield in October 2022. The total value of applications reached S$10.5 billion, up from S$8.6 billion in the previous auction. Strong demand was seen, with investors locking in returns despite expectations of rates peaking. The yield is at the lower end of OCBC's expected range, reflecting expectations of rates peaking.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
The yield on the T-bills appears to have peaked. Yields have stayed at elevated levels in recent months amid steep interest rate hikes by the US Federal Reserve.
While bond yields are up, investors should bear in mind that interest rates are rising because central banks worldwide are trying to tame inflation.

site_title: It’s Dry January, so pour one out for the bar owners
summary: Dry January, a month-long sobriety trend, is causing financial strain on New York City bars and breweries. Owners like Gil Maestro of BierWax and Laura Dierks of Interboro Spirits and Ales report reduced sales, with some bars cutting hours and letting go of staff. The trend is attributed to 15% of American adults participating, with many forgoing alcohol to save money. To adapt, some businesses are offering non-alcoholic beverages, and liquor stores are exploring alternative sales to make up for lost revenue.

images.alt_text: Diners toast at Brat in the Shoreditch neighborhood, in London, Dec. 28, 2022. ItÕs one of the worldÕs best cities for wine and you can find terrific lists in pubs, bars and all sorts of restaurants in almost any neighborhood. (Peter Flude/The New York Times)

site_title: US and EU in talks on access to Biden’s green plan benefits
summary: The US and EU are discussing a potential deal on access to benefits under President Biden's green investment plan, the Inflation Reduction Act. The US is likely to focus on extraction and processing of critical minerals, while the EU wants to include recycled materials. This could allow the EU to qualify for tax credits and other incentives for electric vehicles and batteries. Discussions are at an early stage, with other countries such as Indonesia and Argentina potentially involved. The agreement aims to reduce reliance on Chinese supplies and address concerns that the US law unfairly subsidizes American companies.

images.alt_text: Bruno Le Maire, France's finance minister, says: “I strongly believe that in the world game, China must be in, China cannot be out.”

site_title: Sweden’s housing rout persists as Riksbank keeps raising rates
summary: Sweden's housing market continues its decline for a ninth straight month, with prices falling 16% since March last year. The Riksbank is expected to raise interest rates again in February, which analysts say won't lift the gloom in the market until this summer at the earliest. Most forecasters expect a 20% peak-to-trough drop in home prices, with Stockholm's apartment prices showing a slight increase in the first half of January. The Riksbank's rate hike is part of a global trend of real-estate markets retreating due to higher borrowing costs and inflation.

images.alt_text: Delays in projects in China are being keenly watched by everyone from economists to distressed debt investors amid plunging sales across the nation and sporadic mortgage boycotts.

site_title: China’s luxury shoppers free to travel, but many buy locally
summary: China has lifted its travel curbs, allowing luxury shoppers to travel freely, but many prefer to buy high-end goods locally, particularly on the island of Hainan. Thousands of travelers flocked to duty-free stores in Sanya city, stocking up on cosmetics and handbags. Despite the relaxation of COVID-19 policies, some experts believe a significant portion of China's luxury spending will remain within the country, with brands likely to cater to both domestic and international markets. This shift is expected to revive demand in the global luxury retail market.

images.alt_text: The government’s target of drawing 25 million overseas holidaymakers in 2023 stands to gain momentum now that China has abandoned its Covid-Zero policy and reopened its borders.
The Chinese Center for Disease Control and Prevention says that daily fatalities dipped to 896 on Monday, from a high of 4,273 on Jan 4.

site_title: Global 2023 economic view downgraded, at odds with market optimism: poll
summary: Global economic growth is forecast to barely clear 2% this year, downgraded from previous estimates, despite market optimism. The downgrade is due to the full impact of interest rate hikes, which can take a year or more to show up in economies. Economists cite a range of factors, including tighter monetary policy and persistently high inflation, as major threats to growth. Central banks are expected to keep interest rates steady, contradicting market expectations of easing in the fourth quarter.

images.alt_text: Global economic growth is set to slump in 2023, from an estimated 3.0 per cent in 2022 to 1.9 per cent this year, said the United Nations in its World Economic Situation and Prospects report.
Over 13,400 elderly people across the UK, unable to heat the homes due to spiralling energy costs, have died from cold homes related deaths in the last year.

site_title: PropertyBT: Deep diving into property-related taxes (Ep 15)
summary: A podcast episode from PropertyBT explores the possibility of introducing new property-related taxes in Singapore, impacting various physical property types. Experts discuss potential tax hikes on residential and non-residential properties, including higher transaction taxes, capital gains taxes, and inheritance taxes. The episode highlights the need for new tax structures to address changing market conditions and encourage sustainable property investment.

images.alt_text: What are the roperty trends in the Orchard Road belt and suggestions to make Orchard Road vibrant?
What to look out for when buying a freehold, a new 99-year leasehold or an older leasehold home.

site_title: Industrial space rents up 2.1%, prices climb 1.7% in Q4: JTC
summary: Singapore's industrial space rents rose 2.1% quarter-over-quarter and 6.9% year-over-year in Q4 2022, driven by growth in the manufacturing sector. Industrial space prices increased 1.7% on the quarter and 7.5% year-over-year, despite interest-rate hikes and a decline in transaction volumes. The overall occupancy rate slipped to 89.4% and new completions exceeded demand, leading to a surge in available stock. Experts predict a slowdown in rent growth and price increases in 2023, with some sectors, such as warehouses and high-tech, expected to continue growth.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim
About 70 per cent of Extra Space Asia's customers are using the facility to store their personal belongings and 30 percent are companies storing their inventories.

This will bring Jurong Island’s total solar energy capacity to 103.2 megawatt peak (MWp), an eightfold increase from the current 12.3 MWp generated from Jurong Island companies’ rooftop installations.
This round’s IGLS launch includes four sites on the confirmed list and three sites on the reserve list.

site_title: UK commercial property extends downturn as investors retreat: survey
summary: UK commercial property market continues its downturn, with 83% of respondents in the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors' quarterly survey believing the market is already in a downturn. Investor inquiries declined for the first time since the pandemic, with a net balance of minus 30 citing lower investment demand. The market outlook worsened, with almost half considering the downturn to be in its early stages, and borrowing costs are affecting the sector.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A general view is seen of the London skyline from Canary Wharf in London, Britain, October 19, 2016. REUTERS/Hannah McKay/File Photo

site_title: Global phone shipments plunge most ever as consumers spend less
summary: Global smartphone shipments plummeted 18.3% in the December quarter, marking the largest quarterly drop on record, with a total of 300 million units shipped. The decline is attributed to cooling consumer demand, inflation, and economic uncertainties, as well as Covid lockdowns in China disrupting production. This decline signals more pain for manufacturing hubs like South Korea and Vietnam, with Samsung Electronics reporting its biggest profit fall in over a decade.

site_title: ENI unable to deliver February LNG cargo to Pakistan, declares force majeure
summary: ENI, an Italian major, has declared force majeure due to a disrupted LNG delivery to Pakistan LNG Limited in February. The delivery, part of a 15-year long-term deal, is the latest disruption to LNG shipments to Pakistan, which are insufficient to meet the country's rising fuel demand. Pakistan's LNG imports decreased 20% from 2021, and the country faces challenges in procuring spot cargoes amid elevated global gas prices. ENI stated it did not benefit from the disruption and applied contractual provisions to manage the situation.

images.alt_text: A liquefied natural gas (LNG) tanker. For a shipment to be declared carbon neutral, companies must show transparent emissions data, reduce emissions at its operations and use offsets for any remaining emissions for the cargo’s lifecycle or those generated when the fuel is consumed.

site_title: Hyundai Motor’s Q4 net profit triples but misses expectations
summary: Hyundai Motor reported a 3x increase in Q4 net profit to 1.7 trillion won (S$1.8 billion), driven by strong demand for high-margin SUVs and a weak won. However, the result missed analyst expectations, and the company faces challenges from high inflation and slowing global economic growth. Despite this, Hyundai's shares rose 4.4% in afternoon trade. The company benefits from tight supply of new vehicles, which has kept retail prices high, but faces uncertain consumer demand in the coming year.

site_title: 💰 Are T-bills the way to go?
summary: A recent article in the Thrive newsletter questions the suitability of investing in T-bills, specifically for CPF (Central Provident Fund) holders. The article suggests that T-bills may not be the best option due to low returns and inflation risks. It emphasizes the importance of financial literacy among Gen Z, who have few excuses for financial ignorance. The article encourages readers to consider alternative investment options and seek professional advice before making financial decisions.

images.alt_text: Vivien Shiao

site_title: Asia: Hong Kong returns to lead most markets higher
summary: Asia's markets rose on Thursday, with Hong Kong leading the way, as investors welcomed slowing inflation and hints of a lighter approach to tackling prices. The majority of Asian markets returned from the Lunar New Year break on an optimistic note, despite uneven earnings from tech giants. The US market ended on a soft note, with traders awaiting the release of US growth data and the Federal Reserve's preferred gauge of inflation. Despite concerns of a recession, there is growing hope for a "soft landing" in the world's top economy, with some analysts predicting a stronger recovery this year due to China's reopening.

images.alt_text: The Nikkei was slightly higher after rallying more than three per cent over the previous three trading days.

site_title: Brokers’ take: Maybank upgrades Frencken Group to ‘buy’, says worst is over
summary: Maybank Research upgraded its call on Frencken Group from "sell" to "buy", citing new orders and recovery in margins as key growth drivers. The research house raised its target price to S$1.21 from S$1.02 and increased core net profit forecasts by 11.7% and 12.9% for FY2023 and FY2024, respectively. The upgrade comes after ASML's strong fourth-quarter results and a projected 25% year-on-year net sales growth for FY2023, which is expected to boost Frencken's semiconductor segment.

images.alt_text: Sats share price sank after the ground handler and inflight caterer proposed acquisition of the world’s air cargo handler Worldwide Freight Services (WFS) for an enterprise value of about 2.3 billion euros (S$3.3 billion), including assuming WFS’  borrowings of 1 billion euros.
Potential de-rating catalysts for Frencken are further cost escalation affecting net profit negatively, and further weakening of demand in the group's semiconductor business segment

site_title: Singapore Q1 manufacturing outlook gloomy; electronics rebound likely temporary, say analysts
summary: Singapore's manufacturing outlook for Q1 2023 is expected to remain gloomy, with factory output contracting for the third straight month. The electronics sector rebounded in December, but analysts predict it will be temporary due to weaker global demand. Economists forecast 2023 full-year manufacturing growth of 1.6% year on year, with some predicting a contraction of 5.4%. The outlook is influenced by the ongoing post-Covid-19 surge in China and moderation in external economies.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
Singapore’s factory output shrinks by worse-than-expected 3.2% in November

site_title: Nippon Steel, Mitsubishi, Exxon to look at CCS value chains in Asia-Pacific
summary: Nippon Steel, Mitsubishi, and ExxonMobil have signed a Memorandum of Understanding to study carbon capture and storage (CCS) value chains in the Asia-Pacific region. The joint research aims to capture CO2 emissions from Nippon Steel's steel plants and evaluate necessary infrastructure development. This is the first study of its kind in Japan and storage overseas in the region, covering storage opportunities in Malaysia, Indonesia, and Australia. The study will help reduce carbon emissions from steelmaking, a significant contributor to global CO2 emissions.

images.alt_text: The move comes as companies around the world step up efforts to develop carbon capture and storage (CCS) technology to help combat climate change.

site_title: Toyota’s Thai unit sees its local car sales up 7.3% this year
summary: Toyota's Thai unit expects a 7.3% increase in local car sales to 310,000 vehicles in 2023, up from 288,809 units in 2022. The company aims to export 405,000 vehicles this year, a 7% increase from 378,454 cars shipped out last year. The Thai market is expected to recover as the country's economy grows, with the reopening of the tourism industry boosting domestic demand and easing production part shortages.

site_title: Boeing hints new jet it’s testing with Nasa could replace 737 Max
summary: Boeing is developing a new, single-aisle jet with NASA, potentially replacing the 737 Max, which could reduce fuel consumption and emissions by 30% over current models. The design features extra-long, thin wings stabilized by diagonal struts, and Boeing plans to test a full-scale prototype later this decade. CEO Dave Calhoun stated the company's intent to commercialize the design, which would meet the "standard needed to launch a commercial airplane." Boeing has allocated $1.15 billion to the project, with additional funding to be provided by NASA.

images.alt_text: The 737 MAX crashes in Indonesia and Ethiopia, which cost Boeing more than US$20 billion, led to a 20-month grounding for the best-selling plane and prompted lawmakers to pass sweeping legislation reforming airplane certification.
Boeing is starting to step up jet deliveries and chip away at its stockpile of hundreds of already-built 737 Max (above), 787 Dreamliners and 777X jetliners.

site_title: Meta’s social media apps down for thousands of users: Downdetector
summary: Meta's social media apps, including Instagram, Facebook, WhatsApp, and Facebook Messenger, experienced widespread outages for thousands of users in the US. Over 12,000 Instagram users and 8,000 Facebook users reported issues, according to Downdetector.com. Meta did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

site_title: The real debt crisis is low taxes
summary: The US debt ceiling debate is being overshadowed by a broader fiscal issue: low taxes. The country's government has spent 20.8% of GDP on average, while collecting only 17.3% in revenue, leaving a $31.4 trillion gap covered by IOUs. This pattern, followed by both Republicans and Democrats, has masked the true debt problem. The author argues that the debt ceiling serves as a rare opportunity for Congress to reassess its fiscal policies, particularly tax rates.

images.alt_text: A default on the US debt could ignite a global financial crisis and force the fragile American economy into a full-blown recession.

A board at a bus stop in Washington showing the US national debt figure after the US government hit its US$31.4 trillion borrowing limit on Jan 19 amid a standoff between the Republican-controlled House of Representatives, President Joe Biden and Democratic legislators that could lead to a fiscal crisis in a few months.

site_title: German software giant SAP to cut 3,000 jobs
summary: German software giant SAP plans to cut 3,000 jobs as part of a "targeted restructuring programme" to strengthen its core business and improve efficiency. The move, affecting approximately 2.5% of its 120,000 employees, aims to enhance the company's competitiveness in the global tech sector. SAP's decision follows a wave of layoffs in the industry.

images.alt_text: An automobile passes a SAP SE logo at the software company's headquarter campus building in Walldorf, Germany, on Tuesday, Jan.  29, 2019. SAP, Europe’s biggest software company that spent more than $10 billion on acquisitions last year, is starting a restructuring program in the face of intense competition from Salesforce.com Inc. and Oracle Corp. Photographer: Alex Kraus/Bloomberg

site_title: Philippines shakes off inflation for best growth since 1976
summary: The Philippines delivered a 7.6% GDP expansion in 2022, the country's best annual performance since 1976, driven by services and consumption growth. In the fourth quarter, GDP rose 7.2% year-on-year, surpassing estimates. The country weathered high inflation and policy rates, with inflation expected to cool in the coming months. The economy is poised to continue growing near 7% in 2023, with China's reopening expected to be a boon, according to government officials.

images.alt_text: Food prices have pushed the Philippines' consumer price index last month up 8.1 per cent from a year earlier, bringing full-year average inflation to 5.8 per cent, outside the central bank’s comfort range.

site_title: Blackstone gets extra US$500m from University of California
summary: The University of California is investing an additional US$500 million in Blackstone's real estate fund, Breit, bringing the total commitment to US$4 billion. The new investment has the same structure and terms as the initial US$4 billion commitment, with a six-year lockup period and a requirement for Blackstone to contribute US$125 million to support a minimum 11.25% annual return. This investment comes as Breit's institutional class shareholders received an 8.4% total return in 2022, despite most real estate funds losing money and stocks and bonds declining.

site_title: Indonesia’s US$20b deal to cut coal not enough, says Ember
summary: Indonesia's $20 billion deal to reduce coal emissions may not be enough to meet global climate goals. Energy think tank Ember says the country needs to retire more coal power plants and reduce operational levels to reach net zero by 2040, a decade ahead of the current target, to avoid a 1.5C rise in global temperatures.

site_title: Bank of Japan policymakers divided on wage, inflation outlook, Jan meeting summary shows
summary: Bank of Japan policymakers are divided on achieving their 2% inflation target, with some warning it could take time for wages to rise sustainably. Despite this, many agree on the need to retain ultra-loose monetary policy to support the economy and help companies raise wages. The BOJ maintained low interest rates and strengthened a monetary policy tool to prevent a 10-year bond yield from breaching a 0.5% cap. The central bank aims to curb interest rates to encourage firms to raise wages sustainably and achieve its 2% inflation target.

images.alt_text: “Our hope is that wages start to rise and that could make the 2 per cent inflation target to be met in a stable and sustainable manner,” Kuroda told a panel discussion on Friday (Jan 20) in Davos.

Finance Minister Shunichi Suzuki notes that Japan’s public finances have increased in severity to an unprecedented degree due to supplementary budgets to respond to the coronavirus and similar issues.

site_title: Tesla reports record profits, confirms growth plan
summary: Tesla reported record fourth-quarter profits of US$3.7 billion, a 59% increase from the year-ago period, driven by a 31% rise in vehicle deliveries. Revenues jumped 37% to US$24.3 billion. The company confirmed its long-term growth outlook despite concerns about competition and macroeconomic headwinds.

images.alt_text: Elon Musk ended three days on the stand defending against claims that he defrauded investors by tweeting on Aug 7, 2018, that he had “funding secured” to take Tesla private.

The trial requires jurors to delve into Musk’s state of mind when he tweeted on Aug 7, 2018, that he had “funding secured” to take Tesla private at US$420 a share and added that “investor support is confirmed”.
The move suggests Tesla is finally committing to large-scale production of the Semi, which was initially supposed to begin rolling out of factory doors in 2019.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at Thursday’s open; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.3% at Thursday's open, with the Straits Times Index (STI) reaching 3,362.53. Singtel was the most actively traded stock, increasing 2% to S$2.54, followed by Koh Brothers Eco Engineering and Genting Singapore. The three local banks, DBS, UOB, and OCBC, also traded higher, with DBS rising 0.8% and UOB up 0.4%. The gains followed losses in US and European markets, which were driven by concerns over tech sector outlook and interest rate hikes.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, gainers outnumbered losers 265 to 143 after 975.2 million securities worth S$1.5 billion were traded.
Gainers outnumber losers 122 to 36 on the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: Exodus of wealthy Chinese accelerates with end of zero-Covid policy
summary: Wealthy Chinese citizens are accelerating their exodus due to the end of zero-Covid policy, with over 32,000 holding wealth exceeding $50 million. Since December, many have traveled abroad to invest in real estate or emigrate, threatening a brain drain in China's economy and potential capital outflows. The decision by President Xi Jinping to dismantle Covid-19 travel restrictions has heightened concerns among the rich, who are worried about the Communist Party's control. This exodus could lead to billions of dollars in capital outflows, pressuring China's financial markets.

images.alt_text: It makes more financial sense for wealthy individuals to purchase properties under their own names, rather than through the family offices, experts noted.

site_title: UK business confidence drops to lowest since financial crisis
summary: Business confidence in the UK has dropped to its lowest level since the 2009 financial crisis, according to a survey by the Institute of Chartered Accountants in England and Wales. The index reading of minus 23.4 reflects persistently high inflation and fears of a recession. Retail, property, and manufacturing sectors are particularly pessimistic, with construction firms having the lowest confidence. The Federation of Small Businesses' confidence index also plummeted to minus 46 points, the lowest since the UK's second Covid lockdown. Experts warn that 2023 will be a bleak year for the economy.

images.alt_text: While some heavy users get a big discounts, business groups have warned the state support is not enough.

site_title: Binance acknowledges storing user funds with collateral in error
summary: Binance, the world's largest crypto platform, acknowledged that it mistakenly stored collateral for some of its B-Token stablecoins in the same wallet as exchange customer funds. The issue was identified in January, and the company has since transferred the assets to dedicated collateral wallets. This mistake raises concerns about the management of reserves and the lack of transparency in the industry, following the collapse of FTX in November. Binance's use of a single wallet to store both collateral and customer assets has made it difficult to verify the company's reserves, and the incident highlights the need for improved oversight and transparency in the crypto industry.

images.alt_text: Binance, the world’s largest crypto exchange, was among Bitzlato’s top three counterparties by the amount of Bitcoin it received between May 2018 and September 2022.

site_title: South Korea’s economy contracts as exports fall, rates rise
summary: South Korea's economy contracted 0.4% in the first quarter, marking its first contraction since the pandemic, as exports fell and consumer spending decreased due to rising interest rates. The contraction was expected, following a 25 basis point interest-rate hike by the Bank of Korea, which flagged the possibility of a contraction. The economy still expanded 1.4% from last year, but growth is expected to slow to 1.7% this year. Policymakers are concerned about the impact of a slowdown in China and US curbs on semiconductor exports on the country's economy.

images.alt_text: South Korea’s government expects overseas sales in 2023 to fall 4.5 per cent, after a 6.1 per cent gain in 2022.

site_title: UK factories curtail production at record rate, CBI survey says
summary: British factories are curtailing production at a record rate due to concerns over rising energy costs. According to a CBI survey, 62% of manufacturers are operating below full capacity, the highest share since January 2021. This reflects a global slowdown in manufacturing and is attributed to energy-intensive industries being hardest hit by rising energy prices. Despite easing cost increases and strong hiring, the industry warns that demand is easing too, and the Chancellor's decision to reduce government energy subsidies may further impact manufacturers.

images.alt_text: A worker walks past a crucible containing molten metal at the United Cast Bar Group's foundry in Chesterfield, Britain, April 12, 2022. REUTERS/Phil Noble

site_title: Six Serangoon Road shophouses sold for S$62.5m
summary: A portfolio of six adjoining freehold shophouses at Serangoon Road has been sold for S$62.5 million, translating to S$2,304 per square foot per plot ratio based on the property's potential gross floor area. The site is zoned for commercial use and has a gross plot ratio of 3.0. The sale price represents a significant opportunity for redevelopment into a six-storey commercial building with a gross floor area of 27,125 square feet.

images.alt_text: H2 2022 saw 67 transactions for a total value of S$625.6 million, according to Knight Frank's Wednesday market report.

site_title: Winning Acclaim for providing cover to firms
summary: Acclaim Insurance Brokers, a Singapore-based independent insurance broker, has achieved significant success in a market dominated by global giants. Founded 40 years ago by Anthony Lim, the company has grown to serve over 2,000 enterprise clients and has established itself as a regional player through strategic mergers, acquisitions, and partnerships. Under the leadership of Tony Lim, the firm has transformed into a premium risk and insurance consulting company, serving complex insurance needs for clients across various industries.

images.alt_text:
smeacclaim - From left: Acclaim chief executive Tony Lim; Acclaim-Heartware Endowment Fund 2021 recipients Dewi Murni Binte Musa and Crystal Khoo Jinying; and Acclaim chairman Anthony Lim.




Source: Acclaim Insurance Brokers

site_title: Gold steadies near 9-month peak with spotlight on US data
summary: Gold prices reached a 9-month high, trading steady at $1,946.73 per ounce, ahead of US economic data that could influence the Federal Reserve's policy tightening path. Investors expect a 25-basis-point rate hike at the Fed's Jan 31-Feb 1 policy meeting. The fourth-quarter US GDP data, due Friday, may set the tone for the Fed's decision. Lower interest rates benefit gold, and some analysts predict further rate increases in the second quarter.

images.alt_text: Swiss exports of gold to countries including China, Turkey, Singapore and Thailand surged to multi-year highs in 2022.

site_title: Meta to restore Donald Trump’s Facebook, Instagram accounts
summary: Meta plans to restore Donald Trump's Facebook and Instagram accounts in the coming weeks, two years after suspending them following the January 6 Capitol Hill riot. The move comes after Trump regained access to Twitter in November and has sparked concerns about the potential for spreading misinformation. Meta has put new guardrails in place to deter repeat offenses, stating that content violating its rules will be removed and Trump's accounts suspended for up to two years. Trump's return to the platforms could impact his 2024 presidential campaign.

images.alt_text: Trump’s company faces only a maximum US$1.6 million penalty, but it plans to appeal the sentence.

Facebook banned Donald Trump a day after the Jan 6, 2021 insurrection, when a mob of his supporters tried to halt the certification of his election defeat to Joe Biden by storming the US Capitol in Washington.

site_title: US housing demand climbs as market starts to show signs of life
summary: US housing demand is showing signs of recovery, with pending home sales rising 2.9% in December, the first month-over-month increase in over a year, according to Redfin data. The uptick in demand is attributed to easing borrowing costs, with mortgage rates dropping to 6.15% and loan applications increasing. However, Redfin warns that the market is still quiet and faces potential challenges from an economic slowdown, inventory shortage, or affordability issues.

images.alt_text: Homes in a subdivision in Atlanta. Photographer: Elijah Nouvelage/Bloomberg

site_title: Stocks to watch: Koh Brothers Eco Engineering, ComfortDelgro
summary: Two Singaporean companies made significant announcements: ComfortDelGro invested S$5.7 million in a venture capital impact fund, Shift4Good, while Koh Brothers Eco Engineering posted a 7% increase in net profit to S$2.2 million for the full year 2022, driven by growth in its engineering and construction segments.

images.alt_text: ComfortDelGro head office located along Braddell Road on Nov 25, 2021.

site_title: New Zealand’s central bank unveils new enforcement framework
summary: The Reserve Bank of New Zealand has unveiled a new enforcement framework, consisting of three public documents that outline policy for investigating serious non-compliance. The framework aims to maintain public confidence in regulated entities and encourages compliance among banks, insurance, and anti-money laundering sectors. The new framework is part of a standalone enforcement department launched last year, which oversees actions for serious or repeated breaches of regulatory requirements.

site_title: Relatives of 737 MAX crash victims seek monitor for Boeing after plea deal
summary: Relatives of victims killed in 737 MAX crashes are seeking a US judge to appoint an independent corporate monitor to oversee Boeing's compliance efforts. The move comes after a 2021 deferred prosecution agreement was reached to resolve a 737 MAX fraud conspiracy charge. The families want to ensure Boeing commits no new crimes and discloses its compliance efforts publicly. Boeing is expected to enter a not guilty plea on Thursday, following a 20-month grounding and $20 billion in losses due to the crashes.

images.alt_text: US District Judge Reed O’Connor rejected Boeing’s argument that its presence at an arraignment wasn’t required, directing the company to have an “appropriate person” at a Jan 26 hearing in Fort Worth, Texas.
Boeing is starting to step up jet deliveries and chip away at its stockpile of hundreds of already-built 737 Max (above), 787 Dreamliners and 777X jetliners.

site_title: Credit Suisse dismisses bankers in Mexico as part of global job cuts
summary: Credit Suisse dismissed most of its Mexico-based bankers as part of its global drive to reduce 9,000 roles by 2025. The cuts focused on structured-finance investment bankers, leaving the brokerage unit intact. This move follows previous staff dismissals, including local equity analysts in December and the transfer of its local wealth portfolio to Corporacion Actinver. Credit Suisse stated it remains committed to clients in Mexico and Latin America, despite the layoffs.

site_title: Europe: Stocks fall on earnings jitters, rate hike worries
summary: European stocks fell 0.3% on Wednesday, closing near a two-week low, amid concerns over the tech sector and interest rate hikes. Microsoft's weak earnings forecast and hawkish ECB messages doused hopes of a rate hike pause. Energy and industrial firms also declined, while a few companies, such as Lonza, saw gains. Economists now expect a euro zone recession in 2023 and lowered inflation outlook, but see the ECB maintaining hawkish policies.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose less than 0.1 per cent to 33,743.84 on Wednesday.

site_title: European gas slips again as ample supplies help to soften crisis
summary: European natural gas prices fell for a third day, declining 4.8% as ample supplies and milder weather eased the energy crisis. Strong LNG shipments and healthy gas stockpiles, above normal levels due to reduced consumption, contributed to the decline. Temperatures are expected to rebound after a cold snap, and more LNG is anticipated as a US export terminal restarts, leading some to suggest the worst of the crisis is over.

images.alt_text: A liquefied natural gas (LNG) tanker. For a shipment to be declared carbon neutral, companies must show transparent emissions data, reduce emissions at its operations and use offsets for any remaining emissions for the cargo’s lifecycle or those generated when the fuel is consumed.
Private-sector activity in Germany has remained resilient in January, and inflationary pressures have continued to cool,

site_title: Government-owned firms buy over half of India’s first green-bond issue: traders
summary: India's central bank raised 80 billion rupees (S$1.3 billion) through its first sovereign green-bond issue, with state-run firms and insurance companies snapping up at least half of the auction. The Life Insurance Corporation of India and government-owned banks purchased a significant portion, with the insurer cornering one-fourth of the auction. The bonds were sold at a coupon rate of 7.1% and 7.29% for the 5-year and 10-year notes, respectively, with yields lower than comparable government securities.

images.alt_text: Green-bond proceeds will be used for India's infrastructure and renewable-energy projects.
A general view of Mumbai's central financial district. Asia’s third-largest economy will need to lean more on local investors, who may be unwilling to pay extra for a green issuance.
India plans to sell the bonds in two auctions, on Jan 25 and Feb 9.

site_title: Levi revenue beats expectations as denim demand holds up
summary: Levi Strauss & Co. reported quarterly revenue exceeding expectations, with $1.59 billion in the fourth quarter, surpassing analyst estimates. The company expects net revenue growth of 1.5-3% for the fiscal year, driven by strong momentum in its direct-to-consumer business and improving trends in Europe. Total inventories increased 58% in the fourth quarter, but Levi expects more normal inventory levels by the end of the second quarter.

images.alt_text: Swiss watch exports hit a new record in 2022, climbing 11.4 per cent year-on-year to 24.8 billion Swiss francs.

site_title: Changes to Singapore’s FDI tax strategy may come only after Budget 2023
summary: Singapore may introduce new measures to attract foreign direct investment (FDI) after Budget 2023, as the country watches how other jurisdictions adjust to new global tax rules. The proposed Global Anti-Base Erosion rules could require countries like Singapore to introduce top-up taxes, limiting traditional tax incentives. To counter this, the government may consider grants, credits, and industry-specific measures, such as tax credit schemes for specific industries or enhanced tax deduction schemes for financing costs. The government may also customize the incentive framework by industry and engage with individuals to attract investments.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
Deloitte said it would not be in Singapore’s best interest to be the first mover in enacting Pillar Two rules, and waiting for international consensus on implementation options is “more prudent”.
KMPG also called for targeted grants for some GST-registered businesses to address concerns over higher costs from complying with the rate hikes.

EY’s Singapore head of tax Soh Pui Ming said: "While the pandemic is behind us, Singapore continues to face a highly volatile and uncertain global environment. Hence, we should stay focused as a nation and prime ourselves for any potential challenges and upcoming opportunities."

site_title: Traders bet BOE will cut rates before year-end to shore up economy
summary: Traders are betting that the Bank of England (BOE) will cut its key interest rate by a quarter-point before year-end to support the economy. This is the first time such a bet has been made since last August, as economic data suggests growth is stalling and inflation is easing. The BOE's policy rate currently stands at 3.5%, the highest in over a decade, and is expected to peak at around 4.5% in the summer. A half-point rate hike is still anticipated for next month.

images.alt_text: Input prices paid by factories fell by 1.1 per cent in month-on-month terms, also the biggest drop since April 2020.
Governor of the Bank of England, Andrew Bailey, speaks during the Bank of England's financial stability report news conference, at the Bank of England, London August 4, 2022. Yui Mok/Pool via REUTERS

site_title: IBM to cut about 3,900 workers, still hiring in ‘higher growth’ areas
summary: IBM announced plans to cut about 3,900 workers, approximately 1.5% of its global workforce, in an effort to reduce costs. The company's current headcount is around 260,000. Despite the job cuts, IBM expects to hire in "higher-growth areas" and reported a positive annual sales forecast, with free cash flow expected to be $10.5 billion. The company's revenue is expected to increase in the mid-single digits, driven by growth in its cloud-computing market.

images.alt_text: The agreement comes as US-China relations remain tense, especially over chips.

site_title: Boards should communicate regularly to reduce stakeholder uncertainty
summary: The International Monetary Fund has warned of a difficult year ahead for countries, citing weakening global growth in the US, Europe, and China. As interest rates rise, borrowing costs increase, and economic uncertainty grows, companies are advised to maintain regular communication with stakeholders to reduce uncertainty and anxiety. Regular updates on business proceedings, strategy, and risk assessments can foster greater trust and confidence among investors. Implementing stakeholder engagement initiatives, such as e-newsletters, profit guidance, and town hall meetings, can help companies stay connected with investors and prepare for the challenges of 2023 and beyond.

images.alt_text: MAS and Acra will propose legislative amendments to allow general meetings to be held electronically

Founder disputes have arisen more frequently as the startup ecosystem matures and more companies move into later stages of fundraising. Conflicts often revolve around existing or pending unequal contributions of founders, and often one or more co-founders choose to leave the company or is “forced” to exit.

site_title: Bitcoin options exchange Deribit looks to relocate to Dubai
summary: Deribit, the world's largest Bitcoin and Ether options exchange, plans to relocate to Dubai as soon as the third quarter if authorities provide clarity on regulations. The company, currently based in Panama, aims to open a Dubai office with 10 employees and is seeking a Full Market Product licence from Dubai's Virtual Assets Regulatory Authority. The move comes after the collapse of rival FTX and a desire for regulated trading, with Dubai offering a more flexible regulatory regime. Deribit also plans to obtain broker licences in countries like the UK, Brazil, and Singapore in the next few years.

images.alt_text: Binance, the world’s largest crypto exchange, was among Bitzlato’s top three counterparties by the amount of Bitcoin it received between May 2018 and September 2022.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower as weak earnings updates dent sentiment
summary: US stocks opened lower on Wednesday, January 25, 2023, as the Nasdaq Composite dropped 1.66% to 11,146.53, led by declines in technology shares. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.58% and the S&P 500 dropped 0.85%. Weak quarterly updates from Microsoft and Boeing fueled recession fears.

site_title: Chevron to buy back US$75b in stock after record profit
summary: Chevron plans to buy back US$75 billion of shares, triple the size of its previous authorization, following a year of record profits amid soaring energy prices. The stock repurchase program will kick in April 1 and is equivalent to almost one-fourth of the company's market value. Chevron's move comes despite criticism from politicians who accused the oil industry of war profiteering. The company also announced plans to increase dividend payouts.

images.alt_text: More than 60 tonnes of oil was pumped into the Gulf of Thailand last January after an issue with a pipeline operated by Star Petroleum Refining Public Company.

site_title: NYSE glitch caused by manual error in disaster-recovery system
summary: A manual error in the New York Stock Exchange's disaster-recovery system caused a glitch on Tuesday, resulting in over 1,300 trades and 84 stocks being marked as "aberrant". The error led to wild price swings and trading halts, affecting banks, retailers, and industrial companies, including Wells Fargo, McDonald's, and Walmart. The NYSE has resolved the issue and plans to process the affected trades. The incident is being investigated by the US Securities and Exchange Commission.

images.alt_text: The amount of stock traded at away-from-market prices was just a tiny fraction of the usual volume in stocks that normally see millions of shares change hands each day.

site_title: Navigating rough waters, CapitaLand Investment can surprise shareholders by distributing units in Reits
summary: CapitaLand Investment (CLI) may surprise shareholders by distributing units in real estate investment trusts (Reits) it owns amid challenging market conditions. The group's business model makes it vulnerable to rising interest rates, and volatile stock markets make it harder for Reits to buy assets. CLI's relatively large China exposure also raises uncertainty. However, the company's asset-light strategy, growing lodging business, and private fund management business could help it weather economic headwinds. Distributing Reit units could also lighten its balance sheet and reward shareholders. CLI's strong cash balance, credit profile, and experienced management team position it to navigate the challenges ahead.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee
CapitaLand India Trust's trustee-manager says the acquisition complements an existing portfolio in Bangalore.
Amid a "general nervousness" in the market, Sanjeev Dasgupta, CEO of CapitaLand India Trust, is optimistic about India's growth trajectory.
Even without acquisition growth, Singapore-listed Reits merit serious consideration if organic growth drivers deliver.

site_title: Need IT solutions? ‘Can,’ says ITCAN
summary: ITCAN, a Singapore-based IT company, has thrived despite the challenges of the COVID-19 pandemic, with revenue reaching S$77 million in 2021, doubling in just three years. Founder Amit Sujan attributes the company's success to its focus on delivering high-value IT services at a reasonable cost, as well as its commitment to building a strong company culture that attracts and retains top talent. With over 1,900 employees across four locations, ITCAN plans to continue expanding its services and exploring new product development opportunities.

images.alt_text: (From left) Sing Fuels chief executive officer Vikash Dhanuka, marcomms manager Jez Lee, head of global business Sonnich Thomsen and business analyst Shivani Jha.
From left: Acclaim chief executive Tony Lim; Acclaim-Heartware Endowment Fund 2021 recipients Dewi Murni binte Musa and Crystal Khoo Jinying; and Acclaim chairman Anthony Lim.

site_title: Unesco lists Odessa historical centre as world heritage site
summary: Unesco has added the historic centre of Odessa, Ukraine's port city, to its World Heritage List despite opposition from Russia. The decision was made with six votes in favour, one against, and 14 abstentions. The city, known as "the pearl of the Black Sea," was added to the List of World Heritage in Danger to access international assistance for protection and rehabilitation. Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelensky had requested the listing to protect the site from Russian air strikes.

images.alt_text: Black Sea port Odesa is just a few dozen kilometres from the frontline and has already been struck by artillery fire, Unesco said.

site_title: SoftBank deals hit record low, sapping funding for startups
summary: SoftBank's startup investments hit a record low in the last quarter, with the company participating in just eight investment rounds totaling $2.1 billion. This marks the first time the number of SoftBank's deals fell to single digits since the launch of its Vision Fund. The decline in startup investments follows a year of writedowns, with SoftBank's Vision Fund unit losing $7.2 billion in the September quarter. Global venture capital investments fell 37% to $527 billion last year, and SoftBank is unlikely to reverse course anytime soon.

images.alt_text: Another benefit would come from Arm, Son’s latest love affair.

site_title: Boeing reports quarterly loss as high costs hamper recovery
summary: Boeing reported a quarterly loss of $1.75 per share, citing high costs that hindered its recovery. Despite delivering a surge in cash, the company still faces challenges, including shortages of critical components and supplier issues. Boeing is ramping up jet deliveries and reducing its stockpile of undelivered aircraft, but faces added expenses from bringing aircraft out of storage and meeting airworthiness standards.

images.alt_text: US District Judge Reed O’Connor rejected Boeing’s argument that its presence at an arraignment wasn’t required, directing the company to have an “appropriate person” at a Jan 26 hearing in Fort Worth, Texas.

site_title: Tory turmoil grows over sleaze and recession
summary: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak's government is facing intense turmoil due to economic challenges and sleaze allegations. The country's economic downturn, with a recession looming, has led to a sharp drop in business activity, with the purchasing managers' index showing a reading of 47.8, below the market consensus of 48.8. The government's approval ratings have also plummeted to -15, with Prime Minister Sunak's lowest ever level of approval. Senior ministers are under investigation for ethics-related challenges, including Nadhim Zahawi, chairman of the Conservative Party, and Deputy Prime Minister Dominic Raab.

images.alt_text: Sunak listed his five promises: halving inflation, growing the economy, reducing debt, cutting National Health Service waiting lists and stopping the small boats that carry illegal migrants across the English Channel from France.
A sign regarding strike action outside Shortlands railway station, closed due to strike action by the National Union of Rail, Maritime and Transport, near Sevenoaks, UK, Jan 6, 2023.
Some 800,000 people who are renewing their mortgages in 2023 will see their interest rates double, as the era of cheap money comes crashing to a halt.

site_title: ‘Not the time’ for austerity as global growth slows: UN
summary: The United Nations predicts global economic growth will slow to 1.9% in 2023, down from 3.0% in 2022, amid shocks from the pandemic, Russia's invasion of Ukraine, and surging inflation. The UN urges against "short-term thinking" and austerity measures that could worsen inequality and threaten development goals. Secretary-General Antonio Guterres calls for "unprecedented action" to address the unprecedented economic circumstances, warning that slower growth and rising debt vulnerabilities could set back sustainable development goals, including achieving food security and eliminating poverty by 2030.

images.alt_text: Over 13,400 elderly people across the UK, unable to heat the homes due to spiralling energy costs, have died from cold homes related deaths in the last year.
Key economic indicators appear to have turned up of late, yet the world economy is weaker than at any point since the lockdowns of 2020.

Nadhim Zahawi, chairman of the Conservative Party, arrives at the party headquarters in London, Jan 25, 2023. Zahawi is facing calls to resign following allegations of tax evasion. The British prime minister has ordered an ethics probe into Zahawi's tax affairs.

site_title: Self-storage business growing as homes get smaller and pricier; rental rates set to rise
summary: Singapore's self-storage market is experiencing growth due to increasing property prices and smaller living spaces, with demand expected to rise 5% year-on-year. Operators are facing rising costs, including industrial space rentals and financing costs, which may lead to further increases in storage rental rates. Despite this, occupancy rates remain high, averaging 80% for facilities. Operators are adjusting rental rates to cope with rising costs, with some projecting further increases in the future. The market is expected to continue growing, albeit at a slower pace, with a possible consolidation of smaller operators.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei
United Hampshire US Reit lowers sale consideration for self-storage assets
Both parties are drawn to the Asian self-storage sector due to its strong fundamentals.

site_title: Egypt's Suez Canal nets record US$8b in annual revenue
summary: Egypt's Suez Canal Authority announced a record annual revenue of US$8 billion in 2022, a 25% increase from the previous year. The surge in revenue is attributed to a series of toll hikes, which helped pad Egypt's foreign reserves amid a worsening economic crisis. The canal, a vital source of foreign currency, carried 1.41 billion tonnes of cargo last year, with an average of 68 ships passing through daily. The Suez Canal's expansion in 2015 is credited with the revenue increase, with authorities expecting revenues to reach US$10 billion and US$12 billion in the future.

images.alt_text: The M/V Glory (above) is just over half the length of the Ever Given, which similarly blocked the Suez for six days in March 2021.

site_title: Investors are missing key earnings data after 2022 IPO collapse
