summary: The IPO market's collapse in 2022 has left a void in earnings data, hindering investors' ability to assess the economy and corporate balance sheets. With only four 2022 IPOs confirmed to report earnings, investors are missing crucial signals on consumer spending power and the industry's response to costs. The lack of data is complicating listing plans for 2023 IPO candidates and adding uncertainty to the market.

images.alt_text: Hakan Sjogren, who is responsible for company listings at Nasdaq in Sweden said that Russia’s war in Ukraine and inflation pressures have put a damper on IPOs.

site_title: Cargo ship sinks off Japan, leaving two dead, nine missing
summary: A Hong Kong-registered cargo ship, Jintian, sank off southwestern Japan, resulting in two deaths and nine missing. The 6,651-tonne vessel, carrying 22 crew members, issued a distress call and sank amid fierce winter winds. Six rescued crew members remained unconscious, while five had been revived. The cause of the sinking is unknown, but strong winds are suspected. The Japan Coast Guard is continuing to search for survivors, seeking assistance from patrol ships and aircraft.

images.alt_text: South Korean coast guard forces search for missing people after a Hong Kong cargo ship sank off South Korea's southern island of Jeju.

site_title: US: Markets tepid on earnings concerns
summary: US stocks experienced a tepid rise on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average increasing less than 0.1% to 33,743.84, while the Nasdaq Composite Index fell 0.2% to 11,313.357. Concerns over lackluster company earnings, particularly from Microsoft's disappointing fiscal guidance, contributed to the market's hesitation. Boeing reported a fourth-quarter loss, but its shares rose 0.3% on the news. Investors will be closely watching Tesla's earnings report and key economic data releases later this week, including GDP figures on Thursday morning.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange during opening bell in New York City on January 18, 2023. - Wall Street stocks climbed early on January 18, 2023, on easing worries about further Federal Reserve moves to aggressively counter inflation following the latest US economic data. (Photo by ANGELA WEISS / AFP)

site_title: Google makes changes to Android in India after antitrust setbacks
summary: Google has announced changes to its Android system in India, following a Supreme Court ruling that said the company abused its market position. The company will allow device makers to license its individual apps for pre-installation and give users the option to choose their default search engine. These changes come after Google was fined US$161 million by India's Competition Commission of India for exploiting its dominant position in Android. The move aims to address concerns raised by the court, which rejected Google's challenge to the ruling.

images.alt_text: A three-judge bench at the Supreme Court delayed the Jan 19 implementation of the CCI’s directives by one week, but declined to block them.

site_title: How to live better
summary: News outlets explore how to live more meaningfully in the face of life's challenges. Authors Kieran Setiya and Dean Rickles' books, "Life is Hard" and "Life is Short", offer insights on mental well-being. Meanwhile, design solutions and new features are showcased in various sections, including a renovated HDB flat, new watches, art exhibitions, and restaurants. These pieces aim to provide practical advice and inspiration for living a fulfilling life amidst uncertainty.

site_title: Oil prices steady after smaller-than-expected US crude build
summary: Oil prices remained steady on Wednesday after US crude inventories rose by 533,000 barrels, contrary to market expectations of a 1 million-barrel increase. Brent crude futures settled at US$86.12 a barrel, down a cent, while WTI crude futures settled at US$80.15 a barrel, up 2 cents. The market is cautiously optimistic about the data, but concerns about an economic slowdown and demand destruction persist, with some analysts warning of tight supply and no backup supply.

images.alt_text: A Pumping unit, also known as a "nodding donkey" or pumping jack, stands silhouetted against the sun at an oil plant operated by Moravske Naftove Doly (MND) AS in Damborice, Czech Republic, on Friday, Jan. 8, 2016. Oil capped the biggest two-year loss on record in 2015 as the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries effectively abandoned output limits amid a global glut. Photographer: Martin Divisek/Bloomberg

site_title: Red Bull sales top 11 billion cans in post-pandemic surge
summary: Red Bull's sales reached 11.58 billion cans in 2022, a post-pandemic surge, with revenue increasing by almost a quarter to 9.68 billion euros (S$13.85 billion). The company's new management, led by Mark Mateschitz, son of late founder Dietrich Mateschitz, attributed the growth to global sales. This marks a record year for the company, with sales, turnover, and operating profit also reaching new highs.

site_title: India joins sovereign green-bond club with US$1b issuance
summary: India has issued its first sovereign green bond worth $1 billion, priced at a 7.29% coupon rate, six basis points lower than its maturity sovereign debt. The bond will be used for renewable-energy projects and infrastructure to bolster the country's resilience to extreme weather events. The move is part of Prime Minister Narendra Modi's goal to cut India's greenhouse emissions to zero by 2070. The bond's sale reflects investors' interest in financing India's environmental projects, and it is expected to deepen the green bond market.

images.alt_text: A general view of Mumbai's central financial district. Asia’s third-largest economy will need to lean more on local investors, who may be unwilling to pay extra for a green issuance.
India plans to sell the bonds in two auctions, on Jan 25 and Feb 9.
The move is targeted to help India, one of the world’s biggest greenhouse gas emitters, achieve net-zero carbon emissions by 2070.

site_title: Microsoft scrambles to fix global outage
summary: Microsoft is investigating a networking issue affecting multiple services, including Teams and Outlook, with over 3,900 incidents reported in India and over 900 in Japan. The outage impacted thousands of users globally, preventing message exchange, call joins, and feature usage. Microsoft Teams, used by 280 million people, forms a crucial part of daily operations for businesses and schools. The company has identified a potential networking issue and is reviewing telemetry to determine next steps, with other services like Exchange Online and SharePoint Online also affected.

images.alt_text: A Microsoft office in New York, US, on Friday, Jan. 20, 2023. US technology stocks are about to hit their next hurdle when earnings season for the most influential segment of the S&P 500 Index gets underway in the coming week: vanishing profits. Photographer: Victor J. Blue/Bloomberg

site_title: Nasdaq misses quarterly profit estimates as subdued IPO market, expenses weigh
summary: Nasdaq Inc missed quarterly profit estimates due to a subdued IPO market and higher business expenses. The company hosted only 18 IPOs in the fourth quarter, down from 195 a year earlier. Operating expenses rose 3% to $557 million, while net revenue increased 2% to $906 million. Excluding one-time items, Nasdaq earned 64 cents per share, missing the analyst average estimate of 65 cents per share.

images.alt_text: Hakan Sjogren, who is responsible for company listings at Nasdaq in Sweden said that Russia’s war in Ukraine and inflation pressures have put a damper on IPOs.
The amount of stock traded at away-from-market prices was just a tiny fraction of the usual volume in stocks that normally see millions of shares change hands each day.

site_title: Elephants’ diet choices helping to fight climate change, says new study
summary: A new study suggests that elephants' dietary preferences are helping mitigate global warming by allowing forests to absorb more carbon dioxide. The research found that Asian and African elephants prefer to eat from small, leafy trees, leaving larger trees to grow and absorb more carbon. This results in forests with elephants holding more carbon than those without them. The study highlights the importance of conserving elephants, which is in line with recent agreements to protect a third of the Earth's land and oceans by 2030.

images.alt_text: Carbon capture and storage technology, which captures carbon dioxide from a range of sources and stores it underground, usually in depleted oil or gas reservoirs, has proved a controversial technology.
It's estimated that a single forest elephant today contributes US$2.6 million worth of carbon sequestration services.

site_title: Natural disasters caused US$313b in economic loss in 2022, says Aon
summary: Natural disasters, driven by climate change, caused US$313 billion in economic losses globally in 2022, according to Aon. This represents 57% above the 21st-century average, with US$132 billion in insured losses, leaving a 58% "protection gap." Despite a rise in catastrophic events, such as floods and hurricanes, the protection gap is one of the lowest on record, with 421 individual events compared to an average of 396 since 2000.

images.alt_text: Mangroves, nature, forest, water, river
Scientists have warned that climbing temperatures have wrought major changes to ocean stability faster than previously thought

The destroyed Pine Island Road following Hurricane Ian in Matlacha Isles, Florida, US, on Saturday, Oct. 1, 2022. Research firm Enki Holdings LLC pegs the economic cost of Hurricane Ian at $60 billion to $70 billion, based on damage to homes and infrastructure, as well as the cost of reconstruction and longer-term knock-on effects including the disruption in tourism. Photographer: Eva Marie Uzcategui/Bloomberg

site_title: US announces anti-poaching task force with South Africa
summary: US Treasury chief Janet Yellen announced the establishment of an anti-poaching task force with South Africa to "follow the money" behind the illegal wildlife trade, targeting rhino and other wildlife poaching. The task force aims to improve information sharing and support law enforcement agencies. South Africa, home to nearly 80% of the world's rhinos, has been hard-hit by poaching, driven by demand from Asia for rhino horns used in traditional medicine. The move is part of Yellen's continental tour to forge a new "mutually beneficial" economic strategy with African countries.

images.alt_text: Endangered pangolins get fresh chance in South Africa clinic
It's estimated that a single forest elephant today contributes US$2.6 million worth of carbon sequestration services.

site_title: Ford to confirm Europe job cuts by mid-Feb as buyers eye German site
summary: Ford plans to confirm job cuts in its European site in Saarlouis, Germany, by mid-February. The site, which produces the Ford Focus, will stop production in 2025, and among potential investors are Chinese electric vehicle maker BYD and Dutch carmaker VDL Nedcar. The company aims to present a solution for the plant's future by the end of the first quarter, with union representatives set to meet on Saturday to discuss the planned job cuts, which could be up to 2,500.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Signage is seen outside the Ford Halewood transmissions plant in Liverpool, Britain, December 1, 2022. REUTERS/Phil Noble/File Photo

site_title: Amazon faces first strike by UK workers
summary: Amazon faces its first strike by UK workers in a Coventry warehouse, with hundreds of employees walking out over a five-per-cent pay increase deemed unacceptable in the cost-of-living crisis. The strike is part of a larger wave of UK worker protests seeking pay rises that keep pace with inflation. Amazon has offered a 29-per-cent increase in minimum UK hourly wage since 2018, but workers claim poor working conditions and excessive workload measures. The GMB union urges Amazon UK bosses to give workers a proper pay rise and improve working conditions.

images.alt_text: Microsoft plans to reduce its workforce by 5 per cent.

site_title: Fed’s Brainard is frontrunner for Biden’s economic council head
summary: US Federal Reserve Vice-Chair Lael Brainard is a frontrunner to head the National Economic Council, according to sources. President Joe Biden's decision is not imminent, with interviews still ongoing. Brainard's appointment would open a slot on the Fed's seven-member board, which is debating interest rate hikes. She has been seen as a key figure in implementing the Inflation Reduction Act and semiconductor funding in the Chips and Science Act, and her views on monetary policy align with those of Fed Chair Jerome Powell.

images.alt_text: The US Federal Reserve has moved forcefully to lower demand and bring inflation closer to its 2 per cent target, raising the benchmark lending rate six times this year despite fears that it could trigger a recession.
Powell, who was renominated by US President Joe Biden, drew bipartisan backing in the divided Senate, with a final tally of 80 senators in favour of his confirmation and only 19 opposed.

Try to make a reservation in a restaurant, book a flight or get a room in a hotel, and you would have to conclude that the American economy is booming – a sentiment that runs contrary to the Fed’s mission of getting consumers to stop spending so much, in its fight against inflation.
"We've still got a lot of work to do to get inflation down to our 2 per cent target." Federal Reserve's vce chair Lael Brainard said on Thursday (Jun 2).

site_title: Covid deaths, severe cases down more than 70%, China says
summary: China's Covid-19 deaths and severe cases have declined by over 70% from peak levels in early January, according to the Chinese Center for Disease Control and Prevention. Daily fatalities dropped to 896, and severe cases fell to 36,000, from highs of 4,273 and 128,000, respectively. The decline comes after Beijing ended its zero-Covid policy, prompting criticism from the World Health Organization. The true toll may be higher due to unreported deaths outside hospitals.

images.alt_text: Passengers wait to board a train to travel for Spring Festival ahead of Chinese Lunar New Year festivities after China lifted its COVID-19 restrictions in Beijing, January 20, 2023. REUTERS/Thomas Peter

site_title: Dollar edges higher as traders await Fed decision
summary: The US dollar edged higher against major currencies on Wednesday due to anticipation of the Federal Reserve's policy decision next week. The euro fell 0.26% to $1.086, while the yen rose 0.32% to 129.74 yen per dollar. Market expectations of a possible slowdown in inflation and interest rate hikes have led to a decline in the dollar index, which is down over 11% from its September peak. Traders expect the Fed to increase rates by 25 basis points next week, and investors will also scrutinize US fourth-quarter economic growth figures.

images.alt_text: The euro, which traded around its highest since last April on Monday, was flat against the dollar at US$1.0868, down from a session high of US$1.0898.

site_title: Sun Cable’s solar project wins lifeline to carry on building
summary: Sun Cable, a $30 billion Australian solar project backed by two of the country's richest people, has secured a lifeline after a court in Sydney agreed to a sales process for the company. With less than $3.6 million in cash and looming bills of over $10 million, the project's administrators were granted an extension to find a buyer until May 31. An interest-free interim loan of $65 million from tech mogul Mike Cannon-Brookes is expected to help the project continue operations. Investment bank MA Financial is searching for a buyer, with Cannon-Brookes and mining magnate Andrew Forrest among likely bidders.

site_title: Koh Brothers Eco Engineering FY2022 profit rises 7% to S$2.2m on higher revenues
summary: Koh Brothers Eco Engineering reported a 7% increase in net profit to S$2.2 million for FY2022, driven by higher revenues of 15.9% to S$209.4 million. The company's engineering and construction, and bio-refinery and renewable energy segments saw growth. A final dividend of 0.025 Singapore cent per share was recommended for shareholders' approval.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
After hovering around the S$0.045 mark on Monday’s early trade, KBE later eased down to S$0.043 at 9.31am.

site_title: EasyJet shares surge after carrier predicts strong second quarter
summary: EasyJet shares surged 12% after the airline predicted a strong second quarter and exceeded market expectations for the full year, with a pre-tax profit of £126 million. The company expects to beat expectations for the full year, with holiday bookings and summer travel showing continued strong momentum. Despite cost-of-living concerns, EasyJet sees growth opportunities, with analysts predicting a positive earnings season.

images.alt_text: Easyjet said on Thursday (May 19) it would fly 90 per cent of its 2019 capacity in the third quarter, and had capacity on sale of around 97 per cent of pre-pandemic schedule in the fourth quarter
Easyjet has been hit by a string of problems since the removal of Covid-19 restrictions led to a rebound in travel.
Ryanair will operate 19 fewer routes and 230 fewer weekly flights in and out of Berlin airport than it did in the winter of 2019, the company said in a statement.

EasyJet said it expects the airline’s capacity in the group’s current third quarter to be 87 per cent of the pre-pandemic 2019 level. The budget carrier stressed, however, that its bookings remained “strong” for the peak-demand summer months of July and August.
Low-cost carrier EasyJet says it will step up investment in efficient aircraft, sustainable aviation fuel and operational efficiencies, and end its carbon-offsetting scheme.

site_title: Singapore’s Sea said to be eyeing sale of Phoenix Labs to cut costs
summary: Sea Ltd, a South-east Asian e-commerce and gaming group, is considering the sale of Vancouver-based indie developer Phoenix Labs to cut costs. The sale process has not started, but the company is working with an adviser and has muted investor interest. Sea acquired Phoenix Labs about three years ago for over $150 million. The tech giant is scaling back its overseas footprint and peripheral businesses due to rising competition and investor scepticism, and faces pressure to cut costs as growth in its e-commerce and gaming business slows.

site_title: Germany approves sending Leopard tanks to Ukraine
summary: Germany has approved sending Leopard 2 tanks to Ukraine, following weeks of pressure from the international community and amid expected spring offensives that could turn the tide of the war. Chancellor Olaf Scholz's government had initially been hesitant due to concerns of escalating the conflict and pulling the Nato alliance into the war. The move comes after other Nato allies had begun sending tanks to Ukraine, and is seen as a crucial step in Kyiv's efforts to defeat the Russian invasion.

images.alt_text: The issue of supplying the German-made Leopard 2 tanks to Ukraine has dominated recent discussions among Western allies about how much and what sort of material aid they should give Ukraine as the first anniversary of the Russian invasion nears.

Western allies have provided Ukraine with more and more sophisticated weaponry throughout the nearly year-old war, albeit often with fear of antagonising and getting into a full-blown war with nuclear-armed Russia.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's core inflation remained steady at 5.1% in December, despite smaller price increases for retail and other goods offset by higher inflation for food and services. The country's headline inflation averaged 6.1% in 2022. Meanwhile, shophouse sales sank 35.6% in the second half of 2022 to S$625.6 million, as investors became wary of interest-rate hikes. The Straits Times Index rose 1.8% on Wednesday, driven by a strong performance from real estate investment trusts (REITs).

images.alt_text: The single most important input in the production of food is water, says Marcos Troyjo, president of New Development Bank.

site_title: MAS could tighten monetary policy in April after ‘sticky’ inflation data in December: economists
summary: Singapore's headline inflation dipped to 6.5% year-on-year in December, down from 6.7% in November, but core inflation remained at 5.1% for the third consecutive month. Economists expect the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) to remain hawkish at its next review, citing "stickiness" in core inflation. Analysts predict MAS may tighten monetary policy in April, with some expecting a 50-basis-point adjustment to the policy band. This could lead to higher interest rates and a slower economy, but may also mitigate inflation pressures.

images.alt_text: Sharon See

ST20221226-202288710689-Lim Yaohui-pixgeneric/

People shopping for shoes at Pedro at Wisma Atria on Dec 26, 2022. 

The goods and services tax (GST) rate will be raised from 7 to 8 per cent from January 2023 and to 9 per cent from 2024.

From 2023, the new rate will also apply to any item valued up to $400, defined as low-value goods, bought from GST-registered sellers or platforms, such as e-commerce sites, and imported into Singapore via air or post.

(ST PHOTO: LIM YAOHUI)
Private-sector economists are split as to whether there will be further monetary policy tightening moves this year.
Headline inflation was unchanged from the previous month at 6.7 per cent, with most broad categories seeing prices hold steady last month.

site_title: Twitter sued in Germany over anti-Semitic posts
summary: Twitter has been sued in a Berlin court by an anti-hate speech organisation and a European group of Jewish students over six anti-Semitic posts that were not deleted despite being reported. The lawsuit seeks to force Twitter to clarify its obligations when moderating criminal content, citing Germany's law that makes Holocaust denial a criminal offence.

images.alt_text: Elon Musk, who styles himself as a champion of free speech, acquired Twitter for US$44 billion.

site_title: Could the world really avoid a recession?
summary: Global economic indicators have improved, with many indices seeing their best start to the year in decades. The Euro Stoxx 600, Hong Kong's Hang Seng, and the S&P 500 are up, and the dollar's trade-weighted value has fallen by 7%. Analysts at JPMorgan Chase, Nomura, and Citigroup have revised their recession forecasts, with the probability of a global recession now estimated at around 30%. Despite this, the world economy remains weaker than at any point since the lockdowns of 2020, with core inflation still at 5-6%. Energy prices and private-sector finances are contributing factors, with companies proving flexible to high costs and families holding onto excess savings.

images.alt_text: Eurozone GDP is now expected to increase 0.6 per cent this year, compared with an earlier forecast for a contraction of 0.1 per cent.
Some 18 per cent considered a world recession “extremely likely” in World Economic Forum (WEF) survey, more than twice as many as in the previous survey conducted in September 2022.

site_title: For tech companies, years of easy money yield to hard times
summary: US tech companies are facing hard times after years of easy money fueled by rock-bottom interest rates. Companies like Carvana, an online used car seller, have seen their valuations plummet from $80 billion to $1.5 billion, with two rounds of staff layoffs due to slowed sales. Despite the larger economy's low unemployment rate and 3.2% annualized growth rate, tech businesses are struggling, with many shedding employees and cutting back on operations as interest rates return to normal.

images.alt_text: Microsoft told workers in May that it was slowing down hiring in the Windows, Office and Teams groups as it braces for economic volatility.
Clockwise from top left: Elon Musk, Jeff Bezos, Changpeng Zhao and Mark Zuckerberg alone saw some US$392 billion erased from their cumulative net worth.

site_title: UK competition watchdog probes US$61b Broadcom-VMware deal
summary: The UK's Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) has launched an investigation into Broadcom's US$61 billion acquisition of VMware, one of the largest deals globally in 2022. The regulator is examining whether the deal could substantially harm competition in Britain. The investigation is ongoing, with the CMA expected to make a decision by March 22. The probe follows concerns over market clout and the potential for acquisitions to stifle competition.

site_title: Former vice-president Chen to become new Taiwan premier
summary: Former Taiwanese Vice President Chen Chien-jen will become the new premier, following a cabinet reshuffle after the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's losses at local elections last year. Chen, 71, is a devout Catholic and has experience in healthcare, having served as Taiwan's health minister during the 2003 SARS outbreak. He will oversee the island's slowing economy and military conscription plans, but his appointment is expected to be confirmed by President Tsai Ing-wen in a news conference on Friday.

images.alt_text: Taiwan's Premier Su Tseng-chang receiving a Covid-19 vaccine last March. He has held the post since 2019, and is known for his pithy remarks and slick, often humorous, social media presence.

site_title: Train-maker Alstom’s sales gain steam as orders beat estimates
summary: Alstom, a French train-maker, posted an 8% rise in third-quarter sales to 4.22 billion euros, beating estimates. The increase was driven by forecast-beating orders, particularly in Europe, as train ridership improved with the easing of Covid-19 restrictions. Despite increased costs due to supply-chain issues and the war in Ukraine, Alstom's sales are expected to continue due to a "high level of activity in the rail industry." The company confirmed its full-year outlooks and midterm objectives, with shares rising 1.12% following the announcement.

images.alt_text: The Coradia iLint is the world’s first passenger train to be powered by hydrogen. On Thursday (Sep 15), it successfully travelled 1,175km without refueling its hydrogen tank.
BT20221123_202288172511/mtalstom/Mark Cheong Alstom Asia Pacific President, Ling Fang

site_title: First carbon-neutral LNG cargo arrives in Taiwan
summary: The International Group of Liquefied Natural Gas Importers (GIIGNL) announced the delivery of the world's first carbon-neutral liquefied natural gas (LNG) cargo to Taiwan. The cargo, sourced from the Gorgon LNG project in Australia, was delivered by Shell Eastern LNG and meets GIIGNL's Monitoring, Reporting and Verification (MRV) and GHG Neutral Framework requirements. To achieve carbon neutrality, the company had to show transparent emissions data, reduce emissions at its operations, and use offsets for any remaining emissions. This milestone marks a step towards greater transparency and accuracy in LNG emissions reporting.

images.alt_text: Buying carbon credits by financing projects to protect rainforests has become a popular way for companies to claim they are carbon neutral, even though their activities generate gases that cause global warming.
Pressure mounts on companies to critically focus on their suppliers and actively assist them in reducing their carbon footprint as it would ultimately add to their “own” emissions.

site_title: Singapore shophouse sales sink 35.6% in H2 2022
summary: Singapore shophouse sales plummeted 35.6% in the second half of 2022, reaching S$625.6 million, down 38.7% from the same period in 2021. The market saw a significant decrease in volume, with 67 transactions, mainly driven by investors' wariness amid interest rate hikes. Leasehold shophouses saw a 34.6% drop in sales, while freehold shophouses accounted for 80.6% of transactions. Despite this, District 8 remained a hotspot, with 26 transactions, and Knight Frank predicts a more moderate sales range of S$1.3 billion to S$1.5 billion in 2023.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim
Spanning the odd numbers from 185 to 193 Joo Chiat Road, the property has dual-road frontages about 70 metres across the Joo Chiat Road and Joo Chiat Lane.
According to a report by Propnex on Wednesday (Oct 26), the median rental for shophouses stood at S$5.65 psf per month in Q3, up from S$5.50 psf per month last quarter.
Real estate agency Huttons noted that investors are shifting their focus to shophouses in Joo Chiat, Kampong Glam and Jalan Basar (pictured above), especially as price resistance sets in.

site_title: India's Tata Motors posts surprise profit on demand surge
summary: Tata Motors, an Indian automaker, reported a surprise quarterly profit of 29.58 billion rupees (S$477.2 million) for the quarter ended Dec 31, its first profit in two years. The company's luxury unit Jaguar Land Rover (JLR) turned profitable due to higher sales, favorable product mix, and better pricing. The company's passenger vehicle business continued to grow 33% year-on-year, driven by a rebound in demand from pandemic lows.

images.alt_text: Market participants are keenly watching Tata Consultancy Services for signals on the demand outlook for the sector, which is staring at the possibility of a recession in the US and Europe from where it draws a bulk of its revenue.

site_title: Thailand central bank raises key rate by a quarter-point as expected
summary: Thailand's central bank, the Bank of Thailand, raised its key interest rate by a quarter-point to 1.5% for a fourth consecutive meeting, aiming to curb high inflation. The unanimous decision follows expectations, with 21 out of 23 economists polled by Reuters forecasting a rate hike. The move is seen as a step to manage inflation despite the country's economic growth prospects being boosted by the return of Chinese tourists.

images.alt_text: The government’s target of drawing 25 million overseas holidaymakers in 2023 stands to gain momentum now that China has abandoned its Covid-Zero policy and reopened its borders.

site_title: ComfortDelGro invests 4m euros in impact fund for sustainable transport startups
summary: ComfortDelGro, a transport company, has invested SGD 5.7 million (EUR 4 million) in Shift4Good, a venture capital impact fund focused on sustainable mobility startups. The investment was made through ComfortDelGro's US$100 million venture capital fund, with the aim of supporting promising startups in the sector.

images.alt_text: ComfortDelGro is making a US$4m investment in an Israeli company that develops teleoperation software for autonomous vehicles.
Among the major participants in the fund were French carmaker Renault Group, and the European Investment Fund (EIF).

site_title: UK factories cut prices, helping Bank of England's  inflation fight
summary: UK factories reduced prices by 1.1% in December, the largest drop since April 2020, contributing to the Bank of England's inflation fight. Output prices fell by 0.8% and input prices by 1.1% month-on-month, exceeding economists' expectations. The central bank is watching for signs of future inflation pressure as it considers interest rate hikes, with a potential 4% rate target. This news comes as the UK's main inflation measure, the consumer prices index, remains above the BOE's target of 10.5%.

images.alt_text: City of London economists have warned that the tight jobs market will keep the pressure on the BOE to increase interest rates again next month despite some signs of a cooling in employer demand.

site_title: Hindenburg targets Asia’s richest man, triggering Adani selloff
summary: US-based Hindenburg Research accused Asia's richest man, Gautam Adani, of "brazen" market manipulation and accounting fraud, triggering a selloff in Adani Group companies. Adani Enterprises and Adani Ports and Special Economic Zone fell 3.7% and 7.3% respectively, while cement makers ACC and Ambuja Cements plummeted 7.2% and 9.7%. Adani Green Energy's bond also dropped 2.7 cents to 92 cents. Adani Group's chief financial officer denied the allegations, calling them a "malicious combination of selective misinformation and stale allegations." The report's timing coincided with a key share sale from Adani Enterprises, which may have been intentionally undermined.

images.alt_text: The Adani Group's proposed US$2.5 billion follow-on public offering launches later this month.
Adani New Industries, Adani Airport Holdings, Adani Road Transport, AdaniConnex and the group’s metals and mining units will become independent units.
The share offering would increase Adani Enterprises’ public float from the current 27.4 per cent level.

site_title: Tapping in-house skills to uplift those in need
summary: Aetos Holdings and law firm Dentons Rodyk have been recognized as Champions of Good for their philanthropic efforts. Aetos trained 250 youth volunteers in inclusive customer-service skills, including interacting with persons with disabilities, ahead of the National Day Parade. The company's approach to "doing good" has also boosted employee engagement and retention. Dentons Rodyk has established a practice group for philanthropy and non-profits, offering expert legal advice to clients. The firm has also supported community initiatives, such as the Community Legal Clinics scheme, and has encouraged lawyers to give back through multiple channels.

images.alt_text: Simon Cooper (centre) and StanChart volunteers collecting gifts for children under the Grant-A-Wish project.
NVPC's CEO Tony Soh.
Minister for Culture, Community and Youth Edwin Tong says: "Corporate purpose is about companies that are not just profit-oriented but also ensure their operations generate value for society.”

site_title: Heavy snow, deep cold halts transport across Japan, at least one dead
summary: Heavy snow and extreme cold blanketed Japan, halting transport and causing disruptions across the country. At least one person died, with two others under investigation. Over 300 flights were canceled, and bullet train services were suspended or delayed in northern Japan. Thousands were stranded at train stations, and some passengers had to hike through the snow to reach shelter. The bitter weather is expected to continue through Thursday, with strong winds also reported, including a cargo ship sinking between Japan and South Korea, with 13 rescued crew members.

images.alt_text: South Korean coast guard forces search for missing people after a Hong Kong cargo ship sank off South Korea's southern island of Jeju.

site_title: China formally arrests nine over Covid protests, group says
summary: China has formally arrested nine people in connection with Covid-19 protests in November, with charges of "picking quarrels and provoking trouble". The arrests follow a wave of demonstrations that called for freedom of speech and even President Xi Jinping's resignation. The government has since rolled back Covid restrictions, but authorities have continued to pursue those involved in the protests. At least 12 people are believed to be in custody, with some detained for up to two months before charges are brought.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians walk outside the Chinese embassy in Seoul on January 10, 2023. - China has suspended the issuing of short-term visas to South Koreans in response to Seoul's imposition of travel restrictions on Chinese travellers over Covid concerns, Beijing's embassy in Seoul said on January 10. (Photo by Anthony WALLACE / AFP)
Workers at a Chinese factory making Covid-19 test kits clashed with police early this month after managers terminated their employment without notice.

site_title: JTC launches tender to raise solar capacity of Jurong Island
summary: JTC launches a tender to solarise 60 hectares of land and rooftops on Jurong Island, aiming to increase the island's total solar energy capacity to 103.2 MWp. The project supports Singapore's Green Plan 2030 and is part of JTC's SolarLand and SolarRoof programmes. The tender, which closes on March 17, will generate enough electricity to power 24,300 four-room flats annually. This move supports the government's efforts to transform Jurong Island into a sustainable energy and chemicals park.

images.alt_text: photovoltaic system, solar, solar energy

site_title: Bitcoin eyes first two-day drop of 2023 as Microsoft dents mood
summary: Bitcoin is experiencing its first two-day drop of 2023, falling 2.5% to around $22,380, as investors reacted to a poor revenue outlook from Microsoft. The decline comes despite digital assets experiencing a strong start to the year, driven by expectations of central banks slowing or reversing interest-rate hikes. Market analysts attribute the drop to reversals in investor sentiment, with some warning of potential risks ahead.

images.alt_text: Binance, the world’s largest crypto exchange, was among Bitzlato’s top three counterparties by the amount of Bitcoin it received between May 2018 and September 2022.
After Celsius filed for bankruptcy last year, the company solicited bids for its assets and tried to sell itself as an operating business.

site_title: Eight missing after ship sinks between Japan, South Korea
summary: Eight crew members from a Hong Kong cargo ship, the Jin Tian, are missing after the ship sank between Japan and South Korea, off the southern island of Jeju. 14 crew members were rescued, with 11 being transported to Japan's Nagasaki after being found unconscious. The ship sent a distress signal on Tuesday evening, and three private ships helped pick up several crew members. Japan's and South Korea's coast guards are searching for the missing crew, cooperating in the rescue mission. The crew included 14 Chinese nationals and eight people from Myanmar.

images.alt_text: World container rates climbed more than sixfold by October 2021 from pre-Covid-19 levels.

site_title: Tesla plans US$3.6b Nevada expansion to make Semi truck, battery cells
summary: Tesla plans to invest over US$3.6 billion in its Nevada Gigafactory to expand production of its Semi electric truck and 4680 battery cell. The new factories will employ 3,000 people, enabling Tesla to meet its goal of halving battery costs and ramping up battery production nearly 100-fold by 2030. The move comes after the company initially committed to producing the Semi in 2019 and has struggled to scale up manufacturing of the 4680 battery cell.

images.alt_text: FREMONT, CALIFORNIA - OCTOBER 19: In an aerial view, brand new Tesla cars sit in a parking lot at the Tesla factory on October 19, 2022 in Fremont, California. Electric car maker Tesla will report third quarter earnings today after the closing bell.   Justin Sullivan/Getty Images/AFP

site_title: Feng shui and the market in the year of the rabbit
summary: Feng shui experts predict opportunities in the 2023 Year of the Water Rabbit, with market trends influenced by the Chinese New Year. Key areas to watch include Asia's markets, which may swing due to traders weighing growth outlooks. Companies like Creative Technology and London's Heathrow are also making headlines, with concerns over revenue and fees. Meanwhile, Singapore's stock market is experiencing a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Vivienne Tay
Yong Hui Ting

site_title: UN Sustainable Development Goals : Prioritise the most crucial
summary: The UN Sustainable Development Goals, established in 2015, aim to address major global problems by 2030. However, due to prioritization issues, progress will be far from the original targets, with many goals likely to be achieved half a century late. A study by the Copenhagen Consensus and Nobel laureates identifies the most crucial goals, including eradicating hunger and improving education. Effective solutions, such as daily multivitamin supplements for pregnant mothers and adaptive tablets for personalized education, can deliver significant social benefits, but are often overlooked in favor of peripheral targets.

images.alt_text: epa10037487 A displaced Yemeni child waits for her mother receiving food aid amid a heightened food insecurity, at a camp for Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs) on the outskirts of Sana'a, Yemen, 29 April 2022 (issued 27 June 2022). The World Food Programme (WFP) announced on 27 June 2022 that it was forced to reduce aid to millions of people at risk of hunger in war-ravaged Yemen due to a financial shortfall and the knock-on effects of the war in Ukraine. WFP provides monthly food aid to about 13 million out of Yemen's 30-million population. Five million Yemenis are now receiving less than 50 percent of their daily requirement, while another eight million are receiving only 25 percent of their daily needs. Yemen is experiencing a severe food insecurity because of more than seven years of war between the Houthis and the Saudi-backed government.  EPA-EFE/YAHYA ARHAB

FILE PHOTO: A woman collects grain at a camp for the Internally Displaced People in Adadle district in the Somali region, Ethiopia, January 22, 2022. Claire Nevill/World Food Programme/Handout via REUTERS THIS IMAGE HAS BEEN SUPPLIED BY A THIRD PARTY. MANDATORY CREDIT./File Photo

site_title: North Korea locks down capital over ‘respiratory illness’: report
summary: North Korea has imposed a 5-day lockdown in its capital city, Pyongyang, due to a "respiratory illness", despite previously declaring victory over COVID-19 in August 2022. Residents are ordered to stay home and submit to multiple temperature checks daily. The lockdown comes as the country faces a Siberian cold snap, with temperatures dropping as low as -22°C. This appears to be the first city-wide restrictions since Pyongyang declared COVID-19 victory. The move has raised concerns about the accuracy of North Korea's COVID-19 statistics and its healthcare system.

images.alt_text: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un attends the sixth enlarged meeting of the eighth Central Committee of the Workers' Party in Pyongyang, North Korea, in this undated photo released on December 26, 2022 by North Korea's Korean Central News Agency (KCNA). KCNA via REUTERS ATTENTION EDITORS - THIS IMAGE WAS PROVIDED BY A THIRD PARTY. REUTERS IS UNABLE TO INDEPENDENTLY VERIFY THIS IMAGE. NO THIRD PARTY SALES. SOUTH KOREA OUT. NO COMMERCIAL OR EDITORIAL SALES IN SOUTH KOREA.

site_title: Balkrishna Doshi, first Indian architect to win a Pritzker, dies at 95
summary: Architect Balkrishna Doshi, the first Indian to win the Pritzker Prize, has died at 95. Born in 1927, Doshi worked with Le Corbusier and Louis Kahn before developing his own approach to building in India's climate and culture. He designed over 500 buildings, including public housing developments and monuments, and founded the CEPT University architecture school in Ahmedabad. Doshi's buildings were known for their humility and blending of nature and culture. He received numerous awards, including the Pritzker Prize in 2018, and was recognized for his contributions to Indian architecture and education.

images.alt_text: A 12-ton industrial 3-D printer is used to print concrete for the first 3-D-printed, two-story home under construction in Houston, Texas, U.S., January 3, 2023. REUTERS/Evan Garcia
Yang is on a mission to preserve South Korean heritage in modern architectural design..
French fashion designer Julien Fournie (left) working on an embroidered dress at his studio

site_title: Gen Z finding time for second-hand luxury watches
summary: The global second-hand watch market is booming, driven by Gen Z buyers seeking luxury goods while prioritizing sustainability. Swiss watch exports hit a record 24.8 billion Swiss francs in 2022, with the pre-owned market estimated to reach 35 billion francs by 2030. Online sales platforms and watch manufacturers are now involved, verifying authenticity and expanding the market. This trend is attributed to consumers' concerns about the environment and the difficulty of buying new luxury watches due to long waiting lists.

images.alt_text: Zenith presented a new skeletonised version of the the Defy Skyline at LVMH Watch Week in Singapore.

site_title: Reits lead Singapore stocks higher on Wednesday; STI up 1.8%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 1.8% on Wednesday, led by real estate investment trusts (Reits), with the Straits Times Index (STI) closing at 3,352.77. Keppel DC Reit and Mapletree Logistics Trust were top gainers, while local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC also performed strongly. Only Jardine Cycle & Carriage declined, slipping 0.04%. The market saw 265 gainers versus 143 losers in a day of 975.2 million securities traded worth S$1.5 billion.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
Generic pictures of SGX

site_title: Gold prices hover near 9-month peak
summary: Gold prices hovered near a nine-month peak at $1,936.39 per ounce, steady on Wednesday, as investors awaited the US Federal Reserve's policy meeting and expected slower interest rate hikes. US gold futures rose 0.1% to $1,938.10. Meanwhile, Swiss exports of gold surged to multi-year highs in 2022, and the US fourth quarter GDP growth estimates are expected to be released on Thursday.

images.alt_text: Lower interest rates tend to be beneficial for bullion, decreasing the opportunity cost of holding the non-yielding asset.

site_title: Indonesia to set coal power plants emission quotas this month
summary: Indonesia plans to issue emission quotas for some coal-fired power plants by January 31, as part of its effort to create a domestic carbon trading mechanism. The move aims to reduce carbon emissions by 31.89% by 2030, exceeding the 29% target set in the 2015 Paris Agreement. The first phase of carbon trading will cover 99 power plants with a combined capacity of 33.6 gigawatts, and those with lower emissions can trade with those exceeding their quotas. Companies failing to implement carbon trades will receive lower emission allocations for the next year.

images.alt_text: As a resource-rich country, Indonesia has been trying to capitalise on its abundant nickel reserves to develop battery and electric vehicle industries at home.

site_title: US sees some Chinese companies helping Russia’s Ukraine effort: source
summary: The US has warned China of potential consequences if China provides non-lethal assistance to Russia for use in the Ukraine war. According to a source, some Chinese companies are providing non-lethal military assistance and economic support to Russia, which US officials view as a "significantly scaled-down version" of China's initial plan to sell lethal weapons. US officials are reaching out to Chinese authorities through diplomatic channels, with Secretary of State Antony Blinken set to discuss the issue with Beijing. The US has expressed concern over the involvement of Chinese companies in the matter.

images.alt_text: A giant screen displays stock indexes in Shanghai. At least 80 companies listed in mainland China are in danger of triggering delisting thresholds linked to finances, according to Caixin calculations.

site_title: News Corp in talks to sell real estate site for US$3b
summary: News Corp is in talks to sell its Move online real estate business, parent of Realtor.com, to CoStar Group for approximately US$3 billion. The deal, if finalized, would be part of an effort to maximize shareholder value. News Corp acquired Move in 2014 for US$950 million, and the sale would mark a significant shift in the company's strategy. CoStar, a US-based real estate information and marketing services provider, has a market value of about US$32 billion and owns Apartments.com. The sale is expected to be announced within days.

images.alt_text: T. Rowe Price is the largest shareholder in News Corp after the Murdoch family and owns about 17.88 per cent, according to Refinitiv data.

site_title: China boots record number of companies from its bourses
summary: China has delisted a record number of companies from its stock exchanges in 2022, with 42 companies removed, more than double the previous year. The trend is expected to continue in 2023, with at least 80 companies at risk of delisting due to poor financial performance. Companies can be expelled based on four indicators: financial performance, share performance, compliance, and law violations. The delisting process aims to cull poorly performing firms and those that break rules or laws, as regulators ramp up efforts to improve the market's overall health.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A view of a giant display of stock indexes, following the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) outbreak, in Shanghai, China October 24, 2022. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo
Many economists expect a reopening in China only after March next year, when the political reshuffle is finally completed.
About 376 Chinese companies have announced IPO plans over the past six months that are now under pending status, meaning they can go public in 2023.

site_title: Property market in Vietnam faces headwinds, but market watchers see positives in the longer term
summary: Vietnam's property market faces headwinds due to a crackdown on corporate bond irregularities, but experts predict a low likelihood of a major downturn. Despite concerns over affordability, property prices have remained resilient, with average prices increasing 8.6% in the first half of 2022. Maybank analysts believe the moderate size of the real estate sector reduces systemic risks, while Fitch analysts note that banks have buffers for a moderate stress scenario. Long-term positives are seen in the sector's financing, with regulators' pre-emptive moves and tightening oversight of bank loans.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim

site_title: Singapore’s headline inflation averaged 6.1% in 2022, core inflation at 4.1%
summary: Singapore's inflation averaged 6.1% in 2022, with core inflation at 4.1%. In December, headline inflation eased to 6.5% and core inflation remained steady at 5.1%. Private transport inflation fell to 15.5% year-over-year, while food and services inflation rose to 7.5%. The authorities expect inflation to remain firm, with headline inflation averaging 5.5-6.5% and core inflation at 3.5-4.5% in 2023.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
Headline inflation was unchanged from the previous month at 6.7 per cent, with most broad categories seeing prices hold steady last month.
Private-sector economists are split as to whether there will be further monetary policy tightening moves this year.

site_title: Ad spending on Twitter falls by over 70% in Dec: data
summary: Twitter's ad spending plummeted by 71% in December, with most top advertisers halting their spending after Elon Musk's takeover. The decline follows a 55% drop in November, with companies citing concerns over scams and platform instability. Twitter has since introduced initiatives to win back advertisers, including free ads and greater control over ad positioning. The platform's ad revenue accounts for about 90% of its income, and a slump in advertising led to a 35% year-over-year decline in fourth-quarter revenue.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A view of the Twitter logo at its corporate headquarters in San Francisco, California, U.S. November 18, 2022. REUTERS/Carlos Barria/File Photo
The Crown Estate has filed a suit against Twitter over its London premises in the West End.

site_title: NYSE says certain trades to be cancelled after glitch at open
summary: The New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) reported a glitch that caused hundreds of securities to trade without an opening auction price, resulting in wild swings and trading halts. Over 250 stock symbols were impacted, including major US companies such as Wells Fargo, McDonald's, and Morgan Stanley. The NYSE is reviewing trades as "clearly erroneous" and will void some transactions. The exchange cited a "system issue" as the cause of the glitch, which is being investigated by the US Securities and Exchange Commission.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.3 per cent higher at 33,733.96 on Tuesday.

site_title: Gorging and gagging on the beauty
summary: Fashion designers this season prioritized beauty as a value, with shows that blurred lines of gender demarcation. Anthony Vaccarello's Saint Laurent show featured theatrical, elegant designs, while Grace Wales Bonner's Paris show wove together Afro-Atlantic spirit and European luxury. In contrast, Matthew M Williams' Givenchy collection was stealthy and guerrilla-like, while Rick Owens' show was chaste and corrective. Meanwhile, designers such as Pierre Mahéo, Bianca Saunders, and Emily Adams Bode Aujla found inspiration in familiar styles, stripping away gimmicks to create uncomplicated yet memorable collections.

images.alt_text: A model presents a creation by designer Anthony Vaccarello during his Menswear ready-to-wear Fall/Winter 2023-2024 collection show for fashion house Saint Laurent as part of Men's Fashion Week in Paris, France, January 17, 2023. REUTERS/Benoit Tessier

A model presents a creation by designer Anthony Vaccarello during his Menswear ready-to-wear Fall/Winter 2023-2024 collection show for fashion house Saint Laurent as part of Men's Fashion Week in Paris, France, January 17, 2023. REUTERS/Benoit Tessier

site_title: Texas Instruments’ sales drop for the first time since 2020
summary: Texas Instruments, a leading chipmaker, reported its first sales decline since 2020, with revenue expected to range between $4.17 billion and $4.53 billion in the first quarter. The company attributed the decline to an industry slump, with customers focusing on reducing their stockpiles of used chips. Texas Instruments' chief financial officer, Rafael Lizardi, expressed uncertainty about when orders and revenue might rebound, and the company has no plans to reduce its headcount. The decline in sales is expected to continue throughout 2023, with analysts predicting a broader-based inventory correction.

site_title: Sri Lanka keeps key rate at 15.5% as country awaits IMF loan
summary: Sri Lanka's Central Bank maintained its benchmark interest rate at 15.5% for a fourth consecutive meeting, as inflation showed signs of cooling. The move aims to support the economy, which ground to a halt last year due to a debt crisis. The bank's decision is seen as a positive step pending a crucial IMF loan, which is expected to help turn the economy around.

images.alt_text: An IMF bailout will give troubled Sri Lanka much-needed funds to continue mending an economy that has fallen deeper into recession amid sky-high inflation and elevated borrowing costs.

site_title: Australia inflation surges again in Q4, argues for more rate hikes
summary: Australia's consumer price index (CPI) surged 1.9% in the December quarter, surpassing market forecasts of 1.6% and reaching a 33-year high. The annual CPI rate climbed to 7.8%, the highest since 1990, driven by increased costs of travel and electricity. This data supports the case for the Reserve Bank of Australia to raise interest rates again at its upcoming policy meeting, as inflation outpaced wages growth.

site_title: Australian dollar jumps as shock inflation data sends yields higher
summary: The Australian dollar surged nearly 1% to its highest level since August, reaching US$0.7114, after a shock 7.8% inflation rate, its 33-year high, led markets to price in another interest rate hike from the Reserve Bank of Australia next month, with yields sharply higher. This move sent the Aussie up against the Singapore dollar and the kiwi dollar, with experts predicting higher interest rates and a tougher currency to bet against.

images.alt_text: Australia's consumer price index climbed 1.9 per cent in the December quarter, outpacing market forecasts of 1.6 per cent.

site_title: Japan whaling firm pins hopes on vending machines to revive sales
summary: A Japanese whaling firm, Kyodo Senpaku, has introduced vending machines offering whale sashimi, steak, and bacon in hopes of reviving sales of whale meat, which has been declining due to increased competition from other protein sources. The vending machines, set up in upscale shopping districts, are seen as a desperate attempt to revive interest in the product, which has totalled just 1,000 tonnes in 2021. Conservationists view the move as a misguided effort, citing a lack of interest in whale meat among the Japanese public.

images.alt_text: Manuka honey is made by bees that pollinate the Leptospermum scoparium, or manuka tree, which grows throughout New Zealand and in some parts of Australia.

site_title: Apple begins hiring for effort to bring retail chain to Malaysia
summary: Apple has begun hiring employees for its first retail stores in Malaysia, bolstering its presence in South-east Asia. The company posted job listings on its website for various positions, including store managers, technical specialists, and salespeople. This move is part of Apple's expansion plans, which already include locations in Thailand and Singapore, as well as a planned store in India. The first Malaysian store is likely to be in Kuala Lumpur, and the company generated over $29 billion from its Asia-Pacific segment in the last fiscal year.

images.alt_text: The minister’s comments echo a JPMorgan Chase report cited by local media last year that said Apple will make 25 per cent of all iPhones in India by 2025.

site_title: Europe: Shares slip as economic growth data fuels rate hike concerns
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index fell 0.2% on Tuesday as economic growth data in the euro zone sparked concerns about the European Central Bank's interest rate hike plans. The data showed modest growth in January, potentially easing recession fears and giving the ECB room to raise rates. Euro zone government bond yields fell, and investors assessed the ECB's future monetary tightening path. Despite this, the Stoxx 600 has risen 6.7% so far in 2023, outperforming the US S&P 500 index.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.3 per cent higher at 33,733.96 on Tuesday.

site_title: Green bond sales from automakers could double in global EV push
summary: Automakers could borrow up to $28 billion in green bonds globally this year, doubling last year's amount, as they transition to electric vehicles. The surge is driven by maturing bonds that can be rolled into green bonds, with Volkswagen, Honda, and General Motors among the largest issuers. The global sustainable-debt market is expected to see a smaller decline this year, with green bonds posting the smallest year-on-year decline. Automakers, including Toyota and Mercedes-Benz, are tapping debt markets to finance their transition to EVs and cut carbon emissions.

images.alt_text: A general view of Mumbai's central financial district. Asia’s third-largest economy will need to lean more on local investors, who may be unwilling to pay extra for a green issuance.

site_title: Aims Apac Reit’s DPU rises 10.2% to S$0.0259 in Q3 on higher earnings
summary: Aims Apac Reit's distribution per unit (DPU) rose 10.2% to S$0.0259 in Q3, driven by higher gross revenue and net property income, increasing 14.1% and 14% year-over-year. The Reit's distributable income also rose 11.7% to S$18.7 million. Despite macro uncertainty, the CEO believes Singapore's industrial market will be supported by favourable demand and supply dynamics. The Reit will focus on tenant retention and portfolio strengthening through active asset enhancement.

images.alt_text: Sabana Industrial Reit's NTP+ at 151 Lorong Chuan. Its substantial shareholder launches a voluntary conditional offer to acquire an additional 10 per cent of its units.
The amount distributable to unitholders inched up 0.4 per cent to S$33.7 million in H1 FY2023, from S$33.6 million in the same period last year.
Manulife US Reit reported 85.7 per cent of debt pegged to fixed rates as at end June 2022.

site_title: Justin Bieber sells music catalogue to Blackstone-backed Hipgnosis
summary: Justin Bieber has sold his music catalogue to Hipgnosis Song Management, an investment entity backed by Blackstone, for an estimated US$200 million. The deal includes Bieber's publishing copyrights, master recordings, and neighbouring rights for his entire back catalogue of over 290 titles released before 2021. Universal Music Group retains ownership of the original recorded music catalogue. This acquisition is one of the biggest deals for an artist under 70, according to Hipgnosis CEO Merck Mercuriadis.

site_title: Asia: Markets swing as traders weigh growth outlook
summary: Asian markets fluctuated on Wednesday, with the Nikkei slightly higher after a strong rally over the previous three days. Traders weigh the impact of last year's interest rate hikes on the economy and growth outlook, despite optimism over China's reopening from zero-Covid measures. US factory and services activity data showed a slight improvement, but concerns about recession and higher rates persist. The Federal Reserve policy meeting next week is expected to lift interest rates by 25 basis points, and investors will closely follow the bank's statement for future moves.

images.alt_text: Analysts note that the rally in stocks this year makes markets vulnerable to negative surprises and unprepared for recession.

An electric vehicle from VinFast, a Vietnamese automaker producing electric cars and SUV on display at a showroom in California. Last December, VinFast filed for a US listing, which was once reported to help the company raise about US$2 billion.

site_title: How a Taiwan electronics firm’s subsidiary became Thailand’s largest listed company
summary: A Taiwanese electronics firm's subsidiary, Delta Electronics (Thailand), became Thailand's largest listed company in December 2022, with a market capitalization of over 1.09 trillion baht. The company's share price reached an all-time high of 876 baht on December 30, driven by strong sales of power supplies and electronic components during the pandemic, particularly in the work-from-home (WFH) market. Delta Thailand's shares are expected to continue rising due to its diversification into electric vehicles (EVs), with revenue from EVs projected to reach $1.5 billion in the 2024/25 financial year.

images.alt_text: Big C has also chosen four local banks for the potential first-time share sale, sources say.
Exxon will continue to supply finished lubricants and chemical products in Thailand through a new company to be formed.
Regulations on the equilibrium price will be adjusted to be in line with the new trading system.
Singapore, Malaysia, Thailand, Indonesia and the Philippines collectively saw 149 IPO listings in 2022, versus 132 recorded in 2021.

site_title: Family behind Singapore’s 3-in-1 coffee empire Super Group gets in on oat milk
summary: The Teo family, behind Singapore's 3-in-1 coffee empire Super Group, has expanded into the oat milk market through their venture Apricot Capital. The siblings, Darren and Elaine Teo, have co-founded two companies, Fundamental Foods and Listen Up, which supply oat milk and plant-based dairy alternatives. Fundamental Foods has received S$22 million in funding and produces oat milk powder, liquid concentrate, and ready-to-drink forms, while Listen Up produces an oat milk beverage called Oatbedient. The Teos aim to promote sustainable, plant-based foods in Asia and provide consumers with healthier alternatives to traditional ingredients.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
Singapore plant-based milk startup sings a new Oat to joy

site_title: Singapore stocks open strong on Wednesday; STI up 1.2%
summary: Singapore stocks opened strong on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 1.2% to 3,333.10. Gainers outnumbered losers 122 to 36, with top performers including The Place Holdings, Thai Beverage, and Singtel. Local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC also traded higher, with DBS up 1.6% and UOB rising 1.9%. The gains followed mixed activity on Wall Street, where the Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.3% and the S&P 500 slipped 0.1%.

images.alt_text: Dasin Retail Trust saw its unit price sink 6.5 per cent after it reported receiving a letter of demand from a lender.
Singapore Exchange (SGX) Centre.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Aims Apac Reit, Sabana Reit
summary: Aims Apac Reit's distribution per unit rose 10.2% to S$0.0259 for the third quarter of FY2023, driven by higher gross revenue and net property income. Meanwhile, Sabana Industrial Reit's substantial shareholder launched a voluntary conditional offer to acquire an additional 10% of units at S$0.465 apiece, representing a 9.4% premium over the volume-weighted average price.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Sabana Industrial Reit's NTP+ at 151 Lorong Chuan.

site_title: First-time homebuyers are teaming up to get on UK housing ladder
summary: First-time homebuyers in the UK are increasingly teaming up with partners or groups to overcome the challenges of saving for a deposit. According to Halifax, 63% of first-time mortgage completions were in two or more names in 2022, up from 59% in 2021. This trend is driven by the significant cost of purchasing a home and the need to save for a deposit. Britons buying their first home made up 52% of all mortgage deals in 2022, the highest share in the last decade.

images.alt_text: The S&P Global/CIPS flash composite Purchasing Managers’ Index (PMI) has dropped to 47.8 in January from 49.0 in December, at the bottom end of economists’ forecasts in a Reuters poll and the lowest since January 2021.

site_title: New Zealand’s newly sworn-in PM known for his candour, diet and poor dress sense
summary: New Zealand's newly sworn-in Prime Minister Chris Hipkins, 44, has taken over from Jacinda Ardern after her resignation. Known for his candour, Hipkins is a seasoned politician with 14 years in opposition and government. He was architect of the country's Covid-19 response and is seen as a personable and capable leader. Hipkins has a humble background and a love for diet Coke, and has been described as "sensible, likeable, tough and capable" by commentator Josie Pagani. He will now face the challenge of turning around the sagging popularity of Ardern's Labour government.

images.alt_text: With an economic downturn expected as interest rates soar, Chris Hipkins faces an uphill battle to win Labour a third term.
“My overall experience in this job of New Zealand and New Zealanders in this job has been one of love, empathy and kindness,” says Jacinda Ardern.

site_title: Musk ends ‘funding secured’ testimony without citing binding Tesla deal
summary: Elon Musk testified for three days in a San Francisco federal court trial, defending against claims he defrauded investors by tweeting in 2018 that he had "funding secured" to take Tesla private. Musk stated that he had discussed the idea with investors and the Saudi sovereign wealth fund, but admitted he lacked binding agreements for financing. The trial will decide if Musk artificially inflated Tesla's share price by touting the buyout's prospects, and if so, by how much. A jury of nine will deliberate on the findings.

images.alt_text: “Just because I tweet about something doesn’t mean people believe it or will act accordingly," says Elon Musk.
The Crown Estate has filed a suit against Twitter over its London premises in the West End.
Twitter rents more than 460,000 square feet of space on eight floors of the San Francisco building, according to the complaint.

Layoffs are already painful for workers who are being let go, so why make it worse than it has to be? Yet the recent wave of tech layoffs have unveiled what organisational behaviour researchers and human capital consultants see as corporate callousness reaching new depths.

site_title: Binance moved US$346m for seized crypto exchange Bitzlato, data shows
summary: Binance, the world's largest crypto exchange, processed almost $346 million in Bitcoin for seized digital currency exchange Bitzlato, whose founder was arrested for allegedly running a "money laundering engine." The US Justice Department charged Bitzlato's co-founder with operating an unlicensed money-exchange business that "fuelled a high-tech axis of crypto crime." Binance was among Bitzlato's top three counterparties by the amount of Bitcoin it received, with other major exchanges and dark-net marketplaces also involved. The move may focus attention on Binance's compliance checks with Bitzlato.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Representations of cryptocurrencies are seen in front of displayed Binance logo in this illustration taken November 10, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Shipping-cost drop a ‘smoking gun’ foretelling inflation to cool
summary: A sharp drop in maritime-freight expenses, which peaked at $8,585 in March last year and has since plummeted to $1,200, is expected to contribute to an easing in global inflation pressures. According to a study by a former IMF official, a doubling of maritime-transport expenses caused inflation to increase by 0.7 percentage point, with the pandemic-era surge in shipping costs being a "smoking gun" that foretold the global inflation spike. The decline in shipping costs is expected to bring inflation down, with the IMF estimating that most of its inflationary impact has already been seen.

images.alt_text: Shipping has been under growing pressure from environmentalists to deliver more concrete action, including a carbon levy.

site_title: Salesforce job cuts, big deals at stake as Elliott pushes for profit
summary: Salesforce may face pressure from activist investors Elliott Investment Management and Starboard Value to cut more jobs, make board changes, and spin off acquisitions to boost profitability. The company has been struggling with slowing growth, executive departures, and investor pressure, with its shares losing half their value since 2021. Elliott, which has taken a multibillion-dollar stake in the company, has expressed concerns over Salesforce's operating margins and is likely to push for strategic changes and board representation. The company's board is up for reelection this year, and discussions over potential candidates are expected to move quickly.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on December 1, 2020, The Salesforce logo at Salesforce Tower in San Francisco, California. - Cloud computing giant Salesforce on January 4, 2023, said it was shedding about 10 percent of its employees, or just under 8,000 jobs, and closing several offices. With the plan, Salesforce joins other US tech giants including Facebook-owner Meta, Twitter and Amazon that have also imposed job cuts as the world economy heads into a downturn. (Photo by Stephen Lam / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / AFP)

site_title: Finland says it mulled joining Nato without Sweden
summary: Finland has acknowledged that it may consider joining NATO without Sweden, following Turkey's criticism of anti-Turkey protests in Sweden. The protests, which included burning a Quran outside the Turkish embassy, have delayed the NATO membership process for both Finland and Sweden. Finland's Foreign Minister Pekka Haavisto said the situation has "clearly put a brake on the progress" of their applications, with a delay likely until Turkey's elections in mid-May. However, a joint application remains the preferred option for Finland.

images.alt_text: Estonian and EU flags fly outside the Estonian embassy in Moscow; the Russian foreign ministry said it had told the Estonian envoy he must leave next month, and both countries would be represented in each other’s capitals by an interim charge d’affaires instead of an ambassador.

site_title: To grow, companies should move from a customer-centric approach to a life-centric one
summary: Companies must shift from a customer-centric approach to a life-centric one to succeed in today's turbulent environment. A life-centric approach considers the broader context of a customer's life, including their values, needs, and emotions, to deliver relevant solutions. Businesses that adopt this approach are three times more likely to outperform their peers on speed-to-market and customer lifetime value. Examples of companies and government agencies that have successfully implemented life-centric approaches include Robinhood, Telkomsel, and Singapore's Central Provident Fund Board, which have seen significant growth and user satisfaction.

images.alt_text: F&B outlets can tap data -- directly, safely and properly -- to provide meaningful and personalised experiences for guests.

Companies that tested a four-day work week registered gains in revenue and employee productivity, as well as drops in absenteeism and turnover. Workers on a four-day schedule also were more inclined to work from the office than home.
Growing despite pandemic challenges, global uncertainties

site_title: UK’s Crown Estate sues Twitter over unpaid rent at London HQ
summary: The Crown Estate has filed a lawsuit against Twitter for unpaid rent at its London headquarters, valued at over $1 million. This comes as Twitter's landlord in San Francisco has also sued the company for unpaid rent, totaling $6.76 million. Twitter's new owner, Elon Musk, has been cutting costs since taking over, including halting rent payments. The lawsuit against Twitter in London is the latest in a series of disputes between the social media company and its landlords.

images.alt_text: Twitter rents more than 460,000 square feet of space on eight floors of the San Francisco building, according to the complaint.
Singapore serves as Twitter’s Asia-Pacific headquarters.

site_title: New Zealand inflation holds at 7.2%, near three-decade high
summary: New Zealand's inflation rate remains near a three-decade high at 7.2% in the fourth quarter, exceeding expectations of 7.1%. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) has forecast inflation to reach 7.5% in the first quarter and 3% by the second half of 2024. Despite the annual inflation rate being lower than forecast, the RBNZ is likely to continue raising interest rates to cool demand, with its next rate decision set for February 22.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians are reflected in a store window in Wellington, New Zealand. Photographer: Birgit Krippner/Bloomberg

site_title: Celsius may issue a bankruptcy crypto token to pay creditors
summary: Celsius Network, a bankrupt crypto company, is considering issuing a new digital-asset token to repay creditors as part of a proposal to reorganize and exit bankruptcy. The new token would be issued to creditors as part of a payout plan, potentially bringing in more money than selling hard-to-liquidate assets at depressed prices. A federal judge must approve the plan, which would also require a vote from creditors, including Celsius customers with cryptocurrency on the platform. The company plans to file court papers with details later this week.

images.alt_text: Alex Mashinsky, CEO of Celsius Network, was accused of promoting Celsius as a safe alternative to banks, while concealing that Celsius was actually engaged in risky investment strategies that contributed to its collapse and bankruptcy.

site_title: Pompeo says US averted nuclear war between India, Pakistan
summary: Former US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo wrote in his book that in 2019, US diplomats intervened to prevent a nuclear war between India and Pakistan, which had come close to escalating after India launched airstrikes inside Pakistani territory in response to a suicide bombing. Pompeo claimed that he convinced both countries that neither was preparing to use nuclear weapons, preventing a "horrible outcome." He also recalled his diplomatic efforts with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, including a conversation where Kim expressed concerns about China's influence.

images.alt_text: President Joe Biden earlier this month expanded Covid-related restrictions that allow migrants caught at the US-Mexico border to be rapidly expelled back to Mexico.
Blinken will visit Beijing on Feb 5-6, according to a US official, in the first trip by a secretary of state to the rising Asian power since October 2018.

Facebook banned Donald Trump a day after the Jan 6, 2021 insurrection, when a mob of his supporters tried to halt the certification of his election defeat to Joe Biden by storming the US Capitol in Washington.

site_title: Ticketmaster blames cyberattack for Taylor Swift tour debacle
summary: Ticketmaster blames a cyberattack for its botched sales for Taylor Swift's US tour in November, leaving thousands of fans empty-handed. The company's president, Joe Berchtold, told lawmakers the website was hit with three times the amount of bot traffic it had ever experienced, causing the issue. Ticketmaster apologized to Swift and her fans, and the incident highlights long-standing criticism of the company as a monopoly.

images.alt_text: Swift also holds the top spot on Billboard’s Hot 100 singles chart, with “Anti-Hero” notching its fourth week at No. 1.
Taylor Swift performs during the iHeartRadio Jingle Ball concert at Madison Square Garden in the Manhattan borough of New York City, U.S., December 13, 2019.

site_title: Startups begin to acquire peers as valuations fall
summary: Startups in South-east Asia are acquiring peers as valuations soften due to macroeconomic headwinds. With investors becoming more cautious, startups are raising money to make acquisitions, often through share swaps to preserve cash reserves. This trend is pushing up M&A activity, with 75 publicly disclosed deals involving at least one startup in 2022, a high from 41 in 2021 and 60 in 2019. Deals typically value startups between $10 million and $50 million, and some companies are considering inorganic growth for the first time.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
Tech IPOs in the region has tapered off after a flurry of listings from Grab to Blibli, as exiting via public markets aren't as attractive to investors as in the past.

site_title: India enters green bond market with US$1b debut auction
summary: India's sovereign green bond, valued at $1.3 billion, will be auctioned on January 25, with the proceeds to be used for unspecified projects aligned with the country's green bond framework. Authorities have promoted the issue to domestic and foreign investors, with the insurance regulator allowing the bonds to count towards infrastructure investments. Analysts expect strong demand, but the yield is expected to be smaller than comparable bonds, at 2-3 basis points. The success of this debut auction will pave the way for larger green issuance in India.

images.alt_text: The Reserve Bank of India will auction 5- and 10-year green bonds worth 40 billion rupees each on Jan 25 and on Feb 9.

site_title: Time running out for Sun Cable’s grand plan to ship sunshine to Singapore
summary: Sun Cable's ambitious Australia-Asia PowerLink project to ship solar energy from the Australian outback to Singapore has stalled due to a shareholder spat. The company, which aimed to build the world's largest solar farm and battery storage project, has entered voluntary administration. The project's fate has been eclipsed by disagreements between billionaire backers Mike Cannon-Brookes and Andrew Forrest over the project's direction and funding. With a targeted financial close of early 2024, the project's chances of success have diminished, and Singapore's Energy Market Authority has set a deadline for licensed electricity importers, further complicating the project's prospects.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

“We are pulling all the pieces (regulatory, commercial and operational) together for a financial close in 2024,” said Sun Cable's co-founder and chief strategy officer Fraser Thompson on its mega solar project, which aims to supply power to Singapore
