To regain its impact, the WEF needs to prioritize inclusivity, bringing together a diverse range of voices and perspectives, particularly from the developing world.

images.alt_text: Joan Ng

"As much as we want to think about nearshoring for resilience... no country, no region, is entirely self-sufficient," says Jacqueline Poh, managing director of the Singapore Economic Development Board.
Until companies and organisations offer more linguistic options, a segment of Singapore’s population must continue to accept a world that has moved beyond their linguistic reach.

site_title: Philippines inflation to be below 4% by Q3: central bank governor
summary: The Philippines' central bank governor predicts inflation will ease to below 4% by Q3 and 2% by early next year due to aggressive policy tightening and supply-side intervention. Food prices, which have pushed the consumer price index up 8.1% from last year, are expected to contribute to this decline. The central bank's comfort range for inflation is above 4%.

site_title: Amazon begins air freight services in India
summary: Amazon has begun air freight services in India, offering space on its planes and charter flights to Hyderabad, Bangalore, New Delhi, and Mumbai. The move aims to sell unused cargo capacity as the company adjusts to a post-pandemic slowdown, having cut 12,000 employees. Amazon Air, which began operations in 2016, operates out of small regional airports near its warehouses, helping with one- and two-day delivery. The e-commerce giant seeks to expand in Asia despite a slowdown in global online sales growth.

site_title: Geely plans to turn maker of London black cabs into EV powerhouse
summary: Geely, a Chinese automotive company, plans to invest heavily in London Electric Vehicle Company (LEVC), the maker of London's iconic black taxis, to turn it into a high-volume, all-electric brand. The investment will focus on expanding the product portfolio and technology infrastructure, with the goal of attracting other investors and partnering with other carmakers. LEVC aims to build a range of commercial and passenger vehicles on a common electric platform, with the potential to increase production capacity to 20,000 taxis per year. The move is part of Geely's broader strategy to grow its presence in the UK market and compete with larger EV makers.

images.alt_text: Zeekr, a brand created by Chinese automaker Geely, sold 72,000 vehicles in 2022, mostly in China.

site_title: Investors struggle with when to dive back into US stock market
summary: Investors are uncertain when to re-enter the US stock market due to conflicting economic data and historical trends. The S&P 500 has dropped 0.7% and rallied 1.9% in the past week, with forecasts predicting a 75% chance of an economic slowdown in the first half of 2023. Historically, sectors like materials and consumer staples tend to perform well before a recession, while rate-sensitive industries lag. Analysts are monitoring earnings reports from tech companies and the release of fourth-quarter US GDP data for clues, with some predicting a recession in the second and third quarters.

images.alt_text: A looming earnings recession “by itself could be similar to what transpired in 2008/2009,” and spark a new stock-market low that’s “much worse than what most investors are expecting,” says Wilson.
Americans are spending less, creating tough conditions for retailers such as Bed Bath & Beyond

site_title: Blinken sees lower US tensions with China but risks on Taiwan
summary: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken plans to visit Beijing on Feb 5-6, marking the first trip by a secretary of state to China since 2018. Blinken stated that tensions with China have eased, but expressed concerns over Beijing's intentions regarding Taiwan. He emphasized the need for responsible management of the US-China relationship, which affects not just the US but the rest of the world. The visit comes as China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

images.alt_text: Chinese Vice-Premier Liu He and US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen conducted extensive exchanges on the macroeconomic situation and bilateral and multilateral cooperation

US Secretary of State Antony Blinken said in a statement that Washington will provide Ukraine with Bradley Infantry Fighting Vehicles, self-propelled Howitzers, armoured personnel carriers, surface-to-air missiles, ammunition, and other items to support Ukraine.
The exchange of pleasantries indicates that US Secretary of State Antony Blinken is still set to visit Beijing soon to follow up on a November summit between Joe Biden and Xi Jinping.
resident Xi Jinping has sought to mend frayed ties with the US and its allies, holding his first in-person summit with President Joe Biden in Bali, Indonesia, last month.

site_title: New Zealand’s incoming prime minister signals policy overhaul to win back voters
summary: New Zealand's incoming Prime Minister Chris Hipkins faces a tough battle to win a third term for the Labour Party. With an economic downturn expected due to soaring interest rates, Hipkins plans to prioritize the economy and may scrap some policies introduced by his predecessor, Jacinda Ardern. He acknowledged some New Zealanders feel Labour is doing too much too fast, vowing to work hard to address the country's issues. The Labour Party has endorsed Hipkins, aiming to unite behind him ahead of an October election.

images.alt_text: Chris Hipkins must be formally endorsed by the party’s caucus on Sunday to take over as the country’s 41st prime minister.

site_title: Tee International enters agreement for loan of up to S$1.8m to fund restructuring
summary: Tee International has entered a loan agreement with Meta5 for up to S$1.8 million to fund restructuring costs, mortgage loan instalments, and operating expenses. The loan proceeds come after a conditional subscription agreement with Meta5 in August last year to issue new shares worth S$7.5 million. Trading in Tee International's shares has been suspended since June 2021. The company's restructuring efforts aim to address financial challenges and continue operations.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai

site_title: Economists forecast dismal year for Latin American economies, especially Chile
summary: Latin American economies are forecast to experience a sharp growth slowdown this year, with Chile expected to contract 1% due to interest rate hikes to control soaring inflation. Brazil's economy is projected to expand just 0.8%. The slowdown is attributed to central banks' efforts to rein in inflation.

site_title: The women who dress men
summary: Women are making a significant mark in men's fashion, breaking the industry's "fabric ceiling" dominated by men. Designers such as Grace Wales Bonner, Bode, Marine Serre, and Bianca Saunders showcased their menswear collections in Paris, highlighting the sector's growing opportunities for female designers. The trend is driven by women seeking creative expression and a fresh perspective, with many citing sustainability and a desire to challenge traditional masculine norms as motivations. As the industry continues to evolve, women are increasingly being recognized for their contributions, with some designers, like Wales Bonner, being considered frontrunners to replace prominent male designers.

images.alt_text: Luxury retailers look forward to Chinese tourists returning to Milan in large numbers.

site_title: Milan luxury real estate booms as bankers leave London for Italy
summary: Milan's luxury real estate market is booming as bankers and investors flee London due to Brexit. Since 2017, thousands of foreigners and Italian nationals have relocated to the city, driven by generous tax breaks and a renaissance in urban revitalization projects. The city's appeal lies in its compact size, connectivity to major European hubs, and high-quality lifestyle. Luxury property prices have risen 25% to €5.8 billion, with the average luxury property staying on the market for just over two months. Milan is positioning itself as a global financial hub, with new development projects underway.

images.alt_text: Some of the world’s biggest banks are under pressure to move more traders into EU cities such as Paris, Frankfurt and Amsterdam.

site_title: With rooms going for up to US$100,000 a night, new Dubai resort makes big luxury bet
summary: Dubai's new Atlantis The Royal resort has opened with a reported US$24 million performance by Beyonce and a US$1.5 billion price tag, marking a big luxury bet for the emirate. The 44-suite hotel, featuring infinity pools and a jellyfish aquarium, has already sold 231 ultra-luxury residences at an average of US$1,000 a night. Despite concerns over the timing, experts believe Dubai is in a stronger position than in 2009, with a broader tourism sector and reduced systemic risks, and that the appetite for luxury travel will not stop, despite potential recessions.

images.alt_text: Once a niche group of buyers in Dubai, Russians’ interest in real estate there surged after the war in Ukraine.

Dubai’s property sector surged in 2020 as it opened up again during the pandemic before most major cities and as rich buyers snapped up luxury units, boosting a sector that had been sluggish since the 2014-15 oil price crash.

In expatriate-dominated Dubai, though, home prices and rents have surged amid an influx of Russians looking to protect their wealth after the invasion of Ukraine, and as bankers fled strict lockdowns in Asia.

site_title: Airbus seeks outside investment for solar-powered Zephyr drone programme
summary: Airbus is seeking outside investment for its solar-powered Zephyr drone programme, Aalto, to scale the business and accelerate commercialization. The drone, designed for high-altitude surveillance and communications, relies on solar energy and will operate under the brand name Aalto. Airbus plans to maintain ownership but consider external investment to meet objectives. The company aims to start commercial operations by the end of next year, with the Zephyr at a final design stage, and expects to bring in like-minded partners to scale the business.

images.alt_text: Airbus is currently testing the system, which also provides taxi assistance, both on the ground and in the air on an A350.

site_title: Europe bracing for sharp and abrupt real estate reversal
summary: Europe's real estate market is bracing for a sharp and abrupt reversal due to rapidly rising interest rates, which have caused lending markets to seize up. Investors are scrambling to find ways to bridge financing gaps, with hefty declines in valuations threatening to cause breaches of loan covenants. The European Banking Authority estimates 1.9 trillion euros in commercial property debt, with 20% maturing this year. Regulations designed to contain real estate lending risks may make a correction steeper and more abrupt, with borrowers facing the burden of dealing with distressed assets.

images.alt_text: The Generali Tower at the CityLife district designed by Zaha Hadid; CityLife is a mixed-use luxury district on the north-east outskirts of Milan featuring swanky buildings by starchitects Daniel Libeskind, Hadid and Arata Isozaki.

site_title: China aims to approve WTO fisheries subsidy deal in 2023
summary: China is expected to approve the World Trade Organization's agreement on cutting fisheries subsidies by the end of 2023, a significant endorsement for the deal. The WTO's 164 members agreed to reduce subsidies that spur over-fishing in June 2022. Switzerland also plans to ratify the deal, seen as a crucial step for the agreement to come into effect. China's endorsement would be particularly important, as it is a major subsidizer. The deal aims to reduce over-fishing and promote sustainable fishing practices globally.

site_title: UK grid ready for emergency measures to fight power squeeze
summary: The UK's National Grid has prepared for emergency measures to combat a power squeeze due to below-freezing temperatures. The grid will pay customers to use less power on Monday evenings through the Demand Flexibility Service, which has been trialled but not run in a live situation before. The service will run from 5 pm to 6 pm and aims to reduce electricity demand during peak periods. The move is not expected to compromise electricity supplies, and the grid advises against worrying about the situation.

images.alt_text: People walk on the street in front of The Elizabeth Tower, more commonly known as Big Ben, as cold weather continues, in London, Britain, December 12, 2022. REUTERS/Toby Melville
The cold snap is expected to last for the next seven days across north-west Europe.

site_title: Paul Singer’s Elliott raked in record US$13b last year
summary: Paul Singer's Elliott Investment Management raised a record US$13 billion last year through two fundraising rounds in 2022, its largest-ever capital haul. The firm, led by Singer, uses a drawdown method and managed almost US$56 billion as of June 30. Elliott's multi-strategy hedge fund gained 5.9% last year, its best performance in two years. Singer has long warned of an end to the Federal Reserve's easy-money policies, which may present new investing opportunities.

images.alt_text: While the pace of hikes has slowed, chair Jerome Powell has also been clear that rates still have to go higher and will stay elevated for some time.
BEA selling life insurance arm in US$653m deal with AIA
Michael Dell, Paul Singer, Facebook co-founder latest to join SPAC bandwagon

site_title: 'The battle is not over': US anti-abortion groups dig in for fight ahead
summary: US anti-abortion groups are preparing for a long fight ahead after the Supreme Court overturned federal protections for nationwide abortion access in June 2022. Despite a modest victory lap by protesters outside the conservative-led institution, activists acknowledge the battle is far from over. Over a dozen states have enacted abortion bans, and referendums on reproductive rights have been won by abortion rights advocates, including in conservative states. Anti-abortion groups vow to continue the fight, with the 50th anniversary of Roe v. Wade decision marking the start of a new phase in the struggle.

images.alt_text: Anti-abortion demonstrators celebrate outside the United States Supreme Court as the court rules in the Dobbs v Women’s Health Organization abortion case, overturning the landmark Roe v Wade abortion decision in Washington on June 24, 2022.

site_title: With the global economy needing a new powerhouse, India is stepping up
summary: India is positioning itself as a global economic powerhouse, driven by Prime Minister Narendra Modi's efforts to transform the country's economy. The government is investing heavily in capital investments, and global manufacturers are looking to India as a "China-plus-one" alternative. India's economic transformation is expected to drive a fifth of world expansion this decade, with Morgan Stanley predicting it will become a $10 trillion economy by 2035. However, Modi still faces challenges, including the remnants of corruption and bureaucracy, and rising inequality. Despite these issues, Modi's administration is working to reduce absolute poverty and boost supply-side productivity, aiming to propel India to developed nation status within the next 25 years.

images.alt_text: Air India has spent months negotiating an order of about 400 narrowbody and 100 widebody jets that would allow the country’s flag carrier to upgrade service and reliability.
Hindustan Unilever's total profit for its third quarter has climbed nearly 12 per cent to 25 billion rupees (S$406.8 million).
Sacks of refined sugar at a wholesale store in New Delhi in May last year.  The country is the world's biggest sugar exporter after Brazil.

site_title: Virtual worlds, real money: Tax issues in the metaverse
summary: The metaverse's growing digital economy raises tax issues as business models and behavioural patterns shift. Despite being a virtual world, the metaverse's user remains in the same tax jurisdiction. Three main business models will emerge: platform operators, businesses, and individuals. Platform operators' revenue will likely be taxable in the residence state, while businesses may be taxed in both residence and source states. Individuals may pay Goods and Services Tax (GST) on purchases, but income from gig economy activities may be subject to income tax in their physical location. The OECD's Base Erosion and Profits Shifting plans suggest adapting tax systems to the digital economy's rapid growth.

images.alt_text: Interactions among avatars in the metaverse could result in breaches of the law, as in the real world.

Visitors are pictured in front of an immersive art installation titled "Machine Hallucinations - Space: Metaverse" by media artist Refik Anadol, which will be converted into NFT and auctioned online at Sotheby's, at the Digital Art Fair, in Hong Kong, China September 30, 2021. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu     TPX IMAGES OF THE DAY##########pic##########
Visitors at an immersive art installation at the Digital Art Fair, in Hong Kong, September 2021. Businesses expect metaverse and immersive experiences to be the new frontier of the digital economy.

site_title: US debt-ceiling crisis may set off de-dollarisation of global trade
summary: US politicians are engaged in a debt ceiling standoff, with the current limit of $31.4 trillion reached last week. A bipartisan group proposes changing the ceiling to a percentage of national economic output, but the impasse continues. The US Treasury is using financial maneuvers to avoid an immediate default. This crisis may lead to the de-dollarization of global trade, as the US dollar's status in international trade begins to lose its luster.

images.alt_text: Unfortunately, allowing the GOP to drive the US economy off a cliff may be President Joe Biden’s best option right now.
The US government hit the US$31.4 trillion debt ceiling set by Congress on Thursday.
A default on the US debt could ignite a global financial crisis and force the fragile American economy into a full-blown recession.

site_title: WealthBT: Steps to enhance your portfolio in 2023 (Ep 22)
summary: WealthBT podcast series, hosted by Genevieve Cua, discusses strategies to enhance portfolios in 2023. Key takeaways include: a more positive macro environment, bonds returning to favor, and the importance of a balanced portfolio. Additionally, experts recommend scouting for higher-interest options, maximizing CPF interest rates, and committing to a balanced portfolio. The podcast aims to provide general information and is not intended to be investment advice, encouraging listeners to consult professional advisors.

images.alt_text: Why do some investments need guardrails? Wealth editor Genevieve Cua has insights.
How can you be sure your ESG investments are doing good?

site_title: Abbott faces US criminal probe over baby formula: WSJ
summary: The US Justice Department is conducting a criminal investigation into Abbott Laboratories, the largest US supplier of baby formula, over the 2022 recall of Similac and other infant formula products due to bacterial infections. The investigation is being led by the consumer-protection branch. Abbott has cooperated fully with the investigation, following the shutdown of its Michigan plant and subsequent product recalls, which exacerbated the US baby formula shortage.

site_title: Bankman-Fried assets of almost US$700m may be forfeited
summary: Former FTX CEO Sam Bankman-Fried's assets valued at almost $700 million may be forfeited if he's found guilty of fraud. A court filing revealed 10 accounts, including shares, cash, and cryptocurrency, subject to forfeiture. The asset pool includes 55 million shares in Robinhood Markets Inc., valued at $526 million at Friday's closing price. Bankman-Fried is currently on bail under a $250 million package at his parents' home in California.

images.alt_text: Some Three Arrow creditors — who are collectively owed US3.5bn by the firm — would “have the option to convert their claims into equity in the new claim-trading company” being set up by co-founders of the bankrupt crypto hedge fund.
FTX is currently in Chapter 11 bankruptcy, a legal process that gives companies protection from creditors while hashing out a restructuring plan.

Some US$323 million in crypto had been hacked from FTX’s international exchange and US$90 million had been hacked from its US exchange since it filed for bankruptcy on Nov 11, CEO John Ray said in a separate statement on Tuesday.
Sam Bankman-Fried is accused of diverting billions of dollars in FTX client funds to Alameda to bankroll venture investments, luxury real estate purchases, and political donations.

site_title: Why this debt-ceiling fight is different
summary: The US has reached its $31.4 trillion debt limit, prompting a partisan standoff between President Biden and Republicans. The current impasse may not end with a last-minute compromise, and some experts argue that letting Republicans drive the economy off a cliff may be President Biden's best option. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen plans to pursue "extraordinary measures" to postpone the threat of a Treasury default until early June. Potential solutions, such as invoking the 14th Amendment or minting a trillion-dollar platinum coin, are being explored, but experts warn that these gimmicks could obscure blame and compromise the Fed's independence. Ultimately, Republicans must back down, and the government may be forced to shirk some obligations for a few days or weeks, potentially persuading holdouts to raise the debt ceiling.

images.alt_text: The US government hit the US$31.4 trillion debt ceiling set by Congress on Thursday.
A default on the US debt could ignite a global financial crisis and force the fragile American economy into a full-blown recession.

site_title: Not too late for a safe landing
summary: The global economy remains uncertain, with high levels of uncertainty and a huge range around consensus forecasts. Investors face a risk of a harsh hard landing or a soft landing, with insufficient progress on inflation potentially leading to an aggressive tightening path and financial market stress. Despite improved inflation data, the Federal Reserve and European Central Bank remain hawkish, and overtightening risks have risen. The forecast for global growth to slow sharply to 2.3% in 2023 marks a 30-year low, but is considered manageable, with policymakers needing to carefully steer the economy to avoid a crisis.

images.alt_text: China is expected to follow a similar pattern of post-Covid consumption seen in emerging markets, with consumers enthusiastically pursuing “revenge spending” in the Year of the Rabbit.

site_title: Juul settlement to end youth-vaping lawsuits gets initial approval
summary: US District Judge William Orrick has given preliminary approval to a settlement worth at least $1.2 billion between Juul Labs and nearly 10,000 lawsuits filed by local governments over the e-cigarette maker's role in the US youth-vaping epidemic. The settlement aims to resolve personal-injury, class-action, and school-district claims against Juul. Final approval is pending, with lawyers expected to return to the judge in July. The settlement comes as Juul faces ongoing challenges, including declining sales and a wave of lawsuits accusing the company of failing to warn consumers about vaping risks.

images.alt_text: The Bill seeks to ban smoking and vaping for those born from 2007, and to stop them from buying, possessing or using tobacco and other related products even after they reach 18.
Chinese e-cigarette maker seeks up to US$1.2 billion in US IPO

site_title: US House eyes creating task force on flawed aviation computer system
summary: The US House of Representatives plans to establish a Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) task force to improve the pilot messaging database, known as the Notice to Air Missions (NOTAM) system, which failed last week and disrupted 11,000 flights. The outage, which occurred on January 11, prompted a nationwide groundstop of US passenger traffic, the first since the 9/11 attacks. The task force aims to address the issue and prevent similar disruptions in the future.

images.alt_text: The study commences in the first quarter of 2023 and aims to assess the various models for driving structural offtakes for Singapore.
Airfares from China are now 160 per cent higher than before the pandemic, data from travel firm ForwardKeys shows, due to limited supply.
Avolon, the world's second-largest jet lessor, says that Asia will drive the aviation sector's rebound this year.

site_title: South Korean exports fall 2.7% in Jan 1-20 period
summary: South Korea's exports fell 2.7% in the first 20 days of January, a slower decline than in December. Exports to China dropped 24.4% and to the US rose 18.1%. Imports rose 9.3% over the period, increasing the trade deficit to $10.26 billion. The government expects 2023 exports to fall 4.5% after a 6.1% gain in 2022, but the trade ministry aims to achieve growth in exports.

site_title: US officials advise Ukraine to wait on offensive, official says
summary: US officials advise Ukraine to wait on launching a major offensive against Russian forces until the latest US weaponry is in place and training has been provided. The US is holding off on providing Abrams tanks due to a controversy with Germany over Leopard tanks. US officials believe an offensive would be more successful with training and new US weaponry. The US has announced sending hundreds of armoured vehicles to Ukraine for use in the fight, amid concerns that Russia will eventually push Ukrainians out of the city of Bakhmut.

images.alt_text: Western allies have provided Ukraine with more and more sophisticated weaponry throughout the nearly year-old war, albeit often with fear of antagonising and getting into a full-blown war with nuclear-armed Russia.
Interior Minister Denys Monastyrsky, responsible for the police and security inside Ukraine, would be the most senior Ukrainian official to die since the war began.
The 57-year-old Lambrecht came under scrutiny over a perceived lack of military expertise.

site_title: Biden will speak to McCarthy, warns US default would be ‘calamity’
summary: US President Joe Biden warned of a "calamity" if the US defaults on its obligations, stating it would be a financial disaster. He plans to discuss the debt limit with Republican House Speaker Kevin McCarthy and raise the issue in his State of the Union address. The US debt has accumulated over 200 years, with Biden set to discuss this with the new majority leader of the House.

images.alt_text: Chinese Vice-Premier Liu He and US Treasury secretary Janet Yellen meet in Zurich as the two leading political and economic powers seek to revive engagement with each other.
While Republicans like to portray themselves as fiscally conservative and deride Democrats as the “big-spending party,” US President Joe Biden said the reality was different.
US President Joe Biden and Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell at an event on the bipartisan infrastructure law in front of the Brent Spence Bridge in Covington, Kentucky, on Jan 4, 2023.

Kevin McCarthy agreed to major concessions to secure a role that is second in line to the Oval Office behind Democratic Vice-President Kamala Harris, including a rule that means that any of the 435 members of the House could force a vote for his removal at any time.

site_title: US can slow inflation without unemployment spike: Fed study
summary: A new study by the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago suggests that the US and other industrialized countries may be able to reduce inflation without triggering a significant spike in unemployment. The study analyzed data from 29 countries and found that the Phillips curve, which measures the inverse relationship between inflation and unemployment, has steepened since the pandemic. This could indicate that the US economy can achieve a "soft landing" as the Federal Reserve raises interest rates to combat inflation. The study's findings bolster hopes that rate hikes can curb high inflation without causing widespread job losses.

images.alt_text: Many young workers in India say they prefer to wait for skilled jobs they have been trained for, instead of accepting badly-paid menial jobs on offer.
UK supermarkets say that consumers stocked up early for Christmas, then reduced their spending in December due to higher food and living costs.
The US government hit the US$31.4 trillion debt ceiling set by Congress on Thursday.

site_title: Elon Musk plays down impact of his tweets at Tesla fraud trial
summary: Elon Musk testified in a trial over his 2018 tweet about taking Tesla private, downplaying the impact of his tweets on the company's stock price. Musk claimed that his tweets were not taken seriously by investors and that they didn't lead to wild stock price swings. He defended himself, stating that he was providing information to the public and that his tweets were not intended to be taken as accurate statements. Musk's lawyers argue that his tweets accurately conveyed his sincerity about taking Tesla private, while investors claim they were lies that cost them big losses.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: SpaceX owner and Tesla CEO Elon Musk speaks during a conversation with legendary game designer Todd Howard (not pictured) at the E3 gaming convention in Los Angeles, California, U.S., June 13, 2019.  REUTERS/Mike Blake/File Photo

site_title: Treasury has about US$500b worth of extraordinary measures
summary: The US Treasury Department has approximately $500 billion in extraordinary measures to avoid breaching the debt limit, with two special accounting manoeuvres set to free up $350 billion by early June and potentially another $143 billion by late June. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen has not specified the X-date, but analysts estimate it could be July or August. The measures include changes to government funds and suspending investments, with tax revenues expected to impact the available amount. Yellen has stated that any non-payment of obligations would be a default.

images.alt_text: The "extraordinary" measures to be taken by the US Treasury (above) can help reduce the amount of outstanding debt subject to the borrowing limit, currently set at US$31.4 trillion, and they would start when the ceiling is breached.
Cargo containers at the Port of Mombasa, Kenya. The US has taken a renewed interest in Africa as it vies for influence with Russia and China.
The US government hit the US$31.4 trillion debt ceiling set by Congress on Thursday.

site_title: Chris Hipkins to be New Zealand PM
summary: New Zealand's former Covid-19 response minister Chris Hipkins will replace Jacinda Ardern as prime minister, after receiving the only nomination from fellow MPs. Hipkins, 44, must be formally endorsed by the Labour Party's caucus on Sunday to take over as the country's 41st prime minister. He will face an uphill battle to win general elections in October, as the party lags in opinion polls. Ardern, a global figurehead for progressive politics, stunned New Zealand by announcing her abrupt exit from office, citing a lack of "enough in the tank".

images.alt_text: New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern leaves with longtime partner Clarke Gayford following the announcement of her resignation at the War Memorial Hall, in Napier, New Zealand Jan 19, 2023.

Chris Hipkins, a minister in the New Zealand government and a top contender for the job, said he expected Labour lawmakers to reach consensus on a new candidate, but declined to say whether he planned to run.
New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern: "I know that I no longer have enough in the tank to do this job justice."
New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern plans to step down no later than early February, she said  on Thursday.

site_title: US border arrests drop in January after new Biden restrictions: sources
summary: US Border Patrol agents arrested an average of about 4,000 migrants per day in January, down from 7,400 per day in mid-December, amid a seasonal slowdown and new Biden restrictions that allow migrants to be rapidly expelled back to Mexico. The number of border arrests could be the lowest since February 2021 if the trend holds. The Biden administration also launched a humanitarian entry program for 30,000 Cubans, Haitians, Nicaraguans, and Venezuelans per month if they have US sponsors and enter by air.

images.alt_text: President Joe Biden delivers a holiday message from the White House in Washington on Thursday, Dec. 22, 2022. Biden lamented partisan divisions and urged togetherness and moments of quiet reflection and simple acts of kindness for the holidays. He and the first lady are expected to visit the ChildrenÕs National Hospital tomorrow ahead of the holiday break. (Tom Brenner/The New York Times)

US President Joe Biden said he had no immediate plans to contact Vladimir Putin but left open the possibility.

site_title: Oil rises a second week as Chinese buying spree buoys market
summary: Oil prices rose for the second week, with West Texas Intermediate reaching its highest level since mid-November, settling above $81 a barrel. China's end of Covid-Zero policies boosted demand, while forecasts of record consumption and increased crude imports contributed to the rally. However, recession fears and potential interest-rate hikes from the Federal Reserve restrained the gains. Markets will closely watch the EU's sanctions on Russian refined products, which were implemented on February 5, and the potential for lower crude price caps.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures gained US$1.18, or 1.4 per cent, to settle at US$86.16 per barrel on Thursday.

site_title: What if homes were sold only for occupation and not investment?
summary: In an alternate universe, homes in Singapore could be sold only for occupation, rather than investment. This concept is explored by Leslie Yee in a recent column, where she imagines a world where nearly 90% of households own their homes for personal use. This shift could lead to a more community-focused and less speculative housing market. However, the feasibility of such a system is unclear, and experts would need to weigh the benefits against potential drawbacks.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee
HDB flats, including Sky Habitat condominium in Bishan as viewed from Block 79D Toa Payoh Central on Mar 17, 2022.
Property owners in Singapore may need to brace for higher transaction and recurring taxes in the year ahead.

site_title: Europe: Stocks end lacklustre week higher
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index rose 0.4% on Friday, despite weekly losses, driven by travel and leisure, retail, and China's reopening from Covid-19 lockdowns. The benchmark Stoxx 600 fell 0.1% for the week, weighed by disappointing earnings reports, weak US economic data, and hawkish central banker comments. Investors remain cautious, with some sectors like luxury stocks and China-exposed companies rising, while others, such as Orsted and Ericsson, fell on earnings announcements.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 index fell 1.6 per cent, breaking a six-day winning streak and marking its biggest percentage loss since Dec 15.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher on Netflix boost
summary: Wall Street opened higher on Friday, January 20, driven by a positive start from Netflix's earnings report. The Dow Jones rose 28.90 points, or 0.09%, to 33,073.46, while the Nasdaq Composite gained 72.40 points, or 0.67%, to 10,924.66. Despite recession concerns, investors were encouraged by the growth sector's earnings season kickoff.

site_title: The questions hanging over Ant Group
summary: Ant Group's restructuring efforts have largely resolved regulatory issues, with the company's business, operations, and management undergoing significant changes. The company has decoupled its consumer lending business from its payments service Alipay and severed ties with Alibaba Group Holding. Despite relinquishing control, Ant Group will not revive its IPO plans this year due to listing regulations, with the Shanghai and Shenzhen stock exchanges requiring a three-year wait after a change in actual controller. The company's valuation has also shrunk due to falling revenues from its consumer loan products, with estimates ranging from $58 billion to $72 billion.

site_title: US existing home sales lowest since 2010; price growth slows
summary: US existing home sales plummeted 1.5% to 4.02 million units in December, the lowest level since November 2010, according to the National Association of Realtors. This marks the 11th straight monthly decline in sales, the longest such stretch since 1999. Despite a 34% year-on-year drop in home resales, declining mortgage rates raised cautious hope that the housing market could be nearing a floor, with the 30-year fixed mortgage rate falling to 6.15%.

images.alt_text: The average contract rate on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage fell by 19 basis points to 6.23 per cent for the week ended Jan 13

site_title: Milan quietly gears up for return of big-spending Chinese tourists
summary: Milan is preparing for the return of Chinese tourists, with luxury retailers displaying clothes and accessories dedicated to Chinese New Year, despite the tourists not yet arriving in large numbers. Stores such as Salvatore Ferragamo and La Rinascente have showcased collections and given prominence to spirits popular among Asian customers. Chinese business travelers have been returning to Milan since last autumn, with the retail group expecting a return to pre-pandemic levels from the third quarter of 2023, according to Mariella Elia, chief financial officer of La Rinascente.

images.alt_text: Thailand is estimated to have welcomed at least 11.5 million foreign travellers last year, surpassing the initial 10 million estimate.
Malaysia's tourism industry players observed that there are increasing number of Chinese tourists choose to travel in smaller groups and more outdoor activities due to health safety concerns.
The meetings, incentives, conventions and exhibitions (mice) and corporate travel segments are expected to pick up first, followed by the return of Chinese leisure tourists.
The reopening of the world’s second-largest economy will have a critical impact on financial markets, as they seek to recover from double-digit losses in 2022.

site_title: GM and LG shelve plans for fourth US EV battery plant
summary: General Motors (GM) and its battery joint-venture partner LG Energy Solution have cancelled plans to build a fourth US battery plant, citing a tense stretch in the partnership. GM still intends to build two more plants to support its electric-vehicle ambitions, with a goal of producing 400,000 EVs in North America by mid-2024 and 1 million by 2025. The company will explore alternative partnerships, following disagreements over EV volume targets, recall costs, and union organizing efforts.

site_title: G7 agrees to review level of price cap on Russian oil in March: US Treasury
summary: The G7 economies, EU, and Australia agreed to cap sea-borne exports of Russian oil at US$60 a barrel as part of Western sanctions for Moscow's invasion of Ukraine. This price cap will be reviewed in March, according to US Treasury deputy secretary Wally Adeyemo.

site_title: US: Wall Street rallies to end higher on Alphabet, Netflix lift
summary: US stocks rallied on Friday, January 20, as the S&P 500 and Dow snapped a three-session losing streak, while the Nasdaq rose over 2%. Netflix jumped 8.5% after reporting better-than-expected subscribers and announcing Reed Hastings' departure as CEO. Alphabet climbed 5.3% after announcing 12,000 job cuts. The gains helped the communication services index rise 4%, its biggest daily percentage gain since November 30. Despite concerns about corporate earnings and a possible recession, the market is expected to continue its upward trend as investors view an opportunity to buy into beaten-up stocks.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange during opening bell in New York City on January 18, 2023. - Wall Street stocks climbed early on January 18, 2023, on easing worries about further Federal Reserve moves to aggressively counter inflation following the latest US economic data. (Photo by ANGELA WEISS / AFP)

site_title: Walmart starts e-commerce site to target small businesses, taking on Amazon
summary: Walmart has launched Walmart Business, a new e-commerce site targeting small- and mid-sized businesses, offering a one-stop shop for office supplies, furniture, food, and electronics. The platform aims to compete with Amazon, providing a business membership plan with extra savings. The move is part of Walmart's expansion into the business-to-business market, seeking to tap into the growing demand for B2B services.

images.alt_text: Walmart has majority ownership of PhonePe, after it acquired the digital payment company's parent outfit, Flipkart.
Amazon has been bracing for likely slower growth as soaring inflation forces businesses and consumers to cut back spending.
The lessons from all the disruptions since 2020 have underscored how the term “supply chain” itself is something of a misnomer, because it suggests that global trade is seamless and unbreakable.

site_title: Singapore’s Covid-19 situation stable but ‘stay vigilant even as we celebrate’ CNY: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong urged the public to remain vigilant during the upcoming Chinese New Year (CNY) celebrations despite a stable Covid-19 situation. He called for self-testing, staying home if unwell, and keeping vaccinations up-to-date. The government also plans to announce further support for parents and children, including changes to pre-school fees, in the coming months. Lee expressed gratitude for the hard work of those fighting against the pandemic and appreciation for the importance of family.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said in his New Year message that the authorities are sparing no efforts to build more HDB flats and keep public housing affordable.

site_title: Cathay Pacific flags HK$7b loss in FY2022
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways reported a forecasted loss of HK$6.4 billion to HK$7 billion for FY2022, exceeding analyst expectations of a HK$4.17 billion loss. The airline aims to operate at 70% of its pre-pandemic capacity by the end of 2023 and plans to hire 4,000 staff to rebuild staffing levels. Despite the forecast, Cathay CEO Ronald Lam noted an upbeat outlook due to improved operations and demand for short-haul travel.

images.alt_text: Cathay Pacific aims to operate over 100 return flights to China from Hong Kong a week by March.
The airline last week forecast a “substantial” annual loss even though second-half results are expected to improve sequentially.
Cathay Pacific has previously said it plans to hire 4,000 staff over the next 18 to 24 months, as it works to rebuild capacity that was cut during the pandemic.
Cathay Pacific carried over five times more passengers in October than last year, although the figure was still 85.4 per cent lower than pre-pandemic levels in 2019.
Travel industry groups have warned Hong Kong will not see a meaningful return of visitors until the three-day monitoring period and most other restrictions are lifted.

The top five destinations were Singapore, South Korea, Hong Kong, Japan and Thailand. Flight bookings to Singapore jumped 600 per cent, while bookings to the remaining four destinations soared around 400 per cent.

site_title: GM invests US$918m in US plants for gas engine, EV components
summary: General Motors (GM) is investing US$918 million in four US plants to produce V-8 petrol engines and EV components, supporting its two-prong strategy to ramp up EV production while continuing to invest in petrol-engine vehicles. The majority of funding (US$854 million) is for engine and component production, with the remaining US$64 million for castings and components. GM aims to end new petrol-powered vehicle production by 2035, but says the investments will provide job security for years to come.

site_title: Temasek-backed Zilingo to liquidate after crisis at fashion startup
summary: Zilingo, a Singapore-based fashion-tech startup backed by Temasek, is set to enter liquidation after a months-long crisis. The company's implosion was sparked by complaints of financial irregularities, leading to the dismissal of high-profile CEO Ankiti Bose in May. Despite Bose's denials, the board appointed EY Corporate Services as provisional liquidator, and major shareholders and creditors were informed of the decision. Zilingo's assets have been transferred to a new owner for an undisclosed purchase price, marking the end of the once-high-flying startup.

site_title: China air travel approaches pre-pandemic levels for holidays
summary: China's air travel has returned to pre-pandemic levels ahead of the Chinese New Year holidays, with airlines operating 99.8% of January 2019 flights. Domestic travel has driven the recovery, with seating 9.5% higher than 2019 levels. International travel remains significantly diminished, with departures from China nearly 90% lower than pre-pandemic levels. The 40-day New Year period, the largest annual migration on Earth, is expected to boost the industry.

site_title: European junk debt sales spring back to life as sentiment improves
summary: European junk-rated companies raised $1.4 billion from bond sales in January, marking a positive start to the year after a long period of market closure due to rising interest rates and Russia's war in Ukraine. Sales of sub-investment grade bonds, considered the riskiest assets globally, remain below last year's levels but are showing signs of improvement. Companies are either selling new debt or extending existing debt with higher interest rates, indicating a return to the high yield market.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Euro banknotes are seen in this illustration taken July 17, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Malaysia’s egg shortage sets Indian hatcheries on path for record exports
summary: India is set to export a record 50 million eggs to Malaysia, boosted by the country's acute egg shortage caused by soaring feed prices due to the Ukraine war. Malaysia, which used to export eggs to Singapore and other Asian countries, has turned to India as a supplier, with plans to ship 5 million eggs in December, 10 million in January, and up to 15 million in February. This unexpected order is expected to remain strong during the first half of 2023, with other Middle Eastern countries and possibly Singapore and Sri Lanka also considering Indian egg exports.

site_title: Bolivia taps Chinese battery giant CATL to help develop lithium riches
summary: Bolivia has partnered with a consortium led by Chinese battery giant CATL to develop the country's vast lithium reserves. The deal, worth over $1 billion, aims to unlock Bolivia's potential as a major supplier of lithium for electric vehicle batteries. The project, set to start in Potosi and Oruro salt flats, could boost infrastructure and pave the way for lithium production. Bolivia's President Luis Arce sees this as a key step towards industrialization and a sovereign alternative to foreign exploitation models, with the project set to produce lithium cathodes and batteries.

site_title: Singapore, other WTO members aim to firm up e-commerce agreement in 2023
summary: Singapore and 22 other WTO members have committed to intensifying negotiations for a key e-commerce agreement by year's end, aiming to establish global rules for digital trade with more legal predictability and consumer confidence. The Joint Statement Initiative on Electronic Commerce (JSI) seeks to address the rapid digital transformation of economies, with 70% of new economic value expected to come from digitally-enabled platform business models. The agreement is expected to provide greater certainty and stability for businesses and consumers, and Singapore's Minister for Communications and Information Josephine Teo hailed it as a "timely update" to international trade rules.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

site_title: Shipping still in the dark on clean fuel, says industry official
summary: Shipping industry officials are still waiting for concrete "real green" fuel solutions to reduce carbon emissions. Despite testing cleaner fuel options like ammonia and methanol, the industry lacks a global bunkering infrastructure to support the world fleet. The Greek Shipping Co-operation Committee (GSCC) chairman, Haralambos Fafalios, is calling for a simple incentive like a carbon levy to drive adoption of cleaner fuels until safer alternatives become available. The industry is under growing pressure from environmentalists to deliver more action to clean up the industry, which accounts for nearly 3% of the world's CO2 emissions.

images.alt_text: The sanctions are likely to see a great re-routing of global diesel flows – aided by Russia’s new crude buyers sending fuel back to Europe. In the short term, there is a risk of higher prices.
India’s top refiner Indian Oil, top power utility NTPC and conglomerates including Reliance and Adani group have announced plans to build green hydrogen projects.
Flagship PSA Singapore contributed 37 million TEUs in 2022, down 0.7 per cent.
The plans to supply Singapore with clean electricity from Australia via a 4,200 km-long cable are no longer feasible, says tycoon Andrew Forrest.

site_title: Ex-FTX US president Harrison taps Coinbase, Circle for new crypto firm
summary: Former FTX US President Brett Harrison has secured $5 million in funding for his new crypto software startup, Architect, from investors like Coinbase Ventures and Circle Ventures. The venture aims to build trading software for centralized and decentralized crypto markets, with the goal of regaining investor confidence. Harrison, 34, left FTX US in September amid the company's collapse, and has denied any wrongdoing. Architect's product is expected to launch in the second quarter, with plans to incorporate the software into Coinbase and Circle's platforms.

site_title: US, Philippines to boost security ties to address 'flashpoints'
summary: The US and Philippines have agreed to "invigorate" their defence cooperation to address shared security concerns, including the South China Sea dispute. The two countries vowed to strengthen their alliance, plan for potential flashpoints, and speed up the completion of US military equipment storage projects at Philippine bases. They also agreed to develop a roadmap for defence modernisation and hold a maritime dialogue to identify potential joint activities. The move aims to restore a seven-decade partnership between the two countries, which had been unsettled by the previous administration's ties with Beijing.

images.alt_text: Speaking at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr said his nation was watching as a “bystander” whenever tensions rise after Chinese or US warships cross the region.

site_title: Australia’s Sun Cable receives A$65m loan to stay afloat
summary: Australian billionaire Mike Cannon-Brookes' Grok Ventures has provided a loan of A$65 million to keep renewable-energy startup Sun Cable operational while administrators seek a buyer. The funding includes a six-month interest-free period. Sun Cable's A$30 billion project, which aimed to construct the world's biggest solar farm and export power to Singapore, entered voluntary administration amid a dispute between Cannon-Brookes and iron-ore magnate Andrew Forrest. Administrators expect to appoint bankers for a sale process within three months.

images.alt_text: Sun Cable designed its key project, Australia-Asia PowerLink, to send power from a 20 gigawatt (GW) solar farm in northern Australia across what would be the world’s longest undersea cable, to Singapore.
The plans to supply Singapore with clean electricity from Australia via a 4,200 km-long cable are no longer feasible, says tycoon Andrew Forrest.
The proposal for Singapore to draw critical energy supply from a source some 4,200 KM away through an undersea cable was deemed a hard sell from the get-go by market watchers.

site_title: ECB’s resolve to hike rates sets the stage for euro whiplash
summary: The euro is poised for renewed volatility after European policymakers pushed back against market expectations of a slowdown in interest rate hikes. Despite easing inflation and a slower pace of rate hikes from the Federal Reserve, the ECB has signaled its commitment to returning inflation to target, with President Christine Lagarde stating "stay the course." Implied euro volatility, which measures market expectations of future price movements, has dropped to 8% but is seen as undervalued, with some traders positioning for potential swings.

images.alt_text:
(FILES) In this file photo taken on October 21, 2020 people wearing face masks walk in front of the euro sign at the former ECB headquarters in the city center of Frankfurt am Main, western Germany. - The European Central Bank is expected Thursday to unleash more stimulus to help shore up a eurozone economy devastated by the coronavirus pandemic, analysts said, in a move eagerly awaited by financial markets.

The Frankfurt institution already has a 1.35-trillion-euro ($1.6-trillion) emergency bond-buying programme in place, but ECB chief Christine Lagarde all but promised in October that extra support was on the way. (Photo by Yann Schreiber / AFP)

European Central Bank (ECB) President Christine Lagarde (C) speaks next to ECB vice president Luis de Guindos (L) and the Netherlands Bank (DNB) Klaas Knot (R) during a press conference after a Governing Council meeting focused on monetary policy in the euro zone in Amsterdam on June 9, 2022. (Photo by JOHN THYS / AFP)
The Stoxx 600 index fell 1.6 per cent, breaking a six-day winning streak and marking its biggest percentage loss since Dec 15.

site_title: Swiss group Volare makes partial offer for Sabana Reit at S$0.465 per unit
summary: Swiss group Volare has made a partial offer to acquire an additional 10% of Sabana Reit's units at S$0.465 per unit, representing a premium of 9.4% over the volume-weighted average price. The move aims to diversify Volare's business away from fossil fuels and build its real estate portfolio. Analysts, including Quartz Capital, see the offer as attractive, citing the premium over a lowball implied-merger offer and the potential for unitholders to monetize their holdings.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
Higher interest expense for the period results in a 27.8 per cent rise in finance costs for the Reit.
Rising borrowing costs and more challenging conditions for inorganic growth could weigh on MLT's distributable income growth in the near term, OCBC has said.

site_title: Western climate subsidies to hit emerging markets: IMF
summary: IMF managing director Kristalina Georgieva warns that Western climate subsidies, such as the US Inflation Reduction Act, could lead to technology and production transfers from poorer emerging countries to the rich world. The US program, worth around $370 billion, may encourage businesses to move factories to the US, threatening the industrial development of emerging markets. Georgieva cautions that ignoring the impact on emerging markets could have severe consequences for the global economy.

site_title: Vanished US$4b brings down century-old Brazilian retailer in just a week
summary: Americanas, a century-old Brazilian retailer, filed for bankruptcy protection in just one week after revealing a US$4 billion accounting gap. The company's stock plummeted 77% and bonds lost half their value, wiping out US$8.2 billion in debt. The collapse is seen as "the biggest fraud in Brazil's capital markets" and has left investors and creditors scrambling. The company's founder, Americanas, was founded in 1929 in Rio de Janeiro and was backed by billionaires Jorge Paulo Lemann, Marcel Telles, and Carlos Alberto Sicupira. The bankruptcy threatens to tarnish the reputation of its main shareholders and may have far-reaching consequences for the Brazilian economy.

images.alt_text: The filing, which estimated inconsistencies of 20 billion reais (S$5.2 billion), shocked investors who had begun to snap up Americanas shares as a sign of faith in Sergio Rial’s ability to turn the company around.

A shopper at the Shein pop-up store in New York Oct 28, 2022. The breakneck supply chain pioneered by Shein is allowing a new swathe of brands to make the most of operating in the colossal retailer’s slipstream.

Supporters of Brazil's former President Jair Bolsonaro demonstrate against President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva while security forces operate, outside Brazil’s National Congress in Brasilia, Brazil, Jan 8, 2023.

site_title: Record inflows into emerging market funds on China reopening
summary: Investors poured a record $12.7 billion into emerging-market debt and equity funds in response to China's easing of Covid-19 restrictions, boosting asset classes such as commodities, mining stocks, currencies, and equity markets in popular tourist destinations. European equities saw their first weekly inflow in almost a year, while the BofA "Bull & Bear indicator" reached a 10-month high. However, markets still face uncertainties, including central bank interest rate hikes, economic "hard landing" risks, and US debt ceiling tensions.

site_title: Australia-to-Asia power project to go up for sale in January
summary: Sun Cable, a Singapore-based company, will be put up for sale by the end of January, with the sale process expected to take about three months. The company, which designed the Australia-Asia PowerLink project, will be sold after its two top investors failed to agree on future funding plans. The project aims to send 20 GW of solar power from northern Australia to Singapore via the world's longest undersea cable, estimated to cost over US$20 billion. The sale process will involve bids from both investors, Mike Cannon-Brookes and Andrew Forrest, who have differing views on the project's future.

images.alt_text: The plans to supply Singapore with clean electricity from Australia via a 4,200 km-long cable are no longer feasible, says tycoon Andrew Forrest.
The proposal for Singapore to draw critical energy supply from a source some 4,200 KM away through an undersea cable was deemed a hard sell from the get-go by market watchers.

site_title: As Covid surges in China, so is spending by funeral providers
summary: China's lifting of its zero-Covid policy in December 2022 has led to a surge in spending by funeral homes, with documents showing increased purchases of body bags, cold-storage containers, and cremation ovens. Funeral homes in provinces such as Shantou and Zigong have bought emergency supplies, citing exhaustion of existing stock. The rise in spending is attributed to the deadly toll of Covid-19 in the country, although neither facility cited a surge in Covid-related deaths as the reason for their purchases.

images.alt_text: Analysts still forecast the PBOC to keep its cash infusion measured based on its actions this week.

Patients in a hallway at a hospital in Shanghai, China, on Jan. 7, 2023. Beijing’s efforts to limit discord over its sudden “zero Covid” pivot are being challenged with increasing rancor, including from Communist Party supporters. (Qilai Shen/The New York Times)
People line up to buy fever and cold medicine as a delivery worker picks up an order at a pharmacy, in Beijing, China, Dec 6, 2022.
The virus has been spreading at a faster pace in China after the government relaxed controls in November and abruptly abandoned its Covid Zero policy in December.

site_title: Britain faces new ambulance strike dates in Feb, March
summary: Britain's ambulance workers will strike on multiple dates in February and March, following a wave of industrial action by healthcare workers demanding higher wages amid inflation. The strikes, set for Feb 6, 17, 20, 22, and Mar 6, 20, coincide with other health-related unions staging industrial action. The Unite labor union, which represents ambulance workers, urges the government to negotiate over current pay to end the dispute, stating that one-off payments and future pay increases are insufficient to resolve the issue.

images.alt_text: The walkout has piled further pressure on the National Health Service, at a time of peak demand due to winter illnesses and lengthening waiting lists for treatment caused by Covid cancellations and understaffing.

site_title: Real estate companies may find it tough getting funding if they don’t go green: OCBC
summary: Real estate companies in Singapore may face reduced funding opportunities if they don't adopt sustainability practices. OCBC's sector report notes that green financing for the real estate sector is becoming mainstream, with developers and banks increasingly looking at environmental, social, and governance (ESG) risks. Green buildings command a premium among buyers and tenants, with 54% of homeowners willing to pay up to 4% more for a certified green building. The report also highlights regulatory moves to encourage greener practices, including grants for retrofitting and the government's plan to issue $35 billion in green bonds by 2030.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
The resumption of high-impact events, including the Formula One (F1) race in Singapore, brought throngs of business cum leisure (b-leisure) travellers back to the island.

site_title: Genesis, a crypto lending firm, files for bankruptcy
summary: Genesis Global Holdco, a major crypto lender, filed for bankruptcy on January 19, becoming the fourth major crypto lender to fail since last spring. The firm, which survived longer than others but suffered from FTX's implosion, froze withdrawals in November citing "market turmoil." The bankruptcy filing covers three entities and is related to the SEC's charges against Genesis for offering unregistered securities in a partnership with Gemini. The move follows other major lenders Celsius Network and Voyager Digital, whose customers lost billions of dollars in deposits.

images.alt_text: Some Three Arrow creditors — who are collectively owed US3.5bn by the firm — would “have the option to convert their claims into equity in the new claim-trading company” being set up by co-founders of the bankrupt crypto hedge fund.

site_title: Alibaba seen fighting off Cohen’s pressure for stock buybacks
summary: Alibaba Group Holding has purchased US$7.3 billion of its US-listed stock in the nine months of 2022, a 21% drop from the previous year. Billionaire investor Ryan Cohen's efforts to push Alibaba to buy back more shares may face challenges due to his relatively small stake and the company's less focus on shareholder value compared to US counterparts. Analysts consider a buyback to be a signaling effect, requiring significant investments to be convincing.

site_title: Opec development fund raises US$1b with first bond
summary: The Opec Development Fund has raised $1 billion from its first bond, with investors paying 4.5% interest. The three-year bond will fund projects in food security, healthcare, and renewable energy. The majority of buyers were central banks and official institutions, with asset managers and insurance pension funds also participating. Geographically, the buyers were mainly from Europe, the Middle East, and Africa.

site_title: Jubilant Chinese head home for New Year celebrations
summary: Millions of Chinese people are traveling to reunite with their families for the Chinese New Year, after the lifting of the country's zero-Covid policy. Commuters on a packed train from Shanghai to Wuhan, where the first cases of the disease were reported in 2019, eagerly awaited their reunions. Despite case numbers surging nationwide, many passengers were celebrating, with some having caught the virus and recovered. The end of the zero-Covid policy marks a return to normal life, but concerns remain about rural areas and medical facilities.

images.alt_text: Analysts still forecast the PBOC to keep its cash infusion measured based on its actions this week.

Patients in a hallway at a hospital in Shanghai, China, on Jan. 7, 2023. Beijing’s efforts to limit discord over its sudden “zero Covid” pivot are being challenged with increasing rancor, including from Communist Party supporters. (Qilai Shen/The New York Times)
China is expected to follow a similar pattern of post-Covid consumption seen in emerging markets, with consumers enthusiastically pursuing “revenge spending” in the Year of the Rabbit.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The world's largest investors are bullish on commodities, infrastructure, and real estate, with a focus on China due to its large size. Malaysia's inflation rate eased to 3.8% in December, while Singapore shares jumped 0.5% following Asian market gains. SPH Media will reassess its circulation data methodology after an internal review found it to be overstated. The COE supply for February to April increased by 3.4% to 3,144 per month, marking the first rise after two quarters of decline.

site_title: Google cutting 12,000 jobs in 6% slash to global workforce
summary: Google, the parent company of Alphabet, announced it will cut 12,000 jobs, approximately 6% of its global workforce, due to a faltering global economy and soaring inflation. CEO Sundar Pichai takes "full responsibility" for the decisions. The layoffs follow a slowdown in digital advertising and trail Amazon and Microsoft Corp. in cloud computing. Google will provide 16 weeks of severance and six months of health benefits to affected employees. This move joins other tech giants like Meta Platforms, Twitter, and Amazon in retrenching amid economic uncertainty.

images.alt_text: THE parent company of India's ShareChat has raised nearly US$300 million in fresh funding from Alphabet's Google, media giant Times Group and Singapore's Temasek Holdings, valuing the social media firm at nearly US$5 billion, 2 sources involved in the deal discussions told Reuters.

site_title: Few jobs and meagre pay for urban youth despite India’s economic growth
summary: India's economy is experiencing a surge despite high urban unemployment, with the urban unemployment rate reaching 10.1% in December. Many young workers are choosing to wait for skilled jobs over poorly paid menial positions, exacerbating the problem. The number of job seekers has increased to 37 million, with rural youths driving up the labor-force participation rate. Economists warn that worsening employment could affect consumer demand, drag private investments, and hurt growth prospects. The government has proposed policies to stimulate economic growth, but critics argue that incentives are not creating enough jobs, leading to a "K-shaped" recovery.

images.alt_text: India, where half the population is under the age of 30, is set to be the world’s fastest-growing major economy in the coming years.
Expenses rose faster due to greater energy, food, staff and transportation costs so prices charged remained elevated despite moderating slightly from November.

Workers make glass bangles at a workshop in Firozabad, India, Oct 12, 2022. India's manufacturing purchasing managers’ index, compiled by S&P Global, rose to 57.8 in December from November’s 55.7, better than a Reuters poll median forecast for 54.3.

Average house prices in India were expected to rise 5.0 per cent over each of the next three years, lagging the current consumer price inflation rate, after increasing by 7 per cent in 2022, according to the Nov 9-Dec 1 poll.

site_title: Kuroda signals no policy shift after inflation hits 41-year high
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda signaled no policy shift despite the highest inflation rate in 41 years, which reached 4% in a government report. Kuroda attributed the inflation to import-price increases, stating that it may start cooling from next month. He expressed hope that rising wages could help meet the 2% inflation target in a stable and sustainable manner, but emphasized that it would take time. Kuroda's comments reinforced his determination to continue with monetary easing despite market speculation about a potential policy shift after his term ends on April 8.

images.alt_text: Haruhiko Kuroda, governor of the Bank of Japan (BOJ), during a panel session on the closing day of the World Economic Forum (WEF) in Davos, Switzerland, on Friday, Jan. 20, 2023. The annual Davos gathering of political leaders, top executives and celebrities runs from January 16 to 20. Photographer: Stefan Wermuth/Bloomberg

site_title: Church of England bishops apologise to LGBTQI+ people
summary: The Church of England bishops have issued an open letter apologizing to LGBTQI+ people for the rejection and exclusion they faced in churches, calling their treatment "shameful" and "profoundly wrong." The bishops acknowledged that they had not loved LGBTQI+ individuals as God loves them, and reaffirmed that they are welcome and valued. The apology comes after the church published proposals that would refuse to allow same-sex couples to get married in its churches, but would allow priests to bless them. The bishops' apology marks a significant shift in the church's stance on LGBTQI+ issues.

site_title: Siemens Energy’s troubles mount on wind turbine issues
summary: Siemens Energy faces a 2023 net loss of around 647 million euros due to ongoing issues with its Spanish wind turbine business, Gamesa, which has found costly flaws in its turbines. The company had previously moved to fully control Gamesa to address protracted problems. Despite improvements in other business areas, such as gas service and grid technology, the wind turbine issues offset these gains, taking the company's total deficits over four years to 3.7 billion euros.

site_title: US wants to oppose China, EU wants to engage it: French finance minister
summary: French Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire says the EU should not get caught in a standoff with the US over China, instead forging its own path to strengthen economic relations. Le Maire believes China must be a part of the global game, and the EU should work with China to achieve goals like tackling climate change and furthering trade. In contrast to the US, which wants to oppose China, the EU should adopt a "two-track approach" with both demanding concessions and developing its own measures, such as a European Inflation Reduction Act.

site_title: UK retail sales had worst year on record amid spending squeeze
summary: UK retail sales fell 5.8% in December, marking the worst December decline since 1997, amid a cost-of-living squeeze. The drop was driven by non-food sales, with consumers cutting back on spending due to increased prices and affordability concerns. Despite a 13.6% increase in sales value in December compared to pre-Covid levels, volumes were 1.7% lower. The figures underscore the severity of inflation in the UK, with the Bank of England likely to hike interest rates to bring prices back under control.

images.alt_text: The fall in revenue reflects the sharp change in fortunes for online clothing retailers, whose sales soared during the pandemic, only to quickly reverse as people returned to stores.
Shoppers are finding it harder to maintain their standard of living as prices rise for basics like food, energy and fuel.
UK consumers have to contend with higher prices, soaring energy bills and transport strikes.
Some 94 per cent of Britons surveyed by Barclaycard said they were concerned about the impact of soaring household energy bills on their personal finances.

site_title: Britain is ‘open to business’ says Starmer at Davos
summary: Labour leader Keir Starmer and shadow chancellor Rachel Reeves successfully demonstrated their party's "open to business" credentials at the World Economic Forum in Davos, impressing British business figures and bankers. Starmer pledged to end new investments in the North Sea, build a closer economic relationship with the EU, and cooperate with the US on subsidies. The meeting comes as Labour is 20 points clear in the polls and seeks to secure the corporate vote to win the next election. The party's efforts aim to repair relations with business after being damaged by former leader Jeremy Corbyn.

images.alt_text: The Labour Party, led by Keir Starmer, has set out to woo business people, including bank executives, investment groups and venture capital firms.

site_title: Didi’s apps reappear on mobile stores in comeback’s first step
summary: Didi Global's main ride-hailing app has returned to China's biggest mobile stores, allowing the company to resume growth after a year in regulatory limbo. The move suggests Beijing's administration sees a need for private sector support to jumpstart the economy, which has been affected by Covid Zero restrictions. Didi's relaunch is a prerequisite for resuming business as usual and listing its stock in Hong Kong, with analysts noting the company must increase licence compliance and introduce a government-trusted shareholder. This marks a positive step for the ride-hailing giant, previously at the center of Beijing's clampdown on the Internet industry.

site_title: Miners in talks with Australian state over new coal export limit
summary: Australia's New South Wales state is in talks with major coal producers to reserve up to 10% of coal production for domestic supply, as part of efforts to curb soaring energy costs. The move aims to drive down household costs, which soared last year due to the Ukraine war and domestic factors. Talks are ongoing to review shortfalls and ensure supply chains are not disrupted. Early signs suggest a limited impact on coal producers, with limited spot supplies to be requisitioned.

images.alt_text: Australia has been slow in developing its offshore wind sector to replace a fleet of ageing coal plants that still provide most of its energy.

site_title: Malaysian crude flows to China surpass Iraq with record volume
summary: Malaysia surpassed Iraq and the UAE as China's sixth-largest crude supplier, with 35.7 million tons imported last year. In December, Malaysia shipped 5.52 million tons, equivalent to 1.3 million barrels per day. This marked a record high for Malaysia, which became the third-largest supplier to China, after Saudi Arabia and Russia. The surge in crude imports from Malaysia has raised questions about the authenticity of oil shipments from other countries.

site_title: Singapore shares jump with Asian markets; STI rises 0.5%
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.5% to 3,293.71 points, joining Asian markets in a rally despite losses on Wall Street. The Straits Times Index (STI) has seen its second increase of the week. Key stocks such as Genting Singapore and Wilmar International fell, while others like City Developments and Singapore Exchange declined. The rally is attributed to regional trade and China's reopening, which has supported local economies.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Hong Kong led gains with Tokyo, Shanghai, Sydney, Jakarta and Wellington also edging up.
Singapore Exchange (SGX) Centre.
Mapletree Logistics Trust's gross revenue for the quarter was up 8 per cent to S$180.2 million, thanks to acquisitions completed in Q1 and the prior year.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.8 per cent lower at 33,044.56 on Thursday.

site_title: First raise for Japan day labourer in 20 years, but McDonald’s out of reach
summary: A Japanese day labourer, Masami Fujino, received his first raise in 20 years, but it's not enough to cover the rising cost of living. Fujino works for a moving company and construction, earning 1,072 yen (S$11) an hour, but struggles to afford basic necessities like McDonald's hamburgers. Japan's 4% inflation rate is squeezing workers, with major companies offering raises but smaller firms struggling to keep up. Non-regular workers like Fujino face lower pay and fewer benefits, making it harder for them to save for the future.

site_title: Macron faces prolonged battle over pensions as labour unions dig in
summary: France's President Emmanuel Macron faces a prolonged battle over pension reform after over a million people protested against his plan to raise the minimum retirement age to 64 from 62. Labour unions, led by a rare unity of the normally fragmented labour movements, have called for more action and disruption, with a planned day of coordinated strikes and protests on January 31. Macron has indicated he will not budge, despite public opposition, and the government has proposed minor tweaks to the plan when it is debated in parliament.

images.alt_text: Demonstrators at a protest during a national strike against government plans to revamp the pension system, in Paris, France, on Thursday, Jan. 19, 2023. Strikes coordinated by French unions brought significant disruption to the country as they protest against government plans to revamp the pension system and test of president Emmanuel Macron's ability to resist street pressure. Photographer: Nathan Laine/Bloomberg

site_title: Japan to consider downgrading Covid-19 to less serious infectious disease
summary: Japan is considering downgrading Covid-19 to a less serious infectious disease, with Prime Minister Fumio Kishida instructing relevant ministers to consider reclassification. A downgrade to category five would end isolation requirements for infected individuals and their close contacts, and reduce mask-wearing advice to only those with symptoms. The move aims to restore normal lifestyles, with measures to be implemented as early as this spring.

site_title: The petro-yuan and the role of gold
summary: China's efforts to increase trade in renminbi (RMB) could challenge the US dollar's dominance in global financial markets. The country's strategy to back RMB oil trades with gold is key to building up the petro-yuan system, which could eventually displace the petro-dollar. If successful, this could lead to a shift in the geopolitical balance towards China, allowing countries to evade economic sanctions and weaken the US's global surveillance ability. The renminbi's growing importance could also lead to its emergence as a major global asset class, with China aiming to create more yuan-denominated investible assets to increase its use.

images.alt_text: The yuan has strengthened 2.2 per cent against the dollar this year, hitting an almost five-month high on Tuesday and reversing much of 2022’s annual loss, the biggest in 28 years.
Mohammed Al-Jadaan, Saudi Arabia's finance minister says he is open to discussing how to settle trade arrangements, whether it is in the US dollar, euro or whether it is the Saudi riyal.

site_title: Can machine learning help predict the next financial crisis?
summary: Machine learning algorithms can help predict the next financial crisis by analyzing internal vulnerabilities and identifying patterns in historical crisis episodes. Unlike classical crisis models that rely on logistic regressions, machine learning techniques like clustering can group data points in a sensible way, allowing for more nuanced predictions. While machine learning has its limitations, such as determining the optimal split between training and testing sets, its benefits are undeniable, and it is now a crucial tool for anticipating financial crises.

images.alt_text: Sebastian Petric
The services not only averaged a higher annual growth than manufacturing in the past 15 years but also achieved the growth with much less volatility.
