A survey by McKinsey Global Institute found that 50 per cent of firms across the world tried to use AI in some way in 2022, up from 20 per cent in 2017.

site_title: COE supply for Feb to April up by 3.4% to 3,144 per month; first rise after 2 quarters of decline
summary: The supply of certificates of entitlement (COEs) for the period between February and April 2023 is expected to rise by 3.4% to 3,144 COEs per month, marking the first increase after two quarters of decline. The increase is attributed to a revised method of calculation, which averages the number of vehicles taken off the road over 12 months, rather than just the past three months. This change aims to reduce quarter-on-quarter volatility in COE supply, leading to a potential decrease in premiums for cars and motorbikes.

images.alt_text: The price for Open COE, which can be used for any vehicle type except motorcycles but ends up almost exclusively for bigger cars, dipped slightly to settle at S$107,000, down from S$107,889.

site_title: Chinese oil trader Unipec sweeps up cheap crude, eyes demand recovery
summary: Chinese oil trader Unipec has made large purchases of low-priced crude from Abu Dhabi, Brazil, and the US, taking advantage of low supertanker freight rates and spot prices in a well-supplied market. The company has bought over 9 million barrels of crude, exceeding its usual appetite for the grade, amid expectations of a rebound in oil demand in the second quarter after China scrapped its "zero-Covid" policy. Declining freight rates and narrow price spreads are encouraging Asian buyers to seek cargoes from the Americas, potentially leading to tighter markets if China's economy rebounds and sanctions curb Russian oil exports.

images.alt_text: The increased quotas followed a sizable issuance of 13.25 million tonnes in September as China government sought to shore up its economy by encouraging refiners to step up operations and to benefit from robust export profits.

site_title: Asia: Most markets up as traders weigh China hope, recession fear
summary: Asian markets mostly rose on Friday, with Hong Kong leading gains, as traders weighed the potential boost from China's reopening from three years of lockdowns against recession fears. Despite falling US inflation, top bank officials warned that interest rate hikes may need to continue to control inflation. Weak economic indicators and an underwhelming earnings season added to the sense of trepidation among investors, but the mood in Asia was more upbeat as China's reopening is expected to support regional trade.

images.alt_text: In early trade Tokyo, Hong Kong, Shanghai, Singapore and Manila all fell, though Sydney, Seoul and Jakarta edged up.

site_title: BT Market Focus: Softer sentiment challenges markets (Ep 28)
summary: Softer sentiment is challenging markets this week, according to the BT Market Focus podcast. Claressa Monteiro explores the drivers behind the tepid market mood, citing insights from SGX and The Business Times' newsdesk. Key market-driving news includes notable news and company-focused news, which may have contributed to the softer sentiment.

images.alt_text: Howie Lim
What caused the optimism which drove markets this week?
How markets fared in the new year.

site_title: Smaller Fed rate hike may augur end to 'ongoing' increases
summary: The US Federal Reserve is expected to slow the pace of interest rate hikes at its upcoming meeting, with policymakers signaling that the battle against inflation is far from over. Despite slowing inflation, the Fed's preferred measure of inflation, the personal consumption expenditures price index, increased at a 5.5% annual rate in November. Fed officials will likely hammer home that inflation is still high and will take time to return to the 2% target. The Fed may consider a smaller rate increase, potentially around a quarter of a percentage point, and policymakers will balance risks on both sides of the economy.

images.alt_text: The US government hit the US$31.4 trillion debt ceiling set by Congress on Thursday.

site_title: China’s video game makers come in from the cold as crackdown eases
summary: China's video game industry is expected to experience a recovery this year as the government's crackdown eases. After a 10% decline in game sales in 2022, China's gaming market is expected to approve between 800 and 900 games in 2023, with richer budgets for approved titles. However, restrictions on violent content and youth gaming remain, limiting the extent of the recovery. The industry's growth will be slow and gradual, with analysts predicting a 4% growth in online gaming in 2023.

images.alt_text: A driver using the Didi Chuxing app on his smartphone in Beijing. The "Strong Nation Transport" app will bring together dozens of mobility providers under a single online umbrella. It is unclear whether the dominant Didi Global Inc's Chuxing service will be included on it.
While Jack Ma’s relinquishing of control could clear the way for Ant Group to revive its IPO, it won’t happen within this year due to listing regulations, market observers said.

site_title: CAAS launches tender to study and develop offtake mechanism for sustainable aviation fuels
summary: The Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore (CAAS) launched a tender to study and develop a structural offtake mechanism for sustainable aviation fuels (SAF) in Singapore. The study, starting in Q1 2023, aims to assess various models for driving structural offtakes and shortlist preferred options. The mechanism will determine participation, funding, and metrics, with the goal of encouraging SAF adoption at Changi Airport and bolstering the city-state's competitiveness as a sustainable air hub. The study is one of 15 recommendations from the International Advisory Panel on Sustainable Air Hub.

images.alt_text: If successful in scaling up the use of green hydrogen, Singapore's maritime, aviation and manufacturing sectors can tap low-carbon hydrogen and decarbonise.
Aerial view showing the Essequibo River running in a section of the Amazon rainforest in the Potaro-Siparuni region of Guyana.

site_title: IMDA investigating Gorilla Mobile for ceasing service without approval
summary: IMDA is investigating Gorilla Mobile for ceasing its mobile service without prior approval, violating licensing conditions. Gorilla announced the discontinuation of its local mobile plan on January 31, but provided only a notice on its website advising customers to migrate to another provider. The Infocomm Media Development Authority has asked Gorilla to fulfill its obligations to affected users, including providing support for migration to alternative telco operators. The IMDA takes a serious view of licensees not adhering to their requirements and is investigating the matter.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
office, business, accountant

site_title: Hong Kong home prices to drop 10% before rebound, Goldman says
summary: Goldman Sachs has revised its forecast for Hong Kong home prices, predicting a 10% drop in 2023 before a 4% rebound in each of the next two years. The report attributes the improvement to the border's reopening and an improving economic outlook, despite weaker demand compared to supply. The analysts note that stamp duties and rising mortgage rates will slow the introduction of additional demand from the mainland China border.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars recover ground on a wobbly dollar; bonds rally
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars recovered some ground against the US dollar after fears of a US recession led to market expectations of rate cuts by the Federal Reserve. The Australian dollar rose to US$0.6927, while the New Zealand dollar increased to US$0.6415, despite facing weekly declines. Local bonds rallied after soft jobs data and a shift in market sentiment, with bond yields falling to 2.999% and 3.394% respectively. The RBA is expected to consider a pause in interest rate hikes, with futures market predictions pointing to a peak of 3.5% in the second half of the year.

images.alt_text: Electronic boards display the Japanese yen's rate against the US dollar in Tokyo.

site_title: The lip-smacking diplomacy of murukku and Maine lobster
summary: India's "murukku" diplomacy, a savory snack made of millets, was used to promote healthy foodgrains at the 193-member UN General Assembly in 2021. The US embassy later adopted a similar approach, spending up to $75,000 to produce cooking videos and organize foodie walks in major Indian cities. The Biden administration has also employed culinary diplomacy, including a state dinner with French President Emmanuel Macron featuring butter-poached Maine lobster, to repair strained US-India and US-France relations. This approach highlights the power of food in diplomacy, with meals serving as a symbol of respect and prestige.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden and French President Emmanuel Macron meeting in the Oval Office, at the White House in Washington on Dec 1.

site_title: China injects record amount of cash this week before holidays
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), injected a record 1.97 trillion yuan (S$384 billion) of cash into the banking system this week, ahead of the Chinese New Year holidays. The large cash infusion aims to ease the benchmark seven-day money-market rate, which rose amid cash withdrawals for gift giving and travel. The move is expected to ease liquidity pressures, but analysts still forecast the PBOC to keep its cash infusion measured based on its actions this week.

images.alt_text: Many foreign business people and investors have been unable to travel to China to inspect their businesses or consider new ones for the past three years.

site_title: Tesla uses its profits as a weapon in an EV price war
summary: Tesla is using its significant profit margins to cut prices, challenging traditional profit-over-volume strategies in the electric vehicle (EV) market. The company earned $15,653 in gross profit per vehicle in the third quarter of 2022, more than twice as much as Volkswagen and five times more than Ford. This move follows Tesla's aggressive price hikes earlier this year, which allowed the company to focus on higher-margin models and book strong profits despite declining sales. Industry analysts warn that the global EV market may soon have more production capacity than demand, potentially leading to a market share war.

images.alt_text: Average daily sales for Tesla in China during the Jan 9 to Jan 15 period jumped 76 per cent from the same period in 2022 to 12,654 vehicles, CMBI’s data showed.

site_title: SPH Media to investigate circulation issue more fully
summary: SPH Media Holdings' board has directed its audit and risk committee to investigate the overstatement of circulation data after an internal review found discrepancies in circulation numbers. The review found that 49,000 copies of news titles were recorded as circulation numbers but not distributed, and 17,000 copies were recorded due to discrepancies between reported circulation figures and actual usage. The company is reassessing its methodology for reporting circulation data and will consider its next steps, with the Ministry of Communications and Information also conducting its own review of the issue.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
SPH Media chief executive Teo Lay Lim said data on reach and readership is collected periodically via a survey panel that is statistically representative of the Singapore population.
The inconsistencies led to a 10 to 12 per cent discrepancy in circulation figures.

site_title: Brokers’ take: DBS raises SIA’s target price on brighter earnings prospects
summary: DBS Group Research raised Singapore Airlines' (SIA) target price to S$6.80, citing brighter earnings prospects due to passenger traffic normalization at a quicker pace on China's earlier-than-anticipated reopening. SIA's valuation is currently discounted, trading at 4.7 times FY2024 enterprise value/Ebitda, 0.5 standard deviations below its five-year average. The research team expects a 16.2% upside potential and maintains a "buy" call on the stock. Passenger volumes are expected to reach pre-pandemic levels in the third quarter, lifting net profit by 11% and 8% in FY2024 and FY2025, respectively.

images.alt_text: Group passenger traffic and load factors remained robust across all route regions including East Asia, said SIA Group.
Analyst Raymond Yap noted that SIA’s share price has re-rated 16.5 per cent over the past three months on optimism over China’s reopening.

site_title: Malaysia’s inflation eases to 3.8% in December, bringing full-year rate to 3.3%
summary: Malaysia's inflation rate eased to 3.8% in December, down from 4% in November, bringing the full-year rate to 3.3%. The food and beverages segment, the main contributor to inflation, slowed to 6.8% in December from 7.3% in November. Core inflation, excluding volatile items, was 4.1% in December, slightly lower than the previous month. Experts expect inflation to moderate further in 2023, with projections ranging from 2.8% to 3.5%.

images.alt_text: Bank Negara has paused rate hikes, saying that it needs more time to assess the impact of the cumulative past OPR adjustments in 2022.

site_title: WeWork to cut about 300 global jobs as it pares back presence
summary: WeWork plans to cut about 300 global jobs as it reduces its presence in underperforming locations. The company aims to eliminate roles in countries with weaker economic environments. WeWork's shares fell 3.5% after the announcement. Despite this, the company expects to report fourth-quarter revenue above forecast and narrower adjusted EBITDA losses. WeWork had previously announced its exit from 40 US locations and has long-term lease obligations of $15.57 billion. The company's pre-IPO valuation was once pegged at nearly $50 billion.

images.alt_text: Fitch lowered its rating on WeWork to CCC from CCC+ Friday (Dec 2), saying its challenges will only be exacerbated in the coming year as companies trim workers, scale back spending and move slowly to retreat from hybrid work schedules.

site_title: Bouncing into the Chinese Year of the Rabbit
summary: China is expected to follow a similar pattern of post-Covid consumption, with consumers pursuing "revenge spending" in the Year of the Rabbit, driven by excess savings of RMB 6.6 trillion. While corporate earnings remain weak in the near term, they are expected to recover in the second half of the year as supply chain issues are addressed. The market outlook is positive but uneven, with a strong and recovering Chinese stock market expected to benefit emerging markets. Investors are advised to be flexible and opportunistic, with emerging markets potentially performing well in the year ahead.

images.alt_text: Chunxi Road shopping area in Chengdu, Sichuan province. Even with weaker GDP growth in 2022, China's reopening has spurred expectations for a strong 2023 rebound.

“Chinese tech shares were once the easiest bet, and for most of the past decade you were able to win and see outperformance without doing much,” said Chen Da, managing director at Fortune Hill Asset Management.

site_title: T-Mobile says data of 37 million customers hacked
summary: T-Mobile announced that 37 million customers' data, including names, addresses, email, phone numbers, and account numbers, was hacked. The breach, which began around November 25, was detected on January 5 and fixed within 24 hours. The company stated that customer accounts and finances were not directly at risk, but affected customers will be notified and an internal investigation is underway. T-Mobile may incur significant expenses related to the incident, following previous settlements for data breaches.

images.alt_text: A driver using the Didi Chuxing app on his smartphone in Beijing. The "Strong Nation Transport" app will bring together dozens of mobility providers under a single online umbrella. It is unclear whether the dominant Didi Global Inc's Chuxing service will be included on it.
Shares on the Singapore bourse rose on Tuesday amid a mixed showing by regional peers

site_title: Qantas suffers third mid-air mechanical issue in three days
summary: Qantas flight QF430 returned to Melbourne after receiving a minor engine problem indication, its third consecutive day of mid-air mechanical issues. The incident follows a Qantas flight to Fiji that returned to Sydney with potential engine trouble and a Qantas jet that shut down one engine on its way to Sydney from Auckland. The Boeing 737s, workhorses of the carrier's Australian fleet, have been in service for about 20 years, sparking concerns about the airline's aging fleet.

images.alt_text: Multiple Australian media outlets reported that a Qantas plane - QF144- had issued the mayday alert after encountering issues with one of its engines.

site_title: Zenith greets 2023 with a smile
summary: Zenith CEO Julien Tornare is optimistic about the Chinese market's reopening, despite concerns over a potential spike in Covid cases. He believes the country's love for luxury watches will drive sales, citing the success of the Chronomaster Sport and Defy Skyline collections. Tornare plans to increase Zenith's presence in China, open new boutiques, and recruit staff, with a focus on the Defy Skyline Skeleton and Pilot lines. He downplays concerns about market softening, stating that the brand has a strong foundation and can continue to grow.

images.alt_text: DEFY Skyline Skeleton.

site_title: Over half of Britain’s homes tumbled in value at the end of 2022
summary: Over 16 million UK homes, or nearly half, lost an average of £3,900 in value between October and December 2022 due to high borrowing costs and inflation. This represents a sharp increase from the 2.3 million homes that decreased in value for the year. Despite this, 92% of homeowners saw their property values rise by £19,000, and the total UK housing market value increased by £700 billion to £10.5 trillion in 2022.

site_title: The Era of Markets ended in 2019. What comes next?
summary: The world is at a crossroads, questioning the effectiveness of globalisation, free-market capitalism, and democracy. Since the 2008 financial crisis, rising populism, US-China tensions, and the Covid-19 pandemic have challenged these ideals. The World Economic Forum's Davos gathering reflects this uncertainty, with leaders struggling to articulate a new political economy. McKinsey has identified three eras since 1945, including the Post-war Boom, the Era of Contention, and the Era of Markets, which some believe ended in 2019. The future is uncertain, with a more multipolar world emerging, and rising protectionism, conflict, and climate change posing significant challenges.

images.alt_text: The partially snow-covered Schiahorn mountain, beyond the Congress Center, the venue for the World Economic Forum (WEF), in Davos, Switzerland, on Friday, Jan. 6, 2023. Though it’s perched at an altitude of 1,560 meters, this year’s rare winter heatwave saw the Swiss town of Davos basking in temperatures well above freezing in early January, with its mountainsides covered in dead, brown grass and hikers out with their dogs. Photographer: Francesca Volpi/Bloomberg
The Swiss Alpine town of Davos is hosting this week, at the World Economic Forum, one of the biggest concentrations of billionaires in the world.

site_title: JPMorgan leaves CEO Dimon’s pay at US$34.5m for 2022
summary: JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon's total compensation for 2022 remained at $34.5 million, despite the firm's profit falling 22% and stock performance notching its worst annual performance in over a decade. The board also decided to stop granting Dimon special awards after shareholders expressed frustration over a $50 million retention package in 2021. Dimon received a $1.5 million salary and $33 million in performance-based incentives, with the board praising his "exemplary" stewardship during challenging economic conditions.

images.alt_text: Jamie Dimon Photographer: Al Drago/Bloomberg

A man exits the JPMorgan Chase & Co. headquarters building in New York, U.S. in New York, U.S., on Friday, July 8, 2011. LivingSocial, the second-largest daily-coupon site, is close to hiring JPMorgan Chase & Co. as one of the banks to manage its initial public offering, a person with knowledge of the talks said. Photographer: Jin Lee/Bloomberg

site_title: Ultra-rich flip Palm Beach homes to score as much as 86% returns
summary: Wealthy homeowners in Palm Beach are capitalizing on the region's scarcity of move-in-ready homes, selling properties for significant profits. A five-bedroom beachfront house sold for 86% more than its 2021 purchase price, while a modern home sold for 42% more. The median price for single-family deals in the fourth quarter was $12.65 million, a 50% increase from the previous year. Deep-pocketed buyers are willing to pay top dollar for the exclusive enclave, driven by its private feel, warm climate, and growing office presence.

images.alt_text: Palm Beach, Florida.Photographer: Marco Bello/Bloomberg

site_title: Australian rangers find ‘monster’ 2.7kg cane toad
summary: Australian park rangers discovered a massive 2.7kg cane toad in Conway National Park, Queensland. The toad, described as a "monster," is believed to be a female due to its size and may be a record breaker. It was euthanized after being spotted by a wildlife worker who stopped to investigate a snake. The cane toad, introduced to Queensland in 1935, has been linked to devastating consequences for native wildlife due to its poisonous nature and ability to consume a wide range of prey. Its discovery may end up at the Queensland Museum.

images.alt_text: Countries that signed the landmark Kunming-Montreal Global Biodiversity Framework at the COP15 summit will have to submit their national biodiversity plans in 2024.

site_title: JPMorgan, Standard Chartered win approval to expand in China
summary: JPMorgan and Standard Chartered have secured Chinese regulatory approval to expand their operations in the country. JPMorgan's asset management arm will take full ownership of China International Fund Management, allowing it to integrate the unit into its global operating model. The approval follows a similar move by British bank Standard Chartered, which has won permission to set up a new securities brokerage unit in China. The developments are seen as a boost to foreign companies expanding in China, which is reviving its economy after lifting restrictive Covid-19 policies.

images.alt_text: China’s economy grew just 3 per cent in 2022, far below the official target but the government’s abrupt end to its zero-Covid policy has fanned hopes of a robust recovery.

In the past five years, China (above, Wuhan, in Hubei province) has swung from being a huge source of profit for many firms to becoming nearly uninvestible, amid heavy government interventions and pandemic restrictions. Now it is seeking to jump-start its economy, engage with the world and welcome investors.

site_title: Mask mandate lifted everywhere but public transit in South Korea
summary: South Korea is lifting its mask mandate for most indoor venues, effective January 30, marking a shift towards living with COVID-19. The mandate had been in place since November 2020. Although the outdoors mask mandate was lifted in September 2022, indoor masks will still be recommended. Places such as care homes, hospitals, and public transport will require masks. The country's COVID-19 death rate and critical patient numbers have peaked, with nearly 98.6% of Koreans estimated to have virus antibodies.

site_title: UK employers step up hiring despite drop in consumer confidence
summary: UK employers are stepping up hiring efforts despite a decline in consumer confidence, with over 184,000 new job advertisements in January, a 25% increase from the same period last year. The Recruitment & Employment Confederation reported a 1.5% increase in total job adverts, driven by high demand for certain roles. Meanwhile, consumer confidence fell 3 points to minus 45 in January, the first decline in four months, according to GfK. The strong labor market is putting upward pressure on inflation, leading to predictions of another interest rate hike by the Bank of England.

images.alt_text: With the latest inflation data, some economists are starting to talk about an end to the Bank of England's tightening cycle, which has delivered the fastest rate rises in three decades.

site_title: Candidates to replace Jacinda Ardern to start making their bids
summary: New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern has announced her resignation, stepping down no later than early February and not seeking re-election. A leadership contest is expected to emerge on Friday, with Chris Hipkins, a minister in her government, a top contender for the job. If a candidate fails to secure two-thirds of the available votes, the leadership contest will go to the wider membership. Labour lawmakers are expected to reach consensus on a new candidate, with Ardern remaining neutral during the election.

images.alt_text: New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern plans to step down no later than early February, she said  on Thursday.
New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern: "I know that I no longer have enough in the tank to do this job justice."
New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern leaves with longtime partner Clarke Gayford following the announcement of her resignation at the War Memorial Hall, in Napier, New Zealand Jan 19, 2023.

site_title: SingPost to dilute and potentially sell stake in Chinese e-commerce provider
summary: SingPost's subsidiary QSI will reduce its stake in Chinese e-commerce provider 4PX to 17.61% from 19.75% after a loan capitalization exercise. QSI has been granted put options by Cainiao to sell its 7.6% and 10% stakes in 4PX for approximately S$251.3 million and S$264 million, respectively. This stake dilution may add S$16.6 million to SingPost's retained earnings.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
UOBKH expects SingPost’s increased stake in FMH to boost the group’s profitability from the first quarter of 2024 onwards, given the Australian subsidiary’s robust operating profit growth.
Upon completion of the transaction, SingPost’s total stake in FMH will increase from 51 per cent currently, to 88 per cent.

site_title: Air India’s mega jet deal with Airbus, Boeing held up by engine-cost debate
summary: Air India's order for up to 500 aircraft from Airbus and Boeing is being held up due to a disagreement with engine makers CFM International and Pratt & Whitney over engine costs. The deal, which could be announced as soon as this month, centers on hourly repair rates for the 737 Max engines. With supply of new jetliners becoming increasingly constrained, the Tata Group, Air India's parent, is under pressure to finalize the order, which would allow the carrier to upgrade service and reliability. A deal could be finalized in the coming weeks.

images.alt_text: Delivered over the next decade, the 500 jets would replace and expand fleets in the world’s fastest-growing air travel market.

site_title: The clowns of cryptoland haven’t given up
summary: A new crypto exchange, GTX, is being set up by co-founders of bankrupt crypto hedge fund Three Arrows Capital, which collapsed last year. GTX aims to allow customers to trade their crypto bankruptcy claims, offering an option for Three Arrows' creditors, who are collectively owed US$3.5 billion, to convert their claims into equity. This move has raised concerns about the lack of accountability and moral integrity in the crypto industry, with some critics labeling making money out of failure as "morally bankrupt".

images.alt_text: Zhu told The Straits Times on Monday night that the idea was to allow clients from bankrupt exchange FTX and other insolvent estates to access their capital and start investing again.

site_title: Gold flat, set for weekly rise on slower Fed rate-hike bets
summary: Gold prices remained steady at $1,930.59 per ounce, on track for a fifth consecutive weekly gain, driven by a weaker dollar and reduced expectations of US interest rate hikes. The dollar index was poised for a second consecutive weekly decline, making gold cheaper for holders of foreign currency. Data showing declining US inflation and retail sales further fueled the appeal of safe-haven bullion.

site_title: Nintendo plans to boost Switch output to meet resilient demand
summary: Nintendo plans to increase production of its Switch console in the upcoming fiscal year, aiming to meet strong demand despite component shortages. The company has told suppliers and assembly partners it will churn out more units, but has not yet set a precise target. Analysts expect sales to decline, but Nintendo's plan suggests sustained demand for at least another year, potentially bringing the Switch into the 150 million lifetime sales territory. The move comes as the console nears the end of its lifecycle, but Nintendo is confident in meeting its sales targets.

images.alt_text: epa09180302 (FILE) - A man walks past the Nintendo Switch logo during the Nintendo Switch Presentation 2017 in Tokyo, Japan, 13 January 2017 (reissued 06 May 2021). On 06 May 2021, Nintendo Co. announced that its consolidated financial results for the fiscal year ended March 2021 reached a record high with net income of 4.4 billion USD, up 85.7 percent from the previous year thanks to strong sales of its Switch game console.  EPA-EFE/FRANCK ROBICHON

site_title: Oil prices rally to highest close since Dec 1 on China optimism
summary: Oil prices rose 1.4% to their highest close since December 1, driven by rising Chinese demand. Brent crude futures settled at $86.16 per barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose to $80.33 per barrel. Chinese oil demand increased by nearly 1 million barrels per day in November, and energy markets could become tighter in 2023 due to a rebounding Chinese economy and struggling Russian oil industry.

images.alt_text: Brent futures fell 94 cents, or 1.1 per cent, to settle at US$84.98 a barrel on Wednesday.

site_title: FTX token jumps after new CEO says exchange could restart
summary: FTX's new CEO, John J Ray III, has stated that the company is exploring the possibility of restarting the crypto exchange, FTX.com. This move comes after the company's token, FTT, surged by over 40% in value. However, experts warn that a relaunch would likely face significant backlash due to the "toxic" brand reputation. A task force has been set up to consider restarting the exchange, which would be a turnaround plan to maximize recoveries for creditors.

images.alt_text: Some US$323 million in crypto had been hacked from FTX’s international exchange and US$90 million had been hacked from its US exchange since it filed for bankruptcy on Nov 11, CEO John Ray said in a separate statement on Tuesday.

site_title: Global property market faces US$175b debt spiral
summary: The global property market is facing a $175 billion debt spiral, with real estate credit distressed levels four times higher than the next biggest industry. Delays in projects in China, driven by plunging sales and sporadic mortgage boycotts, are being closely watched. The slump has spread to commercial real estate, threatening credit turmoil across the economy. Experts warn of a "unique set of economic circumstances" and a pipeline of potentially defaulting loans, with values under pressure and cash flows struggling. The downturn is expected to impact spending in the real economy, posing a risk to jobs and growth.

images.alt_text: Hui Ka Yan had been part of the political advisory body since 2008 and of its elite 300-member standing committee since 2013.

site_title: Boeing ordered to face MAX victims’ families in US court
summary: US District Judge Reed O'Connor ordered Boeing to appear in court on January 26 to face family members of those killed in 737 MAX crashes, challenging the company's prior government settlement. Boeing had paid over $2.5 billion in fines and restitution to settle US Department of Justice charges it defrauded regulators. The case concerns whether federal law mandated consultation with victims before the agreement. The judge's ruling opens the door to potential prosecution of corporate officials, with attorneys representing victims arguing that the settlement was unfair.

images.alt_text: In terms of deliveries, Airbus finished the year having 661 planes arrive with clients, much higher than Boeing’s 480.
China approved Boeing 737 MAX's return to service in December 2021, but Chinese airlines refrained from rushing it back amid strained US-China relations.
Air India has spent months negotiating an order of about 400 narrowbody and 100 widebody jets that would allow the country’s flag carrier to upgrade service and reliability.

site_title: Japan inflation hits 4% in Dec
summary: Japan's consumer prices rose 4% in December from a year earlier, the highest level since 1981, driven by higher energy bills and government data. The Bank of Japan has maintained its ultra-easy monetary policy, defying peers who have hiked rates to combat inflation. The central bank's inflation goal of 2% remains unachievable, and Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated that the target cannot be achieved in a stable and sustainable manner.

images.alt_text: A total of 34 per cent of Japanese firms polled said they planned wage increases of at least 3 per cent, a jump from 10 per cent in a Reuters survey in October.

epa10253755 A stock market indicator board displays the 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average figures in Tokyo, Japan, 20 October 2022. Tokyo stocks lost more than 300 points in the morning trading session following overnight fall at Wall Street.  EPA-EFE/FRANCK ROBICHON

site_title: Crypto firm Nexo Capital agrees to pay US$45m to settle US SEC, state charges
summary: Crypto firm Nexo Capital agreed to pay a total of $45 million in penalties to settle charges from the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) and state regulators. The company failed to register its crypto asset lending product, known as the Earn Interest Product, for US investors. Nexo will pay $22.5 million to the SEC and $22.5 million in fines to state regulators. The company did not admit or deny the SEC's findings, stating it was "content" with the resolution and expects a clearer regulatory landscape to emerge soon.

images.alt_text: Nexo has said that it is phasing out its products and services in the US after facing multiple cease-and-desist orders from regulators over its interest-earning products.
Vauld is among a string of crypto lenders that suffered major damage in last year’s digital-asset rout.

site_title: Stocks to watch: MLT, Suntec Reit, GuocoLand, SingPost, Dasin Retail Trust, Sim Leisure
summary: Key companies saw new developments affecting trading on Friday. Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT) reported a 8% increase in gross revenue to S$180.2 million, lifting its distribution per unit by 1.9%. Suntec Reit's DPU dropped 9.7% due to higher interest expense. GuocoLand reported a 13% fall in net profit to S$59 million, while SingPost's equity interests in Shenzhen 4PX Information and Technology were reduced to 17.61%. Dasin Retail Trust received a letter of demand from lender Luso International Banking, and Sim Leisure registered "substantial" comprehensive profit for FY2022.

images.alt_text: DBS, UOB and OCBC ATMs at the Singapore Institute of Management (SIM) on March 12, 2020.

site_title: Dasin Retail Trust receives letter of demand from bank over US$13.1m loan
summary: Dasin Retail Trust received a letter of demand from Luso International Banking on January 10 over a US$13.1 million loan facility, declaring an event of default. The trust was unable to top up its reserve account due to technical issues with securing approval from a China onshore lender. The trustee-manager is seeking to engage Luso Bank in discussions and is seeking legal advice on its obligations. Units of Dasin closed flat on Thursday, January 19.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai

site_title: Singapore shares nearly flat on Friday, STI edge up 0.03%
summary: Singapore stocks ended nearly flat on Friday, edging up 0.03% to 3,227.02, amid a disappointing US and European market performance. The Straits Times Index saw 32.1 million securities worth S$44.1 million change hands, with MarcoPolo Marine rising 2.4% and ThaiBev and Mapletree Pan Asia Commercial Trust also gaining. Local banks DBS and UOB rose, while OCBC increased 0.2%. The Dow Jones fell 0.8% and European shares recorded their worst single-day selloff of the year.

images.alt_text: Mapletree Logistics Trust's gross revenue for the quarter was up 8 per cent to S$180.2 million, thanks to acquisitions completed in Q1 and the prior year.

site_title: South Korea’s Q4 GDP likely shrank, hints at possible recession: poll
summary: South Korea's economy is expected to have shrunk 0.3% in the fourth quarter of 2023, according to a Reuters poll, marking the country's worst performance in 2.5 years. The contraction is attributed to falling foreign demand and rising interest rates, which have hurt private consumption. On a year-on-year basis, GDP is forecast to have grown 1.5%, half the growth in the third quarter. The data is set to be released on January 26, with economists warning of a challenging growth outlook amid a global tech downcycle and a faltering property market.

images.alt_text: Trucks move into a port in Busan, on the day truckers voted to end a nationwide strike, South Korea December 9, 2022. Yonhap via REUTERS ATTENTION EDITORS - THIS IMAGE HAS BEEN SUPPLIED BY A THIRD PARTY. SOUTH KOREA OUT. NO RESALES. NO ARCHIVES.
This marks the seventh consecutive month of declines in the country’s house prices, following a 1.4 per cent loss in November 2022.

site_title: Zoom says competition and job cuts haven’t hurt its business
summary: Zoom Video Communications president Greg Tomb said the company's collaboration software business has held up despite widespread layoffs and competition, citing long-term contracts that have not significantly impacted the business. Tomb acknowledged that Microsoft's Teams, a free collaboration tool, has been adopted by many companies, but said that companies rarely quit using Zoom. The company is trying to reverse slowing growth by expanding its tools for business, focusing on getting existing customers to use features beyond video calls.

images.alt_text: Zoom is fighting to reverse a slowdown in growth for its video communications service by expanding its tools for business.

site_title: Netflix co-founder Hastings steps down as CEO as company adds subscribers
summary: Reed Hastings, co-founder of Netflix, stepped down as CEO, handing over the reins to co-CEOs Ted Sarandos and Greg Peters. Despite facing challenges, including subscriber losses and competition, Netflix added 7.66 million subscribers in the fourth quarter, beating forecasts. Shares rose 6.1% after-hours trading. Hastings will serve as executive chairman. The company projects "modest" subscriber gains through March and 4% year-over-year revenue growth.

images.alt_text: All companies with 15 or more employees advertising jobs based in the state are required to post an estimate for what the employer “reasonably expects to pay” with the posting.
HBO Max, an online extension of the company’s HBO cable channel but with more content, launched in May 2020.

site_title: UBS braces for hard landing in US credit, favours European debt
summary: UBS analysts recommend buying European credit amid signs of distress in US loan markets, warning of a hard landing in US credit. They predict loan default rates could reach 9% by end-2023 and junk defaults 6.5%. US high-yield debt is seen as better positioned, but with severe downside risk. The bank favors sectors insulated from default risks, such as utilities and industrials, and is underweight CCC-rated debt and overweight BBs.

images.alt_text: Kelleher’s comments underscore the importance that many bank executives have attached to the EU’s effort to allow more banking services across the entire bloc.
Colm Kelleher, chairman of UBS Group, says: “Banks and insurance companies are well regulated. They’re systemically safe, we can argue.”

site_title: Jack Ma lands in Hong Kong on the latest stop of a global tour
summary: Jack Ma, co-founder of Alibaba Group Holding, has arrived in Hong Kong for meetings with tech and finance executives, following a recent global tour that included stops in Tokyo, Thailand, the US, and Israel. Ma's appearances come as Beijing appears to be easing its crackdown on internet giants, with him ceding controlling rights to his Ant fintech empire earlier this month. Ma has kept a low profile since 2020, but his recent activities suggest he is re-emerging as a prominent figure in the tech industry.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Jack Ma, founder and executive chairman of China's Alibaba Group, speaks in front of a picture of SoftBank's human-like robot named 'pepper' during a news conference in Chiba, Japan, June 18, 2015. REUTERS/Yuya Shino/File Photo

site_title: Infrastructure, commodities, water – here’s what some of the world’s largest investors are buying
summary: World's largest investors, including sovereign wealth funds, are bullish on commodities, infrastructure, real estate, and water assets. They see China as a significant investment opportunity due to its large size. The panel discussion at the World Economic Forum highlighted the importance of water as a crucial input in food production. The investors also emphasized the potential for dollar asset diversification, particularly in Asia, and the growth of ETFs in the region.

images.alt_text: Joan Ng
GIC's joint acquisition of real estate investment trust Store Capital alongside private equity firm Oak Street is the third-largest transaction made by sovereign wealth funds ever.

François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor, Central Bank of France speaking in the The Role of Finance in a Recovery session at the World Economic Forum Annual Meeting 2023 in Davos-Klosters, Switzerland, 18 January. Congress Centre - Aspen 1. Copyright: World Economic Forum/Manuel Lopez

site_title: Europe: Shares suffer worst selloff of the year on recession fears
summary: European shares suffered their worst single-day selloff of the year, falling 1.6% due to recession fears fueled by disappointing earnings reports, weak US economic data, and hawkish comments from central bankers. Rate-sensitive technology stocks led losses, while retail, industrial, and mining stocks also declined. Despite a glimmer of optimism about the global economy, investors worry about upcoming earnings season and its potential impact on corporate profitability. The European Central Bank pushed back against market bets of slower interest rate hikes, further exacerbating the downturn.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.8 per cent lower at 33,044.56 on Thursday.

site_title: Uber not planning layoffs: CEO
summary: Uber CEO Dara Khosrowshahi stated at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, that the company is not planning any company-wide layoffs. This contradicts the downsizing trend in the tech sector, where companies like Microsoft, Meta, Amazon, Twitter, and Salesforce have announced thousands of layoffs. Khosrowshahi emphasized that the core business and workforce of Uber are well-balanced and positioned for the future, and the company is working with automakers to design cars for its ride-hailing and delivery services.

images.alt_text: The Jelbi app lets travellers book and pay for rides on Berlin's subways, trams and buses.
FILE PHOTO: A Deliveroo delivery rider cycles in London, Britain, March 31, 2021. REUTERS/Toby Melville/File Photo

site_title: Capital One cuts more than 1,100 tech jobs
summary: Capital One eliminated over 1,100 tech jobs as part of its efforts to improve efficiency through cloud technology investments. The company cited the need to integrate agile delivery processes into its core engineering practices. Affected employees will be eligible for a severance package with at least 16 weeks of compensation. The move follows years of investment in systems aimed at enhancing products and improving profitability.

images.alt_text: The layoffs will result in a charge of US$1.2 billion in the second quarter of fiscal 2023, representing a negative impact of 12 cents on per share profit, Microsoft said.

site_title: US Federal Reserve will face tough choices the longer debt ceiling impasse persists: analysts
summary: The US government has reached its $31.4 trillion debt ceiling, set by Congress, and will continue to fund the government until early June. However, the prolonged impasse could force the Federal Reserve to make tough choices, particularly in its plans to raise interest rates and reduce its massive balance sheet. The Fed aims to shed $100 billion a month from its balance sheet and potentially lift interest rates above 5% to combat inflation. Analysts expect the Fed to navigate the debt ceiling impasse, but the prolonged standoff may impact its ability to implement these plans.

images.alt_text: The average contract rate on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage fell by 19 basis points to 6.23 per cent for the week ended Jan 13

(FILES) In this file photo taken on April 08, 2022 Cars are seen on the assembly line during a tour of the Tesla Giga Texas manufacturing facility ahead of the "Cyber Rodeo" grand opening party on April 7, 2022 in Austin, Texas. - American factory growth sped up in May after slowing in the prior two months, even as employment contracted and firms continue to face supply challenges, according to a business survey released June 1, 2022. (Photo by SUZANNE CORDEIRO / AFP)

Philadelphia Federal Reserve Bank President Patrick Harker said he is expecting the Fed to get rates over 5 per cent and added that uncertainty about the stopping point is why the central bank should slow the pace of its rate hikes.

site_title: Brexit lifts number of million-euro-a-year bankers in EU, watchdog says
summary: The European Banking Authority reported a 41.5% increase in the number of bankers earning over a million euros a year in the EU in 2021, reaching 1,957, the highest level since 2010. This surge is attributed to Brexit-related relocations, increased trading, and inflation, with 70% of the increase attributed to bankers in Italy, France, and Spain. Germany remains the top earner with 589, followed by France and Italy, with the majority of high earners receiving remuneration between 1 million to 2 million euros.

images.alt_text: Goldman Sachs and other big banks are under pressure to move more traders from London into EU cities such as Paris, Frankfurt and Amsterdam.

site_title: Brazil’s Lula to meet Biden  in Washington on Feb 10
summary: Brazilian President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva will meet US President Joe Biden in Washington on February 10, following a two-day trip to the US starting on February 9. Lula, who took office for a third term on January 1, aims to improve relations with foreign governments strained under his predecessor Jair Bolsonaro. The meeting comes after thousands of Bolsonaro supporters stormed the Brazilian seat of power in Brasilia, and Lula has expressed a desire to discuss how to deal with far-right extremism.

images.alt_text: Petrobras will shield consumers from sharp fuel-price swings and increase investments in refining projects to curb fuel imports.

Supporters of Brazil's former President Jair Bolsonaro demonstrate against President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva while security forces operate, outside Brazil’s National Congress in Brasilia, Brazil, Jan 8, 2023.

site_title: Hong Kong worker shortage ruins reopening for restaurants and shops
summary: Hong Kong's services industries, including restaurants and hotels, are struggling to attract workers due to a manpower shortage, despite the city's reopening. Many businesses have reduced hours, pay, or laid off staff, while others have shuttered entirely. The legacy of border closures and strict social distancing rules has led to a brain drain, with workers switching to more stable industries. Economists warn that the long-term outlook is grim, citing structural issues such as a shrinking local workforce and labor importation policy. The government is exploring solutions, including importing non-local skilled workers, but the challenge remains.

images.alt_text: Customers at a restaurant along the promenade in the Tsim Sha Tsui district in Hong Kong on Saturday, Oct. 15, 2022.Photographer: Lam Yik/Bloomberg
Hong Kong gave up other restrictions in December after China abandoned its strict approach to controlling the virus.

site_title: Baldwin to face manslaughter charge over ‘Rust’ shooting
summary: Alec Baldwin is charged with involuntary manslaughter over the accidental shooting of cinematographer Halyna Hutchins on the set of film 'Rust' in October 2021. The incident occurred when Baldwin discharged a Colt .45, killing Hutchins and wounding director Joel Souza. Armorer Hannah Gutierrez Reed will also face charges. If convicted, both face up to 18 months in jail and a $5,000 fine. A separate agreement was reached with Souza, who will serve a suspended sentence and six months of probation.

images.alt_text: This handout file image courtesy of Santa Fe County Sheriff's Office released April 25, 2022, and part of the investigative files, shows actor Alec Baldwin being processed after the death of cinematographer Halyna Hutchins at the Bonanza Creek Ranch in Santa Fe, New Mexico. - Alec Baldwin is to be charged with involuntary manslaughter over the accidental shooting of a cinematographer on the set of the low budget western "Rust," a prosecutor said on January 19, 2023. The film's armorer, who was responsible for the weapon that fired the shot that killed Halyna Hutchins, will also be charged, New Mexico First Judicial District Attorney Mary Carmack-Altwies announced. (Photo by Santa Fe County Sheriff's Office / AFP) / RESTRICTED TO EDITORIAL USE - MANDATORY CREDIT "AFP PHOTO / Santa Fe County Sheriff's Office / HANDOUT " - NO MARKETING - NO ADVERTISING CAMPAIGNS - DISTRIBUTED AS A SERVICE TO CLIENTS
Baldwin said has reached a civil settlement with the family of the woman he fatally shot with a prop gun on a film set last year.
Baldwin’s cross complaint alleges negligence and seeks damages to be determined at trial for the “immense grief” he endures.

site_title: Google loses bid to block Indian Android antitrust ruling
summary: Google lost its bid to block an antitrust order in India's Supreme Court, which ruled that the tech giant exploited its dominant position in Android and imposed anti-competitive restrictions on device makers. The Competition Commission of India fined Google $161 million and ordered changes to its business model, including removing restrictions on pre-installation of apps and allowing uninstallation of its apps. The court declined to block the directives, with Chief Justice DY Chandrachud saying Google wields significant dominance in the market.

images.alt_text: The logo of Google is pictured during the Viva Tech start-up and technology summit in Paris, France, May 25, 2018. REUTERS/Charles Platiau//File Photo

site_title: KKR caps withdrawals on real estate trust in latest pullback
summary: KKR Real Estate Select Trust, a real estate investment trust, has capped withdrawals at 5% of its net asset value due to investor requests exceeding the limit. The trust fulfilled 62% of shareholder requests, with KKR's stock dropping 5.7% following the news. The move comes as real estate investment vehicles overseen by KKR and Blackstone face pressure from investors seeking redemptions beyond limits set by the funds. KKR cited a strong liquidity position and balance between providing access to private real estate and maintaining regular liquidity for shareholders.

images.alt_text: A deal would mark a rare investment in the European financial services industry for KKR.

site_title: Dollar slips after weak data; yen ticks up
summary: The US dollar slipped 0.2% against the Japanese yen, following weak US data showing retail sales fell and manufacturing output dropped, making dollar-denominated bonds less attractive. The Bank of Japan maintained its ultra-loose monetary policy, but analysts believe the central bank may shift away from it, supporting the yen's rise. The euro rose 0.2% against the dollar, while sterling and the Australian dollar fell, and the New Zealand dollar lost 1.11% to US$0.637.

images.alt_text: The yen was broadly weaker, although analysts said the BOJ was likely to tighten policy soon and the currency walked back some of its losses.
UK data shows that wage growth sped up in the three months to November, with employment also rising faster than expected.

site_title: P&G boosts sales outlook as higher prices offset lower volume
summary: Procter & Gamble (P&G) has boosted its sales outlook, citing higher prices offsetting lower volume sales. The company expects organic sales growth of 4-5% for the fiscal year ending in June, narrowing its previous forecast. P&G's revenue outlook has also increased, driven by a 5% organic revenue expansion in the December quarter. The company trimmed its expected impact of currency fluctuations and higher commodity costs, but maintained its earnings-per-share outlook.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Charmin toilet paper, a product distributed by Procter & Gamble, is pictured on sale at a Ralphs grocery store in Pasadena, California January 21, 2014. Procter & Gamble Co, the world's largest household products maker, reported lower quarterly profit on January 24, 2013, hurt by unfavorable currency movements and lower gross profit margin. Picture taken January 21, 2014. REUTERS/Mario Anzuoni  (UNITED STATES - Tags: BUSINESS)/File Photo
P&G said average prices across its product lines rose 9 per cent in the first quarter ended Sept 30, while sales volumes fell 3 per cent.

site_title: Singapore’s GIC says China policy on Big Tech has become clearer
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund, GIC, says China's policy on Big Tech has become clearer, easing uncertainty for investors. According to GIC's chief investment officer, Jeffrey Jaensubhakij, recent comments from Chinese Vice-Premier Liu He indicate that China has solved regulatory issues, making it more attractive to investors. However, the US-China rivalry and potential political friction remain a key issue for investors, with many firms diversifying their portfolios. Despite this, experts express interest in basic commodities, including water and food, which they see as essential investment opportunities.

images.alt_text: A driver using the Didi Chuxing app on his smartphone in Beijing. The "Strong Nation Transport" app will bring together dozens of mobility providers under a single online umbrella. It is unclear whether the dominant Didi Global Inc's Chuxing service will be included on it.
People walking past the Bank of China headquarters in Beijing, on Dec 22, 2022. In a recent interview, the central bank said it was relaxing the oversight of technology companies.

site_title: French workers strike nationwide, reject Macron's pension reform
summary: Hundreds of thousands of French workers took part in nationwide strikes and marches on January 19 to protest against President Emmanuel Macron's plan to raise the retirement age from 62 to 64. The stoppages, which included train halts, electricity production cuts, and bus driver strikes, were a major test for Macron's government, with protesters citing concerns over increased workload and the need for pension increases. The strikes, which included teachers, refinery workers, and utility staff, are expected to continue with more protests and strikes planned for the evening, as unions argue for alternative solutions to ensure pension system viability.

images.alt_text: France's Prime Minister Elisabeth Borne acknowledged widespread public opposition to the changes and a looming battle with trade unions who are expected to announce strikes later on Tuesday.

site_title: Tackling cyberattacks in 2023
summary: In 2022, Singapore saw a rise in cyberattacks, with 46% of businesses experiencing a cyber incident. Identity-based attacks, particularly those targeting identity and access management gaps, are expected to be the leading attack vector in 2023. Financially motivated groups will continue to use social engineering techniques to gain credentials and access, while state-backed attacks will focus on stealing intellectual property and funds. Companies must implement stronger security policies, detect and respond to breaches, and deploy automated security systems to stay safe.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: 3D printed models of people working on computers and padlock are seen in front of a displayed CYBER ATTACK words and binary code in this picture illustration taken, February 1, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

Shipping containers at the Yangshan Deepwater Port in Shanghai, China, on Tuesday, Jan. 11, 2022. China vowed more measures to stabilize trade as pressure builds on the government to bolster the economy amid worsening domestic Covid outbreaks. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg
Ransomware will still be high on the list of cyber threats in 2023, as it is very lucrative and easy to carry out, with limited risks of retaliation for attackers.

site_title: Mapletree Logistics Trust posts 1.9% rise in Q3 DPU to 2.227 S cents
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust reported a 1.9% rise in third-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.227 Singapore cents, driven by 8% gross revenue growth to S$180.2 million. Net property income rose 7.3% to S$157.2 million, but was offset by currency depreciation. The trust faces headwinds from high interest costs and forex volatility, but will implement prudent risk management strategies. The trust's portfolio occupancy stood at 96.9% and gearing was 37.4%, with 83% of debt hedged into fixed rates.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
Mapletree Logistics Trust's manager said that capital released from the divestments will give it flexibility to pursue investment opportunities of modern assets.

site_title: US: Stocks fall as Federal Reserve official talks tough on inflation
summary: US stocks fell 0.8% on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average closing at 33,044.56, as a top Federal Reserve official vowed to maintain a tough stance on inflation. Despite lower-than-expected jobless claims, the labor market remains hot, and the Fed needs to see job market improvements to keep interest rates on hold. Fed Vice Chair Lael Brainard said policy will need to be restrictive for a while to combat inflation, which remains high. The yield on the 10-year US Treasury note also rose, further underscoring the Fed's tough stance.

images.alt_text: A trader works on the trading floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., January 5, 2023. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly

site_title: US jobless claims drop to 190,000, lowest level since September
summary: US jobless claims dropped to 190,000, the lowest level since September, according to Labor Department data. This decrease, 15,000 fewer than the median forecast, indicates a strong jobs market where businesses are reluctant to let go of workers. Despite this, some sectors such as finance, tech, and real-estate have reduced their workforce in recent months. Continuing claims rose to 1.65 million in the week ended Jan 7, following two weeks of declines.

images.alt_text: EY chief executive officer Di Sibio pointed out that reductions in the tech sector were coming after a period of intense hiring.
The latest round, scheduled to commence Wednesday, will mostly affect the retail division and human resources.
City of London economists have warned that the tight jobs market will keep the pressure on the BOE to increase interest rates again next month despite some signs of a cooling in employer demand.

site_title: India likely to keep lid on sugar exports as output dips, say sources
summary: India is considering limiting its sugar exports due to lower production, which is down from projections. The country, the world's largest sugar exporter, has allowed only 6.1 million tonnes to be exported so far, with mills contracted to ship 5.6 million tonnes. Lower sugar cane yields and reduced production estimates have led to doubts about additional exports, potentially raising global prices and benefiting rivals Brazil and Thailand.

images.alt_text: Sacks of refined sugar at a wholesale store in New Delhi, India, on Wednesday, May 25, 2022. India will restrict sugar exports as a precautionary measure to safeguard its own food supplies, another act of protectionism after banning wheat sales just over a week ago. Photographer: T. Narayan/Bloomberg

site_title: US poised for 'extraordinary measures' as debt limit looms
summary: The US Treasury is set to take "extraordinary measures" on Thursday to prevent a government debt default, as the borrowing limit of $31.4 trillion is expected to be breached. These measures can temporarily reduce outstanding debt subject to the limit, but they are expected to last only six months. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen warned that the limit is expected to be reached on Thursday, prompting a high-stakes clash between Democrats and Republicans over raising the limit. The measures aim to provide a temporary solution until a more permanent solution can be found.

images.alt_text: While Republicans like to portray themselves as fiscally conservative and deride Democrats as the “big-spending party,” US President Joe Biden said the reality was different.
“So the Senate is going to have to recognise the fact that we’re not going to budge until we see meaningful reform with respect to spending.” House Oversight Committee chairman James Comer said.
US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen urged lawmakers to act quickly to raise the debt ceiling to “protect the full faith and credit” of the United States.

site_title: Unilever India posts Q3 profit jump, to pay higher royalties to UK parent
summary: Unilever India's Q3 profit jumped 12% to 25 billion rupees, driven by growing demand for personal care products. The company will pay 3.5% in royalty and central services fees to its parent Unilever, up from 2.7%. CEO Sanjiv Mehta attributed the growth to the end of inflation's "worst phase" and a gradual recovery in demand, with rural pockets showing signs of a rebound. Total sales rose 16% to 149.9 billion rupees.

images.alt_text: India, where half the population is under the age of 30, is set to be the world’s fastest-growing major economy in the coming years.

Alan Jope, who this year came under fierce criticism from investor activists over the failed takeover of the former health care unit of drugmaker GlaxoSmithKline, has spent 5 years as CEO and nearly 4 decades at the company.

site_title: Traders reap big profits in Singapore by mixing cheap Russia oil
summary: Traders in Singapore are capitalizing on cheap Russian oil, blending it with other supplies to sell at a higher price. The city-state's oil storage tanks are in high demand due to the increasing interest and profits from this practice. Despite Singapore not banning the import of Russian oil, some buyers are hesitant to purchase due to the sensitive nature of the issue. Traders are enjoying profit margins of up to 20% from this activity, with some estimates suggesting that blended fuel oil products may be sold to nearby countries like Indonesia and Vietnam.

images.alt_text: The longer voyages, heavy discounts and record-high freight rates ate into profits but the use of supertankers on the Asian routes may now cut shipping costs.
G7, Australia and the European Union  placed a US$60 per barrel limit on sea-borne Russian crude oil sales late last year.
The price cap on crude oil imposed by G7 nations is not expected to have a significant impact on companies in Singapore.

site_title: Viva Land-linked units put Singapore assets up for sale for about S$700m
summary: VivaCapital, a subsidiary of Viva Land Group, has put its Singapore assets, including the 21-storey Robinson Point office building and the Hotel Telegraph, on the market with indicative prices of S$470 million and S$240 million respectively. The sale comes after the arrest of Truong My Lan, a billionaire businesswoman linked to Viva Land Group, over suspected financial fraud. VivaCapital's spokesperson denied any connection between the group and Truong, citing rising interest rates and uncertainty in the global economy as reasons for the divestment. The sale is expected to close in early February via an expression of interest (EOI) exercise.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala
Income At Raffles at 16 Collyer Quay was sold for about S$1 billion in  late-June 2022 to Singapore-based Bright Ruby Resources group.
Vietnam recently broadened its anti-graft drive with a series of high-profile corporate arrests, including top stockbrokers, property developers and even regulators.
The SO /Singapore hotel is being bought by Viva Land group, which in 2021 completed the purchase of Robinson Point next door.

site_title: US: Stocks open lower, extending pullback
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average opened lower, extending a pullback, as investors weighed recession worries and US debt discussions. Stocks dipped 0.4% to 33,170.67, following a 1% drop on Wednesday. Weaker retail sales data highlighted the risk of a downturn in the world's biggest economy, with recession and Fed rate hike fears plaguing investors.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 1.8 per cent, or nearly 615 points, to 33,297.02 on Wednesday.

site_title: China creates ‘Strong Nation’ app as data regime tightens
summary: China has launched a government-backed "Strong Nation Transport" app to integrate various mobility services, including ride-hailing and freight forwarders, under a single umbrella. The app, targeting government and state enterprise employees, aims to address data security concerns and "disorderly expansion" in the ride-hailing industry. The move has sparked uncertainty, as it follows Beijing's pledge to unfetter its Internet sector and comes amid ongoing regulatory scrutiny of dominant ride-hailing platform Didi Global Inc. The app's launch may include Didi's Chuxing service, but its inclusion is unclear.

images.alt_text: People walking past the Bank of China headquarters in Beijing, on Dec 22, 2022. In a recent interview, the central bank said it was relaxing the oversight of technology companies.
Didi Global would take effective measures to ensure platform safety and data security, and safeguard national cyberspace security, it said in the statement.
An arm of the Cyberspace Administration of China took 1 per cent of an Alibaba digital media subsidiary in Guangzhou on Jan 4, according to corporate database Qichacha.
Founders of major Chinese tech firms including Alibaba have exited their leadership roles.

site_title: Germany’s make-or-break moment to defend auto industry is here
summary: Germany faces a crucial year to defend its position as a leader in the electric vehicle industry, with the country's carmakers racing against the US and China to retain an edge. The US has pledged $370 billion in clean-technology subsidies, while Germany has pledged an additional $1.1 billion for battery projects. The automotive industry employs 786,000 people in Germany, making it a vital sector for the country's economy. However, setbacks for German carmakers could reverberate throughout the wider economy, with some warning that Europe risks falling behind in the global clean mobility race.

images.alt_text: Leading the charge is Tesla, where chief executive Elon Musk has outlined an audacious plan to build 20 million EVs in 2030, requiring an estimated 3 terawatt-hours of batteries.

site_title: Singapore shares track Wall Street losses; STI down 0.4%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.4% to 3,276.18 points on Thursday, following overnight Wall Street losses due to recession worries sparked by softer economic readings. The banking trio, which accounts for over 40% of the STI's industry weightage, declined, with DBS dropping 1.4%, OCBC 0.8%, and UOB 0.4%. Prime US Reit was the top-performing real estate investment trust, jumping 5.8% after UOB Kay Hian initiated a "buy" call.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Analysts said rising interest rates could result in higher margins and a revival of wealth management income for local lenders, which would lift their overall earnings.
On the Singapore Exchange, losers outnumber gainers 69 to 49.

site_title: BOE says ‘corner has been turned’ on UK inflation
summary: Bank of England Governor Andrew Bailey stated that inflation has "turned a corner" and will likely fall rapidly this year, starting in the late spring, primarily due to energy pricing. The UK's headline inflation rate declined for the second month in December, falling to 10.5% from a 41-year high in October. Bailey expressed concerns about the tight labor market and potential for a "long but shallow recession." He also noted that rapid wage growth may be slowing, with some forward-looking surveys showing less strong earnings growth.

images.alt_text: With the latest inflation data, some economists are starting to talk about an end to the Bank of England's tightening cycle, which has delivered the fastest rate rises in three decades.

site_title: B Capital closes third growth fund series at US$2.1b
summary: B Capital, a venture capital firm co-founded by Facebook co-founder Eduardo Saverin, has closed its third growth fund series at US$2.1 billion. The firm, which manages US$6.3 billion in assets, has deployed half of the fund and has portfolio companies in Vietnam and India. Despite a global slowdown, B Capital continues to take a long-term view, focusing on sectors like fintech, healthcare, and enterprise technology. The firm's managing partner, Raj Ganguly, said the goal is to have portfolio companies with a runway of at least two years to manage downside risk.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
Karan Mohla, partner at tech investment firm B Capital.

site_title: Malaysia unexpectedly pauses hikes, keeping key policy rate unchanged at 2.75%
summary: Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara, has paused rate hikes, keeping the overnight policy rate (OPR) at 2.75% as it assesses the impact of cumulative past OPR adjustments in 2022. The decision was unexpected and contrary to economists' expectations of a 25 basis point hike. The pause is seen as a temporary measure, with some economists speculating it may be the end of the hiking cycle, while others believe it may be a pause before further adjustments.

images.alt_text: Most economists anticipate the central bank will tighten further, with a quarter-point interest-rate increase to 3 per cent.

site_title: Pulp romance in ancient China
summary: Jeannie Lin's novel "Red Blossom in Snow" is a romance set in ancient China during the Tang Dynasty. The story follows Song Yi, a courtesan who teams up with magistrate Li Chen to solve a murder, as they navigate their dark pasts and societal expectations. Lin's novel blends elements of "Pride and Prejudice," "Sherlock Holmes," and "Memoirs of a Geisha," offering a respectful portrayal of sex workers. The book is part of "The Lotus Palace Mysteries" series and has been listed as one of The New York Times' 100 Notable Books of 2022.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
Sng wears a peach shirt and off-white suit by Celine, as well as a  B.Zero1 pendant chain necklace, B.Zero1 rings, B.Zero1 bangle and Octo Finissimo Chronograph GMT watch, all by Bulgari.
