site_title: EVs could take 20% of car market this year
summary: Electric vehicles (EVs) are expected to take 20% of the car market in Singapore this year, driven by a surge in new models, including the Hyundai Ioniq 5, built in the country. The Ioniq 5, launched at the Singapore Motorshow, comes with a 10-year warranty and free servicing, targeting the lifespan of a Certificate of Entitlement (COE). With prices starting from under S$200,000, EVs are becoming increasingly affordable, with some models undercutting combustion-powered cars. The growth of EVs in Singapore is attributed to a growing number of available models and favorable market conditions, with some manufacturers hoarding EVs for European markets due to strict emissions limits.

images.alt_text: Average daily sales for Tesla in China during the Jan 9 to Jan 15 period jumped 76 per cent from the same period in 2022 to 12,654 vehicles, CMBI’s data showed.
BYD was the world’s biggest seller of BEVs and plug-in hybrids in 2022 with a total of 1.86 million sales.

site_title: Taiwan premier, cabinet submit resignations ahead of reshuffle
summary: Taiwan's Premier Su Tseng-chang and his cabinet submitted resignations to President Tsai Ing-wen on January 19, ahead of a government reshuffle following the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's trouncing at local polls in November. Su, 75, had originally submitted his resignation after the poll losses but was asked to stay on. His successor is expected to be announced after the 10-day Chinese New Year holiday, with speculation surrounding potential replacements.

images.alt_text: Taiwan, which China claims as its own territory, has complained for the past two years of Chinese import bans on various agricultural and aquatic goods, including pineapples and grouper fish, saying it is part of a Chinese pressure campaign.
China's President Xi Jinping arrives for the opening session of the 20th Chinese Communist Party's Congress at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing on October 16, 2022. (Photo by Noel CELIS / AFP)

site_title: Yellen woos Africa as US vies for influence with China, Russia
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen is set to deliver a speech in Dakar, Senegal, on January 20, outlining the Biden administration's renewed focus on Africa over the next two years. Yellen will emphasize the US's commitment to supporting Africa's economic development and its inclusion in the Group of 20 as a permanent member. The US aims to counterbalance China and Russia's influence in Africa, where China is the largest creditor to emerging markets and Russia has strengthened ties. Yellen will also urge African governments to transition to clean energy.

images.alt_text: Janet Yellen’s travel to Senegal, Zambia and South Africa from Wednesday onwards comes after a detour to Switzerland where she is set to meet Chinese Vice Premier Liu He on macroeconomic issues.

site_title: Migration drives German population to record high in 2022
summary: Germany's population reached a record high of 84.3 million people in 2022, driven by an influx of 1.1 million new immigrants, including 740,000 Ukrainians fleeing the war. This balance compensated for the country's low birth rate and ageing population, with immigrants of working age making up 75.9% of the foreign-born population, compared to 61.6% of the overall population. The surge in immigration marked the highest balance since Germany began collecting statistics in 1950.

images.alt_text: People stroll at the shopping district "Hohe Strasse", as the spread of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) continues in Cologne, Germany, April 22, 2020. REUTERS/Thilo Schmuelgen

site_title: CNY gifting in style
summary: Maybank Securities is offering a limited edition box of red packets featuring eight rabbit designs, symbolizing the Water Rabbit Chinese zodiac animal. The designs aim to convey elegance, adaptability, and charm, with Gucci's capsule collection also incorporating playful, refined rabbit interpretations. These red packets serve a greater purpose, promoting corporate purpose and social responsibility.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Design trends for 2023

The British celebration, which London’s mayor had branded the biggest in Europe, also referenced Queen Elizabeth II, who died in September, the red and white of England’s soccer team, and the rainbow colours of the LGBTQ Pride event, which had its 50-year anniversary in 2022.
Time for a tiger

site_title: Thunberg accuses energy firms of throwing people 'under the bus'
summary: Climate activist Greta Thunberg accused the global energy industry of "throwing people under the bus" by continuing to invest in fossil fuels despite the climate crisis. Thunberg, joined by fellow activists, presented a "cease and desist" letter to energy executives, calling for an end to new oil, gas, and coal extraction. The International Energy Agency's head, Fatih Birol, emphasized the need for a transition to clean energy, but acknowledged that the pace is too slow, and emerging countries risk being left behind.

images.alt_text: Climate activist Greta Thunberg gestures as she walks outside during the World Economic Forum in Davos (WEF) in Davos, Switzerland January 19, 2023. REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann

site_title: UK bootmaker Dr Martens warns on profit; shares slide more than 20%
summary: UK bootmaker Dr Martens issued a profit warning, citing operational issues at its US distribution centre, which may reduce annual core profit by £16-25 million. The issues, including inventory bottlenecks, are expected to impact the company's Ebitda and annual revenue forecast, which was revised to 11-13% growth. Shares plummeted 21% in morning trade, hitting a record low.

images.alt_text: Dr Martens boots have been fashion items since the 1960s, after being favoured by the likes of Who guitarist Pete Townshend. Demand for them is still growing.
Shoppers are finding it harder to maintain their standard of living as prices rise for basics like food, energy and fuel.

site_title: Emboldened China protesters test Xi’s resolve after Covid pivot
summary: China's President Xi Jinping is facing growing discontent as protests and unrest spread across the nation, fueled by the lifting of Covid-19 restrictions and related economic woes. Clashes over fireworks, campus lockdowns, and mandatory quarantine measures have sparked widespread outrage, with many questioning the government's credibility and decision-making. Xi's swift retreat on fireworks restrictions has been seen as a sign of vulnerability, while the government vows to crack down on dissent and maintain control. The protests have dealt a blow to Xi's image and the Communist Party's authority, with experts warning of long-term consequences for the country's governance and economy.

images.alt_text: People line up to buy fever and cold medicine as a delivery worker picks up an order at a pharmacy, in Beijing, China, Dec 6, 2022.

site_title: Sim Leisure to report ‘substantial’ comprehensive profit for FY2022
summary: Sim Leisure, a theme park operator, announced a "substantial" comprehensive profit for FY2022, reversing the year-ago loss. The turnaround is attributed to increased revenue from theme park operations and cooperation fee income from a partnership. The company's shares closed flat at S$0.255. This marks a significant improvement following the easing of pandemic restrictions by the Malaysian government.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai

site_title: German remake of ‘All Quiet on the Western Front’ leads Bafta nominations
summary: A German remake of the anti-war classic "All Quiet on the Western Front" led the nominations at the British Academy Film Awards (Baftas) with 14 nods, including best film and best director. The film, based on Erich Maria Remarque's 1928 novel, tied with "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon" for the most non-English language film nominations in Baftas history. Other nominees include "The Banshees of Inisherin," "Everything Everywhere All at Once," and Baz Luhrmann's "Elvis" biopic, which secured 9 nominations each. The Baftas will be awarded on February 19 in London.

images.alt_text: All companies with 15 or more employees advertising jobs based in the state are required to post an estimate for what the employer “reasonably expects to pay” with the posting.
HBO Max, an online extension of the company’s HBO cable channel but with more content, launched in May 2020.
Wakanda: Forever, the sequel to 2018’s blockbuster hit Black Panther, debuted in global theatres in November.

site_title: Indian tycoon Adani says his group has no plans for telecom sector
summary: Indian tycoon Gautam Adani's Adani Group has no plans to enter the country's telecommunications sector, where Jio is a dominant player. The group has stayed away from telecoms despite purchasing airwaves worth $27 million in the country's 5G auction last year. Adani Data Networks aimed to enter the private 5G network space, not consumer services. The conglomerate's proposed $2.5 billion follow-on public offering will be used for capital expenditure and debt repayment. Adani's expansion into sectors like cement and healthcare has raised concerns over elevated debt levels and large promoter shareholding.

images.alt_text: View of Mount Carmel city and port of Haifa in northern Israel. The sale of one Israel’s main seaports marks the culmination of a nearly two-decade reform of an underperforming sector plagued for years by labour strikes.
Gautam Adani Photographer: Edwin Koo/Bloomberg
Billionaire Gautam Adani is known for being bullish about India's prospects, often dovetailing his corporate strategy with nation-building priorities.

site_title: Eurozone bond yields up as ECB maintains monetary tightening path
summary: Eurozone government bond yields rose on Thursday after European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde confirmed the bank will continue raising interest rates to bring down inflation to its 2% target. The ECB will maintain a restrictive monetary policy for as long as necessary, with planned rate hikes of 50 basis points. Dutch central bank chief Klaas Knot warned markets may be underestimating the planned rate hikes, urging investors to take the guidance seriously.

images.alt_text: European Central Bank (ECB) President Christine Lagarde (C) speaks next to ECB vice president Luis de Guindos (L) and the Netherlands Bank (DNB) Klaas Knot (R) during a press conference after a Governing Council meeting focused on monetary policy in the euro zone in Amsterdam on June 9, 2022. (Photo by JOHN THYS / AFP)

site_title: Ukraine's Zelensky ups pressure for more Western weapons
summary: Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelensky urged Western allies to provide Kyiv with more heavy weapons to fight Russia ahead of a key donor meeting. Zelensky criticized Germany for its hesitation to supply modern Leopard tanks, calling for a unified Western response. The Ukrainian leader made the comments following a helicopter crash that killed one of his key ministers. Zelensky emphasized the need for decisive action, saying "there are times when we shouldn't hesitate and shouldn't compare." The plea comes as the nearly year-old war between Ukraine and Russia continues.

images.alt_text: Interior Minister Denys Monastyrsky, responsible for the police and security inside Ukraine, would be the most senior Ukrainian official to die since the war began.
The focus is expected to be on whether Germany will send its Leopard battle tanks to Ukraine.

site_title: Global foundry sales set to drop in 2023 in blow to Taiwan, South Korea
summary: Global foundry sales are projected to drop 4% in 2023 from last year, contrasting with a 28.1% rise in 2022, due to rapidly cooling demand for advanced chips. The decline is attributed to the pace of the global economic downturn, with central bank tightening, China's post-Covid lockdowns, and Russia's war in Ukraine affecting demand. The foundry industry, worth $130 billion, is expected to be impacted, with Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (TSMC) and Samsung Electronics Co holding the largest shares.

images.alt_text: Hidehito Takahashi, a former General Electric executive, led one of the Japanese company’s most transformative deals.
Black Sesame’s potential listing comes as China is pausing its massive investments aimed at building a chip industry to rival the US.
While Taiwan’s assisted local chipmakers in the past with infrastructure construction and other measures, the island is now stepping up its efforts.

site_title: Prime Orchard Road retail rents get boost from tourism rebound
summary: Retail rents in Singapore's prime shopping belt, including Orchard Road, rose 7.4% to S$39.20 per square foot per month in 2022, driven by a rebound in tourism demand. This growth outpaced other submarkets, with retail rents in fringe and suburban areas increasing by 6.7% and in other city areas by 3.7%. The recovery in the tourism sector is expected to continue, with prime retail rents projected to grow 3-5% in 2023, led by the Orchard Road area.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim
Philippine-listed Reits are expected to see consistent earnings growth in FY2023, underpinned by a stable office market.
In the Central Region, the retail vacancy rate was down 0.5 per cent quarter-on-quarter at 9.3 per cent, according to Savills' research arm.
Prices of retail space in the central region falls by 3.2 per cent in Q3 after it dipped 1.2 per cent in Q2.

site_title: GuocoLand’s H1 profit down 13% to S$59m on absence of disposal gain
summary: GuocoLand's net profit for the first half of 2023 fell 13% to S$59 million due to the absence of a disposal gain recorded in the previous year. Excluding the disposal gain, the company's net profit rose 11% to S$59 million, driven by a strong property market and tourism revival. Revenue increased 46% to S$661.6 million, with property development and investment segments posting significant gains. GuocoLand CEO Cheng Hsing Yao attributed the results to the company's delivery of robust results despite sector headwinds.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
GuocoLand says Valerie Wong was instrumental in building up the group’s asset management capability with the development and completion of Guoco Tower.

site_title: SLA to manage state land within public housing estates from HDB on March 1
summary: The Singapore Land Authority (SLA) will take over managing state land within public housing estates starting March 1, replacing the Housing Board. The move aims for "greater administrative and operational efficiency". SLA will issue temporary occupation licenses and handle maintenance, while HDB will manage and maintain existing state land plots. Licensees and tenants can continue to contact HDB before March 1 for help with TOLs and day-to-day operations, and new applications will be submitted through SLA's portal after the handover.

site_title: US$1.1b nickel scam accused Ng Yu Zhi faces possibly over 20 years in jail if convicted
summary: Singaporean accused Ng Yu Zhi, linked to a US$1.1 billion nickel trading scam, faces up to 20 years in jail if convicted. Ng, 35, has 105 charges including cheating, money laundering, and forgery, with a total of S$486.2 million of the S$1.46 billion taken by his companies remaining unrecovered. His bail amount was increased to S$6 million after being remanded, and he is set to be heard by the High Court.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Ng Yu Zhi is facing over 100 criminal charges for his alleged involvement in the US$1.1 billion nickel trading scam.
THE Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has provided updates on the investigation of ongoing high-profile cases in its bid to provide greater transparency on ongoing efforts.

site_title: Bitcoin steadies after ending longest winning streak since 2013
summary: Bitcoin steadied after snapping a 14-day winning streak, ending its longest daily gain since 2013. The largest token rose 0.2% to $20,813, while smaller coins like Solana and Polkadot posted modest increases. Analyst Matt Maley warned of a short-term pullback due to overbought conditions. The crypto sector continues to grapple with the fallout of FTX's collapse, with Genesis Global Capital reportedly preparing for a bankruptcy filing. Bitcoin's 14-day relative strength index has dropped to below 90, hinting at a possible pause in its 2023 advance.

images.alt_text: Miners use specialised computing facilities to secure the Bitcoin network by validating transaction data on the blockchain and earning rewards in the form of the token.

site_title: Wealthy foreigners gain less from buying Singapore property through family offices, experts say
summary: Wealthy foreigners are buying Singapore properties under their individual names to avoid financial disincentives, experts say. Only four commercial property transactions have been attributed to family offices over the past six years, accounting for 0.04% of total commercial property transaction value. This is due to the exclusion of Singapore real estate from local tax incentive schemes for family offices, making it less financially appealing for them to purchase properties through family offices.

Ming Arcade’s owners are represented by Thomas Toh, solicitor of CTLC Law Corporation.
This house on 17,905 sq ft of land in Tanglin Hill and completed in 1997 is currently on the market with an asking price of S$52 million or S$2,904 psf.

site_title: Manchester City top Deloitte Money League for second straight year
summary: Manchester City has topped the Deloitte Football Money League for the second consecutive year, generating 731 million euros (S$1.04 billion) in total revenue in the 2021-22 season. This surpasses Real Madrid (714 million euros) and Liverpool (702 million euros), solidifying the club's position as the world's highest revenue-generating club.

images.alt_text: AC Milan midfielder Tommaso Pobega (right) celebrates after scoring in the 3-1 Champions League win over Dinamo Zagreb on Wednesday night. With him are defender Davide Calabria (left) and forward Alexis Saelemaekers.

Manchester United players pausomg for a silence following the death of Queen Elizabeth II, ahead of the UEFA Europa League Group match with Real Sociedad on Thursday (Sep 8); all Premier League matches this weekend have been postponed.

site_title: China seen preserving benchmark lending rates in January
summary: China is expected to keep its benchmark lending rates unchanged for a fifth consecutive month in January, despite the government's efforts to boost a Covid-ravaged economy. The People's Bank of China pledged steps to stimulate the economy, but analysts predict a cut to the loan prime rate (LPR) next month. China's economy grew 3% in 2022, below the official target, but the end of its zero-Covid policy has raised hopes for a robust recovery.

images.alt_text: Many foreign business people and investors have been unable to travel to China to inspect their businesses or consider new ones for the past three years.

site_title: Healthcare AI startup Qritive bags US$7.5m funding for new markets expansion
summary: Singapore-headquartered healthcare AI startup Qritive has secured US$7.5 million in funding led by MassMutal Ventures, Seeds Capital, and Exfinity Venture Partners. The new capital will be used to expand Qritive's geographical presence, product portfolio, and support regulatory clearances. Founded in 2017, Qritive aims to advance digital pathology for cancer diagnosis and improve health outcomes through AI solutions.

site_title: Car distributor Inchcape seizes EV opportunity instead of waiting for invite
summary: Inchcape, a global car dealership group, has acquired AutoInsure, a Singapore-based workshop for car repairs. The move aims to diversify Inchcape's income streams and gain valuable knowledge about electric vehicle (EV) technology. Although Inchcape's brands, including Toyota and Lexus, have yet to enter the EV market, the acquisition complements their existing operations and provides a designated EV repair centre. The move is seen as Inchcape's way to "join the EV party" without waiting for its brands to make a move, as EV sales are expected to grow significantly in the coming years.

site_title: Indonesia raises key rate to 5.75% as end of tightening nears
summary: Indonesia's central bank raised its benchmark interest rate to 5.75% as it nears the end of its tightening cycle to temper prices, despite inflation unexpectedly picking up last month. The cumulative rate increase is 225 basis points since August 2022, and the bank reaffirmed its 2023 GDP growth estimate at 4.5-5.3%. The move is seen as a calculated step to ensure lower inflation and safeguard growth momentum, as the country prepares for Ramadan.

images.alt_text: Bank Indonesia and Bank Negara Malaysia are expected to raise their respective benchmark rates by 25 basis points on Thursday (Jan 19).
Indonesia's inflation in December stood at 5.51 per cent, driven by rising fuel and food prices.

site_title: More can be done to drive sustainability efforts at SMEs: Isca pre-Budget panel
summary: Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) can benefit from more support in their sustainability efforts, according to a pre-Budget roundtable discussion. Panelists suggested funding for hiring sustainability officers to help SMEs craft concrete environmental policies and measure their carbon impact. A government body to train and certify sustainability officers was also proposed. Additionally, incentivizing multinationals and listed firms to aid SMEs in sustainability efforts and requiring listed companies to make sustainability commitments with their SME vendors were discussed as possible solutions.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
Linus Goh, OCBC's head of global commercial banking, believes there is a chance that SMEs will still remain in expansionary territory for the first quarter of 2023.

site_title: Boohoo forecasts revenue decline as consumers spend less
summary: Boohoo forecasts a 12% decline in revenue for its financial year, with earnings expected to fall at the lower end of its guidance. The decline reflects a shift back to in-store shopping after pandemic-era online spending. The company aims to reduce costs and has cut stock levels and sourced more garments closer to home markets to tackle freight costs. This follows rival Asos' warning of a loss due to heavy discounting and stock write-offs. Boohoo's shares have fallen 71% last year, and the company faces ongoing challenges, including a labour scandal and higher return rates.

images.alt_text: British retailers are battling against weak consumer demand as prices hit a fresh record high this month, with brands increasingly having to pass costs on to consumers.
A customer enters a Tesco Plc supermarket in Potters Bar, UK, on Wednesday, June 15, 2022. Tesco are due to report earnings on Friday. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

site_title: Foreigners turn net buyers of Japanese stocks last week
summary: Foreign investors turned net buyers of Japanese stocks last week, purchasing equities worth 52.65 billion yen and pouring 170.53 billion yen into cash equities. This marked their first weekly net sales in three weeks, after disposing of stocks for four weeks in a row. The move was driven by rising expectations of the US Federal Reserve scaling back rate hikes and optimism around regional growth following China's reopening.

images.alt_text: Many foreign business people and investors have been unable to travel to China to inspect their businesses or consider new ones for the past three years.

site_title: Deliveroo achieves breakeven in Q2
summary: Deliveroo, a meal delivery company, achieved breakeven in adjusted earnings in Q2, boosting its margin for the year to -1% and exceeding expectations. The company's gross transaction value increased 6% to £1.8 billion, driven by item price inflation offsetting a 2% drop in order numbers. Founder Will Shu stated that Deliveroo delivered "significant improvements in profitability" despite a challenging macroeconomic environment. The company remains confident in its ability to adapt financially and make progress towards profitability in 2023.

images.alt_text: The growth of South-east Asia's food delivery gross merchandise value has been muted in 2022 as profitability becomes front of mind.

site_title: LVMH Watch Week kicks off watch season in Singapore
summary: LVMH Watch Week, a major watch show, was held in Singapore from January 10 to 12, marking the start of watch season in the country. The event showcased new timepieces from core LVMH brands, including Bulgari, Hublot, Tag Heuer, and Zenith, with the Paris-based luxury group citing Asia's huge market and China's reopening as reasons for the move from Dubai. The event aims to capitalize on Singapore's ideal market for watch launches and attract clients, collectors, and enthusiasts.

images.alt_text: DEFY Skyline Skeleton.

site_title: Asia: Markets track Wall Street lower as recession fears return
summary: Asian markets fell on Thursday, tracking lower US stocks, amid recession fears. Despite China's economy showing signs of recovery, concerns about inflation and interest rates have shifted to growth fears. The dollar weakened, oil prices dropped, and Tokyo, Hong Kong, Shanghai, Singapore, and Manila fell, while Sydney, Seoul, and Jakarta edged up. Analysts warn of a possible recession in 2023, contradicting earlier hopes for a strong recovery.

images.alt_text: In early equity trade, Hong Kong, Shanghai, Tokyo, Sydney, Singapore, Wellington, Manila and Jakarta were all on the rise, though Seoul dipped on Wednesday.

site_title: Binance named counterparty to firm facing illicit fund charges
summary: Binance, the world's largest crypto exchange, has been named as a top receiving counterparty for illicit funds by Bitzlato, a digital-asset platform accused of processing millions of dollars in illegal funds. Binance provided substantial assistance to law enforcement in the investigation, and its ties to darknet markets and scams are highlighted in a Treasury Department document. Bitzlato's Russian founder Anatoly Legkodymov was arrested on charges of masking proceeds from illegal gambling and drug deals valued at over $700 million.

images.alt_text: US Deputy Attorney General Lisa O. Monaco speaking at a news conference on recent enforcement actions against Bitzlato cofounder Anatoly Legkodymov at the US Justice Department building on Jan 18, 2023 in Washington, DC.

site_title: Vietnam EV maker VinFast plans promotions in response to Tesla price cuts
summary: Vietnam's electric vehicle maker VinFast plans promotions in response to Tesla's price cuts, aiming to maintain competitiveness in the US market. The company, which has secured over 65,000 global orders, plans to expand in the US with two models, the VF8 and VF9, starting at $59,000 and $83,000. VinFast aims to deliver its first batch of 999 EVs to the US by this month and plans to build an EV plant in North Carolina. The company will announce promotions, which may include price cuts, to protect its market share.

images.alt_text: The company, a unit of conglomerate Vingroup, aims to start delivering its cars to US customers this month.

site_title: Closure date for Chip Eng Seng offer extended to Feb 2
summary: The closing date for Chip Eng Seng's mandatory cash offer has been extended to February 2, from January 19. The offer, launched by Celine Tang and her husband Gordon Tang, is priced at S$0.75 per share and aims to acquire 87.26% of the company. The offer was initially launched on November 24 at a lower price and has since been raised to its current price. The company must attain over 90% ownership to take it private.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
Celine Tang, managing director of listed developer SingHaiyi Group

site_title: Banks, consumer sectors likely to come out tops in Q4 earnings; cost pressures could surface
summary: Analysts predict Singapore-listed companies, particularly banks and consumer sectors, to deliver solid earnings in Q4 2022 due to rising interest rates and the reopening of economies. Energy stocks are also expected to benefit from higher energy prices. However, observers warn of potential economic recession and advise investors to prepare for higher funding costs and balance sheet quality. Key sectors to watch include travel and hospitality, healthcare, and industrial Reits, while office and overseas Reits may disappoint due to high gearing levels and declining asset valuations.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi

François Villeroy de Galhau, Governor, Central Bank of France speaking in the The Role of Finance in a Recovery session at the World Economic Forum Annual Meeting 2023 in Davos-Klosters, Switzerland, 18 January. Congress Centre - Aspen 1. Copyright: World Economic Forum/Manuel Lopez

Philadelphia Federal Reserve Bank President Patrick Harker said he is expecting the Fed to get rates over 5 per cent and added that uncertainty about the stopping point is why the central bank should slow the pace of its rate hikes.

site_title: China says critical Covid cases have peaked as holiday travel surges
summary: China's Covid-19 cases have peaked, with the number of patients in critical conditions in hospitals decreasing by over 40% since January 5, according to a health official. Despite this, the country is bracing for a surge in infections during the upcoming holiday season, with as many as 36,000 daily deaths predicted by health experts. China has also seen a surge in demand for Covid-19 treatments, with drugmakers tripling their capacity to meet the demand. The country's reopening is seen as a potential catalyst for its economy, which has been struggling with low growth rates.

images.alt_text: Patients in a hallway at a hospital in Shanghai, China, on Jan. 7, 2023. Beijing’s efforts to limit discord over its sudden “zero Covid” pivot are being challenged with increasing rancor, including from Communist Party supporters. (Qilai Shen/The New York Times)

site_title: Why China’s shrinking population is a big deal
summary: China's population has shrunk for the first time in six decades, with deaths outnumbering births in 2022. This decline, expected to continue through the century, will have significant impacts on China's economy, society, and politics. The shrinking population will lead to a rapidly ageing society, with a quarter of the population expected to be over 65 by 2040. This will impose severe constraints on the elderly, their children, and the government, which will need to provide adequate healthcare and pensions. The Chinese government's response to this demographic shift will be crucial, as failure to address the challenges could result in a crisis for the ruling Communist Party.

images.alt_text: On a per person basis, consumption actually fell last year, according to data released on Tuesday (Jan 17) by the National Bureau of Statistics (NBS).
India, where half the population is under the age of 30, is set to be the world’s fastest-growing major economy in the coming years.
China's birth rate was 6.77 births per 1,000 people last year, down from a rate of 7.52 births in 2021 and marking the lowest birth rate on record.

site_title: Jacinda Ardern gives the world a lesson in humility
summary: New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern announced her resignation on January 19, 2023, after serving as the world's youngest female leader at 37. Ardern's departure was met with shock and respect, highlighting the challenges of achieving diversity in politics. Her decision to step down on her own terms underscores the need for women to be kept in leadership positions, as Ardern's leadership stood out for its contrast to boorish male counterparts. Ardern's legacy includes reforms on gun laws, pandemic management, and Indigenous representation, leaving behind a void for role models who embody strength, compassion, and grace under pressure.

images.alt_text: New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern leaves with longtime partner Clarke Gayford following the announcement of her resignation at the War Memorial Hall, in Napier, New Zealand January 19, 2023. site_title: Infrastructure plays gaining traction as investors seek uncorrelated returns
summary: Investors are turning to the infrastructure sector for stable returns amid slowing macroeconomic conditions. Listed infrastructure assets saw significant growth in 2022, with ClearBridge Investments reporting a 19% year-over-year increase in assets under management. Infrastructure assets retain a residual value, making them attractive in times of economic distress, and provide predictable long-term cash flow. The sector is expected to remain firm, with public policy support for green infrastructure investments and a robust pipeline of capital investment opportunities.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
People near a mine operated by MMG Las Bambas, in a region where locals claim mining activity has negatively affected crop yields and killed livestock, outside of Cusco, Peru October 14, 2021.
The new APAC Sustainable Infrastructure Fund has a target size of US$500 million to US$1 billion.

site_title: China races to make Covid-19 drugs as Xi fears rural outbreaks
summary: China is racing to produce Covid-19 treatments and anti-fever medicines as President Xi Jinping expresses concerns about rural outbreaks during the Lunar New Year holiday season. With up to 36,000 daily deaths predicted by Airfinity, China's healthcare system is expected to be severely burdened. Domestic drugmakers are tripling production to meet demand, while foreign treatments, such as Pfizer's Paxlovid, remain scarce in China. The country's relaxed Covid-19 controls have led to widespread protests and a surge in cases, with nearly 60,000 hospital deaths reported between Dec 8 and Jan 12.

images.alt_text: Local economies are ramping up efforts to revive the Covid-hit services sector as frequent and stringent lockdowns and restrictions kept shoppers at home and disrupted consumption activity.
Hong Kong gave up other restrictions in December after China abandoned its strict approach to controlling the virus.
The world’s second-largest economy is now forecast to expand 5.1 per cent in 2023 and 5 per cent next year.

site_title: Evergrande chairman, once worth US$42b, loses 93% of wealth
summary: Evergrande chairman Hui Ka Yan's fortune has plummeted from $42 billion to $3 billion, a 93% decline. His exclusion from China's elite political advisory body, the CPPCC, reflects the country's shift in attitude towards property developers, many of whom have fallen from grace amid a real estate crisis. The crisis has also led to a crackdown on industries, including a strict "three red lines" policy to curb debt, affecting banks, trust firms, and homeowners. China's five richest property tycoons have collectively lost $65 billion in the past two years.

images.alt_text: The clock is ticking for the world’s most indebted developer, which first defaulted on dollar bonds more than a year ago and has some US$16.6 billion of outstanding dollar notes.
In its Jan 16 resignation letter to Evergrande’s audit committee and board, PwC noted it still hadn’t received information relating to “significant matters” of the 2021 audit.

site_title: JPMorgan’s top pick in Asean is Thai stocks on tourism outlook
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co has named Thai stocks as its top pick in Asean, driven by a strong tourism outlook fueled by China's reopening. The bank expects Thailand's tourism revenue to double to US$39 billion this year, and predicts the benchmark SET Index to rise 7% to near-record levels. JPMorgan recommends stocks such as CP All and Global Power Synergy, citing domestic demand and defensive plays against a global economic slowdown.

images.alt_text: Thailand is estimated to have welcomed at least 11.5 million foreign travellers last year, surpassing the initial 10 million estimate.

site_title: Hong Kong to remove mandatory quarantine for Covid infections
summary: Hong Kong will lift its mandatory Covid isolation order for infected individuals, starting January 30, as the government seeks to revive the economy. This move comes after China abandoned its strict approach to controlling the virus in December. The city has largely abandoned all Covid-19 restrictions, with the exception of mask mandates. The lifting of isolation measures is expected to have a positive impact on the economy, but may also increase the risk of Covid transmission.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong’s real estate companies were cautious about putting projects up for sale in 2022 as home prices retreated.

site_title: Mazda MX-30 review: Short range, but not short-changed
summary: Mazda's MX-30 is the company's first electric vehicle, offering a unique blend of style and minimalism. It boasts a 50 kW charger that can top up the battery in just half an hour, making it suitable for short trips. However, its small battery limits range to around 200 km in real-world traffic, making it less suitable for family use. Despite its quirks, the MX-30 is an appealing option for those who prioritize style and convenience over long-range capabilities. Mazda's entry into the EV market marks a step towards catching up with European competitors.

site_title: Corporate pay is ‘out of proportion’: Norges CEO Tangen
summary: Norges Bank Investment Management CEO Nicolai Tangen stated that corporate pay packages have "gone out of proportion" at the World Economic Forum. The fund, managing the Norwegian Government Pension Fund Global, is voting down poorly structured pay packages. The fund, worth $1.6 trillion, owns stakes in nearly 9,000 companies worldwide, and Tangen's comments highlight the global imbalance in executive compensation.

Previously, long-serving IDs (LSIDs) could continue to be deemed independent if approval was obtained at two tiers of voting: first, from all shareholders; and second, from shareholders excluding directors, the CEO and their associates.

site_title: Pilots fail to cash in on air traffic revival, says global survey
summary: A global survey by Goose recruitment and FlightGlobal found that despite a rebound in air travel, many pilots are concerned about salary. Over half of pilots have not had a salary increase in five years, with Asia-Pacific being the worst-affected region. 73% of North American pilots reported higher salaries, while almost two-thirds of pilots want to change jobs for better pay and conditions. The survey also predicts a shortage of pilots over the next five years, with 89% of respondents believing this will be the case.

site_title: New Zealand PM Jacinda Ardern leaves a legacy forged from crisis
summary: New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern announced her shock resignation on January 19, 2023, citing the unrelenting demands of the job having worn her down. Ardern, who was 37 years old when elected in 2017, had previously faced the country's worst terror attack, a deadly volcanic eruption, and the Covid-19 pandemic. Her departure marks the end of a tumultuous first term, during which she became a global icon for progressive politics.

images.alt_text: New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern plans to step down no later than early February, she said  on Thursday.
The builders and retailers were the most downbeat in the December quarter.
House prices in New Zealand have fallen 13 per cent since their November 2021 peak.

site_title: China foreign investment posts record slump as Covid Zero ended
summary: China's foreign direct investment (FDI) plummeted by 29% in December, reaching a record low of 76.6 billion yuan, amid the government's exit from Covid Zero and rising infections. This slump follows a 33% drop in November, the largest decline since 2015. Despite a 6.3% increase in total FDI for 2022 to a record 1.2 trillion yuan, foreign businesses have become increasingly pessimistic about the Chinese market, and many investors remain hesitant to travel to or invest in China.

images.alt_text: Taylor Swift at the 2018 American Music Awards in October. "I feel strongly that streaming was founded on and continues to thrive based on the magic created by artists, writers and producers," she told her 113 million Instagram followers in a posting.

site_title: London’s luxury houses are defying Britain’s home sales slowdown
summary: London's luxury homes are defying the UK's housing market slowdown, with sales of £5 million+ homes 74% higher in Q4 2022 compared to the pre-Covid average. This is attributed to wealthy buyers being shielded from higher mortgage rates and international buyers being attracted to London's luxury market due to the weak pound. In contrast, the wider London market saw activity drop off in Q4 2022 as borrowing costs soared. Experts expect the market to unfold cautiously in the months ahead.

images.alt_text: The average cost of a home fell to £295,000 in November, down by £1,000 from the month before but £28,000 more than a year ago, the Office for National Statistics (ONS) said on Wednesday (Jan 18).
The freeze in deals comes as buyers wait for rates to feed through to valuations.

site_title: UK home buyers seek energy-efficient properties as prices tumble
summary: UK home buyers are prioritizing energy-efficient properties as prices tumble, with 61% of estate agents reporting that highly rated homes are holding their value. The Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (RICS) survey found that energy efficiency is becoming increasingly important to buyers, with 40% of respondents seeing greater interest in energy-efficient homes. Despite a third consecutive month of falling property prices, the RICS warns that the housing market is on a downward trend due to rising mortgage costs and inflation.

site_title: China’s growth forecasts raised into next year as country reopens
summary: China's economic growth forecasts have been raised to 5.1% in 2023 and 5% in 2024, according to a Bloomberg survey of economists. The country's abrupt end to Covid restrictions and peaking of infections have fueled optimism that the costs of reopening will be limited. Consumption is expected to rebound, driving growth, with the median estimate higher than previous forecasts. This recovery is seen as a key factor in China's economic growth.

images.alt_text: Chunxi Road shopping area in Chengdu, Sichuan province. Even with weaker GDP growth in 2022, China's reopening has spurred expectations for a strong 2023 rebound.

site_title: US CFTC commissioner warns of risks if crypto firms self-certify
summary: US Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) Commissioner Christy Goldsmith Romero warned lawmakers against allowing cryptocurrency exchanges to self-certify with the agency, citing the risk of "regulatory arbitrage" and potential oversight gaps. She expressed concerns about the lack of due diligence in FTX's investments, suggesting that firms may have turned a blind eye to red flags. Romero emphasized the need for strong corporate governance and increased gatekeeper roles to regain public trust in the crypto industry.

images.alt_text: The crypto industry has already downsized from its boom time in 2021 when upstarts poached talent en masse from Silicon Valley and Wall Street firms.

site_title: Ex-Nippon Paint senior VP and two others charged with insider trading
summary: Ex-Nippon Paint senior VP Shae Toh Hock, 62, and his sister Shae Hung Yee, 59, along with her husband Siew Boon Liong, 62, were charged with insider trading for communicating non-public information about Nippon Paint's proposed acquisition of DuluxGroup between April 7-12, 2019.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
Nikhil Wahi and his brother, former Coinbase employee Ishan Wahi, were both arrested in July.
Ng Yu Zhi was declared bankrupt last month on the application of the liquidators of his companies.

site_title: New Zealand Prime Minister Ardern says she will step down next month
summary: New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern announced her intention to step down no later than early February, with a general election scheduled for October 14. Ardern cited her inability to prepare for another term, sparking an internal Labour Party leadership contest. Deputy Prime Minister Grant Robertson will not seek the leadership. Ardern expressed confidence in the Labour Party's chances of winning the election.

site_title: Gold ticks up as investors weigh Fed slowdown chances
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to $1,907.18 per ounce, driven by investors weighing the chances of the US Federal Reserve slowing interest rate hikes. Few Fed officials signaled a slower pace, while traders expect a 25-basis point rate hike in February. Lower interest rates benefit bullion, decreasing its opportunity cost. Spot silver and platinum also gained, while palladium remained unchanged. The news comes after data showed US producer prices fell more than expected in December, indicating receding inflation.

images.alt_text: The US central bank raised rates by 75 basis points (bps) four times last year, before slowing to a 50 bps increase in December.

site_title: BOJ jolts financial markets but risk of a bigger shock remains
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) kept its main policy settings unchanged, maintaining a negative interest rate of -0.1% and a yield curve control policy. The decision, which was expected by some traders, caused a modest jolt in global markets, with the yen initially slumping 2% against the dollar but recovering later. Analysts say the BOJ's stance suggests a temporary setback to bets on policy normalization, but the risk of a larger shock remains, particularly if the central bank shifts policy in the future. The decision also left bonds in other global markets vulnerable to higher Japanese yields.

images.alt_text: The yen was broadly weaker, although analysts said the BOJ was likely to tighten policy soon and the currency walked back some of its losses.
FILE PHOTO: People pass by an electronic screen showing Japan's Nikkei share price index inside a conference hall  in Tokyo, Japan June 14, 2022. REUTERS/Issei Kato/File Photo

site_title: China reopening not enough to power Thai growth to 4% in 2023
summary: Thailand's economy is expected to expand by 3.7% in 2023, the fastest growth in five years, driven by an upswing in tourism from China's reopening. However, this growth is not sufficient to restore pre-pandemic levels, with economists predicting a 4.2% growth in 2017 and 2018. Tourism accounts for 12% of the Thai economy, but shipments abroad are expected to lag due to weak global demand and a strong baht, which may erode price competitiveness.

images.alt_text: Tourists and locals browse goods and food at a walking street market in Phuket, Thailand, on Sunday, Oct. 2, 2022. Thailand will end a nationwide state of emergency declared in the wake of Covid outbreak after the Southeast Asian nation downgraded the virus from a “dangerous” communicable disease to one that only requires surveillance. Photographer: Andre Malerba/Bloomberg

site_title: Most big Japanese firms heed prime minister’s call to raise wages this year
summary: Japan's big companies are planning to raise wages by at least 3% this year, meeting Prime Minister Fumio Kishida's request to help workers cope with surging consumer prices. 34% of firms polled said they planned wage increases, a jump from 10% in October. However, smaller firms, which provide most jobs, are less likely to increase pay due to concerns about losing customers. Meanwhile, companies are divided on a proposed 4% to 4.5% corporate tax surcharge to fund military spending, with 29% opposing the plan.

images.alt_text: The yen was broadly weaker, although analysts said the BOJ was likely to tighten policy soon and the currency walked back some of its losses.
Japan's exports rose 11.5 per cent year-on-year in December, the slowest growth since the start of last year, Ministry of Finance data showed.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sats, CapitaLand India Trust, OxPay
summary: CapitaLand India Trust has entered into a forward purchase agreement to acquire a 1 million square foot IT park in Bangalore, India for 12.3 billion rupees (S$201 million). Sats shareholders have voted in favor of acquiring Paris-based air cargo handler Worldwide Flight Services for S$1.8 billion.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open 1.1% lower after US falls
summary: Tokyo shares fell 1.10% in early trade on Thursday, following a decline on US stocks amid concerns about slowing economic activity. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 295.86 points to 26,495.26. The move is attributed to the latest US retail and wholesale data, which indicated a slowdown.

site_title: Japan’s trade deficit persists as recession risks loom
summary: Japan's exports rose 11.5% year-on-year in December, the slowest growth since last year, due to weak demand from China. Imports jumped 20.6% year-on-year, driven by cost-push inflation, resulting in a 17th consecutive trade deficit of 1.45 trillion yen. This data dashes hopes for an export-led economic recovery from the pandemic and highlights Japan's reliance on imports, particularly of commodity and energy resources.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People pass by an electronic screen showing Japan's Nikkei share price index inside a conference hall  in Tokyo, Japan June 14, 2022. REUTERS/Issei Kato/File Photo
The BOJ kept its main policy settings unchanged Wednesday, leaving its negative interest rate at -0.1 per cent.

site_title: Let’s-a-go (to Hollywood)! First US ‘Super Mario’ theme park to open
summary: Universal Studios Hollywood is set to open its first Nintendo-themed park, Super Nintendo World, on February 17, 2023. The immersive experience will feature rides, mini-games, and interactive technology, including a "Mario Kart: Bowser's Challenge" ride with augmented reality goggles. The park is part of a growing trend of theme parks incorporating video game elements, and coincides with the release of The Super Mario Bros. Movie in April. A second Nintendo theme park is planned for Orlando, solidifying Nintendo's presence in the global theme park market.

images.alt_text: Gangwon province, the municipality where the Legoland  theme park is based and which was the guarantor of the securities, missed the repayment of 205 billion won of PF-ABCP in late September.
Roku Kyoto is located in the mountains of northern Kyoto.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares open with big losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened with significant losses, with the Hang Seng Index sinking 1.04% to 21,452.26 in early trade. The decline follows a drop on Wall Street, fueled by recession worries after US retail sales slumped for a second straight month in December. This is a result of global economic concerns, including a slowdown in China's GDP growth.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall at Thursday’s open; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.1% at Thursday's open, with the Straits Times Index (STI) dropping 2.85 points to 3,286.7 points, as losers outnumbered gainers 69 to 49. This follows a depressing session on Wall Street, where the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 1.8% and the S&P 500 fell 1.6%.

images.alt_text: CapitaLand India Trust has entered into a forward purchase agreement to acquire a one million square foot IT park in Bangalore, India for 12.3 billion rupees (S$201 million).

site_title: Higher interest rates no hindrance to innovation, say industry watchers at Davos
summary: Industry watchers at the Davos World Economic Forum say high interest rates will not hinder innovation or private capital investment. Despite concerns, French central bank governor Francois Villeroy de Galhau notes efforts to regulate the non-bank financial sector are underway. Some investors see room for correction in valuations, and more regulation in certain financial areas. Higher interest rates have led to increased caution among investors and tightened belts for startups, but this is not seen as a major concern for innovation.

Germany's finance minister Christian Lindner says that he is “very much concerned” about a possible ban on inducements.

site_title: TSMC supplier Resonac prepares for billion-dollar chip deals
summary: Resonac Holdings, a Japanese chemicals giant, is preparing to spend hundreds of billions of yen on chip acquisitions to boost its role as a pivotal supplier to global giants like TSMC and Samsung Electronics. The company aims to capitalize on the US$580 billion semiconductor industry's consolidation, but is cautious about spending in China due to US sanctions. Resonac CEO Hidehito Takahashi is looking to invest in the US, where two of its largest customers are expanding, and is open to forming alliances and potentially making large acquisitions if justified.

images.alt_text: Hidehito Takahashi Source: Resonac Holdings Corp.

site_title: Chip Eng Seng IFA’s ‘fair and reasonable’ finding needs to consider factors that matter most
summary: Chip Eng Seng Corporation's major shareholders have made an offer of S$0.75 per share, a 43.9% discount to the company's revalued net asset value (RNAV) per share. Independent financial adviser Xandar Capital deemed the offer "fair and reasonable" and recommended shareholders accept it, citing eight factors in favour and three against. However, critics argue that the IFA's assessment should place greater emphasis on material factors, such as the discount to NAV and RNAV, and that the offer's price-to-RNAV ratio is lower than comparable transactions, making it less attractive to shareholders.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim

Terms of the offer by billionaire couple Gordon and Celine Tang (pictured) to privatise the company at S$0.75 per share are fair “on balance”, said Chip Eng Seng's independent financial advisor Xandar Capital.
Celine Tang, chairman of Chip Eng Seng, and her husband Gordon Tang earlier this year took SingHaiyi Group private at a 21.8 per cent discount to book value.

site_title: European executives eye Biden’s green plan with envy in Davos
summary: European businesses are expressing concern over the US Inflation Reduction Act, which includes billions in financial aid that they fear will unfairly benefit US businesses. The EU is under pressure to respond with its own plans to compete, but any meaningful changes seem unlikely. Industry leaders, such as Volvo's Martin Lundstedt, are urging the EU to take inspiration from the US's green-energy subsidy plan to improve its own ability to compete. The EU's fragmented market is seen as a major obstacle, and some executives fear that a tit-for-tat subsidy war could split the global economy.

images.alt_text: Colm Kelleher, chairman of UBS Group, says: “Banks and insurance companies are well regulated. They’re systemically safe, we can argue.”

site_title: The best port in a storm: why tech businesses are flocking to Singapore
summary: Tech businesses are flocking to Singapore, drawn by the city-state's strategic location, diverse talent pool, and favorable business environment. With nearly half of South-east Asia's unicorns and 80 of the top 100 global tech firms based in Singapore, the country is positioning itself as a hub for disruptive startups. The Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) is supporting these companies through its partnership, access, people, and global perspective approach, which has led to partnerships with top startup ecosystem organizations worldwide. This influx of tech businesses is expected to boost Singapore's reputation as a world-leading digital metropolis and drive economic growth.

images.alt_text: The demand for workers with skills in software engineering, cloud and analytics is likely to increase with the rise of tech trends in 5G, cloud computing and AI, according to the Jobs Transformation Map for tech workers.

site_title: Apple to expand smart-home lineup, taking on Amazon and Google
summary: Apple is expanding its smart-home lineup, including a new tablet product that can control smart devices, display video, and handle FaceTime chats. The company is also revamping its HomePod speaker and TV box, with a new HomePod speaker featuring a temperature sensor and a faster processor. Apple aims to challenge Amazon and Google in the smart-home market, where its current devices have struggled with limited functionality and lagging voice-control services. The new devices are part of a broader effort to turn around Apple's fortunes.

images.alt_text: The Apple HomePod smart speaker sits on display at an Apple store in New York in New York, U.S., on Friday, February 9, 2018. Mark Kauzlarich/Bloomberg

site_title: Philippines’ Marcos says South China Sea ‘keeps him up at night’
summary: Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr expressed concern over the South China Sea, stating that tension in the disputed region "keeps him up at night." Marcos said his nation is watching as a "bystander" when tensions rise after Chinese or US warships cross the region. Despite China's territorial claims, Marcos emphasized his country's commitment to peace, with Beijing and the Philippines agreeing to resolve maritime disagreements through "friendly consultation" during Marcos' visit to Beijing.

images.alt_text: The Philippine government will release fourth-quarter GDP data on Jan 26.
Ruthie Ann Miles as Imelda Marcos in the musical "Here Lies Love," during its Public Theater run in New York, April 30, 2014.
Marcos has faced numerous economic challenges in his first six months as the country’s leader, including tight public finances and rising borrowing costs.

site_title: Citigroup boosts pay for most junior bankers despite tough year
summary: Citigroup is boosting pay for its junior investment bankers by 10-15% despite a tough year, as the bank warned investors that inflation would push compensation expenses higher. This move comes after a sharp decline in dealmaking last year, with Citigroup recording a 53% drop in investment-banking fees for 2022. The pay bump aims to retain staff amid a struggle for financial firms to attract and keep talent, with private equity firms poaching talent.

images.alt_text: Citi's investment-banking revenue has plunged 58 per cent, after merger and acquisition activity slowed dramatically in 2022.

site_title: Most rainforest carbon offsets ‘worthless’: media analysis
summary: A media analysis by The Guardian, Die Zeit, and SourceMaterial found that most rainforest carbon offsets are "worthless" due to high rates of "phantom credits." Verra, the world's largest carbon credit provider, has issued over one billion credits since 2009, but only a handful of projects showed evidence of deforestation reductions. The analysis concluded that 94% of credits had no benefit to the climate, with many projects failing to protect rainforests as claimed. Verra disputed the findings, citing a recent review of its calculation methods and a standardization process.

images.alt_text: Antonio Guterres, UN Secretary-General, says: “We learnt last week that certain fossil fuel producers were fully aware in the 1970s that their core product was baking our planet.”

The US' Inflation Reduction Act, signed by President Biden, has sparked a backlash in Europe, which fears that domestic industry will divert investment to take advantage of the generous tax credits and other subsidies

site_title: Asia hedge funds avert disaster on scale of financial crisis with China’s reopening
summary: Asia-Pacific-focused hedge funds narrowly avoided a year of double-digit losses after China's easing of COVID restrictions spurred a late market rally. The percentage of funds that made money in 2022 more than doubled in the last two months to nearly a third. Key funds, including Yunqi Capital and Aspex Management, pared significant losses during the final two months of 2022, with some finishing the year down only 1.7% and 7.8%, respectively. The recovery was driven by optimism over China's economic reopening and slower US rate hikes.

site_title: Goldman says goodbye to ‘greenium’ as ESG now priced like all debt
summary: Goldman Sachs analysts stated that the "greenium" premium offered on ESG bonds has disappeared, as funding costs for conventional debt and ESG-linked debt are now comparable. This follows a decline in global credit markets and increased investor skepticism towards ESG investments. As a result, sales of sustainability-linked bonds (SLBs) fell 21% to $86 billion last year, and many investors are now unconvinced that reputational risk will be enough to ensure issuers meet their ESG targets.

images.alt_text: The US' Inflation Reduction Act, signed by President Biden, has sparked a backlash in Europe, which fears that domestic industry will divert investment to take advantage of the generous tax credits and other subsidies

Mostly sidelined by the Trump administration, the agency’s Loan Programs Office has been revived under President Joe Biden and armed with more money following the passage last year of the country’s landmark climate law.

site_title: Federal Reserve’s Harker says he is ready to downshift to 25-basis-point rate hikes
summary: Philadelphia Federal Reserve President Patrick Harker expressed readiness for the US central bank to slow its interest rate hikes amid cooling inflation. Harker expects inflation to reach 5% and believes the Fed should slow the pace of rate hikes to achieve its goal of slowing the economy modestly and bringing demand in line with supply. He is prepared to raise the benchmark interest rate to 4.50% and expects hikes of 25 basis points going forward, aiming to restrain activity to lower inflation back to its 2% target by 2025.

images.alt_text: Workers build a floor at a home under construction in Saratoga Springs, Utah, U.S., on Tuesday, March 12, 2019. The National Association of Home Builders (NAHB) released housing market index figures on March 18. Photographer: George Frey/Bloomberg
Business inventories rose 0.4 per cent after gaining 0.2 per cent in October, the Commerce Department said on Wednesday (Jan 18).
While some US retailers reported better sales over the holiday period, others said that high inflation continued to weigh on consumers, particularly those of low- and moderate-income households.

site_title: Crypto firm Genesis is preparing to file for bankruptcy
summary: Crypto firm Genesis Global Capital, a unit of Digital Currency Group (DCG), is preparing to file for bankruptcy. The company, which offers cryptocurrency lending services, suspended withdrawals in November amid a liquidity crunch. Genesis has been in confidential negotiations with creditor groups and warned that it may need to file for bankruptcy if it fails to raise cash. The company has proposed a restructuring plan, but creditors have yet to come to an agreement. DCG has also suspended quarterly dividends and engaged a financial adviser to explore options, including a partial or full sale.

images.alt_text: Gemini launched Earn in February of 2021, with the idea of offering users passive returns on their coins in exchange for the right to lend the tokens out.
Genesis' parent company DCG is considering offloading parts of its venture-capital holdings, worth about US$500 million, the Financial Times reports.
Genesis told clients in an update this week that it needs more time to come up with a solution for the troubles at its lending unit.

site_title: Europe: Shares extend winning streak on earnings boost
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index rose 0.2% on its sixth consecutive day of gains, driven by upbeat earnings from mining and technology stocks. Luxury stocks, such as Richemont and Burberry, also benefited from optimism over China's economic recovery. The index has gained 7.7% so far in 2023, despite concerns over inflation and recession.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 1.8 per cent, or nearly 615 points, to 33,297.02 on Wednesday.

site_title: Indonesia, Malaysia enter final laps of rate-hike cycle
summary: Indonesia and Malaysia are set to raise their benchmark interest rates by 25 basis points as they wind down monetary tightening and focus on economic growth. Bank Indonesia is expected to increase its seven-day reverse repurchase rate to 5.75%, its highest level in over three years, while Bank Negara Malaysia is expected to raise its overnight policy rate to 3%. The moves aim to curb price pressures, particularly ahead of Ramadan festivities, and support economic growth, which is predicted to slow this year.

images.alt_text: Despite a slower growth recorded in December, Malaysia’s total trade in 2022 reached a new milestone of RM2.8 trillion, the fastest growth since 1994.
Indonesia's inflation in December stood at 5.51 per cent, driven by rising fuel and food prices.
All but one of 27 economists in the Jan 10-16 Reuters poll forecast the central bank to hike its overnight policy rate to 3.00 per cent, where it was before the pandemic, at its meeting on Jan 19.

site_title: Trump presses Facebook to restore his account
summary: Former US President Donald Trump is urging Facebook to reinstate his account, two years after it was deactivated following the January 6, 2021, US Capitol insurrection. Trump's lawyers argue that the ban has "dramatically distorted and inhibited public discourse" and that his status as a leading contender for the 2024 Republican nomination justifies reinstatement. Facebook has said it will review the ban in the coming weeks, following a two-year review period. Trump has also had his Twitter account blocked, and has since used his own platform, Truth Social, to communicate with followers.

images.alt_text: Republican Representatives Matt Gaetz (Florida) and Kevin McCarthy (California) confer after the House’s 14th vote to select a speaker, at the Capitol in Washington, late on Friday, Jan 6, 2023. It took 15 rounds of voting for McCarthy to win the Speaker's gavel.
Trump’s company faces only a maximum US$1.6 million penalty, but it plans to appeal the sentence.

site_title: Malaysia growth will be key for ringgit this year: Trade Minister
summary: Malaysia's economic growth is expected to influence the country's currency, the ringgit, in 2023. Trade Minister Tengku Zafrul Aziz stated that the country's growth, forecasted at 4-5%, will be a key determinant of the ringgit's strength. Despite a slowing global economy, Zafrul believes the ringgit will continue to strengthen as long as Malaysia remains competitive in trade and investment. The central bank is expected to raise interest rates by a quarter-point to 3%, but Zafrul is optimistic about foreign direct investment, which is projected to rise 20% in 2023.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A man walks past the entrance of Central Bank of Malaysia (Bank Negara Malaysia) in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, July 31, 2019. REUTERS/Lim Huey Teng

site_title: US arrests Bitzlato cofounder, alleges US$700m of illicit funds processed
summary: US authorities have arrested Anatoly Legkodymov, a Russian national and cofounder of Hong Kong-registered virtual currency exchange Bitzlato, on charges of processing $700 million in illicit funds. Legkodymov allegedly operated the exchange as an unlicensed money exchange business catering to "known crooks" and exchanged cryptocurrency with Hydra Market, a notorious online marketplace for illicit activities. The US Justice Department and Treasury Department have labeled Bitzlato a "primary money laundering concern," effectively rendering it an international pariah, and will freeze it out of the global financial sector.

images.alt_text: Some US$323 million in crypto had been hacked from FTX’s international exchange and US$90 million had been hacked from its US exchange since it filed for bankruptcy on Nov 11, CEO John Ray said in a separate statement on Tuesday.
FILE PHOTO: Representations of cryptocurrencies are seen in front of displayed FTX logo in this illustration taken November 10, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
The cryptocurrency lending unit of Digital Currency Group  has been in confidential negotiations with various creditor groups amid a liquidity crunch.

site_title: Crypto software company ConsenSys confirms 11% cut in workforce
summary: ConsenSys, a major Ethereum software company, has confirmed an 11% workforce reduction, eliminating 96 positions. The layoffs follow a wave of cuts at other major digital-asset companies, including Coinbase and Silvergate Capital. ConsenSys CEO Joseph Lubin attributed the cuts to the broader industry's reckoning and the need for conservative financial planning. The company completed a $450 million funding round in March, valuing it at over $7 billion. Lubin stated that the company will continue to fulfill its vision with the remaining resources.

site_title: US business inventories rise in November as sales fall
summary: US business inventories rose 0.4% in November, the highest level in nearly two years, due to depressed sales and a boosted inventory-to-sales ratio. This increase was in line with economists' expectations and marked a slowdown in inventory accumulation from the robust pace in late 2021 and early 2022. Business sales fell 0.8% in November, leading to a backlog of 1.35 months of unsold inventory, the longest since December 2020.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on April 08, 2022 Cars are seen on the assembly line during a tour of the Tesla Giga Texas manufacturing facility ahead of the "Cyber Rodeo" grand opening party on April 7, 2022 in Austin, Texas. - American factory growth sped up in May after slowing in the prior two months, even as employment contracted and firms continue to face supply challenges, according to a business survey released June 1, 2022. (Photo by SUZANNE CORDEIRO / AFP)

Shoppers are seen in a Kroger supermarket on October 14, 2022, in Atlanta, Georgia. - Economic prospects are becoming "more pessimistic" in the United States on growing worries of weaker demand, the Federal Reserve said in a report October 19, 2022, citing heightened inflation and rising interest rates. (Photo by Elijah Nouvelage / AFP)

site_title: Oil eases 1% as US recession worries offset China recovery hopes
summary: Oil prices fell 1% on Wednesday, reversing early gains, as US recession worries outweighed hopes for China's demand boost. Brent futures dropped to $84.98 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude fell to $79.48 a barrel. US Federal Reserve officials' hawkish comments sparked concerns about interest rate hikes, while retail sales and manufacturing production declined more than forecast, fueling recession fears. Despite China's lifting of Covid-19 curbs, analysts expect a drawdown in US crude stocks, providing some price support.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled US$1.46, or 1.7 per cent higher, to US$85.92 on Tuesday.
Antonio Guterres, UN Secretary-General, says: “We learnt last week that certain fossil fuel producers were fully aware in the 1970s that their core product was baking our planet.”

site_title: EU tourist stays neared pre-pandemic levels in 2022: Eurostat
summary: The European Union recorded 2.72 billion nights spent in tourist accommodation in 2022, a 5.6% decrease from 2019 levels but a 91.1% increase from 2020. Domestic travel recovered strongly, exceeding pre-pandemic levels by 0.7%, while international tourism was 12.6% below 2019. Countries like Denmark, the Netherlands, and Belgium saw significant increases, while Latvia and Slovakia recovered slowly. The World Tourism Organization expects international tourism to return to pre-pandemic levels in Europe and the Middle East in 2023.

site_title: Preparing for the worst as Amazon, Microsoft cut jobs
summary: Major tech companies, including Amazon and Microsoft, are cutting jobs in anticipation of a recession. Amazon is laying off the largest number of employees in its history, while Microsoft plans to reduce its workforce by 5%. Goldman Sachs is also cutting over 3,200 jobs, and several Wall Street banks are considering reducing bonus pools. Experts advise employees facing potential layoffs to be proactive, ask about their job status, and prepare for job hunting while maintaining transparency about their situation.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher after retail sales data
summary: Wall Street opened higher on Wednesday after retail sales data revealed a bigger-than-expected drop in December sales, supporting hopes of smaller interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve. The Nasdaq Composite gained 75.84 points, or 0.68%, to 11,170.95, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 37.64 points, or 0.11%, to 33,948.49. Gains in Tesla and Microsoft also contributed to the market's upward momentum.

images.alt_text: A trader works on the trading floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., January 5, 2023. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly

site_title: US economic activity tepid but prices seen easing: Federal Reserve
summary: The US economy showed lukewarm activity in recent weeks, with no significant growth expected in the months ahead. Despite this, selling prices have increased at a modest pace, and future price growth is expected to cool further. The Federal Reserve's latest "beige book" survey found that five districts experienced slight or moderate gains, while six reported no changes or slight declines. Consumer inflation slipped to 6.5% in December, but remains higher than the Fed's target, and employment growth was modest, with wage pressures remaining elevated.

images.alt_text: DUNWOODY, GA - NOVEMBER 25: Shoppers search for Black Friday deals in a Walmart on November 25, 2022 in Dunwoody, Georgia. Walmart opened at 6am on Black Friday for shoppers.   Jessica McGowan/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by Jessica McGowan / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: Confidence among US home builders up, NAHB says
summary: US single-family home builders' confidence improved for the first time in over a year, rising four points to 35 in January, according to the NAHB/Wells Fargo Housing Market index. This marks the end of a 12-month decline streak and suggests the housing slump may have reached its low point. NAHB chairman Jerry Konter expects a rebound in home building later in 2023 as builder sentiment continues to rise, with the index also showing improved expectations for future sales and buyer traffic.

images.alt_text: The average contract rate on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage fell by 19 basis points to 6.23 per cent for the week ended Jan 13

site_title: UK millionaire says rich people like him should be taxed more
summary: Phil White, a British millionaire, is among 200 "patriotic millionaires" urging governments to tax the rich more to bridge the wealth gap. In an interview at the World Economic Forum, White said he's willing to pay higher taxes to reduce inequalities, citing the surge in billionaire wealth and stagnant wages. The group, which includes actors and heirs, proposes taxing fortunes worth £4-5 million at a rate of 1-2% per year, arguing that philanthropy alone cannot solve the root of the problem.

images.alt_text: The cost of living crisis is now top of the agenda for those heading to the World Economic Forum at Davos.
Property owners in Singapore may need to brace for higher transaction and recurring taxes in the year ahead.

site_title: UK inflation eases for second straight month, signalling worst is over
summary: UK inflation eased for the second consecutive month in December 2022, with consumer prices rising 10.5% from the previous year, slower than the 10.7% gain in November. Economists are cautiously optimistic about an end to the Bank of England's tightening cycle, with some predicting a possible slowdown in interest rate rises. However, inflation remains five times higher than the government's target of 2%, and public sector workers are striking over stagnant wages. The Bank of England is set to make its next interest rate decision in February, with some predicting a possible 50-basis-point hike.

images.alt_text: Average earnings in Britain excluding bonuses were 6.4 per cent higher than a year previously – the biggest increase since record began in 2001.
The average cost of a home fell to £295,000 in November, down by £1,000 from the month before but £28,000 more than a year ago, the Office for National Statistics (ONS) said on Wednesday (Jan 18).
UK data shows that wage growth sped up in the three months to November, with employment also rising faster than expected.
Pay excluding bonuses rose by 6.4 per cent, the Office for National Statistics (ONS) said.

site_title: BT Podcast: HNWIs can have a profitable 2023
summary: High Net Worth Individuals (HNWIs) can navigate recessionary pressures in 2023 by employing strategies such as diversifying portfolios, reducing debt, and investing in sectors like technology and healthcare. According to Dr. Neo Teng Hwee, CIO of UOB Private Bank, these strategies can also be accessible to non-HNWIs, who can consider working with financial advisors to create a personalized investment plan. Market conditions will dictate the effectiveness of these strategies, and digital assets and family offices will continue to play a role in wealth management.

images.alt_text: Today's human resource function should be linked it to the company’s strategic agenda, says Dean Tong, managing director and head of group HR at UOB.

site_title: The market for global infrastructure initiatives
summary: Global infrastructure initiatives, such as China's Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) and the US-led Partnership for Global Infrastructure Investment (PGII), are competing to fill the infrastructure gap in developing countries. While competition can promote innovation, it also creates conflicts of interest and hinders cooperation on critical issues like sustainable development and decarbonization. Experts warn of the "infrastructure investment gap" estimated at US$26 trillion, with the Asian Development Bank predicting Asia alone will need US$26 trillion of infrastructure investments from 2016 to 2030. To address challenges, authorities and investors need evaluation tools like cost-benefit analysis to address environmental and social concerns and mitigate Nimby issues.

images.alt_text: Construction of the Luang Prabang Railway Bridge near Luang Prabang in Laos in 2018. This project is part of the Belt and Road Initiative.
A test train departs the Dekalur Station in Bandung, Indonesia, to inspect the Yah Wan High Speed Railway on Nov 16.

site_title:
Prospects for SME growth this year rest
on success of China’s reopening: OCBC
summary: Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) barely stayed in growth territory, with OCBC's latest quarterly index showing a decline to 50.2 in the fourth quarter of 2022. SMEs' prospects this year depend on China's reopening, with OCBC's head of global commercial banking Linus Goh stating that a successful reopening would have a significant influence on growth in the region. The existing Enterprise Sustainability Programme and Energy Efficiency Grant, launched in 2021 and 2022, need more time to see greater take-up.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
OCBC's SME Index report indicates positive readings in Q3 across all industries except for the Information, communications and technology (ICT) sector.

site_title: US manufacturing output tumbles in December
summary: US manufacturing output declined 1.3% in December, exceeding expectations, due to higher borrowing costs and a strong dollar. This drop, combined with a revised 1.1% decrease in November, indicates a loss of momentum in the manufacturing sector. The sector accounts for 11.3% of the US economy, and a softening in global demand is also hurting manufacturing.
