Higher interest rates are undercutting demand for goods, leading to a 0.7% fall in overall industrial production.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on April 08, 2022 Cars are seen on the assembly line during a tour of the Tesla Giga Texas manufacturing facility ahead of the "Cyber Rodeo" grand opening party on April 7, 2022 in Austin, Texas. - American factory growth sped up in May after slowing in the prior two months, even as employment contracted and firms continue to face supply challenges, according to a business survey released June 1, 2022. (Photo by SUZANNE CORDEIRO / AFP)

site_title: Watchdog wants review of S$72.3b in Covid-19 spending for any payment errors
summary: The Public Accounts Committee in Singapore is calling for a review of S$72.3 billion in Covid-19 spending to ensure there were no payment errors. Chairman Foo Mee Har stated that checks should be conducted to verify transactions and recover any losses. The review aims to ensure public funds were spent properly, given the unprecedented complexity of government operations during the pandemic.

images.alt_text: Singapore spent S$72.3 billion on Covid-19 in FY2020 and FY2021, less than budgeted

site_title: Golf action aplenty in 2023 as Singapore’s courses play host to top stars
summary: The Singapore Open, a national golf tournament, has been postponed to the second half of 2023 due to a congested calendar. The event, usually held in January, will feature top stars such as Ko Jin-young, Jordan Spieth, and Sergio Garcia. Meanwhile, other major golf events will take place in Singapore, including the HSBC Women's World Championship and the LIV Golf series, which will include Major champions like Cameron Smith and Phil Mickelson. The DP World Tour will also return to Singapore with the Singapore Classic, with a US$2 million prize purse.

images.alt_text: Asian Tour commissioner and CEO Cho Minn Thant: There will always be some turbulence when there is a shake-up in an industry, but these are exciting times and we're looking forward to what comes next."
Novak Djokovic in action at the Adelaide International earlier this week. His unvaccinated status means he will miss two top events in the US in March.

site_title: OxPay’s managing director to leave earlier following appointment of replacement
summary: OxPay Financial's managing director, Tan Chee Keong, will leave the company on Feb 1, five months earlier than planned. He had intended to "pursue other career opportunities". The company has appointed Koh Jin Kit, a former education and career guidance counsellor at the Ministry of Education, as his replacement. Tan's departure comes amid the company's ongoing efforts to grow its revenue and resolve wrongful dismissal claims against former executives.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
Oxpay is also working on collaborations with Visa, Mastercard and banks, in relation to enabling BNPL and lending platforms, and expects this to be launched in Q1 2023

site_title: Nurses in England stage new walkout over pay
summary: Nurses in England have begun a two-day strike over pay, adding to the pressure on the National Health Service (NHS) amid a surge in winter illnesses and lengthening waiting lists. The Royal College of Nursing (RCN) union accuses the government of failing to negotiate seriously on pay, despite a record-high inflation rate of 10.5% in December 2022. The strike threatens 4,500 cancelled operations and 25,000 cancelled outpatient appointments, with public sympathy for the nurses growing amid discontent over the government's NHS management.

images.alt_text: A sign regarding strike action outside Shortlands railway station, closed due to strike action by the National Union of Rail, Maritime and Transport, near Sevenoaks, UK, on Friday, Jan. 6, 2023. Britain is mired in industrial action with workers ranging from train drivers to nurses and border-control officials protesting against below-inflation pay offers. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg
Britain is experiencing a wave of industrial action as pay rises fail to keep up with double-digit inflation, which is now around 40-year highs.
Ambulance workers are set to strike on Wednesday, having walked out last month.

site_title: US mortgage interest rates fall to lowest levels since September
summary: US mortgage interest rates fell to 6.23% for the week ended Jan 13, the lowest level since September. This decline, 19 basis points, is attributed to evidence of inflation slowing, leading to a decrease in Treasury yields. The Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes have eased, with the central bank expected to slow its pace of rate hikes. This drop in mortgage rates has attracted more buyers, with the Mortgage Bankers Association's Market Composite Index rising 27.9% from the previous week.

site_title: US: Stocks pull back after buoyant start to 2023
summary: US stocks pulled back after a strong start to 2023, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropping 1.8% to 33,297.02. The S&P 500 fell 1.6% and the Nasdaq Composite declined 1.2%. Despite expectations of a pivot by the Federal Reserve, the reports on retail sales and wholesale prices showed lukewarm US economic activity, with five of 12 Fed districts reporting slight or modest gains. Consumer staples stocks were among the hardest hit, while biotech company Moderna rose 3.3% after positive trial results for its RSV vaccine.

images.alt_text: Business inventories rose 0.4 per cent after gaining 0.2 per cent in October, the Commerce Department said on Wednesday (Jan 18).
A trader works on the trading floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., January 5, 2023. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly

site_title: Boulevard 88 unit tops Q4 resale gains; seller reaps S$3.5m profit after 3 years
summary: A 2,799 sq ft unit at Boulevard 88 in District 10 was sold for S$13.78 million, earning the seller a profit of S$3.46 million (9% annualized return) in Q4 2022. This is the most profitable deal by quantum in the quarter, according to data from Cushman & Wakefield. The top five profit-making deals by percentage were in the Core Central Region, with sellers earning profits ranging from 69 to 189%. The largest loss-making resale deal by percentage was for a 657 sq ft unit at The Scotts Towers, with an annualized loss of 5.4%.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim

Boulevard 88 has a stunning architectural design by world-renowned Moshe Safdie and its two 28-storey residential towers, perched above The Singapore EDITION Hotel, offer unrivalled views of the surrounding and beyond.

site_title: Phuket leads Thai tourist hotspots battling labour shortage
summary: Phuket, a major tourist destination in Thailand, is facing a labor shortage of approximately 3,600 workers in the hospitality sector, threatening its goal of attracting 25 million tourists this year. Chiang Mai and Chonburi, other popular tourist spots, also face labor shortages, with Chiang Mai short of about 850 workers and Chonburi needing almost 600 more. The Thai government is taking measures to address the shortage, including supporting students to work part-time and providing training for hospitality and foreign language skills. The labor shortage may impact Thailand's economic recovery.

site_title: Job market still tight despite layoffs, EY CEO says
summary: EY CEO Carmine Di Sibio says the job market remains tight despite layoffs in the tech sector, which is coming after a period of intense hiring. EY is hiring about 220,000 people globally, with its consulting arm potentially delaying its public listing until early 2024. Despite this, Di Sibio notes that EY is not struggling to source talent, but rather, the market is still competitive.

site_title: Microsoft to cut 10,000 jobs as tech layoffs intensify
summary: Microsoft plans to cut 10,000 jobs, resulting in a $1.2 billion charge and a 12-cent negative impact on per-share profit in the second quarter of fiscal 2023. The layoffs come as cloud-computing customers reassess their spending and Microsoft prepares for potential recession. This move is part of the tech sector's broader trend of job cuts, following years of growth during the pandemic. The company's investment in generative artificial intelligence is seen as an industry bright spot, but the layoffs are still a significant blow to the company's workforce.

site_title: Integrate ESG reporting and accounting to align unlisted businesses, say corporate figures at Davos
summary: Business leaders at the World Economic Forum (WEF) in Davos are pushing for standardized reporting standards that integrate environmental, social, and corporate governance (ESG) data into audited accounts for all companies, not just listed ones. Private equity firms are also expected to play a key role in promoting these standards. Experts argue that this will help prevent greenwashing and ensure a level playing field. Companies must be prepared to report both financial and sustainability data, and smaller, unlisted businesses will need to adapt to these new standards.

images.alt_text: Joan Ng
Mangroves, nature, forest, water, river

Investors can look forward to growth in China's manufacturing sector, said Laura Cha (far left), chairman of Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing, at a panel discussion moderated by Francine Lacqua, editor-at-large and presenter at Bloomberg Television. Other panellists were, from left, Mario Centeno, governor of the central bank of Portugal; Axel Lehmann, chairman of Credit Suisse; and Douglas Peterson, president and CEO of S&P Global.

site_title: UBS chairman slams EU impasse over banking union
summary: UBS Group chairman Colm Kelleher criticized the European Union's failure to complete its banking union, saying Europe is losing competitiveness to the US banking system due to national barriers. The EU's effort to allow more banking services across the entire bloc is hindered, hindering mergers and acquisitions in the fragmented European banking sector. Kelleher emphasizes the need for a markets-based banking system to address the issue.

images.alt_text: The European Stoxx 600 closed 0.4 per cent higher, its strongest level since April 22, with miners and food and beverage stocks leading gains.

European Central Bank (ECB) President Christine Lagarde (C) speaks next to ECB vice president Luis de Guindos (L) and the Netherlands Bank (DNB) Klaas Knot (R) during a press conference after a Governing Council meeting focused on monetary policy in the euro zone in Amsterdam on June 9, 2022. (Photo by JOHN THYS / AFP)

Just under half of respondents said “moderate” (34.3 per cent) or “high” (14.6 per cent) when asked how much trust they had in Christine Lagarde and the board when it comes to leading and managing the ECB.

site_title: Yen lower as BOJ sticks to ultra-easy policy, losses trimmed
summary: The Japanese yen was weaker against major currencies on January 18, despite the Bank of Japan (BOJ) maintaining its ultra-easy policy, including keeping interest rates at -0.1% and the 10-year yield target at 0%. The BOJ's decision was seen as a surprise, as markets had expected a tightening of policy. Analysts believe the BOJ will likely adjust its policy in the coming months, which may have contributed to the yen's recovery from earlier losses.

images.alt_text: UK data shows that wage growth sped up in the three months to November, with employment also rising faster than expected.

site_title: UBS head says regulators’ ‘eyes off the ball’ on non-banks
summary: UBS chairman Colm Kelleher stated that traditional finance firms are "systemically safe" due to increased regulation, but regulators have "taken their eyes off the ball" in addressing risks posed by the non-banking sector. Kelleher warned that the recent cryptocurrency sector turmoil may return, and UBS is seeking a regulatory framework to accommodate it for clients.

site_title: StarHub named world’s most sustainable telco on Global 100 list
summary: StarHub, a Singaporean telecommunications company, has been ranked the world's most sustainable telecom provider by Corporate Knights' Global 100 rankings. The company jumped 38 spots to 34th place, ahead of Canada's Telus Corp, and received a "B" grade. StarHub achieved 10% renewable energy use through the procurement of renewable energy certificates and signed a virtual power-purchase agreement with Terrenus Energy to deepen its investment in clean energy. This is the first time Singaporean company Maxeon Solar Technologies has made the list, placing 69th.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting

Keppel’s chief executive officer Loh Chin Hua said on Saturday (Dec 10) the company is honoured to be included on the Dow Jones Sustainability indices this time round, having put sustainability at the core of its strategy as part of its 2030 vision.
For the 9-month period ending Sep 30, 2022, Starhub’s net profit was down 18.4 per cent on year to S$88.3 million, while its total revenue was 10.6 per cent higher, at S$1.6 billion.
While Singtel and StarHub both have very substantial and profitable consumer operations, margins on consumer services have been hit as a result of stiff competition.

site_title: US retail sales drop more than expected in December
summary: US retail sales dropped 1.1% in December, more than expected, due to a decline in motor vehicle purchases and lower prices for goods. Higher borrowing costs, as the Federal Reserve battles inflation, also weighed on sales. Excluding automobiles, gasoline, and other goods, core retail sales fell 0.7%, but economists expect growth in services spending to offset the decline. This puts consumer spending and the overall economy on a weaker growth path heading into 2023, with some economists predicting a recession by the second half of the year.

images.alt_text: Americans are spending less, creating tough conditions for retailers such as Bed Bath & Beyond

site_title: Most Chinese provinces set growth targets of above 5% in 2023
summary: China's most provinces set growth targets above 5% for 2023, with the country's two largest economies, Guangdong and Jiangsu, aiming for 5.5% and 5% GDP growth, respectively. Shanghai and Zhejiang province also set targets above 5%, while Beijing and Tianjin aim for lower growths. The relaxation of COVID restrictions has boosted expectations for an economic revival, but businesses face short-term pains from rising cases. China's economy is expected to rebound to 4.9% growth in 2023, according to a Reuters poll, with domestic demand seen as key driver for the economy.

images.alt_text: Chunxi Road shopping area in Chengdu, Sichuan province. Even with weaker GDP growth in 2022, China's reopening has spurred expectations for a strong 2023 rebound.
On a per person basis, consumption actually fell last year, according to data released on Tuesday (Jan 17) by the National Bureau of Statistics (NBS).

site_title: Taiwan presidential contender says he wants peace with China
summary: Taiwan Vice-President William Lai has pledged to maintain the peaceful status quo with China while defending Taiwan ahead of the 2024 presidential election. Lai, expected to be the Democratic Progressive Party's candidate, promised to protect Taiwan from China's threat while also seeking peace. He has not formally accepted the nomination, but his comments are likely to top the agenda with Beijing, which is ramping up pressure on Taiwan to accept Chinese sovereignty.

images.alt_text: China’s government warned on Tuesday it would take “forceful measures” if US House of Representatives Speaker Nancy Pelosi visited Taiwan, after the Financial Times said she would go to the Chinese-claimed island next month.
Taiwanese Vice President William Lai (C) attends the funeral of late former Japanese prime minister Shinzo Abe at the Zojoji Temple in Tokyo on July 12, 2022.

site_title: Media startup Semafor plans buyout of Sam Bankman-Fried’s investment
summary: Media startup Semafor plans to buy out Sam Bankman-Fried's $10 million investment in the company, citing a need to place the funds in a separate account until the relevant authorities provide guidance. The US Department of Justice accused Bankman-Fried of causing billions of dollars in losses related to FTX, a "fraud of epic proportions." Semafor's CEO Justin Smith stated the plan to repurchase Bankman-Fried's interest and return the funds, following a decision by ProPublica to return $1.6 million received from Bankman-Fried's family foundation.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Former FTX Chief Executive Sam Bankman-Fried, who faces fraud charges over the collapse of the bankrupt cryptocurrency exchange, leaves following a hearing at Manhattan federal court in New York City, U.S. January 3, 2023. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly/File Photo

site_title: Germany forecast to narrowly escape recession in 2023
summary: Germany is expected to narrowly avoid a recession in 2023 with a 0.2% price-adjusted growth, according to a draft economic report. The country's inflation forecast for 2023 is set to be revised down to 6.0%, with further easing to 2.8% in 2024, driven by falling energy prices. This contrasts with the government's previous forecast of a 0.4% decline in GDP for 2023.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The skyline with its office buildings and the banking district are photographed during sunset as the spread of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) continues and the German government plans new pandemic control measures in Frankfurt, Germany, November 18, 2021.  REUTERS/Kai Pfaffenbach/File Photo

site_title: Indonesia to break ground for US$2.7b housing project in new capital in Q2
summary: Indonesia is set to break ground on a US$2.7 billion housing project in its new capital city, Nusantara, in the second quarter of 2023. The project, part of a larger US$32 billion plan to move the capital from Jakarta, will provide apartments for 14,500 civil servants, military, and police personnel. Private developers, including China's CCFG Corp and South Korea's Korea Land and Housing, will build the 184 apartment towers under a public-private partnership. Construction is expected to start soon, with authorities aiming to relocate government administration and civil servants in 2024.

site_title: Sats shareholders vote in favour of Worldwide Flight Services deal
summary: Sats shareholders have voted in favour of the company's acquisition of Paris-based air cargo handler Worldwide Flight Services (WFS), with 96.8% of votes cast in support. The deal is expected to cost S$1.8 billion, with S$1.8 billion raised through a renounceable underwritten rights issue and S$700 million through a term loan. The acquisition is now subject to regulatory approvals and is expected to be completed by March or April this year.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
Sats' recent share price trajectory has been an accurate barometer of the financial implications of its proposed acquisition of WFS
The WFS acquisition will be a positive for shareholders, providing a pathway to profitable growth, says SATS.

site_title: Singapore second most preferred city in Apac for cross-border property investments in 2023: CBRE survey
summary: Singapore is the second most preferred destination for cross-border real estate investment in the Asia-Pacific, following Tokyo, according to CBRE's Asia-Pacific Investor Intentions Survey. The city-state's strong market fundamentals continue to attract core investors, while opportunistic strategies are predicted to gain momentum this year, driven by price dislocation and distressed opportunities. The industrial and logistics sector remains the most preferred, with office and residential sectors also gaining traction, and 60% of investors expect to find discounts in retail and Grade A offices.

images.alt_text: Singapore is third most preferred destination in Apac for cross-border real estate investment in 2022: CBRE
CBRE appoints Luke Moffat as new Asia-Pacific head of advisory and transaction services
Hong Kong-listed Link Reit won the race to acquire Jurong Point and Swing By @ Thomson Plaza for S$2.16 billion.

site_title: All eyes on Germany when defence leaders meet on arming Ukraine
summary: Germany's defence leaders will meet on Friday to discuss arming Ukraine, with a focus on whether to send Leopard battle tanks. The US has committed $24 billion to Ukraine's defence, but Germany has not yet agreed to send tanks or allowed other countries to send their own German-made tanks. Eastern European officials have urged Germany to take the lead, while Britain has announced it will send tanks to Ukraine. The meeting comes as US President Joe Biden faces pressure to ask European allies to do more to support Ukraine.

images.alt_text: Boris Pistorius, who has been interior minister of Germany's Lower Saxony region since 2013, will be appointed to the role of defence minister on Thursday.
The 57-year-old Lambrecht came under scrutiny over a perceived lack of military expertise.

site_title: Deloitte hopes Budget 2023 will include re-evaluation of Singapore’s tax incentives
summary: Deloitte has released its Budget 2023 wish list, which includes a re-evaluation of Singapore's tax incentives and policies to accelerate the country's green transition. The firm suggests a minimum tax rate of 15% for multinational entities under Pillar Two of the Base Erosion and Profit Shifting (BEPS) initiative, but advises waiting for international consensus on implementation options. Deloitte also proposes extending the application deadline for the Enterprise Financing Scheme-Green and investing in green skills to create "good green jobs."

images.alt_text: Sharon See

EY’s Singapore head of tax Soh Pui Ming said: "While the pandemic is behind us, Singapore continues to face a highly volatile and uncertain global environment. Hence, we should stay focused as a nation and prime ourselves for any potential challenges and upcoming opportunities."
KMPG also called for targeted grants for some GST-registered businesses to address concerns over higher costs from complying with the rate hikes.
BEPS 2.0 unlikely to hurt competitiveness, may net Singapore gains in tax revenue

site_title: UK house prices slip from record after mortgage rates jump
summary: UK house prices fell to £295,000 in November, down £1,000 from the previous month and £28,000 from a year ago. This marks the longest slump in four months since 2008, as mortgage rates have jumped and households hold onto cash due to the cost-of-living crunch. House prices rose 10.3% in the year to November, slower than the 12.4% pace in October. Economists predict a further decline in prices this year, with predictions ranging from 5% to 10% fall.

images.alt_text: A street of terraced houses in York, UK, on Friday, Jan. 6, 2023. House prices in York and Woking saw the biggest increases according to a recent report from Halifax building society. Photographer: Ian Forsyth/Bloomberg

site_title: Worst impact of global monetary policy tightening could still be ahead: StanChart global research head
summary: Standard Chartered's global head of research Eric Robertsen warns that the worst impact of global monetary policy tightening may still be ahead, despite narrowing credit spreads. He fears structural damage to the economy, with companies and individuals potentially forced to declare bankruptcy. However, Robertsen notes that emerging markets like South-east Asia are expected to experience 5% growth in 2023, and China may outperform expectations in the next 12-18 months, with a stabilizing economy in the first quarter and improving growth from the second quarter.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
Some 18 per cent considered a world recession “extremely likely” in World Economic Forum (WEF) survey, more than twice as many as in the previous survey conducted in September 2022.
Asean held up valiantly in 2022 as the COVID-19 pandemic lingered and the Russia-Ukraine conflict led to a supply shock
China is expected to grow 5.2 per cent this year, while the US could see a 1.4 per cent expansion, “well above consensus expectations for a 0.3 per cent growth and a technical recession”.

site_title: UN chief slams oil firms for ‘big lie’ on global warming
summary: UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres accused oil firms of peddling a "big lie" about their role in global warming, warning they should be held accountable. In a statement at the World Economic Forum, Guterres said fossil fuel producers were aware in the 1970s that their products were causing global warming. This comes after a study found ExxonMobil's scientists had predicted global warming with "shocking accuracy" but the company denied it for decades. Guterres compared the oil industry's actions to the tobacco industry, calling for those responsible to be held accountable.

site_title: Yellen, Liu agree to enhance communication after ‘frank exchange’
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen and Chinese Vice Premier Liu He agreed to enhance communication on macroeconomic and financial issues during a two-and-a-half hour meeting in Zurich. They pledged to cooperate on climate finance on a bilateral and multilateral basis, and Yellen looks forward to traveling to China soon. The meeting was described as "candid, substantive, and constructive," with both sides agreeing that serious communication and coordination are needed to maintain stability in their bilateral economic and financial relationship.

images.alt_text: Chinese Vice-Premier Liu He and US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen conducted extensive exchanges on the macroeconomic situation and bilateral and multilateral cooperation
Janet Yellen’s travel to Senegal, Zambia and South Africa from Wednesday onwards comes after a detour to Switzerland where she is set to meet Chinese Vice Premier Liu He on macroeconomic issues.
The tariffs make Chinese imports more expensive for US companies, which, in turn, make products cost more for consumers.

site_title: Tycoon says Singapore wants green fuel, not giant power cable
summary: Australian billionaire Andrew Forrest says plans to supply Singapore with clean electricity via a 4,200 km-long cable are no longer feasible due to uncertainty over demand and costs spiralling. The project, valued at A$30 billion, was initiated by Sun Cable but entered voluntary administration amid investor disputes. Forrest sees an opportunity to export green fuels to Singapore instead, citing a more viable alternative to the electricity supply plan.

images.alt_text: The proposal for Singapore to draw critical energy supply from a source some 4,200 KM away through an undersea cable was deemed a hard sell from the get-go by market watchers.
The proposal for Singapore to draw critical energy supply from a source some 4,200 KM away through an undersea cable was deemed a hard sell from the get-go by market watchers.
Rendering of the Sun Cable project. Source: Sun Cable Pty Ltd.

site_title: Vietnam market risks missing 2025 deadline for upgrade to emerging status
summary: Vietnam risks missing its 2025 deadline to upgrade its stock market to emerging economy status due to infighting between state institutions over key reforms. The main bourse, the Ho Chi Minh City Stock Exchange, is the smallest among major South-east Asian economies, with a market capitalization of around $180 billion. Reforms needed to upgrade Vietnam's stock market include settling trades and increasing foreign ownership, but progress has been slow due to disagreements among officials. The delay could result in a loss of potential investments worth around $5 billion.

images.alt_text:
FILE PHOTO: A worker applies the finishing touches to the trading floor of communist Vietnam's first stock exchange July 18, two days ahead of its official opening in Ho Chi Minh City, the country's main commercial centre.

RD/HL/File Photo

site_title: Luxury eyes focused on China after Richemont’s Q3 sales miss
summary: Richemont, the parent company of luxury brands Cartier and IWC, missed market forecasts in its latest quarter due to a resurgence of Covid-19 in China, where sales plummeted by nearly a quarter. The company's sales in mainland China, which accounts for about a fifth of its total sales, struggled with a 24% decline in constant currency terms. However, analysts believe the impact will be temporary, as Chinese consumers are expected to make a strong rebound before the Lunar New Year holidays.

images.alt_text: Local economies are ramping up efforts to revive the Covid-hit services sector as frequent and stringent lockdowns and restrictions kept shoppers at home and disrupted consumption activity.
Chunxi Road shopping area in Chengdu, Sichuan province. Even with weaker GDP growth in 2022, China's reopening has spurred expectations for a strong 2023 rebound.
On a per person basis, consumption actually fell last year, according to data released on Tuesday (Jan 17) by the National Bureau of Statistics (NBS).

site_title: Anthony Bourdain had the idea. How did this street-food market turn out?
summary: Anthony Bourdain's concept for Urban Hawker, a Singaporean street food market in Midtown Manhattan, has been revived by KF Seetoh after the chef's death in 2018. The market features 17 Asian vendors, including some relocated from Singapore, offering a range of Singaporean classics and lesser-known dishes. While the market preserves the cooks and their origins, some dishes lack authenticity, with ingredients and flavors not entirely representative of their Singaporean counterparts. Despite this, Urban Hawker remains a fascinating window into Singaporean culture, showcasing the diversity and complexity of the country's food scene.

images.alt_text: Patrons dine at Urban Hawker in New York, Jan. 9, 2023. With its stalls selling Singaporean classics both famous and obscure, Urban Hawker is unlike any other food court in Midtown Manhattan. (Rachel Vanni/The New York Times)

site_title: Thai supermarket chain picks banks for US$1b IPO
summary: Big C Supercenter, a Thai supermarket chain, has selected Bank of America and UBS to assist with a planned $1 billion initial public offering (IPO) in Bangkok. The company has also chosen four local banks for the potential first-time share sale. The IPO could happen as soon as this year, pending ongoing deliberations. This deal would be Thailand's largest IPO since Thai Life Insurance's $1.02 billion listing in July 2022, and would boost the country's IPO market, which saw $4.1 billion worth of deals in 2022.

images.alt_text: Chinese electric vehicle start-up Nio was amongst those who led large IPOs issuance last year.
Singapore, Malaysia, Thailand, Indonesia and the Philippines collectively saw 149 IPO listings in 2022, versus 132 recorded in 2021.
Temasek fully owns Singapore Technologies Telemedia, the parent of STT GDC.

site_title: Over 1,900 firms receive Progressive Wage Mark accreditation
summary: Over 1,900 firms in Singapore have been accredited with the Progressive Wage Mark or PW Mark Plus since the scheme's launch in December 2022, aiming to encourage consumers to support lower-wage workers. The accreditation recognizes businesses that pay progressive wages to lower-wage workers, and is part of a range of measures to uplift the lower-wage workforce. The scheme is expected to cover 94% of the lower-wage workforce, with 76,000 firms eligible and 14 firms already accredited with the PW Mark Plus.

images.alt_text: The refreshed Environmental Services ITM 2025 seeks to harness opportunities in environmental sustainability.
Singapore has made clear its stand that platform workers aren't employees, but also hasn't said that they would be classified as independent contractors.
In addition to easing manpower shortages by filling lower-wage roles, foreign talent are also sought after to take up top positions and transfer knowledge and resources to Singaporeans.

site_title: Supporting our future generations
summary: Standard Chartered Bank has partnered with Temasek Trust, the Ministry of Social and Family Development (MSF), and Awwa to support children and families in need through the Grant-A-Wish initiative. The program provided gifts to over 500 children from less privileged backgrounds during the festive season. The partnership aims to promote social and emotional well-being, and has also launched the Family Empowerment Programme (FEP), which provides direct cash assistance to 75 families to meet their immediate needs. The FEP is funded via a Pay-For-Success model, ensuring that funds are used to achieve positive outcomes.

images.alt_text: Over 360 volunteers gathered to pack and distribute the National Day care pack from early July to August.
The festive bags, or fu dais, are packed by more than 1,300 volunteers over two days.
The Awwa School students, aged 15-16, were introduced to various job roles at the bank’s newly revamped flagship branch at Six Battery Road, such as that of a sales and services manager.

site_title: Pfizer to sell more drugs at cost to poor nations
summary: US pharmaceutical giant Pfizer announced it will expand its not-for-profit sales of medicines and vaccines to 45 low-income nations, offering around 500 products, including off-patent medicines. This move is part of "An Accord for a Healthier World" initiative, aiming to address the "disease burden and unmet patient needs" of 1.2 billion people. Pfizer's CEO hopes the expansion will help achieve a world where all people have access to necessary medicines and vaccines, reducing the health equity gap.

images.alt_text: Pfizer chief executive Albert Bourla said that talks with China on future pricing for antiviral drug Paxlovid had broken off after China had asked for a lower price than Pfizer is charging for most lower middle income countries.

site_title: Dispute resolution clause key when seeking recourse from failed crypto entities, say lawyers
summary: Cryptocurrency investors should review the dispute resolution clause before investing to protect themselves in case of an insolvency, according to lawyers. FTX, one of the largest cryptocurrency exchanges, owed $3.1 billion to its top 50 creditors when it filed for bankruptcy in November 2022. Investors who failed to secure their claims may only recover a small percentage of their investment. Lawyers recommend scrutinizing the fine print, including the terms and conditions, to avoid additional costs and jurisdiction issues in the event of insolvency.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting

Some US$323 million in crypto had been hacked from FTX’s international exchange and US$90 million had been hacked from its US exchange since it filed for bankruptcy on Nov 11, CEO John Ray said in a separate statement on Tuesday.
DCG’s crypto lending unit Genesis stopped reimbursements in November.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore-listed real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) such as CapitaLand Ascott Trust are expected to benefit from the return of Chinese tourists. S-Reits will release their financial results for the period ending December 2022, with asset valuations and capital management strategies under scrutiny. The release of these results marks a significant period for the industry, with many anticipating a boost from the expected influx of Chinese tourists.

site_title: Malaysia’s December exports up 6%, missing forecasts; trade surplus narrows to RM27.8b
summary: Malaysia's December exports grew 6% year-on-year to RM131.9 billion, missing forecasts of 9% growth, while imports rose 12% to RM104.1 billion. The trade surplus narrowed to RM27.8 billion, down 12% year-on-year. Despite slower growth, Malaysia's total trade in 2022 reached a new milestone of RM2.8 trillion, the fastest growth since 1994. The country's exports to major trading partners, including Asean and China, reached new record highs in 2022.

images.alt_text: Malaysian central bank’s monetary policy and the government’s implementation of targeted subsidies this year will affect consumers spending power.

site_title: Ukraine's interior minister among 16 dead in helicopter crash
summary: Ukraine's Interior Minister Denys Monastyrsky, responsible for police and security, was among 16 people killed in a helicopter crash in a suburb of Kyiv on January 18. The crash also claimed the lives of senior officials, including Monastyrsky's deputy, and injured 10 others, including two children. The cause of the crash is unknown, and Russia, which invaded Ukraine in February, has not commented. Monastyrsky's death marks the most senior Ukrainian official to die since the war began.

images.alt_text: A Ukrainian tank fires at Russian positions near Kreminna, Lugansk region, on Jan 12, 2023.

site_title: Carmaker Stellantis strikes nickel sulphate supply deal with Terrafame
summary: Stellantis, the world's third-largest automotive group, has struck a five-year deal with Finnish company Terrafame to supply nickel sulphate, a key raw material for electric vehicle battery packs, starting from 2025. The agreement aims to cover a significant portion of Stellantis' sustainable regionally sourced nickel needs. The move is part of the carmaker's goal to have 100% of its European passenger car sales and 50% of its US passenger car and light-duty truck sales be battery electric vehicles by 2030.

site_title: More than 500 advertisers have paused spending on Twitter
summary: More than 500 Twitter advertisers have paused spending on the platform since Elon Musk took over last October, citing concerns over layoffs and a paid verification feature that led to scammers impersonating companies. This drop in revenue has resulted in a 40% decline in Twitter's daily revenue compared to the same period last year. The social media platform has recently reversed its ban on political ads and relaxed advertising policies for "cause-based ads" in the US.

site_title: COE premiums up for cars and motorbikes, but price of Open COE slips
summary: COE premiums rebounded in the latest tender, with car premiums up 7.5% to S$86,000 and larger cars up 3.4% to S$105,459. However, the Open COE premium dipped 0.8% to S$107,000. Industry watchers expect lower confidence in upcoming tenders, with underlying demand set to dip further, and the next three-month quota expected to be slightly larger.

images.alt_text: The COE price for cars with engines up to 1,600cc and 130bhp, as well as electric vehicles (EVs) with up to 110 kilowatts of power, ended at S$80,000, which is 9.1 per cent below the S$88,007 recorded two weeks ago in December.

site_title: Chipmaker Black Sesame considers US$200m Hong Kong IPO
summary: Black Sesame Technologies, a developer of AI chips, is considering a Hong Kong IPO worth around US$200 million. The Xiaomi-backed firm is working with China International Capital and Huatai International on the IPO preparations. This move comes as China pauses its massive investments in building a chip industry to rival the US, with policymakers seeking alternative ways to support homegrown chip firms. Black Sesame, founded in 2016, focuses on AI technologies for image processing and system-on-a-chip design, and has already raised over US$500 million in funding.

site_title: Japan yields tumble to well below policy cap as BOJ stands pat
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) kept its yield curve control policy unchanged at its Wednesday meeting, defying market expectations. Japanese government bond yields plummeted to 0.36% after the decision, the largest one-day decline in two decades. The BOJ also announced a new policy tool, offering five-year loans to financial institutions to enhance liquidity. The yen retreated 2.6% and the Nikkei 225 share average rose 2.5% in response to the decision, which was seen as a test of the BOJ's resolve to keep yields low.

images.alt_text: THE Bank of Japan on Wednesday maintained ultra-low interest rates, including its 0.5 per cent cap for the 10-year bond yield, defying market expectations.

site_title: Injured champion Nadal crashes out of Australian Open
summary: Tennis champion Rafael Nadal crashed out of the Australian Open in the second round after aggravating a hip problem during a 6-4, 6-4, 7-5 loss to Mackenzie McDonald. The injury, which had been bothering him for a couple of days, forced Nadal to withdraw from the match. The loss shakes up the men's draw and puts Novak Djokovic in a position to draw level with Nadal's 22 major championships if he wins the tournament.

images.alt_text: Nadal says his involvement in the hotel chain did not mean he was ending his sporting career.

site_title: Chinese restaurants hold on to tradition
summary: Singapore's oldest Chinese restaurants, such as Cheng Hoo Thian, are holding on to traditional heritage cooking despite the unpredictable food and beverage industry. Owners are aging, and the next generation is not always willing to take over, but they plan to continue for as long as possible. Meanwhile, Chinese New Year festivities bring a surge in demand for traditional Cantonese food, and modern restaurants like Jia He Grand offer a taste of modern Cantonese cooking.

site_title: China’s property sector shrinks 5.1% in 2022: NBS
summary: China's property sector contracted 5.1% in 2022, the lowest annual decline since 1999, according to the National Bureau of Statistics. This marks one of the biggest drags on the economy last year, contributing to China's economic growth slump to a 50-year low. Authorities have implemented policies to support homebuyers and property developers, but investment in real estate remains 10% lower than in 2021. The sector is seen as a key pillar of the economy, and policymakers vow to promote completion and financing for property firms.

images.alt_text: To boost economic growth, China needs a sustained effort to generate domestic demand. Getting folks moving around again is a definite plus, but unlikely to be sufficient
Hong Kong’s real estate companies were cautious about putting projects up for sale in 2022 as home prices retreated.

site_title: Coinbase stops Japan operations after slump in digital assets
summary: Coinbase is halting operations in Japan due to market conditions, with customers having until February 16 to withdraw fiat and crypto holdings. The company plans to convert any remaining crypto held after February 17 to yen and send any remaining cash to a guaranty account. This move follows the firm's decision to cut 20% of its workforce globally and comes as Japan loosens some crypto rules, despite Coinbase previously partnering with a local player to launch a crypto exchange in 2021. The company aims to make the transition "as smooth as possible" for its clients.

images.alt_text: Coinbase employees spray champagne during the company's initial public offering (IPO) outside the Nasdaq MarketSite in New York, U.S., on Wednesday, April 14, 2021. Coinbase Global Inc., the largest U.S. cryptocurrency exchange, is set to debut on Wednesday through a direct listing, an alternative to a traditional initial public offering that has only been deployed a handful of times. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

site_title: CapitaLand India Trust to acquire IT park in Bangalore for 12.3b rupees
summary: CapitaLand India Trust has entered into a forward purchase agreement to acquire a 1 million sq ft IT park in Bangalore, India for 12.3 billion rupees (S$201 million). The project complements an existing portfolio in Bangalore and comprises two buildings with a total net leasable area of 1.5 million sq ft. The trustee-manager plans to fund the development and acquire a net leasable area of 1 million sq ft, retaining the remaining area for the landowners.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
Hospitality S-Reits such as CapitaLand Ascott Trust are expected to ride on the tailwinds of the return of Chinese tourists.

site_title: Yield on latest 6-month Singapore T-bill falls to 4%
summary: Singapore's latest six-month Treasury bill closed with a cut-off yield of 4% on January 18, marking a potential peak after staying at elevated levels amid US Federal Reserve interest rate hikes. The T-bills were 2.6 times subscribed for the S$5 billion allotment, with non-competitive bids totaling S$1.4 billion and fully allotted. Market participants expect the Fed to end the hike cycle, leading to stabilizing T-bill demand.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
While bond yields are up, investors should bear in mind that interest rates are rising because central banks worldwide are trying to tame inflation.
The total value of applications in this auction is S$12 billion, up from S$11.8 billion in the last auction in 2022.

site_title: Biden, Kishida held ‘very productive’ talks on China export controls
summary: US President Joe Biden and Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida held "very productive" talks on China export controls, including semiconductor-related measures to slow Beijing's technological and military advances. The Biden administration has not yet convinced key allies Japan and the Netherlands to implement similar equipment curbs. The consultations, which include industry coordination, are expected to yield progress in coming weeks, according to officials.

images.alt_text: Mostly sidelined by the Trump administration, the agency’s Loan Programs Office has been revived under President Joe Biden and armed with more money following the passage last year of the country’s landmark climate law.
Japan's core machinery orders fell 8.3 per cent in November from the previous month, government data showed on Wednesday.

site_title: George Santos is the congressman America deserves
summary: US Congressman George Santos is facing calls to resign due to numerous lies about his biography, including claims of being a volleyball star and Jewish heritage. Despite these falsehoods, Santos won his election by a significant margin, reflecting a broader wave of discontent in the Democrat-dominated state of New York. The article argues that Santos' lies are a symptom of a larger problem of misinformation in American politics, with politicians often prioritizing power over veracity. The article concludes that Santos' presence in Congress is a national disgrace, highlighting the need for leaders to demonstrate virtue and honesty in their actions.

images.alt_text: FILE — Rep. George Santos (R-N.Y.) is surrounded by reporters as he walks through the U.S. Capitol building, in Washington on Jan. 6, 2023. Santos, who was sworn into Congress last week, is facing calls to resign by several Republican House colleagues. (Kenny Holston/The New York Times)

site_title: China lets Marvel movies back in, sets dates for Black Panther, Ant-Man sequels
summary: China has lifted its ban on Marvel movies, allowing Walt Disney's Marvel Studios films to return to its cinemas. The first movies to be released in China are "Black Panther: Wakanda Forever" on February 7 and "Ant-Man and the Wasp: Quantumania" on February 17. This marks the first time Marvel films have played in China in nearly four years, resulting in significant lost revenue for Disney, estimated to be tens of millions of dollars. The decision is seen as a significant win for Disney, allowing it to regain a major market share.

images.alt_text: Zoa will triple its marketing spending this year in order to get its name in front of consumers with ad campaigns rolling out through the year, Dwayne Johnson said in an interview.

site_title: China’s reopening spurs optimism, but brace for a choppy ride
summary: China's domestic consumption is expected to pick up, but the recovery may take time due to challenges such as a surge in Covid infections and a declining demographic. Despite a 3% GDP growth in 2022, the country's growth is slower than the government's target of 5.5%. Economists have upgraded their GDP forecasts to over 5% for 2023, driven by policymakers' focus on boosting consumption and investment. However, the country faces long-term pressures, including an ageing population and debt in the property market.

site_title: BOJ crafts new weapon to defend yield control policy
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) has amended its rules for a funds-supply market operation to make it a tool for preventing long-term interest rates from rising too much. The change allows for both fixed-rate and variable-rate loans with terms of up to 10 years, enabling the central bank to control the yield curve. The BOJ will offer five-year loans starting January 24, 2023, with a duration until January 24, 2028, to maintain its yield curve control policy of a 0.5% cap on the 10-year bond yield.

images.alt_text: THE Bank of Japan on Wednesday maintained ultra-low interest rates, including its 0.5 per cent cap for the 10-year bond yield, defying market expectations.

site_title: M&A firm aims to link up Japan investors with Singapore SMEs seeking successors
summary: Nihon M&A Center Singapore, a boutique deal advisory firm, aims to connect Japanese investors with Singapore small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) seeking successors. The firm, established in 2016, has closed 11 deals so far, primarily involving mid-size Japanese companies with revenue between S$100 million and S$1 billion. The Singapore market is considered less mature for succession planning compared to Japan, where a rapidly aging population has driven more family-run businesses to seek M&A services. Nihon M&A Center Singapore seeks to fill the gap in connecting Japanese buyers to potential targets in South-east Asia.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim

Elderly people at a day care facility. As the country’s birthrate has plummeted and its population has grown older, nearly 60 per cent of the country’s businesses report that they have no plan for what comes next.
Industry players and market watchers said rising inflation, rental costs and the ongoing manpower crunch are pushing some F&B players to exit the market or seek out strategic partners for support.

site_title: India’s population has already overtaken China’s, analysts estimate
summary: India's population has surpassed China's, with estimates suggesting 1.417 billion people as of end-2022, surpassing China's 1.412 billion. This milestone underscores the need for Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi to create jobs and sustain the country's world-beating growth. With half the population under 30, India is poised to become the world's fastest-growing major economy in the coming years.

images.alt_text: China's birth rate was 6.77 births per 1,000 people last year, down from a rate of 7.52 births in 2021 and marking the lowest birth rate on record.

site_title: Hong Kong home sales to surge 50% as rates peak, border reopens
summary: Hong Kong's new home sales are expected to surge 50% in 2023, reaching HK$175 billion, due to the reopening of the border with mainland China and interest-rate increases ending. This forecast from Bloomberg Intelligence comes after a 9-year low in new home sales in the past year. Property developers are already seeing homes being sold at an accelerated pace, with transactions and inquiries increasing. The city's real estate market is expected to recover after a population exodus and recent government policies aimed at attracting talent.

images.alt_text: “There's a lot of room in this region... to continue to build a portfolio," says George Hongchoy, CEO of the manager of Hong Kong's Link Reit.

site_title: Anwar’s visit to S’pore will set stage for ‘significant progress’ in longstanding bilateral issues: Vivian
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim is set to visit Singapore by the end of January, marking his first visit to the country since taking office in November. The visit aims to resolve longstanding bilateral issues, including connectivity and outstanding issues, with Singapore Foreign Minister Vivian Balakrishnan stating it will set the stage for "significant progress." The two countries also plan to discuss new areas of collaboration, such as the digital and green economies, to reduce climate change and lessen carbon footprints.

images.alt_text: When the 4km rail shuttle service is ready, it will take five minutes to travel from Woodlands to Johor Bahru and vice versa.
The International Court of Justice in 2008 awarded sovereignty over Pedra Branca to Singapore.
Given the weaker-than-expected December NODX print, Singapore's key exports are expected to contract further in the coming months, according to private-sector economists.
Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim is expected to present the new spending plan for 2023 on February 24 next year.

site_title: Southpoint office units sold for S$3,000 psf
summary: Savills brokers the sale of approximately 10,893 sq ft of office space at Southpoint in Tanjong Pagar for S$32.7 million, translating to S$3,000 per sq ft, the highest record psf for the property. The sale consists of three adjoining units on the 11th floor.

images.alt_text: Levels 10 and 11 of the freehold Southpoint are changing hands for S$2,444 psf.

site_title: All eyes on asset valuations, capital management strategies as S-Reits gear up for FY results
summary: Singapore-listed real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) are gearing up to release their financial results for the period ending December 2022, amid hopes of a Reit revival due to China's reopening. However, investors will be cautious of challenges in capital management, including asset valuations, aggregate leverage, and funding costs. Hospitality S-Reits are expected to benefit from the return of Chinese tourists, while retail S-Reits are expected to reap the benefits of "revenge travelling" and "revenge spending". Investors will also be watching the office subsector, which may be moderated by a slowdown in office leasing demand.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
DBS has cut the target price of Manulife US Reit, which is currently undergoing a strategic review, by 31 per cent.
CDL Hospitality Trusts, whose portfolio includes W Singapore at Sentosa Cove, was the top performing S-Reit in 2022.
Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) posted a 2.8 per cent decline in distributable income for the second half ended September.

site_title: China fixed-asset investment approvals almost doubled in 2022 to 1.48t yuan
summary: China's state planner approved fixed asset investment projects worth 1.48 trillion yuan in 2022, nearly doubling the value from the previous year. This aims to support the Covid-hit economy, which saw a 3% GDP growth, missing the official target. For 2023, the economic recovery remains complicated due to shrinking demand, supply-chain shocks, and global economic turbulence. The National Development and Reform Commission plans to increase investment in advanced manufacturing, services, and new technologies to drive growth. Domestic demand is expected to slowly recover, but economists predict a bumpy transition period.

images.alt_text: China's property sector was one of the biggest drags on the economy last year.

site_title: China’s growth relies on consumers still too cautious to spend
summary: China's economic growth relies on consumers spending again, as a year of cautious spending led to a 3% growth rate in 2022, driven primarily by investment. Consumption on a per person basis fell for the first time in years, with households saving more and adding a record 17.8 trillion yuan to bank deposits. Policymakers will need to encourage consumers to spend to achieve stronger growth, reversing a trend where consumption was the fastest-growing component of demand for most of the last decade.

images.alt_text: Chunxi Road shopping area in Chengdu, Sichuan province. Even with weaker GDP growth in 2022, China's reopening has spurred expectations for a strong 2023 rebound.
China has been stepping up spending on infrastructure projects to prop up economic growth.
China's property sector was one of the biggest drags on the economy last year.

site_title: Qantas flight lands at Sydney after mid-air mayday alert
summary: A Qantas Boeing 737-800 plane, QF144, issued a mid-air mayday alert after experiencing issues with one engine while flying from Auckland to Sydney. The plane landed safely at Sydney airport, and paramedics were on standby due to the emergency activation plans. The aircraft, carrying over 100 passengers, appeared to have encountered a problem with one of its twin engines. The mayday call indicated a grave and imminent danger, prompting immediate assistance from authorities.

images.alt_text: United shares rose 4 per cent to US$53.22 in extended trading.

Around 20 regional Asian airlines have been unable to restart or increase services to Hong Kong despite months of negotiations with ground handling services, five airline executives told AFP, asking not to be named.

site_title: Apple postpones AR glasses, plans cheaper mixed-reality headset
summary: Apple has postponed its plans to release lightweight augmented-reality (AR) glasses due to technical challenges, instead opting to unveil a lower-cost mixed-reality headset in 2024 or early 2025. The initial mixed-reality headset, set to debut this year, will cost around $3,000, while the follow-up device will aim to lower the price to around $1,500, comparable to Meta's mixed-reality headset. Apple's AR glasses, once planned for release around 2025, have been put on hold indefinitely.

images.alt_text: Apple MacBook Pro models seen in a promotional picture.

site_title: Buoyant markets need to keep an eye on four risk factors
summary: Financial markets have started 2023 on a buoyant note, driven by stronger global growth prospects, falling inflation, and less hawkish central banks. However, four key factors require close monitoring: China's Covid-19 situation, which may impact supply and demand; US growth prospects, which are being accompanied by a depletion of savings and increase in indebtedness; the transition of inflationary pressures to the service sector; and the potential for central banks to cut rates later this year, driven by recession concerns. Investors should be cautious and not extrapolate the favorable driving forces, as there is still uncertainty about the world's growth, inflation, and policy prospects.

images.alt_text: Heightened volatility could continue across asset classes, but with this comes opportunities for active management.
The US dollar index rose 0.2 per cent to 103.45 against a basket of currencies including the euro.

site_title: Staff shortages dent Hong Kong air hub reboot hopes
summary: Around 20 regional Asian airlines have struggled to restart or increase services to Hong Kong due to staff shortages at the airport, hindering the city's plan to regain its status as a travel hub. Hong Kong's airport, once one of the globe's busiest, experienced a decline in air traffic during the COVID-19 pandemic. Months of negotiations with ground handling services have failed to resolve the issue, casting doubt on the city's efforts to recapture its former status.

images.alt_text: Airfares from China are now 160 per cent higher than before the pandemic, data from travel firm ForwardKeys shows, due to limited supply.

epa10406190 Passengers prepare to board a train bound for Jilin province at the Beijing Railway Station, in Beijing, China, 14 January 2023 (issued 15 January 2023). China has reported 60,000 deaths related to COVID-19 from 08 December to 12 January, the first major data released after China stopped reporting cases. A Chinese epidemiologist has warned that cases are expected to surge over the Lunar New Year celebrations as millions are expected to travel to their hometown for the first time since the pandemic began.  EPA-EFE/MARK R. CRISTINO

site_title: China’s Covid deaths expected to hit 36,000 a day during holiday
summary: China is expected to see 36,000 Covid deaths a day during the Chinese New Year holidays, surpassing previous estimates, according to Airfinity's revised analysis. This makes it one of the deadliest periods of the pandemic, with cumulative deaths estimated at 608,000 since December. The forecast suggests a prolonged and severe outbreak, fueled by the holiday's high levels of virus transmission, and a significant burden on China's healthcare system.

images.alt_text: Since the start of the pandemic, China has drawn heavy criticism for not being transparent over the virus.

site_title: Asia:  Most markets rise on recovery hopes
summary: Asian markets rose on Wednesday, driven by hopes for China's recovery and improved inflation outlook. Despite weak earnings from Goldman Sachs and a jobs warning from Microsoft, optimism over China's reopening and potential global growth lifted stocks. The Bank of Japan left its key policy rate unchanged, causing the yen to fall. Key indices, including Hong Kong, Shanghai, Tokyo, and Sydney, rose, while Seoul dipped. Analysts see a strong start to the year, with China's GDP growth expected to rebound and inflation receding.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong, Shanghai, Sydney, Seoul, Singapore, Taipei and Manila were all in negative territory, though there were gains in Tokyo, Wellington and Jakarta.

site_title: UK pay deals hold at 5% for second month as wages lag inflation: XpertHR
summary: The UK's pay deals have held steady at 5% for the second month, below the annual inflation rate of 10.7% and 11.1% in November 2022. Average earnings excluding bonuses rose 6.4% compared to the previous year, the largest increase since 2001. The Bank of England is concerned that slow pay growth may hinder efforts to tame inflation, and employers are urged to support workers amid a recession and cost-of-living crisis.

images.alt_text: The UK and EU have made similar proposals to separate goods only going to Northern Ireland from the rest of the UK versus those which will continue into the EU.
The cost of living crisis is now top of the agenda for those heading to the World Economic Forum at Davos.
The UK ranked third despite the survey being conducted in October and November, shortly after the pound and UK gilts had been hammered by investors.

site_title: Patrizia, Mitsui sustainable infrastructure fund raises US$110m at first close
summary: The Apac Sustainable Infrastructure Fund, launched by Patrizia and Mitsui & Co, has raised US$110 million at its first close, exceeding its initial target. The fund, with a target size of US$500 million to US$1 billion, will invest in sustainable mid-market infrastructure across Asia-Pacific, focusing on developed markets in Singapore, Japan, and New Zealand, as well as select developing Asian markets. The fund aims to support sustainable development in the region and is part of a growing trend in sustainable infrastructure investments.

images.alt_text: People near a mine operated by MMG Las Bambas, in a region where locals claim mining activity has negatively affected crop yields and killed livestock, outside of Cusco, Peru October 14, 2021.
BlackRock's chief executive officer Larry Fink has been outspoken about investing with ESG goals, making it a focal point in his annual letters to the industry.
Mangroves, nature, forest, water, river

site_title: Amazon is set for new round of job cuts affecting 18,000 people
summary: Amazon is set to launch a new round of job cuts, affecting approximately 18,000 employees, primarily in its retail division and human resources. This latest round follows an earlier job cull of over 18,000 corporate employees, which started last year and initially targeted the Devices and Services group. The company is grappling with slowing online sales growth and preparing for a possible recession. The new round is expected to commence on Wednesday, January 18.

images.alt_text: Amazon has been bracing for likely slower growth as soaring inflation forces businesses and consumers to cut back spending.

site_title: Gold stalls as firmer dollar counter slower rate-hike hopes
summary: Gold prices remained unchanged at $1,907.59 per ounce, as the US dollar held firm, despite slower rate-hike expectations from the Federal Reserve. The stronger dollar makes bullion more expensive for other currency holders. The US central bank raised rates by 75 basis points four times last year, but is now expected to slow to a 25 basis point increase. Lower rates are beneficial for gold, but the slower pace of interest rate hikes limits losses in the non-yielding asset.

images.alt_text: Premiums for physical gold rose sharply in China last week.

site_title: Early Ethereum backer raises US$500m to buy the crypto dip
summary: HashKey Capital, a Hong Kong-based asset manager, has raised $500 million to create one of Asia's biggest crypto investment pools, betting on a rebound in the industry. The fund will invest in blockchain infrastructure and applications with potential for mass adoption. HashKey's CEO, Deng Chao, believes the market is at the bottom of a cycle, prompting the investment. The move comes after crypto startup funding plummeted in 2022 due to the FTX collapse and reflects growing caution in the sector.

site_title: Over 5 million new US startups show Covid-era boom has legs
summary: The US Census Bureau reported that over 5 million new businesses were created in the US last year, with 5.1 million applications filed, a 44% increase from 2019. This signifies that the pandemic-era entrepreneurship boom may be long-lasting. The majority of business applications rose by 53% in the South, while other regions plateaued at a higher level than pre-pandemic. The White House praised the numbers, citing resilience and solid labor market performance.

images.alt_text: US tech giants including Meta, Microsoft, Twitter and Snap have purged more than 150,000 staff, according to Layoff.fyi, which tracks technology job losses.

site_title: NYC property values are seen rising 6.1%, boosted by single-family homes
summary: New York City's property values are projected to rise 6.1% for the next fiscal year, driven by a 8.3% increase in single-family homes, with Staten Island seeing the largest gain at 12.1%. Despite a slowdown in home sales, transactions are expected to remain above pre-pandemic levels. The city's office market continues to struggle, with vacancy rates projected to rise further in 2023, while rents are expected to decline to their lowest level in nearly a decade.

images.alt_text: A Federal Reserve Bank of New York survey found that the fewest Americans anticipate changing their primary residence over the next 12 months since the survey started in mid-2013.

site_title: Marcos sees Philippine economy growing fastest in Asia at 7%
summary: President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. predicts the Philippine economy will grow at 7% this year, the fastest in Asia, driven by strong fundamentals and stable unemployment. Marcos credits the domestic economy for its stability and aims to maintain 7% growth. He faces economic challenges, including tight public finances and rising borrowing costs, and has sought to balance US and China interests in agriculture and infrastructure. Marcos also plans to increase production to tame inflation and has expressed openness to cooperation with China on energy exploration in the South China Sea.

images.alt_text: The Philippine government will release fourth-quarter GDP data on Jan 26.

site_title: Vibrant Group files 137.4m yuan claim against associated company
summary: Vibrant Group has filed a 137.4 million yuan (S$26.8 million) claim against its 31%-owned Chinese associate company, Vibrant Pucheng Logistics, citing unpaid repayments to three of its subsidiaries. The subsidiaries, Vibrant Development, New Vibrant (Jiangsu) Supply Chain Management, and Sinolink Financial Leasing, are seeking repayment of loans totaling 121.9 million yuan. The group's financial performance may be impacted if the claims are not successful or fully recovered.

images.alt_text: QAF says its H2 performance is “typically” better than H1, although it had been challenging to comment on the trend in the current volatile environment
Vibrant Group posts a 20.4 per cent rise in net profit to S$3.5 million for the first half of its financial year.
Vibrant remains cautious about its logistics and freight segment.

site_title: Brokers’ take: UOB Kay Hian initiates coverage on Prime US Reit with ‘buy’ call, US$0.78 target price
summary: UOB Kay Hian initiated coverage on Prime US Reit with a "buy" call and a target price of US$0.78, representing an 88% upside from its last closing price. The brokerage projects a 50 basis point increase in the Reit's capitalisation rate to 6.8% due to higher interest rates, but believes this will lead to a "manageable" rise in gearing. The Reit has seen a 40% price correction in the second half of 2022, with analysts considering it undervalued and oversold.

images.alt_text: rents increase S$10.7 per square foot per metre
Average rental in the area now stands at about S$10.69 per square foot per metre (psf pm).

site_title: Two commercial buildings in Tanjong Pagar launched for en bloc sale at S$216m reserve price
summary: Two five-storey commercial buildings on Hoe Chiang Road and Lim Teck Kim Road in Tanjong Pagar, Singapore, will be launched for en bloc sale at a reserve price of S$216 million. The site, comprising the two buildings and a remnant land, has a total estimated land area of 18,540 sq ft and is zoned for commercial use. The successful buyer can redevelop the site into a 35-storey tower or build a hotel or serviced apartments, with potential gains from its 5.6 plot ratio.

images.alt_text: Built in 1959, the 5-storey building on Hoe Chiang Road currently has 5 commercial units on the ground floor and 20 residential units above.

site_title: Japan’s Nov core machinery orders tank more than expected
summary: Japan's core machinery orders fell 8.3% in November from the previous month, more than expected, according to government data. This decline prompted the government to revise its view on corporate investment to "stalling". A separate Reuters survey also showed a decline in confidence among big Japanese manufacturers, with the first negative reading in two years. The slow recovery from the pandemic and rising living costs are contributing factors to the economic downturn.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A worker checks machinery at a factory in Higashiosaka, Japan June 23, 2022.  REUTERS/Sakura Murakami/File Photo

site_title: Stocks to watch: QAF, Vibrant
summary: QAF expects its H2 operating performance to exceed H1 results, despite a challenging volatile environment. The company made no definitive statements about the trend in the current environment. Meanwhile, Vibrant Group has filed a 137.4 million yuan legal claim against one of its subsidiaries for non-payment of debt. Shares of both companies remained unchanged.

site_title: Mizuho adds 20 traders from Credit Suisse in US markets push
summary: Mizuho Financial Group is adding 20 traders from Credit Suisse in its US markets push, as part of its acquisition of a significant portion of Credit Suisse's agency securitised-products trading business. The hires come amid Credit Suisse's costly restructuring, which includes cutting 9,000 jobs and disposing of large parts of its investment bank. Mizuho aims to expand its capital markets business in the US, with CEO Masahiro Kihara vowing to hire bankers to build businesses with non-investment-grade companies.

site_title: Bitcoin miners power up rigs again as market stages a rebound
summary: Bitcoin miners are powering up their rigs as the digital asset experiences its longest winning streak in a decade. The Bitcoin network's mining difficulty surged 10% in two weeks, driven by a 23% weekly gain and a potential record-breaking 11-month winning streak. Miners, who earn rewards in the form of the token by validating transaction data, are capitalizing on the rally despite falling prices and high energy costs. This surge in rig power could lead to thinner margins for miners if Bitcoin prices remain at current levels.

images.alt_text: Representations of cryptocurrencies including Bitcoin, Dash, Ethereum, Ripple and Litecoin are seen in this illustration picture taken June 2, 2021. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration

site_title: FTX says US$415m in crypto was hacked
summary: FTX, the bankrupt crypto exchange, has reported that approximately $415 million in cryptocurrency was stolen due to hacks on its international and US exchanges since filing for bankruptcy on November 11. The company has recovered $5 billion in crypto, cash, and securities, including $1.7 billion in cash, $3.5 billion in liquid cryptocurrency, and $300 million in liquid securities. The hacks resulted in losses of $323 million on the international exchange and $90 million on the US exchange, with $426 million held by the Bahamian government for creditors.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: Representations of cryptocurrencies are seen in front of displayed FTX logo and decreasing stock graph in this illustration taken November 10, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo/File Photo/File Photo/File Photo

In the US, the Securities and Exchange Commission signalled it would step up its crackdown on crypto firms, while Germany’s securities watchdog has called for global rules to ensure financial stability.
While sticking with the familiar, such as Singapore-listed stocks, is sensible, it can be good to become knowledgeable about other markets.
Zhu told The Straits Times on Monday night that the idea was to allow clients from bankrupt exchange FTX and other insolvent estates to access their capital and start investing again.
Despite Bitcoin’s jump back above the US$21,000 level, not everyone is convinced that the rally will continue to run even higher.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Wednesday, STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.4% on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index reaching 3,295.02, driven by gains in local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB. The top-traded stock, Yangzijiang Financial Holding, opened flat, while Genting Singapore remained unchanged. The gains followed mixed activity in US and European markets, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average dipping 1.1% and the S&P 500 falling 0.2%.

images.alt_text: QAF says its H2 performance is “typically” better than H1, although it had been challenging to comment on the trend in the current volatile environment

site_title: International tourist arrivals doubled in 2022: UN
summary: International tourist arrivals doubled to 917 million in 2022, exceeding expectations, according to the World Tourism Organization. This represents 63% of pre-pandemic levels, with Europe reaching nearly 80% and Asia and the Pacific expected to recover to 80-95% in 2023. The lifting of travel restrictions, particularly in China, is driving the recovery.

site_title: Yellen heads to Africa as US seeks closer ties amid China inroads
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen is embarking on an 11-day trip to Africa, starting in Senegal, to deepen economic ties with the continent amid growing competition from China and Russia. Her visit comes after the US-Africa summit in Washington last month, where billions of dollars in projects and private sector investment were pledged. Yellen will meet with African leaders to highlight US efforts to boost trade and investment flows, as well as discuss global health, food production, and clean energy access.

images.alt_text: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen urged lawmakers to act quickly to raise the debt ceiling to “protect the full faith and credit” of the United States.
Chinese Vice-Premier Liu He and US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen conducted extensive exchanges on the macroeconomic situation and bilateral and multilateral cooperation

site_title: Digital Currency Group halts dividend payment to conserve cash
summary: Digital Currency Group (DCG) has suspended quarterly dividends until further notice to conserve cash. The move comes as the company seeks to reduce operating expenses and preserve liquidity amid the crypto industry's downturn. DCG's crypto lending unit Genesis stopped reimbursements in November, and the company's founder Barry Silbert is locked in a dispute with Gemini co-founder Cameron Winklevoss. The decision is part of a larger trend of insolvencies in the crypto industry, with DCG being one of its key players.

images.alt_text: DCG has been dealing with changes and challenges in some of its biggest subsidiaries since the sudden collapse of FTX.
Genesis' parent company DCG is considering offloading parts of its venture-capital holdings, worth about US$500 million, the Financial Times reports.

site_title: China’s BYD takes cautious approach to US in global EV push
summary: China's BYD, the world's largest seller of electric vehicles, is taking a cautious approach to expanding into the US market due to tense relations between Washington and Beijing, anti-China sentiment, and President Joe Biden's focus on home-grown EV production. BYD has been studying how to set up a US distribution network but has not made an announcement, with the project facing challenges such as the Inflation Reduction Act's rules on sourcing battery materials. Despite this, BYD aims to sell over 3 million vehicles worldwide by 2030, with plans to increase its sales quickly at home and abroad, and is better positioned than Tesla in the EV era due to its vertically integrated business model.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The BYD Tang EV and the BYD Han EV are displayed during an exhibition test drive as the Chinese electric-vehicle producer announces its expansion to the consumer market next year in Mexico, in Toluca, Mexico November 29, 2022. REUTERS/Toya Sarno Jordan/File Photo
BYD has been expanding elsewhere in Asia, including Singapore and Japan, and Europe.

site_title: Singapore pitches benefits of diversified supply chain to manufacturers
summary: Singapore's managing director of the Economic Development Board, Jacqueline Poh, emphasized the benefits of diversified supply chains for manufacturers, warning that no country is entirely self-sufficient. Poh's remarks came as companies adjust their supply chains to account for geopolitical risks and pandemic uncertainty. Fellow panelists, including Siemens' Roland Busch and Anheuser-Busch InBev's Michel Doukeris, also highlighted the importance of localized supply chains, citing benefits such as reduced dependency on logistics, lower costs, and increased resilience.

images.alt_text: Joan Ng
The IEA says that the global market for key mass-manufactured technologies will be worth around US$650 billion a year by the end of the decade

Investors can look forward to growth in China's manufacturing sector, said Laura Cha (far left), chairman of Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing, at a panel discussion moderated by Francine Lacqua, editor-at-large and presenter at Bloomberg Television. Other panellists were, from left, Mario Centeno, governor of the central bank of Portugal; Axel Lehmann, chairman of Credit Suisse; and Douglas Peterson, president and CEO of S&P Global.

site_title: Cybersecurity startup Blackpanda raises US$15m
summary: Blackpanda, a cybersecurity firm based in Singapore, has raised US$15 million in a Series A funding round led by Primavera Venture Partners and Gaw Capital Partners. The fresh funds will be used to expand the company's cybersecurity services and develop an artificial intelligence and machine learning-driven cybersecurity insurtech platform. With this round, Blackpanda's total funds raised have reached US$23 million, solidifying its presence in Asia and furthering its mission to provide digital forensics and incident response services.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

site_title: Madonna announces music tour celebrating 40 years of hits
