summary: Music superstar Madonna is set to kick off a new tour, "Madonna: The Celebration Tour", celebrating her over 40 years of hits. The 35-city tour will take fans on an "artistic journey through four decades", starting with Vancouver on July 15 and wrapping in Amsterdam on December 1. The tour will feature special guest Bob the Drag Queen and tickets go on sale on January 20. Madonna expressed her excitement to perform her famous tracks, including "Material Girl" and "Like a Prayer", and pay tribute to the city of New York where her career began.

site_title: Microsoft to cut engineering jobs this week as layoffs go deeper
summary: Microsoft plans to cut engineering jobs on Wednesday, joining other tech giants scaling back due to a prolonged slump in demand. The magnitude of the cuts isn't known, but they will be significantly larger than previous rounds. This move comes as the company prepares for a slowdown in software and services demand. Microsoft has already shrunk its workforce in October and July and paused hiring in various groups. The company's shares have dropped 23% in the past year, and a sales gain of 2% in the fiscal third quarter would be the slowest revenue increase since 2017.

site_title: Taiwan’s economy seen slowing in 2023 as global demand weakens
summary: Taiwan's economy is expected to slow in 2023 due to waning global demand, with a forecasted 2.9% growth in 2022, the weakest pace in four years. The economy is likely to continue to be weighed down by a deteriorating external backdrop, a down-cycle in the semiconductor industry, and a fading reopening impulse. Despite some optimism in Taiwan's semiconductor industry, economists expect GDP growth to slow to 1% in 2023. The central bank is expected to consider interest rate hikes in the coming months.

images.alt_text: While Taiwan’s assisted local chipmakers in the past with infrastructure construction and other measures, the island is now stepping up its efforts.

site_title: United Airlines expects to quadruple profit in 2023
summary: United Airlines expects to quadruple its full-year profit in 2023, forecasting an adjusted profit of $10 to $12 per share, surpassing analyst estimates of $6.54. The airline's fourth-quarter earnings beat expectations, driven by robust travel demand, a strong US dollar, and rising corporate travel. Despite recession fears, airlines say travel demand remains strong, keeping ticket prices high, and limiting capacity growth due to staffing and aircraft shortages.

images.alt_text: Group passenger traffic and load factors remained robust across all route regions including East Asia, said SIA Group.
Airfares from China are now 160 per cent higher than before the pandemic, data from travel firm ForwardKeys shows, due to limited supply.
Marquee international events returned to Singapore in 2022 as MICE tourism recovered with easing Covid restrictions.

site_title: Coinbase, Marathon Digital lead 2023 resurgence in crypto stocks
summary: Crypto-exposed stocks like Coinbase, Marathon Digital, and Riot Platforms have surged 45% or more from the start of 2023, driven by Bitcoin's longest winning streak in over nine years. The NYSE FactSet Global Blockchain Technologies Index has risen over 49%, its best month since February 2021. Crypto-mining stocks have benefited, with some seeing their share prices double since January. Short sellers are exiting positions after making outsized profits, contributing to the rally, but some analysts, like Chase White, believe the price increase is likely a "head fake" that will prove transitory.

images.alt_text: Miners use specialised computing facilities to secure the Bitcoin network by validating transaction data on the blockchain and earning rewards in the form of the token.
Representations of cryptocurrencies including Bitcoin, Dash, Ethereum, Ripple and Litecoin are seen in this illustration picture taken June 2, 2021. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration

site_title: World’s oldest known person dies aged 118
summary: French nun Lucile Randon, known as Sister Andre, died at 118 years old in her sleep at a nursing home in Toulon, France. Born on February 11, 1904, she was previously recognized as the world's oldest European and held the record until Japan's Kane Tanaka's death last year. Sister Andre, who lived a long and fulfilling life, credited her work and caring for others as key to her longevity, saying "work kept me alive." She had been blind and relied on a wheelchair, but continued to care for others until her passing.

images.alt_text: The partially snow-covered Schiahorn mountain, beyond the Congress Center, the venue for the World Economic Forum (WEF), in Davos, Switzerland, on Friday, Jan. 6, 2023. Though it’s perched at an altitude of 1,560 meters, this year’s rare winter heatwave saw the Swiss town of Davos basking in temperatures well above freezing in early January, with its mountainsides covered in dead, brown grass and hikers out with their dogs. Photographer: Francesca Volpi/Bloomberg

site_title: Global growth to bottom out this year: IMF chief
summary: IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva predicts global economic growth will bottom out in 2023, decelerating to 2.7% this year from 3.2% last year, despite the Ukraine war and rising interest rates. The Russia-Ukraine war, cost of living crisis, and high interest rates pose significant challenges. Georgieva emphasizes the need for smart management of supply security to adjust to these challenges.

site_title: Fraud trial begins over Elon Musk’s 2018 Tesla tweet
summary: A US federal trial began in San Francisco over Elon Musk's 2018 tweet claiming he had secured funding to take Tesla private, causing a share price surge. Musk was sued by shareholders for allegedly costing them billions with the false claim. The case dates back to August 2018 when Musk tweeted that funding was "secured" to buy out Tesla shareholders. Musk's lawyers argue that the tweet was not "materially" false, while the plaintiff alleges it artificially affected the price of Tesla stock. The trial will determine if Musk committed fraud.

images.alt_text: Even though Tesla cars are not connected with Starlink equipment, which would allow users to bypass China’s Great Firewall, Beijing has become increasingly concerned about data security and social stability.
Tesla cut prices in China and other Asian markets last week.
Hundreds of workers who were laid off by Elon Musk after he bought the social media company in October have already filed arbitration claims.
In an about-turn, Twitter is now expanding its advertising policy to allow cause-based advertising on the platform.

site_title: ECB pondering slower hikes after half point in February
summary: European Central Bank officials are considering a slower pace of interest-rate hikes after a 50-basis-point increase in February, with a smaller 25-point increase in March gaining support. The decision to slow the pace of increases remains uncertain, and policymakers may still deliver the half-point move for the March meeting. Weaker-than-expected inflation, lower natural gas prices, and the prospect of gentler tightening by the US Federal Reserve have brought comfort to policymakers.

images.alt_text:
(FILES) In this file photo taken on October 21, 2020 people wearing face masks walk in front of the euro sign at the former ECB headquarters in the city center of Frankfurt am Main, western Germany. - The European Central Bank is expected Thursday to unleash more stimulus to help shore up a eurozone economy devastated by the coronavirus pandemic, analysts said, in a move eagerly awaited by financial markets.

The Frankfurt institution already has a 1.35-trillion-euro ($1.6-trillion) emergency bond-buying programme in place, but ECB chief Christine Lagarde all but promised in October that extra support was on the way. (Photo by Yann Schreiber / AFP)

site_title: Oil prices settle higher on hopes of China demand rebound
summary: Oil prices rose 1.7% on Tuesday, settling at $85.92 for Brent crude futures and $80.18 for US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude. The increase was driven by hopes of a rebound in Chinese fuel demand following China's weak but expectation-beating annual economic growth data and a shift in its Covid-19 policy. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) forecast Chinese oil demand would grow 510,000 barrels per day this year, while the International Energy Agency (IEA) will release a report on oil demand strength on Wednesday.

images.alt_text: A Pumping unit, also known as a "nodding donkey" or pumping jack, stands silhouetted against the sun at an oil plant operated by Moravske Naftove Doly (MND) AS in Damborice, Czech Republic, on Friday, Jan. 8, 2016. Oil capped the biggest two-year loss on record in 2015 as the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries effectively abandoned output limits amid a global glut. Photographer: Martin Divisek/Bloomberg
Brent crude fell US$1.08, or 1.3 per cent, to US$84.20 a barrel by 2041 GMT on Monday

Saudi Minister of Foreign Affairs Prince Faisal bin Farhan Al-Saud said his country, the world’s top oil exporter, has a responsibility to continue to provide that stability to oil markets and world economies.

site_title: Goldman and Morgan Stanley fortunes split as strategies diverge
summary: Goldman Sachs reported a 69% drop in net income due to a slump in investment-banking fees and higher expenses, while Morgan Stanley posted a 40% decline in net income but beat expectations with strong performance in wealth management. Morgan Stanley's shares rose 8.1% after the report, while Goldman's fell 8% as investors punished the firm for its identity crisis and high compensation costs. The divergence in strategies has led to a widening gap in market capitalization, with Morgan Stanley's value surging to $167 billion compared to Goldman's $123 billion.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo for Goldman Sachs is seen on the trading floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, New York, U.S., November 17, 2021. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly/File Photo
Goldman’s investment banking fees fell 48 per cent in the quarter.
Profit applicable to Morgan Stanley’s common shareholders for the three months ended Dec 31 was US$2.11 billion or US$1.26 per diluted share.

site_title: Twitter reverses its 2019 ban on political ads
summary: Twitter is expanding its advertising policy to allow cause-based advertising on the platform, including ads related to education, voters' rights, climate change, and civic engagement. The ads will go through a certification process and adhere to Twitter's principle that "political message reach should be earned and not bought." The move is seen as a positive step, as it aligns with Twitter's existing policy and allows for more nuanced and targeted advertising. The expansion is expected to be in line with other social media platforms, such as Meta and Google, and will not allow all political advertising, unlike TikTok.

images.alt_text: While TikTok has banned paid political ads since 2019, campaign strategists have skirted the ban by paying influencers to promote political issues.
FILE PHOTO: Twitter logo and a photo of Elon Musk are displayed through magnifier in this illustration taken October 27, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
Singapore serves as Twitter’s Asia-Pacific headquarters.
Hundreds of workers who were laid off by Elon Musk after he bought the social media company in October have already filed arbitration claims.

site_title: Bitcoin rises to highest in four months
summary: Bitcoin surged to $21,594, its highest level in four months, on January 17, driven by hopes of a potential end to central bank policy tightening. The cryptocurrency has gained nearly 30% this year, boosted by optimism that inflation has peaked. This new year rally follows a period of volatility, with Bitcoin last flat at $21,174.

images.alt_text: Representations of cryptocurrencies including Bitcoin, Dash, Ethereum, Ripple and Litecoin are seen in this illustration picture taken June 2, 2021. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration

site_title: Singapore Medical Group to delist on Jan 20
summary: Singapore Medical Group (SMG) will delist on January 20 after successfully privatising itself through a S$0.40 per share offer. The move follows 95.1% of valid acceptances by TLW Success, a company jointly owned by SMG's non-executive chairman Tony Tan, CEO Beng Teck Liang, and executive director Wong Seng Weng. The privatisation was completed a month after the offer was made, allowing SMG to transition to a private company.

images.alt_text: Beng Teck Liang, SMG chief executive, is one of the 3 owners of TLW Success which launched a bid to take the company private in September.
Beng Teck Liang, CEO of Singapore Medical Group (SMG), partially owns investment vehicle TLW Success.
Beng Teck Liang, chief executive of Singapore Medical Group and one of the top executives who own TWL Success.
Dr Beng Teck Liang, CEO of SMG said the revised offer price is in appreciation of shareholders' continued support and also in view of the prevailing market conditions and business environment

site_title: Tesla’s retail sales in China surged after price cut
summary: Tesla's retail sales in China surged 76% in the Jan 9-15 period, reaching 12,654 vehicles, despite a 14.5% decline in overall retail auto sales. The surge was attributed to price cuts of 6-13.5% for the Model 3 and Model Y cars in China, following similar price reductions in the US and Europe. In contrast, Xpeng's sales fell 36% in the same period, while BYD's sales more than doubled to 40,435 vehicles.

images.alt_text: Tesla cut prices in China and other Asian markets last week.

site_title: Emerson Electric makes US$7.6b offer for NI Corp public after rebuffed approaches
summary: Emerson Electric made a US$7.6 billion all-cash offer to buy NI Corp, a Texas-based automation equipment maker, after being rebuffed in earlier approaches. The offer represents a 13% premium to NI's closing price and has no financing conditions. Emerson aims to pivot itself as a provider of automation products and services, and the deal is seen as a strategic fit. NI had been exploring strategic options after receiving acquisition interest from companies, including Emerson.

images.alt_text: Workers produce some of the specialized valves at Emerson Electric Co.’s factory in Marshalltown, Iowa, U.S., July 26, 2018. Picture taken on July 26, 2018.   REUTERS/Timothy Aeppel/File Photo
Blackstone says it will receive an upfront payment of about US$9.5 billion, which it will use to scoop up more companies, especially in the automation segment.

site_title: BMW bringing back ‘Knight Rider’ is the easy part of software shift
summary: BMW unveiled its i Vision Dee concept at CES, featuring a chameleon-like talking car with color-changing exterior panels, to showcase its shift towards AI-enabled companionship. The move follows industry trends, as carmakers like Tesla and Stellantis also focus on software development and over-the-air updates. To succeed, companies must adopt a more hands-on approach, shifting their mindset and culture to develop and source components, and take greater ownership of their relationship with customers. BMW aims to create in-house software, unlike Google, to maintain control of its tech stack.

images.alt_text: At BMW, sales of EVs like the i4 sedan more than doubled to 215,755 cars.

site_title: Germany names new defence minister amid pressure to send tanks to Ukraine
summary: Germany has appointed Boris Pistorius as its new defence minister, amid pressure from Western allies to send tanks to Ukraine. Pistorius, a 62-year-old former interior minister, will host US counterpart Lloyd Austin in Berlin on Thursday. The move comes after Christine Lambrecht's resignation and follows a conference on Western plans to provide Kyiv with more arms. Germany has been cautious about approving the despatch of heavy Leopard tanks, but Pistorius is expected to take a hard line on security issues. He will oversee an overhaul of Germany's armed forces, with a 100 billion euro special fund at his disposal.

images.alt_text: epa10410554 (FILE) - Lower Saxony Minister for Interior and Sports, Boris Pistorius attends press conference after the meeting of federal German interior ministers in Dresden, Saxony, Germany, 14 June 2017 (reissued 17 January 2023). Boris Pistorius, the Social Democratic Party (SPD)'s interior minister of the German state of Lower Saxony, is to serve as Germany's next Defense Minister, according to political sources. His predecessor, Christine Lambrecht, resigned from the post on 16 January 2023, following growing skepticism about her ability to bring the German army into shape against the backdrop of the war in Ukraine.  EPA-EFE/FILIP SINGER *** Local Caption *** 53584465
The 57-year-old Lambrecht came under scrutiny over a perceived lack of military expertise.

Irina Shcherbakova (centre) poses with German Chancellor Olaf Scholz and presenter Julia-Niharika Sen (left) after having been awarded the 2022 Marion Dönhoff Prize for International Communication and Reconciliation in Hamburg, Germany on Dec 4, 2022.
German Chancellor Olaf Scholz meets Chinese President Xi Jinping in Beijing on Nov 4. A document by Germany's foreign ministry is proposing measures to reduce the country's dependency on China.

site_title: Saudi foreign minister says oil price stability reflects correct Opec+ policy
summary: Saudi Arabia's foreign minister, Prince Faisal bin Farhan Al Saud, stated that the country's oil price stability reflects its correct OPEC+ policy. This stability is attributed to Saudi Arabia's commitment to providing reliable energy, despite its position during last year's disagreement with the US over oil output targets. Prince Faisal emphasized the need for a robust dialogue with traditional allies, including the US, to address any issues. Saudi Arabia aims to balance its commitment to a clean energy future with the reliability of traditional forms of energy.

site_title: US: Dow falls on weakness from Goldman Sachs and insurer Travelers
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 1.1% to 33,910.85 on Tuesday, weighed down by disappointing results from Goldman Sachs and Travelers. Goldman Sachs plummeted 6.4% after missing analyst estimates, while Travelers dropped 4.6% due to estimated $459 million in catastrophe losses from a winter storm. Despite this, tech shares rose, and Morgan Stanley jumped 5.9% after reporting better-than-expected profits. This week's economic data, including housing and retail sales, will be closely watched.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 80.29 points, or 0.23 per cent, at the open to 34,222.32.

site_title: ECB staff losing faith in leadership as inflation bites, survey shows
summary: European Central Bank staff have lost confidence in the institution's leadership, with 40% of respondents expressing "low" or "no" trust in Christine Lagarde and the board, according to a survey by trade union IPSO. The survey, which involved 1,600 ECB staff, found that high inflation and a pay increase that did not match price rises had damaged trust in the ECB's leadership. The ECB's ability to control inflation and protect purchasing power has also come under scrutiny, with staff worried about the risk of a "wage-price spiral".

images.alt_text:
(FILES) In this file photo taken on October 21, 2020 people wearing face masks walk in front of the euro sign at the former ECB headquarters in the city center of Frankfurt am Main, western Germany. - The European Central Bank is expected Thursday to unleash more stimulus to help shore up a eurozone economy devastated by the coronavirus pandemic, analysts said, in a move eagerly awaited by financial markets.

The Frankfurt institution already has a 1.35-trillion-euro ($1.6-trillion) emergency bond-buying programme in place, but ECB chief Christine Lagarde all but promised in October that extra support was on the way. (Photo by Yann Schreiber / AFP)

site_title: US, Taiwan officials pledge ambitious trade-talk schedule
summary: US and Taiwan officials have concluded a four-day trade negotiation, reaching agreements on trade facilitation, anti-corruption, small and medium-sized enterprises, and regulatory practices. The talks aim for "economically meaningful" outcomes, including discussions on China's economic coercion. No tariff reductions or traditional market-access enhancements are on the table. The US Trade Representative has pledged to maintain an ambitious negotiating schedule, with the next round of talks to be announced later.

site_title: Europe: Shares close up after report says ECB considering smaller rate hikes
summary: European shares closed at a fresh nine-month high, up 0.4%, after a report suggested the European Central Bank may consider smaller interest rate hikes. The Stoxx 600 index has gained nearly 7% this year, driven by hopes of a China economic rebound and easing price pressures. Germany's inflation eased further in December, while luxury stocks like LVMH rose, driven by China's reopening and accumulated savings. However, some sectors, including Ocado Group and Engie, fell due to concerns over inflation and energy bills.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 1.1 per cent lower at 33,910.85 on Tuesday.
Gainers outnumber losers 62 to 35 after 22.3 million securities worth S$29.7 million changes hands.

site_title: Apple introduces faster MacBook Pros and Mac minis
summary: Apple introduced faster MacBook Pros and Mac minis, with the new 14-inch and 16-inch models featuring more powerful M2 Pro and M2 Max chips. The laptops retain their previous design but offer improved performance. The new Macs follow the company's expansion of the M2 chip, which debuted in the MacBook Air and low-end MacBook Pro last year. The updated product line is expected to bolster Apple's revenue, which reached $40.2 billion in the previous year. A variation of the M2 chip is also planned for the Mac Pro desktop computer later this year.

images.alt_text: The current work calls for Apple’s first touch-screen MacBook Pro to retain a traditional laptop design, including a standard trackpad and keyboard.

site_title: Temasek, Toyota back climate biotech firm Living Carbon
summary: Temasek and Toyota have backed climate tech firm Living Carbon with a $21 million Series A funding round, valuing the company at $100 million. Living Carbon aims to increase the carbon-absorbing ability of trees through genetic tweaks, with the goal of producing 5 million saplings and generating carbon credits that can be sold to companies offsetting their emissions. The company's technology, "photosynthesis enhancement," increases biomass and locks away more carbon, preventing it from decomposing and returning to the atmosphere.

site_title: Sterling nears one-month high on UK jobs data, yen in focus
summary: Sterling rose 0.5% to a one-month high against the US dollar, driven by stronger-than-expected UK jobs data, with wage growth speeding up and employment rising by 27,000. The Bank of England is set to monitor the data, gauging interest rate hikes. Meanwhile, the Japanese yen hovered near a seven-month high, as investors await a potential policy shift from the Bank of Japan, with speculation about a change to yield-curve control policy building.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Woman holds British Pound banknotes in this illustration taken May 30, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
The yield on Japan’s benchmark 10-year government bonds breached the central bank’s new ceiling on Friday, adding to pressure for the yield control policy to be scrapped or revised.

site_title: World’s hottest housing market swept by record Russian purchases
summary: Russian nationals purchased a record 16,312 homes in Turkey in 2022, a 203% increase from 2021, making them the top foreign buyers of real estate in the country. This influx of buyers, driven by sanctions over Ukraine, helped sustain Turkey's hottest housing market, with property prices posting 57.6% real growth in the third quarter of 2022. Many Russian buyers are applying for Turkish citizenship, and the southern province of Antalya saw a 77% increase in sales to foreign nationals, with Iranians and Iraqis also making significant purchases.

site_title: Business travel, high-end tourists lead return of China visitors to Singapore
summary: Business travelers and high-end tourists are leading the return of China visitors to Singapore, with mass-market tourism expected to resume gradually due to economic uncertainty and limited flights. The Singapore Tourism Board hopes to see China arrivals recover to 30-60% of pre-Covid levels by the second half of 2023. Higher-end "experiential leisure travelers" are expected to drive the recovery, while mass-market tours are unlikely to resume significantly. The return of Chinese tourists is expected to boost Singapore's luxury retail scene, with luxury handbag brand Ethan K seeing a spike in bookings from Chinese travelers.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
Marquee international events returned to Singapore in 2022 as MICE tourism recovered with easing Covid restrictions.
Sporting events like SailGP will help put Singapore on the map said Minister of State for Culture, Community and Sport, Alvin Tan.

site_title: Biden’s green energy bank races to leverage US$394b to scale cleantech
summary: The US Energy Department's Loan Programs Office is racing to leverage up to $394 billion to support low-carbon technologies and meet the country's goal of halving emissions by 2030. Revived under President Joe Biden, the office has announced four conditional loans and a fifth, a $700 million loan for a lithium-mining project. With two years left in Biden's term, the office faces pressure to act quickly, but its window of opportunity may be short. The office has over 100 applications, and its head, Jigar Shah, emphasizes the need for "execution" in 2023.

site_title: China warns of 'spillover' from Western rate hikes
summary: China's Vice Premier Liu He warned of "spillover effects" from Western interest rate hikes on emerging economies, urging more attention to prevent adding to debt and financial risks. The US Federal Reserve's benchmark rate hikes have strengthened the dollar, increasing borrowing costs for countries with US-dollar debt and discouraging capital flight from emerging countries. Liu also called for an end to the "Cold War mentality" and more global cooperation, amid rising tensions between the US and China. China's export-oriented economy is seen as vulnerable to changes in the global trading system.

images.alt_text: China Vice-Premier Liu He said that it was impossible for China to take the path of a planned economy as some claimed.

site_title: UK oil and gas licensing round attracts 115 bids
summary: The UK government has attracted 115 bids for its oil and gas licensing round, a significant increase from the 104 bids in the previous round. The licensing round, which offers 258 blocks, is expected to be awarded in the second quarter. This move aims to boost domestic hydrocarbon output as Europe weans itself off Russian fuel. However, climate activists have criticized the licensing round, and Greenpeace is working on a legal challenge. Energy majors Shell and BP participated in the round, despite the recent increase in the windfall tax on the oil and gas sector.

site_title: US: Wall St opens after lower Goldman Sachs misses profit estimates
summary: US stocks opened lower on Tuesday after Goldman Sachs missed quarterly profit estimates, contributing to worsening sentiment. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 80.29 points, or 0.23%, to 34,222.32. The S&P 500 also declined, falling 0.01% to 3,999.09 points, while the Nasdaq Composite dropped 9.15 points, or 0.08%, to 11,070.00. The lower opening comes amid downbeat economic data from China earlier in the day.

images.alt_text: A trader works on the trading floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., January 5, 2023. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly

site_title: Nio shares may have turned the corner, but more roadblocks lie ahead
summary: Nio, a Chinese electric vehicle (EV) maker, has seen its shares bounce back from an all-time low in November, gaining 11.9% to US$11.31 in the year to date. Despite reporting healthy growth in vehicle deliveries, Nio faces operational inefficiencies, compressed vehicle sales margins, and a potential price war. CEO William Li acknowledged the company's slower response to supply and demand fluctuations and attributed the lag to delivery performance to the company's slower response to supply and demand fluctuations. Nio aims to break even in 2024, but faces challenges in navigating the rising costs and competition in the EV market.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
NIO EP9 (left) and NIO ES8 (right) on display at SGX Centre
SGX welcomed 11 new listings in 2022. The companies raised a total of S$580.3 million, according to bourse data.
An employee works on the production line of Nio electric vehicles at a JAC-NIO manufacturing plant in Hefei, Anhui province, China, on Aug 28, 2022.
Nio, which until now has targeted premium buyers for its vehicles, plans to roll out its first mass market model in 2024.
At the weekend event in Hefei in central Anhui province, Shanghai-based Nio launched a revamped ES8, an iteration of the original electric sports utility vehicle it’s been selling since 2018.
The auto industry has been forced to spend billions of dollars to strengthen its data protection systems as it deals with a wave of cyberattacks.
Tesla recently upgraded its Shanghai factory to double capacity to about 1 million cars a year.
Nio delivered some 31,607 vehicles in Q3 FY2022, which was a record-breaking quarterly delivery, chief executive William Bin Li noted.

site_title: Container port giant DP World strikes positive tone on trade
summary: DP World's chairman Sultan Ahmed expressed a cautiously positive view on global economic prospects, citing China's reopening as a potential boost to trade and container volumes. He believes the business is capable of overcoming current challenges, despite World Bank warnings of slower growth and recession. Global GDP is expected to increase 1.7% in 2023, with cargo shipments building towards the fourth quarter as export backlogs are addressed. DP World remains committed to investing in the UK, particularly in London, despite financial and political uncertainty.

images.alt_text: A US flag flies near containers stacked high on a cargo ship at the Port of Los  Angeles on September 28, 2021 in Los Angeles, California. - A record number of cargo ships are stuck floating and waiting off the southern California coast amid a supply chain crisis which could mean fewer gifts and toys for Christmas this year as a combination of growing volumes of cargo, Covid-19 related saftey measures and a labor shortage slow the handling and processing of cargo from each ship. (Photo by Frederic J. BROWN / AFP) (Photo by FREDERIC J. BROWN/AFP via Getty Images)

site_title: Pakistan PM makes conditional talks offer to India
summary: Pakistani Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif has made a conditional offer to Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi to engage in talks on all outstanding issues, including the disputed Kashmir region. Sharif stated that talks can only take place if India restores the autonomous status in the part of Kashmir it rules, which was revoked in 2019. This offer comes after Sharif emphasized that the wars between India and Pakistan have brought nothing but misery, poverty, and unemployment.

images.alt_text: UN Secretary-General Antonio Gutteres says Pakistan has been the victim of climate chaos and the global financial system.
An unprecedented monetary policy tightening by central banks to tamp down high inflation is pushing many advanced economies toward a recession, and is tempering growth in others.

site_title: Credit Suisse chair signals bonus cuts after ‘horrifying year’
summary: Credit Suisse chairman Axel Lehmann warned employees of potential bonus cuts, with the bank considering reducing its 2022 bonus pool by about half, amid a grim year of client outflows and billions in losses. The bank is also planning a costly restructuring, including cutting 9,000 jobs and carving out parts of the investment bank under the revived First Boston brand. Lehmann sought to appease shareholders by showing moderation on bonuses while retaining valuable personnel, including investment bankers.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Swiss bank Credit Suisse is seen in front of a branch office in Bern, Switzerland November 29, 2022. REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann/File Photo
Credit Suisse has said that it is set to report a loss of up to 1.5 billion francs for the final three months of 2022, partly on the back of historic outflows of client funds.
Credit Suisse is in the throes of a huge restructuring that will see it cut thousands of jobs and reshape its investment bank to put an end to a string of huge losses and scandals.

site_title: Vice-Premier Liu says it is impossible for China to return to planned economy
summary: Vice-Premier Liu He of China stated that it's impossible for China to return to a planned economy, contradicting claims that China should adopt a more controlled economic model. Liu emphasized support for the private economy, international cooperation, and maintaining world peace, while also championing entrepreneurship and foreign investment. This statement comes as China signals a return to economic focus, following a period of Covid-19 control efforts. Liu's speech at the World Economic Forum in Davos aims to reassure the world of China's commitment to economic growth and cooperation.

site_title: Morgan Stanley profit beats on strength in trading business
summary: Morgan Stanley reported a 41% drop in fourth-quarter profit, beating expectations, due to a boost from market volatility in its trading business. The decline was attributed to sluggish dealmaking, which was largely halted last year due to deteriorating macroeconomic conditions and geopolitical tensions. The bank's trading business offset the impact, with profit reaching $2.11 billion.

site_title: QAF expects H2 operating performance will exceed H1
summary: QAF Ltd expects its operating performance for the second half of 2022 to exceed the first half, despite a challenging volatile environment. The company's H2 performance is typically better than H1, with higher exceptional gains from insurance payouts. However, QAF expects a higher unrealised foreign exchange loss and non-cash impairment on its investment in Gardenia Bakeries. The company will announce its H2 results in August.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun

Yeo, a former top civil servant who currently chairs investment firm Economic Development Innovations Singapore, is most known for his role in helping to develop Singapore’s economy when he led the Economic Development Board (EDB) and Agency for Science Technology and Research (A*Star).
Gardenia is one of the brands under the Singapore-listed QAF group.
Workers process chickens on the production line at the Soanes Poultry factory near Driffield, Britain, October 12, 2021.

site_title: Saudi Arabia says it is not bound to US dollar for trade
summary: Saudi Arabia's finance minister, Mohammed Al-Jadaan, has stated that the kingdom is open to discussing trade arrangements in currencies other than the US dollar, including the euro and Saudi riyal. This move could challenge the dollar's hegemony and strengthen Saudi's relations with countries like China, with whom it has agreed to boost coordination on energy policy and exploration. Saudi Arabia is also investing heavily in vulnerable countries such as Pakistan, Turkey, and Egypt, with plans to invest $10 billion in Pakistan and provide support through multilateral institutions.

images.alt_text: Saudi Tabreed provides district cooling services to major urban developments across Saudi Arabia and the Gulf region.

site_title: Key investment themes for 2023
summary: Heightened volatility is expected to continue across asset classes in 2023, offering opportunities for active management. Key investment themes include a revival in bond interest, 60/40 portfolio strategies, and multi-asset strategies. Small caps and private equity are also expected to perform well due to attractive valuations. Active management is crucial in navigating these market fluctuations, particularly for those with long investment horizons.

images.alt_text: In an earlier session, Dr He Dong, deputy director for monetary and capital markets at the International Monetary Fund (IMF), described 2023 to be a challenging year for monetary policy.

site_title: Singapore exports set to contract further amid weak demand: economists
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) contracted 20.6% year-on-year in December, the lowest level since February 2021, according to Enterprise Singapore data. This marks the third consecutive month of decline, lower than the 17.5% drop expected by private-sector economists. Weakening global demand conditions are attributed to the contraction, with economists expecting further declines in the coming months. However, some improvements are predicted for the second half of the year.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
NODX to XX
The Purchasing Managers' Index dipped 0.1 point to 49.7 in December, the fourth consecutive month of contraction in overall activity.

site_title: Singapore dollar is new short as Asian haven falls from favour
summary: Singapore's Singapore dollar is losing favor as a haven currency, with Goldman Sachs and Societe Generale going short against it. Momentum indicators show the currency is overbought, suggesting a potential pullback. The Monetary Authority of Singapore has signaled the end of its tightening cycle, and China's reopening is expected to weigh on the currency. The Singapore dollar has gained 1.3% against the US dollar in January, but trails its Asian peers. A short trade against the Malaysian ringgit and offshore yuan is being recommended. A pullback is likely in the near term.

site_title: Kitchen Culture, ex-CEO drop legal proceedings, agree to settle
summary: Kitchen Culture and its former CEO Lim Wee Li have agreed to settle their legal proceedings after filing notices of discontinuation. The group had filed a claim against Lim for wrongful termination in 2021, while Lim filed a counterclaim against Kitchen Culture. With the notices, Kitchen Culture is no longer involved in the proceedings, bringing an end to the dispute.

images.alt_text: Poggenpohl showroom by Kitchen Culture. The company's sponsor has issued a statement in response to a Dec 7 article published in The Business Times.
Poggenpohl showroom by Kitchen Culture. The company says it will “carry on its business and affairs normally” as it defends against legal proceedings launched by Ooway Group.
The boardroom fight at Catalist-listed Kitchen Culture, an outfitter of kitchens, is now being played out at the court.

Poggenpohl showroom by Kitchen Culture. Ooway Group became a substantial shareholder of Kitchen Culture in 2020, after it sold 30 per cent of its subsidiary Ooway Technology to Kitchen Culture in exchange for 90 million shares – around 21.2 per cent – of Kitchen Culture.

Ooway claims the directors were elected at the Nov 25 EGM after shareholders representing about 40 per cent of Kitchen Culture's shares approved their appointments. Kitchen Culture maintains that its current board of directors remains unchanged as it denies the validity of the EGM.

site_title: German economy expected to contract slightly in 2023: BDI
summary: The German economy is expected to contract by 0.3% in 2023, according to the BDI industry association, due to the ongoing energy crisis. Mild recessionary trends are predicted at the start of the year, but improvements are expected in the spring. Exports are forecast to increase by 1.0% in real terms, lagging behind global trade. The BDI president calls for diversification of trade partners and a smart industrial policy to counter the US Inflation Reduction Act, warning that confrontation with Washington should be avoided.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People walk through the Mall of Berlin shopping centre during its opening night in Berlin, Germany, September 24, 2014. REUTERS/Thomas Peter///File Photo

site_title: No replacement for Chinese GP, F1 season to have 23 races
summary: Formula 1 has announced it will proceed with a record 23 races this season, despite the cancellation of the Chinese Grand Prix for the fourth year in a row due to COVID-19 restrictions. The decision leaves a four-week gap in April. The sport had considered alternative options, including Portugal's Portimao circuit, but ultimately decided to maintain the current schedule. The 2023 season will now feature 23 races, one more than last year.

images.alt_text:
Formula One F1 - Singapore Grand Prix - Marina Bay Street Circuit, Singapore - October 2, 2022
Red Bull's Sergio Perez celebrates after winning the Singapore Grand Prix REUTERS/Caroline Chia     TPX IMAGES OF THE DAY

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index resumed its downward trajectory in December, dipping 0.1 point to 49.7. Non-oil domestic exports (NODX) contracted 20.6% in December, the third straight month of decline. Tourism receipts reached an estimated S$13.8 billion to S$14.3 billion in 2022, about half of the 2019 pre-pandemic level. South-east Asia's food delivery GMV growth in 2022 slowed to 5% to US$16.3 billion. Singapore shares slid in line with Asian bourses, amid reports of the steepest decline in exports in a decade.

site_title: The ‘business of business’ is changing
summary: The "business of business" is shifting as corporate leaders increasingly prioritize social responsibility alongside profit. The World Economic Forum in Davos is highlighting public-private partnerships and multi-stakeholder dialogues to tackle global issues like income inequality and climate change. A recent Oxfam report shows that the top 1% of earners hold nearly two-thirds of new wealth, sparking calls for business leaders to deliver solutions to global challenges. Poll data suggests growing trust in business, with a rebound in perceptions of corporate competence and ethics, as people expect companies to play a greater role in society.

images.alt_text: Some 18 per cent considered a world recession “extremely likely” in World Economic Forum (WEF) survey, more than twice as many as in the previous survey conducted in September 2022.

World Economic Forum (WEF) President Borge Brende (left) and WEF managing director Saadia Zahidi during a virtual media briefing in Cologny, near Geneva, Switzerland, Jan 10, 2023. The World Economic Forum unveiled the program for its upcomming Annual Meeting Davos 2023, i

The partially snow-covered Schiahorn mountain, beyond the Congress Center, the venue for the World Economic Forum (WEF), in Davos, Switzerland, on Friday, Jan. 6, 2023. Though it’s perched at an altitude of 1,560 meters, this year’s rare winter heatwave saw the Swiss town of Davos basking in temperatures well above freezing in early January, with its mountainsides covered in dead, brown grass and hikers out with their dogs. Photographer: Francesca Volpi/Bloomberg

site_title: China approves 88 games in January, including titles by Tencent and NetEase
summary: China's video game regulator approved 88 online games, including titles from Tencent, NetEase, and miHoYo, in January. This marks a significant increase after a nine-month freeze on licence approvals in August. The approvals come after China granted publishing licences to 44 foreign games for domestic release in October, effectively ending the industry crackdown. The regulator's approval process requires video games to be reviewed before release, a unique requirement in most other countries. The approved games include titles such as Yuanmengzhixing, Chaofanxianfeng, and Honkai: Star Rail.

site_title: UBS is ‘bucking the trend’ as rivals fire bankers, says CEO
summary: UBS CEO Ralph Hamers stated the bank will not make large-scale job cuts, bucking the trend of its global peers, as its wealth management business continues to grow robustly. The bank is focusing on critical jobs in Asia and the Middle East, and Hamers emphasized the importance of hiring in these regions. In contrast, firms like Goldman Sachs and BNY Mellon are cutting thousands of jobs to trim costs. UBS is also increasing its investment in digitalization and product offerings in the US, with a focus on developing banking and deposit products.

images.alt_text: UBS posted a net profit attributable to shareholders of US$1.73 billion, outpacing the US$1.53 billion forecast by 17 analysts in a company-gathered consensus.
Ralph Hamers has been pushing his vision of a new style of banking, one fit for the digital age.
Investment banking revenue for UBS in China has plunged by about half and new issuance in debt and equity markets has slowed this year following sweeping policy changes in China.

A sign on the exterior of the UBS Group AG headquarters in Zurich, Switzerland, on Tuesday, April 19, 2022. UBS increased pay for junior bankers in the U.S. for a second time in less than a year, bringing the Swiss lender in line with Wall Street rivals trying to stem defections amid a race for talent. Photographer: Pascal Mora/Bloomberg

A sign on the exterior of the UBS Group AG headquarters in Zurich, Switzerland, on Tuesday, April 19, 2022. UBS increased pay for junior bankers in the U.S. for a second time in less than a year, bringing the Swiss lender in line with Wall Street rivals trying to stem defections amid a race for talent. Photographer: Pascal Mora/Bloomberg

site_title: Bond landscape: European banks, USD and SGD bonds
summary: The European banking sector is expected to face challenges in 2023, with the eurozone economy weakening and entering recession, leading to lower economic activity and higher prices. Non-performing loans are expected to rise, but European banks remain well-capitalized with a median Common Equity Tier 1 (CET1) ratio of 14.74%. Net interest margins will support bank earnings, but losses are expected to come from investment banking and higher loan-loss provisions.

images.alt_text: A vendor waits for customers at a fresh produce store in Madrid, Spain; April 20, 2022. The hit to household real incomes in Europe from the energy crunch is greater than in any other region of the world.
Recovery in ESG bond issuance seen in 2023 as rates stabilise, inflation subsides

site_title: Ailing Singapore crypto firm Vauld gets more time to restructure
summary: A Singapore court has extended Vauld's creditor protection period to February 28, allowing the crypto lender to restructure. Vauld, which suffered major damage in last year's digital-asset rout, has received bids from two digital-asset fund managers to take over its tokens. The company is in a dispute with Nexo Capital, which attempted to acquire it, but Vauld has declined the offer. Nexo's office was raided by Bulgarian police in an investigation into money-laundering and tax crimes. Vauld has yet to come up with a revival plan.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Representations of virtual cryptocurrencies are placed on U.S. dollar banknotes in this illustration taken November 28, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Singapore stocks slide in line with most Asian bourses
summary: Singapore shares slid 0.1% on Tuesday, following declines at most Asian bourses, amid reports of the country's December exports experiencing their steepest decline in a decade, down 20.6%. The Strait Times Index dropped 3.09 points to 3,280.51 points. Non-oil domestic exports declined due to falls in electronic and non-electronic shipments. Global demand conditions are expected to remain weighted down in the first quarter unless central banks pivot to a rate pause.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Group passenger traffic and load factors remained robust across all route regions including East Asia, said SIA Group.
Analyst Raymond Yap noted that SIA’s share price has re-rated 16.5 per cent over the past three months on optimism over China’s reopening.
NODX to XX
Hong Kong, Shanghai, Sydney, Seoul, Singapore, Taipei and Manila were all in negative territory, though there were gains in Tokyo, Wellington and Jakarta.
Gainers outnumber losers 62 to 35 after 22.3 million securities worth S$29.7 million changes hands.

site_title: Thyssenkrupp, Adnoc sign MoU to cooperate on ammonium cracking plant
summary: Thyssenkrupp and Abu Dhabi National Oil Co (Adnoc) signed a memorandum of understanding to cooperate on technology for industrial-scale hydrogen extraction from ammonia. Thyssenkrupp's Uhde unit will provide ammonia cracking technology used in over 130 chemicals plants globally. The companies will explore options for supplying and shipping ammonia produced via renewable sources from the UAE to large ammonia cracking sites worldwide, aiming to create new revenue streams and grow the global market for hydrogen.

site_title: Another game of brinkmanship
summary: US Republicans face a difficult decision on the debt ceiling, with a default potentially igniting a global financial crisis and recession. Inflation data from the US Bureau of Labour Statistics showed prices fell 0.1% in December, suggesting moderation in price increases and a possible slowdown in interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve. This could lead to positive news for the financial markets and the economy, but the debt ceiling standoff remains a pressing concern for the fragile American economy.

images.alt_text: “So the Senate is going to have to recognise the fact that we’re not going to budge until we see meaningful reform with respect to spending.” House Oversight Committee chairman James Comer said.
US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen urged lawmakers to act quickly to raise the debt ceiling to “protect the full faith and credit” of the United States.

site_title: CEOs buzz about ChatGPT-style AI at World Economic Forum
summary: Business leaders at the World Economic Forum are discussing generative artificial intelligence (AI), particularly ChatGPT, a chatbot developed by OpenAI. CEOs, including Satya Nadella of Microsoft and Matthew Prince of Cloudflare, see AI as a game-changer with applications in programming, marketing, and military supremacy. Microsoft is considering increasing its $1 billion investment in OpenAI, while companies like CarMax are using OpenAI's technology to generate customer review summaries. The technology's potential impact is being weighed, with some experts warning of its military implications.

images.alt_text: The Emobot is a device that continuously monitors the emotional state of the elderly to detect depression, anxiety and other mental health concerns using AI to interpret data collected by the Embot’s camera and microphone.
The lessons from all the disruptions since 2020 have underscored how the term “supply chain” itself is something of a misnomer, because it suggests that global trade is seamless and unbreakable.
OpenAI, the AI research shop backed by a US$1 billion investment from Microsoft, publicly released ChatGPT for users to test in November.
Microsoft which invested US$1 billion in OpenAI in 2019, was working to launch a version of its search engine Bing using the AI behind the now viral ChatGPT.

ChatGPT is a turning point for artificial intelligence, and we need to take advantage of these tools without causing harm to ourselves or others. (Derek Abella/The New York Times) -- FOR EDITORIAL USE ONLY WITH NYT STORY TECH FIX BY BRIAN X. CHEN FOR DEC. 21, 2022. ALL OTHER USE PROHIBITED. --

site_title: A shallow recession is coming, but don’t fear it: Davos panellists
summary: A shallow global recession is expected in 2023, but experts say it won't be a cause for concern, as it's part of a positive rebalancing of global economies and supply chains. Countries and companies that adapt to changing global supply chains and innovate in sectors like energy and healthcare will thrive. China's manufacturing growth is expected to drive global economic growth, and investors can look for opportunities in these areas, rather than focusing on headline numbers. Key risks include corporate credit market instability and geopolitics, but overall, the experts see a "very mild" recession and potential for growth in Asia.

images.alt_text: Joan Ng

site_title: Vietnam’s president quits, pinned for ministers’ ‘violations’
summary: Vietnamese President Nguyen Xuan Phuc has resigned after the ruling Communist Party blamed him for "violations and wrongdoing" by officials under his control while prime minister. Phuc, 68, held the largely ceremonial position of president for less than two years. The Communist Party accepted his resignation, but it's unclear if a replacement has been identified. The move comes as the party intensifies its anti-corruption drive, with 539 party members prosecuted or disciplined in 2022, and two deputy prime ministers dismissed in January.

images.alt_text: Economists warn Vietnam is facing headwinds, with weakening global demand already starting to impact its shipments in December.
The National Assembly voted to dismiss Deputy Prime Minister Vu Duc Dam from office during a four-day special session that began today (Jan 5).

site_title: Indonesia approves US$3.35b revised development plan for Eni’s Merakes fields
summary: Indonesia's upstream oil and gas regulator, SKK Migas, has approved a revised development plan for Eni's Merakes and Merakes East gas fields, with a total investment of $3.35 billion. The project, which started gas production in April 2021, is expected to increase production capacity to 440 million standard cubic feet per day and will provide additional reserves to meet Indonesia's energy demands. The fields are expected to remain onstream until 2032, supporting the country's goal of reaching 1 million barrels of oil per day and 12 billion standard cubic feet per day gas lifting by 2030.

site_title: China doctors say they are discouraged from citing Covid on death certificates
summary: China's doctors are being discouraged from citing COVID-19 as the cause of death on death certificates, according to a notice seen at a private hospital. The notice advises doctors to instead list an underlying disease as the main cause of death. To confirm a COVID-19 death, doctors must report it to superiors, who will conduct two levels of expert consultations before making a confirmation. This move is seen as a way for the Chinese government to downplay the impact of the pandemic.

images.alt_text: Concerns over data transparency were among the factors that prompted more than a dozen countries to demand pre-departure Covid tests from travellers arriving from China.
The virus has been spreading at a faster pace in China after the government relaxed controls in November and abruptly abandoned its Covid Zero policy in December.

site_title: Dalian iron ore slumps as China economic data dents appetite
summary: China's iron ore futures slumped 1.3% on Tuesday, following weak economic data for the country's fourth quarter, which showed a decline in growth to one of its worst levels in nearly half a century. The data, influenced by strict Covid-19 curbs and a property market slump, raised pressure on policymakers to unveil more stimulus this year.

images.alt_text: The reopening could be especially lucrative for Thailand’s baht and the South Korean won, both beneficiaries of Chinese tourism.

(FILES) This file photo taken on May 1, 2018 shows a worker handling steel cable at a steel factory in Lianyungang in China's eastern Jiangsu province.
China opened trade in iron ore futures to foreign investors on May 4, 2018 on the market of the north-eastern city of Dalian, aiming to boost its pricing clout for one of its top imports, in one additional signal of opening up amidst a trade row with the US. / AFP PHOTO / - / China OUT

site_title: Meyer Park en bloc sale relaunches at lower S$390m reserve price
summary: Meyer Park, a freehold sea-fronting condo in District 15, Singapore, has been relaunched for collective sale at a lower reserve price of S$390 million after two previous attempts failed to secure a sale. The 88-meter frontage offers unblocked views of two-storey landed homes to the north and sea views to the south. The site is zoned for residential use with a plot ratio of 2.8, and the successful buyer can consider developing luxurious seafront homes. The tender will close on February 8 at 3 pm.

images.alt_text: 曾四度寻求集体出售的Meyer Park项目，首次获得超过八成业主同意，以4亿2000万元求售。 （戴玉祥产业提供）Meyer Park in Marine Parade.
The site is presently occupied by condominium development Meyer Park, which was completed in the 1980s and houses 60 apartment units ranging from 168 sq m to 258 sq m.

site_title: Former Agritrade CFO gets 20 years jail for defrauding banks involving US$586 million in loans
summary: Former Agritrade CFO Lim Beng Kim was sentenced to 20 years in jail for defrauding over a dozen banks and causing US$586 million in losses. She pleaded guilty to deceiving lenders into believing Agritrade's financial statements were audited, resulting in at least US$586.5 million in loans being disbursed. The company has faced allegations of fraud against its CEO and founder, and is among a string of failures in Singapore's commodities sector.

images.alt_text: While serving as the chief financial officer of Agritrade, Lim instructed her subordinates to submit financial statements which were unaudited and false to the financial institutions.

site_title: The best month to buy stocks
summary: The January barometer effect, a long-standing stock market adage, suggests that the first two weeks of the year can predict the rest of the year's performance. However, statistics show that calendar effects are statistically hard to disprove, and more than a handful of effects exist. Despite this, a strong start to the year, including the Dow Jones Industrial Index's 3.5% gain, could indicate a positive year for the stock market. However, investors should be cautious of relying solely on calendar effects and focus on finding good stocks to hold for the long term.

images.alt_text: Money supply could become tighter next year, and we may want to be more circumspect about where we put it.

site_title: America’s must-win semiconductor war
summary: The US government has launched a significant effort to reverse America's decline in semiconductor production, with the passage of the CHIPS and Science Act, which includes $52 billion in funding for facilities and research. Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) has broken ground on a major plant in Phoenix and will increase its investment there to $40 billion. However, challenges remain, including the high cost of the Phoenix facility compared to its equivalent in Taiwan and concerns about the national security implications of relying on a single supplier.

images.alt_text: President Joe Biden discusses American Rescue Plan investments in regional and community economic strategies at the White House in Washington on Sept 2, 2022.
President Joe Biden signing into law the CHIPS and Science Act of 2022, in a ceremony on the South Lawn of the White House in Washington, August 2022.

Semiconductors have become nearly ubiquitous, but it shouldn't be left to government planners to decide which factories to build now in order to produce the types of high-end chips that will be needed a few years out.

A solar panel installation at a house in Madrid, Spain, on May 24, 2022. EU countries must use the green energy transition as an opportunity to set a fair minimum wage that provides a decent standard of living.

site_title: Luxury giant LVMH hits 400 billion euro in market value
summary: LVMH shares reached a record high, increasing its market value to 400 billion euros for the first time, cementing its lead as Europe's most valuable company. The luxury goods group benefited from China's fast reopening, but analysts predict further gains may be challenging due to tougher comparisons and a potential decline in the US dollar. LVMH chairman and CEO Bernard Arnault reshuffled top management earlier this month, solidifying his family's grip on the company.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: LVMH luxury group Chief Executive Bernard Arnault announces their 2019 results in Paris, France, January 28, 2020. REUTERS/Christian Hartmann/File Photo

site_title: Sri Lanka nears IMF bailout as India said to back debt plan
summary: Sri Lanka is nearing an International Monetary Fund (IMF) bailout, with India's support for the country's debt restructuring plan confirmed. The IMF is expected to approve a $2.9 billion loan program, which will provide much-needed funds to continue mending Sri Lanka's economy. The country still needs assurances from China, Japan, and the Paris Club members before the IMF board can approve the loan. This development brings optimism to the nation, which has been struggling with high inflation and elevated borrowing costs amid a recession.

site_title: South-east Asia food delivery GMV growth in 2022 slows to 5%: report
summary: South-east Asia's food delivery gross merchandise value (GMV) grew 5% to $16.3 billion in 2022, slowing from 30% and 183% growth in 2021 and 2020, respectively. Profitability became a focus for platforms, with capital markets demanding more profitability and border reopenings affecting dine-in services. Larger markets, such as Indonesia, Thailand, and Singapore, saw declines in GMV, while Malaysia, the Philippines, and Vietnam recorded growth. Food delivery platforms are now prioritizing cost optimization and exploring additional revenue streams to achieve profitability.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
Online grocers like RedMart are competing with incumbent supermarkets that possess institutional knowledge and experience in running a profitabke grocery business.
Appetite for food delivery dips after Singapore’s reopening, but still above pre-pandemic levels
Deliveroo's Singapore general manager Jason Parke said that the company is focused on profitable growth.

site_title: Poor economy shows China needs to own recovery
summary: China's economy, despite a re-opening, is forecasted to experience a slowdown or recession due to a major slowdown in the US and Europe. To boost growth, China needs a sustained effort to generate domestic demand, with getting people moving around again being a plus but unlikely to be sufficient. The People's Bank of China has expressed caution over stimulus measures, focusing on avoiding inflation. Despite low inflation, economists predict a rate cut in coming months to support the economy. Success in China's recovery will be defined by its domestic steps, and the country should not rely on external factors for growth.

images.alt_text: Travelers at Beijing Capital International Airport in Beijing, China, on Saturday, Jan. 14, 2023. There are growing concerns that this month’s Lunar New Year holiday will see Covid sweep through smaller cities and rural areas as hundreds of thousands of people travel home, with many finally able to reunite with family after three years. Source: Bloomberg
The funding should be mainly used for treatment, temporary work allowance for medical staff, vaccinations and improving medical treatment capabilities.
Ten experts interviewed by AFP forecast an average 2.7 per cent year-on-year rise in GDP for the world’s second-largest economy, a sharp plunge from China’s 2021 growth of more than 8 per cent.

site_title: UK jumps into top three countries for growth: PwC
summary: The UK has become the third-most important country for business leaders seeking growth, according to PwC's 26th annual poll. Despite a survey conducted in October and November, shortly after the UK's economic downturn, the UK ranked behind the US and China, but tied with Germany. The UK's strengths in technology and business-friendly conditions were cited as factors in its ranking. 18% of CEOs surveyed said the UK was important for revenue growth, double the proportion from 2020. British bosses were also more confident in their companies' revenue prospects than average.

images.alt_text: A person’s face is made up of 68 different points that frequently change position, according to scientist Mario Savvides, who co-authored a study on facial “landmarks” in 2017.
Strategists are optimistic about European stocks after they outperformed their US peers.

site_title: 3AC founders seek US$25m to set up new crypto marketplace
summary: Founders of bankrupt crypto hedge fund Three Arrows Capital (3AC) Su Zhu and Kyle Davies are seeking a US$25 million investment to set up a new crypto marketplace called GTX. The platform aims to "verify and tokenise" claims from bankrupt exchange FTX and other insolvent estates, allowing clients to access their capital and invest again. The project estimates the claims market size to be US$20 billion and plans to "dominate" the market within two to three months. The move comes amid controversy surrounding 3AC's collapse last year, which was attributed to a wave of collapses, including the Terra-Luna crash.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
The blowup of Three Arrows shook the digital-asset industry last year and put the interconnected nature of the sector on display.

Former FTX chief executive Sam Bankman-Fried, who faces fraud charges over the collapse of the bankrupt cryptocurrency exchange, walks from the Manhattan federal court after securing bail in New York City, US, December 22, 2022.

site_title: Beware of cyber fraudsters targeting global supply chain
summary: Cyber fraudsters are targeting the global supply chain, with international freight transport insurer TT Club stating that carrier fraud accounted for 84% of its claims involving fraud or deception in 2022. Organised crime gangs are using sophisticated tactics, including impersonating executives, creating fake carriers, and manipulating bank transfer details, to steal large amounts of money or cargo. TT Club is urging the industry to increase awareness and take steps to protect against these types of fraud, which can result in significant losses and undermine the security of the global supply chain.

images.alt_text: Investigations showed that a “significant proportion” of the reports lodged involved unauthorised overseas PayNow transfers.

site_title: Foxconn replaces iPhone business chief after tumultuous year
summary: Foxconn Technology Group has appointed Michael Chiang as the new head of its iPhone assembly business, succeeding Wang Charng-yang after a tumultuous year in China. This move is part of Chairman Young Liu's efforts to elevate younger executives to maintain supply chain leadership amidst growing competition from Chinese contenders. Chiang's appointment follows a recent promotion to chief of the A business group, as Wang steps back to focus on a board role. The move aims to prepare Foxconn for a post-Covid world.

images.alt_text: While recent financial incentives under Modi offered Apple a cost-efficient path to set up shop in India, the California-based company is still making a fraction of its iPhones in the nation.

(FILES) This file photo taken on May 27, 2010 shows Chinese workers in the Foxconn factory in Shenzhen, in southern China's Guangdong province. - Violent protests have broken out around Foxconn's vast iPhone factory in central China on November 23, 2022, as workers clashed with security personnel over Covid restrictions at the plant. (Photo by AFP)
While Taiwan’s assisted local chipmakers in the past with infrastructure construction and other measures, the island is now stepping up its efforts.

site_title: Traders can’t predict the market. Maybe their faces can
summary: Researchers at Carnegie Mellon University are developing a facial recognition system to predict price swings in the stock market. The system, which involves tracking traders' facial expressions and gestures, aims to identify correlations between emotional states and market volatility. A 12-month study involving 70 traders in the US will test the system, which could lead to an alert system for investment firms. The study raises concerns about the potential for facial analysis to be used to exploit traders and amplify herd-like behavior in the market.

images.alt_text: man, face, facial recognition
The prospect of banks using facial recognition has concerned some privacy experts.

HUMAN rights groups have urged video-conferencing company Zoom to scrap research on integrating emotion recognition tools into its products, saying the technology can infringe users' privacy and perpetuate discrimination.
Existing customers of the tools can keep using them for a year before they expire.

site_title: New ambassador programme to draw young talent to semiconductor industry
summary: Singapore's Semiconductor Industry Association (SSIA) has launched a new ambassador programme to attract young talent to the semiconductor sector. The program, called Semiconductor Active Youth, will pair industry leaders with selected youth ambassadors for one-on-one mentoring sessions. The goal is to encourage more graduates to join the sector, addressing SSIA's top priority of building a robust pipeline of talent. Major companies such as AMD and GlobalFoundries Singapore will participate in the initiative.

images.alt_text: Part of the weak outlook for Singapore's overall manufacturing sector is due to semiconductors, which contribute about a third of Singapore’s electronics output.

site_title: China travellers to make shorter trips and in smaller groups amid Covid-19 fears: Malaysia tourism players
summary: Malaysia's tourism industry players report a shift in travel patterns among Chinese tourists due to health safety concerns. Since China ended mandatory quarantines, bookings for shorter trips have increased, with most opting for smaller groups of 4-6 people staying in one place rather than sightseeing tours. The Malaysia Inbound Chinese Association has received around 200-300 bookings, with a focus on outdoor activities. This change in travel pattern is expected to remain due to ongoing concerns over public health.

images.alt_text: Tan Ai Leng
For services, China expects the number of international flights to rebound to the equivalent of 15 per cent-25 per cent of their pre-pandemic levels by the end of March.

site_title: Chinese chip giant weighs IPOs, land sales to slash debt burden
summary: Unigroup, a Chinese semiconductor giant, is exploring ways to reduce its debt burden through industrial property sales and initial public offerings (IPOs) for its subsidiaries, including Unisoc and Unicloud. The company, once affiliated with Tsinghua University, is now under new ownership after a US$9 billion takeover. Executives have discussed IPOs for the subsidiaries, which could lead to a prominent debut in China's semiconductor industry. This move aims to stave off creditors and stabilize the company after years of massive spending on building domestic giants like Yangtze Memory Technologies.

images.alt_text: Foxconn said in a statement to the Taipei stock exchange that Xingwei, 99 per cent controlled by its China-listed unit Foxconn Industrial Internet, has agreed to sell its holdings for at least 5.38 billion yuan.

site_title: Gold holds above US$1,900 per ounce on smaller US rate-hike bets
summary: Gold prices held above $1,900 per ounce, steady at $1,917.24 per ounce, as investors awaited the Federal Reserve's interest rate hike. Hopes of slower rate hikes buoyed gold, with prices reaching a high since late April 2022. The expected 25 basis point rate hike is seen as beneficial for gold, as lower rates decrease the opportunity cost of holding the non-yielding asset.

site_title: In investing, stick with the familiar while always learning
summary: A seasoned investor shares the importance of sticking to what's familiar in investing, while also being open to learning and exploring new markets. They cite their own experience with investing in a US exchange-traded fund (ETF) as a lesson in the potential risks of venturing out of one's comfort zone. The investor emphasizes the value of building domain expertise and finding time to learn about new markets, sectors, and geographic regions, highlighting the benefits of actively managing investments as one ages to keep the mind sharp and maintain mental well-being.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee
Cryptocurrencies had an awful 2022 as a number of the industry’s key projects combusted, wiping out billions.

site_title: China's Lunar New Year travel offers economic rebound from Covid crunch
summary: China's Lunar New Year travel offers a boost to the domestic economy as hundreds of thousands of people return to the country's hinterland, spending more on transportation, food, and accommodations. The travel rush, which is expected to see 2.1 billion passenger trips, marks an early sign of economic recovery after three years of Covid-19 restrictions. However, health experts warn of a potential broadening and deepening of the Covid outbreak, particularly affecting the elderly in rural villages. The WHO is seeking a more comprehensive accounting of death rates, citing concerns about under-reporting.

images.alt_text: Marquee international events returned to Singapore in 2022 as MICE tourism recovered with easing Covid restrictions.

site_title: Singapore prime office rents outperform most APAC cities in Q4: Knight Frank
summary: Singapore's prime office rents outperformed most Asia-Pacific cities in Q4, with a 1.7% quarterly increase and a 5.5% year-on-year increase. Rents rose S$10.69 per square foot, while vacancy dipped slightly to 5%. The city-state ranked third among 23 cities in the index, behind Auckland and Bangkok. Knight Frank projects an increasing 12-month rental outlook for Singapore, with rents expected to continue rising amid declining vacancy.

images.alt_text: Average rental in the area now stands at about S$10.69 per square foot per metre (psf pm).
Major transactions in Q4 include the S$1,988.9 million sale of mega suburban mall Jurong Point by Hong Kong's Link Reit.
Apac prime office rents seeing sustained recovery: Knight Frank

site_title: Nomura cuts around 18 Asia banking jobs as dealmaking slows: sources
summary: Nomura Holdings has cut 18 Asian banking jobs, primarily in China-focused investment roles, due to a slowdown in dealmaking activities in 2022. The layoffs affected multiple divisions within the investment banking function, including equities capital markets, debt capital markets, and corporate finance. The bank cited a sharp drop in global investment banking fee pools as the reason for the cuts, with a 63% decrease in equity capital market deals in 2022 compared to 2021. Nomura's international investment banking operations were also impacted, with redundancies in the US, Europe, the Middle East, and Africa.

images.alt_text: The majority of reductions are focused on areas where Nomura has limited scale.
In Asia, Nomura has hired about 50 relationship managers since 2020.

site_title: Japan’s ANA, JAL expand sustainable aviation fuel purchases with Itochu deal
summary: Japan's All Nippon Airways (ANA) and Japan Airlines (JAL) have expanded their sustainable aviation fuel purchases with a deal from Japanese trading house Itochu and US producer Raven SR. The agreement aims to support ANA's mid- and long-term carbon reduction goals and meets the airlines' targets of using 10% of their fuel from sustainable sources by 2030. Raven SR plans to start commercial production of sustainable aviation fuel in California by 2025, with a production capacity of 200,000 tons per year by 2034.

site_title: Hugosave’s parent to set up digital bank in Pakistan
summary: A Singapore-based consortium led by Atlas Consolidated, the parent company of Hugosave, has obtained a no-objection certificate from the State Bank of Pakistan to launch a new digital bank, HugoBank. The bank aims to serve financially underserved customers, offering services such as online account opening and fund transfer, at accessible price points. The goal is to increase bank account penetration in Pakistan to 85% within five years, addressing the issue of over half the population being unbanked. The consortium plans to launch HugoBank in the coming months.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
Komunal achieved a positive earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization (Ebitda) in October last year after its loans business expanded more than four times on the year.
UN Secretary-General Antonio Gutteres says Pakistan has been the victim of climate chaos and the global financial system.

site_title: Norway’s wealth fund buys 49% stake in Spanish renewables portfolio
summary: Norway's sovereign wealth fund has agreed to purchase a 49% stake in Spanish energy company Iberdola's renewable energy portfolio for 600 million euros. The portfolio consists of 12 renewable projects with an installed capacity of 1,265 megawatts, equivalent to the annual electricity consumption of 700,000 Spanish households. Iberdola will remain a co-owner and operator of the portfolio. This deal is part of Iberdola's plan to sell minority stakes in renewable developments to finance its climate action plan, which aims to produce 67% of Spain's electricity from renewables by 2026.

images.alt_text: The proposal for Singapore to draw critical energy supply from a source some 4,200 KM away through an undersea cable was deemed a hard sell from the get-go by market watchers.
India plans to sell the bonds in two auctions, on Jan 25 and Feb 9.
Australia has been slow in developing its offshore wind sector to replace a fleet of ageing coal plants that still provide most of its energy.

site_title: Bukit Sembawang kicks off sales at landed project Pollen Collection
summary: Bukit Sembawang Estates has started selling its new landed housing project Pollen Collection, with 24 units released for sale so far. The 132-unit development, comprising 128 terrace houses and 4 semi-detached houses, is priced from S$3.59 million for terraces and S$4.4 million for semi-detached houses. Construction is expected to take around three years, with the first phase expected to deliver vacant possession in Q3 2026. The project's CEO notes that the target market is families with children or multi-generational families looking to upgrade from HDB flats or private residences.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim
The Bukit Timah Link land parcel is on a site area of 4,611.1 sq m and comes with a maximum GFA of 13,834 sq m.
Simon Ang in front of his family home along Jalan Rindu

The landed property market looks set to continue at the current pace for the rest of 2022 as global geopolitical uncertainties persist. Total demand for landed homes could reach around 2,000 units and the URA price index for landed homes could gain some 10 per cent for the whole year, according to List Sotheby’s International Realty.

site_title: Indonesian fintech firm Komunal raises US$8.5m led by East Ventures
summary: Indonesian fintech firm Komunal has raised US$8.5 million in funding led by East Ventures, with plans to accelerate financial inclusion in tier 2 and 3 cities through its neo-rural bank services. The company aims to strengthen its ecosystem and increase financial inclusion for micro, small & medium enterprises.
