Komunal's transaction volume is expected to exceed US$500 million by 2023, following a four-fold expansion in its loans business last year.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
E-commerce aggregators are still bullish on the prospects for South-east Asia, while still looking for a slowdown on the horizon.

site_title: Investcorp targets Indonesia to expand South-east Asia footprint
summary: Investcorp, a Bahrain-based private equity firm, is expanding its presence in South-east Asia through multiple initiatives in Indonesia, including a partnership with the country's sovereign wealth fund. The firm's co-CEO, Hazem Ben-Gacem, mentioned two ongoing initiatives: expanding Indian dialysis service provider NephroPlus into Indonesia and acquiring a leading local specialty retailer. With Indonesia's natural resources and investment-friendly government, Ben-Gacem sees opportunities for growth in the country, particularly with a potential global economic slowdown.

images.alt_text: The partially snow-covered Schiahorn mountain, beyond the Congress Center, the venue for the World Economic Forum (WEF), in Davos, Switzerland, on Friday, Jan. 6, 2023. Though it’s perched at an altitude of 1,560 meters, this year’s rare winter heatwave saw the Swiss town of Davos basking in temperatures well above freezing in early January, with its mountainsides covered in dead, brown grass and hikers out with their dogs. Photographer: Francesca Volpi/Bloomberg

site_title: China’s 2022 property investment falls for first time since 1999
summary: China's property investment declined 10.0% year-on-year in 2022, the first drop since 1999, according to official data. Property sales by floor area fell 24.3% in 2022, the largest drop since 1992. New construction starts also declined 39.4% year-on-year, while funds raised by developers slumped 25.9% on the year. Chinese authorities have introduced support policies to relieve a liquidity squeeze affecting developers and delayed housing projects.

site_title: Singapore, Uzbekistan to strengthen cooperation in areas such as food security, digitalisation
summary: Singapore and Uzbekistan signed 18 memoranda of understanding to strengthen economic cooperation in areas such as food security, digitalisation, logistics, and urban planning. The move aims to foster economic growth and increase trade between the two countries. Singapore's Minister for Trade and Industry Gan Kim Yong expressed support for Uzbekistan's World Trade Organization (WTO) accession, which will open up more international trading opportunities. The two countries also plan to collaborate on education, tourism, and renewable energy.

images.alt_text: The KSDPA’s “expeditious” entry into force is reflective of Singapore and South Korea’s commitment towards integrating both countries’ digital ecosystems to unlock new growth opportunities for businesses, says the authorities.
Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong meeting Thai Prime Minister Prayut Chan-o-cha at the 29th APEC Economic Leaders' Meeting in Bangkok on Nov 18, 2022.

site_title: India's rising home prices, rentals pose new inflation threat
summary: India's rising home prices and rentals pose a new inflation threat to the country's central bank. Housing rentals and ancillary costs have a 10.1% weightage in the consumer price inflation basket, near three-year highs. Urban housing inflation rose to 4.5% year-on-year in December, and core inflation remains close to 6%. Analysts warn that sticky rental prices could spill over into core inflation, despite the RBI's comfort zone of 2-6% inflation.

images.alt_text: Flats under construction in Noida, a Delhi suburb. Most millennials looking for affordable housing in Indian cities have to depend on new highrise buildings away from central business districts.

Average house prices in India were expected to rise 5.0 per cent over each of the next three years, lagging the current consumer price inflation rate, after increasing by 7 per cent in 2022, according to the Nov 9-Dec 1 poll.
A newly built housing estate can be seen next to another under construction in a suburb of Auckland in New Zealand, June 24, 2017.

site_title: UK pay growth speeds up again as BoE frets about inflation
summary: UK pay growth accelerated to 6.4% in the September-to-November period, the largest increase since 2001, according to the Office for National Statistics. This rise is expected to fuel inflation concerns, prompting the Bank of England to consider a potential interest rate hike. The data also showed a gap in pay growth between private and public sectors, with private sector pay rising 7.1% compared to 3.3% in the public sector. The BOE is set to raise interest rates for a tenth time, with markets pricing in a potential half-point hike.

site_title: Australia consumer mood brightens for second month in a row
summary: Australia's consumer sentiment index rose 5.0% in January, its largest monthly gain since April 2021, according to the Westpac-Melbourne Institute index. The increase is attributed to the absence of an interest rate hike by the Reserve Bank of Australia in January, providing temporary relief for borrowers. Despite the gain, pessimists still outnumber optimists, with the index reading of 84.3.

images.alt_text: Visitors at Pitt Street Mall in Sydney, Australia, on Wednesday, Dec. 15, 2021. Australian household sentiment declined this month as concerns mounted about the new omicron variant of coronavirus in the nation's recently re-opened eastern states of New South Wales and Victoria. Photographer: Brent Lewin/Bloomberg
The Aussie hit an intraday high of US$0.7019, its highest since Aug 17, after having advanced 1.4 per cent last week to as far as US$0.6994.

site_title: DBS, IMDA launch digital-inclusivity movement
summary: DBS Foundation and the Infocomm Media Development Authority of Singapore (IMDA) launched a two-year digital-inclusivity campaign to close digital-literacy gaps among Singapore's elderly, youths, hawkers, and individuals with special needs. The first set of 12 digital literacy workshops for senior citizens covered digital payment topics, reaching 250 participants. The campaign aims to support projects that enhance digital awareness, learning, and adoption among 100,000 beneficiaries, with the DBS Foundation donating S$1 million to the DfL Fund.

images.alt_text: At least 2,500 of the bank’s employees will be deployed to run some 800 workshops at DBS/POSB branches.

site_title: Evergrande is said to propose two offshore restructuring options
summary: Evergrande Group, China's most indebted developer, has proposed two offshore restructuring options to creditors, aiming to extend payment deadlines on unsecured debt. The options include instalment payments on principal with a 12-year repayment term, or swapping debt into shares via new hybrid securities. The terms of the proposals are subject to feedback from major creditors and could change. This move comes as the firm faces US$16.6 billion of outstanding dollar notes and has defaulted on dollar bonds over a year ago.

images.alt_text: In its Jan 16 resignation letter to Evergrande’s audit committee and board, PwC noted it still hadn’t received information relating to “significant matters” of the 2021 audit.

site_title: Basis trade is back in Japan’s bond market as BOJ meeting nears
summary: Japanese bond yields are under upward pressure ahead of the Bank of Japan's (BOJ) two-day meeting, with speculation that the central bank may abandon its yield-curve control policy. The spread between 10-year debt and futures has widened, fueling basis trades that aim to profit from the difference. The BOJ has purchased record amounts of debt to support prices, and investors are demanding more from its lending program, indicating arbitrage trading is underway. The BOJ's decision to widen its trading band for 10-year bonds last month has fueled bets on further changes, potentially leading to higher yields if the yield-curve control policy ends.

images.alt_text: In the US, the Securities and Exchange Commission signalled it would step up its crackdown on crypto firms, while Germany’s securities watchdog has called for global rules to ensure financial stability.

site_title: Giant legs of Vietnam’s ‘dragon chicken’ a new year delicacy
summary: Vietnam's "dragon chicken" breed, known for its thick, lumpy legs, is a delicacy during the Vietnamese New Year, Tet. The Dong Tao chicken, bred in northern Vietnam, can fetch up to $2,000 a head and is prized for its tough, chewy meat and low fat content. The birds are raised on a diet of corn and rice, and their freedom to roam is believed to contribute to their strength and flavor. The meat is often served boiled, fried, or stewed, and the thicker the legs, the tastier they are considered.

images.alt_text: At Jade in The Fullerton Hotel, reunion dinner slots have been fully booked since the first week of January, with an additional venue opened to meet higher demand, said The Fullerton Hotels and Resorts general manager Gino Tan.

site_title: Indonesia close to EV deals with BYD Group and Tesla: minister
summary: Indonesia is nearing agreements with China's BYD Group and US carmaker Tesla to invest in electric vehicle production facilities, driven by its rich nickel resources and efforts to reduce exports. Coordinating Minister Luhut Pandjaitan stated that major automakers, including Hyundai, are finalizing deals in the country. This move aims to capitalize on Indonesia's abundant raw materials and establish itself as a key player in the EV industry.

images.alt_text: Amazon has launched dozens of private label goods in the past year.

site_title: Amro cuts growth forecast for Asean+3 on weakness in China and Japan
summary: The Asean+3 Macroeconomic Research Office (Amro) has revised its growth forecast for the region downward, citing weaker growth in China-Hong Kong and Japan. The region is projected to have grown 3.3% in 2022, lower than the 3.7% estimated in October. However, Asean economies, led by Malaysia and Vietnam, are expected to have grown 5.6% in 2022. For 2023, the region is projected to grow 4.3%, with China's reopening expected to boost growth, while the US and Europe's economic slowdown will continue to impact the region.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan
The reopening could be especially lucrative for Thailand’s baht and the South Korean won, both beneficiaries of Chinese tourism.
People near a mine operated by MMG Las Bambas, in a region where locals claim mining activity has negatively affected crop yields and killed livestock, outside of Cusco, Peru October 14, 2021.
The previous government presented a tighter budget for 2023 in October.

site_title: Nissan, Renault on track to complete deal to revamp alliance
summary: Nissan and Renault are nearing a deal to rebalance their 20-year alliance, with Renault aiming to reduce its 43% stake in Nissan to 15%. Final negotiations are underway for Nissan to invest in Renault's electric-vehicle business, code-named Ampere, with a potential valuation of $14.3 billion. The deal is expected to be completed this month, with Renault planning an initial public offering for Ampere in the second half of the year. The agreement is seen as a response to the lopsided ownership structure and potential friction between the two companies.

images.alt_text: Renault is looking for Nissan to invest in an electric-vehicle (EV) business that it will carve out of its operations.

site_title: Renault, Geely look to bring Aramco into engine venture: sources
summary: Renault and Geely are finalizing a deal to bring Saudi Arabian oil producer Aramco as an investor and partner to develop and supply petrol engines and hybrid technologies. Aramco may take a 20% stake in the joint venture, leaving Renault and Geely with 40% each. The venture aims to produce over 5 million low-emission and hybrid engines annually, focusing on advanced four-cylinder engines and hybrid systems. The deal, codenamed "Horse" by Renault and "Rubik" by Geely, is seen as a strategic move to expand beyond electric vehicles and reduce CO2 emissions.

images.alt_text: Renault is in the middle of a complex split of its business into five different units.

site_title: With Malaysia’s national debt at RM1.5t, it cannot be business as usual, says Anwar
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim emphasized the need for fiscal discipline amidst rising sovereign debt levels, which reached RM1.5 trillion. The government will prioritize technology, green economy, and boosting small and medium-sized enterprises, while maintaining a budget deficit of 5.8% in 2022. Anwar stated that "it cannot be business as usual" and plans to expedite priority projects and plug leakages in the budget review. The revised 2023 budget will be tabled in Parliament on February 24.

images.alt_text: All but one of 27 economists in the Jan 10-16 Reuters poll forecast the central bank to hike its overnight policy rate to 3.00 per cent, where it was before the pandemic, at its meeting on Jan 19.

site_title: Europeans launch alliance for climate-friendly cities
summary: European culture ministers from 31 countries have launched the "Davos Baukultur Alliance" to create more sustainable and climate-friendly buildings and urban landscapes. The alliance aims to pursue goals set out in the 2018 Davos Declaration, which emphasizes the importance of high-quality building culture for sustainable development. The alliance will help meet planning and construction challenges, including transitioning to more sustainable energy sources, and combat overdevelopment to enable cities and villages to evolve to meet the needs of an inclusive and diverse society.

images.alt_text: The partially snow-covered Schiahorn mountain, beyond the Congress Center, the venue for the World Economic Forum (WEF), in Davos, Switzerland, on Friday, Jan. 6, 2023. Though it’s perched at an altitude of 1,560 meters, this year’s rare winter heatwave saw the Swiss town of Davos basking in temperatures well above freezing in early January, with its mountainsides covered in dead, brown grass and hikers out with their dogs. Photographer: Francesca Volpi/Bloomberg
The theme of the 2023 World Economic Forum in Davos this week is 'Cooperation in a fragmented world'.
Chinese Vice-Premier Liu He and US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen conducted extensive exchanges on the macroeconomic situation and bilateral and multilateral cooperation

site_title: Indonesia central bank sees 2022 Q4 GDP growth at 4.81%
summary: Indonesia's central bank expects 2022 Q4 GDP growth at 4.81%, slower than the previous quarter's 5.72%. The full-year 2022 growth is projected at 5.25%, and 2023 growth is forecast to slow to 5.03%. Inflation in December was 5.51%, driven by fuel and food prices, but is expected to come down to 3-4% in the second half of 2023. The central bank may review its monetary policy later this week, with a possible 25 basis point interest rate hike.

images.alt_text: Inflation has been largely cooling since September, but December’s reading of 5.51 per cent was still above Bank Indonesia’s target range of 2 per cent to 4 per cent that the central bank established in 2005.

site_title: China’s economy set to slow sharply in Q4, policymakers face post-pandemic test
summary: China's economy is expected to slow sharply in the fourth quarter due to stringent Covid-19 curbs, with GDP growth forecast to be 1.8% in October-December, down from 3.9% in the third quarter. This would be the worst showing since 1976, and 2022 growth would be one of its worst in nearly half a century. Economists expect growth to rebound to 4.9% in 2023, driven by a relaxation of Covid curbs and policy support, with the government aiming for economic growth of at least 5% in 2023.

images.alt_text: The funding should be mainly used for treatment, temporary work allowance for medical staff, vaccinations and improving medical treatment capabilities.
The meetings, incentives, conventions and exhibitions (mice) and corporate travel segments are expected to pick up first, followed by the return of Chinese leisure tourists.
Kantamanto market in Accra, Ghana, Nov 30, 2022. Ghana recently became only the fourth country to apply for support under the G20's Common Framework facility.

site_title: Asia: Stocks struggle, even as China growth tops forecasts
summary: Asian stocks fell on Tuesday, despite China's economy beating forecasts with a 3.0% growth rate, the slowest in four decades. The growth was driven by a rebound in retail sales and a healthy fourth-quarter reading. However, regional markets struggled to maintain the momentum, with Hong Kong, Shanghai, and other markets in negative territory. Analysts remain optimistic about the outlook, citing a potential strong rebound in 2023. The Bank of Japan is set to make a key policy decision on Wednesday, and the annual Davos summit will also focus on finance officials' speeches and corporate earnings reports.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong was among the biggest gainers and is not up around 10 per cent since the start of the year, while Shanghai, Sydney, Seoul, Singapore, Taipei, Manila, Wellington and Jakarta also rose on Monday.
The ComfortDelGro office building along Braddell Road on 27 July 2022.

site_title: China’s economy expands 3% in 2022 as zero-Covid policy hurts growth
summary: China's economy expanded 3% in 2022, below its original target of 5.5%, due to the impact of zero-Covid policies and business disruptions. Despite this, analysts expect a recovery in 2023 as the country reopens and implements policy stimulus. Key indicators, such as retail sales and industrial production, declined in December, but high-frequency indicators suggest a quick recovery of economic activities. Analysts predict a sustained economic recovery in 2023, with some expecting growth to reach 4.3% in 2023 and 7.1% in 2024.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan
Airfares from China are now 160 per cent higher than before the pandemic, data from travel firm ForwardKeys shows, due to limited supply.

site_title: Tourism receipts total S$13.8b-S$14.3b in 2022; higher forecasts for 2023: STB
summary: Singapore's tourism receipts reached an estimated S$13.8 billion to S$14.3 billion in 2022, about half of the 2019 pre-pandemic level, with 6.3 million international visitor arrivals. The tourism growth momentum is expected to continue in 2023, with estimated 12-14 million visitors and S$18-21 billion in tourism receipts. The Singapore Tourism Board (STB) aims to fill 3,000 job vacancies and increase traffic from China to pre-pandemic levels, with a focus on marketing in markets including China and promoting deeper experiences.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan

本地餐饮业者自冠病疫情暴发后，首次迎来四个大型实体行业展，三天的活动预计将吸引3000人参与。亚洲餐馆行业展（Restaurant Asia 2021）、亚洲咖啡行业展（Cafe Asia 2021）、国际咖啡与茶叶展（International Coffee & Tea Industry Expo 2021）及亚洲烘焙与甜食展（Sweets & Bakes Asia 2021），2021年11月18日起在滨海湾金沙会展中心举行。
Sporting events like SailGP will help put Singapore on the map said Minister of State for Culture, Community and Sport, Alvin Tan.
The return of Chinese travellers is an economic boost that the global tourism and retail sectors have been missing.

site_title: Bank Indonesia nears end of rate-hike cycle but poised to deliver 25 bps interest rate hike: poll
summary: Bank Indonesia is expected to deliver a 25 basis points interest rate hike on January 19 to bring inflation under control, despite a cooling trend since September. Inflation remains above the central bank's target range of 2-4%, with a forecast of 4.1% this year and 3% by the end of 2024. The rate hike is seen as a softer approach, with no clear majority predicting a peak rate of 6% or higher by end-March. The move is expected to have a limited impact on economic growth, which is forecast to slow to 4.8% this year and 5% in 2024.

images.alt_text: Exports from Indonesia rose 6.58 per cent on a yearly basis to US$23.83 billion, roughly in line with the poll’s forecast of a 6.65 per cent increase.

site_title: Singapore exports down 20.6% in December in third straight month of contraction
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) contracted 20.6% year-on-year in December, extending the third consecutive month of decline. The decline was driven by falls in non-electronic shipments and deliveries to top 10 markets, including mainland China and Indonesia. Electronic exports also declined, with integrated circuits, disk media products, and PC parts experiencing significant drops. Total trade fell 7.7% year-on-year, with exports down 7.1% and imports down 8.2%. The decline may lead to a downward revision in Singapore's GDP figures for trade-related services.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
The Purchasing Managers' Index dipped 0.1 point to 49.7 in December, the fourth consecutive month of contraction in overall activity.
NODX to Singapore’s top 10 markets shrink overall in November, mainly due to mainland China, where exports are down 31.2 per cent; Hong Kong, down 41 per cent; and Malaysia, down 12.9 per cent.

site_title: Business outlook sours in Canada, complicating interest-rate path
summary: Canada's business outlook indicator fell to 0.07 in the fourth quarter, from 1.74 previously, indicating a pessimistic sentiment among firms. About 70% of businesses expect a recession, and more expect sales to decline. The data suggests the Bank of Canada may be close to ending its interest rate hikes, but a premature pause in 2023 could be detrimental. Inflation expectations remain elevated, and consumers expect earnings to not catch up with price pressures, with about half of households anticipating a negative impact from a potential recession.

images.alt_text: The vacancy rate in downtown Toronto, Canada’s financial capital, rose to 13.6 per cent, the highest since the third quarter of 2003.

site_title: Germany, Italy GDP will fall below pre-Covid level, Moody’s says
summary: Moody's predicts a "mild recession" in the eurozone this year, with Germany, Italy, and Slovakia expected to see their GDP fall below pre-pandemic levels in 2023. The ratings company forecasts 60% of euro area sovereigns will be in recession, citing stagflation risks for southern European countries. While some support measures may soften the effects, Moody's warns of severe credit consequences for affected nations.

site_title: Brokers’ take: DBS downgrades iFast to ‘fully valued’ amid reduced earnings estimates
summary: DBS Group Research downgraded its call on iFast Corporation from "hold" to "fully valued" due to reduced earnings estimates and increased operating costs resulting from a delay in the Hong Kong Pension platform. Analyst Ling Lee Keng slashed the target price to S$3.98 from S$4, citing a 19.5% year-on-year increase in operating costs. DBS expects iFast's share price to weaken in the near term, especially after its recent rebound in late 2022.

images.alt_text: Lim Chung Chun, chief executive officer of iFast Corporation, advises investors to endure the teething losses of iFast’s recent acquisitions.
Lim Chung Chun, chief executive officer of iFast Corporation
Lim Chung Chun, chief executive officer of iFast Corporation. The company has embarked on a 4-pillar plan to grow its assets under administration over the next 5 years.

Lim Chung Chun, CEO of iFast Corp. iFast noted that on Aug 15, the South China Morning Post had published an article on the upcoming e-pension platform of Hong Kong’s Mandatory Provident Fund, for which the tender was awarded to PCCW Solutions.

site_title: BOE sceptical over digital pound as eurozone backs work on digital euro
summary: Bank of England Governor Andrew Bailey expressed skepticism over the need for a digital pound, questioning its necessity for now. This comes as eurozone finance ministers backed further work on a digital euro. The Bank is updating its real-time gross settlement system, but Bailey noted that retail payment systems do not require an upgrade at the moment. A digital euro is expected to complement, not replace cash, with an "offline functionality" to be explored for wider use and financial inclusion.

images.alt_text: Officials at the BOE estimate the UK is now in recession, thought the economy is slightly stronger than it anticipated in November.

site_title: Marks and Spencer plans 3,400 new jobs after Covid axe
summary: Marks and Spencer (M&S) plans to create over 3,400 new jobs in the UK after axing 7,000 positions during the pandemic. The retailer will open 20 new large stores across the country, investing £480 million. The new jobs are part of a recovery plan following a bumper Christmas period, but cost pressures and macroeconomic headwinds remain challenges. Shares in M&S rose 2.7% following the announcement, but analysts question whether the retailer can sustain the momentum.

images.alt_text: Companies in Japan facing the fastest pace of inflation in decades, forcing them to consider wage hikes to retain and motivate employees.

site_title: Move over Ben Franklin: Laser lightning rod electrifies scientists
summary: Scientists have developed a high-powered laser system that can divert lightning strikes, potentially revolutionizing lightning protection. Building on Benjamin Franklin's 18th-century innovation, the Laser Lightning Rod uses a laser aimed at the sky to redirect lightning. The technology has the potential to safeguard critical infrastructure, such as power stations, airports, and wind farms, which are often damaged or destroyed by lightning strikes. With further development, the Laser Lightning Rod could save billions of dollars in damage and thousands of lives annually.

images.alt_text: In a brief moment lasting less than 100 trillionths of a second, 2.05 megajoules of energy – roughly the equivalent of a pound of TNT – bombarded a hydrogen pellet in a small cylinder about the size of a pencil eraser.
Scientists have warned that climbing temperatures have wrought major changes to ocean stability faster than previously thought

site_title: China’s population shrinks for the first time since 1961
summary: China's population declined for the first time since 1961, falling to 1.41175 billion people at the end of 2022, a 0.15% drop from the previous year. The country's birth rate hit a record low of 6.77 births per 1,000 people in 2022, down from 7.52 births in 2021. A death rate of 7.37 per 1,000 people also reached its highest level since 1976. China's one-child policy and high education costs are cited as major factors contributing to the demographic downturn.

images.alt_text: Avolon, the world's second-largest jet lessor, says that Asia will drive the aviation sector's rebound this year.
Airfares from China are now 160 per cent higher than before the pandemic, data from travel firm ForwardKeys shows, due to limited supply.
The meetings, incentives, conventions and exhibitions (mice) and corporate travel segments are expected to pick up first, followed by the return of Chinese leisure tourists.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SIA, ISOTeam
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) reported a 11.7% month-on-month increase in passengers in December, with 2.7 million flying on SIA and Scoot. SIA shares closed down 0.5% due to the announcement. ISOTeam's wholly-owned subsidiary has been ordered to stop work-at-height activities following a foreign worker's death, affecting its shares which rose 5.4% before the announcement.

site_title: Singapore stocks open lower on Tuesday, STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks opened 0.1% lower on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) dipping 2.86 points to 3,280.74. Gainers outnumbered losers 62 to 35, despite gains in Europe. The decline follows a 7.7% trade decline in December and 7.1% drop in total exports. Notable movers included Oceanus, which rose 14.3%, and MarcoPolo Marine, which remained unchanged.

images.alt_text: In its operational update on Monday (J noted robust group passenger traffic and load factors across all route regions.

site_title: EU vows to protect European industry to counter US subsidies
summary: The European Union has vowed to protect its industry by taking "decisive steps" to counter massive US subsidies under the Inflation Reduction Act, which includes $370 billion in subsidies for green energy and electric cars. The EU's economy commissioner, Paolo Gentiloni, announced plans to establish a European sovereignty fund to support members, while some EU countries, including France, call for a common subsidy scheme. The bloc's members are divided over how to respond, with concerns over a trade war and fragmentation in the single market.

images.alt_text: EU leaders agreed last March that Europe must cut its dependence on outside suppliers of energy, critical raw materials, semiconductors, drugs and food.
Germany's finance minister Christian Lindner says that he is “very much concerned” about a possible ban on inducements.
Predicting a negative outlook for sovereign creditworthiness in the eurozone this year, Moody's said that the region faces a “mild recession.”

site_title: Airlines face hurdles to cashing in on China’s reopening
summary: Airfares from China have skyrocketed 160% since the pandemic, mainly due to limited supply. As China's borders reopen, US and European airlines are poised to benefit from pent-up demand for travel. However, route approvals, new Covid-19 testing rules, and insufficient large aircraft remain hurdles to increasing sales. China's tourism market, worth $255 billion in 2019, is expected to return, but airlines face significant challenges in capitalizing on this growth.

images.alt_text: The return of Chinese travellers is an economic boost that the global tourism and retail sectors have been missing.
Avolon, the world's second-largest jet lessor, says that Asia will drive the aviation sector's rebound this year.

site_title: Europe: Shares near 9-month high as new year rally continues
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index closed at a near-nine-month high, up 0.5% at 454.6, driven by a new year rally fueled by hopes of a China economic rebound and easing prices pressures. The index has gained 6.6% since the start of the year, with real estate and retail stocks contributing to the gains. European blue-chip indices rose, with Britain's FTSE 100 inching closer to its record high, while Germany's DAX and France's CAC 40 also reached near-one-year highs.

images.alt_text: Strategists are optimistic about European stocks after they outperformed their US peers.

site_title: Brokers’ take: UOBKH raises SingPost target to S$0.58 on Australia expansion
summary: UOB Kay Hian (UOBKH) raised its target price for Singapore Post (SingPost) from S$0.52 to S$0.58, maintaining a "hold" call. The research house forecasts SingPost's revenue to reach S$2.2 billion in FY2024 and S$2.3 billion in FY2025, driven by its increased stake in Australian subsidiary Freight Management Holdings. Analyst Llelleythan Tan expects SingPost's profitability to boost from the first quarter of 2024, citing favorable tailwinds from China's relaxed Covid-19 policies and robust operating profit growth in FMH.

images.alt_text: Upon completion of the transaction, SingPost’s total stake in FMH will increase from 51 per cent currently, to 88 per cent.

site_title: New Zealand business confidence at lowest since 1974
summary: New Zealand's business confidence has reached its lowest level since 1974, according to a private think tank. In the December quarter, a net 70% of firms surveyed expected general business conditions to deteriorate, with 73% expecting worsened business conditions on a seasonally adjusted basis. This is attributed to higher interest rates, cost pressures, and soft demand, following the hawkish central bank meeting in November. Builders and retailers were the most downbeat, with many firms reducing staff and investment plans.

images.alt_text: Property prices have tumbled as the RBNZ raises interest rates to combat soaring inflation.

site_title: Malaysia central bank to hike rates to 3.00% on Thursday: poll
summary: Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara Malaysia, is set to hike its overnight policy rate to 3.00% on January 19, its fifth consecutive quarter-point hike, to control high inflation and support the struggling currency. The rate hike is in line with forecasts from 26 out of 27 economists polled, with inflation expected to average 3.0% this year, an upgrade from 2.8% in October. The move aims to keep inflation under check, despite a slowdown in global demand due to China's economic slowdown.

images.alt_text: EPF, one of the world’s biggest pension funds with total assets of RM1.01 trillion, is looking to sell assets held by its Malaysian education real estate investment trust, Alpha Reit.
When the 4km rail shuttle service is ready, it will take five minutes to travel from Woodlands to Johor Bahru and vice versa.

site_title: Japan pushes global counterparts to regulate crypto like banks
summary: Japan is urging global regulators to treat cryptocurrencies as strictly as traditional banks, following the collapse of FTX and other scandals. Deputy Director-General Mamoru Yanase called for consistent global regulation, citing loose governance and lax controls as causes of the problems. Japan's regulator has urged US, European, and other countries to subject cryptocurrency exchanges to similar supervision as banks and brokerages, and has suggested creating a multinational resolution mechanism for large crypto companies.

images.alt_text: This photo illustration shows a person counting out Japanese 10,000 yen banknotes (75 USD) in Tokyo on June 8, 2022. - The dollar fetched 133.03 yen in Asian trade on June 8, its highest in two decades. (Photo by Behrouz MEHRI / AFP)

site_title: Global recession in 2023 seen as likely in WEF survey
summary: The World Economic Forum (WEF) survey found that 18% of chief economists consider a global recession "extremely likely" in 2023, more than twice as many as the previous survey. Two-thirds of private and public sector economists expect a global recession, with high inflation, low growth, high debt, and fragmentation being major concerns. The survey also found that supply chain disruptions are not expected to significantly impact business activity in 2023, and a majority (68%) expect the cost-of-living crisis to become less severe by the end of the year.

images.alt_text: The scarcity of new jobs will hit countries at a time when many are still recovering from the economic shock of the global pandemic and the coronavirus is tearing through China after Beijing lifted tight lockdown restrictions.

site_title: Philippines says 2022 GDP likely grew much faster than 6.5%-7.5%
summary: The Philippines is likely to have experienced faster-than-expected GDP growth in 2022, with a possible expansion of 6.5% to 7.5%, according to Finance Secretary Benjamin Diokno. The country's strong manufacturing sector, stable banking system, and record low unemployment are contributing factors. Despite a potential slowdown in the global economy, the Philippines' strong economic fundamentals are expected to mitigate the impact, with growth forecast to reach 6.5% in 2023. The government plans to invest at least 5-6% of GDP in infrastructure.

images.alt_text: Philippine Photographer: Veejay Villafranca/Bloomberg

site_title: Goldman, UBS join bullish bets on global assets as China reopens
summary: China's reopening from COVID-19 curbs is expected to boost global assets, with forecasts predicting a 20% gain in Chinese equities and oil prices potentially surpassing US$100 a barrel. Emerging-market stocks and Asian currencies, such as Thailand's baht and South Korea's won, are also expected to benefit. The resumption of Chinese economic activity is expected to unleash over US$836 billion of excess savings and ease fears of a global downturn. However, some analysts caution that the US Federal Reserve's hawkish stance will remain a dominant theme for financial markets.

images.alt_text: Tourists visit the Grand Palace, one of the top tourist attraction spots as Thailand is expecting arrivals of Chinese tourists after China reopens its borders amid the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic, in Bangkok, Thailand, January 7, 2023. REUTERS/Athit Perawongmetha
In an earlier session, Dr He Dong, deputy director for monetary and capital markets at the International Monetary Fund (IMF), described 2023 to be a challenging year for monetary policy.

site_title: Biden calls Republican lawmakers ‘fiscally demented’
summary: US President Joe Biden criticized Republican lawmakers as "fiscally demented" for proposing legislation that would enrich the wealthy while increasing the tax burden on the middle class. He claimed that the reality of their spending habits is different from their public portrayal as fiscal conservatives. Biden's comments come as Republicans now control the House of Representatives, setting the stage for a potential clash on budget and spending priorities.

images.alt_text: “So the Senate is going to have to recognise the fact that we’re not going to budge until we see meaningful reform with respect to spending.” House Oversight Committee chairman James Comer said.
Chinese Vice-Premier Liu He and US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen conducted extensive exchanges on the macroeconomic situation and bilateral and multilateral cooperation

Last year, Washington passed the landmark Inflation Reduction Act (IRA) that contains around US$370 billion in subsidies for green energy, as well as tax cuts for US-made electric cars and batteries, to speed up the transition to a low-carbon economy.

site_title: Binance to allow crypto collateral off exchange for institutional users
summary: Binance, the world's largest crypto exchange, will allow institutional investors to keep collateral for leveraged positions off the platform. This move aims to alleviate concerns caused by the collapse of FTX, with users now able to post collateral with Binance Custody, a separate entity registered in Lithuania. This change will enable users to manage risks and diversify on-exchange risks, as Binance's institutional arm experiences a 17.4% increase in new clients in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Yellen sets surprise meeting with China’s Liu in Switzerland
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen is set to meet Chinese Vice Premier Liu He in Zurich on January 18, exchanging views on macroeconomic developments and economic issues. The meeting aims to strengthen economic and financial policy coordination and implement agreements made during a summit between Chinese President Xi Jinping and US President Joe Biden. Despite tensions over trade, human rights, and Taiwan, the meeting could be a step towards a modest thawing of relations between the two governments.

images.alt_text: The exchange between Chinese Vice Premier Liu He and US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen came as President Joe Biden considers lifting some tariffs on imports from China to try and ease soaring inflation.

site_title: Canada home prices see record drop as high rates hit buyers
summary: Canada's benchmark home price fell 1.6% in December to C$730,600, marking the largest peak-to-trough decline since 2005. The 13.2% decrease since February's peak is the largest calendar-year drop since records began. Rising interest rates have priced out buyers, leading to a 39% decline in transactions in December. Economists predict a recession in the first part of the year, with mortgage costs remaining high and job losses making it harder for people to keep up with loan payments.

images.alt_text: The central bank’s business outlook indicator fell to 0.07 in the fourth quarter, from a revised 1.74 previously.

site_title: France to push for ‘Made in Europe’ strategy at Feb EU summit
summary: France is pushing for the European Union to adopt a "Made in Europe" industrial strategy to reduce dependence on outside suppliers and retain companies involved in key sectors. The proposal, set to be discussed at an EU summit on Feb 9-10, aims to cut dependence on outside suppliers of energy, critical raw materials, semiconductors, and food by 2030. The strategy would include four pillars: EU targets for production goals, simplified permitting, state aid, and EU funding for sensitive sectors. France seeks to reassure businesses that the EU is committed to strengthening the bloc's economic attractiveness and preventing companies from moving outside Europe.

site_title: Evergrande says PwC resigns after 2021 audit disagreements
summary: Evergrande Group announced that PwC has resigned as its auditor due to disagreements over the scope of work for the 2021 audit. The resignation was prompted by PwC's lack of access to "significant matters" such as cash flow forecasts, property values, and consolidated financial statements. This move adds to the pressure on Evergrande, a developer at the center of China's property crisis.

images.alt_text: Evergrande is slated to meet in Hong Kong with members from an ad-hoc group of dollar-bond holders, the first of its kind since the company became a defaulter more than a year ago.

site_title: ISOTeam unit hit with suspensions after death of foreign worker at Bedok condo
summary: ISOTeam unit ISOTeam C&P has been suspended from hiring new foreign workers for three months and from conducting work-at-height activities and operating suspended scaffolds at a Bedok condominium following the death of a 37-year-old Myanmar national who fell four storeys while painting. The incident, the first workplace fatality in 2023, is under investigation by the Ministry of Manpower and Singapore Police Force. The company is reviewing its policies and procedures to assess improvements.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
For listed companies, ensuring a safe working environment also ties in with environmental, social and governance (ESG) responsibilities.

site_title: German defence minister quits in blow to Scholz
summary: German Defence Minister Christine Lambrecht, 57, has resigned amid speculation over her future, citing intense media scrutiny as a distraction. Chancellor Olaf Scholz has accepted her resignation, praising her service and promising to name a successor swiftly. Lambrecht's departure is a blow to Scholz's government as it considers crucial decisions on arming Ukraine, including supplying Leopard battle tanks. The Social Democrats will appoint a successor, with potential candidates including SPD defence expert Eva Hoegl and former SPD leader Andrea Nahles.

images.alt_text: Chancellor Olaf Scholz has been subject to a barrage of open letters on the issue of how Germany should position itself in the Russia-Ukraine war.

site_title: Teachers in England and Wales announce strike over pay
summary: Teachers in England and Wales have announced a series of strikes over pay, with the National Education Union voting overwhelmingly to walk out. The strikes, set to begin on February 1, will affect schools for four days, amid calls for an above-inflation pay rise. The union's leaders are set to meet the education minister on Wednesday, as public sector workers continue a wave of walkouts to address double-digit inflation. The strikes come after similar actions by nurses, paramedics, and ambulance workers, putting pressure on the National Health Service.

images.alt_text: Ambulance workers are set to strike on Wednesday, having walked out last month.

A sign regarding strike action outside Shortlands railway station, closed due to strike action by the National Union of Rail, Maritime and Transport, near Sevenoaks, UK, on Friday, Jan. 6, 2023. Britain is mired in industrial action with workers ranging from train drivers to nurses and border-control officials protesting against below-inflation pay offers. site_title: Oil holds in sight of recent highs on Chinese demand recovery hopes
summary: Oil prices fell 1.3% on Monday to near their highest levels this month, as easing Covid-19 restrictions in China raised hopes of a demand recovery. Brent crude dropped to $84.20 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude fell to $78.85 a barrel. The price decline follows a recent surge driven by concerns over supply disruptions and the ongoing Ukraine conflict. The easing of restrictions in China has led to increased speculation about a potential demand recovery, supporting oil prices.

images.alt_text: An expected resurgence in travel for the Chinese New Year holiday at the end of this week has raised the outlook for transport fuel demand.

site_title: No signs of slowdown in South-east Asia e-commerce demand yet, say aggregators
summary: E-commerce demand in South-east Asia remains strong, with projected gross merchandise value of US$131 billion in 2022 and US$211 billion in 2025. Unlike the US market, which has slowed due to macroeconomic uncertainty, South-east Asia's e-commerce market continues to grow. E-commerce aggregators such as Una Brands and Rainforest are capitalizing on this trend, with investors pouring in funding. However, they are preparing for potential changes in the macroeconomic environment, including consumers cutting back on spending, and will need to operate more efficiently to sustain growth.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
The team behind Una Brands, whose acquisitions include ErgoTune and EverDesk+, ergonomic furniture brands from South-east Asia.
Una Brands commits US$100m into South Korea; allies with KlickBrands
Una Brands acquires Singapore consumer brands ErgoTune and EverDesk+

site_title: External headwinds will test Asean’s mettle once again
summary: Asean's economic resilience will be tested in 2023 due to external headwinds, including recessionary pressures in the US and Europe from rising interest rates and inflation. Despite the challenges, Asean's mettle was proven in 2022, with the region withstanding supply shocks and maintaining relatively stable currencies. The World Bank warns that a new adverse development could push the global economy into recession, but Asean's macro landscape is less vulnerable. The region's recovery is expected to be boosted by China's grand reopening, which will drive activity for Asean and lead to a significant recovery in trade and commodities demand.

images.alt_text: Vehicles travel along the Third Ring Road in Beijing. Morgan Stanley said China’s faster reopening will be an “additional pillar of domestic demand support in Asia, while also imparting the largest positive spillover effects to the rest of Asia”.
Malaysian central bank’s monetary policy and the government’s implementation of targeted subsidies this year will affect consumers spending power.

site_title: Helping clients manage risk is new challenge in commodities sector: StanChart’s John Chen
summary: Standard Chartered's head of commodity sales for Asean and head of corporate sales for Singapore, John Chen, notes that market dislocation contributes to volatility in commodity prices, creating opportunities for those who understand the industry and its risks. This trend is driven by factors such as transportation disruptions, terminal capacity constraints, and conflicts, like the Russia-Ukraine crisis. As a result, Chen's role involves helping clients manage price risks and cash flows, as initial margins for commodities have risen due to price volatility.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
Exports from Indonesia rose 6.58 per cent on a yearly basis to US$23.83 billion, roughly in line with the poll’s forecast of a 6.65 per cent increase.

Goldman sees the aluminium, used to make everything from beer cans to plane parts, climbing to US$3,750 a ton in the next 12 months.

Edible-oil buyers, including price-sensitive consumers in South Asia and Africa, will bear the brunt of the supply-side constraints.

site_title: Office Reits in the Philippines get a boost as spotty Internet limits work-from-home
summary: Philippine-listed office real estate investment trusts (Reits) are expected to see consistent earnings growth in FY2023, driven by a stable office market despite spotty internet infrastructure limiting work-from-home trends. In contrast, US office Reits are struggling with low physical occupancy rates, with some conducting strategic reviews to assess opportunities. The Philippines Reits' stable office market and favorable dividend yields of 7.2-8.6% make them an attractive option, with analysts recommending Ayala Land Reit and Megaworld Reit as top picks.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
Mapletree Pan Asia Commercial Trust’s (MPACT) Mapletree Business City (MBC) recorded yoy growth in both gross revenue and NPI in H1FY23.
DBS has cut the target price of Manulife US Reit, which is currently undergoing a strategic review, by 31 per cent.
"We're taking a look at all of our options at this point," says Tripp Gantt, CEO of Manulife US Reit .

site_title: Hong Kong judge defends judiciary amid fears of ebbing independence
summary: Hong Kong's Chief Justice Andrew Cheung defended the independence of the judiciary, stating judges rule according to the laws before them and ignore criticism that they haven't. Cheung said judges faithfully applied the law, regardless of their designation under the national security law. The law, introduced in 2020, has been criticized for eroding judicial independence and freedoms. Cheung's remarks came as significant national security cases move through the courts, sparking international scrutiny and concerns about the rule of law and capitalist way of life in Hong Kong.

images.alt_text: UK judges to withdraw from Hong Kong's top court

site_title: Business bustling for CNY but restaurants face manpower woes
summary: Singapore's first Chinese New Year (CNY) since Covid-19 group size limits were lifted has seen a surge in demand for dine-in reunion dinners, with restaurants like Peach Garden and Tung Lok fully booked. However, the industry is facing manpower woes as workers are in a festive mood, leading to higher hourly rates and a shortage of casual workers. To cope, some restaurants have taken measures such as offering early reunion promotions and festive dishes until February. Takeaway sales are mixed, with some restaurants seeing a decline and others experiencing an increase.

images.alt_text: Maybank Securities is offering a limited edition box of red packets with eight different rabbit designs.

luxeraffles13 - raffles hotel cny - MasterChef Jereme Leung (1)

Credit: Raffles Hotel Singapore

site_title: China to boost spending for Covid prevention, treatment
summary: China's finance ministry plans to boost funding for COVID-19 prevention and control, mainly for treatment, temporary work allowances for medical staff, vaccinations, and improving medical treatment capabilities. This comes after a surge in COVID infections following Beijing's removal of anti-virus curbs. Nearly 60,000 people with COVID have died in hospitals between December 8 and January 12. The funding is aimed at supporting local fiscal departments in rural and poor areas.

images.alt_text: The return of Chinese travellers is an economic boost that the global tourism and retail sectors have been missing.
Consumer sentiment also plunged, private surveys showed, having already hit record lows in previous months.
Passengers prepare to board a train bound for Jilin province at the Beijing railway station, Beijing, China, Jan 14, 2023.

site_title: Germany speaks out against EU ban on commissions for financial products
summary: Germany's finance minister Christian Lindner expressed concern over a possible EU ban on commissions for financial products, calling it a "serious setback" to the EU's capital market and limiting consumer choice. EU financial services chief Mairead McGuinness is set to propose a ban in her "retail investment strategy," but EU states and the European Parliament would have the final say. Commission-based selling is prevalent in the German insurance market, and banks and insurers are pushing back against the proposed ban, citing concerns about the impact on investment advice and retail investment.

images.alt_text: The European Commission’s proposals are designed to encourage more business to move to clearing houses in continental Europe from the City of London by June 2025, when a temporary waiver that allows its banks and money managers to clear trades in the UK expires.
Sustainable investing is about creating value.

site_title: Daughter of Thailand’s exiled former PM Thaksin to seek premiership
summary: Thailand's daughter of exiled former PM Thaksin Shinawatra, Paetongtarn Shinawatra, has declared her readiness to run for prime minister in an upcoming election. She will run under the Pheu Thai Party, aiming for a landslide victory to realize promises made to the people. Paetongtarn, 36, has led opinion polls and has attended party rallies, surpassing incumbent Prayuth Chan-ocha. Her father Thaksin and aunt Yingluck both led governments toppled by the army, and both are living overseas to avoid jail terms.

site_title: Siemens signs 3 billion euro train deal in India
summary: Siemens has signed a 3 billion euro contract with India to supply and service 1,200 electric locomotives for 35 years, marking the German engineering company's largest locomotive deal in its history. The Siemens-designed trains, with a top speed of 120 km/hr, will be assembled in India over the next 11 years, starting deliveries in 24 months.

images.alt_text: The German engineering and technology group said industrial profit rose 38 per cent to 3.16 billion euros (S$4.5 billion) in the three months to the end of September.

site_title: China and the sovereign debt bomb
summary: China's emergence as a major creditor to developing countries has created a debt crisis, with 74 of the world's lowest-income countries owing $35 billion in debt, 37% of which is owed to China. The G20's Common Framework for addressing debt distress has been largely ineffective, and countries like Ghana have only recently applied for support. The IMF's inability to approve loans without creditor agreement has led to paralysis, putting many countries at risk of economic stagnation or decline. A renewed push for debt restructuring and economic policy reforms is needed to prevent humanitarian crises and sharp increases in poverty.

images.alt_text: A pair of shoes hang over power lines at the Kantamanto market in Accra, Ghana, November 30, 2022. REUTERS/Francis Kokoroko
The firm’s top conviction is to avoid long-term sovereign securities as inflation will continue to outpace central bank targets.

site_title: Man Utd set up shop with luxury lounge in Swiss Alps
summary: Manchester United has set up a luxury lounge in the Swiss Alps during the World Economic Forum in Davos, aiming to entertain clients and partners rather than attract potential buyers. The lounge, designed with black velvet lounge chairs and couches, features video screens showcasing players and club slogans. The club's strategic review, which began in November, is ongoing, with reports of bids from the US, Middle East, and Asia expected within the next month. United's executive co-chairman Avram Glazer is expected to attend events at the lounge, which also features a reception with golden insignia and specialty cocktails.

site_title: S-Reits may come to rue missing out on Mercatus portfolio sale
summary: Singapore's S-Reit managers, including Frasers Centrepoint Trust and CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust, have been optimistic about the retail sector's outlook. However, they missed out on acquiring Mercatus' retail portfolio for S$4 billion, which was ultimately sold to Hong Kong-listed Link Reit for S$2.16 billion. The sale includes Jurong Point and Swing By @ Thomson Plaza. The limited upcoming supply of retail space in Singapore, with only 0.4 million sq ft added annually from 2022 to 2025, is expected to support improvements in occupancy levels and rents. The sale is seen as a steal for Link Reit, with an NPI yield of 4.9% and expected to be DPU accretive.

Mercatus owns and runs the AMK Hub, Jurong Point and Swing By @ Thomson Plaza, and co-owns NEX. The company also has strata-titled assets within retail malls and at sites in various locations across Singapore, and One Marina Boulevard, a 31-storey office building.

Mercatus said sale and purchase agreements were entered into on Wednesday with various subsidiaries of Link Reit to divest the group’s entire interest in Jurong Point and Swing By @ Thomson Plaza.

site_title: Microsoft faces EU antitrust warning over Activision deal
summary: Microsoft is likely to receive an EU antitrust warning over its $69 billion bid for Activision Blizzard, a maker of Call of Duty games. The European Commission is preparing a statement of objections, citing concerns about the deal, which could delay its completion. Microsoft has been working with the commission to address these concerns and has reached a deal with Nintendo to make Call of Duty available on Nintendo consoles. The EU's decision on the deal is due on April 11.

site_title: Sterling slips ahead of UK jobs, inflation data
summary: Sterling slipped 0.3% against the dollar at US$1.2200, its lowest since mid-December, amid UK jobs and inflation data due later this week. Traders await clues on Bank of England monetary policy plans, as hopes for post-Brexit trade rule progress with the EU dwindle. Significant differences remain between Britain and the EU, according to the British prime minister's spokesperson.

images.alt_text: The yield on Japan’s benchmark 10-year government bonds breached the central bank’s new ceiling on Friday, adding to pressure for the yield control policy to be scrapped or revised.

site_title: India’s insurance regulator to treat green bond purchases as infra investments
summary: The Insurance Regulatory and Development Authority of India has announced that insurers will be allowed to classify their sovereign green bond purchases as infrastructure investments, effective immediately. The move aims to "de-concentration and diversification" of insurers' infrastructure portfolios and participation in environmental, social, and governance (ESG) initiatives. This decision is part of India's plan to raise 160 billion rupees through its first-ever sovereign green bonds, issued by the Reserve Bank of India. The bonds, worth 40 billion rupees each, will be auctioned on January 25 and February 9.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) seal is pictured on a gate outside the RBI headquarters in Mumbai, India, February 2, 2016. REUTERS/Danish Siddiqui/File Photo

site_title: Geopolitics threatens to destroy the world Davos made
summary: The World Economic Forum (WEF) in Davos is taking place amidst fears that a long period of peace and economic integration could be coming to a close due to geopolitical threats. The COVID-19 pandemic has shattered the assumption of globalisation, and businesses are now diversifying production to avoid complex supply chains vulnerable to disease, war, or other emergencies. The conflict in Ukraine has shown how war can sever economic ties, and politicians and industrialists are scanning the horizon for the next big geopolitical threat. The forum's slogan, "Cooperation in a fragmented world," reflects the need for cooperation to address these challenges.

images.alt_text: The partially snow-covered Schiahorn mountain, beyond the Congress Center, the venue for the World Economic Forum (WEF), in Davos, Switzerland, on Friday, Jan. 6, 2023. Though it’s perched at an altitude of 1,560 meters, this year’s rare winter heatwave saw the Swiss town of Davos basking in temperatures well above freezing in early January, with its mountainsides covered in dead, brown grass and hikers out with their dogs. World Economic Forum (WEF) President Borge Brende (left) and WEF managing director Saadia Zahidi during a virtual media briefing in Cologny, near Geneva, Switzerland, Jan 10, 2023. The World Economic Forum unveiled the program for its upcomming Annual Meeting Davos 2023, i

site_title: Oil stays high on expected Chinese demand recovery
summary: Oil prices held near year-highs on Monday as easing Covid restrictions in China raised expectations for a recovery in demand from the world's top crude importer. Brent crude fell 0.5% to $84.87 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude dropped 0.4% to $79.58 per barrel. China's crude imports rose 4% year-over-year in December, and an expected resurgence in travel for the Chinese New Year holiday has raised the outlook for transport fuel demand. However, reports of increased Covid-related deaths weighed on sentiment, with analysts noting a gradual normalization of China's oil demand.
