The sanctions are likely to see a great re-routing of global diesel flows – aided by Russia’s new crude buyers sending fuel back to Europe. In the short term, there is a risk of higher prices.

site_title: Russian buyers help propel Dubai property sales to record levels
summary: Dubai's property market has seen record levels of sales and value, driven by international buyers, particularly Russians, who have surged in interest after the war in Ukraine. In 2022, Dubai registered over 86,000 residential sales transactions, surpassing a previous record, with about 208 billion dirhams (S$74.8 billion) worth of property sold, marking an 80% gain from 2021. The market has bucked global trends, with prices and rents buoyed by bankers, Israeli investors, and cryptocurrency millionaires, cementing Dubai's position as the region's top business hub.

images.alt_text: In expatriate-dominated Dubai, though, home prices and rents have surged amid an influx of Russians looking to protect their wealth after the invasion of Ukraine, and as bankers fled strict lockdowns in Asia.

Dubai’s property sector surged in 2020 as it opened up again during the pandemic before most major cities and as rich buyers snapped up luxury units, boosting a sector that had been sluggish since the 2014-15 oil price crash.

site_title: Singapore shares buck Asian peers; STI closes 0.3% lower
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed 0.3% lower at 3,283.60 points on Monday, bucking Asian peers that rose due to China's reopening optimism. ComfortDelGro shares hit a 52-week low, down 2.6%, while iFast shares dropped 8.5%. UOB was the top STI decliner, while DBS and OCBC rose 0.1% and 0.08% respectively. The decline was attributed to reduced earnings expectations and a downtrend for ComfortDelGro, despite iFast maintaining its financial guidance.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek

site_title: Japanese firms seen to offer the biggest wage hikes in 26 years
summary: Japanese firms are expected to offer the largest wage hikes in 26 years, with an average pay rise of 2.85% for the financial year starting in April. This includes a 1.08% rise in base salaries and a 1.78% increase in additional salary based on seniority. The move aims to support policymakers' goal of sustainable wage growth and stimulate economic growth led by the private sector, as inflation remains above the Bank of Japan's 2% target.

images.alt_text: Core inflation in Japan recently hit a four-decade high, making it increasingly difficult for wages to keep up.

site_title: European stocks can extend lead over the US: Morgan Stanley
summary: European stocks are poised to continue their lead over US peers, according to Morgan Stanley strategists. The outperformance began three months ago and is driven by optimism over China's reopening, lower natural-gas prices, and resilient economic data. European stocks broke above their 100-week moving average relative to US peers for the first time since the global financial crisis. Strategist Graham Secker expects a favorable backdrop for the European equity market, citing tighter monetary policy and easier fiscal policy, which will benefit value stocks over growth peers.

images.alt_text: Investors may think that things can only get better in 2023, but it's not time for complacency.

A sooner-than-expected reopening of China’s economy, a warmer-than-normal winter in energy-strapped Europe and a sustained fall in US inflation – are combining to dissipate some of the gloom that engulfed financial markets at the end of 2022.
For the third straight week, global investors have been net buyers in money market funds.

site_title: China lifts ban on ride-hailing giant Didi’s new user registration
summary: China has lifted the ban on ride-hailing giant Didi's new user registration, allowing the company to resume its core services effective Monday. Didi had been awaiting approval to return to normal business after regulatory troubles started in mid-2021. The company has cooperated with Chinese authorities and taken measures to ensure platform safety and data security, paving the way for its return to the domestic app stores and the Chinese market.

site_title: SIA Group passenger traffic up 11.7% in December on travel relaxations
summary: Singapore Airlines' SIA Group saw a 11.7% month-on-month increase in passenger traffic in December, with 2.7 million passengers flying on SIA and Scoot. The group reached 80% of pre-Covid passenger capacity and recorded its highest monthly passenger load factor at 89.7%. Cargo operations experienced weaker demand, with a 24.5 percentage point year-on-year decline in load factor. Despite this, SIA Group's passenger network covered 111 destinations in 36 countries and territories.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
Analyst Raymond Yap noted that SIA’s share price has re-rated 16.5 per cent over the past three months on optimism over China’s reopening.

site_title: Equities: why it’s too early for investors to relax
summary: Investors may feel relieved that 2022 is behind them, but it's too early to relax, according to experts. Despite the worst calendar year for stocks since 2007/08, many market pressures, such as high energy prices and rising interest rates, have yet to fully impact the real economy and consumers. Equity valuations have fallen, but it's essential to be cautious, as earnings expectations may take a hit in 2024, and wage inflation remains a significant cost uncertainty. Focus on "quality" businesses with strong cash flows, solid balance sheets, and pricing power for a more sustainable approach to investing in 2023.

images.alt_text: A sooner-than-expected reopening of China’s economy, a warmer-than-normal winter in energy-strapped Europe and a sustained fall in US inflation – are combining to dissipate some of the gloom that engulfed financial markets at the end of 2022.

“Chinese tech shares were once the easiest bet, and for most of the past decade you were able to win and see outperformance without doing much,” said Chen Da, managing director at Fortune Hill Asset Management.

site_title: Johor Bahru-Singapore Rapid Transit System Link on track to be operational by end-2026
summary: The Johor Bahru-Singapore Rapid Transit System (RTS) Link is on track to be completed by end-2026, with foreign ministers of Singapore and Malaysia noting the project's good progress during a meeting on January 16. The 4km rail shuttle service will take five minutes to travel from Woodlands to Johor Bahru and vice versa, serving up to 10,000 passengers per hour. The project received its approval from Malaysia in 2019 and has made significant progress despite a change in government.

images.alt_text: Johor Baru’s proximity to Singapore and the Rapid Transit System Link between Johor Bahru and Singapore, are the city’s biggest advantages in becoming the future Internet City.

site_title: Credit Suisse could cut 10% of European investment bankers: FT
summary: Credit Suisse is considering cutting 10% of its European investment banking staff amid a string of scandals and heavy losses. The bank aims to refocus on stable parts of its business and overhaul its investment banking arm. Following a mass layoff in London and Zurich last month, the Zurich-based bank declined to comment on the potential staff cuts.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Swiss bank Credit Suisse is seen in front of a branch office in Bern, Switzerland November 29, 2022. REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann/File Photo
Credit Suisse has said that it is set to report a loss of up to 1.5 billion francs for the final three months of 2022, partly on the back of historic outflows of client funds.

site_title: UK property sellers lift prices for first time in three months
summary: UK property sellers boosted asking prices by 0.9% in January, the largest gain since 2020, with average prices increasing by £3,301 to £362,438. This marks a reversal of the market's decline over the past two months. The data from Rightmove suggests a positive start to 2023, with a 55% jump in potential buyer inquiries and a 4% increase in prospective buyers contacting agents. However, affordability constraints and rising mortgage rates are expected to hold back some segments of the market in the first half of the year.

images.alt_text: Some 800,000 people who are renewing their mortgages in 2023 will see their interest rates double, as the era of cheap money comes crashing to a halt.

site_title: Swiss startup takes on Apple and Google with privacy-first OS
summary: Apostrophy, a Swiss startup, is unveiling a privacy-first operating system, AphyOS, as a third alternative to Apple's iOS and Google's Android. The OS, built on an open-source version of Android, segregates apps to prevent tracking of user behavior. Apostrophy, founded by mobile industry veterans, aims to capitalize on regulators' push to rein in the duopoly power of Apple and Google. The company is seeking 10 million euros in funding and has recruited former software engineers from KaiOS, a collaborative venture targeting emerging markets. AphyOS will charge a subscription fee for its combination of software and services.

site_title: Volkswagen takes on competition in Chinese EV market
summary: Volkswagen aims to expand its presence in China's electric vehicle market, lagging behind domestic competitors like BYD. The German carmaker plans to release higher-end and lower-end models, including the ID.7 and a new model below the ID.4, to reduce its time to market from four years to 2.5 years. By localizing research and development, Volkswagen hopes to compete with Chinese counterparts, citing cheaper electricity costs as a factor in the country's fast-growing EV market.

images.alt_text: New energy vehicles, which include pure electric and plug-in hybrids, could account for one third of the overall passenger vehicles sales in China in 2023, VW China president Ralf Brandstaetter said.

Sales are up 12 per cent in the second half of the year but full-year output figures have been dragged down by an output drop of over a fifth in the first half as the war in Ukraine has upended supply chains and Covid-19 has shuttered plants in China.
Hahn first worked at Volkswagen in North America and later completed a stint at tyre company Continental in Hanover before returning to the German group as chief executive.

site_title: Qatar’s US$450b wealth fund eyes soccer, tech in revamp
summary: Qatar's US$450 billion sovereign wealth fund, the Qatar Investment Authority (QIA), is looking to rebalance its portfolio amid economic turmoil, considering investments in sectors such as venture capital, fintech, and sustainability. The fund is also eyeing opportunities in soccer, financial institutions, and tech, with a focus on Europe, Asia, and the US. CEO Mansoor Al Mahmoud stated that the fund will prioritize investments in trophy assets, including sports clubs, and has expressed support for Elon Musk's vision for Twitter.

images.alt_text: Mansoor Bin Ebrahim Al Mahmoud, chief executive officer of Qatar Investment Authority, following a Bloomberg Television interview ahead of the World Economic Forum (WEF) in Davos, Switzerland, on Monday, Jan. 16, 2023. The annual Davos gathering of political leaders, top executives and celebrities runs from January 16 to 20. Photographer: Hollie Adams/Bloomberg

site_title: Japan's top economic panel debates potential shift away from 'Abenomics'
summary: Japan's top economic policy panel has begun debating the potential shift away from "Abenomics," a reflationary policy implemented by former premier Shinzo Abe to combat deflation. The panel, comprising eight economists, will discuss the medium-to-long term direction of fiscal and monetary policies. Financial markets are focused on the central bank's potential exit from monetary stimulus due to sharp inflation rises. The sessions do not discuss the Bank of Japan's exit strategy or draft new policy objectives. The panel's discussions aim to stimulate a "virtuous cycle" of growth, potentially reflected in the government's annual mid-year policy blueprint.

images.alt_text: The yield on Japan’s benchmark 10-year government bonds breached the central bank’s new ceiling on Friday, adding to pressure for the yield control policy to be scrapped or revised.

site_title: Lollobrigida, Italy's wickedly witty screen goddess, dead at 95
summary: Italian actress Gina Lollobrigida, known for her biting wit and sensual beauty, has died at the age of 95. Born on July 4, 1927, Lollobrigida was a cinema sex symbol and iconic figure of the Golden Age of Hollywood, starring alongside leading men such as Humphrey Bogart, Errol Flynn, and Burt Lancaster. She won seven David di Donatello awards and was dubbed "La Lollo" by fans, but later turned to sculpture and photojournalism, and even attempted a bid for a seat in the Italian parliament.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on September 18, 1978, Italian actress Gina Lollobrigida poses at Poujeaux castle in Moulis-en-Medoc. - Gina Lollobridgida died at 95 on January 16, 2023, according to French Culture Minister. (Photo by AFP)

epa10408919 FILE Italian actress Gina Lollobrigida during a ceremony honoring her on the Hollywood Walk of Fame in Hollywood, California, USA, 01 February 2018 (reissued 16 January 2023). Lollobrigida, a high profile European actress in the 1950s and early 1960s, has died at the age of 95 Corriere della Sera reported 16 January 2023.  EPA-EFE/MIKE NELSON

site_title: Container volumes handled by PSA International dips in 2022
summary: PSA International, a global container handling company, reported a 0.7% decrease in container volumes to 90.9 million 20-foot equivalent units (TEUs) in 2022, down from a record 91.6 million TEUs in 2021. The company's flagship PSA Singapore contributed 37 million TEUs, while terminals outside Singapore handled 53.9 million TEUs. CEO Tan Chong Meng attributed the decline to supply chain disruptions and challenges caused by the global pandemic, war in Ukraine, and inflation. The company aims to build on its core business and widen its focus on supply chain management.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
A boat sails past the PSA container terminal port in Singapore on August 11, 2021. (Photo by ROSLAN RAHMAN / AFP)

PSA, the world’s second-biggest container terminal operator, whose global network encompasses 160 locations in 42 countries, had acquired the stake in the Hong Kong-based conglomerate’s ports business for US$4.4 billion in 2006.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Consumer sentiments on inflation are mixed, with 41% expecting a decrease and 45% expecting an increase. Singapore's headline inflation expectations fell to 3.8% in December from an 11-year high of 4.6% in September 2022. New private home sales plummeted in December 2022 to their lowest since 2009. The upcoming Budget announcement on February 14 may bring higher taxes on luxury homes and non-residential properties.

site_title: The Way of Water stays afloat atop North America box office
summary: Avatar: The Way of Water stays atop the North American box office for a fifth straight week, earning an estimated US$38.5 million over the Martin Luther King Jr weekend. The film's domestic total now stands at US$570 million, while its international total reaches US$1.33 billion. If it continues, The Way of Water could be the first film to reach US$2 billion worldwide since the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Global jobs growth will halve in challenging 2023: ILO
summary: Global employment growth is expected to slow down to 1% in 2023, down from 2% in 2022, due to economic fallout from the war in Ukraine, high inflation, and tighter monetary policy. The number of unemployed people is projected to rise to 208 million, with inflation eating into real wages. The International Labour Organization (ILO) warns that the slowdown in global employment growth may not recover until 2025, with many workers facing lower-quality jobs at low pay and potentially pushing more people into poverty.

site_title: StanChart partners Community Chest in distribution of festive bags
summary: Standard Chartered partnered with Community Chest to distribute over 8,500 festive bags to families in need in Singapore. The bags, packed by 1,300 volunteers over two days, contained staple food items and more extravagant ones like baby abalone. This is the 10th year of the event, which aims to build upon partnerships to make giving a sustainable way of living through donations, volunteering, or providing resources. The initiative aligns with Standard Chartered's commitment to sustainable social and economic development in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Launched on Sunday (Jan 8), the AEAS Fun Club features arts and creative activities.

site_title: China bad-debt firms plan property support of up to 160 billion yuan
summary: Chinese financial regulators and bad-debt management companies plan to offer up to 160 billion yuan (S$31.4 billion) of refinancing support to high-quality developers in the first quarter. The loans, offered at 1.75% annual interest, will be channeled through China Huarong Asset Management and its peers to selected developers. This measure is part of a series of steps to support China's property market, which has been hit by a slump since November. The goal is to ease the woes of sector-exposed bad-debt managers.

site_title: India now buying 33 times more Russian oil than a year earlier
summary: India purchased a record 1.2 million barrels of Russian oil per day in December, 29% more than in November, representing a 33-fold increase from a year earlier. This makes Russia India's largest oil supplier, surpassing Iraq and Saudi Arabia. The surge is attributed to deepening discounts offered by Russia due to additional sanctions, including a $60-a-barrel price cap. India's reliance on imports makes it vulnerable to price volatility, with state-owned refiners favoring cheaper Russian imports.

images.alt_text: The sanctions are likely to see a great re-routing of global diesel flows – aided by Russia’s new crude buyers sending fuel back to Europe. In the short term, there is a risk of higher prices.

site_title: Fundamental question for crypto: Does it have any real-world value?
summary: Crypto's value and potential as a store of value, vehicle for speculation, or asset with productive use are questioned. Following Bitcoin's 77% fall and Ether's 82% decline, concerns arise about the asset's long-term viability. The author argues that if crypto only generates more crypto without creating real wealth, it's essentially a Ponzi scheme. The Tether stablecoin's lending practices and lack of transparency also raise concerns about its legitimacy. As investors grow disillusioned with crypto's prospects, the author concludes that time will reveal the truth, and the crypto ecosystem's value may be limited to its current price.

images.alt_text: Binance’s chief executive officer Changpeng Zhao has defended the exchange and said it will emerge stronger after overcoming challenges.
Bitcoin has added more than 10 per cent this month and second-largest token Ether about 17 per cent.

site_title: Violence at Indonesia nickel smelter protest kills 2, dozens detained
summary: Violent protests at an Indonesian nickel smelter in Sulawesi killed two workers and injured dozens, with 71 people detained. The Gunbuster Nickel Industry smelter, owned by China's Jiangsu Delong Nickel Industry, was the site of clashes between protesters and security personnel. Protesters demanded better pay and safety, citing fatal safety lapses and lack of proper safety gear. The incident has raised concerns about worker rights and safety standards in the region, with Indonesia's Industry Minister urging dialogue between workers and management.

site_title: Air traffic back to normal by June on China rebound, says jet lessor
summary: Avolon, the world's second-largest jet lessor, predicts that China's reopening to international travel will drive global air traffic to pre-pandemic levels by June. The aviation sector is expected to thrive in 2023, with Asia leading the recovery after Europe and North America drove the rebound last year. The recent reopening in China is expected to help the recovery, with aircraft-leasing executives gathering in Dublin for conferences after a two-year disruption due to Covid-19.

site_title: Japanese yields top policy cap for second day, defying BOJ buying
summary: Japan's 10-year government bond yield surpassed the Bank of Japan's policy ceiling for a second consecutive trading session, defying the central bank's emergency bond-buying operations. The yield jumped 1 basis point to 0.51% before the BOJ intervened, but rebounded to 0.5% by the start of the session. Speculators expect the BOJ to tweak its policy, with some predicting a wider yield band or even scrapping yield-curve control. Market participants remain uncertain, with some arguing that a complete abandonment of yield-curve control could ease pressure on the bond market.

images.alt_text: While global commodity prices slipped, companies continued to pass on past increases in raw material costs for goods such as auto parts and electricity equipment, said a BOJ official
The yield on Japan’s benchmark 10-year government bonds breached the central bank’s new ceiling on Friday, adding to pressure for the yield control policy to be scrapped or revised.

epa10253755 A stock market indicator board displays the 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average figures in Tokyo, Japan, 20 October 2022. Tokyo stocks lost more than 300 points in the morning trading session following overnight fall at Wall Street.  EPA-EFE/FRANCK ROBICHON

Shigeyuki Goto (C), who will be appointed as the minister in charge of economic revitalization, appears to reporters at the prime minister's office in Tokyo on October 25, 2022. (Photo by JIJI Press / AFP) / Japan OUT

site_title: Here’s what needs to change as Chinese tourists return
summary: Chinese tourists are projected to take 110 million international trips in 2023, accounting for two-thirds of 2019's 170 million trips and contributing $253 billion to the global economy. The return of Chinese travelers is an economic boost for the global tourism and retail sectors, but destinations will need to adapt to a more segmented and independent market. Key adjustments include serving diverse travelers, letting go of mass tourism, communicating safety, offering value-packed experiences, and reducing visitor visa hurdles. Destinations must also be prepared to handle increased demand from niche travelers and those prioritizing sustainability.

images.alt_text: Flight passenger numbers stand at 63% of the 2019 figure before the pandemic, as Chinese return to their hometowns over Chinese New Year.
As of Jan 12, the number of mainland tourists visiting Singapore over the Chinese New Year holiday grew by almost five times year on year.
eveloping-nation stocks and currencies have made the strongest start to a year since the 1990s.

site_title: Here Lies Love, an Imelda Marcos disco musical, will play Broadway
summary: The musical "Here Lies Love," a disco-driven dance production about Imelda Marcos, will make its Broadway debut this summer. The show, created by David Byrne and Fatboy Slim, began as a multimedia song cycle in 2007 and has since undergone stage productions in various venues. Directed by Alex Timbers, the show will be staged at the Broadway Theater with a dance club environment where audiences will stand and move with the actors. Previews begin June 17, and the show is expected to open July 20.

images.alt_text: Ferdinand Marcos Jr., takes oath as President of the Philippines during the inauguration ceremony at the National Museum in Manila on June 30, 2022.

site_title: Room for higher taxes on luxury homes and non-residential properties
summary: Singapore's upcoming Budget may include higher taxes on luxury homes and non-residential properties. The government aims to raise revenue for healthcare and social needs, while also combating wealth inequality. Property taxes are expected to rise, with transaction taxes potentially increasing on homes over $2 million and non-residential properties. Recurring property taxes will also increase, with rates ranging from 11-36% for homes and 10% for non-residential properties. Exemptions may be considered for certain property owners, such as owner-occupiers and listed entities.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee
Private home price rise slows to 0.2% in Q4 as suburban prices drop; 2022 chalks up increase of 8.4%

site_title: Toyota sees vehicle output climbing more than 10% during 2023
summary: Toyota has set a production target of 10.6 million vehicles for 2023, a 16% increase from the planned 9.2 million, citing a "downward risk fluctuation range of approximately 10%." The target comes after the company lowered its outlook in November due to persistent parts shortages, particularly semiconductors, and rising costs. Toyota warns that final output may be lower if it fails to procure enough parts, emphasizing the challenges faced by the global auto industry due to Covid-related lockdowns.

site_title: South Korea December house prices suffer worst fall in at least 19 years
summary: South Korea's house prices suffered their worst decline in at least 19 years, falling 2% in December 2022, marking the seventh consecutive month of declines. This reverses a 10% gain in 2021, with the overall decline of 4.7% for 2022. The decline is attributed to central banks raising interest rates to fight inflation, cooling the economy and pushing up mortgage rates. The government has announced measures to lower taxes and ease restrictions, aiming to ease house prices in an orderly manner without hurting the financial sector.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Korea is 18 months into a tightening cycle designed to curb inflationary pressures and economists predict that a rate rise on Friday may be the final move.
FILE PHOTO: The logo of the Bank of Korea is seen on the top of its building in Seoul, South Korea, March 8, 2016. REUTERS/Kim Hong-Ji
The prices of the country’s imports stood 9.1 per cent higher in December than a year ago.

site_title: Australian dollar breaks past 70 cents for first time since August
summary: The Australian dollar surpassed 70 US cents for the first time since August, reaching an intraday high of US$0.7019, driven by a weaker US dollar, higher commodity prices, and signs of slowing global inflation. The Aussie is expected to continue its upward trend this week, with a potential target of US$0.71, according to analysts. Meanwhile, China's fourth-quarter GDP figures are set to be released on Tuesday, with economists predicting a slowdown in growth.

images.alt_text: Australian dollar notes are seen in Sydney in this August 11, 2010 file photo. The decision by Australia's major banks to quit the country's $35 billion a year remittance business is driving fund-transfers underground, a trend exposing the country as a weak link in the global fight against money laundering and financial crime.  REUTERS/Daniel Munoz/Files
The proposal for Singapore to draw critical energy supply from a source some 4,200 KM away through an undersea cable was deemed a hard sell from the get-go by market watchers.

site_title: Prudential sets up financial advisory firm offering wealth solutions, general insurance
summary: Prudential Singapore is setting up a financial advisory firm to offer wealth solutions and general insurance products, including travel and motor insurance. The new firm obtained regulatory approval from the Monetary Authority of Singapore in December and will add to Prudential's existing distribution channels, including over 5,000 financial consultants. The move aims to provide customers with a wider range of products and services.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting

site_title: Google-backed ShareChat cuts 20% of workforce
summary: Bengaluru-based ShareChat, a short video-sharing platform backed by Google and Temasek, has cut around 20% of its workforce. The company, valued at $5 billion, cited increasing market pressure to cut costs due to a global economic downturn. ShareChat has more than 2,200 employees and is expanding globally across India, the US, and Europe. The move follows other Indian startups reducing their workforce to become profitable amid a turbulent tech market.

site_title: Memories Group to delist on Jan 18
summary: Memories Group, a CATALIST-listed tourism company, will delist on January 18, following its offer to privatize for S$0.047 per share in cash or shares in offeror Memories (2022). The company, based in Myanmar, focuses on experiences, hotels, and services. Approval was granted on December 7, 2022, to delist the group.

images.alt_text: nature, landscape, lake of fire

site_title: British billionaire Jim Ratcliffe’s Ineos to buy Sika assets
summary: British billionaire Jim Ratcliffe's Ineos has agreed to buy Sika's construction company MBCC's admixtures business in the US, Canada, Europe, Australia, and New Zealand for approximately $750 million. The assets, valued at $1.3 billion, generate $920 million in net sales. The deal is part of Sika's efforts to gain regulatory approval for its largest transaction on record, a 5.5-billion-franc takeover of German rival MBCC. The disposal and takeover are expected to be completed in the first half of 2023, with expected annual synergies of $160-180 million.

images.alt_text: The Ineos spokesman told The Times that Jim Ratcliffe, reportedly Britain’s richest man, would be prepared to buy such a stake as a prelude to assuming full control at Old Trafford.
The new joint venture will have a registered capital of about 623 million yuan, Sinopec said.

site_title: Britain's M&S to invest US$587m in store estate
summary: Marks & Spencer plans to invest $587 million in its store estate, opening 20 new bigger stores in the UK by 2024. This investment will generate over 3,400 new jobs across the country. The company aims to accelerate its store rotation programme, reducing full-line stores by 67 to 180 high-quality stores and increasing food-only stores by 104 to 420. CEO Stuart Machin believes stores are a key competitive advantage for the company, stating they need to have the right stores in the right place with the right space.

images.alt_text: A shopper enters a Marks & Spencer Group Plc (M&S) store in Guildford, UK, on Tuesday, Jan. 10, 2023. Marks & Spencer is due to give its Christmas trading update on Thursday. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg

site_title: Refreshed environmental services road map to create over 1,600 PMET jobs by 2025
summary: Singapore's refreshed Environmental Services ITM 2025 aims to create over 1,600 professional, managerial, executive and technical (PMET) jobs by 2025 through innovation, technology adoption, and data-driven solutions in environmental sustainability. The updated roadmap focuses on four key areas: intensifying innovation and technology adoption, nurturing firm development, creating quality jobs, and improving job prospects. The move seeks to harness opportunities in environmental sustainability, particularly in areas like material circularity and decarbonised waste management solutions.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh

Minister for Trade and Industry Gan Kim Yong launches the wholesale trade industry transformation map 2025 at the official opening of seafood trader Fish International Sourcing House’s (FISH) new processing facility.
Minister of State for Trade and Industry Low Yen Ling launched the Retail Industry Transformation Map 2025 at the official opening of Castlery’s flagship store.

site_title: China’s Tencent said it fired more than 100 employees over corruption in 2022
summary: Tencent Holdings, Asia's largest internet company, fired over 100 employees in 2022 for violating laws and company policies, including suspected bribery and embezzlement. The company reported more than 70 cases across various business lines, with some resulting in prison sentences. Tencent's founder Pony Ma previously stated that "serious corruption" issues were discovered within the company, leading to increased measures against internal issues. The company has published annual reports detailing corruption cases, with this year's cases showing an increase in the number of cases and people involved.

images.alt_text: The online giant’s stock has risen 95 per cent in Hong Kong since Oct 28.

site_title: Japan and Europe deepen alliance post-Ukraine
summary: Japan has strengthened its alliance with Europe, particularly with the UK, France, and Italy, following the Ukraine War. Prime Minister Fumio Kishida signed several defense pacts, including a reciprocal access treaty with the UK, and discussed security and economic issues with European leaders. The alliance is seen as increasingly important as Japan and Europe face concerns over Russia, China, and the US's reliability as an ally. Japan and Europe are also stepping up cooperation in areas such as hydrogen and renewable energy, with the EU and Japan collectively holding over half of the international patents in the field.

images.alt_text: Britain's Prime Minister Rishi Sunak (right) and Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida (left) walks towards the exit at the end of their bilateral meeting at the Tower of London, London, on Jan 11, 2023. Japan is hosting this year’s G7 and Kishida is visiting all bloc members except Germany on a trip capped by talks in Washington on Friday with US President Joe Biden.

site_title: ECB interest rates seen hitting peak of 3.25% before cut in July
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is expected to raise interest rates to a peak of 3.25% before cutting them in July, according to economists polled by Bloomberg. This would mark a drastic turn of events, as most ECB officials do not foresee rate cuts. The rate hikes will be implemented in three steps, with the first two being 25 basis points each in February and March, followed by a 50 basis-point hike in May or June. This scenario would suggest the ECB's battle with inflation is nearing its end.

images.alt_text: Companies are finally starting to adjust wages, leading to worries that high inflation could be perpetuated if wage-setting is adjusted on a more permanent basis.

site_title: Nine-year rule for IDs: A necessary but small step
summary: Singapore has introduced a mandatory nine-year tenure limit for independent directors, joining other markets such as Malaysia and France. The move aims to improve board effectiveness and address the issue of long-serving directors who refuse to leave. However, critics argue that a mandatory tenure limit is a blunt instrument and may not address other governance issues. The Singapore Exchange will also revoke the two-tier vote for IDs who have served more than nine years. Experts suggest that the ultimate goal should be to strengthen other areas of governance, such as robust search and nomination processes, to improve board effectiveness.

images.alt_text: Previously, long-serving IDs (LSIDs) could continue to be deemed independent if approval was obtained at two tiers of voting: first, from all shareholders; and second, from shareholders excluding directors, the CEO and their associates.
The Singapore Exchange Regulation has proposed to do away with the two-tier voting system in a consultation paper in October 2022.

site_title: Indonesia’s Dec trade surplus shrinks more than expected
summary: Indonesia's trade surplus narrowed to $3.89 billion in December, beating expectations of $4.01 billion. Exports rose 6.58% to $23.83 billion, while imports declined 6.61% to $19.94 billion, the largest drop in two years. The country's export growth slowed in December after a strong year, with exports reaching a historic high of $291.98 billion in 2022.

images.alt_text: “Looking forward we will limit development of smelters that are not oriented towards green energy,” Indonesian Minister of Investment Bahlil Lahadalia said.
Edible-oil buyers, including price-sensitive consumers in South Asia and Africa, will bear the brunt of the supply-side constraints.

site_title: London office deals hit 20-year low after Truss budget turmoil
summary: London's office market experienced a 20-year low in deals in the final quarter of 2022, with only £400 million in transactions, an 88% drop from the previous quarter. The market freeze was triggered by former Prime Minister Liz Truss' unfunded tax cut plans, which spooked markets and led to soaring borrowing costs. Buyers are now waiting for rates to feed through to valuations, while sellers have yet to mark down their holdings or breach loan terms, putting pressure on them to sell.

site_title: Lighthouse Canton raises US$20m in first close of maiden venture debt fund
summary: Singapore-based investment firm Lighthouse Canton raised US$20 million in the first close of its US$100 million venture debt fund. The fund targets tech-enabled startups in the region and aims to deploy capital for 35-40 companies over the next two years. Venture debt, which includes bonds and loans for short-profits or bank financing difficulties, has seen a rise in demand as venture capital activity grows. Lighthouse Canton expects to increase its proportion of venture debt in the market, citing a 15-20% share in mature ecosystems compared to less than 2% in India and South-east Asia.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

site_title: China braces for Covid holiday surge as people leave megacities for hometowns
summary: China is bracing for a potential surge in COVID-19 cases during the Lunar New Year holidays, with nearly 60,000 deaths reported in hospitals between December 8 and January 12. Experts forecast over 1 million deaths this year, and authorities are bolstering medical supplies in rural areas. The country is expecting over 2 billion trips during the holidays, lifting expectations for a rebound in the economy, which is suffering its lowest growth rates in nearly half a century.

images.alt_text: China's new home prices in December declined 0.2 per cent month-on-month.
eveloping-nation stocks and currencies have made the strongest start to a year since the 1990s.

site_title: Developers’ 2022 sales slip to 14-year low on crimped supply, holiday lull
summary: Singapore's new home sales plummeted to a 14-year low in December 2022, with 170 units sold, a 34.6% decrease from the previous month and 73.8% less than the same month in 2021. This brings the year's total to 7,153 units, the lowest since 2008. Despite a "cocktail of challenges" in 2022, including recession concerns and rising interest rates, experts say demand remains strong for new homes, particularly in the Core Central Region. New project launches are expected to improve in 2023, with around 30 projects comprising 12,000 units forecast for the year.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim
Private home price rise slows to 0.2% in Q4 as suburban prices drop; 2022 chalks up increase of 8.4%

Data from the Urban Redevelopment Authority showed that just 5,103 private homes were completed in the first nine months of 2022, down from the estimated  pipeline supply of 11,247 private homes in Q4 2021.
Over 18,000 new private homes, excluding executive condominiums, are slated for completion in 2023, said OrangeTee in a report released on Friday.

site_title: Inflation and tax breaks making inequality worse, UK groups say
summary: UK think tanks warn that high inflation and "unnecessary" tax breaks are exacerbating income inequality, with the poorest households being disproportionately affected. Research suggests 60% of the population, mostly low-income households, have burned through savings to maintain daily spending due to the cost of living crisis. The richest 10% are expected to gain £800 on average from government policies, while the poorest 10% receive £38. The Resolution Foundation criticizes the UK's savings incentives, saying they are "not fit for purpose" and prioritizing tax reliefs for the wealthy.

images.alt_text: Many households on the lowest incomes were dragged into debt during the pandemic and have since faced spiraling costs as inflation hit a 40-year high.

site_title: Logistics startup Locad secures US$11m funding led by Temasek-backed VC fund
summary: Logistics startup Locad has secured $11 million in Series A funding led by Reefknot Investments, a joint venture between Temasek and Kuehne & Nagel. The funding will be used to expand its supply chain platform, build the region's largest fulfillment network, and scale in South-east Asia and Australia. Locad's platform enables brands to store, pack, ship, and track orders in a distributed, end-to-end supply chain as-a-service. The company plans to add warehouses, partner with transport operators, and hire talent across Asia-Pacific to support its growth plans.

images.alt_text: Shipping containers and gantry cranes at the Kwai Tsing Container Terminals in Hong Kong, China, on Monday, March 14, 2022. Hong Kong is schedule to release trade figures on March 28. Photographer: Bertha Wang/Bloomberg
GenZero is a decarbonisation-focused investment company that is wholly owned by Temasek, which co-led Chooose's US$15 million funding round.
Temasek fully owns Singapore Technologies Telemedia, the parent of STT GDC.

site_title: Prime grade office rents rise 1.7% qoq, leading to landlord’s market: Knight Frank
summary: Prime office rents in the Raffles Place/Marina Bay precinct rose 1.7% quarter-over-quarter to S$10.69 psf pm, exceeding Knight Frank's earlier projection. The office sector has become a landlord's market due to tight supply and steady demand. Occupancy rates improved to 95.5% in the fourth quarter of 2022, with expected growth slowing in 2023 due to inflation and tech sector volatility. Despite this, demand for office spaces is expected to be sustained by businesses shifting operations to Singapore.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
20 Cecil Street is a 28-storey Grade A office development with a 99-year leasehold starting from Dec 7, 1989.
According to CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust's website, Twitter is one of CapitaSpring's top three tenants by gross rental income.

site_title: China’s central bank injects fresh funds through medium-term loans, rate unchanged
summary: China's central bank injected 779 billion yuan (S$153.1 billion) into the economy through medium-term loans, maintaining the interest rate unchanged for a fifth straight month. The move aims to keep liquidity "reasonably ample" ahead of Chinese New Year, when companies and households typically seek more funds. Analysts expect further stimulus measures to boost the Covid-ravaged economy, with some predicting a 10 basis-point cut in policy rates in the first quarter. China's GDP growth is expected to rebound to 4.9% this year, following a predicted 2.8% growth in 2022.

images.alt_text: Consumer sentiment also plunged, private surveys showed, having already hit record lows in previous months.

site_title: China’s new home prices fall further in December
summary: China's new home prices declined 0.2% month-on-month in December, marking the fifth consecutive month of decline. Prices dropped 1.5% year-on-year, following an 1.6% decline in November. The decrease is attributed to ongoing Covid outbreaks and sluggish demand, despite recent property support measures and Beijing's reopening. The market is expected to continue to recover, but policymakers face pressure to address the slowdown in GDP growth.

site_title: Singapore’s inflation expectations dip with higher interest rates, global headwinds: poll
summary: Singaporeans' inflation expectations for the year ahead fell to 3.8% in a December poll, down from an 11-year high of 4.6% in September 2022. However, one-year-ahead expectations remain higher than the average of 3.2%. Consumers expect to spend slightly more despite possible cutbacks on consumption, with 41% expecting inflation to decrease and 45% expecting it to increase. A global downturn and rising interest rates are contributing to a "cognitive dissonance" among consumers and policy economists.

images.alt_text: Excluding motor vehicles. retail sales for November have expanded by 8.7 per cent.
From a top-down perspective, analysts say things are generally seen as changing for the better in 2023 for most EM currencies after a difficult year in 2022.

site_title: Japan’s sharp wholesale price rise heaps pressure on BOJ’s ultra-easy policy
summary: Japan's wholesale prices rose 10.2% year-over-year in December, exceeding forecasts and adding to inflationary pressure. The BOJ may consider raising interest rates as a result, despite recent global commodity price declines. Companies continue to pass on raw material costs, and the yen's recent ascent has tempered fuel and raw material imports. The BOJ is expected to raise its inflation forecasts and debate further policy steps at its upcoming meeting.

images.alt_text: Shigeyuki Goto (C), who will be appointed as the minister in charge of economic revitalization, appears to reporters at the prime minister's office in Tokyo on October 25, 2022. (Photo by JIJI Press / AFP) / Japan OUT
The yield on Japan’s benchmark 10-year government bonds breached the central bank’s new ceiling on Friday, adding to pressure for the yield control policy to be scrapped or revised.

site_title: Tencent shares nearly double from October low as crackdown eases
summary: Tencent Holdings' shares have nearly doubled from a recent low, rising 95% in Hong Kong since October 28, as China's crackdown on major tech firms appears to be easing. The online giant's stock has regained its position as one of the world's ten most valuable companies. The approval of Ant Group's $1.5 billion funding and optimism about China's reopening have contributed to the sector's rebound. This marks a significant shift in investor sentiment, with the Hang Seng Tech Index experiencing a three-month surge.

site_title: China A-shares, North Asian markets continue to attract foreign buying, while South-east Asia lags
summary: Foreign investors continued to buy into China A-shares and North Asian markets, with a week-end inflow of $9 billion led by China A-shares ($7 billion). This follows a $35 billion inflow since November 2022, driven by China's growth target of over 4.5% for the year. In contrast, South-east Asia saw muted flows. The trend is expected to remain strong, driven by China's expansionary stance and optimism about its renewed focus on growth.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan
The online giant’s stock has risen 95 per cent in Hong Kong since Oct 28.
The move also comes amid expectations that Chinese authorities will do more to stimulate the country’s Covid-ravaged economy.

site_title: Citi appoints new Singapore country officer
summary: Citi has appointed Tibor Pandi as its new Singapore country officer, effective February 1. Pandi, who has spent 22 years with the company, will oversee all businesses and operations in Singapore and drive overall franchise performance. He previously worked in European branches and was Citi's country officer for Thailand. Pandi's appointment is seen as a strategic move to build on Citi's presence in Singapore and tap into emerging growth opportunities.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting

site_title: Brokers’ take: CGS-CIMB downgrades SIA to ‘hold’ on share price rerating
summary: Singapore Airlines' share price has rerated 16.5% over the past three months on optimism over China's reopening, but broker CGS-CIMB downgrades its call to "hold" from "add" due to a lack of compelling upside. Analyst Raymond Yap notes the airline's strong dividends and projected earnings normalisation post-pandemic, but also expects revenue passenger kilometres demand to be lower due to a likely global slowdown. The brokerage maintains its price target of S$5.97 and advises investors to lighten their positions ahead of the Q3 FY2023 earnings announcement.

images.alt_text: A group of Taiwanese travellers checking their flight status in the departure hall of Changi Airport Terminal 3 on Aug 5, 2022.
After close to three years, SIA is reinstating its Singapore to Beijing passenger service every Friday on a fortnightly basis.
Caterer and ground handler Sats hopes to diversify its revenue base in order to better prepare for any future pandemics.

site_title: Gold hovers near 9-month peak on slower rate-hike hopes
summary: Gold prices held near a nine-month peak at US$1,918.60 per ounce, supported by expectations of slower interest rate hikes from the US Federal Reserve. Market participants anticipate a 25 basis points rate hike, which could benefit gold as lower rates decrease its opportunity cost. US consumers' one-year inflation expectations fell to the lowest level since 2021, also contributing to the rise in gold prices.

images.alt_text: Gold is seen as an inflation hedge, but higher interest rates increase the opportunity cost of holding the asset.

site_title: China boost for flagging world economy looms as reopening starts
summary: China's sudden reopening is expected to boost the flagging world economy through services sectors such as aviation, tourism, and education. International flights are forecast to rebound to 15-25% of pre-pandemic levels by March, with tourism-reliant nations in South-east Asia and developed economies like the US, UK, and Australia benefiting from the return of Chinese visitors. China's economic reboot is expected to deliver a jolt to global growth, with the International Monetary Fund predicting a positive contributor to average global growth by mid-year, and copper prices surging through $9,000 a ton.

images.alt_text: Ten experts interviewed by AFP forecast an average 2.7 per cent year-on-year rise in GDP for the world’s second-largest economy, a sharp plunge from China’s 2021 growth of more than 8 per cent.

site_title: Asia: Most markets rise on optimism over China, rates
summary: Asia's stock markets rose on Monday, driven by optimism over China's economic reopening and slowing inflation. Hong Kong, Shanghai, and other markets gained, with some up over 10% since the start of the year. China's expected annual growth slowdown and easing of COVID-19 restrictions are boosting hopes for a strong rebound in 2023. Market analysts expect a global economic boost from China's emergence, with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) predicting a strong recovery.

images.alt_text: Tokyo dropped more than one per cent as an increasingly stronger yen took its toll on exporters.
Gainers outnumber losers 84 to 39 on the Singapore Exchange on Monday.

site_title: After a torrid 2022, Indian rupee seeks some reprieve as economy stays resilient
summary: The Indian rupee experienced a 10% decline against the US dollar in 2022, its steepest drop since 2013. The country's strong foreign reserves and rising exports offered some cushion, but its heavy dependence on energy imports and currency account deficit contributed to the decline. Analysts predict the rupee may weaken further to 84 against the greenback in 2023, influenced by US Fed rate hikes, energy prices, and global economic trends. Despite near-term challenges, the rupee's real effective exchange rate suggests it remains firm compared to its trading partners.

images.alt_text: Consolidated net profit at the country’s No 2 information technology services firm by revenue rose to 65.86 billion rupees (S$1 billion) in the three months to Dec 31, from 58.09 billion rupees a year ago.
India plans to sell the bonds in two auctions, on Jan 25 and Feb 9.
india indian rupee Photographer: Dhiraj Singh/Bloomberg
Mercedes plans to launch 10 new cars in India in 2023, most costing more than 10 million rupees, the top-end segment that grew 69 per cent in 2022.

site_title: China’s GDP report set to show damage from Covid Zero exit
summary: China's GDP report is expected to show a marked weakening in growth at the end of 2022, following the abrupt end of the Covid Zero policy. Consumer sentiment has also plummeted, with private surveys showing record lows. The GDP growth in the final quarter of 2022 is likely to slow to 1.6% compared to the third quarter's 3.1%, according to economists' estimates. This slowdown raises pressure on policymakers to address the economic impact of the policy change.

images.alt_text: Passengers prepare to board a train bound for Jilin province at the Beijing railway station, Beijing, China, Jan 14, 2023.
eveloping-nation stocks and currencies have made the strongest start to a year since the 1990s.

site_title: Iron ore falls as China Covid woes dent demand hopes
summary: China's May iron ore futures fell 4.3% to 832.5 yuan (S$163.5) a tonne on the Dalian Commodity Exchange due to renewed concerns over demand amid reports of an increase in Covid-19 deaths in the top steel producer. This decline also affected Singapore's benchmark February iron ore, which dropped 4.4% to US$120.00 a tonne. The drop in iron ore prices indicates reduced expectations for Chinese demand, which is a significant factor in the global iron ore market.

images.alt_text:
(FILES) This file photo taken on May 1, 2018 shows a worker handling steel cable at a steel factory in Lianyungang in China's eastern Jiangsu province.
China opened trade in iron ore futures to foreign investors on May 4, 2018 on the market of the north-eastern city of Dalian, aiming to boost its pricing clout for one of its top imports, in one additional signal of opening up amidst a trade row with the US. / AFP PHOTO / - / China OUT

site_title: Air finance summit tackles jet shortages amid China travel thaw
summary: The International Air Transport Association predicts a full recovery in 2024, with global traffic expected to return to pre-pandemic levels by June. China's decision to free travel has boosted demand, with passenger traffic jumping to 63% of 2019 levels. However, the industry faces shortages of narrow-body jets and bottlenecks in maintenance, leading to higher fares and compensation demands from airlines and leasing firms. Macroeconomic concerns, including inflation and interest rates, are also affecting the industry's resilience.

images.alt_text: China Eastern Airlines (above) and China Southern Airlines stated in separate filings on Friday (Jan 13) their intentions to apply to voluntarily delist their American depositary shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange.
Flight passenger numbers stand at 63% of the 2019 figure before the pandemic, as Chinese return to their hometowns over Chinese New Year.
Caterer and ground handler Sats hopes to diversify its revenue base in order to better prepare for any future pandemics.

site_title: Asia’s largest Reit looks to get even bigger as it expands outside of Hong Kong
summary: Link Real Estate Investment Trust (Link Reit), Asia's largest Reit, is expanding its portfolio outside of Hong Kong, with a focus on Singapore, Japan, and other mature markets. The Reit manager, George Hongchoy, sees opportunities to acquire assets in times of crisis, with nearly three quarters of its portfolio still based in Hong Kong. Link Reit has recently acquired two retail malls in Singapore for S$2.16 billion and is eyeing the potential acquisition of Nex shopping mall. The deal is expected to be accretive to net property income and distribution per unit.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
NEX shopping mall in Serangoon
Mercatus said sale and purchase agreements were entered into on Wednesday with various subsidiaries of Link Reit to divest the group’s entire interest in Jurong Point and Swing By @ Thomson Plaza.
Mega suburban mall Jurong Point is one of two properties that Hong Kong's Link Reit is buying in its foray into the Singapore market.

site_title: Fomo stirs again in Bitcoin’s best start since before pandemic
summary: Bitcoin has surged over 28% in January, its best start since 2020, driven by hopes of an end to interest-rate hikes. The token's value has lifted the overall value of digital assets past $1 trillion, with smaller coins also rising. However, investors are cautious, citing uncertainty and concerns that assets have moved too far, too fast, amid central banks' pledge to keep policy rates elevated. Some technical indicators suggest Bitcoin's jump is becoming stretched, raising concerns about a potential market correction.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Representations of the Ripple, Bitcoin, Etherum and Litecoin virtual currencies are seen on a PC motherboard in this illustration picture, February 14, 2018. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Brexit talks are closing in on a possible customs solution
summary: The UK and EU are nearing a customs solution to end their post-Brexit trading arrangements dispute in Northern Ireland. Following an agreement on real-time trade data, negotiators are closing in on a comprehensive deal by the end of February. The UK and EU have proposed separating goods destined for Northern Ireland from those bound for the rest of the UK, reducing frictions between Great Britain and Northern Ireland. A deal could thaw strained relations and end a political standoff preventing the formation of Northern Ireland's devolved administration.

images.alt_text: The skyline of St Paul's Cathedral and the City of London. The UK government’s trade strategies are nurturing some promising growth shoots, although there are still many concerns among businesses.

site_title: Wilmar obtains US$200m in sustainability-linked trade finance facility
summary: Wilmar International has secured a US$200 million sustainability-linked trade finance facility from Standard Chartered. The facility's margin will adjust according to the company's performance against predefined sustainability metrics. This is part of Wilmar's holistic approach to integrating sustainability principles into its business operations, as stated by its chief financial officer Charles Loo. The agreement aims to promote environmentally friendly practices within the company.

site_title: Australia-to-Singapore solar plan no longer viable: Project’s billionaire investor
summary: Australia's 4,200-kilometre solar power cable project to Singapore is no longer commercially viable due to funding disagreements. Billionaire investor Andrew Forrest's Squadron Energy unit has advised the project to focus on a solar and battery facility in the Northern Territory to feed green industries at home. The project, A$30 billion in cost, had faced industry skepticism over its ambitious plans to export clean energy to Singapore. Forrest's Fortescue Future Industries aims to produce 15 million tons of green hydrogen by 2030.

site_title: Germany falls to bottom rung of investment ranking on energy costs, labour shortage
summary: Germany has fallen to the 18th position out of 21 industrial economies in a ranking of investment attractiveness, according to a study by the ZEW economic research institute. Rising energy costs and labour shortages have exacerbated existing issues such as high taxes and complex bureaucracy. The decline is attributed to factors like expensive energy costs and a slow pace of innovation. Germany is now below countries like Hungary, Spain, and Italy in the ranking.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 1.14% lower on strong yen
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 1.14% lower on Monday as the yen strengthened against the dollar, following rallies on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index fell 297.98 points to 25,821.54, while the Topix index lost 11.89 points to 1,891.19. The yen's strength was seen as a result of investors speculating that the Fed may slow its rate hikes.

site_title: Singapore stocks start the week higher, STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks started the week higher, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 0.2% or 6.14 points to 3,299.89. Gainers outnumbered losers 84 to 39, with Sembcorp Marine being the most actively traded stock. Local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB also saw gains, with Singtel and Mapletree PanAsia Commercial Trust also rising. The strong performance follows a similar trend in the US and Europe markets, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index closed at their highest levels in a month.

images.alt_text: Mapletree Logistics Trust's manager says the trust will be divesting two warehouses in Malaysia worth a total of RM50.2 million (S$15.3 million) to Sigma Warehousing.

site_title: Startup eyes Australia to build China-free battery production
summary: An Australia-based startup, Recharge Industries, plans to build a $300 million factory in Geelong, Australia, to produce lithium-ion batteries without Chinese materials. The operation will start construction in 2023 and begin production by 2024, with an initial capacity of 2 gigawatt-hours and a planned total of 30 gigawatt-hours. The move aims to reduce reliance on Chinese imports, which currently dominate the global battery production industry. Recharge Industries has secured funding and sales agreements with Indian energy storage projects, positioning Australia as a key player in the global clean energy manufacturing capacity expansion.

images.alt_text: Ore falls from a conveyor belt onto a stockpile at Bald Hill Lithium mine site, one of Tawana's operations, outside of Widgiemooltha, Western Australia, on Monday, Aug. 6, 2018. Photographer: Carla Gottgens/Bloomberg
SK On is the wholly owned battery unit of SK Innovation and counts Hyundai Motor, Volkswagen and Ford Motor among its customers.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Wilmar, Mapletree Logistics, Rex, Lian Beng, Centurion
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust is divesting two Malaysian warehouses worth RM50.2 million to Sigma Warehousing, a 6.1% premium over the latest valuation. Wilmar International secured a US$200 million sustainability-linked trade finance facility from Standard Chartered, with a margin ratchet tied to its performance. Meanwhile, stocks such as Rex, Lian Beng, and Centurion are recommended for watch due to recent developments.

site_title: UK’s poor have seen the highest rent increases in last decade
summary: The UK's rental housing market has disproportionately affected the country's poorest families, with rent prices more than doubling for the most disadvantaged households over the last decade. According to census data, households in the lowest 10% of income levels pay the highest rent increases, with a 50% rise in rental costs between 2012 and 2022. This is attributed to a post-Covid surge in demand and a shortage of available homes, leading to a 7.7% annual rent increase in December 2022.

images.alt_text: Britain's GDP growth in November 2022 has defied economists' predictions of a 0.2 per cent decline.

site_title: Share buybacks: Good or bad for investors?
summary: Singapore-listed companies repurchased nearly S$1.69 billion worth of shares in 2022, a significant increase from 2021 and 2020. Companies like Keppel Corp and Raffles Medical Group saw their share prices rise after buying back shares, with Keppel's stock closing 10% above its repurchase price and Raffles Medical's up 17%. However, some companies, like Singtel and ST Engineering, are trading below their repurchase prices, raising concerns about the timing of share buybacks. The trend may continue in 2023, with analysts predicting a decline in share buybacks due to market weakness.

images.alt_text: Ben Paul
Keppel constituted the bulk of 2022 share buybacks by Singapore-listed corporates.

site_title: AIA Singapore appoints Tottenham star Son Heung-min as first brand ambassador
summary: AIA Singapore appoints Tottenham forward Son Heung-min as its first brand ambassador in Singapore, as part of the AIA One Billion movement aiming to engage a billion people across the region to live healthier lives by 2030. Son will promote holistic wellness in three key aspects: physical health, motivation, mental health, and financial health, inspiring Singaporeans to live better every day. His appointment marks a strong connection between Son and Singapore, following his recent English Premier League match with Arsenal in London.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: BT Money Hacks: Uptick in value investing extends to ETFs (Ep 135)
summary: Value investing has seen an uptick, extending to ETFs, which now offer better income generation in an uncertain economic environment. According to Salim Ramji, global head of iShares and index investments at BlackRock, digitalisation has improved ETFs' game, while lowered fees and a diversified nature are key factors to consider when selecting ETFs. The focus for 2023 is on value investing, not growth, with specific ETFs expected to perform well.

images.alt_text: Correspondent Howie Lim explores the ins and outs of fractional property investing with Keith Ong from RealVantage.
Which beaten down asset classes in 2022 will make a comeback in 2023?
What happened with FTX and can cryptocurrency survive this? Correspondent Howie Lim discusses with Wayne Huang from XREX.

site_title: IMF says fragmentation could cost global economy up to 7% of GDP
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) warns that a severe fragmentation of the global economy could reduce global economic output by up to 7% if technology is also decoupled. The report notes that global flows of goods and capital have leveled off since the 2008 financial crisis, and a surge in trade restrictions has led to increased skepticism about globalization. The IMF says limited fragmentation could shave 0.2% off global GDP, but more work is needed to assess the estimated costs to the international monetary system.

images.alt_text: In an earlier session, Dr He Dong, deputy director for monetary and capital markets at the International Monetary Fund (IMF), described 2023 to be a challenging year for monetary policy.
IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva said the IMF expected the slowdown in global growth to “bottom out” and “turn around towards the end of ‘23 and into ‘24.”

site_title: Bangladesh raises key rate a quarter point to contain inflation
summary: Bangladesh's central bank raised the benchmark repurchase rate by 25 basis points to 6% to contain inflation, its fourth consecutive increase. Inflation remains elevated at 9.5% in September, above the bank's 5.6% target. The central bank aims to maintain a "cautiously accommodative" policy stance to support economic growth and address exchange rate pressures. The move is seen as a response to the country's dwindling foreign currency reserves and rising import costs, which have widened the trade deficit.

site_title: Arsenal’s Ramsdale confirms altercation with Spurs fan after derby win
summary: Arsenal goalkeeper Aaron Ramsdale confirmed an altercation with a Tottenham Hotspur fan after the Gunners' 2-0 win in the North London derby. The fan allegedly punched Ramsdale on the back after he was given a verbal warning by the Tottenham player, Richarlison. The Metropolitan Police are investigating, and the English Football Association and Professional Footballers' Association have condemned the incident. Tottenham pledged to take action, including banning the fan from the stadium.
