site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Capesize market had a positive opening on Monday but declined consecutively on timecharter routes, with the Cape5TC falling over $2,000. A few period fixtures were reported, including a 171,000-dwt vessel fixed for six to eight months at 85% of the C5TC, and a 180,000mt vessel fixed for four to six months at $10,500 per day. The Brazil to Qingdao trade closed the week at $17.708, while the west Australia to Qingdao trade was priced between $6.99 to $7.18.

images.alt_text: Demand and cargo enquiry next week will determine which direction the Capesize is taking before the fast approaching Lunar New Year.

site_title: Nature can't wait: Will COP15 biodiversity pact spur fast action?
summary: The COP15 biodiversity summit in Montreal resulted in the adoption of the Kunming-Montreal Global Biodiversity Framework, a landmark global deal to protect nature, with 195 countries agreeing to conserve at least 30% of land and oceans by 2030. China and Canada, as the "parents of the deal," are now expected to work together to build momentum and help countries meet biodiversity goals at the national level. The deal includes measures to restore degraded ecosystems and hold governments accountable for their promises, but critics warn that implementation must start immediately and that more financing is needed from rich countries to help poorer nations meet the new targets.

images.alt_text: Around half of global GDP is moderately or highly dependent on nature, according to the World Economic Forum.

The landmark international biodiversity framework that came out of COP15 raises the need for businesses and investors to gain a greater understanding of the risks that biodiversity degradation presents to their bottom line and portfolios.
Guido Broekhoven, head of policy research and development for World Wildlife Fund International (WWF), speaks during the COP15 UN Biodiversity Conference in Montreal, Quebec, Canada, on Dec 12, 2022.

site_title: Santos to be removed from US Congress if he broke campaign finance laws: Comer
summary: US Representative George Santos is facing removal from Congress if found to have broken campaign finance laws, according to House Oversight Committee Chairman James Comer. Despite calls to resign from several Republican colleagues, Santos has refused, stating he will vacate his seat only if he loses the next election. At least six fellow Republican representatives from New York have joined the calls for his resignation, with Democratic Representative Dan Goldman urging Republican leaders to cooperate with an ethics investigation into the matter.

images.alt_text: As American households struggled with decades-high inflation in the past year, the Federal Reserve hiked its benchmark lending rate at a pace unheard of since the 1980s, in hopes of cooling the world’s biggest economy.
“So the Senate is going to have to recognise the fact that we’re not going to budge until we see meaningful reform with respect to spending.” House Oversight Committee chairman James Comer said.

site_title: Biden declares disaster as California takes another storm-pounding
summary: US President Joe Biden has declared a major disaster in California due to severe winter storms, flooding, and landslides. The declaration makes federal funding available for relief efforts, including temporary housing and repairs. At least 19 people have died from storm-related causes in the past three weeks. Heavy rain continues to batter California, with over 16,000 homes without power and nearly 26 million Californians under a flood watch. The storms are expected to continue bringing hazardous travel conditions and new flooding, with parts of the Sierra Nevada seeing significant snowfall.

site_title: Lithium’s next big risk is grand supply plans falling short
summary: Global lithium demand has surged due to booming electric vehicle sales, doubling over the past two years and causing consumption to reach $35 billion in 2022. However, forecasters predict a more balanced market in 2023, with a 22-42% increase in supply. Despite this, some experts warn of potential supply chain issues and the need for established producers to execute flawlessly to meet demand. Prices are expected to fall around 8% from 2022 levels, but some unconventional sources, such as lepidolite, may pose a threat to prices and the market's overall stability.

images.alt_text: Australia is the world’s largest supplier of lithium, a critical battery metal, though currently sends the majority of its battery raw materials to be processed into components in China.

site_title: Wagyu goes high tech to meet surging demand from rich Asians
summary: Japanese Wagyu farmers are adopting high-tech solutions to meet the surging demand from wealthy Asians. A Tokyo-based startup, Desamis, provides sensors and algorithms to monitor livestock movements, detect unusual behavior, and alert farmers to potential illnesses or injuries. This technology helps prevent losses and ensures the quality of high-quality Japanese beef. With Japan's government highlighting Wagyu farming as a business in need of support, this technology is seen as a key factor in the industry's growth.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on January 10, 2022 a customer shops for food items inside a Tesco supermarket store in east London. - UK inflation accelerated in June to 9.4% year-on-year, hitting a new four-decade high - in the midst of a cost-of-living crisis - which may push the Bank of England to tighten its rate policy. The acceleration in prices in June was fuelled by fuel and food, the Office for National Statistics (ONS) said in its monthly report published on Wednesday. In May, inflation was 9.1% year-on-year. (Photo by Daniel LEAL / AFP)

site_title: China’s reopening is a mixed blessing for emerging-market assets
summary: China's easing of Covid Zero policies and stimulus to revive growth has sent emerging markets surging, with developing-nation stocks and currencies making their strongest start to a year since the 1990s. China's economy is expected to grow at 4.8% in 2023, compared to 0.4% in the US and 0.1% in the EU. However, some analysts are warning of stagflation risks, citing potential inflationary pressures and a potential delay in the Federal Reserve's policy pivot. Despite these concerns, investors are riding the rebound, with many expecting the China reopening to continue driving emerging-market growth.

images.alt_text: For services, China expects the number of international flights to rebound to the equivalent of 15 per cent-25 per cent of their pre-pandemic levels by the end of March.

site_title: Centurion-Lian Beng joint venture wins tender for foreign workers’ dormitory
summary: A joint venture between Centurion Corp and Lian Beng has won a tender to lease and develop a land in Singapore for a foreign workers' dormitory, valued at approximately S$40.2 million. Centurion will commit S$43.4 million, funded by internal resources and borrowings, with no financial impact on either company. The project aligns with Centurion's strategy to expand its workers' accommodation business, and Lian Beng expects to derive rental returns and add to its earnings.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher

site_title: Taiwan is still semiconductor leader as chip exports rise again
summary: Taiwan's semiconductor exports rose 18.4% in 2022, marking the seventh consecutive year of growth, solidifying its leadership in the global industry. The country's exports of integrated circuit chips, driven by giants like Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing (TSMC), have been boosted by efforts to diversify supply chains amid US-China tensions. Analysts predict that Taiwan's significance in the industry will remain, despite efforts by other countries to bolster chip production, and that the future of diversification will depend on where semiconductor fabrication plants are constructed.

images.alt_text: While Taiwan’s assisted local chipmakers in the past with infrastructure construction and other measures, the island is now stepping up its efforts.

site_title: Switzerland moves to soften restrictive arms export law
summary: Switzerland has started working on a reform to its restrictive arms export law, allowing some countries to export Swiss-made ammunition to Ukraine without needing to consult Bern. A compromise in the upper house of parliament is expected as early as February, but further scrutiny in the lower house could block the bill. This move comes after international criticism of Switzerland's law, which has faced opposition from Germany and Spain. The reform aims to soften the country's longstanding tradition of neutrality while still maintaining some export controls.

site_title: The future of fintech: From digital lenders to neobanks
summary: Fintech companies are revolutionizing access to financial services for underserved populations in South-east Asia and India. Digital lending platforms like SCB Abacus, Fairbanc, and Kissht are providing novel ways to supply capital to SMEs and individuals. The "Third Wave" of digital lending is driven by the convergence of AI, open finance, and embedded finance, enabling better credit assessment and customer outreach. Governments and startups are working together to improve financial inclusion through digital infrastructure, such as Aadhaar and UPI. The rise of AI and data infrastructure startups will power better credit underwriting, with private credit investments expected to grow to $2.3 trillion over the next five years.

images.alt_text: Solutions can take on issues in carbon credits projects from a demand or supply perspective. For example, Fairatmos, a carbon technology platform  enables communities as project developers to develop carbon sequestration projects and companies that want to offset their carbon footprint.
The new fund’s size will exceed an initial target of US$400 million, compare with an earlier, similar fund that raised US$275 million, said Tay Choon Chong, managing partner at Vertex Ventures China.
Robotic arms made by industrial robot manufacturer KUKA at its factory owned by Chinese home appliances giant Midea Group in Foshan, in China's southern Guangdong province, in July 2022.

While there are consequences for founders when there are breaches of statutory obligations such as filing annual financial statements, we don’t think that a penalty of SS$600 would act as sufficient deterrence for “bad players”. It is still critical for VCs to be observant and detect undercurrents.

site_title: Signs point to further upside for AUDUSD in 2023
summary: The Australian dollar is expected to continue its upward trend in 2023, driven by a breakout from a falling wedge chart pattern and an inverse head and shoulders reversal. The AUDUSD pair has rebounded from a 1,840-pip loss and is currently trading around 0.697. Analysts predict further upside, targeting resistance levels at 0.712, 0.728, and potentially reaching 0.766 or 0.789, with a psychological resistance at 0.8.

images.alt_text: Australian dollar notes are seen in Sydney in this August 11, 2010 file photo. The decision by Australia's major banks to quit the country's $35 billion a year remittance business is driving fund-transfers underground, a trend exposing the country as a weak link in the global fight against money laundering and financial crime.  REUTERS/Daniel Munoz/Files

site_title: Goldman raises aluminium forecasts on higher Chinese and European demand
summary: Goldman Sachs has raised its aluminium price forecasts due to higher demand in Europe and China, predicting an average price of US$3,125 a ton in London this year, up from US$2,595. The bank expects the metal to reach US$3,750 a ton in the next 12 months, citing low global inventories and a potential return to aggregate deficits. This forecast is part of Goldman's bullish outlook on commodities, which expects investors to generate returns of over 40% this year as the global economy picks up in the second half of the year.

site_title: Gas rollercoaster throws Europe’s inflation outlook wide open
summary: Europe's inflation outlook is becoming more favorable as mild temperatures and increased gas supplies ease pressure on the economy, which was severely impacted by Russia's invasion of Ukraine last year. Natural gas prices have dropped, and if they remain low, it could lead to a faster-than-expected decline in inflation. The European Central Bank (ECB) may revise its projections downward, potentially reaching its 2% inflation target earlier than expected, with some economists predicting a reduction in the fourth quarter. However, uncertainty about gas prices remains, and some warn that the worst of the energy crisis may not be fully behind Europe.

images.alt_text: The sanctions are likely to see a great re-routing of global diesel flows – aided by Russia’s new crude buyers sending fuel back to Europe. In the short term, there is a risk of higher prices.

site_title: Banks need to start managing nature-related risks: WWF-Singapore
summary: Banks in the Asia-Pacific region need to manage nature-related risks and integrate them into their policies and processes, according to a WWF-Singapore report. Despite recognizing these risks, banks have not yet incorporated them into their operations. The report also highlights the need for banks to prepare for upcoming nature-risk standards, targets, and reporting. Experts note that significant hurdles remain for the region's financial players to achieve sustainable banking goals, despite a growing focus on sustainable finance in the region.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
Most banks in Singapore, Japan and South Korea, including DBS Group Holdings and Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group, have set net zero targets.
Around half of global GDP is moderately or highly dependent on nature, according to the World Economic Forum.

site_title: Billionaires heading to Davos reflect changed world order
summary: The World Economic Forum is returning to its annual gathering in Davos after two years of pandemic disruption. However, the billionaire guest list has changed significantly, with zero Russian billionaires in attendance due to the war in Ukraine and Russia's ostracization by the West. The shift reflects the global upheaval, including war, disease, and inflation, which have reshaped fortunes and shifted centers of power. The forum's attendance reflects a changed world order, with new economic and geopolitical dynamics at play.

images.alt_text: The partially snow-covered Schiahorn mountain, beyond the Congress Center, the venue for the World Economic Forum (WEF), in Davos, Switzerland, on Friday, Jan. 6, 2023. Though it’s perched at an altitude of 1,560 meters, this year’s rare winter heatwave saw the Swiss town of Davos basking in temperatures well above freezing in early January, with its mountainsides covered in dead, brown grass and hikers out with their dogs. Photographer: Francesca Volpi/Bloomberg
Its Global Risks Report suggests there will be little respite as countries grapple with “energy, inflation, food and security crises.”

site_title: House Oversight Committee chair urges spending cuts to avoid US debt default
summary: House Oversight Committee Chairman James Comer urged Democrats to agree to spending cuts to avoid a US debt default, stating that Republicans will not budge until meaningful reform is achieved. The US Treasury Secretary, Janet Yellen, warned that the country will hit its $31.4 trillion debt limit on January 19, forcing extraordinary cash management measures that may prevent default until early June. Comer's comments come as Republicans threaten to use the debt ceiling as leverage to demand spending cuts from Democrats, raising concerns about a potential bruising fight over the debt ceiling this year.

site_title: Dubai property price rises seen slowing further in 2023: Betterhomes
summary: Dubai's residential property prices are expected to rise by about 5% in 2023, a slowdown from a 21% increase in 2021, according to Betterhomes. The market has shown resilience despite rising interest rates and a strong US dollar, with cash purchases accounting for 70% of transactions. Russians were the top non-resident buyers in 2022, followed by Britons and Indians. The sector saw a record year in 2020, with 34,000 new units added, and is expected to continue growing, with 30,000-35,000 new units forecast for 2023.

site_title: Saudi inflation edges up to 3.3% in December
summary: Saudi Arabia's inflation rate rose to 3.3% in December, up from 2.9% in November, driven mainly by housing costs. Prices increased 0.3% month on month, with housing costs rising 5.9% from a year earlier. Food and beverage prices, the main driver of inflation in 2022, fell 0.1% month on month. The annual inflation rate exceeded the finance ministry's forecast of 2.6% at the end of 2022.

site_title: China’s 2022 growth seen as its lowest in 40 years
summary: China's 2022 economic growth is expected to be its lowest in 40 years, averaging 2.7% year-on-year, according to 10 experts' forecasts. This marks a sharp decline from the 8% growth in 2021, driven by the pandemic and property woes. Strict lockdowns and the loosening of "zero-Covid" restrictions in December are believed to have contributed to the slowdown. The World Bank forecasts China's GDP will rebound to 4.3% for 2023, with economists predicting growth to accelerate in the coming year.

site_title: Sats’ WFS purchase represents short-term pain for long-term gain
summary: Sats, a Singapore-based airline caterer and ground handler, is set to acquire air cargo handler Worldwide Flight Services (WFS) for 1.3 billion euros. The deal, which was announced in September 2022, has seen Sats' shares fall due to concerns over the acquisition's impact on the company's finances. However, management argues that the deal will provide long-term benefits, including expanded revenue and increased presence in major airports across the Americas, Europe, and Asia-Pacific. The acquisition is expected to be "short-term pain but long-term gain," with potential synergies of over S$100 million.

images.alt_text: Sats' recent share price trajectory has been an accurate barometer of the financial implications of its proposed acquisition of WFS

Glass Lewis noted that Sats still has access to other funding sources to fully fund the proposed transaction, including the acquisition bridge facility of S$1.7 billion to fund and complete the proposed acquisition.
ISS said that as a split-funded purchase, the proposed acquisition also gives the company flexibility to not put too much pressure on any one funding stream.

site_title: How to pre-empt disputes when all is well to avoid conflict when founders fall out
summary: Founder disputes are becoming increasingly common as the startup ecosystem matures, often due to unequal contributions, differing visions, or personal issues. To pre-empt conflict, founders can build trust through common grounds and establish accountability through routines, reviews, and processes. A founders' agreement can also help align expectations and responsibilities, including equity vesting and clawback mechanisms. In the event of a dispute, bringing in a trusted adviser or mediator can help resolve issues and manage personalities. Founders should prioritize open communication, align on values and principles, and iron out details upfront to maintain healthy relationships and avoid costly conflicts.

images.alt_text: Twitter’s strain on Musk’s personal finances – he recently became the first person ever to lose US$200 billion of net worth – and his sale of almost US$40 billion of Tesla shares amid months of impulsive tweeting have aggrieved several prominent Tesla investors.
This comes as Ant adjusts its voting rights structure.
The blowup of Three Arrows shook the digital-asset industry last year and put the interconnected nature of the sector on display.

Caring for others is no soft option in life nor is it easy to do properly. It requires discipline to think about them, not you. It demands being effectively tough, not brutally brash. It presupposes a release to independence, not a debilitating lasting dependence.
Advisers for FTX have been sorting through the wreckage left behind by its founder, Sam Bankman-Fried, since the company collapsed into bankruptcy in November.

site_title: China’s 60,000 Covid death toll spurs calls for more data
summary: China has reported 59,938 Covid-related deaths in a month, sparking calls for more data on the country's Covid wave. The World Health Organization (WHO) urges China to share more detailed information, including on sub-variants and hospital data. Experts believe the actual number of deaths may be higher due to a narrower definition of a Covid fatality and the absence of comprehensive information. China's Covid surge may be peaking in major cities, but rural areas still show signs of infection.

images.alt_text: A surge in travel ahead of the holiday celebrations set to begin on Jan 21, as hundreds of millions of people return home from cities to small towns and rural areas, has fuelled worries about more infections.
Flight passenger numbers stand at 63% of the 2019 figure before the pandemic, as Chinese return to their hometowns over Chinese New Year.

site_title: UAE pledges to invest US$30b in South Korea
summary: The United Arab Emirates has pledged to invest $30 billion in South Korea's industries, including nuclear power, defense, hydrogen, and solar energy. The investment decision was announced during a four-day state visit between South Korean President Yoon Suk-yeol and UAE President Sheikh Mohamed bin Zayed Al-Nahyan. The investment will be led by sovereign wealth funds, including Mubadala Investment Company, and is seen as a step to expand economic cooperation between the two countries. The agreement includes 13 memorandums of understanding, including a cooperation agreement between the Korea Development Bank and Mubadala.

site_title: Paris to hold referendum on e-scooter rental services
summary: Paris plans to hold a referendum on April 2 to decide whether to allow electric scooter rental services to continue operating in the city. Mayor Anne Hidalgo says the issue is "extremely divisive" and critics argue riders often disregard traffic rules. The three main operators, Lime, Dott, and Tier, have proposed improvements, but a cost-benefit analysis suggests a ban may be more effective. If the referendum favors a ban, Paris would be the first major city to do so, making it an exception among peers.

site_title: Boom time for menswear as Paris Fashion Week returns
summary: Paris Fashion Week returns with excitement, marking a boom time for menswear. Award-winning US designer Emily Bode returns after skipping the event during the pandemic, known for her use of recycled materials. The industry sees a shift towards bold, colorful outfits, with red carpet appearances by Timothee Chalamet and Harry Styles. Unprecedented growth in menswear sales has been reported, with Vogue declaring the night belonged to menswear at the Golden Globes. The changing landscape of male style suggests a promising future for the industry, despite economic headwinds.

site_title: France sees investment in commercial real estate tumble by 52%
summary: France saw a 52% decline in commercial real estate investments in the fourth quarter of 2022, totaling 5.4 billion euros, due to rising interest rates and decreased demand. The Paris area experienced an even sharper decline, with deals falling 62% to 2.5 billion euros. The average office price in the Paris region fell 1% to 7,980 euros per square meter, marking the lowest level since 2020. Overall, investment in commercial real estate declined 2% to 25.5 billion euros for the full year, with the Paris area seeing a 3% decline to 15 billion euros.

site_title: What do your colleagues mean to you?
summary: A recent article by John Bittleston emphasizes the importance of trust, loyalty, and perseverance in building strong relationships between bosses and workers. Caring for others requires discipline, being effectively tough, and releasing independence, not debilitating dependence. The author shares his experiences learning from observations during World War II and attending a communications course in 1960, which highlighted the need for leaders to stabilize boss-worker relations. Key takeaways include: treating colleagues fairly, not cosseting them, and dealing with the impossible before tackling issues with solutions.

images.alt_text: The balancing act between keeping customers and remaining profitable makes that inevitable. Customers are making the same choices. Each purchase and every sale represents a vote for survival, a chance to make the world a better place and a hope that 2023 will see the world start to turn the corner towards stability and peace.
Companies often approach the question of "who to buy from" from the wrong angle – the answers don’t depend on means; they depend on purpose
We all shape our own life patterns within the constraints and opportunities we are given.

I was 13 when an old Polish soldier, living out the war as a refugee in Britain, taught me how to plough. He showed me that aiming for the “Tree on the other side of the Field” would achieve a straight furrow, and all subsequent furrows would follow the line of the first. Ever since then I have known each morning, when rising from bed, where my Tree is.

Across the span of societies, from the wealthy to those near or at starvation point, consumers are both better and worse informed than they have ever been before.  The internet and the mobile phone have precipitated the greatest change in the distribution of information that humanity has ever seen.

People widely have a poor view of planning, especially in times of emergency. This may be partly because they see the process of planning as something you do for a posh wedding, where everything must be tickety-boo and there is no room for mishap.  The point is: How much worse would they have been without planning?

site_title: Depots full of containers and sailings with no cargo signal weak consumer demand: analysts
summary: Container depots are expected to remain overstocked in the first quarter of 2023 due to weak consumer demand, with 46.2% of industry professionals surveyed predicting congestion at the start of the year. Increased blanked sailings, where carriers skip ports or routes, also signal low demand, with a 715% increase in Asia-North Europe trade blanked sailings compared to 2019. Retailers in the US have kicked off restocking activities earlier than expected, but overall replenishment is weak, and exports from China to the US and UK have declined.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

Shipping containers and gantry cranes at the Kwai Tsing Container Terminals in Hong Kong, China, on Monday, March 14, 2022. Hong Kong is schedule to release trade figures on March 28. Photographer: Bertha Wang/Bloomberg
Back to the future for container shipping

site_title: Britain’s housing market is flashing red and Sunak’s Tories are scared
summary: The UK housing market is facing a crisis as interest rates double for 800,000 people renewing mortgages in 2023, affecting the aspirational middle classes who are the core of the Conservative vote. This could devastate millions and mark a generational shift in British politics, with some Tory MPs fearing the party's worst nightmare. The crisis is compounded by the government's high tax burden, lack of support for younger voters, and crumbling National Health Service, leading to concerns about the party's electoral prospects in 2024.

site_title: Sean Lee adds to Marco Polo Marine stake; OCBC leads buybacks
summary: Institutions were net sellers of Singapore stocks for the five sessions ending Jan 12, with S$96 million of net outflow. The Straits Times Index declined 0.8%, while the Hang Seng Index gained 0.5%. UOB, Singtel, and City Developments led the net institutional outflow. Meanwhile, 16 primary-listed companies conducted share buybacks, with OCBC buying back 500,000 shares at S$12.59 per share. Director and substantial shareholder transactions included Marco Polo Marine CEO Sean Lee acquiring 2.5 million shares, and A-Sonic Aerospace CEO Janet Tan acquiring 17,000 shares.

images.alt_text: Shares on the Singapore bourse rose on Tuesday amid a mixed showing by regional peers

site_title: WFS acquisition to increase share value, provide pathway to profitable growth: Sats
summary: Sats will acquire air cargo handler WFS, increasing share value and providing a pathway to profitable growth. The acquisition is expected to transform Sats' portfolio, create an Americas-Europe-Asia-Pacific network, and allow for scaling and efficiencies across its network. Sats believes the acquisition will lead to a trajectory of positive financial performance, benefiting shareholders. The company has secured a three-year euro term loan facility and is confident it can deleverage and meet debt commitments with potential free cash flows. The acquisition is expected to drive long-term growth, despite short-term pain.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
Sats' recent share price trajectory has been an accurate barometer of the financial implications of its proposed acquisition of WFS
Caterer and ground handler Sats hopes to diversify its revenue base in order to better prepare for any future pandemics.

Glass Lewis noted that Sats still has access to other funding sources to fully fund the proposed transaction, including the acquisition bridge facility of S$1.7 billion to fund and complete the proposed acquisition.

site_title: Banks swap roles with money managers in US$8t mortgage bond market
summary: US mortgage bond trading fell 14% in 2022, the lowest since 2018, as banks cut back on buying due to huge unrealised losses on securities purchased during the 2020-2021 refinancing wave. The Federal Reserve's end of MBS purchases has created an opening for hedge funds and money managers, who are drawn to unusually high yields. These investors expect prices to more accurately reflect reality and fundamentals, potentially leading to a shift in the market, with money managers expected to lead demand in the first half of the year.

site_title: Former Volkswagen boss Carl Hahn dies aged 96
summary: Carl Hahn, former head of Volkswagen from 1982 to 1993, has died at 96. Hahn is credited with overseeing changes that propelled Volkswagen to international success during his tenure. He previously worked at Volkswagen in North America and Continental in Hanover before returning to the German group as chief executive. Hahn's death comes at a time when Volkswagen is facing new challenges, but he remains remembered for his role in the company's heyday in the 1980s.

site_title: Huge sanctions are looming for the fuel that powers the world
summary: The European Union, G-7, and its allies will impose a cap on Russia's fuel exports, starting February 5, and a ban on almost all imports of Russian oil products. This is expected to lead to a re-routing of global diesel flows, with Russia's new crude buyers sending fuel back to Europe. The EU will need to replace 600,000 barrels of diesel imports daily, and Russia will struggle to find new buyers for its diesel exports, with only about a third expected to be sold. This may lead to higher prices and logistical challenges in the short term.

images.alt_text: John Kerry told the Atlantic Council Global Energy Forum in Abu Dhabi the aim was to create bankable deals to accelerate reduction of emissions, stressing that the ETA was not a substitute for other funding sources and would be time-limited.
The longer voyages, heavy discounts and record-high freight rates ate into profits but the use of supertankers on the Asian routes may now cut shipping costs.
In 2021, UAE became the first Persian Gulf country to declare a net-zero carbon emissions goal – joining a growing list of countries around the world who have made long-term climate pledges.

site_title: Investing when your time horizon is short
summary: Wealth and investing expert Jeff Sommer advises against making all the right investment choices over short periods, citing the example of Tesla's 60% loss in value in 2022 and energy companies' 60% gains. Sommer recommends spreading risks with low-cost investments in the entire stock and bond markets and holding onto them for decades.

images.alt_text: money, home, coin
Stocks like Meta, Microsoft, Amazon and Apple have suffered staggering losses this year, but is this a good time to buy?
Recessions come in many varieties. Any would bring pain, but if history is a guide, stocks and bonds are likely to rise eventually

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower after bank results
summary: The US stock market opened lower on Friday, January 13, due to concerns about a slowdown in economic growth. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 257.18 points, or 0.75%, to 33,932.79, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined. This was largely attributed to remarks from US bank executives and a slump in Tesla's shares.

site_title: Key Apple partners plan South-east Asia expansion in 2023
summary: Apple's major contract electronics partners, Foxconn and Pegatron, plan to expand production in South-east Asia in 2023, amid efforts to mitigate geopolitical and economic risks. Foxconn will grow its scale in China, the Americas, and South-east Asia, while Pegatron will allocate $300-$350 million to expand capacity in Vietnam and Indonesia. Both companies currently produce iPhones in India and will also increase production in the region. The diversification of supply chains is an ongoing trend, with Foxconn and Pegatron seeking to reduce reliance on China.

images.alt_text: (FILES) This file photo taken on May 27, 2010 shows Chinese workers in the Foxconn factory in Shenzhen, in southern China's Guangdong province. - Violent protests have broken out around Foxconn's vast iPhone factory in central China on November 23, 2022, as workers clashed with security personnel over Covid restrictions at the plant. (Photo by AFP)
While recent financial incentives under Modi offered Apple a cost-efficient path to set up shop in India, the California-based company is still making a fraction of its iPhones in the nation.

site_title: China pledges crackdown aimed at cooling surging iron ore prices
summary: China's National Development and Reform Commission has pledged a crackdown on illegal activities in the iron ore market to stabilize prices, which have surged in recent months. The agency will target spreading false information, hoarding, and price gouging. Some information providers have been summoned over publishing old or false news, and authorities are seeking to consolidate purchases by 20 of China's largest steelmakers. A new state-owned company, China Mineral Resources Group, is set to become the world's biggest buyer of iron ore this year, aiming to bolster China's influence over pricing.

site_title: Sceneca Residence sells 60% of 268 units on launch day at average S$2,072 psf
summary: Sceneca Residence, a 268-unit project in eastern Singapore, sold 60% of its units on launch day, with 160 units transacted at an average price of S$2,072 per square foot (psf). The bulk of the units sold were one and two-bedroom units, with prices starting from S$958,000 for a one-bedroom unit and S$1.33 million for a two-bedroom unit. The largest unit, a 2,756 sq ft four-bedroom penthouse, was sold at between S$5 million and S$6 million.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
The mixed-use development project includes Sceneca Residence, consisting of 268 residential units, and a 20,000 square feet retail mall Sceneca Square.
The 14 residential projects will supply some 5,300 private homes in Q1 2023, said Huttons senior research director Lee Sze Teck.

site_title: Oil posts biggest weekly gain since October on China hopes, dollar slump
summary: Oil prices rose by their biggest weekly gain since October, with Brent crude futures up 1.5% and West Texas Intermediate up 1.9%, as the US dollar fell to a seven-month low. The decline in the dollar boosts demand for oil, while hopes of growing demand from top oil importer China, driven by recent Chinese crude purchases and a pick-up in road traffic, are also supporting prices. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries and allies will meet in February to assess market conditions.

images.alt_text: UK’s FTSE 100 added 0.6 per cent after data showed the British economy eked out 0.1 per cent growth in November, helped by a boost from World Cup drinkers and video game sales.
Volume on US exchanges was 10.77 billion shares, compared with the 10.81 billion average for the full session over the last 20 trading days.

site_title: US climate envoy Kerry outlines carbon offset initiative for developing nations
summary: US climate envoy John Kerry outlined the core principles of the Energy Transition Accelerator (ETA), a carbon offset initiative aimed at helping developing nations speed their energy transition. The ETA, developed by the US, Bezos Earth Fund, and Rockefeller Foundation, will create bankable deals to accelerate emissions reduction, focusing on transitioning existing fossil fuel facilities and deploying renewables. The initiative, time-limited and not a substitute for other funding sources, will be guided by a high-integrity, accountable, and transparent approach, with a consultative group established to provide input and add participants.

site_title: Don’t let yourself be crippled by your non-compete clause
summary: The US Federal Trade Commission (FTC) has proposed banning non-compete clauses in employment contracts, which could lead to a $300 billion annual wage increase. In Singapore, courts have historically been more favorable to employees, requiring employers to prove the clause's legitimacy and reasonableness. Experts suggest that Singapore may not adopt a blanket ban, instead opting for a case-by-case approach. Employers can review their non-compete clauses to determine their enforceability and potential for litigation, and employees should consider seeking legal advice before quitting their job to join a competitor.

images.alt_text: Jeanette Tan
The FTC proposal is the latest in a series of aggressive and sometimes unorthodox moves to rein in the power of large companies under the agency’s chair, Lina Khan.
Anti-competitive practices lower US wages by 20%: Treasury
Singapore Airlines cabin crew at the departure hall in Terminal 3 of Changi Airport on 24 May 2022.

site_title: As China tech stocks roar back, a new normal will test upside
summary: Chinese tech stocks have experienced a 60% rally since October due to President Xi Jinping's Covid Zero exit and regulatory overhaul. Analysts, including Fortune Hill Asset Management and Goldman Sachs, have made bullish calls on the sector, predicting a 20% upside. However, concerns remain about regulatory risks and fair valuations, with some firms trading at lower price-to-earnings ratios than their peers. The industry's growth story is expected to be lower and more stable than in the past, with some comparing it to consumer discretionary shares.

site_title: The fashion sale of the century
summary: Fashion designer André Leon Talley's estate is auctioning off nearly all his possessions, including designer sunglasses, with proceeds going to the Abyssinian Baptist Church and the Mt Sinai Missionary Baptist Church in Durham, North Carolina. The 448-lot auction, starting Jan 18 in Palm Beach, Florida, will tour to Paris and New York before culminating in a live auction on Feb 15. The sale aims to secure the financial sustainability of these institutions, which Talley was an active member of. The auction will feature a mix of his fashion assets, personal items, and scholarly books, providing a glimpse into his private life and legacy.

site_title: Helping purpose-driven companies thrive in a post-pandemic world
summary: Singapore's National Volunteer and Philanthropy Centre (NVPC) is transforming its "Company of Good" programme to help purpose-driven companies thrive in a post-pandemic world. The programme aims to enable companies to adopt corporate purpose, aligning their operations to make a positive impact on people, society, governance, environment, and economy. Examples of successful companies, such as Speco and Unilever, demonstrate that "doing good" can translate into "doing well." NVPC is calling on all companies to step forward and embrace corporate purpose, with the goal of creating a better future for Singapore.

images.alt_text: Minister for Culture, Community and Youth Edwin Tong says: "Corporate purpose is about companies that are not just profit-oriented but also ensure their operations generate value for society.”

site_title: China, Hong Kong resume high-speed rail link after 3 years of Covid curbs
summary: China has resumed high-speed rail services between Hong Kong and the mainland after 3 years of Covid-19 curbs, allowing hundreds of millions of people to travel home for the Chinese New Year. The move comes amid a surge in travel and a massive wave of infections nationwide, with nearly 60,000 people dying in hospital due to Covid. Despite concerns, some passengers expressed excitement and relief at the easier travel restrictions.

images.alt_text: Flight passenger numbers stand at 63% of the 2019 figure before the pandemic, as Chinese return to their hometowns over Chinese New Year.

site_title: Global equity funds bag first weekly inflow in 10 weeks
summary: Global equity funds drew their first weekly inflow in 10 weeks, attracting US$5.2 billion in net purchases, as investors sought to ease inflation and boost global economies. European and Asian equity funds also received significant inflows, while US investors exited funds worth US$2 billion. Global bond funds saw their highest weekly net purchases since April 2021, with US$16.9 billion in inflows. This comes amid declining US consumer prices and a decline in petrol prices, suggesting a sustained downward trend in inflation.

images.alt_text: The reopening of the world’s second-largest economy will have a critical impact on financial markets, as they seek to recover from double-digit losses in 2022.
The ebbing of inflation will support the purchasing power of consumers who spent much of the last year squeezed by rising prices, especially for such essentials as energy, food and rents.

A vendor waits for customers at a fresh produce store in Madrid, Spain; April 20, 2022. The hit to household real incomes in Europe from the energy crunch is greater than in any other region of the world.
While bond yields are up, investors should bear in mind that interest rates are rising because central banks worldwide are trying to tame inflation.

site_title: Put your portfolio on an even keel in 2023
summary: Volatility is likely to remain elevated in 2023, but bonds are expected to revert to their role as diversifiers, helping long-term portfolios stay on an even keel. US inflation has cooled, with consumer prices rising 6.5% in December, the slowest pace since October 2021. Investors are betting that peak inflation has occurred, but economists caution that earnings expectations are subdued and recession remains on the cards. A diversified, balanced approach to long-term savings is recommended, with a focus on resilient portfolios that may not shoot for the stars but also won't fall as badly as markets.

Better days may lie ahead for 60/40 stock/bond portfolios.

site_title: Recent acquisitions made by CapitaLand India Trust and ARA US Hospitality Trust
summary: Singapore-listed real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) continue their acquisition spree in 2023. CapitaLand India Trust and ARA US Hospitality Trust have made recent acquisitions, including CapitaLand's proposed acquisition of International Tech Park Pune in India for S$221.9 million and ARA US Hospitality's proposed acquisition of a Colorado Hilton-branded hotel for US$29 million. These deals are expected to be yield accretive and expand the trusts' portfolios in India and the US.

images.alt_text: ParkwayLife Reit continued to expand its healthcare focus in Japan nursing homes through portfolio expansions and acquisitions.

site_title: Singapore tourism expected to recover in 2024, S$110m to be pumped into new events
summary: Singapore's tourism sector is expected to recover in 2024, ahead of the initial forecast of the mid-2020s. Minister of State for Culture, Community and Youth Alvin Tan attributes the acceleration to China's reopening and border openings. The government has set aside S$500 million for tourism recovery and will allocate S$110 million to secure events such as SailGP and the Olympic Esports Week. New events, including SailGP and Art SG, are expected to aid in the recovery, with Singapore looking to anchor itself as a hub for sports and tourism.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
A tour boat makes its way out to the Marina Bay in Singapore on December 9, 2022. (Photo by Roslan RAHMAN / AFP)
China was the world’s largest outbound tourism market before the pandemic.

site_title: Yellen warns of US default risk by early June, urges debt limit hike
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen warned that the US will likely hit its $31.4 trillion debt limit on January 19, forcing the Treasury to implement extraordinary cash management measures that could prevent default until early June. Yellen urged lawmakers to act quickly to raise the debt ceiling to protect the full faith and credit of the US. The White House stated it will not negotiate over raising the debt ceiling, and House Republicans are planning a "debt prioritization" measure to continue making certain payments once the debt ceiling is reached, potentially as early as March.

images.alt_text: Consumers expect inflation to rise 3 per cent over the next five to ten years, a slight uptick from the prior month.

site_title: Citigroup’s profit falls on provision hike, dealmaking slowdown
summary: Citigroup reported a decline in fourth-quarter profit due to a 58% drop in investment-banking revenue, largely attributed to a slowdown in merger and acquisition activity. The bank hiked provisions by $640 million to prepare for a worsening economy. Despite this, the markets business revenue jumped 6% to $18 billion, driven by portfolio repositioning amid volatility. Net profit fell to $2.5 billion, down from the previous year's revenue of $3.2 billion.

site_title: Should an oil executive oversee climate talks? The UAE thinks so.
summary: The United Arab Emirates (UAE) has appointed Sultan Al Jaber, CEO of Abu Dhabi National Oil, to oversee the United Nations climate talks (COP28) in Dubai this year. This move has drawn criticism from environmental groups, but the UAE is trying to balance its oil exports with its goal of becoming a net-zero carbon emitter by 2025. Al Jaber has experience in both oil and renewable energy, and his appointment has been welcomed by the US climate envoy, John Kerry.

images.alt_text: New COP28 president Al Jaber is also chief executive of the Abu Dhabi National Oil Company, which pumps nearly all the crude in the UAE. Many concerned with climate policies may find his appointment controversial because of this post he holds.

site_title: At least 68 killed in Nepal’s worst air crash in 30 years
summary: At least 68 people were killed in the worst air crash in Nepal in 30 years when a Yeti Airlines domestic flight carrying 72 people from Kathmandu to Pokhara crashed in the hillside on January 15. The twin-engine ATR 72 aircraft was 15 years old and had an unreliable transponder. The cause of the crash is still unknown, with officials calling off search operations for the day. The European Union has banned Nepali airlines from its airspace since 2013 due to safety concerns. A panel has been set up to investigate the crash, with a report expected within 45 days.

site_title: Ng Yu Zhi of US$1.1b alleged nickel trading scam declared bankrupt
summary: Ng Yu Zhi, a 35-year-old Singaporean businessman, has been declared bankrupt after a US$1.1 billion nickel trading scam. Ng, who faces over 100 criminal charges, had allegedly transferred hundreds of millions of dollars into his personal accounts. A court ruling in 2022 cleared the way for liquidators to pursue recovery of funds from his assets. Ng's case will be mentioned in court on Jan 17, with the total number of charges against him now at 105.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
THE Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has provided updates on the investigation of ongoing high-profile cases in its bid to provide greater transparency on ongoing efforts.
Ng Yu Zhi slapped with 12 new charges from nickel trading fraud
Ng Yu Zhi slapped with 12 new charges from nickel trading fraud; total charges now at 105
Man faces charge for helping Ng Yu Zhi leave Singapore unlawfully while under probe
Ng Yu Zhi faces 18 more charges linked to nickel trading scam; total charges now 93
High Court dismisses Ng Yu Zhi's appeal to halt civil suit against him, Envy Global Trading
Ng Yu Zhi allegedly splashed over S$100m on supercars, watches, property; faces 6 more charges
Singapore's alleged nickel scammer sued in S$517m action

site_title: Spotify back up after brief outage - Downdetector
summary: Spotify experienced a brief outage affecting over 45,000 users in the US, with services returning to normal. The outage was reported by Downdetector, which tracks outages through user reports. Spotify's status update on Twitter stated "everything's looking much better now," indicating the issue has been resolved.

site_title: Europe: Stocks clock second straight weekly gain
summary: European stocks closed near a nine-month high, supported by healthcare and banking stocks, and upbeat economic data from Britain and Germany. The STOXX 600 gained 0.5% and the FTSE 100 added 0.6% after data showed the British economy eked out 0.1% growth in November, reducing the chance of recession. European shares have started the year on a positive note, driven by a slowdown in inflation and easing monetary policy tightening.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 rose 0.6 per cent, closing out at its highest level since late April, with the  European retail sector jumping 1.9 per cent.

site_title: US household formation late last year seen slowing further
summary: US household formation is expected to slow further in the closing months of 2022, driven by high inflation, rising interest rates, and economic uncertainty. A Federal Reserve Bank of New York survey found that the fewest Americans anticipate changing their primary residence in 12 months since 2013. Sluggish household formation could weigh on discretionary consumer spending and inflation, but also potentially help cool the pace of inflation. The fewest new households were created in the July-September period, averaging 1.2 million, the fewest in a year.

images.alt_text: The housing market slowed drastically last year as borrowing costs surged, sidelining many would-be buyers.

site_title: Twitter workers forced to drop group lawsuit over severance
summary: Twitter has won a ruling forcing hundreds of laid-off workers to pursue their claims over severance packages in individual arbitration rather than through a class-action lawsuit. A San Francisco federal judge ruled that five workers who sued are obligated under their contracts to go through arbitration, but US District Judge James Donato will decide later how to handle complaints from workers who opted out of the arbitration agreement. This decision may be costly for Twitter, as an attorney claims to have filed 500 such claims on behalf of workers, accusing the company of shortchanging employees on severance.

site_title: China’s imports of integrated circuits fall for the first time since 2004
summary: China's imports of integrated circuits (ICs) declined 15% in 2022 to 538.4 billion units, marking the first annual drop since 2004. The decline follows US export restrictions on advanced semiconductors used in AI and supercomputing, which weakened electronics demand and led to paused investments in China's chip industry. This marks a significant setback for China's efforts to develop its own chip industry and advance its military capabilities.

site_title: Omicron subvariant XBB.1.5 accounts for 43% of US Covid cases
summary: The Omicron subvariant XBB.1.5 accounts for 43% of COVID-19 cases in the US, according to CDC data. This is a significant increase from last week's estimate of 27.6%. XBB.1.5 is the most transmissible variant, related to Omicron, and its global spread is on the rise, with over 25 countries reporting the variant. Despite its rapid growth, booster shots continue to protect against severe symptoms, hospitalization, and death.

site_title: India central bank chief calls for vigilance on high core inflation
summary: India's Reserve Bank of India (RBI) chief Shaktikanta Das expressed concern over high core inflation, which rose to 6.1% in December, exceeding the target of 4% in the medium term. Das urged vigilance and called for focus on core inflation, which excludes volatile food and fuel components. He noted that the current geopolitical situation may lead to "high for long" interest rates worldwide, and reiterated that the RBI would not revise its inflation target at this juncture. The RBI has already raised interest rates by 225 basis points since May last year.

site_title: Singapore ports handle second-highest ever container throughput despite fall in global container trade
summary: Singapore's ports handled 37.3 million TEUs in 2022, just shy of the record 37.6 million TEUs in 2021, despite a 3-4% decline in global container trade. The country retained its position as the world's largest transshipment port and strengthened its position as a catch-up port for shipping lines, contributing to the resilience of global supply chains. Total business spending by shipping companies exceeded S$4.3 billion, and 30% more companies set up or expanded operations in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
Interested parties may visit either EMA or MPA’s websites to view the EOI document and submit their proposals by 11.59pm on Apr 30, 2023.

port / ST20220512_202233333961 / Alphonsus Chern //

Generic photograph of the Tanjong Pagar container terminal. 12 May 2022.

site_title: Yen jumps on BOJ policy speculation, US dollar edges off 7-month low
summary: The yen surged 1.06% against the US dollar on Friday, January 13, amid speculation that the Bank of Japan will revise its ultra-loose monetary policy, potentially scrapping the yield curve control policy. This move added to earlier gains and follows news that BOJ officials will review the policy's side effects at their meeting next week. The US dollar edged up against most other major currencies, rising off a seven-month low, as investors expect the BOJ to tighten its policy, potentially leading to a stronger yen.

images.alt_text: The US dollar at one point slipped nearly 1 per cent against the yen on the day to a fresh seven-month low of 128.11.

site_title: Yellen sees supply-chain turnaround in latest inflation data
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen welcomed the latest inflation figures, saying some price pressures have declined significantly. Consumer prices rose 6.5% in December, the lowest year-on-year increase since October 2021. Yellen believes the Federal Reserve can bring inflation down to its 2% target without triggering significant unemployment, citing a path that makes this possible. The annualized inflation rate has decreased to 1.9% since June, down from 11% in the first half of 2022.

images.alt_text: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen’s oversight of about US$270 billion in tax credits for electric vehicles, home solar panels and other climate purchases contained in the Inflation Reduction Act have made her a pivotal climate figure in President Joe Biden’s administration.

FILE PHOTO: U.S. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen testifies before a House Ways and Means Committee hearing on President Biden's proposed 2023 U.S. budget, on Capitol Hill in Washington, U.S., June 8, 2022. REUTERS/Jonathan Ernst/File Photo
Americans are spending less, creating tough conditions for retailers such as Bed Bath & Beyond

As American households struggled with decades-high inflation in the past year, the Federal Reserve hiked its benchmark lending rate at a pace unheard of since the 1980s, in hopes of cooling the world’s biggest economy.
Excluding the volatile food and energy components, the CPI climbed 0.3 per cent last month after rising 0.2 per cent in November.

site_title: Big banks set aside billions as they brace for a downturn
summary: US' biggest banks, including JPMorgan, Bank of America, Citigroup, and Wells Fargo, have set aside billions to prepare for a potential economic downturn. The banks' CEOs warned of a "mild recession" later this year, citing a slowdown in consumer spending. Despite this, the banks reported better-than-expected profits, with JPMorgan earning $11 billion in the fourth quarter and Bank of America reporting $7.1 billion in net income. The banks' shares initially fell but rebounded in the afternoon, ending the day in positive territory.

images.alt_text: A sooner-than-expected reopening of China’s economy, a warmer-than-normal winter in energy-strapped Europe and a sustained fall in US inflation – are combining to dissipate some of the gloom that engulfed financial markets at the end of 2022.

site_title: Air travel recovers in China amid Covid-19 infection worries
summary: China's air travel has recovered to 63% of pre-pandemic levels as Chinese return to their hometowns for Chinese New Year, despite concerns about Covid-19 infections. The rapid recovery poses challenges for airlines to ensure safety, and the industry must address pandemic-related risks. Passenger traffic is expected to jump 99.5% during the festival migration, with cinema box office receipts predicted to reach 10 billion yuan. However, rural areas are feared to experience a surge in infections, prompting concerns about the effectiveness of China's response.

images.alt_text: The reopening of the world’s second-largest economy will have a critical impact on financial markets, as they seek to recover from double-digit losses in 2022.

site_title: Nissan to mull Renault proposal on IP safeguards: sources
summary: Nissan's board committee will meet to consider Renault's proposal on protecting its intellectual property (IP) as Renault restructures the alliance. The Japanese carmaker has been concerned about IP safeguard measures, which Renault is now offering to address. The move comes as Renault seeks Nissan's investment in an electric-vehicle business carved out of its operations. The outcome of the meeting is uncertain, with Renault and Nissan declining to comment. This development may impact the restructuring talks between the two carmakers.

images.alt_text: For Geely, the deal extends its pattern of building partnerships to expand beyond China.
Renault will brief investors about its revamp plans, which are still being finalised, during a capital markets day on Nov 8.

site_title: Derby drama in the English Premier League
summary: The English Premier League is set for a thrilling weekend of derbies as Tottenham Hotspur faces off against league leaders Arsenal in the North London derby, while Manchester United takes on Manchester City in the Manchester derby. The matches, which kick off on Saturday and Sunday respectively, feature high-stakes goals and intense rivalries. Manchester City's dominant form has been tempered by recent losses, while Manchester United is riding a hot streak under manager Erik ten Hag. Meanwhile, Tottenham's Harry Kane is poised to break Jimmy Greaves' all-time record for Spurs goals, while Arsenal's Martin Odegaard has been in sublime form.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

Nakata’s sake company and his new luxury tea brand Hanaahu, comprising cold-brew tea blends designed specifically to pair with food, are the opening initiatives in his overall plan to protect independent farmers and promote farm-based industries to a wider audience.
The American Glazer family that owns Manchester United is looking for an investor and might be prepared to sell up.
Novak Djokovic in action at the Adelaide International earlier this week. His unvaccinated status means he will miss two top events in the US in March.
Argentina won their first World Cup trophy since 1986 by beating France in a penalty shootout in the final in Qatar on Dec 18, 2022.

site_title: JPMorgan profit rises 6% on trading strength
summary: JPMorgan Chase reported a 6% rise in fourth-quarter profit to $11 billion, driven by strong trading performance despite a slump in dealmaking. The bank's investment banking unit saw a 57% decline in revenue, while trading revenue gained 12% due to market volatility. Loan loss provisions were $1.4 billion. The bank's profit per share was $3.57, up from $3.33 a year earlier.

site_title: US: S&P 500 ends at highest in month, indexes gain for week as earnings kick off
summary: The US stock market ended at its highest level in a month on Friday, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq gaining 0.40% and 0.71%, respectively, as banks' quarterly results kicked off the earnings season. Financials were the sector that gave the S&P 500 the most support, with JPMorgan Chase and Bank of America beating earnings estimates. Despite this, Wall Street's biggest banks reported weak investment banking results and caution about forecasting income growth. The market is now awaiting further guidance from company executives in the coming weeks, with year-over-year earnings expected to have declined 2.2% for the quarter.

images.alt_text: A trader works on the trading floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., January 5, 2023. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly

site_title: India’s Wipro warns IT services rev could drop on slow client spending
summary: Bengaluru-based IT services company Wipro warned that its fourth-quarter IT services revenue may decline 0.6-1% sequentially due to clients delaying spending decisions amid growing fears of a global recession. The company's peers, Tata Consultancy Services and HCLTech, have also flagged similar concerns. Wipro's IT services revenue rose 0.6% sequentially to $2.80 billion in the third quarter, but the company expects a lag in winning contracts and converting them into revenue. Total order bookings rose 26% year-over-year to $4.3 billion.

site_title: US consumers’ year-ahead inflation views drop to lowest since April 2021
summary: US consumers' year-ahead inflation expectations have dropped to the lowest since April 2021, with a 3% rise over the next five to ten years. This slight uptick from the prior month is a welcome boost to consumer sentiment, with the sentiment index rising to a nine-month high of 64.6. Consumer expectations for a 4% price increase over the next year also fell, surpassing economists' estimates. This improvement in consumer outlook may provide a positive impact on the US economy.

images.alt_text: Americans are spending less, creating tough conditions for retailers such as Bed Bath & Beyond

site_title: BlackRock quarterly profit slips on lower fee income
summary: BlackRock, the world's largest asset manager, reported an 18% drop in fourth-quarter profit to US$1.36 billion, or US$8.93 per share, due to a global market rout that squeezed fee income. The company's adjusted earnings were below analyst expectations. Assets under management (AUM) stood at US$8.59 trillion, down from US$10 trillion a year earlier, but up from US$7.96 trillion in the third quarter.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A sign for BlackRock Inc hangs above their building in New York U.S., July 16, 2018. REUTERS/Lucas Jackson/File Photo
The firm, with US$7.96 trillion of assets under management at the end of the third quarter, didn’t specify which businesses will be most affected by the job reductions.

site_title: Donald Trump's company to be sentenced for 15-year tax fraud
summary: A New York state judge is set to sentence Donald Trump's company for 15-year tax fraud, with a maximum penalty of $1.6 million. The Trump Organization was found guilty of 17 criminal charges, and former CFO Allen Weisselberg is serving a 5-month sentence after testifying as the prosecution's star witness. The expected penalty is deemed insufficient by experts, who argue it offers "zero deterrence" to others. Trump faces other legal woes, including probes into the US Capitol attack and his 2020 election loss.

images.alt_text: The trial – and a host of criminal, civil and congressional probe cases that Donald Trump is facing – will likely complicate the ex-president’s run for a second term in office, which he announced last week.
The Trump Organization was found guilty on all nine counts, marking the first time it had ever been convicted of crimes, prosecutors said in a statement.

site_title: China state-owned airlines to delist in New York, joining exodus
summary: China Eastern Airlines and China Southern Airlines, two of China's largest state-owned airlines, plan to voluntarily delist their American depositary shares (ADRs) listed on the New York Stock Exchange, citing commercial factors. This move follows similar decisions from other state-owned firms, including China Life Insurance, Petrochina, and three other giants, in August. Analysts anticipate that the delistings will not significantly impact the companies, as their shares have gained in Hong Kong and Shanghai. The decision is attributed to the costs of maintaining a US listing with smaller trading volumes compared to Hong Kong.

site_title: Vowles joins Williams from Mercedes as new F1 team boss
summary: Williams Racing appointed James Vowles, 43, as their new Formula One team boss, succeeding Jost Capito. Vowles, who will join the team on February 20, expressed his honor in joining the iconic team and looking forward to the challenge. He will lead the Mercedes-powered former champions ahead of testing in Bahrain from February 23-25 and the season-opening race at Sakhir on March 5.

site_title: Russian oil shipped to Asia in Chinese supertankers amid ship shortage
summary: Russian oil is being shipped to Asia using Chinese supertankers amid a global ship shortage, following the G7 oil price cap that restricts Western cargo services and insurance. At least four Chinese-owned supertankers are shipping Russian Urals crude to China and a fifth to India, with the use of supertankers potentially cutting shipping costs. This move allows Russia to circumvent Western sanctions and secure cheaper oil prices, with discounts of $15-$20 per barrel reported for Russian oil in India.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Liberia-flagged Aframax tanker Suvorovsky Prospect discharges fuel oil from Russia at the Matanzas terminal, in Matanzas, Cuba, July 16, 2022. REUTERS/Alexandre Meneghini/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: China approves import of GM crops – after a decade
summary: China has approved the import of eight genetically modified (GM) crops, including GM alfalfa, after a decade-long wait. The approval process has been a major issue for seed companies, hindering global commercialization of their products. Bayer's glyphosate-resistant alfalfa, submitted in 2011, was approved, along with another variety. The move is seen as a significant step forward for China, one of the world's largest agriculture markets, and could boost the country's role in global GM crop trade.

images.alt_text: Rice fields in Thailand. Asia is home to the world’s smallest-sized farms and largest number of smallholder farmers, generally defined as those with fewer than two hectares of land.
Crude palm oil (CPO) futures fell after Indonesia announced a policy shift in early June this year to encourage exports by cutting export levies.

site_title: Frasers Property Group appoints new CEOs of Frasers Hospitality and Reit managers
summary: Frasers Property Group has appointed Eu Chin Fen as chief executive of Frasers Hospitality, replacing Panote Sirivadhanabhakdi, and Eric Gan as chief executive of the managers of its real estate investment trust (Reit), succeeding Gan. Eu Chin Fen, previously chief investment officer of Frasers Hospitality International, will oversee the hospitality business unit. Eric Gan, current CFO of FH-BT and FH-Reit, will lead the overall business, investment, and operational strategies. The appointments are part of Frasers Property Group's strategic talent and succession planning.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
The resumption of high-impact events, including the Formula One (F1) race in Singapore, brought throngs of business cum leisure (b-leisure) travellers back to the island.
DBS expects Singapore’s economy to slow in 2023, resulting in more cautious business consumer sentiment.

site_title: Wells Fargo profit falls 50% on higher reserves, costs
summary: Wells Fargo reported a 50% decline in profit for the fourth quarter, with a profit of $2.9 billion and a 67-cent per share. The bank's costs rose due to a fake accounts scandal and loan loss reserves, totaling $3 billion. Non-interest expenses increased to $16.2 billion, and operating losses related to litigation and regulatory matters reached $3.3 billion. CEO Charlie Scharf aims to cut costs, scale back mortgage business, and expand investment banking, but faces ongoing challenges to satisfy regulators and repay customers harmed by aggressive sales practices.

images.alt_text: Bank of America's Q4 profit beats estimates

A man exits the JPMorgan Chase & Co. headquarters building in New York, U.S. in New York, U.S., on Friday, July 8, 2011. LivingSocial, the second-largest daily-coupon site, is close to hiring JPMorgan Chase & Co. as one of the banks to manage its initial public offering, a person with knowledge of the talks said. Photographer: Jin Lee/Bloomberg

site_title: Climate tech company Chooose raises US$15m in funding co-led by Temasek’s GenZero
summary: Climate tech company Chooose has raised US$15 million in funding co-led by GenZero and Soundwaves. Existing investors, including Shell Ventures and Vinyl Capital, also participated. The funds will be used to expand Chooose's Software-as-a-Service platform, which enables enterprise users to build and report on customer-centric climate programs. The company plans to broaden its portfolio of carbon solutions and expand its footprint across more geographies to support its international client base. This funding aims to make climate solutions more accessible and embedded in decision-making processes.

images.alt_text: Solutions can take on issues in carbon credits projects from a demand or supply perspective. For example, Fairatmos, a carbon technology platform  enables communities as project developers to develop carbon sequestration projects and companies that want to offset their carbon footprint.

site_title: Mapletree Logistics Trust to divest two warehouses in Malaysia
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust announced plans to divest two warehouses in Malaysia worth RM50.2 million (S$15.3 million) to Sigma Warehousing. The 16-year-old Subang 1 and 18-year-old Chee Wah warehouses will be sold at a 6.1% premium to their latest valuation. The deal is expected to be completed by mid-2024 and will provide the trust with greater financial flexibility to invest in modern logistics assets. The sale will reduce the trust's portfolio to 183 properties, including 15 in Malaysia.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
The proposed sale price of 3 Changi South Lane represents a 39.2 per cent premium to the property’s latest valuation of S$15.8 million as at Oct 1.
VivoCity shopping mall
The Mapletree Business City located on Pasir Panjang Road on 26 July 2019.

site_title: India lets banks use face recognition, iris scan for some transactions: sources
summary: India's government has allowed banks to use facial recognition and iris scans for certain transactions exceeding a two million rupee annual limit. The move aims to reduce fraud and tax evasion. While not mandatory, the verification is intended for cases where an Aadhaar identity card is shared as proof of identity. This decision has raised concerns among privacy experts, who argue that India lacks a dedicated law on facial recognition and cybersecurity.

images.alt_text: AI enables organisations to help support the financial journeys of unbanked and underbanked consumers.
Fintech is driving a convergence of public and private markets, altering the investment landscape.

site_title: Goldman Sachs platform solutions business lost US$1.2b in 9-months
summary: Goldman Sachs' platform solutions business, which includes transaction banking, credit card, and fintech businesses, reported a pretax loss of $1.2 billion for the first nine months of 2022, adding to losses of $1.05 billion in 2021 and $783 million in 2020. The business posted higher revenue but also higher provisions for credit losses and operating expenses. The platform solutions business was created in October 2022 by folding Goldman's consumer business, Marcus, into wealth management. The bank will report fourth-quarter results on Tuesday.

site_title: Bank of America's Q4 profit beats estimates
summary: Bank of America Corp reported a Q4 profit of 85 cents per share, beating estimates of 77 cents. Revenue increased 11% to US$24.5 billion, driven by higher interest rates on loans. The 'higher-for-longer' rate environment contributed to the gains, offsetting sluggish dealmaking and larger provisions for loan losses. Profit applicable to common shareholders rose 2% to US$6.9 billion.

site_title: Yen surges as BOJ policy under pressure, US dollar edges up
summary: The yen surged against the US dollar on speculation that Japan may revise its ultra-loose monetary policy, while the US dollar edged higher after earlier dipping to a fresh seven-month low. The yen reached a fresh high of 128.11, and the US dollar index gained 0.3% to 102.46. Japan's central bank is under pressure to adjust its yield control policy after the yield on its 10-year government bonds breached the central bank's ceiling, and the Bank of Japan is expected to conduct additional bond purchases ahead of a rate-setting meeting on January 17-18.

site_title: China's reopening brings joy – and woe – for markets
summary: China's rapid reopening from Covid-19 lockdowns is expected to positively impact global investors, who are seeking to recover from double-digit losses in 2022. The reopening is anticipated to boost commodity prices, offsetting inflationary risks, and fueling economic growth in emerging markets. Investors are optimistic about tourism, leisure stocks, and commodities-driven currencies, such as the Thai baht and Chilean peso. However, concerns remain about inflationary pressures, with oil prices rising 10% and potentially prompting the European Central Bank to raise interest rates.

images.alt_text: Concerns over data transparency were among the factors that prompted more than a dozen countries to demand pre-departure Covid tests from travellers arriving from China.
China is expected to grow 5.2 per cent this year, while the US could see a 1.4 per cent expansion, “well above consensus expectations for a 0.3 per cent growth and a technical recession”.
As of Jan 12, the number of mainland tourists visiting Singapore over the Chinese New Year holiday grew by almost five times year on year.

site_title: Malaysia's EPF to sell more than US$115m in education assets: sources
summary: Malaysia's Employees Provident Fund (EPF) plans to sell over $115 million in education assets through its Malaysian education real estate investment trust, Alpha Reit. The assets include schools in Kuala Lumpur and Selangor, and the sale could occur as early as the first quarter of this year. The move is part of a regular portfolio rebalancing exercise for EPF, which is also one of the world's largest pension funds with total assets of RM1.01 trillion.

images.alt_text: According to the World Bank, 20 per cent of the population in Malaysia will be aged 65 and above by 2056, which effectively makes the country an ageing nation.

site_title: German Google data probe targets heart of digital dominance
summary: A German antitrust regulator has sent a formal warning to Google, claiming the company gains a competitive advantage by limiting consumer choice about how user data is harvested. The probe targets Google's data collection processes, which the regulator says provide Google with a unique advantage in the digital market. The case builds upon a 2019 Facebook ruling and comes ahead of the EU's Digital Markets Act, which regulates the internet economy. Google plans to adapt its services and engage with German authorities, while the regulator sees the case as a key moment to address fundamental questions about market control and dominance.

images.alt_text: The United States is home to global tech giants Apple, Google, Amazon and Facebook-owner Meta but has trailed governments in Europe and Asia in drawing up more modern rules to curb their power.

site_title: Japan's economic policy panel won't craft new accord with BOJ, minister says
summary: Japan's Economic Policy Panel won't create a new accord with the Bank of Japan, Economy Minister Shigeyuki Goto said. The panel, consisting of eight economists, will discuss the monetary-fiscal policy mix, but won't draft new policy objectives to replace the 2013 accord. The move aims to alleviate market speculation of an abrupt macro policy shift. Professor Tsutomu Watanabe, an expert on Japan's inflation trends, will be among the economists invited to the special sessions.

images.alt_text: epa10253755 A stock market indicator board displays the 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average figures in Tokyo, Japan, 20 October 2022. Tokyo stocks lost more than 300 points in the morning trading session following overnight fall at Wall Street.  EPA-EFE/FRANCK ROBICHON

site_title: Tribunal grants Jet Airways ownership transfer to consortium
summary: The National Company Law Tribunal of India has approved the transfer of ownership of Jet Airways to a consortium led by Murari Lal Jalan and London-based Kalrock Capital, resolving the airline's bankruptcy. Jet Airways, once India's largest private airline, now owes 180 billion rupees (S$2.9 billion) to creditors. The consortium will need to settle its dues within 180 days and implement the resolution plan to restart operations, with the effective date of ownership set as November 16, 2022.

site_title: World economy’s soft landing hopes boosted as 2023 begins
summary: The world economy is beginning the new year on a more optimistic note, driven by a sooner-than-expected China reopening, a warmer-than-normal winter in Europe, and a sustained fall in US inflation. These factors are dissipating the gloom that engulfed financial markets at the end of 2022, and hopes for a "soft landing" are growing. However, central banks, including the Federal Reserve and European Central Bank, still push ahead with higher interest rates, which could lead to a slump later in the year if inflation proves sticky.

images.alt_text: A vendor waits for customers at a fresh produce store in Madrid, Spain; April 20, 2022. The hit to household real incomes in Europe from the energy crunch is greater than in any other region of the world.

site_title: Optimism over China demand sets oil on track for strong weekly gain
