summary: Oil prices rose on Friday, on track for a weekly gain of over 7%, driven by solid signs of demand growth in top oil importer China and expectations of less aggressive interest-rate hikes in the US. Brent crude futures rose 0.6% to $84.56 a barrel, while West Texas Intermediate gained 0.7% to $78.94 a barrel. Analysts attribute the gains to recent Chinese crude purchases and a pick-up in road traffic, as well as a weaker US dollar.

images.alt_text: Brent crude settled at US$84.03 a barrel, rising US$1.36, or 1.7 per cent on Thursday.
Brent futures rose US$2.57, or 3.2 per cent, to settle at US$82.67 a barrel on Wednesday.
Brent futures rose 45 cents or 0.6 per cent, to settle at US$80.10 a barrel, while US crude ended 49 cents, or 0.6 per cent higher at US$75.12 per barrel.
China’s 2022 exports to and imports from Russia accounted for 3 per cent of China’s total trade.

site_title: Japan Dec core CPI tipped at 41-year-high 4%, twice BOJ’s 2% target: poll
summary: Japan's core consumer price index (CPI), excluding volatile food items, is expected to reach a 41-year-high of 4.0% in December, double the Bank of Japan's 2% target, according to a Reuters poll of 18 economists. This rise is attributed to energy inflation and higher food prices. The Bank of Japan is set to review its policy next week, considering further steps to address market distortions.

images.alt_text: Shoppers crowd at the Ameyoko shopping district, which is Tokyo's biggest street food market, as they do their last-minute New Year's shopping in Tokyo, Japan December 29, 2022. REUTERS/Issei Kato

site_title: India’s NDTV says president, other senior execs resign
summary: NDTV, an Indian broadcaster, announced the resignation of President Suparna Singh and other senior executives, including Chief Strategy Officer Arijit Chatterjee and Chief Technology Officer Kawaljit Singh Bedi. The resignations follow the Adani Group's acquisition of 65% of the company, which took control four months after launching a takeover attempt. NDTV is in the process of setting up a new leadership team to set a fresh strategic direction. The move comes after founders Prannoy and Radhika Roy left the company's board and sold most of their stake to the Adani Group.

site_title: Thailand’s investment pledges reach 664.6 billion baht in 2022, up 39%
summary: Thailand saw a 39% increase in investment pledges to 664.6 billion baht in 2022, driven by investments from China, Japan, the US, and Taiwan. China's BYD Auto received approval for a 3.89 billion baht EV battery facility and plans to build a 17.9 billion baht EV factory by 2024. Foreign investors are attracted to Thailand for EV and medical sector investments, with expected pledges of 500-600 billion baht for this year.

site_title: Lemann-backed retailer Americanas loses CEO on US$4b ‘inconsistencies’
summary: Americanas, a Brazilian retailer backed by billionaire Jorge Paulo Lemann, plummeted 77% after its CEO, Sergio Rial, left the company amid billions of dollars of accounting "inconsistencies" found in its financial statements. The inconsistencies include debts with banks from supplier financing operations not adequately reflected in financial statements. Rial, who will be temporarily replaced, acknowledged the issue and expressed a "moral obligation" to support the company, while Lemann and his business partners vowed to continue supporting Americanas.

images.alt_text: Saudi Arabia’s Public Investment Fund and Dubai businessman Mohamed Alabbar sold 2.5 billion shares in Americana Restaurants International.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise on optimism over cooling US inflation; STI up 0.8%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.8% to 3,293.75 points on Friday, driven by optimism over slowing US inflation, lifting investor sentiment. Markets are assuming a risk-on stance, with Asian markets also finishing higher. Singapore Airlines climbed 4.1%, while local banks UOB, DBS, and OCBC rose 2%, 0.9%, and 0.6% respectively. The gains brought the STI up 0.5% for the week.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
The reopening of the world’s second-largest economy will have a critical impact on financial markets, as they seek to recover from double-digit losses in 2022.

site_title: Goldman, JPMorgan diverge in response to richest Russian’s sanctions
summary: Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan have taken different approaches in response to sanctions against Russian billionaire Vladimir Potanin. JPMorgan severed ties with Potanin's UK charity after the UK imposed sanctions, while Goldman Sachs continues to provide banking and investment management services. Goldman has confirmed it has taken steps to comply with sanctions, with decisions made at a high level. The divergence highlights varying responses to sanctions on Wall Street, with some firms exercising caution.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on May 23, 2014 Interros Investment Company President Vladimir Potanin takes part in the St. Petersburg International Economic Forum 2014 (SPIEF 2014) in St. Petersburg. - The US announced financial sanctions targeting one of Russia's wealthiest men, Vladimir Potanin, the Treasury Department and State Department said on December 15, 2022, adding to efforts that curb Moscow's ability to fund its war in Ukraine. (Photo by OLGA MALTSEVA / AFP)
Russian prosecutors up oversight of foreign firms leaving country

site_title: Temasek-backed ST Telemedia Global Data Centres explores over US$1b IPO: sources
summary: ST Telemedia Global Data Centres, backed by Singapore's Temasek, is exploring a potential initial public offering (IPO) valued at over US$5 billion, which could raise more than US$1 billion. The company, which operates over 170 data centres globally, is considering listings in Singapore and the US. If successful, the IPO would boost Singapore's IPO market, which saw US$354 million in first-time share sales last year. This would be the largest-ever first-time share sale by a Singapore-headquartered company in the US.

images.alt_text: An iIllustration of ST Telemedia Global Data Centres in Goodman Business Park.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Mainland tourists visiting Singapore over the Chinese New Year holiday have increased by nearly five times year on year. Travel bookings to South-east Asia from mainland China have surged over 10 times post-reopening. The Korea-Singapore Digital Partnership Agreement is set to come into effect on January 14. Singapore stocks rose 0.8% due to optimism over cooling US inflation, with the Straits Times Index closing at 3,293.75 points. UOB priced S$850m in 5.25% perpetual capital securities, while REX International's unit secured participating interests in two Norway licenses.

site_title: SGInnovate launches initiatives to tackle biotech, deep tech talent shortage
summary: SGInnovate, a deep tech investor, launched initiatives to address the biotech talent shortage in Singapore. The Helix Immersion Programme (HIP) will train over 100 research and academic professionals in biotech fields, while the Deep Tech Talent Central (DTTC) will provide training programs and facilitate domain-specific sharing with industry experts. The initiatives aim to support the growing demand for biotech talent, expected to widen by 30% over the next decade, and onboard over 500 emerging tech startups by 2025.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai

site_title: Sri Lanka to slash army by a third to cut costs
summary: Sri Lanka plans to slash its army by a third to 135,000 personnel by 2024 and 100,000 by 2030 to cut costs amid its worst economic crisis in over seven decades. The aim is to create a "technically and tactically sound and well-balanced" defence force by 2030. The move follows a peak in military spending in 2021, with the defence sector accounting for 2.31% of the country's GDP. The reduction is part of efforts to reduce government expenditure after foreign exchange reserves dried up, forcing the country to cut back on public spending.

site_title: Twitter’s potential exit from CapitaGreen to have ‘immaterial’ impact on revenue
summary: Twitter's potential exit from its office space at CapitaGreen is expected to have an "immaterial" impact on CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust's (CICT) portfolio revenue. Twitter occupies 22,000 sq ft in the 40-storey office tower, contributing 6.7% to CICT's H1 2022 net property income. However, this would be less than 1% of CICT's total gross rental income in Q3 2022, indicating a relatively minor impact.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim
With the layoffs, Alphabet joins a host of other tech giants that have drastically scaled back their workforces amid a faltering global economy and soaring inflation.
The Singapore office market has swung from exuberance to caution in the course of 2022.

The Business Times reported in May last year that Sea Ltd, parent company of e-commerce player Shopee, was expected to lease most of the office space at the CapitaLand Development-owned property in tandem with its business growth.

site_title: Dalian iron ore hits 17-month high on China demand optimism
summary: China's shift away from its zero-Covid strategy has boosted iron ore prices, with Dalian prices reaching a 17-month high of 881 yuan (S$173.48) a tonne. Iron ore futures rose over 3% on Friday, driven by optimism about demand prospects and global supply concerns, including mine maintenance programs and weather-related disruptions. Economists predict growth prospects will improve from the second quarter, supported by domestic consumption and monetary measures.

images.alt_text: Iron ore’s most-active May contract on China’s Dalian Commodity Exchange ended daytime trade 1.6 per cent higher at US$125.14 a tonne.
The most-traded May iron ore on China’s Dalian Commodity Exchange ended daytime trade 1.9 per cent higher at  US$124.72 a tonne.

A mechanical scoop unloads the iron ore aboard a bulk carrier cargo ship docked at an iron ore transfer and storage center operated by the Shanghai International Port Group in Shanghai, China, on Tuesday, Jan. 26, 2010. Iron ore for immediate delivery into China surged to $131.20 a metric ton on Jan. 8, the highest in at least 13 months, according to data compiled by The Steel Index, a venture of Steel Business Briefing Ltd. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

site_title: China’s reopening may not be enough to change global slowdown
summary: China's reopening is expected to boost global economies, with Goldman Sachs forecasting 5.2% growth this year, above consensus. However, other economists, including Barclays and the World Bank, predict a 1.7% global growth rate, citing a slowdown in global growth. The International Monetary Fund also expects a 2.7% growth rate. Despite China's reopening, economists warn that the global economy will face challenges, including interest-rate-sensitive economies and elevated inflation, potentially limiting the impact of China's growth.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan
The ebbing of inflation will support the purchasing power of consumers who spent much of the last year squeezed by rising prices, especially for such essentials as energy, food and rents.
In the United States, a divided Congress and a weak Speaker of the House of Representatives will be less likely to be able to pass budgets and cut spending as needed.

site_title: Taylor Wimpey looks at job cuts to rein in costs, lowers homebuilding target
summary: Taylor Wimpey, a UK housebuilder, is considering job cuts to reduce costs and lower its homebuilding target for 2023. The company aims for annualised savings of around £20 million, with cost-cutting efforts involving lay-offs. This move follows sluggish demand in the UK housing market, partly due to high mortgage rates and lower loan availability. The company's homebuilding target for 2023 is lower than last year, with weekly net private bookings rate dropping to 0.68 homes per outlet.

site_title: Indonesian palm oil curbs, biodiesel plans to hit world vegetable oil supplies
summary: Indonesia's restrictions on palm oil exports and increased use of crops for biodiesel are expected to squeeze global vegetable oil supplies, affecting edible-oil buyers in South Asia and Africa. The country's B35 mandate, requiring 35% palm-based biodiesel in diesel, will take up 11.4 million tonnes of palm oil this year. Indonesia's palm oil exports are forecast to drop, while domestic consumption is expected to increase. This comes as demand is forecast to climb, driven by China's easing Covid-19 controls and India's boosting purchases.

images.alt_text: Crude palm oil (CPO) futures fell after Indonesia announced a policy shift in early June this year to encourage exports by cutting export levies.

(FILES) In this file photo taken on January 10, 2022 a customer shops for food items inside a Tesco supermarket store in east London. - UK inflation accelerated in June to 9.4% year-on-year, hitting a new four-decade high - in the midst of a cost-of-living crisis - which may push the Bank of England to tighten its rate policy. The acceleration in prices in June was fuelled by fuel and food, the Office for National Statistics (ONS) said in its monthly report published on Wednesday. In May, inflation was 9.1% year-on-year. (Photo by Daniel LEAL / AFP)

site_title: Rex International’s unit offered participating interests in two Norway licences
summary: Lime Petroleum, a unit of Rex International, has been offered participating interests in two new offshore licences in Norway through the 2022 Awards in Predefined Areas (APA 2022) round. The licences, PL1178 and PL1190, are located in the North Sea and Norwegian Sea, respectively. Lime Petroleum will hold 50% and 30% interests, respectively, with potential to add valuable resources to its main producing field. The licences are considered high-potential prospects for oil and gas discoveries.

images.alt_text: The move will bump Rex Technology Investments' existing shareholding interest in Xer from 40 per cent to about 53 per cent, making the company a subsidiary of Rex.
Xer Technologies CEO Kristofer Skantze
Dan Broström, executive chairman of Rex International, pictured during an interview at Rex International Holding Ltd on November 21, 2019.
The oil and gas group holds 95 per cent of the interests and operatorship in both the Rhu-Ara and Diwangsa clusters.

site_title: Singapore crypto firm Hodlnaut’s creditors seek its liquidation
summary: Hodlnaut, a Singapore-based crypto lender, faces liquidation after its creditors rejected a proposed restructuring plan. The firm, which halted withdrawals in August, suffered a near-$190 million loss and is being investigated by Singapore's police force for potential cheating and fraud. Creditors, including the Algorand Foundation, prefer to liquidate the company to maximize remaining assets for distribution, citing a provision allowing directors to continue managing the business as a concern. A hearing rejected an application to remove interim judicial managers, leaving the company's future uncertain.

images.alt_text: The cryptocurrency market floundered in 2022, as risk appetite diminished and various crypto firms collapsed.

site_title: TSMC jumps as investors bet on chip giant’s scale in downturn
summary: TSMC surged 4.6% on Friday after investors bet the chipmaker would recover from an industry downturn in 2023, citing its scale and technology. The company forecast small annual revenue growth and plans to ramp up next-generation 2-nanometer chips. Analysts predict TSMC will resume sales growth in late 2023, with steady migration to new process nodes and specialty manufacturing capacity ensuring long-term dominance in the contract chipmaking market. TSMC reported a 78% net income rise in the quarter, with first-quarter sales expected to be $16.7-17.5 billion.

site_title: Man who allegedly shot Japan’s ex-prime minister Abe charged with murder
summary: Tetsuya Yamagami, a 42-year-old Japanese man, has been indicted on murder charges and violating gun laws for allegedly shooting former Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe in July 2022. Yamagami held a grudge against the Unification Church, claiming it impoverished his family and blamed Abe for promoting the organization. The indictment comes after a six-month psychiatric evaluation, and Abe's killing has shed light on deep ties between the church and Japanese lawmakers.

images.alt_text: Mourners pray for late former Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, who was shot while campaigning for a parliamentary election, at Headquarters of the Japanese Liberal Democratic Party in Tokyo, Japan on July 12, 2022.

Hideyuki Teshigawara, general manager of the Japan branch of the Family Federation for World Peace and Unification (FFWPU), widely known as the Unification Church, speaks during a press conference at the FFWPU Tokyo headquarters on Sept 22, 2022.

site_title: Philippines planning at least 30 billion pesos bond sale
summary: The Philippines plans to sell at least 30 billion pesos ($722 million) in bonds for retail investors, with the first tranche set for a price-setting auction on February 7. The five-year debt will be offered to the general public, with funds used to finance state infrastructure and social projects. The sale is expected to increase the amount raised, following a successful previous sale that raised 420.4 billion pesos. The auction will take place amid signs the Philippine central bank is approaching the end of its monetary tightening cycle.

images.alt_text: Another easing measure could involve banks’ reserve requirement ratio (RRR), with a high probability of it being cut in the first half, Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas governor Felipe Medalla said.

site_title: Travel bookings to South-east Asia from mainland China surge over 10 times post-reopening
summary: Mainland Chinese tourists have surged in travel bookings to South-east Asia, growing over 10 times year on year. Data from Trip.com shows a 1026% increase in bookings to the region, with top destinations including Thailand, Singapore, Malaysia, Cambodia, and Indonesia. Air ticket bookings to South-east Asia have also increased by more than eight times. This growth comes after years of border closure due to Covid-19, with outbound flight bookings from mainland China doubling between Dec 26 and Jan 5. The surge in travel is expected to boost regional economies.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting

site_title: India sets targets for green hydrogen use by some industries
summary: India has set targets for green hydrogen consumption by industries, aiming to generate demand for cleaner fuel as part of its quest to reach net zero by 2070. The government has approved a US$2 billion plan to develop 5 million tonnes of green hydrogen production capacity by 2030. Indian Oil, NTPC, and conglomerates Reliance and Adani have announced plans to build green hydrogen projects. The country aims to use green hydrogen to replace grey hydrogen and decarbonize sectors like oil and fertilizers, with plans to set up green hydrogen bunkering facilities and retrofit ships to run on green hydrogen-based fuels.

site_title: China to support financing for quality developers, adjust borrowing curbs
summary: China is taking steps to boost financing for quality property developers, including adjusting borrowing curbs, to ease a liquidity crunch in the real estate sector. A 21-task plan will guide balance sheets of large, systemically important developers back to a safe range. Financial institutions will use their discretion, and regulators will improve the "three red lines" policy, which restricted high leverage in the sector. A 100-billion-yuan fund will be established to buy housing inventory and support developers' offshore debt repayments. This move aims to address a liquidity crunch that has plagued the sector since mid-2020.

images.alt_text: People walking past the Bank of China headquarters in Beijing, on Dec 22, 2022. In a recent interview, the central bank said it was relaxing the oversight of technology companies.
Country Garden’s stock has tripled in value since hitting a record low in late October.

site_title: PBOC to maintain or increase policy-loan liquidity: poll
summary: The People's Bank of China (PBOC) is expected to maintain or increase policy-loan liquidity, with 21 analysts predicting unchanged interest rates at 2.75% for medium-term lending facility (MLF) loans. The central bank will monitor high cash demands before the Lunar New Year holiday and aim to boost the economy. A majority of traders and analysts expect the MLF rate to remain unchanged, but some predict a small rate cut, while others expect further monetary policy easing measures, including cuts to policy rates and reserve requirements, to support economic recovery.

images.alt_text: The People’s Bank of China (PBOC) injected 87 billion yuan (S$17.1 billion) through reverse repurchase agreements in open market operations.

site_title: China set for historic population decline sped up by Covid traumas
summary: China is set to experience its first population decline since the Great Famine in 1961, with a predicted 109 million fewer people by 2050, according to UN estimates. The country's fertility rate of 1.18 is the lowest among the world's 10 most-populous nations, and the birth rate has declined by 11.5% since 2021, with fewer than 10 million babies born last year. The demographic downturn is attributed to the country's stringent Covid-19 restrictions, financial burden of children's education, and a lack of incentives to have more babies, leading to a significant impact on the global economy and world order.

images.alt_text: China, however, faces additional problems spurred in part by the decades-long enforcement of a “one-child policy” that skewed the gender ratio, given the traditional preference among Chinese parents for sons.

site_title: South Korean police blame deadly Halloween crush on negligence
summary: South Korean police have blamed negligence and planning failures for the deadly Halloween crowd crush in Seoul's Itaewon district, which killed over 150 people. The investigation found massive failures in safety measures, poor planning, and inadequate cooperation between agencies. Six people have been arrested, including the former head of a police station and the head of a district office, on charges of professional negligence resulting in death. The interior minister, who faced criticism for downplaying the disaster, has not offered to resign despite mounting pressure.

images.alt_text: A wide-ranging probe is under way into the exact cause of the crush, and an investigative team on Wednesday (Nov 2) raided multiple police offices, including in the district where the disaster happened.

site_title: From disciplinarian to cheerleader: Why China is changing its tone on business
summary: China's leaders, led by Xi Jinping, are shifting their tone on business, embracing a more business-friendly approach amid a fragile economy. The central bank has relaxed oversight of technology companies, and measures have been taken to ease the burden on businesses, including tax cuts and subsidies. Chinese officials have also rolled back restrictions on heavy borrowing by property developers and indicated plans to continue doing so. However, trust remains a concern, and tensions between China and the US continue to impact business confidence, with companies like Apple diversifying their operations outside the country.

images.alt_text: People buy street food in a shopping district as China returns to work despite continuing Covid-19 outbreaks in Beijing, China, Jan 3, 2023.
Xi has made reining in graft a central aspect of his leadership of the world’s second-biggest economy over the past decade.

site_title: China's 2022 trade with Russia hits record US$190b
summary: China's 2022 trade with Russia reached a record $190 billion, accounting for 3% of China's total trade. Shipments of Chinese goods to Russia have grown for six months, while Russia doubled its rail exports of liquefied petroleum gas to China. China's imports of Russian natural gas and crude oil also increased. Despite a slowdown in dollar terms in December, the two countries are expected to deepen their strategic cooperation, including resuming mutual travel, following the dismantling of China's zero-Covid policy.

images.alt_text: China's exports contracted 9.9 per cent year-on-year in December, extending a 8.7 per cent loss in November, slightly beating expectations for a 10 per cent fall.

site_title: UK economy shocks with 0.1% gain in November
summary: The UK economy unexpectedly grew 0.1% in November 2022, defying economists' predictions of a 0.2% decline. This modest growth reduced the chances of a technical recession in the last quarter of the year. However, the economy shrank 0.3% in the three months to November 30, 2022, driven by a 0.6% fall in output in September 2022.

images.alt_text: The ebbing of inflation will support the purchasing power of consumers who spent much of the last year squeezed by rising prices, especially for such essentials as energy, food and rents.

A vendor waits for customers at a fresh produce store in Madrid, Spain; April 20, 2022. The hit to household real incomes in Europe from the energy crunch is greater than in any other region of the world.
Rishi Sunak did not offer any details, or on how he will end a wave of strikes including by nurses and train drivers that has stoked a sense of national paralysis this winter.
Energy prices had spiked after Moscow launched its invasion of Ukraine last year, pushing UK inflation to a 40-year peak and sparking a cost-of-living crisis.

site_title: China operates first Boeing 737 MAX passenger flight since 2019
summary: China's largest airline, China Southern, operated the first Boeing 737 MAX passenger flight in nearly four years on January 13, 2023, from Guangzhou to Zhengzhou. The flight marked a major boost to Boeing, which had been grounded in China since 2019 following crashes in Indonesia and Ethiopia. China approved the 737 MAX's return to service in December 2021, but Chinese airlines refrained from rushing it back amid strained US-China relations. The move is expected to help meet China's surge in air travel demand after the country reopened its borders, with Boeing anticipating a need for 8,485 new aircraft over the next two decades.

site_title: Indonesia details plans to limit development of nickel smelters
summary: Indonesia plans to limit the development of new nickel smelters to those that prioritize green energy and high-value products, such as batteries for electric vehicles. The country aims to increase value addition from 80% to 100%. Existing smelters mostly produce nickel pig iron or ferronickel, which contain lower nickel content. The move follows the country's ban on unprocessed nickel ore exports in 2020, which has led to a significant increase in export value of processed nickel products to $30 billion.

images.alt_text: Indonesian Minister of Investment Bahlil Lahadalia delivers his address on Promoting Open, Fair and Efficient Post-pandemic Global Investment Regime, during the B20 Summit, ahead of the G20 Summit in Nusa Dua, Bali, Indonesia, November 13, 2022. REUTERS/Willy Kurniawan

site_title: Avaya discusses bankruptcy that would give lenders control
summary: Avaya Holdings is discussing a potential bankruptcy filing that could grant lenders control of the company. The telecommunications firm has been in negotiations with first-lien lenders, including Apollo Global Management and Ares Management, over a Chapter 11 plan. A bankruptcy filing could lead to litigation from investors who have seen their investments decline in value. This marks the second time Avaya has filed for bankruptcy, with the previous filing in 2017. The outcome of the current talks is uncertain, with plans potentially changing.

images.alt_text: Bed Bath & Beyond’s suppliers have become increasingly cautious in recent months, worried about getting paid for the products they are selling to the home goods store chain.

site_title: BT Market Focus: Markets driven by optimism (Ep 27)
summary: Market optimism drove markets this week, with key factors including SGX's wrap for the week, insight from The Business Times' newsdesk, and notable market-driving news. The podcast discussed the week's market movements and drivers, with Claressa Monteiro providing analysis and insights. The episode highlighted the importance of understanding market drivers and movements to make informed investment decisions.

images.alt_text: How markets fared in the new year.
How much damage has inflation inflicted on markets this week? Claressa Monteiro finds out.

site_title: Mercedes EQE review: No more fuelling around
summary: The Mercedes EQE 350+ is an all-electric car that offers a unique blend of performance, comfort, and futuristic design. With a 292 hp electric motor, the EQE accelerates from 0-100 km/h in 6.4 seconds and boasts a range of up to 587 km. The car's cabin features a luxurious, digital interior with a beautiful wood veneer and customizable lighting schemes. While the EQE's rear legroom is compromised due to its streamlined shape, its spacious cabin and advanced technology make it an attractive option for those seeking a premium electric driving experience.

images.alt_text: The Audi really is a flagship limo at its best: roomy like hell, plush like anything and lacking for nothing in terms of equipment.

site_title: Art SG a turning point for Singapore market?
summary: The ART SG art fair in Singapore has concluded its VIP preview with positive sentiments, despite some galleries not generating satisfactory sales. Mega galleries like David Zwirner and White Cube sold over $2.5 million worth of blue-chip art, while Singapore galleries such as FOST and Yavuz sold more than half of their works at modest prices. Many galleries reported strong sales, with some selling almost everything in their booths by the end of the first day. The event has been seen as a turning point for the Singapore market, with participants expressing optimism about the fair's potential for future growth.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
National Gallery Singapore's Light To Night festival will feature live performances, large-scale installations, a market and other attractions.
ART SG Co-Founder Magnus Renfrew and Director Shuyin Yang.

site_title: China Covid peak to last two-three months, hit rural areas next
summary: China's Covid-19 peak is expected to last 2-3 months, with rural areas expected to be hit hard due to limited medical resources. The country's sudden lifting of restrictions has led to a surge in infections, with hundreds of millions traveling for Lunar New Year holidays. Despite reporting only 5,000 Covid-related deaths since the pandemic began, concerns over data transparency have prompted over a dozen countries to demand pre-departure Covid tests from travelers. China's economy is expected to grow 4.9% this year, still below pre-pandemic levels.

images.alt_text: China has reported fewer than 40 deaths since the major pivot away from Covid Zero in early December.

site_title: The Pareto principle in healthcare
summary: Singapore's Healthier SG initiative aims to prioritize and optimize healthcare resources, focusing on chronic conditions with the highest social cost and disease burden. The 80/20 principle suggests that 80% of healthcare costs are attributed to 20% of the population, particularly those with chronic conditions. By targeting high-impact conditions like diabetes and investing in community partnerships, technology, and mental health programs, Singapore can achieve sustainable health outcomes while minimizing costs.

images.alt_text: Healthier SG: Leveraging the workplace

site_title: Three forces shaping growth, inflation, and markets in 2023
summary: A global economic outlook shift is underway, driven by three forces: US excess demand and tight monetary policy, Europe's energy crunch, and China's broken growth model. This combination is expected to produce low growth, elevated inflation in the short term, and low medium-term inflation, with average returns in financial markets. US inflation is expected to fall in 2023, but the legacy of high inflation will lead to tighter macroeconomic policy. Europe's supply constraints will remain volatile, and China's demand will continue to be deflationary, with a risk of a housing crash. Market returns will be met with economic reality, with valuations not compellingly cheap and a negative stock-bond returns correlation expected further out.

images.alt_text: The economic outlook has improved somewhat in recent months, and a soft landing has become much more plausible.
The Lujiazui financial district of Shanghai. China is a bright spot amid the bleak economic backdrop. Relaxation of zero-Covid policy is likely to take the brake off the economy.

site_title: Chinese EV maker BYD to build Vietnam component plant: sources
summary: Chinese electric vehicle maker BYD plans to build a plant in Vietnam to produce car parts, with an investment exceeding $250 million. The move aims to reduce BYD's reliance on China and deepen its supply chain in South-east Asia. The plant, which will produce components for its assembly plant in Thailand, is part of BYD's global expansion strategy. The investment will also expand BYD's presence in Vietnam, where its electronic unit produces solar panels, and could serve the local market through maintenance services and spare parts for BYD vehicles imported from China.

images.alt_text: BYD, which entered India in 2007, will launch its third electric model, the Seal luxury sedan, by the last quarter of 2023.

site_title: To activate hope, activate capital
summary: Cooperation among policymakers, regulators, and investors is crucial to unlock global capital markets' vast potential and accelerate the development of affordable clean technologies. The need for vast amounts of capital to support climate-related projects has become clear, with the International Energy Agency estimating trillions of dollars in annual costs. However, recent developments such as higher-quality data, carbon pricing, and taxes offer reasons for hope. Asset owners and investors have also stepped up, with over $70 trillion in assets committed to a low-carbon economy, and global climate investment is expected to exceed $1 trillion in 2022.

images.alt_text: Coins, plant, growth, investment, Cedit: Pixabay

site_title: South Korea December import price growth slowest in 21 months
summary: South Korea's import prices rose 9.1% in December, the slowest pace in 21 months, as the won currency strengthened and oil prices fell. This decline in import prices suggests weakening pressure on consumer inflation. Export prices also rose at a slower rate of 3.1%, marking the slowest since February 2021. The dollar/won exchange rates were 5.0% lower in December, contributing to the decline in import prices.

site_title: Malaysia’s Zahid puts faith in his party over leadership vote
summary: Malaysia's Deputy Prime Minister Ahmad Zahid Hamidi has stated he will let his party, Umno, decide whether his presidency should be open for contest, potentially destabilizing Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim's coalition government. Zahid, who played a key role in supporting Anwar's coalition, has faced increasing pressure after Umno's worst-ever electoral performance last year. He urged party delegates to move forward in unison to maintain political stability, warning that divisions could deepen and affect the federal government. Zahid's leadership is now being challenged by former health minister Khairy Jamaluddin.

images.alt_text: Malaysians are hoping that the new government led by prime minister Anwar Ibrahim could focus on steering the economy and tackling issues on high cost of living.

site_title: Japan yields break central bank ceiling as markets press for policy shift
summary: Japan's central bank, the Bank of Japan, has breached its yield curve control (YCC) ceiling on its 10-year government bonds, with yields reaching 0.54% as investors rush for the exits amid speculation of a policy shift. The BOJ has responded with emergency buying, but market experts warn of a potential "reputational damage" if the policy is abandoned abruptly. Analysts predict a gradual exit from YCC, citing the strain it has caused in global markets, but domestic analysts remain skeptical, citing Haruhiko Kuroda's potential retirement as a key factor in any policy shift.

images.alt_text: The yen rose 1.3 per cent to a session high of 130.80 per US dollar following a Yomiuri report that the BOJ will review the side effects of its monetary easing at next week’s policy meeting.

site_title: Tesla cuts prices in US, Germany in pivot to drive sales
summary: Tesla has cut prices on its top-selling electric vehicles in the US and Germany, with discounts ranging from 6% to 20% and 1% to 17%, respectively. The moves come after the company missed Wall Street estimates for fourth-quarter deliveries and amid a shift in strategy to boost sales. The price cuts, combined with a US$7,500 federal tax credit, result in a discount of up to 31% for US buyers. This marks a reversal of Tesla's pricing strategy in its largest markets, following similar price cuts in China and other Asian markets.

images.alt_text: Even though Tesla cars are not connected with Starlink equipment, which would allow users to bypass China’s Great Firewall, Beijing has become increasingly concerned about data security and social stability.

site_title: IMF chief expects to keep 2023 global growth forecast steady at 2.7%
summary: IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva expects global growth to remain steady at 2.7% in 2023, with the slowdown expected to "bottom out" by the end of the year and turn around into 2024. Labor markets remain strong, and concerns about an oil price spike have not materialized. However, inflation remains stubborn, and central banks should continue to prioritize price stability. The IMF does not expect any major downgrades, but notes great uncertainty due to potential climate events, cyberattacks, or escalation in Russia's war in Ukraine.

images.alt_text: The housing market slowed drastically last year as borrowing costs surged, sidelining many would-be buyers.

As American households struggled with decades-high inflation in the past year, the Federal Reserve hiked its benchmark lending rate at a pace unheard of since the 1980s, in hopes of cooling the world’s biggest economy.

site_title: US market’s celebration of easing inflation could falter as reasons for relief become clear: analysts
summary: US stocks may face a decline as an economic slowdown emerges, despite recent upward momentum. The US Department of Labor reported a 0.1% decline in the consumer price index in December, with year-on-year inflation at 6.5%. Analysts warn that the recent relief may be short-lived, citing a recession as a more significant threat. Some predict a 20% dive in the S&P 500 index to around 3,000 points, with corporate earnings and GDP data expected to take center stage in the coming months.

images.alt_text: Tokyo dropped more than one per cent as an increasingly stronger yen took its toll on exporters.
The ebbing of inflation will support the purchasing power of consumers who spent much of the last year squeezed by rising prices, especially for such essentials as energy, food and rents.

As American households struggled with decades-high inflation in the past year, the Federal Reserve hiked its benchmark lending rate at a pace unheard of since the 1980s, in hopes of cooling the world’s biggest economy.

site_title: Asia: Most markets rise as US inflation boosts Federal Reserve slowdown hopes
summary: Asian markets rose on Friday, with most indexes tracking the New York rally after the US inflation data showed a slowdown in inflation, fueling hopes for a softer Federal Reserve approach. The dollar remained under pressure, while the yen reached its strongest level since June. China's reopening and a report on the first month-on-month dip in US inflation since 2021 also boosted markets. However, the head of the IMF warned that inflation remains stubborn and that central banks still have work to do, citing concerns about the impact of higher rates on corporate earnings and the jobs market.

images.alt_text: In early trade on Thursday, Hong Kong again led the gains by rising more than one per cent while Shanghai, Sydney, Seoul, Wellington, Taipei, Manila and Jakarta also rallied.

site_title: Shopee to close its Polish operations on Jan 13
summary: Shopee to close its Polish operations on January 13, marking the end of its presence in the country after operating since autumn 2021. The decision is not surprising, following previous market withdrawals and job cuts. Analyst Lukasz Wachelko notes that Shopee's exit from the Polish market aligns with the company's strategy of focusing on more promising markets.

site_title: Apple CEO’s pay cut 40% in 2023 after shareholder feedback
summary: Apple CEO Tim Cook's compensation will decrease by 40% in 2023 to $49 million, following shareholder feedback. The company will increase the percentage of stock units tied to performance to 75% in 2023 and future years. Cook's pay package will remain similar to 2022, with a base salary of $3 million and a bonus of $6 million. The decision reflects increasing shareholder criticism of Cook's previous compensation package, which included stock vesting post-retirement and rewards not tied to performance criteria.

images.alt_text: The changes are part of a sweeping effort to replace Apple supplies with homegrown parts, an undertaking that will give the company more control over the design and capabilities of its products.
Apple, which included BOE in its 2021 list of manufacturing partners, uses OLED screens for its latest iPhone smartphones.
The current work calls for Apple’s first touch-screen MacBook Pro to retain a traditional laptop design, including a standard trackpad and keyboard.

site_title: Japan expects local FTX clients to get funds back from February
summary: Japan's financial watchdog expects FTX Japan to repay customer funds starting in mid-February, following a plan announced by the firm. The unit's assets have been segregated, and the regulator is in close communication with FTX Japan. About 41 parties have expressed interest in buying the Japanese unit, which will not lose its licenses even if its owner changes. This is a rare example of investors getting money back following FTX's collapse, contrasting with other countries where the path to recovery remains unclear.

site_title: Gemini and Genesis sued by SEC over crypto ‘Earn’ programme
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has sued cryptocurrency brokerages Genesis Global Capital and Gemini Trust for allegedly breaking securities rules. The SEC claims that Genesis and Gemini's "Earn" programme, which offered passive returns on users' coins, amounted to the offering of unregistered securities and raised billions of dollars from hundreds of thousands of investors. The SEC is seeking penalties, injunctive relief, and return of ill-gotten gains. The firms have denied the allegations, with Gemini co-founder Tyler Winklevoss calling the case a "manufactured parking ticket".

images.alt_text: Genesis' parent company DCG is considering offloading parts of its venture-capital holdings, worth about US$500 million, the Financial Times reports.
Genesis told clients in an update this week that it needs more time to come up with a solution for the troubles at its lending unit.
In mid-November, Tyler and Cameron Winklevoss suddenly halted redemptions after a key partner became ensnared in the crypto contagion caused by the implosion of Sam Bankman-Fried’s FTX.

site_title: Bosch doubles down on China with US$1b EV parts plant
summary: Bosch is investing around $1 billion to build a facility in Suzhou, China, to develop, test, and manufacture electric vehicle (EV) components and automated-driving technology for local automakers. The German manufacturer aims to tap into China's growing EV market, despite concerns from the German government about over-reliance on the country. The new facility, set to be completed by mid-2024, will focus on technology such as silicon carbide power modules and integrated braking systems, further solidifying Bosch's bet on China's automotive sector.

site_title: Samsung fund unit considers more Hong Kong crypto products after ETF
summary: Samsung Asset Management is launching a futures-based Bitcoin ETF in Hong Kong and is considering starting a spot Bitcoin ETF if the city allows it. The company is monitoring Hong Kong's changing rule book for digital assets, which aims to develop a crypto hub in the city. The move comes as Hong Kong pursues a plan to attract crypto business, including retail trading and digital-asset ETFs. Analysts expect spot Bitcoin and Ether products to be allowed in Hong Kong by the end of 2023, with total assets under management in Hong Kong ETFs expected to surpass $50 billion by year-end.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong’s move to allow retail trading in cryptocurrencies has come after months of turmoil in the sector.

site_title: China’s exports, imports tumble sharply in Dec, cloud 2023 growth outlook
summary: China's exports contracted 9.9% year-on-year in December, extending an 8.7% loss in November, beating expectations for a 10% fall. Imports also tumbled, driven by surging Covid-19 infections and a property downturn. The decline highlights risks to China's economic recovery this year, despite the government's efforts to reopen the economy after lifting strict Covid-19 measures. Global demand cooling and the looming global recession are expected to continue weakening China's exports.

images.alt_text: An arm of the Cyberspace Administration of China took 1 per cent of an Alibaba digital media subsidiary in Guangzhou on Jan 4, according to corporate database Qichacha.
Imports increased about 1.5 per cent from a year earlier.

site_title: First digital trade deal between Singapore, South Korea comes into effect on Jan 14
summary: Singapore and South Korea's first digital trade deal, the Korea-Singapore Digital Partnership Agreement (KSDPA), comes into effect on January 14. The agreement aims to integrate both countries' digital ecosystems, promoting new growth opportunities for businesses. It sets rules and standards for digital trade, data flow protection, and digital system protection, enabling seamless and safe cross-border electronic payments and paperless trading. The pact also encourages innovation, protects online consumers, and promotes collaboration among small and medium-sized enterprises.

images.alt_text: PM Lee Hsien Loong and European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen announced the EU-Singapore Digital Partnership on Dec 14, 2022.

site_title: Crypto crime hits record US$20b in 2022
summary: Cryptocurrency transactions involving illicit activities reached a record US$20.1 billion in 2022, according to blockchain analytics firm Chainalysis. This represents a 7% increase from the previous year, with sanctioned entities accounting for 44% of illicit activity. Transactions associated with Russian exchange Garantex, sanctioned by the US Treasury Department, contributed significantly to this figure. The market downturn may have contributed to the decline in other illicit transactions, such as scams and ransomware.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Representations of the Ripple, Bitcoin, Etherum and Litecoin virtual currencies are seen on a PC motherboard in this illustration picture, February 14, 2018. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/File Photo

site_title: Stocks to watch: UOB, Keppel Corp, Lian Beng
summary: UOB priced S$850 million in 5.25% perpetual capital securities, with shares dropping 0.6% to close at S$29.92. Keppel Corp issued stern warnings to six former senior management staff for bribery-related offences, causing shares to fall 1.2% to S$7.17. Lian Beng Group posted a 48% rise in earnings to S$22 million for the first half, with shares remaining unchanged at S$0.515.

site_title: UK first-time home-buyers’ mortgage costs highest since 2008: Nationwide
summary: Mortgage costs for first-time home-buyers in the UK have risen to their highest since 2008, with the average monthly payment equivalent to 39% of a single full-time salary after tax. Despite a 2.5% fall in house prices and 7% annual wage growth, mortgage rates have increased due to the Bank of England's interest rate hikes and previous financial market turmoil. Nationwide estimates that house prices will fall 15% by mid-2024, adding to an inflationary backdrop that makes housing affordability challenging.

images.alt_text: City of London economists have warned that the tight jobs market will keep the pressure on the BOE to increase interest rates again next month despite some signs of a cooling in employer demand.

site_title: Japan racks up new security deals with eyes on China
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida is strengthening the country's security ties with major allies, including the US, Britain, and Australia, amid growing pressure from China. The government has unveiled a major defence overhaul, including doubling spending to 2% of GDP by 2027 and designating China as Japan's "greatest strategic challenge." Kishida has signed agreements with these countries, including a space defence pact with the US and a troop deployment deal with Britain, in an effort to normalise Japan's role as a great power and counter China's growing influence.

images.alt_text: Markets are rife with speculation the BOJ could move further to phase out governor Haruhiko Kuroda’s massive stimulus by tweaking its yield control policy under a new central bank governor.
Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida, who will host a summit of G7 industrial powers in May, will meet leaders of the United States, Britain, France, Italy and Canada this week.
The US rolled out sweeping measures in October to limit the sale of advanced semiconductors and chipmaking equipment to China.

site_title: Bed Bath & Beyond begins talks on bankruptcy loan, takeover
summary: Bed Bath & Beyond is in talks with potential lenders to finance the company during bankruptcy proceedings. The retailer is exploring "multiple paths" to improve its outlook, including a potential stalking horse bid where a party would buy assets and set the low end of the bidding bar. Bed Bath & Beyond has seen significant losses, with a net loss of $393 million in the last quarter, and has considered bankruptcy as a strategic alternative. The company has been advised by law firms and investment banks, and is determining its next steps thoroughly.

images.alt_text: Bed Bath & Beyond was plagued by years of management missteps and a dysfunctional corporate culture that left it ill-equipped to compete against Amazon.com and other online retail juggernauts.

site_title: Bank of Korea raises rates to 14-year high, as expected
summary: South Korea's central bank, the Bank of Korea, raised its policy interest rate by 25 basis points to 3.50%, the highest since 2008, in line with expectations. The move marks the 10th interest rate rise since 2021 and aims to stabilize prices, while also seeking a soft landing for the economy. Annual consumer inflation has been falling, but remains above the central bank's target of 2%. The decision follows Governor Rhee Chang Yong's remarks that the central bank's policy stance would continue to focus on stabilizing prices.

images.alt_text: South Korea government will work to allow US dollar-won spot trading until 2 am as early as the second half of 2024.

site_title: Activist investor Peltz kicks off battle for Disney board seat
summary: Billionaire activist investor Nelson Peltz has launched a bid to join Disney's board, citing the company's problems as self-inflicted and calling for a turnaround. Peltz's Trian Fund Management owns $900 million worth of Disney stock, and he has not provided a detailed plan for achieving his goals. The move is a challenge to Disney CEO Bob Iger, who recently returned to the role. Disney's shares rose 1% in premarket trading, with some analysts seeing Peltz's past successes as a potential solution to the company's issues.

site_title: World economy walks tightrope between recession and soft landing
summary: The world economy is beginning the new year on a more optimistic note, with factors such as China's sooner-than-expected reopening, a warmer winter in Europe, and sustained US inflation easing, fanning hopes of a soft landing. However, the risk of a recession cannot be dismissed, especially if inflation proves sticky and central banks fail to calibrate restraint. Goldman Sachs chief economist Jan Hatzius believes there's a narrow path to a soft landing, but others, including JPMorgan Chase & Co, warn of a 70% chance of a slump later this year or in 2024.

images.alt_text: Residental buildings in Huaian, in China's eastern Jiangsu province. China's reopening will be bumpy and may buffet commerce before buttressing it.

site_title: Gold prices set for weekly gain on smaller US rate-hike bets
summary: Gold prices are expected to gain for the fourth consecutive week, driven by a weaker US dollar and slower interest rate hike expectations from the Federal Reserve. Spot gold rose 0.1% to $1,897.92 per ounce, while US gold futures gained 0.2% to $1,901.80. The dollar index is on track for a weekly loss, making gold more attractive to overseas buyers. The US Federal Reserve's upcoming meeting may see a shift to quarter-point rate hikes, providing hope that inflation is on a sustained downward trend.

images.alt_text: Although gold is seen as an inflation hedge, rising rates increase the opportunity cost of holding bullion.

site_title: India iPhone breakthrough masks struggle to be next China
summary: India's efforts to attract global manufacturers have yielded a breakthrough with Apple, which began assembling its latest iPhone models in the country. Despite recent financial incentives under Prime Minister Narendra Modi's "Make in India" campaign, Apple still makes a fraction of its iPhones in India. Rising tensions between Western nations and China, as well as a growing friendship with the US, Australia, and Japan, are seen as advantages for India in attracting global manufacturers. The move is a significant win for Modi's campaign, but Apple's limited production in India suggests that the country still faces significant competition from China.

images.alt_text: The working group will initially focus on trade facilitation, digitisation of customs procedures, issues related to mobilisation of sustainable finance and scaling up of innovative clean technologies.

site_title: Central bank rates seen peaking soon in S-E Asia
summary: South-east Asian central banks are nearing the end of their interest rate tightening cycle, with economists predicting a slowdown in rate increases. Indonesia, Philippines, and Thailand are expected to raise borrowing costs by a total half-point in the coming months, while Malaysia will cap the rate hike cycle with one more quarter-point increase. The US Federal Reserve's slowdown in rate increases is also expected to support the region's central banks, which have used various tools to cool inflation and support currencies. Policymakers aim to preserve growth amid fears of recession in some advanced economies.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Thailand's central bank is seen at the Bank of Thailand in Bangkok, Thailand April 26, 2016. REUTERS/Jorge Silva/File Photo

site_title: China’s government to take golden shares in Alibaba, Tencent
summary: China's government is set to take golden shares in Alibaba Group Holding and Tencent Holdings, indicating a move to exert greater control over key internet players. This comes as Beijing prepares to loosen its grip on the sector after a year-long crackdown. The golden share structure would grant officials a tool to influence industry decisions over the long term, potentially loosening China's grip on the world's largest internet arena.

images.alt_text: WeDoctor is taking another go at listing after its previous attempts got disrupted.
Alibaba is targeting Turkey for expansion because of its strong production capacity that could back e-commerce and become part of the company’s supply chain in Europe and the Middle East.
The source says that Alibaba sold the Paytm stake at 536.95 rupees per share.

site_title: US mortgage rates fall to 6.33% in biggest drop since early December
summary: US mortgage rates dropped to 6.33% in the largest decline since early December, according to Freddie Mac. This follows a week of increases, and mortgage rates remain volatile but above 6%. The housing market slowed last year due to surging borrowing costs, sidelining many would-be buyers. Despite the rate decrease, buyers face a more expensive market than a year ago, with a $600,000 mortgage costing $3,726 per month. Experts predict a "seesaw trajectory" in the short term, with interest rates continuing to fluctuate.

images.alt_text: As American households struggled with decades-high inflation in the past year, the Federal Reserve hiked its benchmark lending rate at a pace unheard of since the 1980s, in hopes of cooling the world’s biggest economy.

site_title: China posts record trade surplus for 2022 despite slowing demand
summary: China's trade surplus reached a record 5.87 trillion yuan in 2022, exceeding the previous year's record of 4.3 trillion yuan. Despite a global drop-off in demand, exports surged 10.5% and imports rose 4.3% in 2022. Imports increased 1.5% in December, while exports fell 0.6% in yuan terms. The surplus widened due to strong exports in the first half of the year, offsetting the decline in demand in the final quarter.

site_title: Oil up more than 1% on US inflation data, demand optimism
summary: Oil prices rose 1.7% on Thursday, with Brent crude settling at $84.03 a barrel, driven by US inflation data showing a 0.1% decline and optimism over China's demand outlook. The US dollar tumbled to a nearly 9-month low against the euro, boosting oil demand. China's economy is reopening after strict Covid-19 curbs, further fueling hopes of higher oil demand. Despite a jump in US crude oil inventories, the market is bracing for an EU ban on Russian oil supply and a potential decrease in interest rates.

images.alt_text: Brent futures rose US$2.57, or 3.2 per cent, to settle at US$82.67 a barrel on Wednesday.
G7, Australia and the European Union  placed a US$60 per barrel limit on sea-borne Russian crude oil sales late last year.

site_title: Brokers’ take: RHB lowers ComfortDelGro target on reduced earnings estimates
summary: RHB has lowered ComfortDelGro's target price to S$1.65 from S$1.80 due to reduced earnings estimates for FY2022-FY2024, primarily due to weakness in its overseas public transport operations. The analyst still recommends a "buy" rating, citing the land transport operator's undemanding valuation, strong free cash flow generation capability, and potentially higher dividend payout. The lower price target is attributed to a downward revision in ComfortDelGro's taxi earnings estimates for FY2023, following the extension of its 15% daily rental waiver for taxi drivers in Singapore until March 31, 2023.

images.alt_text: ComfortDelGro is making a US$4m investment in an Israeli company that develops teleoperation software for autonomous vehicles.
ComfortDelGro makes US$4m investment in Israeli software company.
As part of the tie-up, the companies have agreed to provide Gojek users access to ComfortDelGro taxis via the Gojek app to help with the driver shortage.
Cost and inflationary pressures will continue narrowing ComfortDelGro's margins in the second half of the financial year, says CGS-CIMB analyst Ong Khang Chuen.
ComfortDelGro posted a PATMI of S$34.3 million, up 32.9 per cent from S$25.8 million in the year-ago period

site_title: Lisa Marie Presley, daughter of Elvis, dies at 54
summary: Lisa Marie Presley, the 54-year-old daughter of Elvis Presley, died after suffering cardiac arrest at her California home. She was rushed to a hospital's intensive care unit and later passed away. Presley had been seen at the Golden Globes ceremony just days prior to her death. Her mother, Priscilla Presley, expressed her shock and devastation in a statement, asking for privacy during this difficult time. The cause of death has not been confirmed, but sources suggest it was not a suicide attempt.

images.alt_text: US director Steven Spielberg (centre) poses with the awards for Best Director - Motion Picture and Best Picture - Drama for "The Fabelmans" alongside Seth Rogen (2nd left), Michelle Williams (3rd right) and US actor Paul Dano (right) at the 80th annual Golden Globe Awards in Beverly Hills, California, on Jan 10, 2023.

Malaysian actress Michelle Yeoh poses with the award for Best Actress - Motion Picture - Musical/Comedy for "Everything Everywhere All at Once" in the press room during the 80th annual Golden Globe Awards at The Beverly Hilton hotel in Beverly Hills, California, on January 10, 2023.

site_title: A soft landing won’t mean the economy is safe
summary: A soft landing, where inflation falls to 2% without harming the labor market or economic growth, may be a reality in the US. However, this outcome won't necessarily mean the economy is safe. A soft landing will likely drag out the inflation cycle, pushing households further into debt and increasing the risk of higher interest rates for longer. This scenario could also destabilize the financial system and negatively impact small businesses and emerging markets. A drawn-out soft landing may ultimately require the Federal Reserve to choose between inflicting damage to get inflation under control or learning to live with higher inflation.

images.alt_text: The economic outlook has improved somewhat in recent months, and a soft landing has become much more plausible.
In an earlier session, Dr He Dong, deputy director for monetary and capital markets at the International Monetary Fund (IMF), described 2023 to be a challenging year for monetary policy.

site_title: Hong Kong sees record mortgage applications from Chinese buyers
summary: Hong Kong saw a record high in mortgage applications from Chinese buyers in the fourth quarter of 2022, with 11.4% of applications coming from mainland Chinese residents. This surge is attributed to the country's stringent Covid lockdowns and economic concerns. The Hong Kong government's talent visa programme and tax incentives have also lured mainland buyers, with 60% of 3,800 applications approved. Resale home values declined 16% last year, but buyers from mainland China are expected to be a key pillar for the market, driven by their income and preference for middle to high-end properties.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong Airlines plans to hire 1,000 new employees by the end of 2023 – 120 pilots, 500 cabin crew and 380 ground staff.

site_title: US consumer prices fall in Dec; weekly jobless claims edge down
summary: US consumer prices unexpectedly fell 0.1% in December, the first decline in over two-and-a-half years, driven by declining petrol and other goods prices. Excluding food and energy, the core CPI rose 0.3%, while inflation remains above the Federal Reserve's 2% target. The labor market remains tight, with the unemployment rate at a five-decade low of 3.5%. Despite this, the Federal Reserve is expected to continue raising interest rates to combat inflation.

images.alt_text: In October, the IMF cut its outlook for global economic growth in 2023.

site_title: US inflation hits slowest pace in over a year amid hopes of less hawkish Federal Reserve
summary: US inflation has slowed to its lowest level in over a year, with a 6th consecutive month of easing price increases. This comes as the Federal Reserve's aggressive rate hikes show signs of success, fueling hopes for reprieve from steeply rising interest rates.

images.alt_text: Excluding the volatile food and energy components, the CPI climbed 0.3 per cent last month after rising 0.2 per cent in November.
In the United States, a divided Congress and a weak Speaker of the House of Representatives will be less likely to be able to pass budgets and cut spending as needed.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.6 per cent higher at 34,189.97 on Thursday.

site_title: UOB prices S$850m in 5.25% perpetual capital securities, first callable in 2028
summary: UOB priced S$850m in 5.25% perpetual capital securities, the first callable in 2028. The deal, backed by strong anchor demand, is the first benchmark transaction in the SGD bond market this year. The capital securities are expected to be rated Baa1 by Moody's and BBB+ by Fitch, and will qualify as Additional Tier 1 regulatory capital. The bank expects the securities to be redeemed at a rate equal to the five-year Singapore Overnight Rate Average plus the initial spread. This deal marks a significant transaction in the SGD bank capital market, with an order book of over S$2.1 billion.

images.alt_text: UOB Kay Hian says Yangzijiang Shipbuilding may announce a higher-than-expected dividend upon the release of its annual results in end-February this year.
Holders will have a right to receive distributions semi-annually at a fixed rate of 4.25 per cent per annum, from the issue date to the first reset date on Oct 4, 2027.

site_title: Airbus tests next level of automation with new cockpit assistant
summary: Airbus is testing the DragonFly system, a cockpit automation technology that provides advanced assistance for emergency situations, including automated landings in difficult weather conditions. The system, currently being tested on an A350, uses cameras, sensors, and computer vision algorithms to communicate with air traffic control and the airline's operations team. The goal is to eventually enable the technology to land an aircraft at any airport worldwide, addressing concerns about the responsibility of having just one pilot in the cockpit. A three-month trial will validate the technology before integrating it into future aircraft generations.

images.alt_text: In terms of deliveries, Airbus finished the year having 661 planes arrive with clients, much higher than Boeing’s 480.

site_title: Noma and the fizzle of too-fine dining
summary: Renowned Copenhagen restaurant Noma is closing for regular service, marking a shift in the fine dining industry. The decision, made by chef René Redzepi, comes as the restaurant faces scrutiny over worker treatment and financial sustainability. Redzepi plans to transform Noma into a food laboratory, offering occasional pop-up meals. Critics argue that elite restaurants have lost sight of their true mission, prioritizing innovation and luxury over fundamental dining experiences. The move raises questions about the role of fine dining in the culinary world and the pursuit of "joy" and "satiation" over elaborate presentations and high prices.

images.alt_text: Copenhagen restaurant Noma, one of the world's top eateries with three Michelin stars, will close in 2025 to reinvent itself as a food laboratory.
Rene Redzepi has been commuting between Copenhagen and Kyoto to prepare for the pop-up.

site_title: Putin signals impatience over Ukraine war in commander switch
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin has replaced his top commander in Ukraine, Valery Gerasimov, in a move seen as a sign of military disarray and growing impatience with the war's outcome. The change comes amid increasing Ukrainian resistance and Russia's failure to achieve key objectives, including controlling the annexed regions of Lugansk and Donetsk. Analysts predict intensified military action, possibly including a fresh offensive, and a new mobilization drive, as Putin seeks to regain momentum in the conflict.

images.alt_text: The announcement comes following a request for a ceasefire during Orthodox Christmas from Russia’s 76-year-old Orthodox leader Patriarch Kirill.
Russia’s budget is increasingly squeezed as President Vladimir Putin’s invasion heads for its second year and the economy contracts under sweeping US and European sanctions.

site_title: Higher rates and falling prices hammer Kiwi homeowners
summary: New Zealand's housing market has experienced a sharp correction, with house prices falling 13% since their November 2021 peak. Rising interest rates, which are expected to reach 6.5% by the end of the year, are causing a double whammy of tumbling house prices and rising mortgage costs. About half of home loans are due to refinance this year, with homeowners facing significant increases in their mortgage payments. Economists predict the economy will enter recession this year due to the housing slowdown and rising interest rates.

images.alt_text: Property prices have tumbled as the RBNZ raises interest rates to combat soaring inflation.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Dow Jones open higher after December inflation data
summary: US stocks opened higher on Thursday, January 12, after inflation data showed signs of cooling, boosting bets on the Federal Reserve slowing interest rate hikes. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 74.85 points, or 0.22%, to 34,047.86, while the S&P 500 opened higher by 7.96 points, or 0.20%, at 3,977.57.

site_title: Crypto firms are cutting more than 1,600 jobs already this year
summary: Crypto companies are cutting over 1,600 jobs in the first two weeks of 2023, with Coinbase, Blockchain.com, Genesis, and Huobi among those embarking on layoffs. The industry, which downsized significantly in 2021, is suffering from a bear market and major meltdowns, with US recession fears contributing to job cuts across industries. Major crypto firms are also resolving debt woes, leading to further upheavals, as Coinbase CEO Brian Armstrong acknowledges the industry may see further contagion.

images.alt_text: The cryptocurrency market floundered in 2022, as risk appetite diminished and various crypto firms collapsed.
Nikhil Wahi and his brother, former Coinbase employee Ishan Wahi, were both arrested in July.

site_title: Lian Beng H1 earnings up 48% to S$22m on higher construction revenue
summary: Lian Beng Group reported a 48% increase in earnings to S$22 million for the first half of 2023, driven by a 14.1% rise in construction revenue to S$354 million. Total group revenue rose 11.6% to S$421 million. The construction order book stood at S$1.7 billion, providing a steady flow of activity through FY2027. The board recommended an interim dividend of S$0.01 per share.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
BCA expects 60 per cent of construction demand to come from the public sector.
The Lamborghini service centre on the eighth floor of Leng Kee Autopoint.

site_title: JPMorgan hires from rivals to boost corporate banking in Europe
summary: JPMorgan Chase has hired executives from Bank of America and Deutsche Bank to expand its corporate banking services for mid-sized companies in Europe. Stephanie Soybel joins as head of Nordics payments sales, Saskia Weller as debt finance lead for Germany, Austria, and Switzerland, and Alex McCracken as head of innovation economy for the UK, Ireland, and Nordics. The hires aim to increase JPMorgan's business with smaller corporate clients abroad, targeting firms in tech, life sciences, and renewable energy. The firm plans to expand its team by 23 people in 2023.

images.alt_text: JPMorgan alleges that Frank founder Charlie Javice and another executive, Olivier Amar, used fake customer accounts to mislead the bank into completing the deal.

site_title: Europe: Shares hover at 9-month highs as retailers jump, US inflation moderates
summary: European shares rose 0.6% to a 9-month high, driven by the European retail sector's 1.9% gain. The sector benefited from shoppers spending freely over the Christmas holiday season. US inflation data showed signs of moderating, easing concerns about the Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes. Despite retailer warnings of belt-tightening in 2023, the Stoxx 600 reached its highest level since late April.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.6 per cent higher at 34,189.97 on Thursday.

site_title: US: Stocks end higher on latest sign of cooling inflation
summary: US stocks rose 0.6% on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average reaching 34,189.97, as inflation data showed a moderation in prices, the smallest increase since October 2021. The Federal Reserve is expected to pivot from aggressive interest rate hikes, with analysts predicting a quarter-point rate increase in February. Individual companies such as American Airlines and Disney surged, while KB Home fell due to disappointing quarterly results. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also gained 0.3% and 0.6% respectively, ahead of a deluge of bank earnings reports.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 74.85 points, or 0.22 per cent, at the open to 34,047.86.

site_title: German employers, with 2m jobs to fill, call for labour reforms
summary: Germany's labour shortage worsens with 2 million unfilled jobs, resulting in a loss of 100 billion euros in potential value creation. The German Chamber of Commerce and Industry calls for labour reforms, including easier recruitment of foreign workers, reduced bureaucracy, and better work-life balance. The situation has been exacerbated by the Covid-19 pandemic and an ageing population. Employers are struggling to find skilled labour, particularly in the machine tools and automobile industries, with 22,000 companies interviewed reporting difficulties in securing workers.

images.alt_text: German Chancellor Olaf Scholz’s Social Democrats (SPD) want to see a reform of the EU’s existing state-aid rules and more funds to match the US green-aid push.
Europe’s real estate firms are grappling with a plunge in valuations and dealmaking, after the European Central Bank and other monetary policymakers rapidly increased interest rates in 2022
ECB president Christine Lagarde notes that eurozone wages are growing quicker than earlier thought, and the central bank must prevent this from adding to already-high inflation.

site_title: US west coast girds for more damaging storms
summary: The US West Coast, particularly California, is bracing for more damaging storms as atmospheric rivers are expected to dump heavy rain across the already soaked region. A cyclone in the Pacific Ocean will spread the rain further north, forming a band from northern California to Washington state. Forecasters warn of up to 15cm of rain near Seattle, with avalanche warnings in effect for Washington state. The storms have killed 19 people in California, with flooding, power outages, and mudslides reported. Scientists attribute the intensified storms to climate change, which is making wild weather more ferocious, but warn that even heavy downpours won't reverse decades of below-average rainfall.

images.alt_text: Forecasters have warned that another “atmospheric river” of dense, moist tropical air will clobber California on Monday with rain and mountain snow.
Scientists have warned that climbing temperatures have wrought major changes to ocean stability faster than previously thought

site_title: DCG crypto broker Genesis owes creditors over US$3b
summary: Digital Currency Group (DCG) parent company is considering selling US$500 million worth of venture-capital holdings to raise funds after its cryptocurrency broker Genesis owes creditors over US$3 billion. Genesis cut 30% of its workforce and is exploring asset sales amid industry-wide turmoil. The company's CEO, Barry Silbert, is under pressure from co-founder Cameron Winklevoss, who called for his removal. DCG is also the parent of prominent crypto firms, including asset manager Grayscale.

images.alt_text: DCG has been dealing with changes and challenges in some of its biggest subsidiaries since the sudden collapse of FTX.
Gemini has a crypto lending product called Earn in partnership with DCG’s crypto firm Genesis.

site_title: Brics may decide on admitting new members this year
summary: The BRICS group, consisting of Brazil, Russia, India, China, and South Africa, is formulating criteria for new member countries and may decide to admit new members by the end of this year. South Africa's foreign minister, Naledi Pandor, stated that the world is changing and countries are seeking like-minded partners, with many countries expressing interest in joining the bloc. Expansion could increase BRICS' influence as a counterweight to developed economies, but admitting weaker economies could erode its clout. The group's voting rights in the World Bank and IMF are currently under 15%, despite accounting for 42% of the world's population.

site_title: HBO Max introduces first price increase to stem streaming losses
summary: HBO Max introduces its first price increase since its launch in 2020, raising the cost of its ad-free service to $15.99 per month from $14.99, a 6.7% increase. The move aims to allow the streaming service to invest in more content and improve customer experience. The price increase follows a shift in the streaming industry from a "grow-at-all-costs" era to a focus on finding a path to profitability. Warner Bros Discovery's CFO, Gunnar Wiedenfels, stated that streaming services are priced too low and that the era of "land grabbing" is behind them.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Toy figures of people are seen in front of the displayed HBO Max logo, in this illustration taken January 20, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Japan current account surplus jumps to November record
summary: Japan's current account surplus surged to a record 1.8 trillion yen ($18.3 billion) in November 2022, marking the first year-on-year growth since March last year. The surplus was driven by a weak yen, which boosted income gains from portfolio and direct investments. The primary income surplus also reached a record 3.7 trillion yen, while the trade deficit narrowed to 1.5 trillion yen, its largest on record for the month. The data indicates a positive outlook for Japan's export might and a strengthening economy.

images.alt_text: The BOJ has raised its economic assessment for four of Japan’s nine regions, and maintained its assessment for the remaining five.
Prices in Tokyo have exceeded the Bank of Japan’s 2 per cent price target for seven months.
The survey on households is among data closely watched by the BOJ to determine the outlook for inflation, and how underlying price moves are affecting inflation expectations.

site_title: Swiss Six exchange opens probe into Clariant whistleblower case
summary: Switzerland's Six stock exchange has opened an investigation into Clariant over possible disclosure of price-sensitive information, following whistleblower allegations that staff manipulated accounts in 2020 and 2021. The investigation relates to a delay in publishing 2021 results, which was due to an independent investigation into accounting practices. In April, an investigation found no impact on sales and cash numbers, but restated financial statements showed a higher Ebitda margin. Clariant has denied any wrongdoing and awaits the outcome of the Six investigation.

site_title: Airlines expect US ops to rebound as probe opens on system outage
summary: US airlines expected normal operations to resume on Thursday, a day after a nationwide system outage grounded flights. 511 flights were delayed and 63 cancelled early on Thursday, with 11,300 flights delayed or cancelled the previous day.
