The FAA attributed the outage to a damaged database file, but no cyberattack was found. The agency is investigating and has called for a review of its modernization efforts, which will be expensive and paid through taxes on air travel.

images.alt_text: In the aftermath of a meltdown that led to 16,700 flight cancellations, blame has fallen on an outmoded crew scheduling system and an unusual point-to-point route network.
The eVTOL aircraft have been touted as air taxis that could be the future of urban air mobility.

(FILES) In this file photo taken on December 15, 2009, Boeing's new 787 Dreamliner taxis for take off at Paine Field in Everett, Washington. - Boeing reported a hefty fourth-quarter loss on January 26, 2022, on mounting costs associated with the widebody 787, of which it has suspended deliveries due to quality problems. The US aviation giant accounted for a total of $3.8 billion in one-time expenses associated with compensating airlines for delayed deliveries and more costly production processes. (Photo by Paul Joseph Brown / AFP)

site_title: Yen jumps, US dollar steady ahead of US inflation data
summary: The yen rose 1.3% to a session high of 130.80 against the US dollar ahead of the Bank of Japan's policy meeting, where it is expected to review the effects of its monetary easing. The US dollar remained steady near its seven-month low against the euro, awaiting US inflation data later in the day. Economists expect moderate inflation in the US, which could support the dollar, while the euro is expected to strengthen due to hawkish ECB messaging.

site_title: Bank of England completes sale of ‘mini-budget’ emergency bond buys
summary: The Bank of England has completed the sale of £19.3 billion of government bonds purchased to stabilize financial markets following former UK Prime Minister Liz Truss' "mini-budget" in September 2022. The central bank had bought the bonds to counter record price falls in long-dated and inflation-linked gilts. The sale, which began in November, has reduced the Bank's main QE stockpile and led to a return in gilt yields to pre-"mini-budget" levels, with 30-year gilt yields at 3.7%. The Bank aims to reduce its QE holdings by £80 billion over the next year.

images.alt_text: City of London economists have warned that the tight jobs market will keep the pressure on the BOE to increase interest rates again next month despite some signs of a cooling in employer demand.
Chair Powell and his colleagues are on track to extend the Fed’s most aggressive tightening cycle since the 1980s well into 2023.

Starting salaries for permanent staff and pay rates for temporary workers grew at the slowest rate since April 2021, similar to their average level in the couple of years prior to the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: World enters 'new age' of clean-energy manufacturing: IEA
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) predicts a "new industrial age" of clean-energy technology manufacturing, with the global market expected to triple in value to around $650 billion by 2030. This will create nearly 14 million new jobs, up from six million currently, but poses risks to supply chains due to concentration of resource extraction and manufacturing. Countries must diversify supply chains to avoid disruptions, according to IEA executive director Fatih Birol, who also emphasizes the importance of international collaboration to facilitate the energy transition.

images.alt_text: Some US$580 billion was arranged in 2022 for renewable energy and other environmentally responsible ventures.
The IEA said one in every eight cars sold globally is now electric.

site_title: JPMorgan accuses Morgan Stanley defector of poaching 32 clients
summary: JPMorgan Chase has accused a former employee, Joseph Michael, of poaching 32 clients with $28 million in assets after he left the bank in December. Michael, a private client adviser, allegedly breached his employment agreement's non-solicitation and confidentiality provisions by actively seeking to induce clients to transfer their accounts to Morgan Stanley. JPMorgan claims Michael's actions caused the bank significant time and money investments, and he has also been accused of suspicious computer activity, accessing client profiles 328 times in the last month.

images.alt_text: The latest hires are part of a push by JPMorgan to do more business with smaller corporate clients abroad.

site_title: Celebrations by the Bay
summary: Mandarin Oriental Singapore offers a range of activities for Chinese New Year, including a cycling tour, reunion dinners, takeaway goodies, and a wellness experience. The hotel's Cherry Garden restaurant features five unique yusheng options, while the online shop offers decadent pineapple tarts and traditional treats. A special Cycle For MOre holiday package includes a guided cycling tour through Marina Bay and Gardens by the Bay.

images.alt_text:
luxemo13 - Prosperity Yu Sheng


Credit: Mandarin Oriental Singapore

site_title: China expects annual production capacity of C919 planes to reach 150 in 5 years
summary: China's state-owned Commercial Aviation Corp of China (Comac) aims to reach an annual production capacity of 150 domestically-produced C919 planes in five years. The company has received over 1,200 orders for the jet, with the first delivery made to China Eastern in December. The maiden commercial flight is expected to take place in spring this year. Comac's deputy general manager, Zhang Yujin, stated that there will be a "qualitative change" in C919 production capacity, indicating an increase in production capacity.

site_title: Permanent rules for Singapore listcos to continue virtual meetings a given, say pundits
summary: Singapore's permanent rules for listed companies to hold virtual meetings are expected to be implemented by July 1, 2023, after the temporary Covid-19 measures expire. The new rules aim to protect shareholder rights and cover best practices for hybrid meetings, allowing shareholders to attend in person and virtually. Market watchers hope the regulations will address issues such as live voting and voting system glitches. Experts, including Professor Mak Yuen Teen and Stefanie Yuen Thio, suggest that hybrid meetings with live Q&A and live voting will be the ideal model, but regulators should avoid being too prescriptive, setting a minimum baseline for physical meetings.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
online, meeting, learning

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Building and Construction Authority (BCA) expects S$27-32 billion in construction demand for 2023, primarily from the public sector. The city-state's plans to import clean energy via the Sun Cable project are unaffected by the company's collapse. Investment sales of Singapore property dropped in Q4 but ended stronger for the full year. PropNex calls for tweaks to the Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD) rule for upgraders, while DBS Group Research sees a boost to regional stocks due to Asean festivities. Six former Keppel O&M staff were issued stern warnings for bribery-related offences.

site_title: KPMG calls for clarity over wealth taxes, policies to spur green investments in Budget 2023 wish list
summary: KPMG has released a Budget 2023 wish list, calling for clarity on Singapore's plans for wealth taxes and green investments. The firm recommends targeted grants for GST-registered businesses to address higher compliance costs. Ajay Kumar Sanganeria, partner and head of tax at KPMG in Singapore, urged the government to address speculation on a new wealth tax or reintroduction of estate duty. KPMG's proposals aim to address concerns over the government's tax policies and promote sustainable investments.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh

EY’s Singapore head of tax Soh Pui Ming said: "While the pandemic is behind us, Singapore continues to face a highly volatile and uncertain global environment. Hence, we should stay focused as a nation and prime ourselves for any potential challenges and upcoming opportunities."

site_title: 3D printing reaches new heights with two-storey home
summary: A 12-tonne 3D printer is creating what is believed to be the first 3D-printed, two-storey home in the United States, in Houston. The printer, steadily humming away, is extruding layers of concrete to build the 4,000 square foot home. This innovative project marks a new height for 3D printing in home building, showcasing the potential for this technology to revolutionize the construction industry.

images.alt_text: 3D printing technology, which allows complex shapes to be built up in layers from particles of plastics or metal, is viewed by Washington as an innovation that will enable US manufacturers to flourish and create jobs.

site_title: Vietnam’s largest refinery to shut for 55 days from Aug 25 for maintenance
summary: Vietnam's largest refinery, Nghi Son, will be shut down for 55 days starting August 25 for major maintenance. The 200,000-barrel-per-day refinery processes 7.96 million tonnes of crude oil this year, supplying over a third of Vietnam's refined fuels. The refinery's unit for residual fluid catalytic cracking had been shut down since late December due to a leak. The closure will cause a 20-25% fall in the refinery's total output, with the unit expected to restart by January 15 at the latest.

site_title: Rolex presents gold in many festive colours
summary: Rolex releases six festive timepieces for Chinese New Year, featuring 18 ct gold alloy in yellow, white, and Everose colors, as well as models studded with diamonds and paired with Oystersteel. The watches include the Oyster Perpetual Datejust 36, 41, and Day-Date 36, each with unique designs and features. Prices range from S$14,040 to S$51,150. The watches are designed to bring auspicious colors and shine to the wearer's collection, marking the start of the Year of the Water Rabbit.

images.alt_text: Oyster Perpetual Datejust 36

site_title: Heartwarming CNY reunions at the Raffles
summary: Raffles Hotel Singapore offers special Chinese New Year (CNY) menus curated by master chef Jereme Leung, featuring dishes like Iberico Pork Char Siew and Braised Abalone. Dine-in set menus are priced from S$188++ per person, while luxurious Lo-Hei (yusheng) selections start from S$98++. Takeaway options include a Decadent set menu (S$1,388+) and auspicious home dining sets. The hotel also offers exclusive gift hampers, luxurious blooms, and traditional CNY goodies.

images.alt_text:
Chef Chong’s Harvest Yusheng is just one of five creative Lo Hei platters you won’t want to miss in your reunion dinner to welcome the Year of the Rabbit. 
credit PARKROYAL COLLECTION Marina Bay

site_title: UAE names oil chief Al Jaber as COP28 climate president
summary: The United Arab Emirates (UAE) has named Sultan Al Jaber, head of the Abu Dhabi National Oil Company, as president of the COP28 climate summit in Dubai later this year. Al Jaber, who also serves as the UAE's special envoy on climate change, aims to promote an "inclusive approach" and foster consensus among participating nations. His appointment has raised concerns due to his role in the oil industry, but he also chairs the UAE's renewable-energy company, Masdar, which produces 20 gigawatts of clean power. The summit will take place from November 30 to December 12.

images.alt_text: Around half of global GDP is moderately or highly dependent on nature, according to the World Economic Forum.
The WTO's 2024 ministerial meeting, to be held in Abu Dhabi, will come at a critical time for a slowing global economy.
The closing session of the COP27 climate conference, on Nov 20, 2022. This year's meeting in Egypt is the 27th in the series, and like last year's in Glasgow, is a monster compared to its forebears.

Youth activists hold signs during a demonstration urging world leaders to maintain policies that limit warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius since pre-industrial times and provide reparations for loss and damage, at COP27, in Sharm el-Sheikh, Egypt, Nov 19, 2022.

Climate activists demonstrate calling upon the G20 conference to adhere to limit global temperature rise to 1.5 degrees Celsius compared to pre-industrial levels, at the Sharm el-Sheikh International Convention Centre, in Egypt's Red Sea resort city of the same name, during the COP27 climate conference, on November 16, 2022. (Photo by Fayez Nureldine / AFP)

Activists holding a demonstration to implore countries to phase out all fossil fuels at the COP27 climate summit in the Red Sea resort of Sharm el-Sheikh, Egypt, on Friday (Nov 18).  Egypt is keeping a tight lid on demonstrations by requiring permits.

The aftermath of heavy monsoon rains in Pakistan's Balochistan province, August 2022. As climate disasters such as Pakistan’s catastrophic flooding wreak havoc, we believe developing nations are right to demand reparations and climate justice.

site_title: Alibaba sells Paytm stake worth US$125m via block deal, says source
summary: Alibaba sold a 3.1% stake in Indian digital payments firm Paytm for $125 million through a block deal. The stake was sold at 536.95 rupees per share, and shares of Paytm fell 8.8% in afternoon trading. Alibaba previously held a 6.26% stake in Paytm, which has risen 9% this year after reporting strong preliminary figures for its third quarter. The sale comes after Paytm listed in 2021 with a $2.5 billion initial public offering (IPO).

images.alt_text: Alibaba is targeting Turkey for expansion because of its strong production capacity that could back e-commerce and become part of the company’s supply chain in Europe and the Middle East.
This comes as Ant adjusts its voting rights structure.
Nexus is betting that India – where Internet and mobile phone usage is rising rapidly – will remain a long-term, attractive bet for investors of its new fund.
The announcement comes after Reuters reported in November that SoftBank Group sold a 4.5 per cent stake.
Paytm is among a number of Indian startups that went public last year amid a boom in IPOs and zest for the country’s tech sector that have since suffered a slump in market value.
Paytm reiterated that it expects to reach operating profitability by the quarter ending September 2023 amid continued revenue growth.

site_title: Singapore property investment sales drop in Q4, but end stronger for full year
summary: Singapore's property investment sales declined in Q4 2022, with Knight Frank reporting S$4.5 billion in real estate investment deals, a 22% drop from the previous quarter. However, full-year investment sales reached S$31.9 billion, a 20.4% increase from 2021. The slowdown was attributed to investors' caution amid interest rate hikes and worsening global macroeconomic conditions. Despite this, the office sector saw a 53.6% increase in full-year sales, driven by strong demand for strata office space, while hotel and retail sector sales rose significantly in anticipation of a tourism recovery.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei
Westgate Tower near Jurong East MRT Station
JLL anticipates Japan to be the most attractive destination when it comes to investment, followed by Singapore and Australia.
Colliers is especially positive on office assets given rising rents and tight supply. It also expects keen interest in prime retail assets as tourism recovers.

site_title: UK jobs boom cools as vacancies slip below pre-Covid level
summary: The UK's jobs market is cooling, with online job advertisements slipping below pre-Covid levels for the first time in almost two years. The Office for National Statistics reported a 16% drop in total job ads in January, with vacancies at their lowest since April 2021. This slowdown is attributed to a sharp decrease in manufacturing hiring. City of London economists warn that the tight jobs market will continue to pressure the Bank of England to raise interest rates again next month, despite signs of a cooling in employer demand.

images.alt_text: Houses at a Taylor Wimpey Plc residential housing construction site in Hoo, UK, on Monday, Jan. 9, 20233. Taylor Wimpey is due to give a trading update on Friday. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

A sign regarding strike action outside Shortlands railway station, closed due to strike action by the National Union of Rail, Maritime and Transport, near Sevenoaks, UK, on Friday, Jan. 6, 2023. Britain is mired in industrial action with workers ranging from train drivers to nurses and border-control officials protesting against below-inflation pay offers. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

site_title: Telling time in the Year of the Rabbit
summary: Several watch brands, including IWC, TAG Heuer, Blancpain, Piaget, Vacheron Constantin, and Breguet, have released limited-edition timepieces to celebrate the Chinese New Year, marking the Year of the Rabbit. These designs incorporate traditional Chinese motifs, such as the rabbit, red, and gold, into their watch cases and dials. The timepieces showcase various features, including enamel work, intricate details, and high-end materials, and are priced between $9,800 and $203,000. The watches are available in limited quantities, with some pieces being sold for high prices, reflecting their exclusivity and craftsmanship.

images.alt_text: DEFY Skyline Skeleton.

site_title: Singapore shares slip ahead of US inflation report; STI down 0.1%
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) in Singapore dropped 0.1% to 3,267.78 ahead of the US inflation report, with Singapore banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC experiencing declines. The wider market saw 1.13 billion securities traded worth S$1.04 billion, with gainers outnumbering losers 285 to 235. Asian markets finished higher, with the top performer being Sats, which rose 2.5%. The STI has now had a 5-day rally ahead of upcoming GDP data.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
SINGAPORE stocks rose in early trade on Thursday (Jan 13), following a strong showing in the US and Europe markets.

site_title: Patek Philippe shines in red and gold
summary: Patek Philippe releases three luxury watches for Chinese New Year, featuring red and gold designs. The watches, including the Ref 4947R-001 Annual Calendar, showcase the brand's festive spirit. Gold is a traditional favorite for Chinese New Year celebrations, while red symbolizes good fortune. These timepieces are available in precious metals and rich red hues, marking the start of the Year of the Rabbit with joy and good fortune.

images.alt_text: Tudor Black Bay Fifty-Eight 18K.

site_title: Out with the old, time for the new at Zenith
summary: Zenith unveiled the DEFY Skyline Skeleton, a new open-worked high-frequency chronograph, at LVMH Watch Week in Singapore. The watch features the El Primero 3600 movement, measuring tenths of a second, and is available in 41mm stainless steel or 36mm mid-size versions. The DEFY Skyline Skeleton is priced at CHF10,900 (S$15,914) for the 41mm model and CHF8,400 (S$12,264) for the 36mm model. The watch is part of Zenith's DEFY Skyline collection, which also includes the DEFY Extreme Glacier and DEFY Skyline Pink.

images.alt_text: Tudor Black Bay Fifty-Eight 18K.

site_title: Porsche mulls complete integration of Google infotainment
summary: Porsche is in talks with Google to integrate Google Apps into its infotainment system, potentially replacing existing systems. The luxury car brand, owned by the Volkswagen group, is considering taking its own course and completely integrating Google into its cockpits. No official deal has been announced, but the integration would allow Porsche owners to access Google's suite of apps and services, including Google Maps and Google Assistant. The move could enhance the driving experience and provide users with a more seamless integration of technology.

images.alt_text: Google maps and applications built into a Volvo are demonstrated at Alphabet’s Google Android plaza booth during the Consumer Electronics Show (CES) in Las Vegas, Nevada on January 5, 2023. (Photo by Patrick T. Fallon / AFP)

site_title: Exploring underrated Oman, the next big travel destination
summary: Oman, a Middle Eastern sultanate, is gaining popularity as a travel destination, with its surreal beauty and mystique drawing visitors. The country's golden deserts under blue skies, oases in arid mountain ranges, and forgotten mud villages on hillsides are just a few of its attractions. The Bedouin, who have made the desert their home, offer a glimpse into traditional Omani culture. From hiking in the rugged beauty of Wadi Bani Awf to exploring the bustling markets of Nizwa and Jabal Akhdar, Oman is a hidden gem waiting to be discovered.

images.alt_text: Stefanie Yuen Thio
The beautiful surrounding nature reflected on the surface of Roku Kyoto's water basin.

site_title: China’s resale-home transactions 39% higher in Jan than Dec: private survey
summary: China's resale-home transactions saw a 39% increase in January compared to December, according to a private survey, indicating early signs of recovery in the property sector. The number of home buyers' visits to housing showrooms and home sales also rose 22% in the first half of January. This uptick is attributed to government support measures and Beijing's reopening, which have boosted market expectations. The real estate market is expected to see an upturn in the first quarter of 2023.

images.alt_text: Consumer inflation gained 1.8 per cent compared to a 1.6 per cent increase in November, in line with economist expectations.

China's consumer price index was 1.8 per cent higher than a year earlier, rising faster than the 1.6 per cent annual gain seen in November, data from the National Bureau of Statistics showed on Thursday.

site_title: HSBC wins appeal against 33.6 million euros Euribor cartel fine
summary: HSBC has won an appeal against a 33.6 million euro fine by the European Commission for its role in a 2007 Euribor cartel, but the European Court of Justice upheld the finding that HSBC participated in the cartel. The court dismissed HSBC's challenge, allowing the fine to stand. The fine was initially imposed in 2016, with the European Commission stating that HSBC, along with six other banks, colluded to manipulate Euribor interest rates to increase profit or reduce risk.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A logo of HSBC is seen on its headquarters at the financial Central district in Hong Kong, China August 4, 2020. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu/File Photo

site_title: Indonesia says investment talks with Tesla still ongoing
summary: Indonesia's investment talks with Tesla are ongoing, with senior minister Luhut Pandjaitan stating that discussions include plans for production facilities and supply chain facilitation. The talks come as Tesla is reportedly nearing a preliminary deal to build a one million unit production facility in Indonesia. The country aims to develop its downstream industry for electric vehicles, leveraging its rich nickel reserves. This follows other automakers, such as Hyundai and Toyota, expressing interest in investing in EV production in Indonesia.

images.alt_text: An Indonesian factory would be Tesla’s third outside its home market in the US, joining facilities in Shanghai and a plant near Berlin.
The world’s most valuable automaker has been facing Covid-driven production and logistics snags at its key Shanghai hub, coupled with growing demand concerns.

site_title: Tudor goes gold
summary: Tudor has released limited-edition watches in 18K gold to celebrate Chinese New Year, symbolizing good fortune and prosperity. The Tudor Black Bay Fifty-Eight 18K features the precious metal, blending refined aesthetics with technical performance. These gold watches mark a unique way to welcome the Year of the Rabbit, offering a touch of luxury and good fortune to those who wear them.

site_title: Asia’s reliance on fossil fuels is its ‘Achilles heel’, says top climate leader
summary: Asia's reliance on fossil fuels poses a significant risk to the region's climate and competitiveness, according to Christiana Figueres, former UNFCCC executive secretary. The private sector, particularly manufacturing and financial industries, should wake up to the climate crisis as both a risk and an opportunity for growth. Despite climate commitments, Asia still heavily relies on fossil fuels, making it vulnerable to price volatility and exposing the region to high risks. Decarbonizing energy is key to sustaining Asia's competitiveness.

images.alt_text: Sharon See

site_title: Tesla China factory’s expansion plans in doubt amid data concerns
summary: Tesla's Shanghai factory expansion plans are in doubt due to concerns over data security and social stability. The phase three expansion, which would double the factory's capacity to two million cars a year, has been delayed amid growing public resentment towards the company in China. Tesla has been expanding in China despite consumer demand taking a hit from slowing economic growth and COVID-19 lockdowns. The delay coincides with tensions between the US and China, with some central government officials expressing concern about a US company with ties to Elon Musk's Starlink initiative having a large presence in the country.

images.alt_text: The waiting time for orders of the rear-wheel-drive and long-range versions of Model Y were a week longer on Monday than on Friday.

site_title: SPAC-squared is Wall Street’s latest wheeze
summary: Wejo Group Ltd, a British connected-vehicle data company, is merging with TKB Critical Technologies I, a blank-cheque firm, to secure up to $100 million in cash. This is the first "Re-SPAC" deal, where a company that has already completed a SPAC merger is merging with another blank-cheque firm. Wejo's financial struggles, including a cash balance of only $15 million and burning $6 million a month, led it to seek funding. The deal offers TKB shareholders $11.25 of value for their initial $10 investment, with the potential to own almost three quarters of the company.

images.alt_text: Chamath Palihapitiya, the founder of Social Capital, at a conference in New York on Oct 26, 2022. Palihapitiya, once a relentless cheerleader of special purpose acquisition companies, blames the Federal Reserve for the end of SPAC mania.

site_title: China’s factory deflation continues as Covid outbreaks spread
summary: China's factory-gate prices fell 0.7% in December, exceeding expectations, while consumer inflation rose 1.8% due to the sudden end of Covid Zero. The producer price index (PPI) declined for the third consecutive month, while consumer prices remained stable. The data suggests the weakest month for economic activity in China since early 2020, with major cities experiencing outbreaks only rebounding in late December. Economists expect a faster rebound once Covid infections peak, with a median estimate of 4.8% GDP growth this year.

images.alt_text: China's consumer price index was 1.8 per cent higher than a year earlier, rising faster than the 1.6 per cent annual gain seen in November, data from the National Bureau of Statistics showed on Thursday.

site_title: UK homebuilder offers mortgage holidays to lure reluctant buyers
summary: UK homebuilder Persimmon is offering a "10 months mortgage free" customer offer to boost demand for its homes amid high borrowing costs and a threat of a house price plunge. The offer has generated strong interest in its first week, but it's too early to determine its impact on sales. Over 800,000 households will see their mortgage rates double in 2023, driving predictions of a 10% drop in house prices this year, according to industry predictions.

site_title: Thai consumer confidence at 25-month high in December as tourism recovers
summary: Thai consumer confidence reached a 25-month high in December, rising to 49.7 from 47.9 in November, driven by improved economic activity and higher foreign tourist arrivals, particularly from China. The University of the Thai Chamber of Commerce expects consumer confidence to continue improving as Chinese tourists arrive at a faster-than-expected pace, supporting the economy.

images.alt_text: Tourists and locals browse goods and food at a walking street market in Phuket, Thailand, on Sunday, Oct. 2, 2022. Thailand will end a nationwide state of emergency declared in the wake of Covid outbreak after the Southeast Asian nation downgraded the virus from a “dangerous” communicable disease to one that only requires surveillance. Photographer: Andre Malerba/Bloomberg

site_title: TSMC to cut spending to offset falling near-term sales
summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (TSMC) is reducing spending to offset weaker-than-expected sales, its first revenue drop in four years. The company forecasts slight growth for the full year due to a recovery in demand for server chips, despite a slowdown in the technology industry. TSMC's capital expenditure is expected to decrease to $32-36 billion, and shares have fallen 27% last year. The company is betting on its technology and scale advantages to weather the slump, with plans to increase investment in the US and build new plants in Japan and Europe.

images.alt_text: TSMC’s business has been boosted by a global chip shortage that was sparked by pandemic-fuelled sales of smartphones and laptops.

site_title: Bank of Japan more upbeat on regional Japan, wage prospects
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) has raised its economic assessment for four of Japan's nine regions, maintaining its assessment for the remaining five. The central bank cited a rebound in overseas visitors and growing wage increases as positive developments for the economy, which is on track to achieve its 2% inflation target. Japan's core consumer prices rose 3.7% in November, exceeding the BOJ's target for eight straight months. The BOJ is expected to raise its inflation forecasts next week, signaling its growing conviction that conditions could support dialing back stimulus.

images.alt_text: Markets are rife with speculation the BOJ could move further to phase out governor Haruhiko Kuroda’s massive stimulus by tweaking its yield control policy under a new central bank governor.
The yield on 10-year JGBs rose to 0.500 per cent, its highest since July 2015.

site_title: JPMorgan says it was defrauded in US$175m college site purchase
summary: JPMorgan Chase claims it was defrauded in a US$175 million college financial-planning site purchase by Frank's founder Charlie Javice and executive Olivier Amar. The bank alleges they used fake customer accounts to mislead JPMorgan into buying a business with 4.3 million customers when it actually had fewer than 300,000. Javice is also suing JPMorgan for legal fees, accusing the bank of rushing to buy Frank without proper due diligence and trying to deflect attention from student-privacy law violations.

site_title: Mercedes to drop EQ product brand: report
summary: Mercedes-Benz plans to drop its EQ product brand for battery-electric cars as the company shifts focus to electric-only vehicles. The decision comes after CEO Ola Kaellenius' emphasis on electric-only cars, making the EQ brand redundant. The EQ brand, launched in 2016, currently markets Mercedes' all-electric model series, including the EQC electric SUV. A Mercedes spokesperson stated that the brand is crucial to the carmaker's electromobility strategy, but no further details on the brand's future use have been announced. The change is expected to take effect with the next generation of compact cars in 2024.

site_title: 💸 Feeling unappreciated? Here’s how to ask for more
summary: A newsletter article advises readers to discuss their value to their company, rather than just asking for a raise, to increase their chances of getting what they want. Before approaching their boss, readers should research market rates, make a list of their achievements, and consider alternative options such as a promotion or additional benefits. The article also emphasizes the importance of timing, preparation, and taking feedback on board, even if the initial request is denied. Ultimately, readers are encouraged to consider whether staying with the company is worthwhile if they feel undervalued and underappreciated.

images.alt_text: Vivien Shiao

site_title: Malaysia’s growth may slow to 4% in 2023 on high base, weak exports: Standard Chartered
summary: Malaysia's economic growth may slow to 4% in 2023 due to unfavourable base effects and moderating exports, according to Standard Chartered Global Research. The forecast is in line with Bank Negara's projection of 4-5% growth. Consumer spending is expected to fall due to higher debt servicing costs and changes to government subsidies, while China's reopening will boost tourism and services industries. The firm also expects Bank Negara to raise interest rates twice in January and May to bring the overnight policy rate back to pre-pandemic levels.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's domestic-oriented industries continue to expand, supported by vehicles production activities and processed food products.

site_title: Menswear puts on the dog
summary: Pitti Uomo, a menswear trade fair in Florence, has debuted a pavilion showcasing animal apparel for the first time, featuring 15 stands from indie brands and mid-size labels. The pet apparel market, valued at $5.7 billion in 2021, is driven by increased urbanization, disposable income, and societal shifts giving pets priority over family members. Brands such as Moshiqa, Max Bone, and Wagwear are capitalizing on this trend, offering luxury canine offerings like designer coats and accessories. The market is expected to continue growing, with designers crediting considerate design as key to creating garments for pets.

images.alt_text: Almost 70 catwalk shows and 110 presentations are scheduled over the next 6 days, featuring the giants of Italian fashion, from Gucci to Prada, Versace, Armani, Dolce & Gabbana and Bottega Veneta.

site_title: Samsung India says reviewing govt notice on tax dispute
summary: Samsung India's Indian unit is reviewing a government notice related to a tax dispute, following a media report that the company allegedly evaded import duties worth 17.28 billion rupees by misclassifying networking devices. The Directorate of Revenue Intelligence (DRI) accused Samsung India of skirting import taxes by misclassifying remote radio heads to claim undue exemption of basic customs duty. Samsung India is exploring legal opinion and has not given further details on the dispute. This is a tax dispute involving interpretation of law, and the outcome is yet to be determined.

site_title: BT Future of Finance: Delivering on customer demands (Ep 5)
summary: Citibank Singapore CEO Brendan Carney discusses the future of finance, highlighting the challenges faced by the wealth management space and the need for digital transformation. Key takeaways include the importance of personalization, leveraging technology to reach individual customers, and ensuring growth readiness. Carney emphasizes the need for true digitalization in banking, enabling a seamless customer experience and capitalizing on emerging technologies like blockchain.

images.alt_text: Why do we even need a digital bank? Dwaipayan Sadhu, CEO of Trust Bank tackles that burning question.
“And we all know happy employees mean happy customers!” - Serene Koh, OCBC Bank.
Heng Koon How from UOB discusses blockchain shock waves.
Transforming financial services will be the key to future proofing, according to Shayan Hazir, CDO, HSBC.

site_title: South Korea plans to extend won trading hours starting  2024
summary: South Korea plans to extend won trading hours to allow US dollar-won spot trading until 2 am as early as the second half of 2024. This move aims to improve access for foreign investors and boost the nation's stock market. The current close is 3:30 pm, and changes will also enable foreign financial companies to participate in the onshore market. The goal is to lure foreign investors and increase the country's chances of being included in MSCI's developed-market stock index.

images.alt_text: South Korean 50,000 won banknotes are arranged for a photograph at the KB Financial Group Inc. headquarters in Seoul, South Korea, on Tuesday, July 17, 2012. South Korea's won rose for a fourth day as Federal Reserve Chairman Ben S. Bernanke said policy makers are studying further easing, which would increase the flow of funds seeking higher-yielding assets. Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg

site_title: Philippines central bank hopes to cut rates in 2024, flags RRR reduction
summary: Philippines central bank governor Felipe Medalla hopes to cut benchmark interest rates in 2024 once inflation is under control. He also flags a high probability of lowering the reserve requirement ratio (RRR) for banks in the first half of 2024, which could be a key easing measure. The move comes as the US Federal Reserve has raised interest rates to contain elevated inflation, and the BSP aims to bring inflation back to its target range.

images.alt_text: “Monetary policy is responding to inflation. It is not causing inflation,” Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP) governor Felipe Medalla said.
BSP has raised the key rate by 3.5 percentage points so far in this tightening cycle, starting in May, taking the benchmark rate to 5.5 per cent which is the highest since 2008.

With the BSP set to take further steps to help curb pressure on consumer prices, governor Felipe Medalla expects inflation to be within this year’s 2 per cent-4 per cent target band by the second half.

site_title: India, US establish new trade group to bolster supply chains
summary: India and the US have established a new working group to build sustainable supply chains and boost bilateral trade. The group will focus on trade facilitation, digitization of customs procedures, and sustainable finance. The countries also agreed to increase dialogue on food and agricultural trade issues and consider the restoration of beneficiary status under the US generalised system of preferences programme. The Trade Policy Forum, revived in 2021, will reconvene on a ministerial level before the end of 2023. The goal is to achieve a $500 billion trade relationship between the two countries.

images.alt_text: TOPSHOT - Farmers inspect sunflowers in a field on the outskirts of Bengaluru on January 3, 2023. (Photo by Manjunath KIRAN / AFP)

site_title: BCA projects Singapore construction demand in 2023 to hit S$27-32b, with public sector leading the way
summary: Singapore's Building and Construction Authority (BCA) forecasts construction demand in 2023 to range between S$27 billion and S$32 billion, with 60% of demand coming from the public sector. The public sector is expected to contribute S$16-19 billion, driven by public housing projects and industrial developments. The private sector is anticipated to contribute S$11-13 billion, with residential and industrial building construction demand similar to last year. BCA expects total construction demand to remain steady from 2024 to 2027, with the public sector leading demand.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Yong Jun Yuan
建筑业、预购组屋建筑工地。

site_title: Twitter tells staff in Singapore office to clear desks, work from home
summary: Twitter has instructed staff at its Singapore office to clear desks and work from home due to cost-cutting efforts by new owner Elon Musk. The move, which was made via email, comes after the company's Asia-Pacific headquarters was hit hard by deep job cuts. The staff were given until 5pm on January 11 to leave the premises and resume their duties remotely. The decision is part of Musk's efforts to pare expenses globally, including not paying rent on its San Francisco headquarters.

site_title: Jaguar owner to make EV battery cells in Europe
summary: Tata Group plans to establish electric vehicle (EV) cell-manufacturing operations in Europe, with Jaguar Land Rover and Tata Motors as anchor customers. The facility will produce two cell chemistries and sell battery cells to the wider market, aiming to control critical supply chain parts and mitigate disruptions. The project will require significant investments, with details to be announced soon. The move is part of Tata's efforts to accelerate Jaguar Land Rover's shift to battery-powered cars, following the UK car industry's struggles with the transition to EVs.

images.alt_text: A Range Rover Sport is seen on the production line at Jaguar Land Rover’s factory in Solihull, Britain, December 15, 2022. REUTERS/Phil Noble

site_title: New Zealand sees record-low house sales as buyers stay away
summary: New Zealand saw a record-low 14,966 house sales in the third quarter of last year, the lowest since records began in 1990. Property prices have tumbled 5% in December, the biggest drop since 2008, due to the Reserve Bank of New Zealand's interest rate hikes to combat inflation. Sales slowed as buyers stepped away from the market wary of overpaying, following a 30% gain in 2021. The central bank's policy tightening is expected to continue, leading to further price drops.

site_title: Biden-McConnell : Will two 80-year-old dealmakers control the crazies on Capitol Hill?
summary: US President Joe Biden and Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, both 80 years old, have formed a long-standing friendship and work relationship that spans over 30 years in the Senate. Despite their party affiliation, they have maintained a bipartisan approach, with Biden noting their efforts to control the crazies on Capitol Hill. The two dealmakers have a history of surprising pundits with their upset victories, with Biden winning his first Senate seat in 1972 and McConnell winning his first Senate seat in 1984. Their friendship and collaboration have become a hallmark of their time in office.

images.alt_text: The coming Republican Congress: Will Trumpists set the tone?

site_title: EMA says no setback to plans to import clean energy, following Sun Cable’s abrupt demise
summary: Singapore's Energy Market Authority (EMA) remains on track to meet its target of importing 4 GW of low-carbon electricity by 2035, despite the collapse of Sun Cable, a proposed solar power project from Australia. The EMA has received over 20 proposals to import electricity from countries such as Indonesia, Lao PDR, and Malaysia, with "viable offers" involving projects that can potentially supply more than 4 GW. The EMA is continuing to discuss the proposals with the other request-for-proposal (RFP) participants to support the development of their projects.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

“We are pulling all the pieces (regulatory, commercial and operational) together for a financial close in 2024,” said Sun Cable's co-founder and chief strategy officer Fraser Thompson on its mega solar project, which aims to supply power to Singapore
Rendering of the Sun Cable project. Source: Sun Cable Pty Ltd.

site_title: Bitcoin extends its longest winning streak since pandemic days
summary: Bitcoin has extended its longest winning streak since the pandemic, with a 9-day rally and over 10% gains this month. The second-largest token, Ether, has also surged 17%. The recent rally is attributed to bets on cooling inflation and slower interest-rate hikes by the US Federal Reserve. Analysts expect institutions to return to the market once the market issues clear up, potentially pushing up transactions and prices.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong’s move to allow retail trading in cryptocurrencies has come after months of turmoil in the sector.

site_title: PropNex calls for ABSD rule tweaks for upgraders, more OCR land in Budget 2023
summary: PropNex, a Singaporean real estate agency, has urged the government to align the additional buyer's stamp duty (ABSD) remission treatment for married couples upgrading from HDB flats to private homes with that of those upgrading to new executive condominiums (ECs) from developers. Currently, couples must sell their HDB flats within six months after receiving their temporary occupation permit (TOP) or certificate of statutory completion to qualify for ABSD remission. PropNex suggests introducing a contractual undertaking to ensure timely sale.

images.alt_text: Generic pix of buildings, HDB flats, private houses and condos in southern Singapore July 2, 2022.
Property owners in Singapore may need to brace for higher transaction and recurring taxes in the year ahead.
While new HDB homes are priced to ensure they are affordable, some concerns over housing affordability in Singapore persist, possibly for valid reasons.
Resale volumes rise for the second straight month, advancing 4.8 per cent.

site_title: India to test green bond market with debut US$2b sale
summary: India plans to sell $2 billion in green bonds in two auctions, aiming to raise funds for sustainable projects and lower borrowing costs. The sale comes as the global green bond market has slowed, with a 19% drop in 2022. India's sovereign green bond will be its first, and officials are seeking a significant "green premium" to attract foreign investors. The sale may help meet India's renewable energy goals and boost its infrastructure resilience to climate change.

images.alt_text: The Jan 4-9 poll of 45 economists put consumer price inflation at 5.90 per cent in December from a year earlier, little changed from an eleven-month low of 5.88 per cent in November.

site_title: Logitech cuts sales outlook after Q3 miss
summary: Logitech International reported lower earnings and sales for its third quarter, citing a difficult economic backdrop and supply-chain uncertainties linked to China's Covid-19 outbreak. The company cut its sales outlook, expecting year-to-March sales to fall between 13% and 15% on a constant-currency basis. Preliminary third-quarter GAAP operating income fell around 35% year-over-year, and sales declined 22% to a figure between $1.26 billion and $1.27 billion. The company attributed the weaker-than-expected results to challenging macroeconomic conditions and uncertainty in supply availability.

images.alt_text: The maker of keyboards, mice and headsets posted a 12% decline in sales at US$1.15 billion in the three months that ended Sep 30.
LOGITECH International reported a 20 per cent drop in sales for its fourth quarter on Tuesday (May 3), as the computer mice, webcam and keyboard maker lapped high comparables from a year earlier.

site_title: Apple is working on adding touch screens to Macs in major turnabout
summary: Apple is reportedly working on adding touch screens to its Mac computers, a move that would reverse the company's long-held stance on the technology. The first touch-screen MacBook Pro is expected to retain a traditional laptop design, including a standard trackpad and keyboard, and could launch in 2025 as part of a larger update to the MacBook Pro. This would be a significant turnabout for the company, which has previously argued that touch screens don't work well on laptops and have cannibalized iPad sales.

images.alt_text: The changes are part of a sweeping effort to replace Apple supplies with homegrown parts, an undertaking that will give the company more control over the design and capabilities of its products.
Apple is Broadcom’s largest customer and accounted for about 20 per cent of the chipmaker’s revenue in the last fiscal year, amounting to almost US$7 billion.

site_title: Adobe tried to buy Figma twice before US$20b deal
summary: Adobe's $20 billion acquisition of design firm Figma was finalized after the company's co-founder, Dylan Field, agreed to the deal in early July 2022. Field had previously met with Adobe executives and Microsoft to discuss a potential acquisition, but ultimately chose Adobe due to its superior value. The acquisition, announced in September, is one of the most expensive ever of a closely held software maker and is being reviewed by regulatory bodies for potential antitrust issues.

images.alt_text: Adobe announced in September an agreement to purchase smaller rival Figma for US$20 billion.

site_title: Malaysia urges palm oil producers to boost cooperation after EU rules
summary: Malaysia urges top palm oil producers Indonesia and Malaysia to strengthen cooperation following the EU's new law aimed at reducing palm oil-based fuels due to deforestation concerns. The EU plans to phase out such fuels by 2030, expected to significantly reduce demand for palm oil within the next decade. Malaysian Commodities minister Fadillah Yusof called for coordinated efforts to combat "baseless allegations" made by the EU and US about the sustainability of palm oil, amid a call to "fight discrimination against palm oil".

images.alt_text: During their bilateral meeting, Anwar and Jokowi signed eight memorandums of understandings covering shipping, export-import financing, green energy, the development of battery industry.

site_title: Asia: Markets rise on optimism ahead of US inflation data
summary: Asian markets rose on Thursday as traders grew optimistic ahead of US inflation data, expected to show another softening of inflation. Hong Kong led the gains, rising over 1%, followed by Shanghai, Sydney, and other markets. The rally was fueled by optimism over China's reopening and signs that the Federal Reserve's monetary tightening campaign is finally paying off. This optimism lifted Wall Street's three main indexes, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq soaring over 1% each.

images.alt_text: In early trade, Hong Kong again led the gains by piling on more than one per cent, having already added about eight per cent in 2023.

site_title: China stops reporting Covid tally as data criticism intensifies
summary: China has stopped reporting its daily Covid tally, with fewer than 40 deaths reported since the major pivot away from Covid Zero in early December. The last daily update was on January 9, and health officials announced a switch to monthly reports without specifying a date. The move has raised global concerns about the true impact of the outbreak, as calls to Chinese health officials went unanswered. This shift in reporting is part of China's downgrade of virus management, which has sparked criticism and data vacuum concerns.

images.alt_text: Patients in a hallway at a hospital in Shanghai, China, on Jan 7, 2023.
The WHO is working with China on how to mitigate the risks of travel ahead of the Lunar New Year public holiday.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SingPost, EuroSports
summary: SingPost plans to acquire a 37% stake in Freight Management Holdings for A$175.4 million, increasing its stake to 88% and strengthening its logistics presence overseas. EuroSports Global's electric vehicle brand Scorpio Electric raised US$6.8 million to develop prototypes of its first electric motorcycle, with mass production and deliveries scheduled for the second half of 2023.

site_title: Six former Keppel O&M staff issued stern warnings for bribery-related offences
summary: Six former senior management staff of Keppel Corporation's Offshore & Marine unit have been issued stern warnings by the Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau for bribery-related offences. The individuals were not named, but the warnings were issued for bribe payments to Petrobras officials related to rigs building contracts. The offences were punishable under the Prevention of Corruption Act. The individuals were given warnings instead of prosecution, indicating that the authorities deemed the cases not severe enough to warrant prosecution.

images.alt_text: The latest development is not expected to have a material impact on its net tangible assets nor earnings per share on Keppel Corporation for the current financial year.

site_title: Singapore’s framework for companies to ‘do good’ shifts from corporate giving to corporate purpose
summary: Singapore's National Volunteer & Philanthropy Centre has updated its framework for companies to 'do good' to focus on corporate purpose, shifting from corporate giving. The new framework, "Corporate Purpose: A Framework and Blueprint for Businesses in Singapore," evaluates companies in five impact areas: people, environment, society, economic, and governance. The evaluation assesses a company's corporate purpose, plans, and efforts in these areas. The update aims to recognize businesses that integrate corporate purpose as part of their operations, with the goal of making Singapore the "City of Good."

images.alt_text: Reach Community Services Society social worker Nina Catrina says the session allows participants to gather feedback from their peers.

site_title: Uniqlo parent Fast Retailing says profit slid 2% in first quarter
summary: Fast Retailing, owner of Uniqlo, reported a 2% decline in first-quarter profit to 117.1 billion yen (S$1.2 billion), following a record figure in the previous year. This falls short of the consensus forecast of 135.3 billion yen. The company had previously announced plans for big wage rises.

images.alt_text: Companies in Japan facing the fastest pace of inflation in decades, forcing them to consider wage hikes to retain and motivate employees.

site_title: DBS sees boost to regional stocks on Asean festivities without restrictions
summary: DBS Group Research predicts a boost to regional stocks due to the relaxation of COVID-19 restrictions in many countries during the festive season. Analysts expect "revenge spending" and a rebound in consumer staple and discretionary stocks, particularly in Asean markets. This comes as consumer staples have generally fared well despite rising prices and rates in 2022, and discretionary stocks benefit from the global reopening. The forecast is optimistic despite an environment of rising prices and rates.

images.alt_text: One of Asia’s most popular travel destinations, Thailand is enjoying an influx of tourists during its first peak season since the removal last year of tight entry restrictions.
Malaysia's tourism-related stocks have gained buying interest as analysts expect the Chinese tourists will catalyse the country's economy.

site_title: Scientists sound alarm as ocean temperatures hit new record
summary: Scientists have warned that ocean temperatures reached a new record in 2022, with heat content exceeding previous years by 10 Zetta joules. The oceans, which absorb 90% of excess heat from greenhouse gas emissions, are experiencing major changes to stability, leading to devastating effects on underwater life. The study, published in Advances in Atmospheric Sciences, also found increasing water temperatures and salinity contributing to ocean stratification, which affects heat, oxygen, and carbon exchange between the ocean and atmosphere.

images.alt_text: The Pantheon, dating to the 2nd century AD, is a circular concrete building faced with brick, boasting the world’s largest and oldest unreinforced concrete dome.

site_title: China solar firm plans US plant in win for Biden energy push
summary: A Chinese solar panel maker, JA Solar Technology, has leased space for its first US factory in Phoenix, Arizona, with plans to be operational by the fourth quarter of this year. The $60 million plant will produce 2 gigawatts of panels annually, providing US customers with flexibility and ease of access to its solar products. This move is seen as a win for President Joe Biden's efforts to build up the nation's clean energy manufacturing base, following a series of new factory announcements, including a $2.5 billion expansion in Georgia.

images.alt_text: solar

site_title: Asia’s banks see widening gap between ESG leaders and laggards
summary: Asia's major banks are seeing a widening gap between ESG leaders and laggards, according to a WWF report. While leading banks in Singapore, Japan, and South Korea set net-zero targets, many in Vietnam and the Philippines lagged, with over half making little to no progress on environmental and social risk policies. 39% of banks committed to net-zero financed emissions by 2050, up from 15% in 2021, and regulators are needed to ensure no "loopholes" to prevent unsustainable activities.

site_title: Mapletree Investments, PAG to acquire Goldin Financial Global Centre for HK$5.6b
summary: Mapletree Investments and PAG have formed a 50:50 joint venture to acquire Goldin Financial Global Centre in Hong Kong for HK$5.6 billion (S$953.7 million). The 886,703 sq ft building is located in the CBD2 commercial and business district of Kowloon East. The joint acquisition is seen as a "great opportunity" to boost Mapletree's presence in Hong Kong's commercial sector at an attractive price.

images.alt_text: Mapletree to pick banks for US$1b Singapore Reit IPO, sources say
Mapletree Investments raises US$552m for maiden US office fund
Mapletree Logistics Trust to acquire Baeksa Logistics Centre in South Korea for 88.5b won
The Learning Lab tuition centre in United Square. A pair of siblings who study there have tested positive for Covid-19. All classrooms at its eight outlets will be deep-cleaned over the weekend.

site_title: ExxonMobil to sell Thai refinery, retail unit to Bangchak
summary: ExxonMobil will sell its 66% stake in Esso (Thailand), a refinery and retailing business, to Bangchak for an undisclosed price. Bangchak will gain control of Sriracha Refinery, distribution terminals, and Esso-branded retail stations. Exxon will continue to supply finished lubricants and chemical products through a new company. The deal is expected to be completed in 12 months, subject to regulatory approvals. Exxon is focusing on its home market and production of lower-emission fuels.

images.alt_text: The EU's windfall profits tax is “counter-productive,” discourages investments and undermines investor confidence, ExxonMobil spokesperson Casey Norton said on Wednesday.

site_title: Hong Kong Airlines plans hiring spree, sees full capacity by mid-2024
summary: Hong Kong Airlines plans to hire 1,000 new employees by the end of 2023, including 120 pilots, 500 cabin crew, and 380 ground staff, to reach 60-70% of pre-Covid workforce levels. The airline aims to return to 75% of pre-pandemic capacity by the end of 2023 and 100% by mid-2024. Basic pay will increase by 8% and flying hourly rates by up to 10% for crew, while ground staff will receive a 5% pay rise. The carrier has also increased operations to 30% this month.

images.alt_text: Lufthansa will remain the biggest operator of the A340 and the only major airline still flying the jet.
Scores of passengers due to fly domestically reported delays on social media, and there was no estimate available for the restoration of the Notice to Air Missions System, or NOTAMs.
Chinese tourists arriving at the Suvarnabhumi International Airport in Samut Prakan province, Thailand, Jan 9, 2023.

site_title: EuroSports subsidiary gets US$6.8m funding for electric motorcycle prototypes
summary: Scorpio Electric, a subsidiary of EuroSports Global, has secured US$6.8 million in funding to develop, test, and manufacture its first batch of electric motorcycles, the Scorpio Electric X1. The funds will also be used to develop new premium electric motorcycle models and expand its portfolio. Mass production and global deliveries of the X1 are slated for the second half of 2023, with some of the funds allocated to working with a Chinese conglomerate to assemble the X1.

images.alt_text: EuroSports Global's FY2022 revenue grew 10.7 per cent on-year to S$54.4 million from S$49.1 million, due to higher sales in Lamborghini automobiles.
An empty Eurosports Global Alfa Romeo showroom in Leng Kee road on Oct 3, 2022.

site_title: Most long Covid-19 symptoms clear up in a year for mild cases: study
summary: A large Israel study found that most long Covid-19 symptoms, particularly in mild cases, clear up within a year. Researchers analyzed nearly two million medical records of people tested for Covid between March 2020 and October 2021, excluding those with serious illness. The study found a significantly increased risk of breathing problems, weakness, and brain fog, but most symptoms cleared up within 12 months. Vaccinated patients had a lower risk of breathing problems compared to unvaccinated cases, and children had fewer health problems and recovered well within a year.

images.alt_text: A man passes in front of a Covid 19 laboratory at the Saint-Jacques CHU (Centre Hospitalier Universitaire) in Nantes, western France, on January 11, 2023. (Photo by LOIC VENANCE / AFP)

site_title: China outbound flight bookings at 15% of pre-pandemic levels despite recent surge: ForwardKeys
summary: China's outbound flight bookings are at 15% of pre-pandemic levels, despite a 192% surge from the same period last year. Airlines are operating at 11% of pre-pandemic capacity, with average fares 160% higher than 2019. Travel restrictions, high air fares, and testing requirements pose challenges to industry recovery. ForwardKeys predicts a stronger pick-up in the second quarter, driven by airline capacity increases and the Lunar New Year holiday period.

images.alt_text: Just 227 home sales were made by Chinese buyers in 2022.
Hong Kong chief executive John Lee vows for Hong Kong to resume normalcy "fast" and in a "safe and orderly manner".
The WHO is working with China on how to mitigate the risks of travel ahead of the Lunar New Year public holiday.
Patients in a hallway at a hospital in Shanghai, China, on Jan 7, 2023.

site_title: China’s consumer inflation accelerates in December, PPI falls with soft demand
summary: China's consumer price index rose 1.8% in December, faster than the 1.6% annual gain in November, driven by rising food prices. The producer price index (PPI) fell 0.7% for a third straight month. The economy continues to struggle with a property sector slump under huge debts, while the COVID-19 lifting has dampened consumer activity. The consumer price index for 2022 was 2.0%, below the government target of 3%. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

images.alt_text: Chinese tourists arriving at the Suvarnabhumi International Airport in Samut Prakan province, Thailand, Jan 9, 2023.
In an earlier session, Dr He Dong, deputy director for monetary and capital markets at the International Monetary Fund (IMF), described 2023 to be a challenging year for monetary policy.

site_title: TSMC Q4 profit rises 78%, helped by advanced chip sales
summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing (TSMC) posted a 78% rise in fourth-quarter net profit to a record T$295.9 billion, driven by strong sales of advanced chips amid a global chip shortage. Revenue climbed 26.7% to US$19.93 billion, beating analyst estimates. The company attributed its success to its dominance in making high-performance computing chips for 5G networks and data centers, as well as increased use in gadgets and vehicles. TSMC's share price has risen 8.5% this year, giving the firm a market value of US$412.78 billion.

images.alt_text: The logo of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC) at the Southern Taiwan Science Park in Tainan, Taiwan, on Thursday, Dec. 29, 2022. TSMC kicked off mass production of next-generation chips Thursday, ensuring the island remains the linchpin of a critical technology fought over by governments from Washington to Beijing. Photographer: Lam Yik Fei/Bloomberg

site_title: Oil gains 3% on global economic optimism, despite surprise US crude build
summary: Oil prices rose 3% to a one-week high on Wednesday, driven by optimism over a global economic outlook and concerns about sanctions on Russian crude output. Brent futures rose $2.57 to $82.67 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude rose $2.29 to $77.41. The expected US interest rate hike and China's reopening of its economy also contributed to the price increase, with analysts predicting higher oil demand.

images.alt_text: Brent futures rose 45 cents or 0.6 per cent, to settle at US$80.10 a barrel, while US crude ended 49 cents, or 0.6 per cent higher at US$75.12 per barrel.

site_title: Gold flat as traders await US inflation data
summary: Gold prices remained flat at $1,876.93 per ounce as traders awaited US inflation data, which could influence the Federal Reserve's policy path. Rising interest rates increase the opportunity cost of holding bullion, despite gold being seen as an inflation hedge. Barclays predicts a mild recession in the US, citing declining manufacturing activity. The European Central Bank also expects to continue raising interest rates "significantly" at future meetings.

images.alt_text: Gold is highly sensitive to rising interest rates, as that increase the opportunity cost of holding the non-yielding bullion.

site_title: Electrolux slides into quarterly loss on weak North America sales, costs
summary: Electrolux, Europe's largest appliance maker, reported a fourth-quarter loss due to weak demand in North America and high costs. The Swedish group estimated a group operating loss of 2.0 billion crowns, a significant drop from the 900 million profit in the same period last year. Organic sales fell 8% during the quarter. Electrolux will publish its full fourth-quarter earnings report on February 2.

images.alt_text: The job cuts of 3,500 to 4,000 employees form part of a cost reduction problem that was announced alongside Electrolux’s third-quarter earnings.

site_title: South Korea’s Kakao Entertainment secures 1.2t won investment from sovereign wealth funds, including GIC
summary: South Korean entertainment company Kakao Entertainment secured a 1.2 trillion won (S$1.3 billion) investment from sovereign wealth funds, including Singapore's GIC and Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund. This is the largest overseas investment in a South Korean content company, indicating investors' confidence in the growth potential of Korean content. The investment signals a "recession-proof" outlook for the industry, despite weak economic conditions in other sectors.

images.alt_text: Kakao struggled for hours to recover operations of its popular messaging service, widely used by government officials and businesses.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Thursday; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.4% in early trade on Thursday, driven by a strong US and European market performance. The Straits Times Index (STI) reached 3,283.32, with gainers outnumbering losers 84 to 32. Key movers included Thai Beverage, which rose 0.7%, and DBS, which rose 0.2%. The market awaited US inflation data for its impact on interest rate policy, following a shift in focus from inflation readings in the US and Europe.

images.alt_text: SingPost is planning to acquire an additional 37 per cent stake in fourth-party logistics service company Freight Management Holdings for A$175.4 million in cash.

site_title: Royal Mail hit by cyber-incident
summary: Royal Mail has experienced "severe disruption" to its international letter and parcel services due to a cyber incident. The company has asked customers to stop sending international mail until the problem is resolved, warning that items already shipped may experience delay or disruption. Domestic operations remain unaffected. This incident follows the UK postal group's struggles, including a drop in revenue of over 10% and plans to cut up to 10,000 jobs.

images.alt_text: Royal Mail will be starting the process of consulting on the cuts “in response to the impact of industrial action, delays in delivering agreed productivity improvements and lower parcel volumes.”
A postal worker makes a delivery in London, Britain, July 21, 2022.  REUTERS/Peter Nicholls

site_title: Biden urges US Congress to rein in Big Tech
summary: US President Joe Biden urged Congress to pass laws to rein in the power of Big Tech, citing risks to ordinary Americans. He called for reforms on privacy, targeted advertising for children, and fair competition for small businesses. Biden's administration is seeking legislation to give authorities access to social media algorithms and rethink a law absolving tech companies of content responsibility. Despite bipartisan support, disagreements between parties on how to proceed and the reluctance of Republicans to thwart big business hinder progress.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Meta Platforms' business group is seen in Brussels, Belgium December 6, 2022. REUTERS/Yves Herman/File Photo

Insider Intelligence estimates that Meta’s and Alphabet’s share of ­digital ad revenue in the US, the ­biggest market, was below 50 per cent last year, the first time that’s happened since at least 2015.

site_title: Russian oil revenues falling because of price cap: US official
summary: US Treasury officials say Russia's oil revenues are falling due to a US$60 per barrel price cap imposed by Western countries on sea-borne Russian crude oil sales. The cap, set in late 2022, forces countries above the cap to use non-Western ships, increasing shipping costs. As a result, Russia is losing millions of dollars daily, further weakening its economy. The cap also limits Russia's revenue from oil products, such as petrol and diesel, set to be implemented on February 5.

images.alt_text: From Feb 5, the coalition – which consists of Australia, Canada, Japan and the United States, plus the 27-nation European Union, will also impose price caps on Russian products, such as diesel, kerosene and fuel oil.
Jars containing rare earth minerals produced by Australia's Lynas Corp from its Mount Weld operations are seen near Laverton, northeast of Perth, Australia, August 23, 2019.
Brent futures rose US$2.57, or 3.2 per cent, to settle at US$82.67 a barrel on Wednesday.

site_title: Poor economies of scale raise questions about viability of grocery delivery startups
summary: Online grocery startups face viability concerns due to poor economies of scale, competing with incumbent supermarkets that possess institutional knowledge and experience. Recent closures include UglyFood, HappyFresh, and a reportedly staff-cutting Sayurbox, while Grab has discontinued its grocery business. As interest rates rise and the era of easy money ends, the startup space is rationalizing, with grocery delivery proving particularly unappealing. This raises questions about the long-term viability of these businesses in the competitive market.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
Founded as one of the first Instacart-style grocery delivery services in South-east Asia, HappyFresh has raised at least US$97 million in equity funding in addition to debt financing.
Revenue for the quarter surged 79 per cent to hit an all-time high of US$321 million.

site_title: Jill Biden has two cancerous growths removed
summary: US First Lady Jill Biden underwent successful surgery on Wednesday to remove two cancerous growths, one near her right eye and another on her left chest. The procedure, known as Mohs surgery, confirmed that both lesions were basal cell carcinoma and were successfully removed. Biden is considered clear of danger and is expected to make a full recovery. She will return to the White House later today, with her husband, President Joe Biden, accompanying her to the hospital.

images.alt_text: Cancer diagnoses are rising globally due to a number of factors, including excessive smoking, exposure to carcinogens and obesity.
The United States is home to global tech giants Apple, Google, Amazon and Facebook-owner Meta but has trailed governments in Europe and Asia in drawing up more modern rules to curb their power.

site_title: Subway explores sale that could value it at over US$10b: WSJ
summary: Subway, the world's largest quick-service restaurant brand, is exploring a sale that could value it at over $10 billion, according to the Wall Street Journal. The process, in its early stage, is expected to attract corporate buyers and private-equity firms. The company, owned by its two founding families for over five decades, has over 37,000 restaurants in more than 100 countries. A spokesperson for Subway declined to comment on the ownership structure and business plans.

site_title: China’s BYD plans push into India’s burgeoning EV market
summary: Chinese carmaker BYD plans to push into India's electric vehicle (EV) market, aiming to capture 40% of the market by 2030. BYD will launch its third electric model, the Seal luxury sedan, by the end of 2023, and plans to sell 15,000 electric vehicles this year. The company will prioritize introducing higher-priced cars to showcase its "premium" technology before expanding to mass-market vehicles. BYD has invested $200 million in its Indian operations and will explore adding manufacturing facilities when demand increases.

images.alt_text: Warren Buffett-backed BYD’s sales of new-energy vehicles – including pure electric cars and hybrids – climbed to 1.86 million last year from about 604,000 in 2021, even as Covid impacted production.

site_title: South Korea set for one more rate hike as risks mount
summary: South Korea's central bank, the Bank of Korea, is expected to raise its key interest rate for the 18th time in 18 months, to 3.5%, as inflation remains above the 2% target. Economists predict one more rate hike, citing weakening industrial production, falling exports, and declining house prices. The Bank of Korea aims to coordinate policy with the government to ensure a soft landing, while prioritizing inflation concerns. A pause in rate hikes is also possible, but the central bank is likely to deliver further rate increases to return inflation to its target.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Korea is 18 months into a tightening cycle designed to curb inflationary pressures and economists predict that a rate rise on Friday may be the final move.

site_title: Chip supplier to Amazon and Apple faces UK identity crisis
summary: A London judge dismissed Skyworks' appeal to overturn the UK Intellectual Property Office's decision rejecting the chipmaker's request for three trademarks. Skyworks, a supplier to Amazon and Apple, sought to trademark the word "Skyworks" but was blocked by broadcasting giant Sky, citing unfair advantage and misrepresentation. The court found the word "Skyworks" to be too similar to Sky, potentially harming the broadcaster through misrepresentation. The decision is a setback for Skyworks, which now faces an identity crisis in the UK market.

images.alt_text: The current work calls for Apple’s first touch-screen MacBook Pro to retain a traditional laptop design, including a standard trackpad and keyboard.
The changes are part of a sweeping effort to replace Apple supplies with homegrown parts, an undertaking that will give the company more control over the design and capabilities of its products.
Pointing to the enduring power of the Prime membership program, Amazon said the number of customers who bought a product after clicking on it increased 25 per cent on sites using the service.

site_title: BlackRock plans to cut 500 jobs in first retrenchment since 2019
summary: BlackRock plans to cut approximately 500 jobs, about 2.5% of its global workforce, due to sharp declines in equity and bond markets last year. This is the firm's first job cut since 2019 and will leave headcount about 5% higher than a year ago. The decision aims to stay ahead of market changes and deliver for clients, according to CEO Larry Fink and President Rob Kapito.

images.alt_text: JPMorgan and Citigroup were among the top financiers of the fossil fuel industry in 2021.

site_title: Pursuing sustainability in commodity trading
summary: Khaitan International, a Singapore-based commodity trading house, aims to build sustainable business models that support recycling and a waste-free circular economy. The company, founded in 1985 by Pawan Khaitan, focuses on metals and scraps, agro-produce, and industrial raw materials. It has overcome early challenges by implementing checks and diversifying its customer and supplier base. With a strong network of loyal customers and suppliers, Khaitan International has achieved annual revenue of US$150 million and won the Enterprise 50 Award in 2018. The company is now exploring new commodities and expanding into new markets to strengthen its network and create business opportunities.

site_title: South Korea’s Hanwha Qcells to invest US$2.5b in US solar supply chain
summary: South Korea's Hanwha Qcells plans to invest $2.5 billion in the US solar supply chain, creating up to 2,500 jobs in Georgia. This is one of the largest corporate manufacturing commitments since the passage of the US Inflation Reduction Act, which includes $300 billion in subsidies for clean energy products. The investment will expand Hanwha's existing solar panel factory in Dalton, Georgia, and open a second facility, producing solar panel components and modules. The White House hailed the announcement as evidence the IRA legislation is working, creating "thousands of good-paying middle-class jobs."

site_title: Germany’s Scholz backs joint EU funding to counter US green plan
summary: German Chancellor Olaf Scholz's Social Democrats propose reforming the EU's state-aid rules and increasing funding to match US green subsidies. They aim to create joint financing instruments to help EU member states compete, particularly those with tighter budgets. The proposal is part of a broader European industrial strategy to address the green-subsidy race.

site_title: Daily Mirror publisher to cut 200 jobs after profit warning
summary: Reach, the publisher of the Daily Mirror and Daily Express, is cutting 200 jobs, about 4% of its workforce, due to weak digital and print advertising revenue. The company expects to miss market expectations for annual operating profit and will save at least £30 million. Digital revenue fell 6% and print advertising revenue slumped 20% in the three months to Dec 25, with circulation revenue growing 1.8%. Shares dropped 24% after the profit warning.

site_title: Tesla nears preliminary deal for Indonesia electric car plant
summary: Tesla is near a preliminary deal to set up a factory in Indonesia, its third outside the US, to produce up to 1 million cars annually. The factory would utilize Indonesia's key battery metals, aligning with Tesla's global production capacity goal. Discussions include multiple facilities for production and supply chain functions. A deal has not been signed, and the agreement could still fall through. The Indonesian Investment Ministry is leading the talks, with representatives from the ministry and Tesla not immediately commenting.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise on bets of easing rate hikes; Direct Line plunges
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 rose 0.4% on Wednesday, driven by hopes of less aggressive interest rate hikes, with investors awaiting US inflation data for clues on the Federal Reserve's policy. Shares in rate-sensitive tech stocks and energy companies also rose, while Direct Line Insurance Group Plc plummeted 23.5% after scrapping its dividend. The Stoxx 600 has risen 5.4% so far in the year, boosted by a decline in natural gas prices and data indicating a milder-than-expected recession in the euro zone.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed 0.8 per cent higher at 33,973.01, while the broad-based S&P 500 added 1.3 per cent to 3,969.61.

site_title: US mortgage rates decline to 6.42%, first drop in three weeks
summary: US mortgage rates dropped 16 basis points to 6.42% in the week ended Jan 6, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association. This decline provided a modest lift to refinancing activity, with applications rising 5.1% in the week. Despite the rate drop, refinancing activity remains near a two-decade low, and homeowners who locked in low rates in the last two years are staying put, keeping purchase applications depressed.

site_title: WHO seeks more China Covid data, praises US ‘transparency’
