The token, which is meant to have a constant $1 value, was at times undercollateralized, with a gap between reserves and supply surpassing $1 billion on three occasions between 2020 and 2021. Binance has improved the process, but the exchange has faced scrutiny for its management of reserves, particularly after a US$60 billion wipeout of the TerraUSD algorithmic stablecoin ecosystem in May.

images.alt_text: Customers pulled more than US$3 billion from Binance in a single day last week as part of a three-day frenzy that saw more than US$6 billion withdrawn.

site_title: WHO urges travellers to wear masks as new Covid variant spreads
summary: The World Health Organisation (WHO) is urging travellers to wear masks on long-haul flights due to the rapid spread of the latest Omicron subvariant of Covid-19 in the US and small but growing numbers in Europe. More than a dozen countries, including the US, are demanding Covid tests from travellers from China. The WHO recommends that passengers wear masks in high-risk settings, such as long-haul flights, arriving from areas with widespread Covid-19 transmission.

images.alt_text: A medical worker in a protective suit registers information for a patient at the entrance to the fever clinic of the Central Hospital of Wuhan, amid of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) outbreak, in Wuhan, Hubei province, China December 31, 2022. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang

site_title: French PM proposes raising retirement age to 64 by 2030
summary: French Prime Minister Elisabeth Borne proposed raising the retirement age from 62 to 64 by 2030 to balance the pension system, citing the risk of massive tax increases and pension reductions. The move is expected to face opposition from trade unions, who are set to announce strikes. Borne acknowledged public anxiety and fears, but framed the changes as necessary to prevent the system's collapse. The proposed changes are set to be examined by parliament early next month.

site_title: Golden Mile Tower owners in private talks after close of S$650m en bloc tender
summary: Golden Mile Tower owners have entered a 10-week private treaty negotiation period after its en bloc sale tender closed with a few expressions of interest. Almost 90% of owners have signed the collective sale agreement, valuing the 99-year leasehold commercial development at S$598 million. The property, launched for sale at an indicative price of S$650 million, has a plot size of 8,727 sq m and a gross floor area of 38,953.72 sq m.

site_title: Insured losses hit US$120b as extreme weather spreads
summary: Insured losses from natural disasters reached US$120 billion in 2022, with Hurricane Ian causing about half of that, US$60 billion. Climate change is driving these losses, with insured losses exceeding US$100 billion a year, a new normal for the industry. The total cost, including uninsured losses, was US$270 billion, with floods and storms being the most destructive. The surge in losses is also affecting the catastrophe bond market, with investors demanding higher premiums.

images.alt_text: The destroyed Pine Island Road following Hurricane Ian in Matlacha Isles, Florida, US, on Saturday, Oct. 1, 2022. Research firm Enki Holdings LLC pegs the economic cost of Hurricane Ian at $60 billion to $70 billion, based on damage to homes and infrastructure, as well as the cost of reconstruction and longer-term knock-on effects including the disruption in tourism. Photographer: Eva Marie Uzcategui/Bloomberg

site_title: Oil edges higher as petroleum demand set to touch record next year
summary: Oil prices edged higher on Tuesday as global petroleum consumption is forecast to reach a record 102.2 million barrels per day in 2024, driven by growth in countries like India and China. Brent futures rose 45 cents or 0.6% to $80.10 a barrel, while US crude ended 49 cents or 0.6% higher at $75.12 per barrel. A weaker dollar, hovering at its weakest level in seven months, is also expected to boost demand for oil.

site_title: Intel rolls out design aimed at winning back server market share
summary: Intel has released its delayed server design, Sapphire Rapids, to regain control of the lucrative server market. The new Xeon processors are already being used in cloud-computing systems by Google and Amazon Web Services, and will be available in machines from Hewlett Packard Enterprise and Dell Technologies. This move aims to stem market share losses and rebuild confidence in Intel's competitive chip offerings, a key step in regaining leadership in the computer industry.

images.alt_text: The move comes as Intel doubles down on accelerated computing, a growing segment dominated by Nvidia as AI use surges.

site_title: SGX mandates exact remuneration disclosures for CEO and directors; removes two-tier vote for IDs
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has mandated companies to disclose the exact remuneration paid to CEOs and directors in their annual reports, starting from financial years ending on or after December 31, 2024. The exchange also removed the two-tier vote mechanism for long-serving independent directors (IDs), imposing a hard tenure limit of nine years. The changes aim to strengthen director independence, encourage board renewal, and improve market transparency, with unanimous support from institutional and retail investors.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
meeting room, table, business
SGX RegCo upcoming consultation on pay disclosure comes amid poor compliance from SGX-listed companies when it comes to remuneration disclosures, which currently apply on a “comply or explain” basis.

A review of corporate governance disclosures by KPMG in Singapore, published in September, found only 35 per cent of companies disclosed the actual remuneration of directors on a named basis, while 18 per cent did so for CEOs.
SGX wants to bring disclosure requirements for board and CEO pay closer to global standards

site_title: World Bank cuts 2023 forecasts and warns of global recession
summary: The World Bank has cut its global growth forecasts for 2023, predicting a 1.7% increase, half the pace forecast in June, due to persistent inflation, higher interest rates, and the impact of Russia's invasion of Ukraine. This marks the third-worst performance in the last three decades, with emerging-market and developing economies expected to be 6% below pre-pandemic levels by the end of 2024. The bank warns of a potential global recession and debt distress, calling for urgent global action and increased investment in developing nations.

images.alt_text: Asia-Pacific carriers are the hardest hit in terms of air cargo volumes in November 2022.

site_title: Meta named favourite Internet stock for 2023 in JPMorgan survey
summary: Meta Platforms is expected to be the top-performing internet stock in 2023, according to a JPMorgan survey of investors, with 41% of respondents naming the company as the best performer. This follows Meta's worst year on record in 2022, with a 64% drop. The survey suggests investors see Meta rebounding due to attractive valuations, easing year-over-year comparisons, and improved cash flows and margins. Meta's shares rose 0.7% following the survey, while Amazon and Netflix gained 1.8% and 1.5%, respectively.

images.alt_text: US tech giants including Meta, Microsoft, Twitter and Snap have purged more than 150,000 staff, according to Layoff.fyi, which tracks technology job losses.

site_title: Number of compulsory wind-ups rises after two-year fall; over 200 businesses shut in 2022
summary: Singapore saw a rise in compulsory wind-ups, with 205 companies forced to shut down in 2022, exceeding 2021 and 2020 numbers. The High Court received 238 applications to wind up companies, and over 800 bankruptcy orders were issued, resulting in 908 discharges. The increase is attributed to rising inflation rates and geopolitical pressures since Singapore reopened its borders in April 2022.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting

Employers added 4.31 million jobs last year through November – second only to 2021’s surge, and data to be released on Friday (Jan 6) are projected to show that payrolls rose another 200,000 in December.
Bed Bath & Beyond was plagued by years of management missteps and a dysfunctional corporate culture that left it ill-equipped to compete against Amazon.com and other online retail juggernauts.

site_title: Airbus tops Boeing in 2022 plane orders and deliveries
summary: Airbus delivered 661 planes in 2022, surpassing Boeing's 480 deliveries, solidifying its leadership in the civil aviation industry. Despite a narrower lead in new orders, Airbus reported 820 net orders, while Boeing saw a 40% increase in annual deliveries, its best year since 2018. Both companies face supply chain challenges, including labor shortages and volatile energy prices, which hindered production and delivery targets. Boeing aims to increase production in 2023 and 2024, but faces engine constraints, particularly with the 737 MAX.

site_title: Amazon plans to shut three UK warehouses, impacting 1,200 jobs
summary: Amazon plans to shut three UK warehouses, impacting 1,200 jobs, following a recent announcement of cutting over 18,000 roles globally. The move comes as the company's UK business faces demands for better pay from warehouse staff, who are set to go on strike on January 25. The layoffs are part of a larger series of tech industry cuts.

site_title: Europe: Shares end lower, Bayer shares jump
summary: European stocks closed 0.6% lower, marking the first decline in three sessions, as investors took profit after a strong start to the year. Despite this, shares of German drugmaker Bayer jumped 4.1% after predicting peak annual sales of €5 billion for its experimental blood clot treatment. US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's speech focused on climate change, easing concerns about monetary policy. Market participants now focus on the US Labor Department's consumer prices report on Thursday.

site_title: US: Tech shares lift stocks higher on Tuesday
summary: US stocks rose on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average finishing 0.6% higher at 33,704.10, and the S&P 500 gaining 0.7% to 3,919.25. Tech shares led the market, driven by a downgraded global growth forecast from the World Bank and anticipation of moderation in inflation data. Large tech companies, including Amazon, Netflix, and Meta, saw significant gains, while Boeing fell 0.9% despite reporting a jump in plane deliveries. The market awaits Thursday's consumer price index report for further implications on Federal Reserve policy.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians walk past a Wall Street sign near the New York Stock Exchange in New York, U.S., on Monday, July 26, 2010. U.S. stocks rose, with the Standard & Poor's 500 Index gaining for a third day, after FedEx Corp. boosted its profit forecast and a report showing improved new-home sales raised builder shares. Photographer: Jin Lee/Bloomberg

site_title: US: S&P 500, Nasdaq open lower after Powell’s comments
summary: US stocks opened lower on Tuesday, January 10, following Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's comments that did not provide further clarity on interest rate hikes. The S&P 500 dropped 0.09% to 3,888.57, and the Nasdaq Composite fell 0.26% to 10,607.72. The Dow Jones Industrial Average remained flat. The lack of clear guidance on interest rate hikes has sparked concerns about the outlook for US stocks.

site_title: Hackers hit websites of Danish central bank, other banks
summary: Hackers disrupted access to the websites of Denmark's central bank and seven private banks, including Jyske Bank and Sydbank, due to a distributed denial of service (DDoS) attack. The attack, which targeted Bankdata's servers, briefly restricted access to the websites of the affected banks. The central bank's website remained operational, and the attack did not impact the bank's other systems or day-to-day operations. The incident highlights the vulnerability of financial institutions to cyberattacks.

site_title: GSM Building at Middle Road up for sale again at same S$85m guide price
summary: The GSM Building at 141 Middle Road in Singapore has been put up for sale for the second time at a guide price of S$85 million. The building, which sits on a 12,003 sq ft land plot with a 59-year remaining lease term, was previously offered for sale in August 2022 but withdrew before a sale agreement was signed. The site is zoned for commercial use under the URA's Master Plan 2019, with an approximate S$1,352 per sq ft price per plot ratio. The tender closes on January 27.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei
GS Building has a land area of approximately 3,426.7 sq m (36,885 sq ft).
The 99-year development comprises 269 units across 16 floors.
Golden Mile Tower was completed in 1974, one year after its sister building, Golden Mile Complex.

site_title: US wholesale inventories rise solidly in November; sales fall
summary: US wholesale inventories rose 1.0% in November, a strong increase, but sales fell 0.6% amid higher borrowing costs. This marks the second quarter in a row that inventories have subtracted more than one percentage point from GDP. Inventories rose 20.9% year-over-year, driven by increases in furniture, computer, and electrical equipment stocks. Motor vehicle inventories remained unchanged, and wholesale inventories excluding autos increased 1.0% in November. The data suggests inventory accumulation has decelerated due to improved supply chains and reduced demand.

images.alt_text: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell said we should not wander off "to pursue perceived social benefits that are not tightly linked to our statutory goals and authorities.”

site_title: ‘Nature positive’ will be as big as net zero
summary: Around half of global GDP is moderately or highly dependent on nature, and the world has lost 70% of its wildlife population since 1970. The Global Biodiversity Framework (GBF) aims to halt and reverse biodiversity loss by 2030, but a set of rules and standards for "nature positive" capital allocation is needed. A global disclosure standard based on complementary metrics is possible, and Target 15 of the GBF requires large and transnational companies to monitor and disclose their biodiversity risks and impact. Aligning standards internationally and integrating with climate standards could unlock financing needed to tackle the biodiversity threat, but ignoring the issue is not an option due to associated risks.

images.alt_text: Jenn-Hui Tan
An estimated 63 per cent of Asia Pacific's GDP, US$19 trillion, is at risk from nature loss.

The National Parks Board (NParks) will be announcing plans to restore and enhance the habitats of Labrador Nature Reserve including a new Keppel Coastal Trail, as part of efforts to transform Singapore into a City in Nature, a key pillar of the Singapore Green Plan.

site_title: Sats-WFS deal: Pro forma financials in circular show lower immediate boost to earnings, EPS
summary: Sats, Singapore's largest ground handler and in-flight caterer, has updated its pro forma financials for its proposed acquisition of Worldwide Flight Services (WFS). The updated numbers show a lower immediate boost to earnings and EPS, with net profit rising from S$20 million to S$28 million and EPS from 1.8 Singapore cents to 1.9 Singapore cents. The company attributed the decrease to increased interest expense due to a S$700 million term loan. The updated numbers also include adjustments to WFS's financial statements to align with Singapore Financial Reporting Standards (International), which had a negative impact on the company's EPS.

images.alt_text: Ben Paul
Sats' share price fell precipitously after the company said it would acquire WFS, the largest air cargo handling firm in the world
The company’s directors recommended that shareholders vote in favour of the resolution at the EGM as they believed that WFS was the “right asset of scale and reach” for the company to acquire.
ISS said that as a split-funded purchase, the proposed acquisition also gives the company flexibility to not put too much pressure on any one funding stream.

site_title: Crypto exchange Coinbase to cut nearly 1,000 jobs
summary: Coinbase, a cryptocurrency exchange, announced it will reduce its workforce by 20% or 950 employees as part of a restructuring plan, citing a challenging environment in the industry. The company expects to incur $149-163 million in restructuring expenses. This is the third round of layoffs for Coinbase since last year, following a decline in trading volume and a crisis of confidence in the industry.

images.alt_text: DFS found Coinbase treated its onboarding requirements for customers as a “simple check-the-box” and had not done sufficient background checks, DFS said in a statement.

site_title: Upholding democracy: US should be a model, not a crusader
summary: US presidents have long sought to export American values worldwide, but this approach has proven unrealistic. Historical examples show that American presidents have allied with authoritarian leaders, such as the Soviet Union during World War II, and have accommodated non-democratic regimes to contain threats. The US model of liberal democracy and capitalism has been successful, but exporting it to other nations is impractical due to cultural and historical uniqueness. Instead, the US should focus on protecting and rebuilding its own system, and serve as a model to the world through diplomatic means and commercial ties.

images.alt_text: Veterans take part in a flag-raising ceremony at a former military post on Kinmen, Taiwan, Oct 15, 2021. Taiwan lives under constant threat of invasion by China, which claims the self-ruled democracy as part of its territory to be retaken one day, by force if necessary.

Supporters of Brazil's former President Jair Bolsonaro demonstrate against President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva while security forces operate, outside Brazil’s National Congress in Brasilia, Brazil, Jan 8, 2023.

Republican Representatives Matt Gaetz (Florida) and Kevin McCarthy (California) confer after the House’s 14th vote to select a speaker, at the Capitol in Washington, late on Friday, Jan 6, 2023. It took 15 rounds of voting for McCarthy to win the Speaker's gavel.

site_title: US dollar stabilises near seven-month low
summary: The US dollar has stabilized near its seven-month low against the euro, trading at US$1.0736, after hawkish comments from US Federal officials and anticipation of a speech by Fed chair Jerome Powell. Markets doubt the Fed will need to raise interest rates above 5% to cool inflation, and investors expect rates to peak just under 5% by June. The dollar has been sliding due to concerns about inflation persistence and the Fed's decision-making process.

site_title: Amazon, Salesforce job cuts are warning signs for stock prices
summary: Amazon and Salesforce announced significant job cuts, with Amazon cutting over 18,000 jobs and Salesforce reducing its workforce by 10%. While investors have applauded the moves, expecting they will help protect margins, analysts warn that the cuts may be too little, too late, as demand for tech companies is expected to decline in a slowing economy. Analysts predict a 20% downside for tech shares in a worst-case scenario, citing reduced revenue growth estimates and earnings expectations.

images.alt_text: The peril of failing to heed the central bank’s action is best illustrated by the timing of the S&P 500’s worst performance during 2022. All of the index’s five biggest weekly declines took place immediately before or around a Fed meeting.

site_title: Amazon expands Prime delivery service to more web stores
summary: Amazon is expanding its "Buy With Prime" service, allowing Prime subscribers to use the company's speedy delivery service when shopping on other websites. The service, which was introduced by invitation only, is set to be generally available in the US by the end of the month. According to Amazon, the number of customers who bought a product after clicking on it increased 25% on sites using the service. This move aims to boost sales for merchants and collect more shipping fees, while also providing a competitive edge in the logistics business.

images.alt_text: Amazon last week said it would cut more than 18,000 roles, impacting its e-commerce and human resources organisations.

site_title: China passenger vehicle sales rise in Dec, Tesla sales slump 41%
summary: China's passenger car sales rose 2.4% in December due to a surge in electric vehicle (EV) purchases before a decade-long subsidy expired. However, sales are expected to sharply weaken in January as automakers, including Tesla, offer deeper discounts to maintain sales. The market is expected to remain weak until the Chinese New Year, which begins on January 21.

images.alt_text: The waiting time for orders of the rear-wheel-drive and long-range versions of Model Y were a week longer on Monday than on Friday.
Posts on Chinese social media showed Tesla owners at different stores and distribution centres voicing their frustration about the cuts, which followed discounts made in October.

Forvia chief executive Patrick Koller said Chinese EV makers can produce vehicles for less because they have lower research and development costs, lower levels of capital spending and lower labour costs than rivals in Europe.
Warren Buffett-backed BYD’s sales of new-energy vehicles – including pure electric cars and hybrids – climbed to 1.86 million last year from about 604,000 in 2021, even as Covid impacted production.

site_title: Russia’s budget gap surges to record as war hits finances
summary: Russia's federal budget deficit widened to a record 3.9 trillion roubles ($75 billion) in December, reversing a surplus in the previous 11 months, due to plunging revenues amid restrictions on oil exports and increased spending on the Ukraine war. The full-year deficit reached 3.3 trillion roubles, or 2.3% of gross domestic product (GDP). The government is discussing higher taxes and reducing non-war spending to cover the shortfall, which is forecast to remain strong despite the pressures.

site_title: China to adopt more targeted monetary policy to spur economy and high quality growth
summary: China is adopting a more targeted monetary policy to spur its economy and achieve high-quality growth, with a focus on expanding effective demand and deepening supply-side reform. Chairman Guo Shuqing of the China Banking and Insurance Regulatory Commission aims to increase incomes of low- and middle-income groups and bolster support for service consumption. The government will also prioritize infrastructure investments, financial services for foreign trade, and private enterprise funding. However, economists warn that deep structural issues, such as the property sector's challenges, may weigh on longer-term growth, with GDP growth forecasted to slow to 2% in 2024.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan
CHINA created 12.06 million new urban jobs in 2022, achieving the government’s annual target despite the Covid-19 hit to economic growth, state media Xinhua reported late Monday.
China received 325 inbound flights and 396 inbound ships on Sunday.

Passengers push their luggage through the international arrivals hall at Beijing Capital International Airport after China lifted the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) quarantine requirement for inbound travellers in Beijing, China January 8, 2023. REUTERS/Thomas Peter

site_title: Philippines central bank flags 25 or 50 bps rate hike next month
summary: The Philippine central bank's governor, Felipe Medalla, expects inflation to be within the 2-4% target band by the second half of this year. The BSP is set to raise interest rates by 25-50 basis points at its next policy meeting on Feb 16 to curb pressure on consumer prices. Medalla noted that the pressure to match US rate hikes is waning, and inflation is expected to fall below the midpoint of the target range by end-2023 or early 2024.

site_title: Adani-led group completes purchase of Israel's Haifa Port
summary: A consortium led by India's Adani Group has completed the purchase of Haifa Port in northern Israel for $1.15 billion, marking the culmination of a nearly two-decade reform of the underperforming port sector plagued by labour strikes. The sale is part of Israel's efforts to sell state-owned ports and build new private docks to reduce costs and waiting times for vessels.

images.alt_text: “As a part of the company’s business growth strategy, we continue to evaluate various viable options,” an Adani Group representative said.

site_title: Vietnam posts record 2022 trade surplus with US as China deficit rises
summary: Vietnam recorded a record trade surplus of $94.9 billion with the US in 2022, driven by exports of garments, electronics, and wooden furniture. Total exports rose 10.6% to $371.85 billion, while imports from China increased 6.6% to $117.87 billion. However, economists warn of weakening global demand impacting shipments, and a widening trade deficit with China to $60.2 billion. Vietnam's export-driven economy grew 8% in 2022, benefiting from 15 free trade agreements.

site_title: China’s reopening a relief to Malaysia’s ‘dour investment sentiment’
summary: Malaysia's tourism-related stocks have seen buying interest as China's reopening to the world is expected to boost the country's economy. Analysts predict that Chinese tourists will catalyze demand for spending on transport, hotels, and retail, uplifting Malaysia's trade balance and the ringgit. Beneficiaries include tourism and consumer sectors, commodity stocks, and real estate investment trusts (Reits), particularly those related to retail and hospitality. The reopening is seen as positive for Asia amid concerns about the US economy and recession in Europe, with stocks such as Sunway Reit and Malaysia Pacific Industries gaining momentum.

images.alt_text: While the ringgit is expected to consolidate in the near-term, Fitch Solutions analysts noted some broader upsides in a report on Friday (Jan 6).

site_title: Goldman Sachs raises US$1.6b private capital for climate fund
summary: Goldman Sachs Asset Management has raised US$1.6 billion for its first private equity fund focused on investing in climate and environmental solutions. The fund, launched in 2021, provides "growth capital" to companies in clean energy, sustainable transport, waste, and more. The final close comes as investors increasingly prioritize companies addressing global warming. The fund has made 12 investments, targeting specific sustainability outcomes such as CO2 sequestration and wetland restoration. This marks a growing trend in investors backing bigger companies in the climate sector.

images.alt_text: Rhodium said that the US may start to see emission reductions in 2023 if the government fast-tracks implementation of the Inflation Reduction Act (IRA).

site_title: China to tighten scrutiny of firms’ foreign debt next month
summary: China is set to implement a new regulation on foreign debt for Chinese companies, effective February 10. The regulation will require firms to register, report, and receive approval for selling debt instruments with tenors over one year, and submit information on fundraising proceeds. This move aims to strengthen risk prevention and improve post-issuance regulation. Defaults on foreign notes reached a record high of $46.5 billion in 2022, prompting the change. The new rules may also allow defaulted companies to access foreign debt markets.

site_title: Nomura senior Asian bankers depart amid dealmaking downturn
summary: Several senior Nomura Holdings bankers in Asia, including Hong Kong-based managing directors Maryann Tseng and Wallace Wong, are departing amid a slump in fees and broader global cuts. The majority of reductions are focused on areas with limited scale. Nomura's global investment banking revenue fell 21% in the three months ended September 30, and the firm is closing its small Malaysia investment banking operation. The company aims to retain focus in its key areas while maintaining core capabilities for sustainable profitability.

site_title: How technology is redefining the boundaries of the firm
summary: Companies are reorganizing themselves in response to digital upheaval, with technology changing how firms operate and what they do. The rise of remote work, freelancing, and outsourcing has blurred the boundaries between collaborating with colleagues, freelancers, or other firms. This shift is driven by technological advances, such as fast broadband Internet, cloud computing, and new communication platforms. As a result, jobs are trickling out of corporate headquarters to smaller cities and towns, and the boundary between firms is becoming increasingly fluid. According to a study, the number of jobs in tech, finance, and professional services has grown by five percentage points more in rural areas than in metropolitan areas since the pandemic.

images.alt_text: communication, connection, signal transmission

site_title: Who’s afraid of the big bad rate pause?
summary: Central bankers are expected to struggle conveying a positive message about the pause in interest rate hikes, as the bulk of the work against inflation is done. Despite this, they will likely talk tough to avoid appearing too relaxed. This week, the Bank of Korea will set borrowing costs, with a possible final quarter-point increase or pause, and will need to balance the need to signal that the battle is won with the reality of the slowdown in growth. Effective communication will be crucial to reassure consumers and businesses that price pressures will be addressed in the medium term.

images.alt_text: Residental buildings in Huaian, in China's eastern Jiangsu province. China's reopening will be bumpy and may buffet commerce before buttressing it.
The BOK raised its rate by 50 basis points at two of its meetings this year, seeking to narrow the gap with the Fed and rein in the won’s depreciation.
Chair Powell and his colleagues are on track to extend the Fed’s most aggressive tightening cycle since the 1980s well into 2023.

site_title: Japan banks target end-January for Toshiba bid loan decision
summary: Japan's top banks are targeting the end of January to issue commitment letters for a 1.4 trillion yen loan backing Japan Industrial Partners' takeover offer for Toshiba. The loan, which includes 1.2 trillion yen for financing and 200 billion yen for operational costs, has been stalled due to covenants and collateral disputes. Despite ongoing discussions, the JIP-led consortium remains opposed to some banks' demands, but a consensus is hoped for in the coming weeks. The loan, which is part of Toshiba's push to go private, has secured 1 trillion yen in financing from 20 co-investors.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's business climate has seen a significant improvement, with over half of the 931 surveyed firms expressing satisfaction, up from 23% in 2020 and 37% in 2021. Businesses cite manpower and increased costs as major challenges for 2023, with 74% hoping the Singapore Budget 2023 will address costs, 57% manpower challenges, and 48% cash flow management. This shift in sentiment reflects a more positive outlook for the country's business environment.

site_title: WHO meeting on Jan 27 to decide if Covid-19 still a global emergency
summary: A World Health Organization committee will meet on January 27 to consider whether the Covid-19 pandemic still represents a global emergency, three years after it was first declared. High levels of infections in China, which recently dismantled its zero-Covid policy, may lead to a delay in declaring the pandemic's end. The decision will be made by WHO Director General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus after consultation with the Emergency Committee.

images.alt_text: A medical worker in a protective suit registers information for a patient at the entrance to the fever clinic of the Central Hospital of Wuhan, amid of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) outbreak, in Wuhan, Hubei province, China December 31, 2022. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang

site_title: New British law to blunt strikes to be introduced to parliament
summary: The British government plans to introduce a new law to parliament requiring key public services to maintain minimum safety levels during strike action. The move comes as the country experiences a wave of industrial action due to pay rises failing to keep up with 40-year-high inflation. The bill, which has been met with criticism from trade unions, would not be debated on its introduction and could take months to become law. Opponents argue it is undemocratic and unworkable, and the opposition Labour Party has vowed to repeal it if it comes to power.

site_title: Powell: Fed needs independence to fight inflation, should avoid climate policy
summary: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell emphasized the importance of the Fed's independence in combating inflation, warning against taking on new goals beyond its statutory mandate. He cautioned against pursuing perceived social benefits that are not directly linked to the Fed's core objectives, stating that this would undermine its case for independence. Powell's comments highlight the Fed's commitment to maintaining its autonomy in order to effectively manage the economy and address inflationary pressures.

images.alt_text: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell attends the Central Bank Symposium at the Grand Hotel in Stockholm, Sweden, January 10, 2023. TT News Agency/Claudio Bresciani/via REUTERS      ATTENTION EDITORS - THIS IMAGE WAS PROVIDED BY A THIRD PARTY. SWEDEN OUT. NO COMMERCIAL OR EDITORIAL SALES IN SWEDEN.

site_title: Commodity prices to fall as Chinese companies return to full capacity: UOBKH
summary: UOB Kay Hian advises investors to reduce exposure to commodities, citing China's border reopening and relaxation of its zero-Covid policy, which is expected to lead to a gradual return to pre-Covid-19 business activities. As supply capacity ramps up, commodity prices are anticipated to decline, negatively impacting the coal industry. However, the report also highlights the benefits of lower commodity costs for the consumer staple sector, leading to predicted declines in inflation and interest rates, which would benefit banks and property companies.

images.alt_text: Crude has greeted the new year with a chunky decline as lacklustre demand and China’s virus turbulence leave the market plentifully supplied.
OPEC+ have tried to balance markets through changes in supply this year, which since October involved cuts
Passengers arriving at Pudong International Airport in Shanghai, China, on Sunday, Jan 8, 2023, the day the country ended its zero-Covid policy.
Singapore is not anticipating any major supply chain disruptions as a result of the Covid-19 situation in China.

site_title: BMW sales recover in fourth quarter as supply chain issues ease
summary: BMW reported a 10.6% rise in fourth-quarter sales, driven by easing supply chain bottlenecks. Full-year deliveries fell 4.8% due to supply chain troubles in Europe and China, but bounced back in the fourth quarter. Sales of electric vehicles more than doubled to 215,755. The company plans to transition to a direct sales model in 24 European markets by 2024, with the Mini brand to follow in 2026.

site_title: Malaysia to open special lanes for China travellers at entry points
summary: Malaysia will introduce special lanes for travellers from China at international entry points, amid concerns over a rapid Covid-19 outbreak in the country. Travellers from China who are symptomatic will be referred to health officials, undergoing throat swabs and RTK-Antigen Covid-19 tests. All travellers will be screened through thermal scanners, with symptomatic visitors undergoing further examination. This measure aims to reduce the risk of transmission and protect public health.

images.alt_text: As many as 76 per cent of Chinese travel agencies ranked South-east Asia as the top destination when outbound travel resumed, according to a survey released in December by trade show ITB China.

site_title: Review of ministerial salaries targeted for 2023: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Minister-in-charge of the Public Service Chan Chun Sing announced that the next review of ministerial salaries is targeted for 2023. He assured that more details on the review will be shared in due course. The Committee to Review Ministerial Salaries was formed in 2017 and previously concluded that the salary framework remained relevant and sound. The government had decided not to make changes to salaries during the last review due to the economy being in transition, with the intention to review the matter again after five years or as needed.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh

site_title: Back to the future for container shipping
summary: Container shipping lines face a challenging 2023 due to weak spot rates and a decline in freight rates, according to Xeneta's chief executive officer, Patrik Berglund. Despite a slight increase in long-term ocean freight rates, Berglund warns that the industry is heading for "far worse" in 2023, with spot rates expected to drop significantly. Analysts Drewry predict a deep-seated instinct to preserve volumes and lower rates, leading to a managed decline in capacity, but ultimately, a return to thin returns for shipping lines. The industry's over-capacity and lack of control over the market are major concerns.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Chinese container ship "Cosco Shipping Aries" is unloaded at a loading terminal in the port of Hamburg Germany July 27, 2018. Picture taken July 27,2018. REUTERS/Fabian Bimmer/File Photo
The lessons from all the disruptions since 2020 have underscored how the term “supply chain” itself is something of a misnomer, because it suggests that global trade is seamless and unbreakable.
New guidelines aim to protect seafarers better, in response to a significant rise in cases of crew abandonment.

site_title: US greenhouse gas emissions rose 1.3% in 2022: Rhodium
summary: US greenhouse gas emissions rose 1.3% in 2022, remaining 15.5% below 2005 levels and falling short of the 50-52% reduction goal by 2030. This is despite a decline in carbon intensity due to economic growth outpacing emissions, primarily driven by a drop in power sector emissions. However, building emissions rose 6% due to increased heating demand. The Inflation Reduction Act's implementation could lead to emission reductions in 2023, but more aggressive policies are needed to meet the 2030 target.

site_title: Investing lessons for 2023
summary: The S&P 500 index experienced its worst performance since 2008 in 2022, with a 19.4% decline. However, investing over a long period can yield vastly different results, as those who started investing early in 2022 may still see positive returns. The article emphasizes the importance of considering a time horizon when evaluating investment performance, as it can significantly impact the outcome.

images.alt_text: The outlook for the S&P 500 in Q1-Q3 2023 is expected to be bearish as the US enters a mild recession and corporate earnings see a significant decline.  PHOTO:  EPA-EFE
The Lujiazui financial district of Shanghai. China is a bright spot amid the bleak economic backdrop. Relaxation of zero-Covid policy is likely to take the brake off the economy.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall as US interest rate fears dampen China optimism; STI sinks 1.3%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1.3% to 3,262.91 points on Tuesday, driven by fears of higher US interest rates overshadowing optimism over China's reopening. The decline was partly attributed to profit-taking and risks from the hawkish shift of the Bank of Japan. Key performers included Jardine Cycle & Carriage, which rose 2%, and losers such as Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust, which fell 4.2%. Local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC also finished lower.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
The Straits Times Index (STI) is down 0.1 per cent, or 3.09 points, to 3,302.58 as at 9.01am.

site_title: China Dec new bank loans rise to 1.4 trillion yuan, beat forecasts
summary: China's new bank loans rose to a record 21.31 trillion yuan in 2022, exceeding forecasts. In December, new loans reached 1.4 trillion yuan, beating expectations of a drop to 1.1 trillion yuan. The central bank continues to support the economy, which was hit hard by Covid-19 lockdowns. Analysts predict a "precise and forceful" policy to support the economy in 2023, with liquidity and funding costs to be kept reasonably ample.

site_title: China state media warn of two-way volatility for yuan in 2023
summary: China's state media has warned investors to expect two-way volatility in the yuan's value in 2023, despite its 2.2% strengthening against the dollar this year. The yuan's recent gains are attributed to economic recovery following the lifting of pandemic controls. However, the media cites shrinking current account surplus and yield gap between China and the US as factors that may lead to depreciation pressure on the yuan. Investors are advised to adopt risk neutrality in foreign exchange.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Banknotes of Chinese yuan and U.S. dollar are seen in this illustration picture taken September 29, 2022. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Teneo nears deal to buy British PR firm Tulchan
summary: Teneo, a global public relations and consulting firm backed by CVC Capital Partners, is nearing a deal to acquire British PR firm Tulchan Communications. The acquisition, expected to be announced as early as Tuesday, marks the latest step in consolidation in the PR industry as firms seek a global presence. Tulchan, with about 90 professionals, provides communications advice to blue-chip companies, including Unilever and Marks & Spencer Group. This deal follows Teneo's previous acquisitions, including restructuring businesses from KPMG, and is part of its strategy to expand globally.

images.alt_text: ISS said that as a split-funded purchase, the proposed acquisition also gives the company flexibility to not put too much pressure on any one funding stream.

site_title: No major supply chain disruptions expected from China’s Covid-19 situation: MTI
summary: Singapore is not anticipating major supply chain disruptions due to China's Covid-19 situation, according to Minister of State for Trade and Industry Low Yen Ling. While some localized disruptions may occur in China's production capabilities and supply chains, Singaporean companies have strengthened their business continuity and supply chain resilience plans, mitigating potential disruptions.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh

site_title: Of home prices and affordability
summary: Singapore's private home prices showed an 8.4% rise for the year, down slightly from 2021's 10.6% growth. Despite a 36% decrease in transaction sales volume, prices are 22.5% higher than in 2019 and 35.7% more than in 2017. The slowdown in prices was attributed to government intervention and caution over rising mortgage rates, with prices flattening in the fourth quarter of 2022 after five years of continuous growth.

images.alt_text: Michelle Low
While new HDB homes are priced to ensure they are affordable, some concerns over housing affordability in Singapore persist, possibly for valid reasons.

Data from the Urban Redevelopment Authority showed that just 5,103 private homes were completed in the first nine months of 2022, down from the estimated  pipeline supply of 11,247 private homes in Q4 2021.
Private home price rise slows to 0.2% in Q4 as suburban prices drop; 2022 chalks up increase of 8.4%
The 14 residential projects will supply some 5,300 private homes in Q1 2023, said Huttons senior research director Lee Sze Teck.

site_title: Goldman no longer sees eurozone recession as it lifts outlook
summary: Goldman Sachs has revised its forecast, no longer predicting a eurozone recession due to the economy's resilience at the end of 2022, falling natural gas prices, and China's earlier Covid-19 restrictions. The bank now expects eurozone GDP to increase 0.6% this year, up from a previous forecast of a 0.1% contraction. Goldman predicts the European Central Bank will tighten interest rates significantly in the coming months, with half-point increases expected at the February and March meetings.

site_title: Parasites are in need of conservation, just like any other species
summary: A groundbreaking study found that most parasitic species declined in population over 140 years, with 38% decline per degree Celsius of temperature increase. This contradicts the assumption that a warmer planet would lead to a buggier, more disease-ridden world. Instead, parasites that play key roles in maintaining healthy ecosystems, such as keeping species populations in check and pushing energy up the food web, are in need of conservation. The study's findings, based on 85 species of parasites from 699 fish specimens, highlight the importance of protecting these vital organisms and the ecosystems they inhabit.

images.alt_text: Butterflyfish swimming on a reef, off the coast of Christmas Island, an Australian external territory.  It is not clear if the fish will be able to adapt to the changes brought about by coral bleaching quickly enough, researchers warn.

site_title: Paris makes a bid to steal art spotlight from London
summary: Paris has solidified its position as Europe's premier contemporary art capital, surpassing London in the international art scene. The city's luxury barons, including LVMH chairman Bernard Arnault, have invested heavily in art institutions such as the Fondation Louis Vuitton and Lafayette Anticipations, creating a vibrant art ecosystem. France's government has also prioritized arts funding, allocating over 4 billion euros in 2022. This influx of resources has attracted new galleries and collectors, making Paris a hub for cutting-edge exhibits and fresh talent, with the city's art scene expected to continue growing.

images.alt_text:
Visitors walk past artwork pieces displayed by Mariane Ibrahim gallery as Paris+ par Art Basel international contemporary art fair opens in Paris, France, October 19, 2022. REUTERS/Christian Hartmann

NO RESALES. NO ARCHIVES

A visitor walks past the painting "Nu au Chale Vert" (1921-1922) by artist Henri Matisse as Paris+ par Art Basel international contemporary art fair opens in Paris, France, October 19, 2022. REUTERS/Christian Hartmann

NO RESALES. NO ARCHIVES

site_title: Young, educated American men ‘quiet quit’ jobs most during Covid
summary: Young American men, aged 25-39, led the "quiet quitting" movement during the Covid-19 pandemic, reducing their annual work hours by 16, while men with a bachelor's degree cut back 14 hours. This trend, distinct from layoffs, was driven by workers seeking flexible hours or jobs. US workers, on average, had 11 fewer hours on the job during the pandemic compared to prior years. Men worked more hours than women, who reduced their hours by six.

images.alt_text: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - DECEMBER 16: People walk by Goldman Sachs headquarters in Manhattan on December 16, 2022 in New York City. Goldman Sachs, the global investment bank, has announced that it plans on cutting up to 8% of its employees early next year as world economies and markets continue to struggle with inflation, the war in Ukraine and China's Covid policies among other issues.   Spencer Platt/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by SPENCER PLATT / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: China says Covid wave has peaked in many areas
summary: China reports that Covid-19 infections have peaked in many areas, with officials citing declining cases in Beijing and several provinces. Despite international concerns about the outbreak's severity, China has stopped publishing daily infection tallies and reported fewer than five deaths per day since a policy U-turn in early December. Many funeral homes and hospitals report being overwhelmed, and international health experts predict at least 1 million Covid-related deaths in China this year.

images.alt_text: China was the world’s largest outbound tourism market before the pandemic.

site_title: China sees over 250,000 arrivals on day one of reopening
summary: China welcomed approximately 251,045 inbound passenger trips on its first day of reopening, marking a significant drop from pre-pandemic levels. The country received 325 inbound flights and 396 inbound ships, with Hong Kong and Macau being the top destinations for outbound Chinese residents. The reopening, which ended China's Covid Zero policy, has sparked interest among diaspora travelers but remains challenging due to expensive airfares and limited flight capacity.

site_title: Businesses identify manpower and increased costs as core challenges for 2023
summary: Singapore businesses are facing core challenges in 2023, with manpower and increased costs being the top concerns. Over 96% of surveyed firms reported manpower issues, including rising costs and limited local high-skilled labor. Business costs, such as wages and logistical costs, also pose significant challenges. Despite these challenges, more than half of the firms surveyed are satisfied with Singapore's business climate, and 52% are optimistic about the region's business climate. The businesses are looking to drive transformation through digitalization, innovation, and cost-cutting measures.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan
Similar to the fourth quarter, five out of six indicators remains expansionary.

Fireworks are set off at the New Year countdown at Marina Bay in Singapore. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong exhorted Singaporeans to be bold and to seize opportunities for “even the darkest of clouds have silver linings”.

site_title: Pfizer CEO rules out generic Covid drug Paxlovid for China
summary: Pfizer CEO Albert Bourla stated that talks with China on future pricing for the Covid-19 treatment Paxlovid have broken off due to China's request for a lower price than Pfizer charges for most lower-middle-income countries. Pfizer is in discussions about a price for the branded product, but has an agreement with a Chinese partner to manufacture Paxlovid locally. China's Healthcare Security Administration will not include Paxlovid in its list of covered medicines due to the high price, sparking heated discussions on social media.

images.alt_text: Passengers arriving at Pudong International Airport in Shanghai, China, on Sunday, Jan 8, 2023, the day the country ended its zero-Covid policy.
China received 325 inbound flights and 396 inbound ships on Sunday.

Tang Shunping, 80, receives IV drip treatment at a clinic in a village of Lezhi county after strict measures to curb Covid-19 were removed nationwide, in Ziyang, Sichuan province, China, Dec 29, 2022.

site_title: Hong Kong homebuyer optimism rises as china border reopens
summary: Hong Kong's property market is experiencing a surge in optimism as the border with mainland China reopens, allowing for increased capital flow and economic activity. Transactions in 35 major residential projects rose 31% in the week ending January 1, the highest level in eight months. Analysts predict a recovery in the residential sector, with Morgan Stanley forecasting a 5% increase in property prices for the full year. The border reopening also boosts economic growth expectations, with median estimates of 3.3% growth in 2023.

images.alt_text: Economists are upgrading their forecasts for Hong Kong this year as the city accelerates its reopening with mainland China and the rest of the world.

site_title: Populists ‘down but not out’ after tough 2022
summary: Populism, which sent shockwaves across the world in the 21st century, appears to have reversed its growth trend, with the number of populist leaders at a two-decade low. This reversal is attributed to the removal of Rodrigo Duterte and Gotabaya Rajapaksa from power, resulting in an 800 million decline in the number of people living under populist rule since the pandemic began. Despite this, populism remains prevalent in Europe, particularly in Italy, where Giorgia Meloni's rise to power as prime minister is seen as a success. Economic inequality and the disruptive role of social media and technology may fuel further growth of populism.

images.alt_text: Giorgia Meloni, Italy's new prime minister, speaks during a parliamentary session inside the Chamber of Deputies, the lower house of parliament, ahead of a confidence vote in Rome, Italy, on Tuesday, Oct. 25, 2022. Meloni said her government will make its voice heard strongly in proposing reforms to the European Union, while pledging to respect the bloc’s financial rules and criticizing the strategy of the European Central Bank. Photographer: Alessia Pierdomenico/Bloomberg

site_title: China hits back at South Korea, Japan in first Covid retaliation
summary: China has suspended issuing short-term visas for South Korea and Japan in response to South Korea's Covid testing requirements for Chinese travelers. The suspension, effective January 10, will be adjusted if South Korea removes its "discriminative inbound restrictive measures" targeting China. China has also stopped issuing visas to travelers bound for Japan, marking its first retaliation against Covid-related curbs. The move is expected to impact China's hopes of a recovery in inbound tourism.

images.alt_text: Tang Shunping, 80, receives IV drip treatment at a clinic in a village of Lezhi county after strict measures to curb Covid-19 were removed nationwide, in Ziyang, Sichuan province, China, Dec 29, 2022.
China received 325 inbound flights and 396 inbound ships on Sunday.

Pfizer chief executive Albert Bourla said that talks with China on future pricing for antiviral drug Paxlovid had broken off after China had asked for a lower price than Pfizer is charging for most lower middle income countries.

site_title: Manhattan House up for collective sale with S$280m reserve price
summary: MANHATTAN House, a 99-year-old development in Singapore, has been launched for collective sale by tender with a S$280 million reserve price. The 16-floor building comprises 269 units and sits on a 4,167.7 sq m land plot zoned for commercial use. The site may be rezoned to "residential with commercial at the first storey" and is near several MRT stations and schools. The tender closes on March 8.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
位于牛车水一带的珍珠大厦（People's Park Centre）外观。

Dissenting owners filed their objections to the STB, alleging that Chuan Park’s CSC and marketing agent ERA Realty failed to disclose material facts relating to a higher development baseline for the condominium - which translates into a “deep discount” for the buyers - among other issues.

site_title: The alchemist’s paradox, central bank sovereignty and the fate of crypto
summary: Cryptocurrencies face major and insoluble problems, making it doubtful they'll supplant fiat currencies. Despite their supposed supply constraint, crypto technology is easily replicable, resulting in over 12,000 varieties. The alchemist's paradox highlights the challenge of scaling and maintaining value. The collapse of FTX, with Sam Bankman-Fried's estimated net worth plummeting from $16 billion to zero, also raises concerns about the speculative nature of the crypto craze. Cryptocurrencies fail to meet critical requirements, such as serving as a peg for currency value, making it unlikely they'll replace traditional currencies.

images.alt_text: Mark J Higgins
Those seeking to make blockchain work for the finance world will have a great deal of work to do in 2023 to overcome the fiascos that occurred in the crypto industry in 2022.
Representations of cryptocurrencies including Bitcoin, Dash, Ethereum, Ripple and Litecoin are seen in this illustration picture taken June 2, 2021. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration

site_title: The era of easy money is over; what does that change?
summary: The era of easy money has come to an end as the US Federal Reserve raised interest rates from near zero to 4% in six months to combat inflation, which reached over 9% in the US and 10% in the European region in 2022. This shift has increased the risks of recession and defaults, raised concerns about financial vulnerabilities, and led to a slowdown in the US equity market, which plummeted 25% from its peak, and bond prices, which fell by decades. The rate hikes have also made dollar-denominated sovereign and corporate debt in emerging markets more expensive to repay, and higher costs have created expectations of a rise in default rates, especially among highly indebted companies.

images.alt_text: Chair Powell and his colleagues are on track to extend the Fed’s most aggressive tightening cycle since the 1980s well into 2023.

site_title: World’s biggest chipmaker TSMC misses sales forecasts as demand wanes
summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (TSMC), the world's largest chipmaker, reported its first quarterly revenue miss in two years due to a global slowdown in electronics demand. The company's fourth-quarter revenue rose 43% to NT$625.5 billion, missing analyst forecasts. TSMC's sales were affected by rising interest rates, inflation, and problems at Apple's assembly operations in China. Despite this, the company expects long-term growth in electronics demand and is diversifying its production to reduce reliance on Taiwan. TSMC's shares fell 27% last year.

site_title: Bentley cruises to record sales in 2022 despite China drop
summary: Bentley reported record vehicle sales for 2022, with 15,174 vehicles sold, a 4% increase from 2021. The company's strong demand was driven by growth in every regional market except China, where a 9% drop in sales was caused by coronavirus-related lockdowns. The Bentayga luxury SUV remained the top-selling model, accounting for 42% of vehicle sales. Bentley's average pre-tax sales price increased by nearly 30% to 220,000 euros per car, driven by customisation options. The company expects a slight drop in production in 2023 due to Chinese shutdowns.

images.alt_text: Bentley has risen above all the morass around it by mastering the art of selling over-the-top opulence.

site_title: Asian tourism-focused businesses ready for China rebound as border reopens
summary: China's border reopening has sparked excitement among Asian tourism-focused businesses, with many eager to reconnect with the country's largest economy. Chinese tourists, who were once the world's largest outbound travel market, are expected to return, with Thailand aiming to double its pre-pandemic visitor numbers to 10 million. K-pop groups, including South Korean groups, are also expected to benefit from the reopening, with predicted increases in ticket and merchandise sales. However, some businesses remain cautious due to ongoing travel restrictions and the pandemic's ongoing impact on the mainland.

images.alt_text: Tourists are seen at Myeongdong shopping district in Seoul, South Korea, Jan 9, 2023. The China embassy in South Korea will adjust the policy subject to the lifting of South Korea’s “discriminatory entry restrictions” against China, it said on its official WeChat account.
China received 325 inbound flights and 396 inbound ships on Sunday.

site_title: Global air cargo demand wanes in November as economic headwinds persist: Iata
summary: Global air cargo demand decreased by 13.7% in November 2022 compared to the previous year, with Asia-Pacific carriers being the hardest hit, down 18.6% from the previous year. Economic headwinds, lower trade and manufacturing activity, and disruptions in supply chains contributed to the decline. Latin American carriers saw a 2.8% increase in cargo volumes, while European carriers fell 16.5% year-on-year. Globally, available capacity decreased by 0.1% from the previous year, marking the second year-on-year contraction since April 2022.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu

The top five destinations were Singapore, South Korea, Hong Kong, Japan and Thailand. Flight bookings to Singapore jumped 600 per cent, while bookings to the remaining four destinations soared around 400 per cent.
Since air freight relies on passenger traffic for capacity, it was one of the most volatile logistics links during the pandemic when passenger carriers were grounded.
Carriers are expected to post a collective deficit of US$9.7 billion this year.
Travellers around the world can expect more ticket price pain in coming months because of higher fuel prices added to crippling losses from the past 2 years..
The SAF will be supplied by Neste, produced from used cooking oil and waste animal fats, then blended with refined jet fuel at Exxon Mobil’s facilities in the city-state.

site_title: Tata nears iPhone plant takeover to grow Apple supply role
summary: Tata Group is nearing a deal to take over a major iPhone plant in southern India, giving the country its first homegrown iPhone maker. The deal, expected to be completed by the end of March, would give Tata a majority stake in a joint venture with Taiwan's Wistron. The acquisition could value Wistron's iPhone manufacturing operation in India at over $600 million and would advance India's efforts to create local contenders to challenge China's dominance in electronics.

images.alt_text: Market participants are keenly watching Tata Consultancy Services for signals on the demand outlook for the sector, which is staring at the possibility of a recession in the US and Europe from where it draws a bulk of its revenue.

site_title: Tokyo inflation hits 4% for first time since 1982, spending dips
summary: Tokyo's inflation has reached 4% for the first time since 1982, surpassing the Bank of Japan's 2% target for seven consecutive months. This increase is attributed to rising food and energy prices, with processed food prices up 7.5% from last year. The Tokyo figure is a leading indicator of nationwide inflation, and economists warn that household spending may be cooling due to the inflationary wave. The Bank of Japan is expected to hold its next policy meeting early next week, amid speculation of potential policy shifts.

images.alt_text: Visitors to Japan jumped to nearly 1 million in November, the first full month after the country reopened its borders to individual tourists, according to government data.

site_title: China creates 12.06 million new urban jobs in 2022: state media
summary: China created 12.06 million new urban jobs in 2022, exceeding its annual target despite the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic on economic growth. This achievement is seen as a key support for the economy, with policymakers prioritizing job market stabilization. The jobless rate in November 2022 was 5.7%, while the rate for young people aged 16-24 was 17.1%. China expects its job market to remain stable in 2023, but faces challenges in stabilizing job employment.

images.alt_text: epa10387189 Workers at the production line of an apparel company in Shijiazhuang, Hebei Province, China, 03 January 2023.  EPA-EFE/XINHUA/LIANG ZIDONG CHINA OUT / MANDATORY CREDIT  EDITORIAL USE ONLY

site_title: Crypto startup funding falls to lowest level in almost 2 years
summary: Crypto startup funding plummeted to its lowest level in almost two years in the fourth quarter of 2022, with VC firms investing US$2.3 billion, a 75% drop from the same period the previous year. The collapse of FTX and other setbacks spooked investors, causing generalist VC firms to pull back and smaller crypto-focused funds to be at risk. However, some venture capitalists remain optimistic, expecting investment to pick up over the summer as crypto funds are under obligation to deploy massive capital.

images.alt_text: Those seeking to make blockchain work for the finance world will have a great deal of work to do in 2023 to overcome the fiascos that occurred in the crypto industry in 2022.
The plunge in token prices has scared away many retail investors who had flooded into the market during the early pandemic years, when lockdowns were still in force.

Venture capitalists appear to have an excessively deferential attitude towards the so-called "rock star" founders of crypto firms, regardless of their credentials as business leaders. FTX's Sam Bankman-Fried is a case in point.

site_title: Playing it safe in 2023, but not too safe
summary: Investors entering 2023 face a bleak economic backdrop, but China is a bright spot, expected to be boosted by the relaxation of its zero-Covid policy. To navigate the year, investors should prioritize sequencing their investments, starting with bonds due to high yields. A recession is likely in the US and Europe in the first half, but equity markets may become more attractive once the Fed shifts its focus to supporting growth in the second half.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People walk by office towers in the Lujiazui financial district of Shanghai, China October 17, 2022. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo

site_title: Xi warns China officials to avoid ‘collusion’ with big business
summary: Chinese leader Xi Jinping warned officials against colluding with the business world, emphasizing the government's crackdown on the private sector will remain a concern for investors. Xi urged regulators to prevent officials from acting for personal interests and to forestall any collusion with businesspeople. This comes despite recent easing of regulatory crackdowns on tech giants, as Xi has pledged to ensure "common prosperity" by reining in wealthy special interests.

images.alt_text: Passengers arriving at Pudong International Airport in Shanghai, China, on Sunday, Jan 8, 2023, the day the country ended its zero-Covid policy.

site_title: Hong Kong optimism gets boost from China reopening
summary: Hong Kong's economy is expected to experience a boost in 2023 due to China's reopening, which is expected to offset potential negative impacts from a global slowdown. Principal economist Joyce Cheung stated that while high inflation and tight monetary policies in advanced economies will continue to affect global demand, the revival in the mainland economy will provide some offset. Hong Kong's growth rate is predicted to be between 2-5% in 2023, according to economists, with the city's economy expected to expand from a low base after shrinking 3.2% in 2022.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
Economists are upgrading their forecasts for Hong Kong this year as the city accelerates its reopening with mainland China and the rest of the world.

site_title: Brokers’ take: UOBKH sees potential for higher dividends at Yangzijiang Shipbuilding
summary: UOB Kay Hian upgraded its recommendation on Yangzijiang Shipbuilding to "buy" due to potential for higher dividends and a $400 million order win. Analyst Adrian Loh cited the company's cash hoard and limited funding needs post de-merger as reasons for the upgrade. The target price remains unchanged at S$1.55. The company may announce a higher-than-expected dividend upon its annual results in end-February, and has a potential order from Lepta Shipping valued at $400 million.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Trinity Seatrading’s application, without stating Yangzijiang Shipping’s alleged debt amount, will be heard by Singapore High Court on Jan 20.
Chinese shipyards this year won 45 LNG tanker orders worth an estimated US$9.8 billion, about five times their 2021 order values.
DBS analyst Ho Pei Hwa believes that the market has "overlooked" Yangzijiang Shipbuilding's earnings growth potential and ESG transformation into the clean vessel space.

Two 24,000 TEU (20-foot equivalent unit) containerships under construction in the dry dock at Yangzijiang Shipbuilding's Xinfu Yard. The group has secured its first GTT (Gaztransport & Technigaz) Mark III LNG (liquefied natural gas) carrier order.

site_title: UK jobs market softens again in December: REC
summary: The UK jobs market showed signs of softening in December, with a monthly index of vacancies falling to 53.0, its lowest since February 2021. Starting salaries for permanent staff and pay rates for temporary workers grew at the slowest rate since April 2021. The slowdown in job placements may ease some of the Bank of England's concerns about inflation pressure. Economists expect the UK economy to contract in 2023, but the Bank of England may still raise interest rates next month to combat double-digit inflation.

site_title: Oil bulls bank on China reopening, but several factors may curb commodity’s ascent
summary: Crude oil prices have dipped below pre-Russia-Ukraine war levels, but are expected to rise as China reopens and accounts for a third of global growth this year. OPEC+ has cut output to keep prices high, while a strong recovery in Chinese demand could lead to tighter market conditions and higher prices. However, several factors, including a potential U-turn in China's Covid policy and restrictions on international travel, could dampen the outlook, and inflation remains a concern.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel
Crude has greeted the new year with a chunky decline as lacklustre demand and China’s virus turbulence leave the market plentifully supplied.
Travellers visiting Thailand must show proof of at least two vaccinations, or recovery from the virus since July.
Brent crude futures rose 53 cents, or 0.7 per cent, to US$79.10 a barrel by 0114 GMT on Monday.

site_title: US needs Japan, Netherlands and South Korea on chips deal, envoy says
summary: US Ambassador to Japan Rahm Emanuel stated that the US needs Japan, the Netherlands, and South Korea to agree on a deal restricting semiconductor exports to China. The deal aims to limit China's access to advanced tech, and all parties have a mutual interest in the outcome. Japan and the Netherlands have agreed in principle to join the US in tightening controls, while South Korea is not in discussions with the US regarding participation. The agreement is crucial for the global supply chain and modern economy, according to Emanuel.

images.alt_text: While Taiwan’s assisted local chipmakers in the past with infrastructure construction and other measures, the island is now stepping up its efforts.

site_title: India’s inflation likely remained steady at 5.90% in December: poll
summary: India's inflation likely remained steady at 5.90% in December, according to a poll of 45 economists, holding within the Reserve Bank of India's comfort zone for a second month. This is slightly above the medium-term target of 4% and has been above it for over three years. Core inflation, a measure of persistent price pressures, is expected to remain sticky, and most economists expect the central bank to remain hawkish in the near term.

site_title: Singapore stocks open lower on Tuesday; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks declined 0.1% on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) falling to 3,302.58. Gainers matched losers at 53 each, with top-traded stocks including Yangzijiang Shipbuilding and Singtel. US equities ended mixed overnight, influencing local market sentiment. The three local banks were mixed, with DBS falling 0.1% and UOB and OCBC gaining 0.03% and 0.1% respectively.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Olam Group is planning to lis.t its agribusiness unit Olam Agri as early as H1 2023

site_title: AIA’s Amplify Health acquires AI startup AiDA, plans hiring spree
summary: Amplify Health, a healthtech set up by AIA, has acquired AI startup AiDA Technologies in an all-cash deal. AiDA's machine-learning technologies will help Amplify Health automate underwriting and claims processing, and detect fraud, waste, and abuse. The acquisition is part of Amplify Health's plan to expand its team by hundreds of staff by the end of 2023, with a focus on engineers and data science experts. The deal is seen as a strategic move to tap into AiDA's expertise and expand Amplify Health's presence in the Asia-Pacific region.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
The UK’s National Health Service aims to provide an extra 2,500 “virtual ward beds” to increase hospital capacity, as health services reach a crisis point.

site_title: Brokers’ take: RHB downgrades Suntec Reit to ‘neutral’ as technology sector slows
summary: RHB Research downgraded Suntec Real Estate Investment Trust (Reit) to "neutral" from "buy" due to slowing growth and rising rates in the technology sector. The analyst lowered distribution per unit estimates by 12% and reduced the target price from S$1.70 to S$1.47. While the Reit's valuation remains "inexpensive," the analyst sees limited catalysts ahead, with potential divestments in the near term to lower gearing and interest costs.

images.alt_text: Suntec Reit's gross revenue and net property income rose in Q3 on stronger operational performance.
The manager of Suntec Reit says its stronger operational performance was weighed down by interest rate and exchange rate pressures.

site_title: China has set it sights on cornering another green energy market: hydrogen
summary: China is expanding its presence in the green hydrogen market, with many of the world's electrolyser production coming from the country. Chinese electrolyzers are cheaper, but less efficient than those made in the US and Europe. Despite this, Chinese companies are developing more efficient technologies and expanding their sales overseas. The US and Europe are determined to compete, with the US providing generous subsidies for domestic hydrogen production. The European Union has set a target for green hydrogen production, but has yet to decide which methods will qualify as "green."

images.alt_text: If successful in scaling up the use of green hydrogen, Singapore's maritime, aviation and manufacturing sectors can tap low-carbon hydrogen and decarbonise.
As one of the world's biggest greenhouse-gas emitters, India is betting on green hydrogen to cut its emissions.

site_title: Noma to reinvent Michelin-starred restaurant as new food 'lab'
summary: Copenhagen's three-Michelin-starred restaurant Noma will close in 2025 to reinvent itself as a food laboratory, focusing on pop-ups and innovation. The restaurant, founded by Rene Redzepi in 2003, aims to create a lasting organization dedicated to groundbreaking food work. Noma will still serve guests in Copenhagen for shorter seasons, but the details of its new "Noma 3.0" incarnation are yet to be worked out. The transformation is seen as a strategic move to secure a long-term future for the restaurant.

site_title: Asia: Markets drift as rate worries halt China reopening rally
summary: Asian markets experienced a mixed performance on Tuesday, driven by growing optimism over China's economic reopening and concerns about US interest rates. Despite a strong start to the year, equities were offset by warnings that US rates will continue to rise. China's economic reopening is seen as a positive factor, but the outlook for US monetary policy remains a key concern. Investors are holding their resolve, with Federal Reserve officials indicating rates may exceed 5% before the policy board decides to stop lifting. The release of consumer price index figures this Thursday will play a key role in the Fed's next policy meeting.

site_title: Jefferies profit tumbles as deal slump persists
summary: Jefferies' profit fell 57% in the fiscal fourth quarter due to a persistent deal slump, with investment banking revenue declining 52% to $568.5 million. Revenue from the equities trading business declined 13.7% from the previous year. Despite the decline, the bank's full-year investment-banking revenue was its second-best ever. CEO Richard Handler and president Brian Friedman expressed optimism about the company's future, stating they intend to aggressively deliver to clients and gain market share.

images.alt_text: UBS managed about US$412 billion in assets for wealthy clients in the region as of the third quarter.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Olam, Tan Chong, Sats, Civmec
summary: Olam Group plans to list its agribusiness unit Olam Agri as early as H1 2023, with a primary listing in Singapore and concurrent listing in Saudi Arabia. Tan Chong International expects an unrealised loss of HK$222 million for the financial year ended Dec 31. Sats' shareholders are advised to approve the proposed acquisition of Worldwide Flight Services. Civmec secured a A$330 million contract for Rio Tinto's Western Range Project. Dasin Retail Trust is conducting an independent business review to assess its financial position.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu

site_title: New US speaker McCarthy faces first major test with rules vote
summary: US House Speaker Kevin McCarthy faces his first major test as he seeks to approve a rules package that has sparked alarm over concessions to the Republican right. The 55-page package, which includes measures to investigate the "weaponisation of government" and withdraw funding for income tax enforcement, is expected to pass with only two Republicans opposed. However, McCarthy's deals with far-right lawmakers remain unclear, and critics warn that the package severely curtails the role of the speaker and cedes power to extreme lawmakers.

images.alt_text: Kevin McCarthy gives a speech after finally winning the vote for Speaker of the House on the 15th attempt, at the Capitol, in Washington on Jan. 7, 2023. His slog to his post ended with a remarkably public show of intraparty strife that played out in a history-making overnight session.

Republican Representatives Matt Gaetz (Florida) and Kevin McCarthy (California) confer after the House’s 14th vote to select a speaker, at the Capitol in Washington, late on Friday, Jan 6, 2023. It took 15 rounds of voting for McCarthy to win the Speaker's gavel.

site_title: Waiting times for some Tesla models in China increase after automaker discounts
summary: Tesla's price cuts in China have led to increased demand, with waiting times for certain Model Y versions extending to two to five weeks. The company's decision to cut prices by 6-13.5% is seen as a sign of a potential price war in the market, as demand has faltered. Analysts believe the price cuts are boosting demand, with shares rising 6% after the announcement. However, some buyers who missed out on the additional discount are protesting and seeking compensation, with Tesla stating it has no plan to provide any.

images.alt_text: Posts on Chinese social media showed Tesla owners at different stores and distribution centres voicing their frustration about the cuts, which followed discounts made in October.
For qualified buyers who have a place for home installation, Tesla will provide the wall connector for charging, although the consumer has to pay for the cost of installation.

site_title: UK retailers got Christmas boost even as inflation hit volumes
summary: UK retailers experienced a 6.5% increase in sales in December, driven by food sales growth of 8% and foot traffic rising 15% despite soaring inflation. However, volumes of goods sold fell 1% due to higher prices, marking the ninth consecutive month of decline. Consumers prioritized affordable items like air fryers and winter apparel, while shunning big-ticket purchases. Despite this, retailers remain cautious due to rising living costs, including energy prices and mortgage costs.

images.alt_text: Energy prices had spiked after Moscow launched its invasion of Ukraine last year, pushing UK inflation to a 40-year peak and sparking a cost-of-living crisis.

site_title: Gold prices ease, Powell’s speech in focus
summary: Gold prices dropped 0.2% to $1,868.85 per ounce on Tuesday, as the US dollar strengthened and traders focused on Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's speech for insights into interest rate hikes.
