Elevated interest rates make gold less appealing as an inflation hedge, and a stronger dollar makes bullion more expensive for other currency holders. Powell's speech, which will influence the central bank's rate hike path, is expected to impact gold prices later in the day.

images.alt_text: Higher interest rates dim gold’s allure as an inflation hedge and raise the opportunity cost of holding the non-yielding bullion.

site_title: Japanese internet firm Rakuten selling US$200m bond
summary: Japanese e-commerce giant Rakuten Group is selling $200 million in bonds to shore up cash for its struggling mobile unit and repay debt. The bond, priced later this week, will yield 12% and be rated BB by S&P Global Ratings, with the option to redeem at a make-whole price discounted by 50 basis points. The move comes as Rakuten's mobile business faces pressure from competition and regulatory intervention, with analysts predicting the company may need to sell minority stakes in its profitable businesses to balance its books.

images.alt_text: The layoffs brought back memories of the dot-com bubble at the start of the century and the 2008 financial crisis when tech companies cut jobs in thousands to reduce spending.

site_title: France captain Lloris retires from international football
summary: French football captain Hugo Lloris has announced his retirement from international football at 36, three weeks after France's World Cup final loss to Argentina. Lloris, who made his debut at 21, becomes France's most-capped player during the World Cup with 145 appearances. He cited the desire to give everything and announced his retirement two and a half months before Euro qualifying.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on June 1, 2021 France's goalkeeper Hugo Lloris smiles during a press conference in Nice, on the eve of the friendly match between France and Wales. - French goalkeeper Hugo Lloris, captain of the 2018 world champions and the most capped player in the history of the French football team (145 caps), announced his international retirement in an interview with sports daily L'Equipe, on January 9, 2023. (Photo by FRANCK FIFE / POOL / AFP)
Argentina fans celebrate winning the Fifa World Cup at the Obelisk in Buenos Aires with an image of team captain Lionel Messi.
The players arrived in Buenos Aires to thousands of supporters waiting to greet them, and will begin a tour of the Buenos Aires city centre from Tuesday (Dec 20).

Ronaldo’s first Saudi appearance “will not be in a Al-Nassr jersey” but in a joint Al-Hilal and Al-Nassr team due to face Qatari-owned Paris Saint-Germain, and potentially Lionel Messi, in an exhibition game scheduled for Jan 19.

site_title: Federal Reserve to size up next rate hike with eye on inflation
summary: Federal Reserve policymakers are considering a smaller interest rate hike at their upcoming meeting, citing recent slowing in jobs and wage growth that could signal cooler inflation ahead. Atlanta Fed Bank President Raphael Bostic and San Francisco Fed President Mary Daly expressed willingness to consider a quarter-point rate hike instead of larger jumps. They expect the Fed policy rate to rise to a 5% to 5.25% range to bring inflation to the Fed's 2% target, with Daly warning against "enormous" labour market pain required for faster inflation reduction.

images.alt_text: The US dollar index, which measures the currency against major peers, was last up 0.06 per cent at 104.27 on Thursday.
Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., December 7, 2022.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: UK curbs energy bill support for businesses
summary: The UK government has scaled back its energy bill support for businesses, ending the current scheme in March 2024 and introducing a new discount scheme. The existing scheme, launched in September, has cost over £18 billion, with the government citing unsustainable public finances. The new scheme will provide a discount on energy bills, with more support for energy-intensive sectors, amid falling wholesale energy prices.

site_title: Man United, Liverpool or Spurs may be buyout targets for Qatar Fund
summary: Qatar's investment fund, Qatar Sports Investments (QSI), is reportedly considering buying a stake in or potentially acquiring English Premier League clubs such as Manchester United, Liverpool FC, or Tottenham Hotspur. The move comes after hosting the most expensive World Cup ever, with QSI chairman Nasser Al-Khelaifi holding conversations with Tottenham chairman Daniel Levy. QSI is also exploring investments in other European leagues, following a decade of spending over $200 billion on infrastructure development in Qatar. Any potential deal would further solidify Qatar's strategy of investing in sports assets to boost its profile and invest its vast wealth.

images.alt_text: French goalkeeper Hugo Lloris announced his international retirement in an interview with sports daily L'Equipe, on Jan 9, 2023.

site_title: Historic UK rocket mission ends in failure
summary: A historic UK rocket mission launched from Spaceport Cornwall on January 9, 2023, ended in failure due to an "anomaly" as the Virgin Orbit's LauncherOne rocket neared its goal of entering orbit and discharging nine satellites. The rocket took off from a Boeing 747 aircraft, but failed to reach orbit, causing the satellites to not be deployed. The launch was the first from UK soil, but the failure marks a setback for the UK's space program, which had aimed to join an exclusive club of launch nations.

site_title: AstraZeneca to buy CinCor Pharma for up to US$1.8b
summary: AstraZeneca agreed to buy US biotech CinCor Pharma for up to $1.8 billion, gaining a promising new treatment for hypertension and kidney disease. The deal comes after CinCor's lead therapy, baxdrostat, failed in a mid-stage clinical trial in November. Astra will pay $26 in cash per share plus a $10 non-tradeable payment contingent on regulatory submission. The upfront price is over double CinCor's closing price, with the maximum price about triple. The deal is Astra's first sizable acquisition since the $39 billion takeover of Alexion Pharmaceuticals in 2021.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo for AstraZeneca is seen outside its North America headquarters in Wilmington, Delaware, U.S., March 22, 2021.  REUTERS/Rachel Wisniewski/File Photo

site_title: Crypto and blockchain industries desperately need a win in 2023
summary: The crypto and blockchain industries face significant challenges in 2023, following high-profile failures in 2022, including the collapse of the Terra/Luna stablecoin ecosystem and FTX, the second-largest cryptocurrency exchange. Companies must demonstrate success to regain momentum and build valuable blockchain applications under renewed regulatory scrutiny. Optimists believe these events will shake out bad actors and clear the market of speculative froth, paving the way for the industry to move forward.

images.alt_text: The Federal Reserve, Federal Deposit Insurance and the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency on Tuesday detailed concerns with the volatile asset class.

The Blockchain Association of Singapore said such a blanket ban could instead push people to seek out unregulated offshore firms to lend their tokens to, according to an 11-page feedback that was sent late last month to the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS).

site_title: Ozone layer on track to fully recover within four decades: UN
summary: The ozone layer is on track to recover to 1980 levels by 2066 over the Antarctic, 2045 over the Arctic, and 2040 in the rest of the world, according to the UN's Scientific Assessment Panel of the Montreal Protocol. The recovery is attributed to the phase-out of ozone-depleting chemicals under the 1987 Montreal Protocol, which has also limited global warming. The report highlights the effectiveness of global agreements in addressing environmental issues, setting a precedent for climate action and urging a transition away from fossil fuels to mitigate temperature increase.

images.alt_text: Driving temperatures upward are record emissions of planet-warming greenhouse gases.

site_title: Covid rips through rural China ahead of Lunar New Year migration
summary: Covid-19 is spreading rapidly in rural China ahead of the Lunar New Year migration, where millions are expected to travel, potentially deepening transmission chains. The virus is overwhelming smaller cities and rural areas, where serious illness and death are likely to be more widespread due to the lack of robust medical resources and older age. Doctors are struggling to care for patients, with limited medical supplies and emergency treatment facilities. The National Health Commission has urged local governments to provide Covid antivirals, ventilators, and oxygen, but many areas remain under-resourced.

images.alt_text: A group of Taiwanese travellers checking their flight status in the departure hall of Changi Airport Terminal 3 on Aug 5, 2022.

The Hong Kong government's principal economist Joyce Cheung said the optimism is fuelled by the highly anticipated resumption of trade and travel between Hong Kong and mainland China, which started on Sunday after a three-year border closure, although she cautioned that the city cannot be “immune” to a slowdown in other parts of the world.
Passengers arriving at Pudong International Airport in Shanghai, China, on Sunday, Jan 8, 2023, the day the country ended its zero-Covid policy.

site_title: UK commercial property values drop in 2022, wiping out 2021 gains: data
summary: UK commercial property values dropped 13.3% in 2022, wiping out 2021 gains, according to the CBRE Monthly Index. This decline was driven by rising interest rates and economic uncertainty. In contrast, 2021 saw a 13.8% increase in commercial property values and a 19.9% rise in annual returns. The sharp turnaround marks a reversal from previous years.

site_title: Apple plans to drop Broadcom chip by 2025 to use in-house design
summary: Apple plans to drop its reliance on Broadcom's chip by 2025, shifting to in-house designed components. The move affects Broadcom's revenue, which received nearly $7 billion from Apple last fiscal year. Apple aims to replace Qualcomm's cellular modem with its own component by 2024 or early 2025. The shift will further disrupt the chip industry, which supplies Apple components, and may impact Broadcom's foothold at Apple.

images.alt_text: Foxconn says that production at the major iPhone factory in China has  returned to normal in December.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise on China reopening optimism, tech stocks lead gains
summary: European shares rose 0.9% on Monday, extending a strong start to the year, as China reopened its borders and data showed a moderation in US wage increases, easing fears of aggressive monetary policy tightening. The Stoxx 600 index clocked its best weekly performance in over nine months, with tech stocks leading gains. Investor morale in the eurozone picked up for a third consecutive month, but remained in negative territory due to a challenging economic situation.

images.alt_text: The German share price index DAX graph is pictured at the stock exchange in Frankfurt, Germany, December 23, 2022.    REUTERS/Staff

site_title: Bank regulator weighs new rules as Canada housing risks rise
summary: Canada's banking regulator will review mortgage lending rules to protect the financial system, amid rising housing risks. Home prices fell 11.5% from February's peak in November, with a ninth consecutive month of decline. The regulator will consider debt-to-income constraints and interest-rate stress tests beyond the current minimum-qualifying rate test. Superintendent Peter Routledge questioned the effectiveness of the current stress test, aiming to add more headwinds for the housing market. The review is expected to consider a broader range of debt-serviceability tools to mitigate risks.

images.alt_text: A condo for sale in Montreal last month. Photographer: Christinne Muschi/Bloomberg

site_title: Grab drivers are technically ‘customers’, but not well-placed to bear GST hike
summary: Grab has raised its commission rate for drivers from 20% to 20.18% starting January 1, 2023, to pass on a 1% increase in goods and services tax (GST). Drivers, who are technically "customers" but not GST-registered, are expected to bear the cost. The company has introduced a six-month GST rebate scheme to offset the increase. Critics argue that platforms like Grab could do more to support drivers amid strong cost pressures, while the government is working to instil greater protections for ride-hailing and food delivery workers, including collective representation and Central Provident Fund contributions.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai

site_title: In post-Brexit era, the UK making slow but steady progress on its trade strategies
summary: The UK is making slow but steady progress on its post-Brexit trade strategies, with 71 global trade accords and a focus on bilateral free trade agreements (FTAs) with countries like Australia, Japan, and Singapore. However, businesses remain concerned about the impact of the trade agreement, citing difficulties adapting to new rules and rising import costs. The UK government is also exploring new FTAs with India, Canada, Mexico, and Israel, and is poised to join the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP). Despite these efforts, economists estimate that Brexit has dented economic growth by 4-6%.

images.alt_text: Rishi Sunak did not offer any details, or on how he will end a wave of strikes including by nurses and train drivers that has stoked a sense of national paralysis this winter.
Citi says the survey showed a reduced risk of a recent 41-year high inflation rate becoming entrenched.
The Bank of England plans to sell £40 billion of the gilts it bought under earlier quantitative easing measures, to stimulate the economy.
There is now growing support across the political spectrum, even within Rishi Sunak’s UK government, for a closer economic relationship with the EU.

site_title: Looking beyond China’s Covid Wall
summary: China has lifted its zero-Covid policy, ending nearly 1,000 days of strict border controls and travel restrictions. The sudden move has sparked polarized views, with some citing overcrowded hospitals and others claiming the situation is under control. The World Health Organization questions China's transparency, but experts expect positive economic outcomes as China returns to engage the outside world in trade, tourism, and demand for goods. Growth projections for China are running high, with potential economic benefits for the tourism sector in Southeast Asia and increased inflation.

images.alt_text: People buy street food in a shopping district as China returns to work despite continuing Covid-19 outbreaks in Beijing, China, Jan 3, 2023.

Merck’s Covid-19 antiviral molnupiravir has been granted conditional emergency approval for treating mild and moderate infections among adults at risk of progressing to severe disease, China’s National Medical Products Administration said on Friday (Dec 30).
While nobody knows the true extent of fatalities, it’s clear funeral homes in China major cities are already at capacity – and some experts warn that the worst is yet to come.

site_title: US FAA proposes requiring 5G safeguards on planes by early 2024
summary: The US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has proposed requiring passenger and cargo aircraft in the US to have 5G C-Band-tolerant radio altimeters or install approved filters by early 2024. This is due to concerns that 5G service could interfere with aeroplane altimeters, leading to disruptions at some US airports earlier this year. The proposed airworthiness directive is similar to one that took effect in December 2021 and aims to address aviation safety concerns. Some international airlines have expressed reluctance to install filters without a legal requirement.

site_title: McDonald’s ex-CEO charged with misrepresentation to investors
summary: Former McDonald's CEO Stephen Easterbrook was charged by the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) for making false and misleading statements about his 2019 termination. Easterbrook was fired for poor judgment, but also failed to disclose undisclosed relationships with other employees. He agreed to a five-year ban and a $400,000 civil penalty. McDonald's was also charged with shortcomings in public disclosures but received no fines due to substantial cooperation. Easterbrook returned $105 million of his severance package in 2021 to settle a lawsuit.

site_title: UK, EU agree on data sharing in step towards resolving North Ireland trade row
summary: The UK and EU reached a data sharing agreement, a step towards resolving the Northern Ireland trade row. The agreement is crucial for further talks on the Northern Ireland Protocol, which requires checks on goods coming from the rest of the UK to Northern Ireland. The EU seeks live or semi-live data to determine if checks are necessary, while Britain has sought to reduce barriers. The deal is expected to preserve the peace deal and avoid a hard border between Ireland and Northern Ireland.

images.alt_text: Britain's Foreign Secretary James Cleverly speaks during a joint press conference with his German counterpart following the first UK-Germany Strategic Dialogue meeting at Lancaster House in London on January 5, 2023. (Photo by Kin Cheung / POOL / AFP)

site_title: US: Stocks end mixed as markets ponder ‘soft landing’ odds
summary: US stocks ended mixed on Monday, January 9, as markets considered the possibility of a "soft landing" for the US economy. Despite a strong start, indices lost momentum in the afternoon, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.3% and the S&P 500 slipping 0.1%. The Nasdaq Composite Index advanced 0.6%. This week's inflation data and bank earnings will be closely watched for their impact on US monetary policy. Analysts expect a 4.1% drop in S&P 500 profits for the fourth quarter.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Raindrops hang on a sign for Wall Street outside the New York Stock Exchange in Manhattan in New York City, New York, U.S., October 26, 2020. REUTERS/Mike Segar/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Oil rises over 1% on demand optimism as China reopens borders
summary: Oil prices rose over 1% on Monday, boosted by China's reopening borders and optimism over fuel demand. Brent crude increased to $79.65 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude rose to $74.63 a barrel. The rally comes as China issued second batch of 2023 crude import quotas, raising total imports by 20% from last year. Despite concerns over potential Covid infections, the market structure suggests bearish sentiment.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures rose 53 cents, or 0.7 per cent, to US$79.10 a barrel by 0114 GMT on Monday.

site_title: Olam targets agribusiness IPO in H1 with listings in Singapore, Saudi Arabia
summary: Olam Agri, the agribusiness unit of Olam Group, plans to list on the Singapore and Saudi Arabia stock exchanges as early as H1 2023, making it the first dual-listing on both exchanges. The IPO will result in a primary listing in Singapore and a concurrent listing in Saudi Arabia, with Olam Agri also being demerged from the group through a distribution in specie of shares. The listing aims to raise up to US$1 billion and will allow Olam Agri to access the large incremental investor base in Saudi Arabia, enhancing its activities in the Gulf region.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Olam Group shares jumped as much as 3.4 per cent on Friday, touching their highest intraday level in nearly six months.
“This transaction gives Olam Agri significant financial flexibility while Olam Group continues on its reorganisation pathway,” said Olam Group CFO N Muthukumar.

The facility comprises a 2- and 3-year revolving credit facility as well as a 3-year loan, with its interest margin linked to the achievement of sustainability targets across ESG (environmental, social and governance) areas.

Benefits of being a signatory include access to valuable asset-level information that can be used to assess potential climate risks that may impair returns in the future, according to the Poseidon Principles’ website.
The facility is guaranteed by Olam Group with Olam Agri subsidiaries, Olam Global Agri and Olam Global Agri Treasury, as co-borrowers.
Olam said it expects to deliver a better year-on-year performance for the full year as revised sales pricing and margin recovery gathers pace in H2.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher on China optimism, easing rate hike concerns
summary: US stock markets opened higher on Monday, driven by optimism over China's potential border reopening, easing concerns about interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.10% and the S&P 500 gained 0.40%, while the Nasdaq Composite increased 0.88%. These gains were attributed to signs of a cooling labor market, which boosted bets of a slower pace of interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve.

site_title: More than 7,000 nurses go on strike in New York City
summary: Over 7,000 nurses at Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx and Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan went on strike in New York City due to stalled contract negotiations over pay and staffing levels. The strike caused procedures and appointments to be postponed at Montefiore, but most appointments at Mount Sinai are proceeding as scheduled. The New York State Nurses Association and hospitals have been negotiating for four months, with the union having reached agreements at seven other hospitals.

site_title: Britishvolt in talks on possible majority stake sale
summary: Britishvolt, a UK-based EV battery manufacturing startup, is in talks with a consortium of investors about selling a majority stake in the company. The discussions aim to achieve long-term sustainability and secure necessary funding for battery development and production. Britishvolt had previously received backing from Glencore and government funding, but struggled to secure further investment due to external economic headwinds. The company plans to build a 38 gigawatt-hour plant in Blyth, Northumberland, which has planning permission and local support.

images.alt_text: “Our commitment to a carbon net-zero future includes creation of a smart supply chain to ensure we meet our customers’ desire for EVs,” Stellantis CEO Carlos Tavares said.
SK On is the wholly owned battery unit of SK Innovation and counts Hyundai Motor, Volkswagen and Ford Motor among its customers.
Battery Ventures plans to eventually merge the firms and use the combined platform to consolidate Europe’s fleet-management software space, Morad Elhafed, a Battery general partner, said.

With the notable exception of Sweden’s Northvolt, some European startups hoping to build so-called gigafactories to compete with the Asian behemoths are going for smaller plants, with the aim of attracting more investment further down the line.

site_title: Environmental, social credit risks to rise in 2023, Moody’s says
summary: Moody's predicts environmental, social, and governance (ESG) credit risks will rise in 2023 due to economic and political turbulence caused by the Covid-19 pandemic and Russia's invasion of Ukraine. Policymakers will face trade-offs between supporting vulnerable households and restoring fiscal positions, leading to increased scrutiny of company emission reduction efforts and worker wage demands. Lower-rated issuers, particularly those rated B3 and below, will face higher refinancing risks due to weaker risk management capabilities or leveraged capital structures. This will heighten policy and market risks for companies failing to meet stakeholder expectations.

site_title: Morgan Stanley’s COO Jon Pruzan exits firm
summary: Morgan Stanley's Chief Operating Officer Jon Pruzan is leaving the firm at the end of the month after a 28-year tenure, including a six-year stint as Chief Financial Officer. Pruzan, 54, will depart as the public face of the firm to investors and analysts. He was a trusted adviser to CEO James Gorman and had a seat at the decision-making table. Pruzan plans to pursue other opportunities, according to Gorman.

site_title: Cancer’s growing burden and its investment implications
summary: The global cancer burden is intensifying, with rising diagnoses attributed to factors such as excessive smoking, obesity, and lifestyle habits. Asia has the world's largest share of cancer patients, while geographic variations in cancer types and mortality rates exist across regions. Immunotherapy is emerging as a promising cancer treatment, with significant investment opportunities in the genomics industry. The global immunotherapy market is expected to revolutionize oncology, with the US alone estimated to be worth over $500 billion by 2040, offering a better chance of survival and recovery for many cancer patients.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Signage for GlaxoSmithKline is seen on it's offices in London, Britain, March 30, 2016. REUTERS/Toby Melville/File Photo

MSD’s new investments will inject a “booster shot” for Singapore’s Manufacturing 2030 Vision and support its ambitions to become a leading biopharma manufacturing hub, said Trade and Industry Minister Gan Kim Yong (right).

site_title: Thai PM launches re-election bid
summary: Thai Prime Minister Prayut Chan-o-cha has launched his re-election bid, citing his commitment to the nation, religion, monarchy, and people. He joined the Ruam Thai Sang Chart party and made a vow to fix the kingdom's problems ahead of expected polls in the year. Prayut, who took power in a 2014 coup, will face his old Palang Pracharath Party (PPRP) in the polls, marking the start of months of campaigning.

images.alt_text: Thaksin’s daughter, Paetongtarn Shinawatra, is emerging as one of Pheu Thai’s potential candidates for the premiership and has played a key role in rallying support for the party in recent months.

site_title: UK ambulance strike to go ahead after health talks flop
summary: The UK government's efforts to avert strikes in the health service have failed, with ambulance workers set to strike on Wednesday after talks with the government collapsed. The strikes follow a series of industrial actions, including rail strikes and a major nurses' strike. The government has proposed productivity savings in exchange for pay raises, which union representatives have deemed "an insult." The strikes are exacerbating the UK's economic woes, with inflation above 11% and the country likely to be in recession. Prime Minister Rishi Sunak's government is under pressure to address the crisis ahead of the next election.

images.alt_text: A sign regarding strike action outside Shortlands railway station, closed due to strike action by the National Union of Rail, Maritime and Transport, near Sevenoaks, UK, Jan 6, 2023.

site_title: Dasin Retail Trust conducts independent business review to extend loan maturity dates
summary: Dasin Retail Trust's trustee-manager is conducting an independent business review to assess the financial position of the group and extend loan maturity dates. The review will inform discussions with lenders to extend the loan maturity date from Dec 31, 2022, to Apr 30, 2023. The review aims to validate the group's financial position and provide a basis for loan extension discussions. The trust closed at S$0.26, down 3.7% on the announcement.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan

site_title: Ford to partner LG on Turkey battery plant, drops SK
summary: Ford is partnering LG Energy Solution to build a new battery plant in Turkey, replacing a deal with SK On, as part of its efforts to speed up the shift to clean cars and diversify its battery suppliers. The Turkish plant, expected to open in 2025, will have an annual capacity of 30-45 gigawatt hours. Ford will continue to work with SK On on other projects, including two US factories and a Hungarian plant, aiming to produce 2 million electric vehicles annually by 2026.

images.alt_text: The Tennessee site will include a battery factory and the first all-new assembly plant that Ford has built since 1969.

site_title: India’s Tata Consultancy Q3 profit misses view
summary: Tata Consultancy Services (TCS), India's largest IT exporter, reported a lower-than-expected profit for the third quarter, with consolidated net profit rising to 108.46 billion Indian rupees (S$1.8 billion) from 97.69 billion rupees a year earlier. The company reduced its workforce by 2,197 on a net basis and saw its order book decline to $7.8 billion from $8.1 billion in the previous quarter. This move is seen as a signal that the demand outlook for the sector is weakening due to a possible recession in the US and Europe, where TCS draws a significant portion of its revenue.

site_title: Proxy adviser ISS recommends Sats shareholders approve WFS acquisition
summary: Proxy adviser ISS recommends Sats shareholders approve the acquisition of Worldwide Flight Services (WFS) for S$3.3 billion, citing WFS's expertise, global network, and potential for increased operational efficiencies and cost savings. The deal is considered an effective investment opportunity and is valued at 9.7 times WFS's implied earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortisation (Ebitda) over the last 12 months. The acquisition is expected to provide Sats with a diverse customer base, increased cargo handling capabilities, and sustainable business growth.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
The company’s directors recommended that shareholders vote in favour of the resolution at the EGM as they believed that WFS was the “right asset of scale and reach” for the company to acquire.
Sats' share price fell precipitously after the company said it would acquire WFS, the largest air cargo handling firm in the world
Investors fear Sats will raise funds through a deeply discounted rights issue, and that the purchase of WFS will not boost its profitability as much as it implicitly claims

Sats share price sank after the ground handler and inflight caterer proposed acquisition of the world’s air cargo handler Worldwide Freight Services (WFS) for an enterprise value of about 2.3 billion euros (S$3.3 billion), including assuming WFS’  borrowings of 1 billion euros.

site_title: UK credit card rates reach record in new blow to consumers
summary: UK credit card rates have reached a record high of 30.4% due to inflation eroding pandemic-era savings. Shoppers are taking out new credit cards, spending £1.2 billion in November, driven by holiday spending. This has contributed to a cost of living crisis, with families expected to be £2,100 worse off. Credit card providers have also made their terms less attractive, with rising balance transfer fees and shorter interest-free balance transfer terms. This comes as the UK economy shrinks for the second month, posing a challenge to Prime Minister Starmer.

site_title: US dollar hovers near seven-month lows after jobs data
summary: The US dollar hovered near its seven-month lows against other major currencies after jobs data suggested the Federal Reserve may slow the pace of interest rate hikes. The dollar posted its biggest quarterly loss in 12 years, driven by investors' expectations of a rate hike ceiling at 5%. China's reopening borders boosted riskier currencies, while the US dollar index fell 0.2% to 103.54. Sterling and the euro rose against the dollar, while the Australian and New Zealand dollars rallied sharply, with the yuan reaching its highest in five months.

site_title: Spring clean your investment the right way
summary: Investors can benefit from spring cleaning their investments by adopting a disciplined approach. Dollar-cost averaging, investing a fixed amount regularly, can help harness the power of compounding over the long term. Life-stage investing involves tailoring investment strategies to each stage of life, including early career, mid-career, and retirement. At each stage, risk profiles and investment horizons guide asset allocation. Investors should consider separate portfolios for short-term and long-term goals, and be cautious of lifestyle creep. By adopting a disciplined approach, investors can strengthen their finances and meet their investing goals over the decades.

images.alt_text: Sure, everybody knows that with higher expected returns comes the bigger risk of loss. But time and time again investors put this most basic rule to the test in a kind of bull-market delirium.

site_title: China ‘wolf warrior’ diplomatic spokesperson Zhao moves to new role
summary: Chinese foreign ministry spokesperson Zhao Lijian, known for his "wolf warrior" diplomacy, has been transferred to the Department of Boundary and Ocean Affairs, replacing his role as daily media briefing host. Zhao, who gained a large following on Twitter for his combative posts, is now deputy head of the new department. The move comes as China promotes Qin Gang, its ambassador to Washington, to foreign minister in an effort to stabilize relations with the US. Zhao's new role is seen as a demotion, following his hawkish style and controversies, including a Twitter post blaming the US for bringing the coronavirus to Wuhan.

site_title: Honda’s JV with GAC ends production of Acura brand in China
summary: Honda's joint venture with GAC has ended production of Acura brand in China. The move comes after a sharp decline in Jeep sales in China, with GAC previously closing its joint venture with Stellantis. Acura sold 6,554 vehicles in China in 2021, down 45% from the previous year. GAC will continue to provide after-sales services for Acura customers in China through the joint venture's network. The joint venture will continue to produce other Honda brands.

site_title: Southwest crisis reveals clubby world of airline leaders
summary: Southwest Airlines' recent operational chaos, resulting in 16,700 flight cancellations, has been attributed to an outdated crew scheduling system and a point-to-point route network. The crisis has also highlighted the airline's insular management team, which critics say lacks innovation and technological expertise. With a 51-year history of success, CEO Bob Jordan is committed to getting the company back on track, but analysts warn of reputational damage and potential underperformance. The airline's focus on cost-cutting has led to a conservative approach, making it less willing to adopt new technology, a factor contributing to the crisis.

images.alt_text: The chaos will prove costly to the airline, with Citi analysts estimating it could shave 3 per cent to 5 per cent from Southwest’s fourth-quarter earnings.
More than 2,500 Southwest Airlines flights were cancelled as of Wednesday morning, according to the flight tracking website FlightAware.

site_title: Indonesia workers plan protests over emergency regulation on jobs law
summary: Thousands of Indonesian workers plan to protest against an emergency regulation signed by President Joko Widodo to replace a controversial jobs law. The regulation, which was welcomed by foreign investors for cutting red tape, is seen as hurting labour rights and environmental protection. Workers will urge parliament to reject the regulation, which introduces an "index" to determine minimum wage increases, and restricts job outsourcing to only five sectors. The Labour Party claims the president bypassed proper parliamentary debate, and a judicial review has been lodged. The government has promised to issue technical rules acceptable to both workers and employers.

site_title: Pakistan gets pledges of US$8.57b for flood recovery
summary: Pakistan has received pledges of $8.57 billion in aid for flood recovery, exceeding the initial amount sought. The UN Secretary-General, Antonio Guterres, called for massive investments to help the country rebuild after devastating floods last year, which killed 1,700 people and displaced 8 million. The funding will help Pakistan meet its sovereign debt obligations and pay for imports such as energy and food. Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif called for a "coalition of the willing" to support the country's recovery.

images.alt_text: Markets in major Pakistani cities traditionally remain open late into the night, in most cases up to 11.00 pm, as shoppers usually get out in the evenings.

The landmark international biodiversity framework that came out of COP15 raises the need for businesses and investors to gain a greater understanding of the risks that biodiversity degradation presents to their bottom line and portfolios.

site_title: Vietnam 2022 trade surplus at US$12.4b
summary: Vietnam registered a trade surplus of US$12.4 billion in 2022, driven by a 10.5% increase in exports to US$371.3 billion and a 7.8% rise in imports to US$358.9 billion.

site_title: Rolls-Royce rides ongoing luxury demand to sales record in 2022
summary: Rolls-Royce reported record sales of 6,021 luxury cars in 2022, driven by strong demand in the Americas, particularly the US, which accounted for 35% of sales. The company's sales were offset by a decline in China due to coronavirus-related lockdowns. Despite halting sales in Russia, Rolls-Royce's bespoke approach led to increased, imaginative orders from customers. The company's fully-electric Spectre model has exceeded pre-order expectations, with orders stretching into 2023.

site_title: Scientists chip away at how ancient Roman concrete stood test of time
summary: Scientists have made significant progress in understanding the composition of ancient Roman concrete, a revolutionary building material that has stood the test of time for centuries. The new study reveals that Roman concrete was made from a mixture of lime, volcanic ash, and water, allowing it to harden underwater and enabling the construction of iconic structures like the Pantheon. Researchers believe that replicating this ancient concrete could pave the way for modern, sustainable building practices.

site_title: 85% of companies enrolled in scheme to help them scale up create new businesses, products
summary: Enterprise Singapore's Scale-up SG programme has seen promising results, with 85% of companies creating new businesses or products, and over half expanding into new overseas markets. The programme, which supports high-growth companies, has collectively created 500 PMET jobs since its inception in 2019. Minister for Trade and Industry Gan Kim Yong noted that participants work closely with the agency to accelerate growth through management development, business innovation, and market penetration. The programme will continue to gather feedback and develop new tools to support companies' growth.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan

site_title: SPH Media finds inconsistencies in circulation figures after internal review
summary: SPH Media has found inconsistencies in its circulation data, resulting in a 10-12% discrepancy, or approximately 85,000-95,000 daily average copies. The internal review, initiated in March 2022, uncovered issues such as lapsed subscription contracts, destroyed copies, and double-counting of subscriptions. The Ministry of Communications and Information has asked SPH Media to share its full findings and will conduct its own review to determine if the inconsistencies affect government funding decisions.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan

SPH Reit's portfolio includes its anchor asset, Paragon, along with The Clementi Mall and The Rail Mall. 
It has two more such facilities in Australia.

site_title: A vibrant nightlife scene booms in South Africa’s townships
summary: In South Africa's township of Khayelitsha, a vibrant nightlife scene has emerged, attracting Black professionals with entertainment that resonates with their culture. The scene began in 2007 with a local nightclub, and has since grown to include numerous establishments, including restaurants and sushi bars, along Spine Road. The area has become a hub for evening activity, with luxury cars and revelers parked along the road. Despite concerns about crime, the nightlife has created pockets of safety and community, and some entrepreneurs are making a living by offering unique experiences.

images.alt_text: The fund will work with safari operators in Botswana, Kenya, Namibia, South Africa, Tanzania and Zambia.

site_title: Millions of Chinese travel home as holiday period kicks off
summary: Millions of Chinese people are traveling domestically during the Spring Festival holiday period, with 34.7 million trips made on the first day and 35.4 million on the second day, a 40% increase from the same period in 2022. The increased travel suggests the worst of the latest Covid wave may be over for major cities, boding well for China's economic outlook. Economists have upgraded their forecasts for China's growth following the dismantling of its zero-Covid policy, with Barclays projecting a 4.8% GDP growth rate in 2023.

images.alt_text: People lining up at a government office to renew their passports after China dropped border controls.
Economists are upgrading their forecasts for Hong Kong this year as the city accelerates its reopening with mainland China and the rest of the world.
UOBKH believes China’s reopening would lead to a gain in 2023 sector earnings, mostly in the first half of the year.
A group of Taiwanese travellers checking their flight status in the departure hall of Changi Airport Terminal 3 on Aug 5, 2022.
One of Asia’s most popular travel destinations, Thailand is enjoying an influx of tourists during its first peak season since the removal last year of tight entry restrictions.

site_title: Civmec secures A$330 million iron ore project in Western Australia
summary: Civmec secures a $330 million contract with Rio Tinto for the Western Range Project in Western Australia, a mining project that includes the construction of a new iron ore processing facility. The project will utilize most of Civmec's in-house capabilities and is expected to employ over 400 people. Off-site work will begin immediately, with mobilization to the site set to start in mid-2023. The project is scheduled for completion by June 30, 2025.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
DBS maintained its “buy” recommendation on Civmec as it expects higher margins for the company, albeit with a “more modest outlook on revenue growth”.
Civmec’s assembly and sustainment facility at Henderson in Western Australia.

site_title: Russian crude oil price cap should not significantly impact Singapore: Gan Kim Yong
summary: Singapore's energy and chemicals sector is not expected to be significantly impacted by the G7 price cap on Russian crude oil, according to Minister for Trade and Industry Gan Kim Yong. Russian crude oil accounts for only 2% of Singapore's crude oil imports from 2017 to 2021. The Ministry of Trade and Industry and Monetary Authority of Singapore have issued an advisory on the potential impact of the policy. No direct feedback from companies affected has been received, suggesting minimal disruption to the sector.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan

site_title: China Citic Bank offers Covid shots in HK to woo mainland cash
summary: China Citic Bank International is offering free COVID-19 vaccinations to wealthy customers in Hong Kong who meet a minimum deposit requirement of HK$4 million (S$683,471) for a dual currency credit card. The offer includes a shot of Pfizer-BioNTech's Comirnaty bivalent, as well as perks such as 15% off at the Four Seasons Hotel. The move aims to woo mainland Chinese customers and provide comprehensive wealth management services.

site_title: Avatar on top but M3GAN scares up strong sales in North America
summary: Avatar: The Way of Water maintained its lead at the North American box office, earning an estimated US$45 million in its fourth week. However, horror movie M3GAN surpassed expectations with a US$30.2 million opening weekend, taking second place. The film's strong performance was attributed to young moviegoers seeking thrill on the big screen. Avatar has now earned domestic earnings of US$516.8 million and internationally US$1.19 billion, solidifying its position as the seventh biggest movie in history.

site_title: ‘Hospital-at-home’ startup expands into clinical trials
summary: UK-based "hospital-at-home" startup Huma Therapeutics acquired clinical-trials specialist Alcedis for £20 million, expanding into clinical trials. The technology will remotely monitor trial participants, reducing hospital visits and enabling more frequent data collection. Huma's platform is already used to monitor patients with Covid, diabetes, and cardiovascular disease, and the UK's National Health Service aims to increase hospital capacity by 2,500 "virtual ward beds" due to a crisis in health services.

images.alt_text: Pat Cullen, head of the Royal College of Nursing union, poses with NHS nurses during a strike, due to a dispute with the government over pay, outside St Thomas' Hospital in London.
Rishi Sunak’s response has been to hold the line against what he sees as inflation-busting pay raises.

site_title: Singapore shares start the week higher; STI up 0.9%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.9% to close at 3,305.67 points on Monday, driven by a surge in Asian markets. The top performer was Thai Beverage, which gained 2.9%, while Yangzijiang Shipbuilding fell 1.6%. The market's performance was influenced by China's border reopening ahead of the Chinese New Year, with analysts citing near-term risks of virus waves.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
Asian equities started Monday on the front foot, with Hong Kong up more than two per cent and Shanghai also up.
People lining up at a government office to renew their passports after China dropped border controls.

site_title: Companies face rising pressure to offer ESG retirement options
summary: A new US Department of Labor rule will take effect on January 30, allowing fiduciaries to consider climate change and ESG factors in corporate-sponsored retirement plans. This change comes as employee pressure builds for more climate-friendly options, with companies facing rising pressure to offer ESG retirement options. The rule clarifies Trump-era guidance, which had left unclear whether climate factors could be considered material risks. While some predict significant changes, others believe the system is too large and slow-moving, and that Republican backlash may hinder the adoption of ESG values.

site_title: Some 4,700 potential violations reported, 69 agents investigated on ‘vacant’ BTO flat sales
summary: The Housing & Development Board (HDB) received 4,700 complaints about potential Minimum Occupation Period (MOP) rule violations between 2017 and 2022, with 51 cases investigated involving 69 agents. Disciplinary action was taken against 18 agents, with 10 issued warning letters and six registrations suspended. The government emphasizes the importance of MOP rules, which require owners to live in HDB flats for the full period before selling. HDB conducts regular inspections and uses data analytics to detect potential infringements, with owners facing fines, warnings, or compulsory acquisition of their flats if they breach the rules.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim
HDB flats in southern Singapore on Dec 22, 2022.

The Housing and Development Board noted that median resident employed household income has kept pace with the increase in average selling prices of built-to-order flats in both mature and non-mature estates.
The median waiting time for flats launched in the November 2022 sales exercise is 4.5 years.

site_title: Businesses citing GST hike for ‘unjustified’ price increases may be publicly highlighted: Low Yen Ling
summary: Minister of State for Trade and Industry Low Yen Ling announced that the Committee Against Profiteering will publicly highlight businesses that use the Goods and Services Tax (GST) increase as an excuse for unjustified price increases. The move aims to promote transparency in price communication. Consumers can report instances of GST misrepresentation to the CAP via its online feedback form or hotline. The government encourages businesses to be transparent in their communication on price increases, citing trade associations' efforts to guide their members.

images.alt_text: People wearing face masks queueing to enter Apple Marina Bay Sands from Basement 2 of The Shoppes at Marina Bay Sands on Sept 27, 2020.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Covid-19 measures have kept imported infections and severe cases from China low. Health Minister Ong Ye Kung explained this is why Singapore is not adopting a blanket pre-departure test requirement. The country's unemployment rates dipped slightly in November, holding steady at pre-pandemic levels. Companies eligible for foreign labour flexibility must be aligned with Singapore's economic goals. Businesses using the Goods and Services Tax increase for unjustified price increases may be publicly named. The STI rose 0.9% to close at 3,305.67 points, following a surge on Wall Street.

site_title: Carmaker Stellantis seals batteries material deal with Element 25
summary: Stellantis, the world's third-largest carmaker, has signed a five-year deal with Australian miner Element 25 to secure a supply of manganese sulphite for batteries in its electric vehicles. The agreement, worth 45 kilotons, will begin in 2026 and is part of Stellantis' efforts to create a smart supply chain for EVs. This deal follows previous agreements with other companies to secure raw materials essential for electric vehicles. The partnership also includes an equity investment by Stellantis in Element 25.

site_title: ECB sees real wages declining despite ‘very strong’ nominal growth
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) expects nominal wage growth to be "very strong" over the next few quarters, but real wages are likely to decline due to rapid inflation. Companies are finally adjusting wages, raising concerns that high inflation could be perpetuated if wage-setting becomes more permanent. The ECB attributes the strong labor market and rising national minimum wages to the expected wage growth.

images.alt_text: The European Central Bank (ECB) is pictured prior to a news conference following the meeting of the governing council of the ECB in Frankfurt am Main, western Germany, on December 15, 2022. - Economic prospects in the eurozone are to the downside in the near term, with the war in Ukraine a "significant" risk, European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde said. (Photo by Daniel ROLAND / AFP)

site_title: Swiss central bank projects record loss, will skip annual government payout
summary: The Swiss National Bank (SNB) is skipping its annual payment to the Swiss government and 26 cantons for the second time in its 116-year history due to a projected record loss of 132 billion Swiss francs (S$190.5 billion) in 2022. The loss stems from collapsed valuations of foreign currency holdings and Swiss franc valuations. This will be the second time the SNB has skipped the payment, with the last instance being in 2020. The SNB's interim earnings had suggested this outcome, citing that SNB profits fluctuate widely and distributions cannot be taken for granted.

images.alt_text: Credit Suisse is shoring up its finances as it seeks to put to rest concerns about its financial strength after billions in losses over the past two years, recent client defections and asset outflows.
Central bank data shows that the policy tightening wave is shifting towards Asia and away from Latin America and emerging Europe, where the cycle is nearing its end.

site_title: Thailand U-turns on Covid vaccination rule for visitors
summary: Thailand has rescinded its policy requiring visitors to show proof of Covid-19 vaccination, citing sufficient global immunisation levels. The policy change comes as the country enjoys its first peak season since the removal of tight entry restrictions last year. Health Minister Anutin Charnvirakul stated that the policy was deemed unnecessary due to the high number of vaccinations administered globally.

images.alt_text: UOBKH believes China’s reopening would lead to a gain in 2023 sector earnings, mostly in the first half of the year.
Travellers visiting Thailand must show proof of at least two vaccinations, or recovery from the virus since July.

site_title: Prince Harry and the value of silence
summary: Prince Harry's new memoir has sparked a discussion about the value of silence in relationships. The author, Patti Davis, compares Harry's words to her own experience with her father, who was suffering from Alzheimer's. Harry's brother, Prince William, has also been portrayed in the memoir, with Harry calling him his "arch nemesis." Davis suggests that silence can be beneficial in preserving relationships and allowing for a broader understanding of the truth, rather than relying on publicly shared words.

images.alt_text: A television interview broadcast on ITV of Britain's Prince Harry on Jan 8, 2023, ahead of the publication of his book, 'Spare'.
When Harry and Meghan stepped down from royal duties in 2020, they wanted to break from the royal family, but here they are, talking about it at length.

site_title: Ship refloated after running aground in Suez Canal
summary: A cargo ship, M/V Glory, has been refloated after running aground in Egypt's Suez Canal, briefly disrupting global trade. The 225m-long vessel, which transports unpackaged cargo, got stuck, but was refloated and navigation in the waterway is now returning to normal. The incident caused minor delays for about 20 ships stopped from traveling south through the canal. The Suez Canal Authority confirmed that navigation will resume normally, following the incident that was not immediately clear in cause.

site_title: Tencent-backed WeDoctor plans IPO filing by end of April
summary: WeDoctor, a Tencent-backed healthcare startup, plans to file for an initial public offering (IPO) by the end of April, with a potential listing in either the US or Hong Kong. This marks the company's third attempt at going public, following previous disruptions by regulators. WeDoctor aims to raise funds amid a tech-sector downturn and adjust operations to appease regulators. The company raised $163 million at a post-money valuation of over $7 billion in September. A final decision on the IPO's size has not been made.

site_title: Apac Realty to acquire additional 22% of ERA Vietnam, taking stake to 60%
summary: Apac Realty is acquiring an additional 22% stake in ERA Vietnam, taking its share to 60%, for S$4.9 million, with potential earn-out payments of up to S$10.5 million. The move aims to support ERA Vietnam's growth and increase Apac Realty's revenue and shareholder value. The company has seen significant growth in Vietnam, with salesperson headcount more than doubling and revenue increasing from S$4.4 million to S$70 million. Apac Realty CEO Marcus Chu expects the investment to be a catalyst for ERA Vietnam's continued growth, with plans to expand the ERA brand in Vietnam and beyond.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
Photo by Yen Meng Jiin: Marcus Chu, CEO of Apac Realty (ERA)
Ling anticipates that the latest round of cooling measures may not have a large impact on the two companies overall, given the “strong supply pipeline” of new launches in 2023.

site_title: Eurozone bond yields rebound after hefty falls
summary: Eurozone bond yields rebounded after a 35-bp drop in the previous week, driven by cooler-than-expected inflation data in December. Germany's 10-year yield rose 5 basis points to 2.261% and Italy's 10-year yield increased 8 basis points to 4.293%. Investors remain cautious about inflationary pressures, despite rising industrial production in Germany. The European Central Bank's interest rate decisions will continue to influence bond yields, with US inflation data due out on Thursday.

images.alt_text: Preliminary inflation data from Germany, France and Spain all show that consumer prices have risen at a slower pace in December than November, following an easing in energy price rises.

site_title: Three office floors on Cecil Street up for sale with S$110m asking price
summary: Three office floors at 20 Cecil Street, a 28-storey Grade A office development, are up for sale with an asking price of S$110 million. The strata offices, located on high floors, have a combined gross floor area of 33,648 sq ft. Foreigners and corporates are eligible to purchase, with no additional buyer’s stamp duty and seller’s stamp duty payable.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Major office and retail property landlords need to carefully balance filling up space with anchor tenants on sweet deals, with signing up smaller tenants on better terms.
Income At Raffles at 16 Collyer Quay was sold for about S$1 billion in  late-June 2022 to Singapore-based Bright Ruby Resources group.
The Singapore office market has swung from exuberance to caution in the course of 2022.
The true cost of empty offices

site_title: China says decision to end Covid zero predated mass protests
summary: China says it consulted with public health experts on lifting Covid restrictions before nationwide protests, which prompted the shift in policy. The changes, announced on Dec 7, included relaxing key aspects of the zero-tolerance approach and reopening borders. A timeline published by Xinhua News Agency shows the party central made a major decision on Nov 10, 20 days before the protests began. The move aims to minimize the influence of the protests on top leaders, including President Xi Jinping, and cast them as proactive in optimizing Covid control policies.

images.alt_text: China’s planned changes come after major cities from Beijing to Shanghai and Shenzhen in the past two weeks rapidly wound back policies such as mass testing and broad.

site_title: Tesla offers discount in Singapore on EVs in inventory
summary: Tesla is offering discounts to qualified buyers in Singapore who purchase existing inventory of the Model 3 or Model Y, with a US$5,000 discount for trading in an internal combustion vehicle and another US$5,000 credit for operating costs in Singapore. Additionally, buyers who have home installation can receive a free wall connector for charging, with installation costs paid by the consumer. This move comes after Tesla cut prices in other countries, including China, South Korea, Japan, and Australia.

site_title: Tesla faces protests in China from owners unhappy over price cuts
summary: Tesla faced protests in China from owners unhappy about missing out on another round of price cuts, which reduced the base price of Model Ys by 10% and Model 3s by 14%. Disgruntled owners, including those who signed a list of demands, ransacked facilities and voiced their frustration on social media. The protests follow Tesla's record-breaking deliveries in November and a sharp decline in December. The company's latest price cuts aim to boost sales in China's competitive EV market, but the move has sparked discontent among owners.

images.alt_text: For qualified buyers who have a place for home installation, Tesla will provide the wall connector for charging, although the consumer has to pay for the cost of installation.

site_title: To avoid abuse, foreign worker flexibility is for companies ‘aligned with Singapore’s goals’: Tan See Leng
summary: Singapore's new Manpower for Strategic Economic Priorities (M-SEP) scheme aims to provide foreign labor flexibility to companies aligned with the country's economic goals. The scheme has two conditions: participating in key priorities such as investments, innovation, or internationalization, and committing to hiring and/or training locals. Only about 1,000 firms, or less than 1% of registered businesses, are eligible. The government will monitor the scheme's take-up rate and review it accordingly, with the goal of reducing dependence on low- and mid-skilled foreign workers.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan
CEO of Goldbell Group Arthur Chua with Dr Tan See Leng, Minister for Manpower and Second Minister for Trade and Industry at Goldbell's Benoi Road premise.
More 'targeted approach' taken to help firms with urgent foreign manpower needs: Tan

site_title: German real estate deals down by half in Q4: BNP
summary: Germany's real estate market experienced a 50% decline in Q4 2022 valuations and dealmaking, largely due to soaring interest rates, a weakening economy, and record inflation. Total commercial property investments reached 9.9 billion euros, a 50% decrease from the five-year average. A similar trend is seen in residential real estate, with a 74% collapse in deal volume for the full year. The European Central Bank's rapid interest rate hikes in 2022 brought an end to a decade-long asset price boom.

site_title: Hong Kong stresses pro-crypto stance as industry reels
summary: Hong Kong's financial secretary, Paul Chan, reaffirmed the city's commitment to becoming a regional crypto hub, despite the industry's current turmoil. Chan stated that Hong Kong's robust regulatory framework and prohibition of free-riders make it an attractive destination for crypto businesses. The city plans to issue more licenses for digital asset trading firms and consult on crypto platforms to explore retail participation. This stance contrasts with Singapore, which has been backtracking due to the FTX debacle. Several tech firms are considering moving their headquarters or expanding to Hong Kong.

images.alt_text: Economists are upgrading their forecasts for Hong Kong this year as the city accelerates its reopening with mainland China and the rest of the world.

site_title: Freehold light industrial site along Whampoa River up for sale at S$65m
summary: A three-storey freehold industrial building, GS Building, located along Whampoa River, has been put up for sale at S$65 million via tender. The 18-unit building sits on a 3,426.7 sq m land area and is zoned "Business 1" under the URA Master Plan 2019. Foreign buyers are eligible to purchase without additional buyer stamp duty, and the owner may apply to rezone the plot for residential use. The sale could be a timely opportunity for developers to acquire land for residential development, given the low unsold housing stock.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
The resumption of high-impact events, including the Formula One (F1) race in Singapore, brought throngs of business cum leisure (b-leisure) travellers back to the island.
ParkwayLife Reit continued to expand its healthcare focus in Japan nursing homes through portfolio expansions and acquisitions.

site_title: Taiwan passes its chips act, offers tax credits to chipmakers
summary: Taiwan has passed the Chip Act, offering tax credits of up to 50% to chipmakers for research and development expenses. The incentives aim to keep cutting-edge semiconductor technologies in Taiwan, maintaining the island's technology leadership. The move follows similar efforts by the US, Japan, and other countries to bolster domestic chip supply chains. The new rules will take effect in 2023 and include tax credits for equipment purchases, with a focus on advanced process technologies.

images.alt_text: Taiwan produces the vast majority of the world’s most advanced semiconductors, and its largest companies including Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co have abided by US-imposed export controls.

site_title: Troubling rise in breaches of ethics, professional standards by lawyers: chief justice
summary: Chief Justice Sundaresh Menon of Singapore expressed concern over the rising number of breaches of ethics and professional standards by lawyers, citing a 25% increase in disciplinary tribunals from 2021 to 2022. The tribunals have investigated cases of lawyers failing to meet client care standards, breaching regulations, and disregarding the court process. Menon emphasized the need for lawyers to uphold values of honesty, integrity, and service, and called for a strategy to re-establish the moral centre of the profession. He also highlighted the importance of mentoring and the need to recognize that law is a calling that requires devotion and stamina.

images.alt_text: Resident unemployment was the same as the previous month at 2.8 per cent, according to the latest figures from the Ministry of Manpower.
Private-sector economists are split as to whether there will be further monetary policy tightening moves this year.

site_title: S$1m Carousell scam shows how fraudsters have blitzscaled
summary: A recent scam on the Carousell classifieds platform in Singapore involved at least 1,115 individuals being cheated out of over S$1 million. The scammers, who targeted over 1,000 sellers in just a few weeks, used spoofed websites to trick victims into keying in their banking details. The scammers then transferred funds to Thailand via the PayNow-PromptPay linkage, evading transaction limits. Authorities, including Carousell and the Singapore Police Force, are working to disrupt the scammers, but victims' chances of recovery are slim due to the international nature of the scams.

images.alt_text: Investigations showed that a “significant proportion” of the reports lodged involved unauthorised overseas PayNow transfers.

site_title: Oil nudges higher after China opens borders, lifts fuel demand outlook
summary: Oil prices rose 0.7% to $79.10 a barrel on Monday, driven by China's reopening of borders, which lifted fuel demand expectations. Brent crude futures gained 53 cents, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose 46 cents. The move partly offset concerns of a global recession and follows the largest weekly decline in oil prices since 2016. China's reopening, expected to see 2 billion domestic trips during the Lunar New Year, may buffer the decline in the near term, according to analysts.

site_title: China central bank to support private firms, ease tech crackdown: CCTV
summary: China's central bank, led by Guo Shuqing, plans to support private firms and ease a crackdown on tech companies to shore up the economy. The focus will be on expanding demand, particularly personal consumption, and increasing income for low- and middle-income groups. Financial institutions will treat all types of enterprises fairly, with a focus on credit growth and lower financing costs for businesses. The central bank aims to widen financing channels for private firms and promote the sound development of online platform companies. This move comes as China battles a surge of infections and slows global demand.

images.alt_text: The immediate impact of China's border reopneing is a surge of overseas Chinese returning home, many of whom have not seen family for years.

site_title: AEA(S), TRCL launch mental wellness programmes for migrant domestic workers
summary: The Association of Employment Agencies (Singapore) and TRCL have launched a mental wellness programme, AEA(S) Fun Club, for migrant domestic workers (MDWs) in Singapore. The programme, which began on January 8, features arts and creative activities, including dance therapy workshops and talks on health and self-development, at three venues managed by TRCL. The initiative aims to provide a safe space for MDWs to rest and recharge, and is in response to new legislation requiring employers to provide MDWs with at least one rest day a month.

images.alt_text: art, watercolors, arts and crafts

Rui Xi Yap, 17, from Raffles Institution won the top prize in the Canvas category for this moving painting depicting the strengthening of generational bonds between grandparent and grandchild through the simple exercise of sewing together.

This is the third donation the hotel is making to BT BAF. Board member of TRCL Pius Tan (centre left) and  general manager of Sheraton Towers Singapore Hotel Steven Long (centre right) with BT BAF beneficiaries.

site_title: World Precision Machinery to acquire assets in China for 155m yuan
summary: World Precision Machinery is acquiring a dormant Chinese company, Wanning Yinhu Hot Spring Holiday Hotel, for 155 million yuan (S$30.2 million). The company holds a state-owned land in the Xinlong Hot Spring Tourism Zone of Wanning, Hainan, China, and existing infrastructure, including above-ground buildings and fixtures. The acquisition is expected to be accretive to World Precision's net tangible assets and earnings per share, and will be funded by internally generated cash. The deal is proposed for investment purposes and will not change the company's risk profile.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Chinese tourists will no longer need to quarantine on return home starting Jan 8.
China's restaurants, hotels eye gloomy CNY on virus worries

site_title: UBS sees wealth business boost as China reopens, looks to hire
summary: UBS predicts an increase in its wealth management business in Asia this year due to China's reopening, which is expected to boost the market and create a positive outlook for investors. The bank, which managed $412 billion in assets for wealthy clients in the region as of the third quarter, reported a $237 million profit for its wealth business. Despite a surge in Covid infections in China, the bank's operations remain unaffected, and it is looking to add talent to its team, with Asia-Pacific president Edmund Koh stating, "I'm here to hire."

images.alt_text: UBS Group, Deutsche Bank, and Julius Baer Group are among firms hiring private bankers to serve clients from the world’s fifth-biggest economy, which has an estimated US$14.2 trillion in wealth.

site_title: Singapore’s Covid-19 measures have kept cases from China low; changes to travel volume to be ‘carefully’ calibrated
summary: Singapore's Covid-19 measures have kept imported cases from China low, with only about 5-10% of total infections detected. The country has maintained its border controls, including pre-departure tests for at-risk travelers, to prevent severe cases. Health Minister Ong Ye Kung stated that Singapore is not adopting a blanket pre-departure test requirement due to the low travel volume and the country's low risk of severe illness. Instead, the government will "carefully calibrate" any changes to travel volume with China as the situation evolves, with a focus on protecting the hospital system and preventing the emergence of a more dangerous variant.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
A group of Taiwanese travellers checking their flight status in the departure hall of Changi Airport Terminal 3 on Aug 5, 2022.
Singapore has maintained its prevailing Covid-19 rules for incoming travellers from China.

Travellers in the transit area at Changi Airport. As air travel with China is progressively restored, MOH will take a cautious approach towards increasing seat capacity on planes, taking into account the overall public health assessment.

site_title: Delhi fog delays flights, cold wave closes schools
summary: Delhi faced severe weather conditions on Monday, with heavy fog delaying flights and a cold wave forcing school reopenings to be deferred by a week. The India Meteorological Department warned of dense to very dense fog conditions until Tuesday, affecting air, road, and train traffic. The city recorded a minimum temperature of 5 deg C, 3 deg C below normal for this time of year. Authorities advised flyers to contact their airlines for updates on flights, and people were warned of lung-related health problems and potential power line trips.

site_title: SK On says it is undecided whether to proceed with battery venture with Ford, Koc
summary: SK On, a South Korean electric vehicle battery maker, has not decided whether to proceed with a battery cell venture in Turkey with Ford Motor and Koc Holding. Despite signing a memorandum of understanding in March 2022, discussions have not been completed, and the final decision remains uncertain due to a weak macroeconomic environment.

site_title: Indonesia and Malaysia agree to fight ‘discrimination’ against palm oil
summary: Indonesia and Malaysia, the world's largest palm oil producers, agreed to combat "discrimination" against the commodity after a meeting between Indonesian President Joko Widodo and Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim. The two leaders signed eight memorandums of understanding to address concerns and strengthen cooperation, including the development of green energy and battery industries. The EU plans to phase out palm-oil based fuels by 2030 due to perceived links to deforestation. The agreement aims to deepen cross-border trade and investment, particularly in the development of Indonesia's new capital, Nusantara.

images.alt_text: Located in eastern Borneo — the world’s third-largest island — Nusantara is set to replace sinking and polluted Jakarta as Indonesia’s political centre by late 2024.

site_title: Why concerns over housing affordability linger despite homes being generally affordable
summary: Despite Singapore's generally affordable housing market, concerns over affordability persist. In the first half of 2022, 90% of HDB flat buyers had a mortgage servicing ratio of 25% or lower, and median home prices were four or below the income ratio. However, affordability issues arise from factors such as long home loan tenures, volatile income, and rising life expectancy. Additionally, BTO flats in mature towns are often more expensive, and Singaporeans may face difficulties in accessing landed housing. The government's efforts to keep housing affordable, such as subsidized BTO units and mortgage grants, aim to alleviate these concerns.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee
Private home price rise slows to 0.2% in Q4 as suburban prices drop; 2022 chalks up increase of 8.4%
Analysts expect about 16,000 flats to reach their minimum occupation period in 2023. In comparison, over 30,000 flats reached their minimum occupation period in 2022.

site_title: Philippines launches benchmark-sized global bond offer: term sheet
summary: The Philippines has launched a benchmark-sized US dollar bond offer with tenors of 5.5, 10.5, and 25 years, following its US$2 billion global bond deal in October. The proceeds will be used for budget financing, with the 25-year tranche comprising green or sustainability bonds. Joint lead managers and joint bookrunners include BofA Securities, Deutsche Bank, Goldman Sachs, and others, with initial price guidance set at Treasuries plus 155-195 basis points.

site_title: UK manufacturers say soaring energy costs may trigger job cuts
summary: UK manufacturers are warning of potential job cuts and production reductions due to soaring energy costs, despite the government's extended support. A survey by Make UK found that energy costs are the biggest concern, with nearly two-thirds of employers worried about blackouts. The government's Energy Bill Relief Scheme will be scaled back by around 85% from April, with companies expecting insufficient protection from the measures. This adds to existing challenges such as supply chain disruptions and high borrowing costs, leaving the industry with a bleak outlook.

images.alt_text: Findings by the Resolution Foundation add to a bleak outlook for UK households, who are experiencing one of the worst cost-of-living squeezes in memory, after inflation jumped to double digits and borrowing costs spiked.

site_title: China’s reopening provides upside for Thailand’s healthcare sector: UOBKH
summary: China's reopening is expected to boost Thailand's healthcare sector, with UOB Kay Hian upgrading the sector to "market weight" and predicting gains in 2023 earnings, mostly in the first half. Key beneficiaries include Bangkok Chain Hospital and Chularat Hospital, which will provide Covid-19-related services for Chinese travelers. The sector's top pick is Bangkok Chain Hospital, preferred for its more attractive valuation.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

The research house has downgraded its sector call to “underweight” as it believes higher expenditure from increasing wages and incentive payments from inflationary pressures will put pressure on healthcare companies’ profit margins.

site_title: 40 cellists play in concert supporting BT Budding Artists Fund
summary: A concert of 40 young cellists supported the BT Budding Artists Fund, with all ticket proceeds donated to the cause. The event, organized by Voice of the Cello, featured works by Paganini, Saint-Saens, and a rendition of "Somewhere Over the Rainbow." The fundraiser aims to support young people from financially disadvantaged backgrounds in pursuing their arts and culture dreams.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim

site_title: Like Cosmos signing Pele, says Ronaldo’s new coach
summary: Cristiano Ronaldo's new coach, Rudi Garcia, compared the Portuguese star's signing with Al-Nassr in Saudi Arabia to Pele's arrival with the New York Cosmos in 1975, highlighting the potential for football development and cultural growth in Saudi Arabia. Ronaldo will make his first Saudi appearance in a joint Al-Hilal and Al-Nassr team, set to face Paris Saint-Germain and potentially Lionel Messi in an exhibition game on January 19. The signing comes after Ronaldo's high-profile departure from Manchester United.

images.alt_text: 14 flights of stairs later, this was our view at Lusail Stadium, which will host the World Cup final between France and Argentina on Sunday (Dec 18).
