For Ronaldo to be forced to play out what will surely be the final chapter of his glittering career in the football backwater of Saudi Arabia is a damning indictment of his lacklustre form over the last 18 months.

site_title: Brokers’ take: Maybank downgrades AEM to ‘sell’ as chipmakers cut costs
summary: Maybank downgraded its "hold" call on semiconductor group AEM to "sell" due to widespread cost-cutting measures in the industry, citing a weak outlook from key customer Intel and a looming recession in Europe and the US. Analysts expect AEM's order book to fall in 2023 compared to a robust H1 2022, but remain confident in the company's long-term prospects. The brokerage reduced its price target to S$3.08, down from S$3.43, and lowered earnings estimates by 5%.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
Chandran Nair, ceo of AEM believes that the mid and long-term prospects remains strong for the semiconductor testing company.

site_title: Mercedes expects double-digit growth in India in 2023 despite weak rupee
summary: Mercedes-Benz expects double-digit sales growth in India in 2023 despite a weakening rupee, which could increase car prices. The company plans to launch 10 new cars, mostly costing over 10 million rupees, and has an order backlog of around 6,000 vehicles. Despite global semiconductor shortages, Mercedes expects a normalization of supply in 12-18 months. Managing Director Santosh Iyer attributes the company's confidence in double-digit growth to a "healthy order bank."

images.alt_text: Mercedes is shifting its focus towards higher-margin vehicles to help pay for its shift to EVs.

site_title: UK landlords on mortgage cliff edge as fixed-rate deals near end
summary: UK landlords are facing a "cliff edge" as more than a third of buy-to-let fixed-rate mortgages are set to end in the next two years, exposing them to higher interest rates since 2008. Almost one in six buy-to-let loans are floating deals, causing payments to rise. The number of homes sold with offers from three or more buyers fell to 30.9% in December, the lowest in over two years. Landlords are vulnerable to rising mortgage rates, with interest-only loans feeding through rate changes quickly.

images.alt_text: Most companies surveyed don’t expect the measures due to be announced will be sufficient to protect their profits.

A row of residential properties stand in front of the City of London financial district in London, U.K., on Monday, April 3, 2017. U.K. house prices fell for the first time in almost two years in March, according to the latest report from Nationwide Building Society. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg

site_title: Asia: Markets extend new year rally on Fed hopes
summary: Asian markets extended their rally at the start of the year, driven by hopes that the Federal Reserve will slow its interest rate hikes following a surprise rise in new jobs and a slowdown in wages growth. Hong Kong and Shanghai led the gains, with traders betting on a 25-basis-point rate hike by the Fed at its next meeting. However, policymakers have warned that rates will continue to rise to control decades-high inflation, and a slowdown in eurozone inflation to 9.2% in December provided some optimism.

site_title: Bolsonaro supporters storm seat of power in Brazil
summary: Hundreds of supporters of former Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro stormed the National Congress, presidential palace, and Supreme Court in Brasilia, breaking through police barricades and trashing property. President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva condemned the attack as "fascist" and declared a federal intervention, giving his government special powers to restore law and order. The protesters, who were demanding a review of the "fraudulent election" that narrowly favored Lula, were met with tear gas, riot police, and international condemnation.

images.alt_text: Brazil's new President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva (centre), accompanied by his wife First Lady Rosangela "Janja" da Silva (second from right),  after his inauguration ceremony at the National Congress, in Brasilia, on Jan 1, 2023.
Petrobras will shield consumers from sharp fuel-price swings and increase investments in refining projects to curb fuel imports.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares start Monday’s session 1.45% up
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 1.45% on Monday, driven by a Wall Street rally on hopes the Federal Reserve will slow interest rate hikes. The Hang Seng Index climbed to 21,295.94, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also increased. These gains follow a broader market trend, with global stocks expected to face pressure due to China's slowing GDP growth.

site_title: UK halfway through squeeze that will cut incomes by £2,100: research group
summary: The UK is halfway through a cost-of-living crisis that will leave families £2,100 worse off, according to the Resolution Foundation. The two-year squeeze, triggered by inflation and rising borrowing costs, will reduce disposable incomes by 7%, with mortgage holders expected to be the worst off. The crisis is already taking a toll on families, with over 6 million adults reporting they are going hungry. The only group set to increase their income is the richest 5% of households.

images.alt_text: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak hosted a “recovery forum” of health professionals and officials at Downing Street on Saturday to address issues including improving emergency treatment and speeding up social-care discharge.
A sign regarding strike action outside Shortlands railway station, closed due to strike action by the National Union of Rail, Maritime and Transport, near Sevenoaks, UK, Jan 6, 2023.

site_title: Twitter jumped the shark, now it looks like MySpace
summary: Twitter's financial struggles and recent gimmicks, such as reinstating banned accounts and introducing blue ticks for all, have raised concerns about the platform's long-term viability. The social media site, which posted a US$5 billion revenue in 2021 with a net loss of US$221 million, trails behind rivals like Facebook, Instagram, and TikTok in terms of users, time spent, and engagement. Twitter's financial struggles, including US$1.5 billion in annual interest payments on a US$13 billion debt, may signal a peak in relevance and popularity, similar to the "jumping the shark" moment experienced by MySpace in the 2000s.

images.alt_text: At the peak of the outage, at about 0035 GMT, DownDetector said more than 10,000 people reported problems with the platform.

site_title: Gold prices gain on hopes of smaller US rate hikes
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to a seven-month high, supported by a weaker dollar and hopes of slower US interest rate hikes. The Federal Reserve's pace of rate hikes may be moderating, making gold an inflation hedge less appealing. Spot gold reached US$1,868.89 per ounce, while silver gained 0.6%, and platinum rose 0.5%. The dollar index fell 0.2%, making gold cheaper for overseas buyers. This uptrend is attributed to a moderation in wage gains and a contraction in US services industry activity, indicating possible abating inflation.

images.alt_text: Central bank purchases of bullion have hit a record in the third quarter of last year at almost 400 tons.
Bullion is seen as a hedge against inflation, but rising interest rates tend to weigh on non-yielding gold.

site_title: Righting Europe’s energy wrongs
summary: Europe's energy prices are expected to rise again due to declining demand and increased alternative sources, but governments should allow prices to increase to incentivize energy savings and investment in renewables. The merit-order system, which sets electricity prices based on the most expensive source, has reduced demand and boosted investment in renewables. However, governments' efforts to shield households and businesses from higher costs, such as price caps and subsidies, have removed the incentive to save energy and driven up public debt. The European Commission's push to abolish the merit-order system at the EU level is misguided, as it ignores the role of high energy prices in reducing demand and boosting investment in renewables.

images.alt_text: 3D-printed natural gas pipes are placed on displayed EU and Russian flags in this illustration.

Gas storage across Europe is 84 per cent full, far above the five-year seasonal norm of 70 per cent and Germany is expected to produce near-record wind power, curbing the need for gas to produce electricity.

A lignite-fired power station operated by German energy giant RWE in Neurath, Germany. With now a  pressing national security dimension to the energy transition, further measures are needed, including accelerated investments in renewable energy, to reduce world demand for oil.

site_title: Goldman to cut about 3,200 jobs this week after cost review
summary: Goldman Sachs is set to cut approximately 3,200 jobs, its largest round of layoffs in history, due to slowdowns in various business lines, an expensive consumer-banking foray, and an uncertain outlook for markets and the economy. The cuts, which will affect about a third of the bank's core trading and banking units, are part of a broader cost-cutting effort. The firm's CEO, David Solomon, has acknowledged the need to prepare for a challenging business environment, citing tightening monetary conditions and slowing economic activity.

images.alt_text: Goldman is on track to post about US$48 billion in annual revenue, its second-best performance behind only last year’s record.

site_title: Singapore shares open stronger on Monday amid global rally; STI up 1.5%
summary: Singapore shares rose 1.5% on Monday, driven by a global rally, with the Straits Times Index reaching 3,325. Gainers outnumbered losers 188 to 93, led by gains in banking stocks, including DBS, UOB, and OCBC, which rose 2.4%, 1.3%, and 1.4% respectively. Other active index counters, such as Singapore Airlines and CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust, also increased.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Samudera Shipping has acquired two container vessels with a total capacity of 3,800 twenty-foot-equivalent units (TEUs) for US$66 million.

site_title: Sunak heads for crunch talks with unions as strikes hobble UK
summary: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak is set to hold talks with union leaders amid a wave of strikes that have hobbled the country since the start of the year. The strikes, including rail and ambulance worker walkouts, are over pay demands, with unions seeking immediate improvements. The government is more willing to discuss public-sector wage settlements for 2023-24, but is resisting large pay demands. The talks come as the UK struggles with an economic downturn, with inflation above 11% and a recession looming.

images.alt_text: Ambulance workers take part in a strike, amid a dispute with the government over pay, outside NHS London Ambulance Service in London, Britain December 21, 2022. REUTERS/Henry Nicholls

UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak hosted a “recovery forum” of health professionals and officials at Downing Street on Saturday to address issues including improving emergency treatment and speeding up social-care discharge.

site_title: Philippines plans to import 22,000 tons of onions after price surge
summary: The Philippines plans to import 22,000 tons of onions to boost domestic supply amid a 14-year high inflation rate, driven by the surge in onion prices. The import proposal, recommended to President Ferdinand Marcos Jr, aims to pull down prices and provide a temporary solution. Red onions were selling for up to 650 pesos a kilogram, about three times the price of chicken and 25% costlier than beef. The imports are expected to arrive in February and will be distributed to main islands Luzon, Visayas, and Mindanao.

images.alt_text: A worker of a retail chain pushes a trolley loaded with onion bags at Manchar village in Pune, India, November 11, 2019. Picture taken November 11, 2019. REUTERS/Rajendra Jadhav

site_title: Oiltek reports fire at customer’s refinery plant in Malaysia
summary: Oiltek International reported a fire at a customer's refinery plant in Malaysia on January 6, causing damage to part of the equipment supplied by the company. Fortunately, there were no casualties or injuries. The incident was limited to one new refinery plant building and is not expected to impact Oiltek's ongoing projects. The company will assess the potential financial impact on its results for the financial year ending December 31, 2023.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

site_title: When Trumpists run amok on Capitol Hill
summary: US House Speaker Kevin McCarthy was elected after 15 roll-call votes and four days of negotiations, but the process exposed a divided and dysfunctional Republican Party. The chaotic standoff was orchestrated by hard-right Republicans, including Donald Trump supporters, who sought to block McCarthy's bid for House Speaker. The group, fueled by personal grudges and a desire to promote Trumpist agenda, nearly caused the House to grind to a halt, delaying the swearing-in of new members and hindering the legislative process. The outcome benefits Trump, highlighting the party's dependence on his electoral base and threatening potential Republican presidential candidate viability.

images.alt_text: Kevin McCarthy agreed to major concessions to secure a role that is second in line to the Oval Office behind Democratic Vice-President Kamala Harris, including a rule that means that any of the 435 members of the House could force a vote for his removal at any time.
“We’ve got some progress going on. We’ve got members talking. I think we’ve got a little movement, so we’ll see,” House Republican Leader Kevin McCarthy told reporters.

site_title: Global central banks aren’t declaring victory over inflation yet
summary: Global central banks continue to hike interest rates to combat inflation, with the Federal Reserve and European Central Bank expected to extend their most aggressive tightening cycle since the 1980s. The Fed's benchmark rate is forecast to peak at 5.1% in 2023 and end the year at 5%, while the ECB's deposit rate is expected to rise to 2.25% by the end of 2023. Other central banks, including the Bank of Japan, Bank of England, Bank of Canada, People's Bank of China, Reserve Bank of India, Central Bank of Brazil, Bank of Russia, and South African Reserve Bank, also plan to raise rates, with some expected to pause or cut rates later in the year.

images.alt_text: Chair Powell and his colleagues are on track to extend the Fed’s most aggressive tightening cycle since the 1980s well into 2023.

site_title: Asia ex-Japan ESG funds return -20.1% in 2022, lagging broader market
summary: ESG funds in Asia excluding Japan suffered a 20.1% loss in 2022, underperforming non-ESG funds by 6.5%. The underperformance was driven by macroeconomic headwinds such as a looming global recession, inflation, and rising interest rates. Despite this, some market watchers expect ESG funds to outperform non-ESG funds over the long term, citing improvements in regulations and disclosure, as well as the long-term nature of ESG investors.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
BNP’s asset management unit said it is aware that its “approach differs” from other investment firms operating under EU rules.
Since the Sustainable Finance Disclosure Regulation was enforced in March 2021, the EU Commission has clarified that Article 9 funds must be reserved for 100 per cent sustainable investments.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, Samudera, World Precision, Oiltek
summary: Samudera Shipping acquired two container vessels with a total capacity of 3,800 TEUs for US$66 million. Meanwhile, Yangzijiang Shipbuilding faces a potential winding up of its subsidiary, Yangzijiang Shipping, due to a debt dispute. World Precision Machinery proposed a full acquisition of a company for 155 million yuan (S$30.2 million) and Oiltek International reported a fire incident at a refinery plant in Malaysia. These developments may impact trading of the respective companies' securities.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting

site_title: Investors can no longer ignore the shift to protect biodiversity
summary: Investors must prioritize biodiversity protection as a critical component of sustainable growth, as the world's natural capital has declined by nearly 40% since 1992, while capital goods have doubled. The COP15 biodiversity summit has set groundbreaking targets to restore degraded ecosystems, protect natural areas, and reduce pollution. Investors must gain a greater understanding of biodiversity risks and invest in companies developing advanced environmental technology and services, potentially worth $4.5 trillion by 2030.

images.alt_text: An estimated 63 per cent of Asia Pacific's GDP, US$19 trillion, is at risk from nature loss.

People stop and have their picture taken at the COP15 logo during the United the Nations Biodiversity Conference (COP15) at the Palais des congrès de Montréal in Montreal, Quebec, Canada, on December 16, 2022. - Montreal is expected to have at least 10cm (4 inches) of snow throughout the day. site_title: BT Mark to Market: What does 2023 hold for markets? (Ep 27)
summary: Senior Correspondent Ben Paul discusses market trends and corporate issues in Singapore, focusing on opportunities and risks for investors in 2023. Key points include: the cumulative impact of higher interest rates, tech companies coping with a "recession" after over-investment, and the hunt for tech companies capable of disrupting the status quo. The Singapore market outperformed in 2022 but faces risks in 2023, with investors expected to experience more volatility.

site_title: Prince Harry says UK royals got into bed with tabloid press ‘devil’
summary: Prince Harry accused British royals of collaborating with the tabloid press to damage his reputation and that of his wife Meghan. In a televised interview, he stated that certain family members have "decided to get in bed with the devil" to rehabilitate their image at the expense of others. Harry, who has written about his rifts with the royal family in his upcoming memoir, "Spare", said he fled the UK in 2020 fearing for his family's safety and no longer recognizes his father or brother, Prince William.

King Charles paid tribute to charities providing support during the nation's cost-of-living crisis in his broadcast, which included footage of staff at food banks, as well as hospital staff and rescue and care workers.

A poster advertising the forthcoming publication of the book 'Spare' by Britain's Prince Harry, Duke of Sussex, is pictured in the window of a book store in London on January 6, 2023. - Prince Harry's autobiography "Spare" is not due out until next week but it dominated headlines on Thursday after a Spanish-language version of the memoir mistakenly went on sale. site_title: Alibaba plans logistics hub at Istanbul Airport, data centre near Ankara
summary: Alibaba plans to invest over $1 billion in Turkey, with a logistics hub at Istanbul Airport and a data centre near Ankara. The move aims to leverage Turkey's production capacity to support e-commerce and supply chains in Europe and the Middle East. Alibaba-backed e-commerce platform Trendyol, Turkey's largest startup, may consider going public, with management planning a potential IPO within 3-5 years. The company's president, Michael Evans, urged Turkey to improve e-commerce regulations for fair competition.

images.alt_text: Alibaba, which runs China’s largest online marketplaces Tmall and Taobao and owns a wide range of businesses from logistics to cloud services, reported net loss attributable to shareholders of 20.56 billion yuan in the quarter.

site_title: California storm leaves over 560,000 homes without power, more rough weather ahead
summary: A severe storm in California has left over 560,000 homes without power, with at least six deaths reported since New Year's weekend. Torrential downpours and damaging winds caused widespread damage. Forecasters warn of another "atmospheric river" of rain and mountain snow expected on Monday, which could bring record-high river levels and flooding.

site_title: Tech at CES shows how farmers can save time, money and the environment
summary: At CES 2023, tech companies showcased innovative tools to help farmers save time, money, and the environment. Startups such as Brad and AimbeLab developed sensors to monitor temperature, moisture, and grain levels in fields, while Meropy's agricultural scouting robot can detect weeds and pests. Simple Labs created a sensor to measure wine quality, and John Deere showcased a tractor with cameras and fast processors to detect weeds and spray only needed areas. These technologies aim to improve decision-making and reduce inputs, such as pesticides, while also addressing labor shortages and food waste in the supply chain.

images.alt_text: NeoPlants, a Paris-based startup, shows off a bioengineered plant capable of purifying indoor air of toxic pollutants.
The bHaptics haptic gloves and vest replicates the feeling of action playing out in virtual worlds, while matching haptic gloves add a feeling of touch.

site_title: UK has ‘laser’ focus on supporting tech firms expanding into South-east Asia
summary: The UK has increased its presence in South-east Asia, with 5,700 British companies active in Singapore, up from 4,500 in 2019. British High Commissioner Kara Owen notes that 70% of UK services exported to Singapore are delivered digitally, a significant aspect of their trade. The UK is also in talks with India for a free trade agreement, aiming to double bilateral trade to $100 billion by 2030. Negotiations for the UK's accession to the Comprehensive and Progressive Trans-Pacific Partnership are also nearing completion.

banner, great britain, british

Sunak listed his five promises: halving inflation, growing the economy, reducing debt, cutting National Health Service waiting lists and stopping the small boats that carry illegal migrants across the English Channel from France.

site_title: The one true secret to successful investing
summary: The article emphasizes the importance of understanding the risk/return trade-off in investing. The author, Allison Schrager, states that there is no free lunch in finance, and investors must be aware of the potential for loss when taking on higher returns. She notes that investors often ignore this fundamental rule, leading to financial scams and market downturns. To succeed, investors should balance risk and return, focusing on low-risk investments and avoiding those that promise unusually high returns with no risk. Schrager advises investors to prioritize risk management and retirement planning over trying to beat the market.

images.alt_text: Declines on Wall Street were especially painful for long-only stock investing firms last year.
Poker begins when you think about what the other guy thinks about your cards.

site_title: The problem with being too easy-going
summary: Research suggests that failing to express personal preferences in everyday situations can make individuals seem less likable and human. Studies found that people who don't express preferences in innocuous contexts, such as food and music, are viewed as "dehumanised" or seen as robotic. This can harm perceptions of work quality and hurt hiring prospects, particularly in creative industries. Expressing preferences can lead to better team morale and professional reputations, and inexpensive solutions such as surveys and team building exercises can encourage open communication. Companies can also model openness by sharing employees' hobbies and tastes, and job applicants can highlight their preferences on resumes.

images.alt_text: Driven by the belief that alternative working areas stimulate creativity, the unconventional office trend is rising.

Flexibility is a high priority for Gen Z, who are increasingly choosing their next job based on the ability to work from anywhere. GenZers also have  less patience than previous generations for inefficiency and hierarchy. Teams are flatter and the job of managers is to support and empower, rather than delegate and control.

“A focus on employee experience has gained traction in the tightest labour market in a generation,” said Caitlin Duffy, research director at consulting firm Gartner. “If you don’t deliver great EX, you risk losing out.”

Companies that tested a four-day work week registered gains in revenue and employee productivity, as well as drops in absenteeism and turnover. Workers on a four-day schedule also were more inclined to work from the office than home.

site_title: Hong Kong’s reopening is likely to push GDP growth above Singapore’s
summary: Hong Kong's economy is expected to grow above Singapore's this year, with economists upgrading their forecasts due to the city's reopening with mainland China and the rest of the world. The median estimate for Hong Kong's GDP growth is 3.3%, higher than the 2.7% forecast for Singapore. Hong Kong's reopening is seen as a boost for businesses, particularly those in the tourism and finance sectors, but the city still faces challenges including a struggling property market and global headwinds.

images.alt_text: Shoppers at a stall in Hong Kong.Photographer: Lam Yik/Bloomberg

site_title: The rise – and huge potential – of China Reits
summary: China's Real Estate Investment Trusts (C-Reits) market has grown exponentially since 2021, raising over $15 billion in capital, with 24 infrastructure and rental housing Reits listed as of December 2022. The market's growth is driven by the government's efforts to support the property sector and provide new funding sources for infrastructure developments. C-Reits focus on infrastructure assets, such as toll roads and logistics parks, and affordable rental housing, offering a potential exit strategy for private investors. The market's potential is enormous, with UBS predicting it could reach $3 trillion in market capitalization by 2030, surpassing the US REIT market.

images.alt_text: The resumption of high-impact events, including the Formula One (F1) race in Singapore, brought throngs of business cum leisure (b-leisure) travellers back to the island.
CDL Hospitality Trusts, whose portfolio includes W Singapore at Sentosa Cove, was the top performing S-Reit in 2022.
ESR Group says its proprosed spin-off and listing comes in line with a pilot programme launched by China’s National Development and Reform Commission and the China Securities Regulatory Commission.
Tenant sales in at 313@Somerset exceeds pre-Covid levels in Q3.
Beijing has progressively stepped up support for the property sector that accounts for a quarter of the world’s second-biggest economy.

site_title: Virgin Orbit says way clear for first UK space launch
summary: Virgin Orbit has cleared the way for its first UK space launch, set to take place on Monday, January 9, from Spaceport Cornwall in Newquay, England. The launch, featuring a modified Boeing 747 jetliner with a rocket under its wing, is expected to occur between 9:40 pm and 11:00 pm. After earlier delays, Virgin Orbit's CEO Dan Hart confirmed that final preparations are proceeding as planned, with the launch focused on the beginning of the window.

images.alt_text: The 'Cosmic Girl' Boeing 747 launch aircraft. Photographer: James Beck/Bloomberg

site_title: Farcical US speaker vote may be precursor to new era of civil unrest
summary: US Speaker Kevin McCarthy was elected after 15 attempts in a protracted struggle, with far-right rebels led by Matt Gaetz gaining significant power. McCarthy made concessions to appease the rebels, including allowing a single legislator to put his dismissal to a vote. The election's aftermath raises concerns about civil unrest and the potential for more conflicts, particularly in the upcoming debt ceiling debate. McCarthy's authority is fragile, and his acceptance speech echoed the Freedom Caucus's concerns about "woke indoctrination" and border security. The far-right's actions may lead to a lasting schism in the Republican Party or trigger economic destruction.

images.alt_text: Republican Representatives Matt Gaetz (Florida) and Kevin McCarthy (California) confer after the House’s 14th vote to select a speaker, at the Capitol in Washington, late on Friday, Jan 6, 2023. It took 15 rounds of voting for McCarthy to win the Speaker's gavel.

The federal government spends far more money each year than it receives in revenues, producing a budget deficit that is projected to average in excess of US$1 trillion a year for the next decade. Those deficits will add to a national debt that topped US$31 trillion last year.

Kevin McCarthy agreed to major concessions to secure a role that is second in line to the Oval Office behind Democratic Vice-President Kamala Harris, including a rule that means that any of the 435 members of the House could force a vote for his removal at any time.

site_title: SGD to strengthen, USD expected to peak against most currencies in 2023
summary: The Singapore dollar (SGD) is expected to strengthen further in 2023 as the US dollar (USD) peaks, according to analysts. Despite a difficult 2022, the SGD is not expected to outpace regional and global peers with the same degree of success. Analysts predict a correction in the USD index, leading to a decrease in volatility and allowing the SGD to appreciate. The SGD-SGD exchange rate is expected to reach 1.32 by the end of 2023, according to HSBC.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
The US dollar index, which measures the currency against major peers, was last up 0.06 per cent at 104.27 on Thursday.
Against a basket of currencies, the US dollar index rose 0.3 per cent to 105.45, having briefly touched a four-week peak of 105.52.

site_title: Financing for Chinese real estate firms jumps 33% in December
summary: Chinese real estate firms raised 101.8 billion yuan (S$19.9 billion) in December, a 33.4% year-over-year increase, driven by state support and measures to bolster liquidity. This follows a 38% decrease in 2022. The central bank has proposed lowering or abolishing mortgage rates for first-time home buyers in cities with declining home prices. The sector, accounting for a quarter of China's economy, was hit hard last year due to unfinished projects and lockdowns. Relaxing borrowing restrictions is also planned to ease the sector's cash crunch.

site_title: Ant Group says no plan for IPO, focusing on business optimisation
summary: China's fintech giant Ant Group has no plan to initiate an initial public offering (IPO), focusing instead on business rectification and optimization. The company's founder, Jack Ma, has ceded most of his voting rights after a series of shareholding adjustments. Ant Group is nearing completion of its two-year regulatory-driven restructuring, with Chinese authorities poised to impose a fine of over $1 billion. The company's US$37 billion IPO, cancelled in 2020, led to a forced restructuring and speculation about Ma's potential ceding of control.

site_title: S&P 500 to remain under pressure in Q1-Q3, followed by mild recovery in Q4
summary: The S&P 500 is expected to remain under pressure in Q1-Q3 2023 due to a mild US recession and declining corporate earnings. The Fed is likely to keep interest rates high to combat inflation, making rate cuts unlikely in 2023. However, a mild market recovery is anticipated in Q4 as the Fed may adopt a more dovish stance, potentially pushing the S&P 500 to around 3,900-4,000 levels by year-end.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finishes up 2.1 per cent at 33,630.61, a gain of about 700 points.

site_title: US dollar tumbles after jobs report, service sector contraction
summary: The US dollar fell 1.17% to 103.88 against a basket of currencies after a jobs report showed a strong but not blockbuster employment picture in December, with 223,000 jobs added. The services industry contracted for the first time in over 2.5 years, with the non-manufacturing PMI dropping to 49.6. This led to a decrease in wages growth and a slight increase in the unemployment rate. The US dollar's decline was also influenced by a separate report showing factory orders dropped 1.8% in November.

images.alt_text: From a top-down perspective, analysts say things are generally seen as changing for the better in 2023 for most EM currencies after a difficult year in 2022.

site_title: 'Once in a century' flood cuts off communities in north-western Australia
summary: A severe "once in a century" flood event has hit north-western Australia, particularly the Kimberley region, due to heavy rain from the former tropical cyclone Ellie. The town of Fitzroy Crossing, with 1,300 residents, has been severely affected, with flooded roads requiring airlifted supplies. Over 233 people have been evacuated, and the Australian Defence Force is assisting with relief efforts. The floodwaters have stretched for 50 kilometers, and the recovery effort is expected to take months, with Prime Minister Anthony Albanese pledging federal assistance.

images.alt_text: Delegates at COP27 in Egypt’s Sharm El-Sheikh reached a last-minute agreement to create a loss-and-damage fund to help developing countries impacted by climate change.

site_title: Japan’s Kishida set to talk military buildup, chips on G7 tour
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida is set to meet leaders of the US, Britain, France, Italy, and Canada during a tour of Western partners, amid Japan's largest military buildup since World War II. Kishida will discuss economic security, semiconductors, and the war in Ukraine, as well as steps to counter China's growing power. He aims to reaffirm Japan's commitment to a free and open Indo-Pacific, and is expected to sign a deal with Britain to allow joint military visits. The talks will also focus on Japan's plans to arm itself with missiles and limit China's access to advanced semiconductors.

site_title: ‘Not a given’ UK inflation will slow this year, Sunak says
summary: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak said it's "not a given" that inflation will slow this year, despite economic forecasts indicating a slowdown. Sunak emphasized the need for continued wage restraint to curb inflation, which surged above 11% last year due to Russia's war in Ukraine. The UK is facing a cost-of-living crisis, with widespread disruptions in the NHS, including a nurses' strike, and growing wait lists for treatment. Sunak is under pressure to address the issues and fix the health service, which is a key concern for his Conservative Party ahead of a general election next year.

images.alt_text: Ambulance workers take part in a strike, amid a dispute with the government over pay, outside NHS London Ambulance Service in London, Britain December 21, 2022. REUTERS/Henry Nicholls

site_title: Theresa May tops list of UK MPs’ earnings from side hustles
summary: Former UK Prime Minister Theresa May earned over £2.5 million from outside engagements since the last general election, the most of any UK MP. This includes a £107,600 payment for a speech in Saudi Arabia, a country she banned officials from visiting. The majority of the £17.1 million extra earned by MPs went to just 20 MPs, with 17 from the Conservative party. The figures were compiled by Sky News based on regulatory filings by MPs.

images.alt_text: A handout photograph released by the UK Parliament shows Britain's Conservative MP Theresa May speaking during Britain's Prime Minister Rishi Sunak statement on illegal immigration at the House of Commons, in London, on December 13, 2022. - UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak on announced on December 13, 2022 a new deal with Albania to stem the flow of migrants from the country crossing the Channel from mainland Europe. "I can announce a new agreement with Albania and a new approach," Sunak told parliament. A third of all those arriving in the UK on small boats this year -- almost 13,000 -- have been Albanian, and Sunak said that under his plan, such people would be immediately sent back to Albania. site_title: Abu Dhabi’s StanChart interest showcases global ambitions
summary: First Abu Dhabi Bank (FAB) explored a bid for Standard Chartered but is no longer considering an offer. The deal would have catapulted FAB into an emerging markets banking giant with over $1 trillion in assets, surpassing HSBC Holdings. FAB's interest showcases Abu Dhabi's global ambitions, driven by the emirate's sovereign wealth and wealthy oil-rich nations. The bank's CEO, Hana Al Rostamani, has led a management overhaul and is focused on inorganic expansion, but a deal would have been complicated and ambitious given the size difference between the two banks.

images.alt_text: While First Abu Dhabi Bank said it is no longer evaluating a possible offer, the news sent shares in Standard Chartered higher as investors weighed the prospects of any deal.

site_title: CapitaLand India Trust CEO bullish on growth opportunities amid global jitters
summary: CapitaLand India Trust CEO Sanjeev Dasgupta is optimistic about India's growth trajectory despite global market uncertainty. The trust signed two deals in December 2022 to expand its data centre footprint in India, and Dasgupta believes the data centre market is poised for takeoff due to increased use of data by mobile phone users and strong cloud adoption by Indian companies. Dasgupta expects data centres to account for 15% of Clint's portfolio in the next five years, with business parks making up 75% and logistics and industrial assets 10%.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
Even without acquisition growth, Singapore-listed Reits merit serious consideration if organic growth drivers deliver.
The last time there were no S-Reit IPOs was in 2008 and 2009, in the aftermath of the Global Financial Crisis.
CDL Hospitality Trusts, whose portfolio includes W Singapore at Sentosa Cove, was the top performing S-Reit in 2022.

site_title: Blackstone loses rent dispute at Manhattan’s biggest apartment complex
summary: Blackstone, the world's largest commercial real estate owner, has lost a rent dispute at Manhattan's Stuyvesant Town-Peter Cooper Village apartment complex. A judge ruled in favor of tenants, who argued that 6,000 units should remain rent-stabilized, rather than being deregulated. The ruling comes after a group of tenants and the Stuyvesant Town-Peter Cooper Village Tenant Association filed a lawsuit in 2020, citing new tenant-friendly laws passed by the state in 2019. The decision is a victory for middle-class families, who were promised affordable housing when Blackstone bought the complex in 2015 for $5.4 billion.

images.alt_text: For US$1 billion, UC Investments, the University of California's investment arm, will hold its investment in Blackstone's unlisted real estate income trust (Breit) for at least six years.

site_title: Portuguese are fed up with incentives for foreign home buyers
summary: Portugal is facing a housing crisis driven by rising property prices and a shortage of affordable housing. A survey found that 90% of respondents agree the country is in a crisis, with 64% blaming incentives for foreign buyers, such as the "golden visa" programme. Foreigners are willing to pay more than double for homes in Lisbon compared to locals. The government has restricted the programme and plans to increase public housing, but pressure mounts to cut incentives further.

site_title: As Asian societies age, ‘retirement’ just means more work
summary: Across East Asia, populations are aging rapidly, with older workers continuing to work well into their 70s. In Japan, 73-year-old Yoshihito Oonami drives an hour to deliver fresh produce, straining his back multiple times a day. Despite his physical strain, Oonami says he needs to keep working "as long as my body lets me." This trend is common among Asian societies, where younger generations are shrinking, and older workers are adapting to changing workforce dynamics.

images.alt_text: Sure, everybody knows that with higher expected returns comes the bigger risk of loss. But time and time again investors put this most basic rule to the test in a kind of bull-market delirium.
A
Invest consistently over time so you don't have to worry about whether the markets are about to go up or down.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for January 6, 2023, reveals a decline in tanker and dry bulk market rates due to lackluster activity and seasonal headwinds. Capesize rates fell 30% in the first week of the year, with the average rate at $12,543. The Panamax market also saw downward pressure, with rates in the Atlantic region improving slightly due to South America activity. Ultramax and Supramax markets suffered limited fresh enquiry and abundance of prompt tonnage. The Handysize market remained negative, with further losses in both basins. LNG and LPG rates also declined due to warm winter and higher inventory levels. The report concludes that demand and cargo enquiry next week will determine the market's direction before the Lunar New Year.

images.alt_text: A roundup of the week’s tanker and dry bulk market (Dec 16, 2022).

site_title: Golden Globes return after Hollywood boycott
summary: The Golden Globes are set to return after a one-year hiatus due to controversy and lack of diversity in the Hollywood Foreign Press Association. The 80th Golden Globe Awards will be broadcast on NBC on January 10, featuring films such as Steven Spielberg's "The Fabelmans" and "Top Gun" sequels. The event aims to stage a celebrity-filled comeback and kick-start the movie awards season. The HFPA has made efforts to reform and now has Black members, marking a significant step towards change. A-listers are expected to attend, including Spielberg.

images.alt_text: US actor Tom Cruise arrives in a helicopter to the world premiere of "Top Gun: Maverick!" in May this year. The movie is among the contenders for Golden Globe awards next month when the ceremony returns to television after a year off following a diversity and ethics scandal.

site_title: Kishida vows to debate government, BOJ roles with new central bank head
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida has vowed to discuss government and Bank of Japan (BOJ) roles with the new central bank governor, set to be chosen in April. Kishida emphasized the need for close collaboration between the government and BOJ to achieve price stability and higher wage growth. He also hinted at the possibility of tweaking the BOJ's ultra-loose policy, but stressed the need for careful communication and explanation with markets. Kishida's comments come amid speculation that the BOJ may phase out governor Haruhiko Kuroda's massive stimulus by adjusting its yield control policy.

images.alt_text: The BOJ shocked markets last week with a surprise widening of the band around its 10-year yield target.

site_title: Sudden surge in Manulife US Reit’s gearing a defining moment for manager, sponsor group
summary: Manulife US Reit faces a defining moment as its gearing surges to 49% following a 10.9% decline in its property assets. The Reit's manager and sponsor group are exploring options to reduce leverage, including suspending fees and appealing to unitholders to accept a distribution reinvestment programme. However, the market's skepticism and unitholders' cynicism pose challenges, with some suggesting the sponsor group may cherry-pick assets, leading to a weaker overall portfolio. The Reit's manager and sponsor group must demonstrate long-term commitment to the market to regain investor trust.

images.alt_text: Ben Paul
"We're taking a look at all of our options at this point," says Tripp Gantt, CEO of Manulife US Reit .
The lobby of Figueroa, Manulife US Reit's 35-storey class A office building in Los Angeles. It makes up 44 per cent of the overall portfolio's valuation decline.
RHB Research analyst Vijay Natarajan notes that Manulife US Reit is trading at a more than 40 per cent discount to its marked-down book value.
Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit's aggregate leverage stood at 37.5 per cent as at end September 2022.

site_title: China’s open borders mark Covid Zero end, spark rush home
summary: China has reopened its borders, marking the end of its Covid Zero policy and lifting quarantine requirements for arrivals. The move is expected to spark a surge in overseas Chinese returning home, with many having not seen family for years. However, a full rebound in travel demand is unlikely to occur immediately, with airlines maintaining tight capacity and prices high due to COVID-19 protocols. The reopening is seen as a significant step towards normalcy, with China rejoining the global community after being isolated for three years.

images.alt_text: Travellers visiting Thailand must show proof of at least two vaccinations, or recovery from the virus since July.

site_title: SE-Asia ESG bond proceeds rose 37.4% year-on-year in Q4 2022
summary: SE-Asia ESG bond proceeds rose 37.4% year-on-year to US$2.9 billion in Q4 2022, bucking global declines. Globally, ESG bond proceeds fell 52.9% to US$133.3 billion, while Asia ex-Japan declined 16.8%. Sustainability bonds were the most popular in Q4, and ESG loans in Asia ex-Japan increased 22% to US$36.3 billion. Macroeconomic uncertainty and rising interest rates contributed to the decline in ESG issuance in 2022, but market watchers expect a recovery in 2023.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim

site_title: Green tech fights for limelight at CES gadget fest
summary: At CES, a tech festival in Las Vegas, companies like NeoPlants and Sensibo showcased innovative green technologies, including a bioengineered plant that purifies indoor air and AI-powered air conditioning systems. Despite the growing trend of environmental tech, industry observers question the industry's commitment to sustainability, citing the need for profitability and consumer behavior change. Major tech companies face increased pressure to meet sustainability goals, with some companies, like ACWA Robotics, focusing on industrial applications, such as water leak detection, to make a significant impact.

images.alt_text: ESG bond volumes swelled over the past few years but dropped by 22 per cent in 2022 amid a broader slowdown in corporate bond issues.
New technologies present solutions for the fashion industry to meet its sustainability goals; others suggest changing consumption patterns instead.

site_title: Speaker drama raises new fears on debt limit
summary: US Speaker Kevin McCarthy secured the House speakership after a dramatic vote, but the deal he made with holdout Republicans has raised concerns about persistent political gridlock and the potential for a debt limit crisis. The federal government's projected budget deficit of over $1 trillion per year and its national debt of $31 trillion could lead to a stand-off between Congress and the White House. Conservative Republicans are demanding significant spending cuts, including cuts to social safety net programs, in exchange for raising the debt limit, which could prevent Congress from doing basic tasks and avoid a default on the nation's debt.

images.alt_text: Kevin McCarthy agreed to major concessions to secure a role that is second in line to the Oval Office behind Democratic Vice-President Kamala Harris, including a rule that means that any of the 435 members of the House could force a vote for his removal at any time.

site_title: From bees to bullets, CES tech show gives gamers the feels
summary: The CES tech show showcased innovative gaming hardware and technology, including haptic gloves and vests that replicate the feeling of action in virtual worlds, and surround-sound audio and haptics head cushions that immerse gamers in the game. Companies like Razer, Dell, and Acer unveiled laptops with rich screens and powerful computer chips, while AMD and Nvidia demonstrated the latest graphics horsepower. The metaverse and blockchain technologies also made appearances, with companies like Clover Gaming and PlayStudios highlighting their potential for gaming and beyond.

images.alt_text: NeoPlants, a Paris-based startup, shows off a bioengineered plant capable of purifying indoor air of toxic pollutants.

site_title: Thailand brings back Covid entry rules as China’s borders reopen
summary: Thailand is reintroducing COVID-19 entry requirements for foreigners, starting January 9, as China's borders reopen. Visitors must show proof of at least two vaccinations or recovery from the virus since July. Unvaccinated visitors need a medical report, and those from countries requiring COVID tests must have health insurance. The rules apply until January 31, ahead of expected 300,000 Chinese visitors in the first quarter of this year.

site_title: China extends gold buying with fresh flows to central bank
summary: China has increased its gold reserves for a second consecutive month, adding 30 tonnes in December, bringing its total holdings to 2,010 tonnes. This follows November's 32-ton addition, which was the country's first reported purchase in over three years. Central bank purchases of bullion reached a record in the third quarter of last year, with China accounting for most of the increase. The move is seen as a sign of Asian nations replenishing their war chests amid waning dollar strength.

site_title: Always racing to meetings? It’s slowing you down
summary: Shopify has implemented a "calendar purge" to reduce meeting overload, banning meetings on Wednesdays, limiting large meetings to Thursdays, and restricting meetings with three or more people for two weeks. However, experts argue that simply cutting back on meetings is not enough to tackle the root causes of the problem. To effectively address meeting overload, companies must address underlying issues such as employee workload, consensus-driven culture, and over-rewarding visibility. Leaders can experiment with different formats, set clear targets, and maintain boundaries to create lasting change.

images.alt_text: Giving workers more flexibility in how, where and when they work is beneficial for both employees and employers, says the ILO.
Our quest for productivity goes back several years.
Driven by the belief that alternative working areas stimulate creativity, the unconventional office trend is rising.

site_title: Republican US House Speaker Kevin McCarthy's dream job could become a nightmare
summary: US House Speaker Kevin McCarthy has been elected, fulfilling a long-held dream despite a four-day standoff. To secure the role, he agreed to concessions, including a rule allowing any of the 435 House members to force a vote for his removal at any time. McCarthy also agreed to pursue deep cuts in government spending and promised greater influence for hardline critics. The concessions raise concerns about his power and ability to govern, particularly in a divided government with a $31.4 trillion debt limit to address later this year.

images.alt_text: “We’ve got some progress going on. We’ve got members talking. I think we’ve got a little movement, so we’ll see,” House Republican Leader Kevin McCarthy told reporters.

site_title: Life after Elon Musk: Tesla’s board takes heat over CEO succession planning
summary: Tesla's board faces pressure to prepare for the potential loss of CEO Elon Musk, who has recently become the first person to lose $200 billion of net worth. A shareholder resolution, submitted by Karen Robertsdottir, aims to require the board to document processes and procedures for succession of key people and mitigate the financial impact of Musk's loss. The resolution comes amid concerns over the company's compensation package, which some say was marred with conflicts of interest and improper disclosures. Tesla's annual meeting is scheduled for May 16, where the resolution may be voted on.

images.alt_text: Tesla’s stock has been in a freefall over the past three months, as wider anxiety about the technology selloff and Musk’s preoccupation with his acquisition of Twitter gave way to growing doubts about the demand for EVs in the face of a recession.
Tesla fell about 65 per cent last year, with declines accelerating after Musk decided to buy social media network Twitter, which some investors see as a distraction to the chief executive.
Tesla plans to run a reduced production schedule in January at its Shanghai plant.
The stock market is pricing in that Tesla will continue to post rapid growth and brokerage analysts are broadly more positive on the company than they were a year ago

Twitter managers who didn’t lose their jobs in mass layoffs last month have been told to approach their spending with a tactic known as “zero-based budgeting”, or operating under the assumption that spending should start at nothing and teams should justify individual costs, according to the costs-savings document.

site_title: Thai exchanges adjust rules before launch of new trading system
summary: Thailand's stock and futures exchanges have adjusted regulations ahead of the launch of a new trading system in the first quarter of 2023. The revised rules align with international standards, allowing the equilibrium price to fall outside a ceiling and floor but not exceed plus or minus one tick. This change will take effect simultaneously with the new trading system, aiming to better reflect market dynamics.

images.alt_text: Singapore, Malaysia, Thailand, Indonesia and the Philippines collectively saw 149 IPO listings in 2022, versus 132 recorded in 2021.
CGS-CIMB has reiterated its end-2022 SET index target of 1,730.

site_title: Big tech targets bond market for cash to buy back sinking stocks
summary: Big tech companies, including Microsoft and Meta Platforms, are expected to borrow billions from the bond market to buy back stock after last year's rout. The sector has ample cash, allowing it to tap into debt markets to fund buybacks and acquisitions. Despite rising interest rates, tech companies may continue to bolster balance sheets to return money to shareholders. Amazon has already secured $8 billion in financing through a term loan. Experts predict that tech companies will prioritize higher-quality names with strong balance sheets, but caution that cash levels may deteriorate further without additional borrowing.

images.alt_text: The Federal Trade Commission, America's antitrust enforcer, has aggressively challenged acquisitions, recently filing suit to block Microsoft’s US$69 billion purchase of video game maker Activision Blizzard, which would be the largest technology deal in decades.
US tech giants including Meta, Microsoft, Twitter and Snap have purged more than 150,000 staff, according to Layoff.fyi, which tracks technology job losses.
Amazon.com’s layoffs will now include more than 18,000 roles as part of a workforce reduction it previously disclosed.

site_title: US announces over US$3.75b in new military assistance to Ukraine, other countries
summary: The US has announced over $3.75 billion in new military assistance to Ukraine and countries affected by the Russian invasion, with the majority going towards Ukraine. The aid package includes Bradley Infantry Fighting Vehicles, self-propelled Howitzers, armoured personnel carriers, surface-to-air missiles, and ammunition. The US will also provide $225 million in Foreign Military Financing and $682 million for regional partners and allies. This is the largest use of the Presidential Drawdown Authority since Russia's invasion last February, with 50 Bradley Fighting Vehicles set to be sent to Ukraine.

images.alt_text: Russia’s budget is increasingly squeezed as President Vladimir Putin’s invasion heads for its second year and the economy contracts under sweeping US and European sanctions.
The announcement comes following a request for a ceasefire during Orthodox Christmas from Russia’s 76-year-old Orthodox leader Patriarch Kirill.

site_title: Macy's expects holiday-quarter sales at low end of forecast
summary: Macy's expects fourth-quarter sales to be at the lower end of its forecast, blaming a deeper-than-expected lull in shopping between major holidays. The company had previously forecast $8.16 billion to $8.40 billion in sales. CEO Jeff Gennette attributed the lower forecast to macroeconomic indicators and proprietary credit card data showing consumer pressure in 2023, particularly in the first half. Shares fell 3.5% in extended trading.

site_title: Oil settles flat, with weekly decline on recession worries
summary: Oil prices ended the first week of the year lower, with Brent and WTI crude falling over 8% due to recession concerns. Despite mixed US jobs reports, a weaker US dollar boosted demand for oil. Global stocks rallied as investors bet on easing inflation and reduced Fed aggression. Saudi Arabia lowered oil prices, and China's reopening optimism boosted markets, but countries are demanding COVID-19 tests from Chinese visitors ahead of its border controls reopening.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures were 94 cents, or 1.2 per cent, higher at US$79.63 a barrel at 0345 GMT, after settling 85 cents stronger at US$78.69 on Thursday.

site_title: Solid fundamentals in S-Reits despite challenging 2022
summary: The Singapore Reits sector experienced solid fundamentals despite a challenging 2022, with the iEdge S-Reits Index declining 16% in price returns. Hospitality Reits saw the strongest performance, with retail and office Reits also reporting growth. Retail investors drove fund flow activities, accumulating S$1.53 billion in net retail inflows, while institutional investors saw net outflows of S$1.28 billion. Reits continued to expand into new markets, with ParkwayLife Reit and First Reit focusing on healthcare investments in Japan nursing homes.

images.alt_text: CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust reported 21.3 per cent y-o-y growth in tenant sales and 21.9 per cent y-o-y growth in shopper traffic for 9M 2022.

site_title: These are the top 10 most profitable side hustles in 2023
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article:

The US job market remains strong, but inflation and rising costs are prompting Americans to seek extra income through side hustles. According to ZipRecruiter's analysis, the top 10 most profitable side hustles in 2023 include family assistants, craftsmen, sales specialists, and nursing aides, with average hourly wages ranging from $15 to over $40. These jobs often require little to no starting requirements and can be done part-time. Experts say side hustles are becoming more common in strong labor markets, providing a cushion in case layoffs occur, and may also offer a way to supplement income.

site_title: US moves to bar non-compete agreements in labour contracts
summary: The US Federal Trade Commission (FTC) has proposed a rule to ban non-compete agreements in labor contracts, which could raise wages and increase competition among businesses. The proposed rule, set to take effect 180 days after publication, would prohibit companies from limiting employees' ability to work for a rival or start a competing business. Studies show that non-competes hold down pay and reduce competition within industries, and experts estimate that the rule could increase wages by nearly $300 billion a year across the economy.

site_title: Netflix, Tesla post wide salary ranges under new California pay law
summary: California's new pay transparency law requires companies with 15 or more employees to post estimated salary ranges for job postings. A study found that Netflix and Tesla posted the widest ranges, with Tesla's software engineer range spanning $83,200 to $417,600 and Netflix's job postings ranging from $90,000 to $900,000 and $50,000 to $600,000. Most companies are complying with the law in good faith, but some are taking a liberal interpretation, sparking concerns about the accuracy of the posted ranges.

images.alt_text: Tesla is also going to freeze hiring, according to the Electrek report.
The tech employment market is quickly turning into an employer's market, with job seekers needing to temper salary expectations.
Aon forecasts for Vietnam to take the lead in the region, with median salary increments of 7.9 per cent in 2023.
Amazon.com’s layoffs will now include more than 18,000 roles as part of a workforce reduction it previously disclosed.

site_title: Digital Currency Group closes wealth division amid crypto slump
summary: Digital Currency Group (DCG) has closed its wealth-management division, HQ, amid a prolonged crypto slump. The decision follows staff layoffs at Genesis, DCG's brokerage, and comes after the collapse of FTX, one of the world's largest crypto exchanges. A DCG spokesperson cited the "state of the broader economic environment" and "prolonged crypto winter" as reasons for the closure. This move follows a series of challenges faced by DCG's subsidiaries since FTX's collapse, with Genesis potentially seeking bankruptcy protection.

images.alt_text: The Blockchain Association of Singapore said such a blanket ban could instead push people to seek out unregulated offshore firms to lend their tokens to, according to an 11-page feedback that was sent late last month to the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS).
