Digital Currency Group operates several subsidiaries, including major cryptocurrency lender Genesis Global Capital, which froze withdrawals in November following the collapse of FTX.
The layoffs come against the broader backdrop of concerns about reserves and solvency at various cryptocurrency exchanges.
Gemini has a crypto lending product called Earn in partnership with DCG’s crypto firm Genesis.

site_title: China’s deep-pocketed tourists are staying home, for now
summary: China's tourism industry, worth $280 billion, may not recover for months due to lingering COVID-19 infections, travel restrictions, and high costs. Despite China's borders reopening, many Chinese tourists are staying home, with some fearing COVID reinfection and high flight costs. Travel agencies are struggling to persuade people to book trips, with prices increasing by 18% since Christmas. The industry expects a delayed recovery to pre-pandemic levels, with some destinations like Thailand expecting less than 10% of pre-pandemic visitor numbers.

images.alt_text: Businesses in China are hoping the busy long weekend was a sign that a rebound for the services sector is on the cards.
As many as 76 per cent of Chinese travel agencies ranked South-east Asia as the top destination when outbound travel resumed, according to a survey released in December by trade show ITB China.
CDL Hospitality Trusts, whose portfolio includes W Singapore at Sentosa Cove, was the top performing S-Reit in 2022.
Hong Kong residents have flocked to clinics to get vaccinated against Covid ahead of the border reopening.

site_title: ‘Spectacular’ trading drop plagues still-reeling crypto market
summary: The cryptocurrency market is experiencing a significant trading drop, with trading volumes plummeting 46% in 2022 compared to the previous year. Bitcoin's trading volumes declined 31% year-on-year, and the "Liquid Tradeable BTC" proxy has slid to June 2020 lows. The decline is attributed to the aftermath of the FTX empire's collapse, which has scared away retail investors and institutional investors alike. Many institutions have abandoned the asset class, and it may take a while for them to regain confidence.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Representations of cryptocurrencies plunge into water in this illustration taken, May 23, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Singapore’s leading crypto group opposes proposed ban on lending tokens
summary: Singapore's leading crypto group, the Blockchain Association of Singapore, opposes a proposed ban on lending tokens by the Monetary Authority of Singapore, citing potential unintended consequences of pushing consumers to unregulated offshore firms. The group suggests a more measured approach, including education and enforcement, and disagrees with a complete ban on firms giving incentives to retail customers. Instead, it proposes allowing gifts not linked to financial purchases, such as door gifts at roadshows.

site_title: Redas gets new president, Tan Swee Yiow
summary: Tan Swee Yiow, director of KEPPEL Land, has been elected as the new president of the Real Estate Developers' Association of Singapore (Redas) for a two-year term starting 2023. Tan is also the chairman of Keppel Reit Management and senior managing director of urban development at Keppel Corporation. Marc Boey and Kwee Ker Wei are the first and second vice-presidents, respectively.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek

site_title: 3M spends more than US$450m in legal costs on earplug cases
summary: 3M has spent over $450 million on defense costs in lawsuits related to defective earplugs sold to the US military, which harmed soldiers' hearing. The company estimates an additional $100 million in legal costs for the rest of 2022, bringing its total bill to approximately $466 million. This is the latest twist in the over four-year litigation, with more than a dozen juries awarding damages and the company winning six defense verdicts.

images.alt_text: 3M’s exit from the category comes 20 years after management phased out an early, popular form of PFAS, known as PFOS, in 2002 under pressure from scientific studies about its potential harms.
3M’s exit from the category comes 20 years after management phased out an early, popular form of PFAS, known as PFOS, in 2002 under pressure from scientific studies about its potential harms.

site_title: FTX teams in US, Bahamas to coordinate fund recovery efforts
summary: FTX's US bankruptcy team has agreed to coordinate with liquidators in the Bahamas to recover billions of dollars in lost funds. The dispute, which began in November, has been resolved, allowing for the sharing of information, securing property, and coordinating litigation against third parties. Bahamian regulators have seized FTX assets, which officials claim will be returned to creditors. The US team disputes the size of the seized assets, saying they are worth $296 million, not $3.5 billion.

images.alt_text: Lawyers for the former CEO of bankrupt exchange FTX argued in a Delaware court filing on Thursday (Jan 5) that the 56.3 million Robinhood shares should be returned to Bankman-Fried.
Sam Bankman-Fried is accused of diverting billions of dollars in FTX client funds to Alameda to bankroll venture investments, luxury real estate purchases, and political donations.
Sam Bankman-Fried was extradited from the Bahamas last month to face fraud charges in the US.
In December, a judge granted Bankman-Fried a US$250 million bail package, one of the largest in US history.

site_title: World number one Alcaraz to miss Australian Open with injury
summary: World number one tennis player Carlos Alcaraz will miss the Australian Open due to a right leg muscle injury sustained during pre-season training. The 19-year-old, who became the youngest men's world number one after winning the US Open last year, had been nearing full fitness ahead of the new season. Alcaraz expressed optimism about his recovery, stating he would look forward to competing in 2024.

site_title: US factory orders tumble in November on aircraft
summary: US factory orders declined 1.8% in November, exceeding expectations, due to a sharp drop in aircraft bookings. Higher borrowing costs and shifting spending to services also contributed to the decline. The decline in factory orders follows a 0.4% gain in October and a 12.2% year-over-year increase. Manufacturing accounts for 11.3% of the US economy, and a recent Institute for Supply Management survey showed its measure of factory activity contracting for a second straight month.

images.alt_text: A measure of prices paid by services industries for inputs dropped to 67.6, the lowest since January 2021, from 70.0 in November as supply bottlenecks continued to ease.

(FILES) In this file photo taken on July 08, 2022, a family walks past a "Hiring" sign at a McDonald's restaurant in Garden Grove, California. - US employers slowed the pace of hiring in August after the surprising surge in the prior month and the jobless rate edged up, the government reported on September 2, 2022. Even with the slowing pace, the job gains bring employment above the pre-pandemic level, the Labor Department said. US employment increased by 315,000 jobs last month, the report said, which was in line with what economists were expecting after the 526,000 hires in July. (Photo by Robyn BECK / AFP)

site_title: Jack Ma to relinquish control of Ant Group
summary: Chinese fintech giant Ant Group's founder Jack Ma will relinquish control of the company, following a change in its voting rights structure. Ma, who owns a 10% stake, will now control 6.2% of the company after agreeing to vote independently with other major shareholders. Ant has also added a fifth independent director to its board, ensuring a majority of independent directors. The move comes after a regulatory crackdown and restructuring of the company, which was triggered by its cancelled IPO in 2020.

images.alt_text: Jack Ma has maintained a low profile since Ant’s IPO was halted.
With Jack Ma giving up control, a revival of Ant's initial public offering (IPO) could be put back another year or more, Dow Jones reported

site_title: Advancing Singapore’s hydrogen journey: Opportunities and Challenges
summary: Singapore is doubling down on its efforts to decarbonize in line with its commitment to reach net-zero emissions by 2050, with developing hydrogen as a low-carbon option. The country aims to tap into the potential of hydrogen to supply up to half of its power needs by 2050. However, challenges remain, including high costs and the need for technological advancements to unlock the full potential of hydrogen. The government is exploring collaboration with industry partners to spur interest in the emerging field and ensure that Singaporeans are prepared to capitalize on the green hydrogen economy.

images.alt_text: Sembcorp's cogeneration plant on Banyan, Jurong Island.
Old power plants nearing end-of-life can be repurposed for the hydrogen economy.

site_title: Digilife Tech, Forise & APTT directors acquire more shares
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index gained 1.3% from Dec 30 to Jan 5, with institutions buying S$5.2 million worth of stocks, while Yangzijiang Shipbuilding and Singapore Exchange led the outflow with S$1.3 million and S$2.8 million, respectively. 19 companies conducted share buybacks, with OCBC buying 100,000 shares and HRnetGroup buying 868,000 shares. Director and substantial shareholder transactions included Digilife Technologies' Bhupendra Kumar Modi increasing his stake to 56.62%, Forise International's Dennis Wan Jinn Woei acquiring 1,409,200 shares, and A-Sonic Aerospace's Janet LC Tan acquiring 120,000 shares, increasing her stake to 61.05%.

images.alt_text: Shares on the Singapore bourse rose on Tuesday amid a mixed showing by regional peers

site_title: How strained China-Australia ties hit trade in coal, barley, beef and wine
summary: China has resumed coal trade with Australia after a three-year halt, but tariffs and restrictions on other products remain. Relations between Beijing and Canberra are thawing following a change in Australia's government, marked by a meeting between foreign ministers and messages between leaders. Goldman Sachs predicts the coal restriction's easing will have a small overall economic impact, but is positive for affected sectors. The resumption of coal trade is seen as a step towards improving bilateral ties, which had been strained due to issues including trade restrictions.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Printed Chinese and Australian flags are seen in this illustration, July 21, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration REFILE - CORRECTING YEAR/File Photo

site_title: TikTok CEO to meet EU antitrust chief Vestager on Tuesday
summary: TikTok CEO Shou Zi Chew will meet EU antitrust chief Margrethe Vestager in Brussels on January 10 to discuss issues like personal data protection and the implementation of the EU's Digital Services Act. Chew will also meet Values and Transparency Commissioner Vera Jourova and European Commissioner for Home Affairs Ylva Johansson. The meetings aim to address concerns regarding online platforms' data protection and the Digital Services Act.

site_title: US: Stocks rally as market bets on moderating Fed policy
summary: US stocks rallied on Friday, January 6, as data suggested a slowing US economy, easing pressure for Federal Reserve interest rate hikes. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 2.1%, the S&P 500 jumped 2.3%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index surged 2.6%. A solid jobs report and a drop in the 10-year US Treasury yield contributed to the gains. However, a weak services sector report and tempering wage growth also weighed on markets.

images.alt_text: Traders on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, US, on Tuesday, Jan. 3, 2023. US stocks fell as losses in Apple Inc. and Tesla Inc. weighed on the S&P 500 and the tech-heavy Nasdaq 100. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

site_title: US service sector contracts in December, price increases slow: ISM survey
summary: The US services industry contracted for the first time in over 2.5 years in December, with the Institute for Supply Management (ISM) reporting a non-manufacturing PMI of 49.6, the lowest since May 2020. This contraction, along with a slowdown in price increases, suggests that inflation is abating. The services sector accounts for over two-thirds of the US economy, and the weakness in this sector is a concern for the broader economy. The Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes are also dampening demand across the economy, but the labor market remains resilient.

images.alt_text: The Commerce Department said on Friday (Jan 6) that factory orders dropped 1.8 per cent after gaining 0.4 per cent in October.

(FILES) In this file photo taken on July 08, 2022, a family walks past a "Hiring" sign at a McDonald's restaurant in Garden Grove, California. - US employers slowed the pace of hiring in August after the surprising surge in the prior month and the jobless rate edged up, the government reported on September 2, 2022. Even with the slowing pace, the job gains bring employment above the pre-pandemic level, the Labor Department said. US employment increased by 315,000 jobs last month, the report said, which was in line with what economists were expecting after the 526,000 hires in July. (Photo by Robyn BECK / AFP)

site_title: The best present is being present
summary: A writer reflects on the post-pandemic social scene, feeling overwhelmed by constant celebrations and social interactions, leading to a sense of exhaustion. Recognizing "social exhaustion" as a real phenomenon, they take steps to prioritize self-care, including learning to say no to invitations and scheduling alone time. They realize that being present in the moment with loved ones is the best gift, and aim to make this a priority in the new year.

images.alt_text: Vivien Ang
All this while, when I was rejecting Yolo-ism and what it entailed, I have come to realise that it actually made more sense than ever to live by this rule.

site_title: McDonald's to boost restaurant growth, streamline some programs
summary: McDonald's to boost restaurant growth by accelerating store development and canceling or de-prioritizing some initiatives. The company aims to build more restaurants and streamline technology and menu development to get new products into use globally more quickly. CEO Chris Kempczinski announced the plan in a letter to global employees, which may lead to layoffs in some areas and expansion in others. McDonald's recently beat sales and profit estimates, driven by higher menu prices and increased foot traffic. The company will begin announcing key decisions by April 3.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A view shows the McDonald's Golden Arches at a closed restaurant of McDonald's in Almaty, Kazakhstan, January 6, 2023. Food Solutions KZ, the Kazakh licensee of McDonald's Corp, will no longer operate under the U.S. corporation's brand due to supply issues. REUTERS/Pavel Mikheyev/File Photo
The hikes follow previous increases in March and September last year, as Japan grapples with inflation and a slide in the yen.

McDonald’s has been forced to raise prices of its burgers and fries to keep up with surging commodity costs, but its meals are still cheaper than eating out at dine-in restaurants keeping demand resilient even as consumer spending power gets crimped.

site_title: Tesla’s demand troubles spell a terrible start to the year
summary: Tesla's stock has plummeted 7.7% in early trading on January 6, falling to $101.81, as investors worry about weakening demand for electric cars amid a recession. The company's market capitalization dropped below Meta Platforms' for the first time in over a year. Weaker-than-expected deliveries for the fourth quarter and price cuts in China have intensified fears. Analysts predict investors will be cautious about the stock's future, citing too many unknowns and a decline that surpasses the Nasdaq 100 index's 33% drop in 2022.

images.alt_text: Tesla already cut prices in China last year to boost sales as competition heats up in both the mass and premium segments.
In China, the world’s biggest electric car market, Tesla is facing intensifying competition from local rivals such as BYD and Nio.
Tesla fell about 65 per cent last year, with declines accelerating after Musk decided to buy social media network Twitter, which some investors see as a distraction to the chief executive.

The Korea Fair Trade Commission (KFTC) said that Tesla had exaggerated the “driving ranges of its cars on a single charge, their fuel cost-effectiveness compared to petrol vehicles as well as the performance of its Superchargers”.
Under Zhu’s leadership, Tesla Shanghai rebounded strongly from lockdowns this year to bring Tesla close to its target for 2022 of 50 per cent production growth.
Tesla plans to run a reduced production schedule in January at its Shanghai plant.

site_title: Eurozone inflation falls sharply in Dec but offers ECB little respite
summary: Eurozone inflation decreased to 9.2% in December, below expectations of 9.7%, but core inflation accelerated to 6.9% and 5.2% excluding volatile food and energy prices. This suggests the European Central Bank (ECB) will continue raising interest rates to combat price growth. However, inflation is likely to peak and then fall, with the ECB's 2% target not expected until mid-2025, raising concerns about the persistence of price growth and the difficulty in taming it.

site_title: Europe: Shares end at 7-month high, best week since March
summary: European stocks reached a 7-month high, closing 1.2% higher at the continent-wide Stoxx 600 index, its best level since May. The index gained 4.6% for the week, driven by miners and oil stocks, with copper prices rising and energy stocks boosted by rising oil prices. This followed calming data on US jobs growth, which eased concerns over the Federal Reserve's rate-hike trajectory.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 closed 0.2 per cent lower on Thursday, having climbed more than 3 per cent in the first three sessions of 2023.

site_title: What’s at stake as China cleans up its property mess
summary: China's real estate sector, which accounts for over 70% of urban wealth, is in a slump, with major developers defaulting on debts and the government attempting to organize a bailout. The industry's growth since President Xi Jinping's presidency has slowed, with prices reaching unsustainable levels and sparking a cash-flow crisis. The government has introduced measures to boost equity, bond, and loan financing for developers, and has relaxed some restrictions on lending. Despite these efforts, the housing sector remains stagnant, with new home sales dropping 31% in December and economists predicting a slow recovery.

images.alt_text: Evergrande is slated to meet in Hong Kong with members from an ad-hoc group of dollar-bond holders, the first of its kind since the company became a defaulter more than a year ago.
China is also planning to relax restrictions on borrowing for property developers by dialling back the “three red lines” policy.

site_title: Bankman-Fried wants US$450m Robinhood stake for legal bills
summary: Bankman-Fried is seeking US$450 million in value from his 56.3 million Robinhood shares, which he allegedly borrowed US$546 million to buy, to cover his legal fees. Lawyers argue that the shares should be returned to him because the company that owns them is not part of the bankruptcy estate, citing several legal precedents. The US Department of Justice is seizing the shares as part of the fraud case against Bankman-Fried, and a court hearing will determine who has the greater claim, including FTX, BlockFi, and Emergent Fidelity Technology.

site_title: Five sports wishes for a happy 2023
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article:

The sports world has ended 2022 on a high note, with memorable moments and exciting events. Fans are making wishes for 2023, including more world-class sports action at the Singapore Sports Hub, Novak Djokovic getting vaccinated to avoid missing top tournaments, the Singapore Lions bouncing back from a disappointing AFF Cup exit, the rise of underdog teams in the English Premier League and Italy's Serie A, and Rory McIlroy finally winning the Green Jacket at the Masters Tournament. With a packed calendar, fans are eagerly anticipating the new year's sports action.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as December jobs report eases rate worries
summary: US stocks opened higher on Friday, January 6, as the December jobs report eased concerns over the Federal Reserve's rate-hike trajectory. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 125.22 points, or 0.38%, to 33,055.30. Cooling wages and moderation in US jobs growth calmed rate-hike worries, leading to a 0.38% gain in the Dow, 0.40% in the S&P 500, and 0.57% in the Nasdaq Composite.

site_title: UK property funds facing curbs on withdrawals hit US$17.8b
summary: UK open-ended real estate funds are facing curbs on withdrawals totaling £15 billion (S$24 billion), with several funds restricting redemptions due to high inflation and economic uncertainty. Asset managers CBRE Investment Management, BlackRock, and M&G are delaying redemptions, with some investors receiving only half of their requested payouts. The situation worsens after pension schemes sold property assets during a liquidity crisis, leading to a "wholesale wave of disinvestment" from illiquid assets.

images.alt_text: Property funds have been buffeted by outflows, partly because economic downturns snuff out demand for commercial property.
The UK's property market is weighed down by soaring interest rates and a tightening cost-of-living squeeze.

site_title: US posts solid job growth in December; jobless rate falls to 3.5%
summary: The US economy maintained strong job growth in December, adding 223,000 jobs, and the unemployment rate fell to 3.5%. Average hourly earnings edged up 0.3% to $32.82. Despite the Federal Reserve's efforts to combat inflation, the labor market remains resilient, sustaining consumer spending. However, experts predict the trend in employment growth could slow significantly by mid-year due to expensive credit weighing on consumer spending and business investment.

images.alt_text: A measure of prices paid by services industries for inputs dropped to 67.6, the lowest since January 2021, from 70.0 in November as supply bottlenecks continued to ease.
The Commerce Department said on Friday (Jan 6) that factory orders dropped 1.8 per cent after gaining 0.4 per cent in October.
Against a basket of currencies, the US dollar index rose 0.3 per cent to 105.45, having briefly touched a four-week peak of 105.52.

site_title: Lufthansa to bring back ageing A340 jets to add more first-class seats
summary: Lufthansa plans to revive five ageing Airbus A340 jets to boost first-class seat availability on lucrative intercontinental routes. The move comes as travel demand rebounds from the coronavirus crisis. The A340s, which range from 14 to 19 years old, will be brought back into service by next summer, with the goal of deploying them at Frankfurt hub to offer more premium seats. This decision marks a shift in Lufthansa's thinking on high-fuel-burn models, following the revival of some A380 superjumbos.

images.alt_text: Lufthansa said on Thursday that the continued high premium demand from leisure travellers was especially remarkable, with load factors in Business and First Class exceeding pre-pandemic levels.

site_title: Samudera acquires two new container vessels
summary: Samudera Shipping Line has acquired two new container vessels with a total capacity of 3,800 TEUs for US$66 million. The acquisition is not expected to impact the company's net tangible assets and earnings per share for the 2022 financial year. The two vessels are expected to be delivered in the fourth quarter of 2024 and early 2025.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek

site_title: Fifa to introduce cap on fees in widespread agent rule changes
summary: FIFA will introduce widespread rule changes for soccer agents, including a cap on transfer commissions and mandatory licensing. Agents can take a maximum 3% commission for transfers above $200,000 and 5% for deals under $200,000. The new regulations also require public transparency of transactions, a licensing system, and prohibit multiple representation to avoid conflicts of interest. The changes come into force on Monday, aiming to establish a fairer and more transparent football transfer system.

site_title: China hotels, flights, cinemas perk up as Covid curbs end
summary: China's services sector is showing signs of a rebound as Covid-19 curbs are lifted, with businesses and consumers catching up on lost time during the New Year's holiday. Hotel bookings and flight numbers surged, and cinemas expect their busiest single day of the year. Economists are cautiously optimistic, with some predicting a 11% growth in retail sales in 2023, while others note that a full recovery will take time, particularly in rural areas. China's chief epidemiologist said infections have peaked in major cities, but caution remains ahead of Chinese New Year.

images.alt_text: The hit to business caused by the new spread of the virus extends the pain to the services sector from the country’s stringent Covid curbs.
How markets fared in the new year.
The recovery in international travel and tourism, particularly with China's border reopening, may help to  cushion Singapore's economic slowdown in 2023, economists said.
Authorities announced that widespread travel between Hong Kong and mainland China would resume from Sunday, initially allowing about 60,000 people a day to cross in each direction.

site_title: Adani among potential bidders eyeing stake in India-backed power trader
summary: Gautam Adani, Asia's richest man, is among potential bidders reviewing preliminary information on selling a stake in state-backed electricity trader PTC India. Other Indian conglomerates, including NTPC, NHP, Power Grid of India, and Power Finance, are also evaluating whether to bid. The sale would help Adani Group bolster its grip on India's energy value chain, which it already has significant interests in through coal mining, trading, transmission, and distribution services. Bids are due at the end of this month, but deliberations are at an early stage.

site_title: India launches first-ever sovereign green bonds auction
summary: India has launched its first-ever sovereign green bonds auction, worth 160 billion rupees ($2.6 billion), to finance clean projects. The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) will auction 5-year and 10-year green bonds on January 25 and February 9, with proceeds used for solar power, wind, and small hydro projects. A green finance working committee will select public sector projects for green financing, guided by environment specialists. Foreign investors and banks are expected to participate, and the investment can qualify for statutory liquidity ratio and be designated as specified securities for foreign investors.

images.alt_text: “Prioritising price stability, may therefore be the optimal policy choice in the current context for the region,” Shaktikanta Das, governor of the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) said.

site_title: US dollar hits four-week peak on resilient US jobs market
summary: The US dollar reached a four-week peak of 105.52 against a basket of currencies, driven by strong US job market data. The US jobs market showed resilience, with a drop in new jobless claims and a 43% decline in layoffs in December. Private employment also increased by 235,000 jobs, exceeding expectations. This data suggests the Federal Reserve may continue to hike interest rates aggressively, supporting the dollar's rise.

site_title: Kitchen Culture dissenting shareholders mull over another EGM to replace directors
summary: Kitchen Culture's dissenting shareholders plan to request a fresh Extraordinary General Meeting (EGM) to replace five directors, following a failed attempt at a court injunction. The shareholders, who represent about 40% of the company's shares, had previously called for the removal of the directors but now intend to withdraw the legal proceedings. Kitchen Culture is unclear whether the proceedings have been withdrawn and is seeking reimbursement of the legal costs incurred. The company maintains that its current board of directors remains unchanged.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek

Poggenpohl showroom by Kitchen Culture. Ooway Group became a substantial shareholder of Kitchen Culture in 2020, after it sold 30 per cent of its subsidiary Ooway Technology to Kitchen Culture in exchange for 90 million shares – around 21.2 per cent – of Kitchen Culture.
The boardroom fight at Catalist-listed Kitchen Culture, an outfitter of kitchens, is now being played out at the court.
Poggenpohl showroom by Kitchen Culture. The company says it will “carry on its business and affairs normally” as it defends against legal proceedings launched by Ooway Group.
Poggenpohl showroom by Kitchen Culture. The company's sponsor has issued a statement in response to a Dec 7 article published in The Business Times.

site_title: VC funding in the US cools from record level as investors stay cautious
summary: US venture capital funding has slowed down to a third of its peak in 2021, despite record amounts of capital raised by new and existing funds. Private venture-backed companies raised $238.3 billion last year, 31% lower than the record $344.7 billion in 2021. Investors are cautious due to rising interest rates, geopolitical risks, and public market volatility, leading to a slowdown in deployment of unused funds to private tech companies.

images.alt_text: Amazon.com’s layoffs will now include more than 18,000 roles as part of a workforce reduction it previously disclosed.
Microsoft which invested US$1 billion in OpenAI in 2019, was working to launch a version of its search engine Bing using the AI behind the now viral ChatGPT.

Last May, the majority of Twitter shareholders decided Silver Lake’s chief executive Egon Durban was juggling too many directorships on top of the day job and voted against his reappointment.

site_title: Indonesia president eyes cabinet reshuffle in coming days
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo is planning a cabinet reshuffle in the coming days, with sources suggesting he will sack poorly performing ministers. The move is seen as an attempt to complete remaining programmes and projects ahead of elections in 2024. Widodo confirmed the reshuffle, but did not elaborate on the timing or which ministers will be affected. The reshuffle comes amid speculation about Widodo's successor, with some parties and politicians calling for him to sack members of his coalition in the cabinet.

images.alt_text: Located in eastern Borneo — the world’s third-largest island — Nusantara is set to replace sinking and polluted Jakarta as Indonesia’s political centre by late 2024.

site_title: Iran says it foiled cyberattack on central bank
summary: Iran's central bank was targeted by a distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attack on Thursday night, according to the country's telecommunications infrastructure company. The attack was part of a larger threat from anonymous and global hacking groups in October, aimed at supporting anti-government protests. The central bank had previously reported a cyberattack briefly taking its website offline in September. The attack was successfully repelled, with no further details provided.

site_title: Norway’s wealth fund suggests expanding into unlisted equities
summary: Norway's $1.3 trillion sovereign wealth fund, Norges Bank Investment Management, has recommended expanding into unlisted equities to boost returns. The fund noticed a larger share of value creation taking place in the unlisted market, where the number of listed companies worldwide has leveled off and companies that list are generally older and larger. The fund's strategy may need to be adjusted to include unlisted equities, and it has previously asked for permission to make such investments, but was rejected in 2018.

site_title: Chinese banks among new lenders buying Orange, Masmovil debt
summary: Chinese banks Bank of China and Industrial & Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) are among lenders finalizing a deal to buy around 600 million euros of debt backing the merger of Orange and Masmovil Ibercom's Spanish divisions. The joint venture is one of Europe's largest leveraged finance deals, attracting Asian lenders amid recession fears. The deal benefits both arrangers and borrowers, with the new lenders bringing a more diverse base and the borrowers gaining from the reduced exposure of the arrangers.

site_title: India set to lose fastest-growing major economy tag this year
summary: India's economy is expected to lose its title as the fastest-growing major economy this year, with a projected 7% growth rate, down from 8.7% in the previous year. Weakening demand at home and abroad, as well as central bank monetary policy tightening to combat high inflation, are contributing to the decline. India's growth will be second only to Saudi Arabia's 7.6% growth, and will impact the government's spending priorities in the upcoming federal budget.

images.alt_text: “The key surprise came from the phenomenal growth in services exports in the first half of the current fiscal year, which goes beyond just software services,” Samiran Chakraborty, chief economist for India at Citi, said in a note.

site_title: Hedge fund fees fall to lowest level since 2008 financial crisis, says research firm
summary: Hedge fund fees have fallen to their lowest level since the 2008 financial crisis, according to research firm Hedge Fund Research (HFR). The fees, which include base fees at 1.35% and incentive fees at 16.01%, declined from the second to third quarter of 2022. This drop was attributed to high inflation and recessionary fears, which negatively impacted long-only stock investing firms. The decline in fees reflects a challenging year for some hedge funds, with the HFRI 500 Fund Weighted Composite Index posting a year-to-date decline of 2.78%.

images.alt_text: Many hedge fund managers expect a mild global recession this year.
Better days may lie ahead for 60/40 stock/bond portfolios.
Data suggests that it is precisely when fixed income’s diversification benefits are most needed — during a recession — that they are least effective.

site_title: South Korea’s SK On plans a new, lower cost EV battery by 2025
summary: South Korea's SK On plans to produce a new, lithium-iron-phosphate (LFP) electric vehicle battery by 2025 to deliver lower-cost batteries to automakers. The move aims to address rising EV costs. SK On's US expansion plans include 150 gigawatt-hours of capacity by 2026, with guarantees from automakers to take the batteries. The company is investing in new US battery plants and cathode production to meet domestic content requirements for US EV subsidies.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of SK Innovation is seen in front of its headquarters in Seoul, South Korea, February 3, 2017. REUTERS/Kim Hong-Ji/File Photo

site_title: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding unit faces US$4.8m winding-up petition
summary: Trinity Seatrading has applied for the winding up of Yangzijiang Shipping in Singapore, seeking US$4.8 million in debt. The claim originated from a dispute over the sale of an oil tanker by Yangzijiang Shipping to Trinity Seatrading. Yangzijiang Shipbuilding said it is considering its options and does not expect the winding-up application to impact its net earnings. The case will be heard on January 20.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek

To position for 2023, analysts The Business Times spoke to recommended plays on interest rate movements as well as China’s reopening. But they also advised caution as there are still plenty of risks looming.
Chinese shipyards this year won 45 LNG tanker orders worth an estimated US$9.8 billion, about five times their 2021 order values.

site_title: Russia looks to press big firms for more cash as war costs mount
summary: Russia plans to increase revenue from state companies and trim non-defence spending to address mounting war costs, amid a squeezed budget due to US and European sanctions. The government aims to set dividends above 50% of net income for state companies and collect a "one-time payment" from fertilizer and coal producers. Authorities also plan to resettle 100,000 people from occupied Ukraine, indicating a lack of hope for retaking the region. The move aims to generate at least 150 billion roubles in savings, but the government's finances remain uncertain due to ongoing sanctions and budget deficits.

images.alt_text: The announcement comes following a request for a ceasefire during Orthodox Christmas from Russia’s 76-year-old Orthodox leader Patriarch Kirill.

site_title: Creative Tech sale, new strategic direction, board refresh could be on the cards
summary: Creative Technology's shares rose 25% after founder Sim Wong Hoo's death, with speculation of a potential sale of his 33.1% stake. Analysts suggest the buyer could decide to take the company private, offering a way out for long-holding shareholders. Alternatively, Sim's heirs could stay invested and promote a new C-suite team to turn the company around. Challenges for new owners include navigating the business and market expectations, but Sim's legacy could also attract investors.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
Creative founder and chief executive Sim Wong Hoo passed away on Jan 4, 2022.

, , pg 0, 

Sim Wong Hoo never wavered from his belief in the value of Creative Technology's audio technology even after the Sound Blaster's heyday had passed.
Sim founded Creative Technology in 1981 and the company designs, manufactures and distributes PC products. It now provides multimedia hardware and software products for use with PCs.
Sim Wong Hoo (pictured above), who has led homegrown electronics company Creative Technology since 1981, died on Wednesday (Jan 4).

site_title: World food prices end year where they started after dramatic run
summary: Global food prices ended 2022 roughly where they started, after a dramatic run due to the war in Ukraine and extreme weather. The UN's Food and Agriculture Organization reported a 1.9% decline in December, resulting in a 1% loss for the year, the first annual decline since 2018. Despite this, prices remain above their 10-year average, exacerbating a hunger crisis and global cost-of-living crunch. Prospects for 2023 depend on favorable weather and exports from major growers like Brazil and Russia.

images.alt_text: Crude palm oil (CPO) futures fell after Indonesia announced a policy shift in early June this year to encourage exports by cutting export levies.

site_title: Battery Ventures invests 200 million euros in European software duo
summary: Battery Ventures is investing 200 million euros in European software companies Vimcar and Avrios, aiming to consolidate the fleet-management software space in Europe. The investment, part of a "roll-up" strategy, will eventually merge the firms and create a dominant platform. Battery plans to increase profitability and growth, and the combined entity will have nearly 90% ownership. The deal is a rare bright spot in a market hit by decreased investor appetite for early-stage tech companies.

site_title: Sunak invites unions for summit talks as strikes spread
summary: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak has invited public-sector unions to summit talks as strikes spread across the country, affecting hospitals, railways, and other critical areas. The strikes are mainly over pay, with inflation reaching 11% in October, and are also driven by issues with working conditions and benefits. Sunak has expressed a willingness to negotiate, stating that he values the work of public-sector workers and wants an "honest, grown-up conversation" about affordability and responsibility. The government has also vowed to enact new legislation requiring a minimum level of key public services during strike action.

images.alt_text: Britain has faced a wave of industrial action over the last few months, with strikes crippling various sectors including the rail network set to continue as surging inflation follows more than 10 years of stagnant wage growth.

site_title: Half the world’s workforce works too much or too little: ILO
summary: The International Labour Organization (ILO) reports that half of the global workforce works either too much (more than 48 hours) or too little (less than 35 hours) per week, with average hours falling short of the normal range at 43.9 hours per week prior to the pandemic. The ILO suggests that flexible working arrangements can benefit both employees and employers, citing increased productivity as evidence. The organization concludes that work-life balance policies provide significant benefits to enterprises, supporting the idea that such policies are a "win-win" for both parties.

images.alt_text: Amazon.com’s layoffs will now include more than 18,000 roles as part of a workforce reduction it previously disclosed.
Amazon has been bracing for likely slower growth as soaring inflation forces businesses and consumers to cut back spending.
Professional and business services reported an additional 212,000 job openings, while vacancies increased 39,000 in nondurable goods manufacturing.
Leisure and hospitality, education and health services, professional and business services and construction have led jobs growth.
Tripartism was important in saving jobs, supporting workers and businesses, and protecting livelihoods during the pandemic, Manpower Minister Tan See Leng says.

site_title: UK construction activity falls by most since May 2020
summary: Britain's construction sector experienced its largest decline since May 2020, with the S&P Global/CIPS Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) dropping to 48.8 in December, below the forecast of 49.6. Rising interest rates and cost pressures led to a three-month growth sequence ending in decline. The sector's output rose 7.4% in the year to October, but falls in house building and civil engineering work, with commercial projects increasing slightly. The Bank of England estimates a shallow but potentially lengthy recession, with the construction PMI measure of input cost inflation at a two-year low.

images.alt_text: The UK's property market is weighed down by soaring interest rates and a tightening cost-of-living squeeze.

site_title: Travel curbs rack up as Covid-hit China readies reopening
summary: China has lifted its "zero-Covid" regime, ending quarantine requirements for inbound travelers starting Sunday. This move comes as the country struggles with a surge in COVID-19 cases, overwhelming hospitals and emptying pharmacy shelves. Over a dozen countries, including Greece, Germany, and Sweden, have demanded COVID-19 tests from Chinese travelers. China's official death toll stands at 5,264, but international health experts believe the true toll could be higher. The country's reopening is expected to boost its economy, which has suffered its lowest growth in nearly half a century, but the sudden change has raised concerns about the spread of the virus.

images.alt_text: As many as 76 per cent of Chinese travel agencies ranked South-east Asia as the top destination when outbound travel resumed, according to a survey released in December by trade show ITB China.

site_title: German industrial orders fall on weak foreign demand
summary: German industrial orders fell 5.3% in November, the steepest drop in over a year, due to weak foreign demand. Orders from eurozone countries dropped 10.3% and those from elsewhere fell 6.8%. High energy prices are weighing on the eurozone, according to VP Bank chief economist Thomas Gitzel. The Federal Ministry for Economic Affairs and Climate Action noted that industry is going through a difficult winter despite improved business expectations. Material shortages remain a problem, with 50.7% of manufacturing companies reporting issues in December.

site_title: Taiwan wants to join WTO talks on China’s protest against US chip sanctions
summary: Taiwan has asked to join World Trade Organization (WTO) talks on China's protest against US chip sanctions, seeking a voice in a debate that could impact the global chip industry. The island produces the majority of the world's most advanced semiconductors and its largest companies have abided by US-imposed export controls. China has filed a WTO dispute to overturn the US curbs, accusing Washington of economic protectionism. US trade officials will travel to Taipei for talks later this month, amid pressure from allies to support the restrictions.

images.alt_text: Dell told suppliers late last year that it aims to meaningfully lower the amount of China-made chips it uses.
Taiwan-based Foxconn makes electric vehicles for Lordstown Motors and has a contract to make Fisker’s second car model, Pear.
General Motors chief executive officer Mary Barra says the industry is planning for around 15 million cars this year.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Creative Technology's founder and sole shareholder Sim Wong Hoo has passed away, potentially leading to a change in the company's direction or ownership. The company's shares fell 0.5% amid a mixed regional market. Singapore fashion brands are gaining popularity, while Vietnam's Ho Chi Minh Stock Exchange is trading at historic lows, presenting a buying opportunity. Olam Agri plans a US$1 billion Singapore listing, and Vietnam's market correction could be a one-in-a-decade opportunity for investors.

site_title: Prince Harry’s book gets critical mauling in UK
summary: Prince Harry's memoir "Spare" has received widespread criticism in the UK, with many calling it "vengeful" and "calculated". The book, which details Harry's rift with the royal family, has been criticized for its perceived malice and lack of accuracy. British media outlets have panned the book, with some calling it "despicable" and urging Harry to "stop for his own good". The palace has remained silent on the matter, fueling speculation about the royal family's reaction to the book's contents.

images.alt_text: When Harry and Meghan stepped down from royal duties in 2020, they wanted to break from the royal family, but here they are, talking about it at length.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall tracking Wall Street retreat; STI down 0.5%
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.5% on Friday, mirroring a decline in US equities, as markets focus on US recession risk. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,276.72, with gainers beating losers 288 to 253. SPI Asset Management managing partner Stephen Innes attributed the decline to a vocal community expecting the Fed not to cut rates this year, boosting the US dollar.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
Hong Kong dipped after three days of gains that saw it add more than six per cent.
How markets fared in the new year.

site_title: Shell LNG trading provides quarterly boost despite output drop
summary: Shell's liquefied natural gas (LNG) trading operations are expected to have generated a quarterly boost despite a significant output drop in the fourth quarter of 2022. The company's LNG liquefaction volumes are forecast to be the lowest since 2016, due to prolonged outages at two major plants in Australia. Additionally, Shell expects to pay approximately US$2 billion in additional 2022 taxes related to European Union and British windfall taxes on the energy sector.

images.alt_text: In the first move that could hit supply, global major Shell paused accepting bids for gas under a plan to boost supply for Australia’s populous east coast in 2023 and 2024 while it assesses the government’s proposal.
With supply tight, businesses and consumers have been asked to reduce usage.

site_title: The value and worth of volunteer work
summary: Singapore's volunteer work rates remain low at 22-29% due to income disparities and an ageing population. Placing a dollar estimate on the value of voluntary work can help address the market underproduction of such valuable contributions to society. Studies suggest that volunteerism has intrinsic value, benefits individuals and companies, and can be a key driver for community-based programmes. To encourage volunteerism, strategies such as time banking, community recognition, and public awareness campaigns can be implemented. The government can also leverage public-private partnerships to promote volunteer work and allocate volunteers effectively.

images.alt_text:
msnvpc12 - P&G Pro Bono School on Sales, 2019.



Credit: Empact
OCBC staff volunteer Pamela Peh working with Food from the Heart’s senior manager of IT and facilities Timothy Lai to analyse data for community shops.
The launch the OCBC Arboretum at Singapore Botanic Garden involved the planting of 160 Dipterocarps trees by 180 OCBC and Bank of Singapore staff and their family members.

site_title: China property shares firm on more policy support, easing curbs
summary: China's property shares rose on Friday as the government announced plans to relax policy support and restrictions on borrowing for developers, easing curbs on the sector. The central bank will lower mortgage rates for first-time home buyers in cities where home prices have fallen for three consecutive months. China is also dialing back the "three red lines" policy, which restricts developers' borrowing, to help cash-strapped firms. This move is seen as a positive step for the sector, which was hit hard last year due to weak sales and investments.

images.alt_text: The easing could mark the most dramatic shift in China’s real estate policy, adding to a clutch of measures issued since November to bolster the battered sector that accounts for about a quarter of the nation’s economy.

site_title: Hong Kong-China border reopening sparks rush for limited quota
summary: Hong Kong's online registration system for mainland China travel was overwhelmed on its first day, with 250,000 bookings made in the first five hours, exceeding the daily quota of 60,000. The border reopened on Thursday, aiming to revive social and business ties with the mainland, but with restrictions including a 48-hour negative PCR test and limited land border checkpoints. The reopening is a step towards pre-pandemic levels, which saw an average of 640,000 trips per day in 2019. Officials plan to increase the daily quota, but the pace of recovery is uncertain.

images.alt_text: Authorities announced that widespread travel between Hong Kong and mainland China would resume from Sunday, initially allowing about 60,000 people a day to cross in each direction.
As many as 76 per cent of Chinese travel agencies ranked South-east Asia as the top destination when outbound travel resumed, according to a survey released in December by trade show ITB China.
The atrium of the ferry terminal in Macau has been empty; there will be 10 trips every day once ferry services resume.

site_title: US House speaker fight enters fourth day amid antebellum-era dysfunction
summary: US House Speaker Kevin McCarthy's bid for the position entered its fourth day, with a scale of congressional dysfunction not seen since before the US Civil War. Despite 11 failed floor votes since Tuesday, McCarthy remains hopeful, saying "we've got some progress going on" and "a little movement." However, a party rift between supporters and hardline conservatives continues, with some holding out for concessions on the speaker's role and potential term limits. The standoff has rendered the 435-seat House impotent, unable to formally swear in new members or scrutinize President Biden's administration.

images.alt_text: House Republican Leader Kevin McCarthy (R-CA) stands in the center aisle of the House Chamber after losing a 7th consecutive round of voting and before the start of an 8th round of voting for Speaker of the House on the third day of the 118th Congress at the U.S. Capitol in Washington, U.S., January 5, 2023. REUTERS/Evelyn Hockstein

site_title: Iron ore rises as China property support counters Covid worries
summary: Iron ore prices rose 1.9% on Friday, ending at $124.72 a tonne on China's Dalian Commodity Exchange, driven by optimism over China's policy support for the property sector. Despite this, the benchmark Dalian contract is down 1.3% for the week due to concerns about local Covid-19 outbreaks. The surge in iron ore prices counters worries about a decline in demand.

images.alt_text: A mechanical scoop unloads the iron ore aboard a bulk carrier cargo ship docked at an iron ore transfer and storage center operated by the Shanghai International Port Group in Shanghai, China, on Tuesday, Jan. 26, 2010. Iron ore for immediate delivery into China surged to $131.20 a metric ton on Jan. 8, the highest in at least 13 months, according to data compiled by The Steel Index, a venture of Steel Business Briefing Ltd. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

site_title: Vince McMahon plans WWE comeback, seeks board seats, strategic review
summary: Vince McMahon, WWE's former CEO, plans to return to the company as executive chairman and is seeking board seats. He proposes a strategic review to capitalize on the company's television rights renewal, which could lead to a potentially awkward family feud with his daughter, Stephanie McMahon, who currently runs the company. McMahon's return could also impact the board, which has been investigating him over payments for alleged sexual misconduct. Shares of WWE jumped 18% in after-hours trading following the announcement.

images.alt_text: WWE signs deal with Fanatics for e-commerce, collectibles
WWE said on Friday (Jun 17) it launched an investigation into alleged misconduct by longtime chief executive Vince McMahon and appointed his daughter Stephanie as interim head.

McMahon stepped down from his roles with WWE last month pending the results of an internal investigation after allegations he had an affair with an employee and paid her US$3 million to keep the matter secret.

site_title: McDonald's Japan hikes prices for third time in 10 months on surging costs
summary: McDonald's Japan announced its third price hike in less than a year, citing currency fluctuations and surging costs for materials, labor, and energy. The price increase affects about 80% of its menu items, with a single cheeseburger rising to 200 yen (S$2) from 140 yen. The Big Mac will cost 450 yen, up from 410 yen. This follows previous hikes in March and September, as Japan grapples with inflation and a slide in the yen, making imported ingredients more expensive.

site_title: Vietnam market correction represents once-in-a-decade buying opportunity: Maybank
summary: Vietnam's main stock exchange is trading at a 10-year low valuation, presenting an "attractive" arbitrage opportunity for investors, according to Maybank Securities. The benchmark VN Index has a trailing 12-month price-to-earnings ratio of about 10 times, lower than most regional indices. Analysts highlight bright spots in Vietnam's economic outlook for 2023, including a pro-growth government, China's reopening, and a planned CCP institution. This market correction is seen as a once-in-a-decade buying opportunity for investors.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo

The Ministry of Industry and Trade has asked fuel traders to increase their imports to compensate for the shortfall “to ensure sufficient fuels for the local market until the end of the first quarter,” the Vietnam government said.
The National Assembly voted to dismiss Deputy Prime Minister Vu Duc Dam from office during a four-day special session that began today (Jan 5).
The State Bank of Vietnam says it will manage monetary policy in a flexible way to keep inflation at 4.5 per cent next year.

site_title: China’s cascade of economic support measures spurs yuan buying
summary: China's offshore yuan advanced 0.4% to 6.8591 per dollar, extending its four-day gain to nearly 1%. The currency has jumped 7% since October 25, driven by policymakers' economic support measures to combat the Covid-battered economy. The People's Bank of China and banking regulator announced plans to lower mortgage rates and relax developer borrowing restrictions, supporting regional risk sentiment. The onshore yuan also gained 0.5% to 6.8504, its strongest level since August.

images.alt_text: Starting on Jan 1, the China Foreign Exchange Trade System (CFETS), which is overseen by the central bank, will lower the US dollar’s weighting in the CFETS currency basket to 19.83 per cent from 19.88 per cent.

site_title: UK house prices may decline by 8% this year: Halifax
summary: UK house prices are expected to decline by 8% this year due to soaring interest rates and a tightening cost-of-living squeeze. According to Halifax, the average home price fell 1.5% last month and 4.3% from its peak in August. The housing market will continue to be impacted by the economic environment, with a reduction in both supply and demand. The Bank of England's benchmark lending rate has increased nine times since 2021, driving up mortgage rates, and investors anticipate another rate hike this year.

images.alt_text: The latest data from the Bank of England underscores the effects of the cost-of-living crisis.
Eating out, takeaways and clothing were the things people said they’d cut first, pointing to weaker demand for retailers and hospitality firms in 2023.
Falling house prices and higher borrowing costs will drain more money from household balance sheets, making many homeowners feel poorer and perhaps more cautious about spending.
Extending the programme comes as Britain’s housing market is headed for its worst slump since the global financial crisis more than a decade ago.
British households are being squeezed by high energy bills, food costs and mortgage rates.
The survey results raise questions about how effective the BOE’s monetary policy will be in reining in inflation.

site_title: Three Arrows Capital liquidators demand documents via Twitter
summary: Three Arrows Capital co-founders Su Zhu and Kyle Davies have received formal demands for information related to the fund's downfall through Twitter, as liquidators try to unwind the crypto hedge fund. The pair's whereabouts are unknown and they are not fully cooperating. The move comes after a US bankruptcy judge approved a subpoena for Davies and a Singapore court order calling for Zhu's information. The liquidators claim the founders have resisted cooperating, leading to the use of Twitter to serve them discovery demands.

images.alt_text: Three Arrows Capital office in Singapore.Photographer: Suvashree Ghosh/Bloomberg

site_title: Standard Chartered faces fresh questions after report of Middle East bank’s takeover bid
summary: Standard Chartered faces fresh questions after First Abu Dhabi Bank (FAB) revealed it had explored a takeover bid for the emerging-market lender. The news sent shares higher as investors weighed the prospects of any deal, despite the enormous regulatory complexity of the potential acquisition. Analysts believe the bank's relatively small market value and exposure to fast-growing economies make it attractive, with some predicting a medium-term yield of double digits. The bank's CEO, Bill Winters, will have to explain why Standard Chartered is best off remaining independent despite years of lacklustre share performance.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians pass the headquarters of Standard Chartered Plc in London, U.K., on Monday, Feb. 14, 2022. European banks have largely thrived in the pandemic thanks to a flurry of dealmaking and unprecedented taxpayer support for the economy. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

site_title: Evergrande plans first in-person meeting with key creditor group
summary: Evergrande Group, China's most-indebted developer, is set to meet with a group of major offshore bondholders in Hong Kong on January 11, marking the first in-person meeting since the company became a defaulter over a year ago. The meeting is aimed at discussing a restructuring framework, with the ad-hoc group expected to present a counter-offer to Evergrande's proposal. The company's debt overhaul would be one of China's biggest ever, carrying broader implications for the country's $58 trillion financial system.

images.alt_text: The world’s most indebted developer failed to come up with a “preliminary restructuring plan” it promised by the end of July.

site_title: Indonesia’s new capital Nusantara imperils ancient Eden with ‘ecological disaster’
summary: Indonesia's new capital, Nusantara, set to replace sinking Jakarta, poses a significant threat to the world's third-largest island's biodiversity, with experts warning of an "ecological disaster." The 2,560-square-kilometer area, home to thousands of animal and plant species, will host 1.9 million residents by 2045, despite being a fragile ecosystem. Construction is set to ramp up this year, with environmentalists expressing concerns over deforestation, habitat destruction, and displacement of Indigenous communities. The government aims for carbon neutrality by 2045, but critics argue that the project's rapid pace and lack of oversight could exacerbate the problem.

images.alt_text: The central bank has issued a white paper to map out its digital currency, while a recently passed law recognises cryptocurrency and digital assets as regulated financial securities.

site_title: What to watch as China gives commodities a wild start to year
summary: China's commodities market is experiencing a volatile start to the year due to the nation's virus turbulence and policy shifts. Crude oil prices declined as demand was lacklustre, while copper rose on reports of potential policy easing by President Xi Jinping. China's uncertain path to recovery will steer commodities this year, with the US Federal Reserve's next moves also influencing gold prices. The energy crisis in Europe remains a concern, and the US jobs report will impact global monetary tightening.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures were 94 cents, or 1.2 per cent, higher at US$79.63 a barrel at 0345 GMT, after settling 85 cents stronger at US$78.69 on Thursday.
While China’s emergence from Covid Zero spurred talk of a demand boom from some of the market’s biggest names, a significant resurgence in energy consumption remains weeks, if not months away.

site_title: BT Market Focus: New cues from China as markets begin 2023 (Ep 26)
summary: Markets in the first week of 2023 saw China as a key driver, with new cues emerging from the country. According to SGX, the wrap for the week highlighted notable market movements. The newsdesk at The Business Times provided insights, while notable market-driving news included China's economic updates and inflation concerns. The podcast discussed how these factors impacted regional and global markets, providing analysis and insights for investors.

images.alt_text: How much damage has inflation inflicted on markets this week? Claressa Monteiro finds out.
Why did markets struggle to find inspiration this week?

site_title: Tensions rise between crypto lending rivals Nexo and Vauld
summary: Tensions escalate between crypto lending rivals Nexo and Vauld, with Nexo accusing Vauld of not acting in creditors' best interests. Nexo is attempting to acquire Vauld but claims the company is pushing for a "questionable" deal with an affiliated fund manager. Vauld has faced hardships, including freezing customer withdrawals and hiring advisers to explore a restructuring. The dispute is the latest setback for the crypto lending space, which has seen recent setbacks including Celsius Network's bankruptcy and Silvergate Capital's massive loss.

images.alt_text: Vauld and Nexo entered talks about a deal in July after Singapore-based Vauld froze withdrawals and hired advisers to explore a potential restructuring.

site_title: China may ease ‘three red lines’ property rules in big shift
summary: China is considering easing its "three red lines" property rules, a policy that restricted developer borrowing and contributed to the country's real estate crisis. The measures could allow developers to add leverage and push back debt targets, potentially boosting the battered sector. The easing could mark a significant shift in China's real estate policy, following a series of measures aimed at reviving the housing market. The move is expected to boost confidence in the sector, with some property stocks and bonds surging.

images.alt_text: China’s home sales continued to slump in December, with the 100 biggest developers seeing new home sales dropping 30.8 per cent from a year earlier.
China's property sales are expected to slip by a median of 8 per cent this year, a Reuters survey of eight economists and analysts showed, compared to a slump of around 25 per cent in 2022.

site_title: “Perfect Strangers” has been remade more than 20 times since 2016
summary: An Italian film "Perfect Strangers" has been remade over 20 times since 2016, becoming a valuable piece of intellectual property. The film, directed by Paolo Genovese, revolves around a dinner party where friends share their phone calls and texts aloud, revealing secrets and lies. The story's straightforward plot and cultural nuances have made it ripe for adaptation, with different versions showcasing varying social attitudes and themes. Despite Hollywood's interest in remaking the film, no English-language version has been produced, leaving the international market open to other countries.

images.alt_text: mobile phones, texting, hands
Academy Award-nominated director of District 9 Neil Blomkamp directs a cast that includes Lord of the Rings star Orlando Bloom and Stranger Things actor David Harbour.

In today's age of AI, the eerie central conceit of Pinocchio – the talking, walking puppet, lively yet not wholly alive, and the attendant issue of what makes a “real boy” – has never been more pressing or more provocative.

“Wakanda Forever” revolves around grief, loyalty, vengeance and territorial security, and its music – both the “inspired by” album and a separate “Original Score” album by Goransson – is largely somber, even ominous.

site_title: Crypto exchange Huobi to lay off 20% of staff: Justin Sun
summary: Huobi, a major cryptocurrency exchange, plans to lay off approximately 20% of its staff, according to Tron founder Justin Sun. The layoffs are part of a "structural adjustment" aimed at improving the exchange's solvency, which has been affected by the broader cryptocurrency market downturn. The move comes after a series of bankruptcies in the industry, including FTX, and is expected to be completed by the first quarter. Despite this, Huobi has seen an average of 20,000 new users over the past three months.

site_title: Singapore stocks decline on Friday; STI down 0.3%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.3% to 3,282.30, tracking overnight declines on Wall Street, amid anticipation of a US government jobs report for December. The decline followed solid hiring data in the US, which raised interest rate angst. Asian-Pacific Strategic Investment was the most traded counter, while CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust and OCBC fell. Banking stocks were mixed, with DBS and UOB experiencing losses, while OCBC gained.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
Markets continue to price in a more dovish fed as investors see ambiguity in the Fed's terminal rate.

site_title: Brokers’ take: UOBKH says Asean, Macau gaming stocks yet to fully price in return of Chinese tourists
summary: Asean and Macau gaming stocks are expected to see a strong recovery in gross gaming revenue (GGR) and earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization (EBitda) through 2023-2025, driven by the return of Chinese tourists. Genting Singapore is identified as a top sector "buy" pick due to its reliance on Chinese patronage. However, analysts at UOB Kay Hian (UOBKH) note that Macau gaming stocks' valuations have partially priced in recoveries, suggesting near-term consolidation.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Genting has casinos globally including in Malaysia, Singapore, the US and the UK. It does not currently operate in Macau.

The main casino floor during a media preview of Resorts World Las Vegas in Las Vegas, Nevada, U.S., on Tuesday, June 22, 2021. Photographer: Roger Kisby/Bloomberg
The chips are looking up for Genting Singapore
Resorts World Sentosa Singapore
Genting's Asean-listed gaming stocks 'set for winning streak' and higher dividend yields: UOBKH
Macau's non-gaming revenue averaged around 5 per cent of overall gaming revenue before the pandemic, and now that figure must grow to more than 30 per cent in the next decade.
China's reopening in January, and Macau’s own moves to scrap quarantine for overseas arrivals, paves the way for a major rebound for casinos in 2023.

site_title: Two ex-Keppel employees, steel company ex-manager charged with corruption
summary: Two former Keppel employees, Tan Seng Cheh and Wong Kok Seng, and an ex-Corus Sea employee, Thong Chee Kong, have been charged with corruption in a Singapore court. Thong allegedly gave Keppel's Tan a fake quotation from a competitor, leading to the sale of scrap steel to Corus Sea. Thong also paid for Tan's and Wong's trips abroad as gratification. Thong faces multiple charges, while Tan and Wong face charges punishable under Singapore's Prevention of Corruption Act.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
The latest development is not expected to have a material impact on its net tangible assets nor earnings per share on Keppel Corporation for the current financial year.
According to Keppel, this is the sixth offshore substation in its portfolio, including two such projects delivered in 2021 that are now operational in Taiwan.
Keppel's chief executive Loh Chin Hua said 2023 will be an important year for the company as it takes the “next leap forward” in its Vision 2030 trajectory.

site_title: Handling a family member’s account
summary: CFA Society Singapore highlights the importance of suitability assessments when handling family members' investment accounts. Finance professionals must consider a client's needs, circumstances, and objectives when determining the appropriateness of an investment. A case study involving a CFA charterholder who traded unit trust fund shares for his mother's account was deemed unsuitable due to the short-term nature of the trades and the lack of consideration for his mother's long-term investment horizon. The CFA Institute's Suitability Standard emphasizes the need for finance professionals to gather information and make a suitability analysis before making investment recommendations or taking action.

images.alt_text: Should a professional be recommended to investors, issues such as potential conflicts of interest and referral fees need to be disclosed.
A pedestrian walks past a residential building damaged by Russian shelling in Kherson on Dec 20, 2022, amid the Russian invasion of Ukraine.

site_title: Singapore fashion players head overseas as homegrown labels take off
summary: Singapore's homegrown fashion brands are gaining popularity, with some expanding overseas. Brands like SuitYourself and Love, Bonito are establishing themselves globally, with SuitYourself considering locations in Sydney and Love, Bonito opening a flagship store in Hong Kong. The Singapore Fashion Council is supporting local talent and education, while the government aims to attract big fashion brands to set up strategic offices in Singapore, potentially boosting the industry and creating demand for local fashion talent.

images.alt_text: New technologies present solutions for the fashion industry to meet its sustainability goals; others suggest changing consumption patterns instead.

site_title: Asia: Markets fluctuate after healthy start to the new year
summary: Asian markets fluctuated on Friday after US job data showed the labor market remained tight, suggesting the Federal Reserve will continue to raise interest rates. Hong Kong dipped after three days of gains, while Singapore and Wellington fell. Despite optimism over China's reopening, concerns over the country's economy and soaring infections weighed on markets. The US stock market's decline also impacted regional markets, with Tokyo, Sydney, and Seoul gaining. The Asian market's volatility is a result of long-running fears of a recession due to central bank policy tightening.

images.alt_text: The Straits Times Index falls 0.3 per cent or 10.36 points to 3,282.30, as at 9.01 am.

site_title: Brokers’ take: CGS-CIMB upgrades Grand Venture to ‘hold’ on new business prospects
summary: CGS-CIMB has upgraded Grand Venture Technology from "reduce" to "hold" due to expected progress in onboarding new customers and revenue contribution in the second half of FY2023. The research house revised its target price to S$0.52, up from S$0.40. Analysts expect the company's semiconductor business to continue making good progress, with sufficient capacity to absorb new orders at its Penang facility. However, they do not expect significant production impacts in China despite rising COVID-19 cases.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo

generic / ST20210126_202104438482 / Alphonsus Chern //

Grand Venture's Q3 revenue was dragged down by a general industry slowdown in the semiconductor segment.
Ricky Lee, executive chairman of Grand Venture Technology.

site_title: Sony Honda Mobility weighs future IPO for electric vehicle joint venture
summary: Sony Honda Mobility, a year-old electric vehicle joint venture, is considering a potential initial public offering (IPO) to raise funds for its high-value electric vehicles, including the Afeela model. Chairman Yasuhide Mizuno stated that an IPO is one of the options for raising funds, citing the significant costs of building such vehicles. The joint venture plans a global roll-out, including Europe, Asia, and the Middle East, with deliveries starting in the US in 2026 and Japan later that year.

images.alt_text: The prototype marks Sony’s attempt to stake a claim in the fast-growing market for electric vehicles.

site_title: Ringgit to continue strengthening in 2023 as investors regain confidence in Malaysia: analysts
summary: Malaysia's ringgit is expected to strengthen in 2023 as investors regain confidence in the country, according to Fitch Solutions analysts. The currency is projected to reach 3.1% inflation this year and 2.3% in 2024, potentially boosting its value further if Malaysia maintains lower inflation rates compared to the US. The analysts note that the ringgit has risen 7.7% against the US dollar since its trough in early November, suggesting limited further gains in the near term. This stability is attributed to Malaysia's efforts to shield its economy from tariff threats and shield it from political uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Malaysia prime minister Anwar Ibrahim said the health surveillance at all international entries will be strengthened, especially to tourist arrivals from countries with higher Covid-19 cases.

site_title: Japan's 10-year bond yield rises to hit BOJ upper limit as MOF raises coupon rate
summary: Japan's 10-year government bond yield rose to 0.5%, its highest since July 2015, after the finance ministry raised the coupon rate on 10-year Japanese government bonds. This move hit the central bank's policy band, which was widened to 0.5% from 0.25% last month. The yield increase is attributed to the Ministry of Finance's decision to raise the coupon rate, which was previously at 0.2%. The move is seen as a response to rising inflation and the central bank's efforts to control it.

images.alt_text: The BOJ on Friday announced an extraordinary JGB-buying operation for the third consecutive day, with super long-term bonds included.

site_title: Oil prices rise US$1 on China’s reopening optimism
summary: Oil prices rose US$1 on Friday, driven by optimism over China's reopening and potential demand boost, as well as lower US fuel inventories. China announced state support measures to boost its property sector, and daily passenger flights averaged 73% of pre-pandemic levels during the Lunar New Year. Despite concerns about a possible global recession, analysts attribute the price increase to China's reopening and a softened US dollar.

site_title: Geely’s EV brand Zeekr aims to double sales in 2023, expand in Europe
summary: Chinese electric vehicle brand Zeekr, a subsidiary of Geely, aims to double sales in 2023 to approximately 140,000 vehicles, mostly in Europe. Zeekr sold 72,000 vehicles in 2022, mostly in China. The company plans to expand in Europe with assisted driving systems and may produce vehicles for Waymo in the US. Zeekr has also filed for a US IPO, seeking a valuation of over $10 billion.

images.alt_text: A Zeekr IPO would be the first major US float of a Chinese firm since Beijing tightened its grip on overseas share sales in July last year.

site_title: ChatGPT creator OpenAI in talks for tender offer valuing company at US$29b: WSJ
summary: OpenAI, the creator of the viral chatbot ChatGPT, is in talks for a tender offer that would value the company at about US$29 billion. Venture capital firms Thrive Capital and Founders Fund will buy existing shares from existing shareholders, including employees. The deal is expected to attract at least US$300 million in investment. Microsoft, which invested US$1 billion in OpenAI in 2019, is reportedly working on a version of its search engine Bing using the AI behind ChatGPT.

images.alt_text: OpenAI, the AI research shop backed by a US$1 billion investment from Microsoft, publicly released ChatGPT for users to test in November.
ChatGPT is only the latest example of technology that seems to be able to carry out so-called "knowledge work".

site_title: SEA AiR – A pioneering arts project for our times
summary: The European Union Delegation to Singapore has launched the inaugural SEA AiR (Studio Residencies for Southeast Asian artists in the EU) exhibition, celebrating EU-Asean ties and promoting cultural exchange. The project, which began in 2022, brought together three Southeast Asian artists – Hoo Fan Chon, Citra Sasmita, and Vuth Lyno – for three-month residencies in European art institutions. The exhibition runs from January 10 to February 5, 2023, and features new works created by the artists during their residencies. SEA AiR aims to foster peer-to-peer cultural and artistic connections between Europe and South-east Asia, highlighting a region that has historically been under-represented in most artist residency programmes in Europe.

images.alt_text: National Gallery Singapore's Light To Night festival will feature live performances, large-scale installations, a market and other attractions.
Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong greets President of the European Council Charles Michel (left) and President of the European Commission Ursula von der Leyen. ST PHOTO: MARK CHEONG
The EU billed its first full summit with the Association of South-east Asian Nations (Asean) in Brussels as a chance to push trade relations with the region’s fast-growing economies.

site_title: Speaker vote on never-ending loop in Washington
summary: US lawmakers have entered a third day of a never-ending loop in the House Chamber, with no end to the voting process in sight. The impasse is largely due to Republican rebels, including members of the House Freedom Caucus, who are trying to prevent Kevin McCarthy's bid to become speaker.
