Bankman-Fried was extradited from the Bahamas to face US fraud charges.

site_title: HDB resale prices up 0.2% in December, the lowest gain in 30 months: SRX, 99.co
summary: HDB resale prices rose 0.2% in December, the lowest gain in 30 months, according to SRX and 99.co. Despite a 4.8% increase in resale volumes, overall prices were up 9.4% year-over-year. Property cooling measures, high interest rates, and buyer resistance to high prices continue to weigh on demand. Resale volumes in mature estates remained unchanged, while non-mature estates experienced a 0.3% price gain.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Real estate consultancy Knight Frank noted that the scant inventory of landed and non-landed homes on the market will continue to shrink in 2023.
Analysts expect about 16,000 flats to reach their minimum occupation period in 2023. In comparison, over 30,000 flats reached their minimum occupation period in 2022.
HDB flats in southern Singapore on Dec 22, 2022.

site_title: Hong Kong airport prepares for return to travel with bond sale
summary: Hong Kong International Airport is preparing to reopen its border with the mainland as early as January 8, with the Airport Authority planning to issue bonds to finance capital expenditure and environmental projects. The airport saw a significant increase in passenger arrivals in the first week of January, with 34,736 net arrivals compared to 4,439 net departures the previous year. This marks a major turnaround after the airport carried 4.05 million passengers last year, down from 71.5 million in 2019. The bond sale is expected to be priced as early as today.

images.alt_text: The start of 2023 has seen issuers globally rush to sell debt as borrowers are looking to take advantage of falling bond yields over the past couple of months.

site_title: Asia: Markets rally on 2023 outlook hopes, oil prices bounce
summary: Asia markets rose on Thursday, led by Hong Kong, driven by optimism over China's reopening and policy changes to encourage investment. Oil prices rebounded, but remain under pressure due to demand concerns. The upbeat mood was boosted by China's decision to allow Ant Group to raise $1.5 billion in funding and measures to support the struggling property sector. Analysts see medium-term prospects as bullish, especially if China bounces back strongly later this year.

images.alt_text: Tokyo fell more than 1.0 per cent on traders’ first day back from a long weekend.

site_title: Are good guys good for business?
summary: A highly empathetic CEO can lead to significant business success, as seen in Sheng Siong's 84% net profit jump in 2020. In contrast, CEOs like Elon Musk and Vishal Garg have been criticized for their ruthless actions, including firing employees without warning and terminating their access to company resources. These actions demonstrate that being a good leader is not only beneficial for employees but also for business reputation and success.

images.alt_text: The power of words
In picking his successor, former GE CEO Jack Welch believed that he fell for a candidate’s charm and political skills rather than choose the person who was the most likely to do the best job.

site_title: China’s December services sector extends declines as Covid cases surge: Caixin PMI
summary: China's services sector activity declined in December due to surging Covid infections, with the Caixin/S&P Global PMI at 48.0, below the 50-point mark for a fourth consecutive month. The decline in demand, caused by the new spread of the virus and China's removal of its zero-Covid strategy, has prolonged the contraction in the sector. Despite this, business confidence rose to a 17-month high. The data suggests the country's economic growth is set to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

images.alt_text: Weakening external demand amid slowing global growth continued to drag on orders for export-oriented producers,.

site_title: BOJ to raise forecasts for key inflation gauge: sources
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) is expected to raise its forecasts for the core-core consumer inflation index, which excludes fuel costs, due to robust domestic demand and sustained price rises. The upgrades would push the outlook closer to the BOJ's 2% target, indicating a growing conviction that inflation can be kept around the target in coming years. However, an immediate interest rate rise is unlikely due to ongoing annual wage negotiations and US interest rate hikes.

images.alt_text: Central bank governor Haruhiko Kuroda piled pressure on companies to hike salaries, saying it would underpin the Bank of Japan’s (BOJ) efforts to sustain prices around its 2 per cent inflation goal.

site_title: Singapore retail sales growth slows to 6.2% in November
summary: Singapore's retail sales growth slowed to 6.2% in November, the first single-digit growth in seven months, according to Department of Statistics data. Excluding motor vehicles, retail sales expanded by 8.7% year-on-year, while online sales accounted for 14.8% of total retail sales. Analysts expect retail sales to moderate in 2023 due to fading reopening tailwinds, high inflation, and moderating domestic GDP growth momentum. Discretionary spending categories such as clothing and jewelry showed signs of slowing, while food and beverage services experienced a 24.7% year-on-year growth.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
Singapore retail sales up 10.4% in October, extending growth

site_title: Japan tuna price soars past US$270,000 at New Year auction
summary: Japan's top-selling tuna at Tokyo's New Year auction sold for over $270,000, nearly doubling last year's price and breaking a pandemic trend of slumping demand. The 212-kilo bluefin tuna was sold by Michelin-starred sushi restaurant Onodera Group and Japanese wholesaler Yamayuki for 36.04 million yen (S$365,049). This marks a recovery for the symbolic auction after three years of slumping prices, still a fraction of the 2019 record price.

images.alt_text: The British celebration, which London’s mayor had branded the biggest in Europe, also referenced Queen Elizabeth II, who died in September, the red and white of England’s soccer team, and the rainbow colours of the LGBTQ Pride event, which had its 50-year anniversary in 2022.

site_title: China stats ‘under-represent’ true impact of Covid outbreak: WHO
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) criticized China's narrow definition of COVID-19 deaths, stating that official statistics underrepresent the true impact of the outbreak. China has recorded only 22 COVID-19 deaths since December, with a revised definition that requires respiratory failure associated with a COVID-19 infection for a fatality to be registered. The WHO urges China to provide more accurate and comprehensive data, while individual health professionals can help provide a more accurate picture. Globally, over 13 million COVID-19 cases were reported last month, and the true toll is likely much higher.

images.alt_text: China will stop requiring inbound travellers to quarantine from Jan 8.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel Corp, Asia-Pacific Strategic Investments
summary: Keppel Corp's offshore and marine arm secured a S$130 million contract to construct a 600 MW offshore substation, set for completion in 2025. Asia-Pacific Strategic Investments' 78.5%-owned subsidiary proposed to dispose of a hotel management company and assets for S$15.6 million, subject to shareholder approval.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu

site_title: China to open border with Hong Kong on Sunday
summary: China is set to reopen its border with Hong Kong on Sunday for the first time in three years, allowing quarantine-free travel between the financial hub and the mainland in a "gradual and orderly" manner. This move comes as China accelerates the unwinding of stringent Covid rules that have impacted its economic growth. Hong Kong residents have flocked to clinics to get vaccinated ahead of the border reopening, as China prepares to welcome international travelers and returning residents without quarantine requirements for the first time since 2020.

images.alt_text: People queue at a community vaccination centre, ahead of an expected border reopening with China, during the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic in Hong Kong, China, January 4, 2023. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu

site_title: Sony, Honda roll out prototype of ‘Afeela’ EV that uses Qualcomm tech
summary: Sony and Honda unveiled a prototype of their "Afeela" electric vehicle, which will use Qualcomm's Snapdragon digital chassis and feature over 40 sensors. The venture aims to deliver the first electric vehicles by early 2026 in North America, with the car priced at a premium. The Afeela will harness Sony's entertainment content and leverage Qualcomm's technology to enhance the cockpit experience, offering potential for subscription services and autonomous driving capabilities.

images.alt_text: The plant would be located in Kumamoto prefecture and Sony plans to bring it online in 2025 at the earliest.

site_title: Dubai rolls out 32 trillion dirham economic plan for next decade
summary: Dubai has unveiled a 32 trillion dirham economic plan for the next decade, aiming to double foreign trade and investment to 25.6 trillion dirhams by 2033. The plan includes boosting the manufacturing and logistics sector, with government spending to rise to 700 billion dirhams over the next 10 years. The emirate seeks to attract foreign direct investment of around 60 billion dirhams annually and remains a global financial hub despite growing regional competition.

site_title: Microsoft sinks as downgrade highlights cloud-growth concerns
summary: Microsoft's shares fell 4.4% on Wednesday, their largest one-day decline since October, after UBS Group downgraded the stock due to concerns over the company's cloud-computing business, Azure. The downgrade, which lowered Microsoft's price target to $250, highlights growing worries about Azure's growth and the company's ability to maintain revenue. Despite a 90% consensus recommendation to buy from analysts, the stock's valuation is seen as fair, not cheap, and the company's earnings and revenue forecasts have been scaled back.

images.alt_text: Like other big tech companies, Microsoft has recently been putting funds into self-driving technology.

site_title: Keppel O&M bags S$130m offshore substation deal
summary: Keppel O&M has secured a S$130 million contract to construct a 600 megawatt offshore substation in the Asia-Pacific region, set to be completed by 2025. This is Keppel's sixth offshore substation project, including two operational projects in Taiwan since 2021. The substation will be deployed to an offshore wind site upon completion, marking a significant milestone for the company's offshore and marine arm.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo

A worker stands in front of the Floatel Triumph, a semi-submersible accommodation rig operated by Floatel International Ltd. and developed by Keppel Offshore & Marine Ltd.'s deep water technology group, during a media tour in Singapore, on Friday, March 11, 2016. Keppel Corp., parent company of Keppel Offshore & Marine, is the world's biggest builder of oil rigs. Photographer: Nicky Loh/Bloomberg

site_title: Philippines December inflation at 14-year high as food prices jump
summary: The Philippines experienced its highest inflation rate in 14 years in December, reaching 6.9% due to spikes in food and energy prices. Core inflation also rose to 6.9% from 6.5% in November. Food inflation reached 10.6% in December, driven by commodities like vegetables and rice. The central bank may consider further interest rate hikes in 2023 to curb inflation and support the weak peso.

site_title: New Zealand housing slump to go on after worst drop since 2008
summary: New Zealand's housing market is expected to continue its decline, with average house prices falling 5% in December from the previous year, the largest drop since 2008. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) predicts a further 20% drop from the peak in late 2021, driven by aggressive interest-rate increases to combat inflation. Experts forecast rising home-loan rates will curb household spending and push property prices down further, with a recession likely in the near future.

images.alt_text: The December ANZ Consumer Confidence survey released earlier on Wednesday dropped to its lowest since it began in 2004.

site_title: Hot stock: Creative shares jump 40% following news of founder-CEO’s death
summary: Creative Technology's shares surged 40% to S$2 following the death of its founder-CEO Sim Wong Hoo. The last time the counter traded near such levels was in August 2022. The company, which designs and distributes PC products, recorded a US$11 million loss in FY2022, up from a US$7.6 million loss in FY2021. As of 2:30 pm, shares were traded at S$1.77, still up 25% from the previous session.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
Sim Wong Hoo (pictured above), who has led homegrown electronics company Creative Technology since 1981, died on Wednesday (Jan 4).
The company said H2 FY2022 revenue was negatively impacted by the “uncertain economic conditions resulting from unexpected global events”.

site_title: Gold prices steady ahead of US jobs data
summary: Gold prices held steady at $1,854.89 per ounce ahead of US jobs data, which could influence the Federal Reserve's policy trajectory. The ADP National Employment Report is due on Thursday, followed by the US Labour Department's nonfarm payrolls data on Friday. Spot gold rose to its highest level since June 13, while US gold futures edged 0.1% higher. The Federal Reserve's minutes showed officials agreed to slow interest rate hikes.

images.alt_text: Bullion is seen as a hedge against inflation, but rising interest rates dull non-yielding asset’s appeal.

site_title: UK’s PM vows better times when dismal winter ends
summary: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak vowed to bring economic growth, lower inflation, and shorter hospital waiting lists as Britain emerges from a "winter of discontent." Sunak promised a five-point plan, including halving double-digit inflation, but did not provide details on how to address ongoing strikes, including by nurses and train drivers. The opposition Labour party criticized the speech as vague and unambitious, with Deputy Leader Angela Rayner calling Sunak the "do-nothing prime minister."

images.alt_text: Citi says the survey showed a reduced risk of a recent 41-year high inflation rate becoming entrenched.

site_title: Brokers’ take: CGS-CIMB upgrades ISDN back to ‘add’ on brighter prospects
summary: CGS-CIMB upgrades ISDN Holdings' stock to "add" due to improved prospects, citing the company's achievement of commercial operation date for its first mini hydropower plant, Lau Biang 1, and expected sequential operational improvement in Q2 FY2023. The brokerage raises its earnings per share forecasts and price target to S$0.55, driven by 8.9 times price-to-earnings multiple. The upgrade comes after ISDN Holdings' president, Teo Cher Koon, announced the achievement, following a previous downgrade in November 2022.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
ISDN sees demand from Asian businesses seeking industrial automation to relieve labour wage pressure, advance manufacturing capabilities and reduce business risk.
ISDN Holdings' president Teo Cher Koon noted in the regulatory filing that the issue price of srip dividend was below the average market price.
ISDN H2 net profit rises to S$13.3m, proposes S$0.0145 final dividend

site_title: Green bonds are set to drive corporate ESG debt out of slump in 2023: Barclays
summary: Barclays predicts corporate ESG debt will rebound in 2023, driven by green bonds, after a 22% drop in 2022. ESG bond volumes are expected to reach $460 billion, with green bonds dominating the market. This growth is driven by strong demand for green projects and companies' decarbonisation plans. Sustainability-linked bonds, a newer instrument, are expected to be less popular due to concerns around greenwashing and KPIs. Barclays attributes the rebound to cheaper financing and investors' increased confidence in green bonds.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong’s government is proposing that the dollar tranche could be spread across three, five and 10-year tranches.

site_title: Western Digital, Kioxia are said to revive merger talks
summary: Western Digital has restarted merger talks with Japan's Kioxia Holdings, potentially uniting two technology storage providers. The companies, which have a joint venture producing flash chips, are discussing merging into one publicly traded company. This revival comes as the industry faces a crisis due to falling demand, prompting companies to consider partnerships to better compete with dominant player Samsung Electronics. The talks, which began late last year, are in the early stage and could end without an agreement.

images.alt_text: Elliott Management had said it offered over US$1 billion of incremental equity capital into Western Digital’s Flash business at an enterprise value of US$17 billion to US$20 billion.

site_title: Singapore shares rise on Thursday; STI up 1.1%
summary: Singapore shares rose 1.1% on Thursday, driven by overnight gains from major markets in the US and Europe. The Straits Times Index (STI) gained 36.6 points to 3,279.06 points, with gainers outnumbering losers 150 to 58. Index constituents such as Yangzijiang Shipbuilding and STI constituent Yangzijiang Shipbuilding slipped, but overall market sentiment remained positive.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
Keppel sky sign taken at Ocean Financial Centre.

site_title: Sim Wong Hoo, Singapore’s pioneering tech titan, dies
summary: Singapore tech titan Sim Wong Hoo, founder and CEO of Creative Technology since 1981, has died at 67. He led the company to become a well-known brand in the personal computer market and made history as the first Singaporean company to list in the US in 1991. Under his leadership, Creative developed innovative technologies such as Super X-Fi, a $100 million computational audio technology. Following his passing, the company has appointed interim executives and paid tribute to Sim's immense contributions to the company.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo

, , pg 0, 

Sim Wong Hoo never wavered from his belief in the value of Creative Technology's audio technology even after the Sound Blaster's heyday had passed.
Sim founded Creative Technology in 1981 and the company designs, manufactures and distributes PC products. It now provides multimedia hardware and software products for use with PCs.

site_title: Europe: Shares clock third day of gains on upbeat economic data
summary: European shares rose for the third consecutive session, with the pan-European Stoxx 600 closing 1.4% higher and France's CAC 40 jumping 2.3%. The gains were driven by a lower-than-expected inflation reading from France and better-than-expected business activity data, suggesting the eurozone recession may not be as deep as feared.

images.alt_text: The pan-regional Stoxx 600 rose 1.2 per cent on Tuesday, closing at its highest level in nearly three weeks.

site_title: US SEC pushes back on Binance.US deal to buy Voyager Digital
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has objected to Binance.US's plan to buy bankrupt crypto lender Voyager Digital, citing concerns over the lack of detail in the purchase agreement. The SEC requires more information about Binance's US operations and customer asset security following the deal. Binance.US has stated it will work to provide requested information and looks forward to completing the transaction. Voyager's lawyers will file revised documents addressing the SEC's concerns, with the agency reserving the right to amend its objection later.

site_title: Pakistani markets refuse to close early under government energy saving plan
summary: Pakistan's government has implemented a plan to close markets and restaurants early to save fuel, but they have largely been ignored. Major cities' markets in Lahore, Karachi, and Peshawar remained open past 8:30 pm, defying the directive. Traders and business owners fear the policy will harm their businesses and slow the economy, which is already struggling with inflation, floods, and energy costs. The government aims to reduce energy imports to curb foreign reserves depletion, but the plan's implementation has been met with resistance.

images.alt_text: The floods that inundated a third of the nation cut the nation’s growth by half, leaving about US$32 billion in damage and losses to the nation’s economy.

site_title: Link Reit’s entry into Singapore via Mercatus deal looks to be well-judged
summary: Hong Kong-listed Link Real Estate Investment Trust (Link Reit) has entered the Singapore market with the purchase of two suburban malls, Jurong Point and Swing By @ Thomson Plaza, for S$2.16 billion. The deal, completed on December 28, 2022, offers a 5% yield on commercial properties requiring active management, outperforming the cut-off yield of the last six-month Singapore Treasury bill issuance. Link Reit's entry is seen as strategic, diversifying into Singapore as Hong Kong's longer-term economic prospects are challenging, and offering a prescient timing given the potential for interest rates to peak soon and soften.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee
Mercatus said sale and purchase agreements were entered into on Wednesday with various subsidiaries of Link Reit to divest the group’s entire interest in Jurong Point and Swing By @ Thomson Plaza.

site_title: Samsung’s quarterly profit set to hit 6-year low as consumers hunker down
summary: Samsung's quarterly profit is expected to plummet 58% to its lowest in six years, reaching 5.9 trillion won, due to a global economic downturn and reduced demand for electronic devices. This is largely attributed to high inflation and climbing interest rates, causing consumers and businesses to cut spending and investment. Samsung's memory chip business is expected to see a 78% drop in operating profit, with its mobile business also expected to see a 14% decline. The company is expected to maintain its investment plans despite the downturn, aiming to expand market share for future recovery.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Samsung Electronics is seen at its headquarters in Seoul, South Korea, April 4, 2016. REUTERS/Kim Hong-Ji/File Photo

site_title: Amazon CEO says job cuts to exceed 18,000 roles
summary: Amazon CEO Andy Jassy announced that the company will cut more than 18,000 jobs, exceeding the previously disclosed 10,000 roles, due to a difficult economy and rapid hiring over the past few years. The layoffs, impacting 6% of the corporate workforce, will primarily affect e-commerce and human-resources organizations. The decision follows Amazon's recent base pay ceiling increase and stock price halving in the past year. The company plans to pay severance and has already begun letting staff go, with the cuts starting January 18.

images.alt_text: The online retailer has been bracing for likely slower growth, as soaring inflation forces businesses and consumers to cut back spending.

site_title: US Fed officials do not expect interest rate cuts this year
summary: US Federal Reserve officials do not expect interest rate cuts this year due to high inflation, which remains at a 40-year high. The Fed has maintained a restrictive policy stance to cool the economy, aiming to return inflation to 2%. Policymakers believe a sustained downward path in inflation is needed before reducing interest rates, and there is concern about unwarranted easing of financial conditions. The labor market remains tight, with low unemployment and robust wage growth, which could impact the economy.

images.alt_text: A sign indicating digital yuan, also referred to as e-CNY, at a shopping mall in Shanghai, China; May 5, 2021.

site_title: Hyundai and Toyota saw strong demand in December
summary: General Motors reclaimed its top spot in US sales in 2022, surpassing Toyota's sales of 2.1 million vehicles, according to estimates. Total US car sales likely fell below 14 million units in 2022, the lowest since 2011. Despite this, December sales showed strong demand, with 13.3 million new cars sold at an annual pace, up 7.3% from last year. Financing costs remain a concern, with average interest rates reaching 6.5% for new vehicles, prompting some buyers to reconsider pre-orders and increasing inventory.

images.alt_text: GM’s 2022 US sales are set to rise 2.3 per cent.

site_title: Sunak promises to tackle Britain's most pressing problems
summary: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak outlined five key promises to address Britain's pressing issues, including halving inflation, growing the economy, reducing debt, cutting National Health Service waiting lists, and stopping small boat crossings of illegal migrants. The ambitious plans aim to reassure his Conservative Party before the next election, which is expected in 2024. However, economists question the feasibility of some of these goals, citing the UK's economic recession and rising national debt.

images.alt_text: Rishi Sunak’s response has been to hold the line against what he sees as inflation-busting pay raises.

site_title: US House rejects Kevin McCarthy a sixth time despite Trump unity plea
summary: The US House of Representatives rejected Republican Kevin McCarthy's bid to lead the chamber for the sixth time, despite former President Donald Trump's call for unity. A small group of 20 holdouts in the party defied Trump's appeal, citing ideological differences with McCarthy. The leadership battle has provided a dismaying start for the new Republican majority in the House, raising concerns about the party's ability to advance its agenda ahead of the 2024 presidential election.

images.alt_text: Kevin McCarthy speaks with reporters at the Capitol, in Washington on Tuesday, Jan 3, 2022. McCarthy, the Republican party leader, fell short in a third vote as 20 Republicans rejected his bid and backed Jim Jordan.

site_title: China’s long-awaited reopening greeted with caution
summary: China is set to lift its border curbs on January 8, sparking global concern over the potential return of millions of Chinese tourists and the risk of a COVID-19 resurgence. Many countries, including the US, Britain, and Italy, have announced new entry restrictions, while others like Singapore and Thailand are allowing direct flights with minimal health controls. China has condemned these measures as "discriminatory" and "unscientific," but the lack of transparency around its COVID situation and rising cases in the under-vaccinated population have fueled concerns. The World Health Organization has called for detailed data sharing from China to assess the risk.

site_title: US job openings remain elevated; manufacturing slump continues
summary: US job openings fell 54,000 to 10.458 million in November, slightly less than expected, amid a tight labor market. Professional and business services saw a 212,000 increase in job openings, while nondurable goods manufacturing vacancies rose 39,000. The job openings rate remained at 6.4%, while hiring decreased to 6.055 million. The Federal Reserve is expected to boost interest rates to tame inflation, with economists predicting higher borrowing costs. A separate report showed input prices plummeting to their lowest level since 2016, reflecting fading demand for goods.

images.alt_text: The Fed has waged an all-out campaign to cool the world’s biggest economy as inflation surged to a 40-year high last year, raising the benchmark lending rate seven times to ease demand.

site_title: Oil falls by more than 5% on global economy worry, China Covid cases
summary: Oil prices plummeted on Wednesday, with Brent falling 9.4% and US crude shedding 5.3% as concerns over the global economy and rising Covid-19 cases in China drove demand destruction. The decline was also influenced by the Federal Reserve's rate hikes and under-represented Covid-19 death tolls in China. US manufacturing contracted further in December, and job openings fell, raising concerns about the Fed's rate hikes. Opec oil output rose in December, but concerns about oversupply persisted.

images.alt_text: West Texas Intermediate fell toward US$76 a barrel after sinking 4.2 per cent on Tuesday (Jan 3), in the biggest drop since November.

site_title: With big bets on Musk, these funds may have a Tesla problem in ‘23
summary: US equity funds heavily invested in Tesla have suffered significant losses, with 50 actively managed funds holding over 5% of their assets in the company, dropping an average of 42.1% last year. The US$6 billion Baron Partners Retail fund, which led all US mutual funds with 52% of its assets in Tesla shares, fell nearly 43% last year. Tesla's stock has declined 65% in 2023, accelerating after CEO Elon Musk's acquisition of Twitter, which some investors see as a distraction. Analysts predict that some institutional investors may reduce their positions, but others believe Tesla's superior battery technology and recent promotions will help it outperform in the long run.

images.alt_text: The Korea Fair Trade Commission (KFTC) said that Tesla had exaggerated the “driving ranges of its cars on a single charge, their fuel cost-effectiveness compared to petrol vehicles as well as the performance of its Superchargers”.

site_title: Coinbase to pay US$100m to settle New York state investigation
summary: Coinbase has agreed to pay a $100 million settlement to New York's Department of Financial Services (DFS) following an investigation into the company's compliance with anti-money laundering regulations. The DFS found that Coinbase treated its onboarding requirements for customers as a "simple check-the-box" and had not done sufficient background checks, resulting in a $50 million penalty. The settlement caps the regulator's investigation into the firm's compliance with requirements to prevent money laundering.

site_title: UK businesses brace for falling profits during 2023 recession
summary: UK businesses are bracing for falling profits in 2023 due to a recession, according to the British Chambers of Commerce. Only one in three companies expect profits to increase, while 36% anticipate a decline. Business confidence is near its lowest levels since the pandemic, with 67% of firms reporting no change or decline in activity. The economy is suffering from high inflation, supply chain issues, and a slump in trade following Brexit. The BCC urges the government to provide clarity on an energy support package to help firms.

images.alt_text: Rishi Sunak did not offer any details, or on how he will end a wave of strikes including by nurses and train drivers that has stoked a sense of national paralysis this winter.
Citi says the survey showed a reduced risk of a recent 41-year high inflation rate becoming entrenched.

site_title: Finding a niche in protected piping
summary: Almarc Engineering has established a niche in providing bespoke corrosion-resistant piping systems, catering to high-purity applications in industries such as pharmaceuticals, food, and chemical processing. The company's PTFE/PFA lined pipes are used by major clients like Pfizer and GSK, and its expertise allows it to address demand not met by mainstream providers. Since its establishment in 2015, Almarc has developed a reputation for swift and specialized solutions, solidifying its position in the market.

images.alt_text: The CK Shipping team, led by group chief executive officer Ken Ngan (centre, seated).
Credibility and trust are two things MaxSteel cannot afford to lose, said founder and chief executive officer Henry Ng.

site_title: Trade pacts will help drive India’s economic rise
summary: India has successfully signed its second trade deal for 2022, the Australia-India Economic Cooperation and Trade Agreement (AIECTA), which came into effect on December 29. The deal aims to boost trade, particularly in pharmaceuticals, textiles, and electronics, and remove a major tax issue for Indian IT companies. India is expected to increase its domestic manufacturing as a share of GDP and exports, with the government aiming to reach 25% of GDP and 1.5% of global exports. The deal marks a significant shift for India, which has broken a decade-long gap in signing free trade agreements with large economies, and is seen as a key driver of the country's economic rise.

images.alt_text: British trade minister Kemi Badenoch, who was appointed to her role in September, will meet Indian Trade Minister Piyush Goyal and address the negotiating teams before the round of talks begins.
A cashier checks Indian rupee notes inside a room at a fuel station in Ahmedabad, India. Earlier this year, India overtook the UK to become the world's fifth-largest economy.

site_title: Salesforce gains on plan to cut jobs, offices amid slowing sales
summary: Salesforce plans to cut about 8,000 employees, approximately 10% of its workforce, and reduce its real estate holdings amid slowing sales. The reductions will cost the company $1.4 billion to $2.1 billion, with $1 billion expected in the fiscal fourth quarter. CEO Marc Benioff acknowledged the company hired too many people during the pandemic and is now adjusting to more cautious spending by customers. The cuts are seen as an attempt to meet its adjusted operating margin goals and improve profit margins.

site_title: Omicron subvariants driving China's latest Covid outbreak, says WHO
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has reported that the latest Covid-19 outbreak in China is primarily driven by Omicron subvariants BA.5.2 and BF.7, which account for 97.5% of local infections. The data, based on over 2,000 genomes, aligns with global sequencing data and shows no new significant variants or mutations. This comes as concerns grow about the rapid spread of the virus in China, the world's second-largest economy.

site_title: From online to the malls, K-pop merchandise is making a big splash
summary: K-pop merchandise stores in Singapore are thriving, with physical shops opening at malls across the island, catering to fans of all ages. House of Kpop and Infinity Kpop have expanded their operations, offering a wide range of merchandise and creating social experiences through activities such as photo booths and lucky draws. Fans prefer brick-and-mortar stores for the tactile experience, ability to browse and compare products, and reliability, citing concerns over scams and delayed group orders. The businesses also provide a space for fans to connect with each other, making shopping a social activity.

images.alt_text: Singapore retail sales up 10.4% in October, extending growth

site_title: US: Stocks shrug off Fed minutes to break losing streak
summary: US stocks closed higher on Wednesday, snapping a brief losing streak, despite the Federal Reserve's commitment to lowering inflation. The tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index rose 0.7% to 10,458.76 and the S&P 500 gained 0.8% to 3,852.97, driven by survey data showing US manufacturing activity remained in contraction. The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed 0.4% higher. Fed policymakers do not expect to cut interest rates this year, citing a need for a restrictive stance until inflation signs improve.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 28.77 points, or 0.09 per cent, at the open to 33,165.14.

site_title: Government likely to achieve balanced budget in current term despite Covid deficit
summary: Singapore's government is expected to balance its budget for the current term, despite a record S$51.6 billion overall budget deficit in financial year 2020, due to tapping past reserves. The Constitution requires a balanced budget, but there is no legal requirement to return the drawn reserves. Analysts expect the government to meet its fiscal target, with revenue from taxes, including property and personal income taxes, and a domestic top-up tax, helping to offset the deficit. The government's fiscal discipline will be tested as it prepares for rising government expenditure due to an ageing population.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
The government will provide an additional S$1.4 billion to the Assurance Package to help households cope with higher inflation, said Finance Minister Lawrence Wong in Parliament.

site_title: Public health remains Malaysia’s top priority over tourism and economic growth: PM Anwar
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim has reaffirmed the country's priority on public health over tourism and economic growth, citing the need to strengthen health surveillance at international entry points, particularly for arrivals from countries with higher Covid-19 cases such as China and the US. Measures include fever screenings and testing for suspected cases, as well as wastewater sampling. Anwar stressed that the government is not discriminating against any country and will not relax rules despite China's reopening.

images.alt_text: Tan Ai Leng
The recovery in international travel and tourism, particularly with China's border reopening, may help to  cushion Singapore's economic slowdown in 2023, economists said.

site_title: Indonesian coal giant Adaro Energy in big push to become greener
summary: Indonesian coal giant Adaro Energy is shifting towards a greener future, with a focus on reducing emissions and increasing renewable energy production. The company, led by CEO Garibaldi Thohir, has installed rooftop solar panels and floating solar panels, reducing CO2 emissions by 515 tonnes annually. Adaro is also developing an aluminum smelter in North Kalimantan's green industrial estate, which will be powered by renewable energy and meet the growing global demand for aluminum. The company aims to become a more sustainable business through long-term initiatives and is exploring partnerships to support its growth.

site_title: US manufacturing sector contracts, prices decline in December: ISM
summary: US manufacturing contracted further in December, with the ISM PMI dropping to 48.4, its weakest reading since May 2020. Weakening demand amid higher borrowing costs pushed prices paid by factories for inputs to a 2½-year low, signaling goods disinflation. Despite a second straight month of contraction, the labor market remains strong, and consumer spending continues to sustain the economy. A PMI reading below 50 indicates contraction, but economists believe the economy is unlikely in recession. Goods price increases have slowed, and economists expect goods deflation this year.

images.alt_text: Last September, Burry had warned of more pain for the stock market, saying: “We have not hit bottom yet.”

site_title: 2023 – a time of living dangerously for region’s tech players ?
summary: Southeast Asia's tech sector faces a challenging 2023, with many companies pivoting, consolidating, or struggling to survive due to economic headwinds, including high inflation, interest rates, and ongoing supply chain disruptions. Despite this, the region's strong fundamentals, young population, and digital economy growth potential remain promising. The e-commerce sector is expected to continue growing, with a projected 17% CAGR, and Web3 technologies, such as blockchain and tokenisation, are expected to be disruptive. Experts predict significant merger and acquisition activity, cost-cutting, and layoffs, but also opportunities for nimble startups and corporations.

images.alt_text: The app of Indonesian e-commerce company Bukalapak, which is among the unicorns that have suffered share price drops. The shares of Bukalapak and Singapore-based Grab Holdings have fallen more than 65 per cent since their IPOs.

site_title: Older resale flats favoured, thanks to their larger size and greater affordability
summary: The proportion of older HDB flats sold in Singapore has more than doubled over the last decade, from 15% in 2012 to 37% in 2022, driven by demand for larger and more affordable resale flats. The oldest flats, with remaining leases of 44-65 years, account for the majority of sales, followed by those with 66-85 years of lease left. The data also shows a decline in transactions involving flats with 66-85 years of lease left, as they are increasingly being sold into the oldest category.

images.alt_text: HDB flats as viewed from Block 79D Toa Payoh Central on March 17, 2022.

site_title: India approves US$2b incentive plan for green hydrogen
summary: India has approved a $2.8 billion incentive plan to promote green hydrogen production, aiming to cut carbon emissions by 50 million tonnes and establish the country as a global hub for the clean energy source. The Strategic Interventions for Green Hydrogen Transition Programme will support the production of 5 million tonnes of green hydrogen per year by 2030, reducing reliance on grey hydrogen made from fossil fuels. The plan aims to make green hydrogen affordable and reduce production costs, with investments expected to reach $8 trillion by 2030.

images.alt_text: Australia's OneSteel Whyalla Steelworks plant. 2023 will likely see steel producers tackle the significant hurdles facing them to take concrete steps toward low-carbon steel production, analysts said.
The Indian government expects industry to invest 8 trillion rupees in green hydrogen and its derivative green ammonia by 2030, said the industry manager and another government official.

site_title: Agri-commodity prices to ease as growth slows, but upward pressure remains amid macro woes
summary: Agricultural commodity prices are expected to ease in 2023 due to a slowing global economy and a higher base effect. However, prices will likely remain high by historical standards due to macroeconomic uncertainty. The Russia-Ukraine war and tight supply due to weather conditions pushed prices to multi-year highs in 2022, but some commodities have since pared gains. Analysts expect a "broad easing" of prices in 2023, with some commodities, such as soybeans and sugar, ending the year on a higher note, while others, like coffee and palm oil, closed out the year lower.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
Indonesia wants to ensure ample domestic supply during the Ramadan and Eid holidays in April, as production will be seasonally weaker in the first quarter.

A labourer separates grains of wheat from the husk at a wholesale grain market in Ghaziabad on May 17, 2022. - The United States hopes that India will reverse its decision to ban exports of wheat, which will worsen global shortages of the commodity, Washington's top diplomat to the United Nations said on May 17. (Photo by Prakash SINGH / AFP)
According to existing laws, an export ban on unprocessed mineral ore such as bauxite and copper is due to take effect in June 2023.
The exports of manufacturing and mining goods in Malaysia continued to rise in November but agriculture goods were declining due to lower exports of palm oil and palm oil-based products.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher with focus on Fed minutes
summary: US stocks opened higher on Wednesday, driven by hopes of an economic recovery in China and the release of Federal Reserve minutes. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 28.77 points, or 0.09%, to 33,165.14, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained. The focus on Fed minutes provided insight into interest rate hikes, contributing to the market's optimism.

site_title: Green lending tops fossil fuel as big oil gets cash elsewhere
summary: For the first time, more money was raised in debt markets for climate-friendly projects ($580 billion) than for fossil-fuel companies ($530 billion) in 2022, according to Bloomberg data. However, this trend may not be a sign of green financing overtaking fossil fuel lending, as high oil prices have freed energy companies from capital market dependence. Instead, Big Oil is likely getting more money from alternative sources.

images.alt_text: The IEA said one in every eight cars sold globally is now electric.

site_title: Microsoft to invest in autonomous trucking startup Gatik: sources
summary: Microsoft is in talks to invest over $10 million in Gatik, a California-based autonomous driving startup, valuing Gatik at over $700 million. As part of the deal, Gatik will use Microsoft's Azure platform to develop autonomous delivery technology for trucks, leveraging cloud and edge computing capabilities. The terms of the deal are subject to change, and both Microsoft and Gatik declined to comment.

images.alt_text: General Motor’s autonomous vehicle unit Cruise says it will deploy driverless taxis in San Francisco in a first for a major US city.
Google, which dominates online mapping, was notably absent from the list of companies teaming up in Overture, which said its goal is to expand membership to speed up progress.

site_title: China ready to resume oil and gas talks with the Philippines, says Xi
summary: China President Xi Jinping announced his country's willingness to resume oil and gas talks with the Philippines, amid previous tensions over maritime issues in the South China Sea. Xi proposed joint exploration of non-disputed areas, cooperation on solar and wind energy, and increased imports of fishery products. The move comes as Xi reopens China's borders to the world after three years of isolation, following a three-day visit by Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. The agreement aims to manage maritime issues "cordially" and pave the way for increased cooperation on various sectors.

site_title: At CES 2023, Sony’s Gran Turismo flags new entertainment strategy
summary: Sony is transforming into a content-driven company, with its Gran Turismo film adaptation at CES 2023 showcasing its new identity. The film reflects the company's shift from hardware-focused innovator to broad-based entertainment provider. This transformation is part of a broader strategy that includes investments in music, games, and anime, with a total of $10 billion spent over the past five years. Sony's "creative entertainment" company approach extends beyond content, with plans for an electric vehicle and recurring subscription revenue. The company's new strategy aims to unite its divisions and deliver results, with a focus on delivering entertainment content.

site_title: New chapter for Pope Francis after death of Benedict XVI
summary: Pope Francis enters a new phase of his papacy following the death of Pope Benedict XVI, who passed away at 95. The former pope's presence at the Vatican had caused confusion, fueling conservative criticism of Francis' reforms. Despite this, Francis has carried out significant reforms, including a reorganization of the Roman Curia and increased transparency in Church finances. However, conservative forces are likely to continue criticizing Francis' policies, and his comments about potentially stepping down may reignite the "two popes" phenomenon.

images.alt_text: Benedict died on Saturday at the age of 95 in the secluded Vatican monastery where he had lived since 2013 when he became the first pope in 600 years to resign.

site_title: US dollar falls as Europe’s inflation cools and China lifts the Aussie
summary: The US dollar fell against the euro and Australian dollar, gaining 0.5% and 2.3% respectively, as European inflation data showed a cooling trend, sparking hopes that the European Central Bank may slow its rate hikes. China's relaxation of COVID restrictions also boosted the Aussie dollar. The euro rose 0.82% against the US dollar, while the yen and sterling also gained ground. The offshore yuan rose 0.47% against the US dollar, near its strongest level in four months.

site_title: China discussing easing of ban on Australia coal imports
summary: China's National Development and Reform Commission is discussing plans to resume imports of Australian coal after a two-year ban, with potential imports starting as early as April 1. The ban was implemented in late 2020 amid hostilities between the two nations, but relations are improving with a recent visit by Australian Foreign Minister Penny Wong. Resuming imports could boost Australian coal prices and improve China's relations with Australia, while also limiting competition from European-led restrictions on Russian energy.

site_title: Foreign investors dump UK gilts at record rate despite Sunak’s austerity drive
summary: Foreign investors sold a record £38.4 billion of UK government bonds between September and November, raising concerns about the weak pound and rising borrowing costs. Despite Prime Minister Rishi Sunak's austerity drive, the trend of foreign investors shifting out of government bonds poses problems for the government in the next financial year, when it needs to raise over £300 billion. A weak pound would drive up the cost of imported goods and higher government bond yields would push up borrowing costs across the economy.

images.alt_text: After one failed attempt at becoming prime minister last year, Rishi Sunak took on the job after his predecessor, and one-time rival, Liz Truss was forced from power in October after just 44 days when markets rejected her unfunded tax-cutting plans.
A cash tray holding British pound banknotes and coins in the UK. From its October low of 1.03 against the US dollar, the pound has rallied by about 17 per cent to 1.21 as of Dec 27.
The latest data from the Bank of England underscores the effects of the cost-of-living crisis.

site_title: China markets kick off 2023 with a bang as policy shift quickens
summary: China's stock market kicked off 2023 with a 5.3% gain, its best start since 2009, as investors became optimistic about Beijing's policy shift towards easing Covid-19 curbs and economic pragmatism. The MSCI China Index rose, with debt-laden property developers and technology firms leading the rally. The yuan reached a four-month high, and US dollar bonds of distressed developers surged. Beijing's new measures to ease the property debt crisis and approval for private equity funds to raise money for residential housing developments lifted sentiment, bringing relief to investors after years of geopolitical tensions.

images.alt_text: People wearing protective face masks arrive at Capital Airport, following an outbreak of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19), in Beijing, China, November 5, 2020. REUTERS/Thomas Peter
An Electric Multiple Unit high-speed train for a rail link project, part of China's Belt and Road Initiative, at the Tegalluar train depot in Bandung, West Java, Indonesia, October 2022.

site_title: UK public’s expectations of future inflation down in December
summary: The UK public's expectations for future inflation have decreased, according to a survey by Citibank and YouGov. The average expectation for inflation in 5-10 years dropped to 3.6% in December, down from 3.9% in November, reducing the risk of a 41-year high inflation rate becoming entrenched. This decrease is attributed to the government's temporary energy tariff cap announcement in August. The Bank of England closely watches these surveys for guidance on future wage demands and cost pass-through.

images.alt_text: After one failed attempt at becoming prime minister last year, Rishi Sunak took on the job after his predecessor, and one-time rival, Liz Truss was forced from power in October after just 44 days when markets rejected her unfunded tax-cutting plans.

The S&P Global/CIPS UK manufacturing Purchasing Managers’ Index (PMI) sank to 45.3 in December from 46.5 in November, its lowest since May 2009 apart from two months at the start of the Covid-19 pandemic in 2020.

site_title: Global bonds extend New Year rally on signs inflation has peaked
summary: Global bond markets continued their rally in 2023, with European bonds leading the way, extending a strong start to the year. Investors are optimistic about slowing inflation and slowing growth, driving up yields on sovereign debt. The 10-year German benchmark rose for a third day, while Italian debt outperformed, narrowing its yield gap with Germany to its narrowest in three weeks. This confidence is prompting investors to buy into yields at multi-year highs, despite concerns about future growth.

images.alt_text: The selling came on the heels of the BOJ’s move in December to double the cap on the benchmark yield and hints at expectations for a further change in policy settings.

site_title: BMW more than doubles fully-electric vehicle sales in 2022
summary: BMW more than doubled its fully-electric vehicle sales in 2022, reaching 10% of total sales, with 2.4 million cars sold. The core BMW brand sold 2.1 million vehicles, down from 2.2 million in the previous year due to coronavirus lockdowns in China and European inflation. The company plans to increase battery electric vehicle sales to 15% of total sales in 2023.

site_title: PBOC will keep liquidity reasonably ample in 2023
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), plans to maintain reasonable liquidity levels in 2023 to support the economy, while mitigating financial risks. The PBOC will increase financing support for domestic consumption and key investment projects, as well as maintain a stable real estate market. The central bank aims to stabilize growth, employment, and prices, and prevent major financial risks. This move comes as Chinese leaders face pressure to boost the economy due to faltering demand at home and abroad.

images.alt_text: On top of repeated Covid outbreaks, China’s economy in 2022 muddled through a persistent property market slump, sluggish consumer demand and waning overseas appetite for its goods.

site_title: A tech ‘golden age’ awaits supply chains limping out of the pandemic
summary: A tech "golden age" is expected in the global logistics industry as supply chains transition from manual, tech-deficient systems to seamless, digital networks. Following the pandemic's disruptions, companies are investing heavily in digital solutions, including artificial intelligence, automation, and real-time tracking. The industry is seeing a surge in funding, with venture capitalists and private equity investors pouring in $9 billion a quarter since 2020. Key players, such as Flexport and Maersk, are racing to digitize all stages of transactions, and companies are expected to reap significant economic benefits from this transformation.

images.alt_text: Pressure mounts on companies to critically focus on their suppliers and actively assist them in reducing their carbon footprint as it would ultimately add to their “own” emissions.
While global supply chains are stabilising somewhat, business and industry aren't yet out of the woods.
Since air freight relies on passenger traffic for capacity, it was one of the most volatile logistics links during the pandemic when passenger carriers were grounded.

Container freight rates have fallen by between 40 and 80 per cent in the last six months. But this was from record highs, fuelled by a surge in consumer demand and supply chain congestion issues caused by Covid-19.

site_title: UK housing market stalls, credit card borrowing rises
summary: The UK housing market slowed in November, with mortgage approvals reaching 46,075, the lowest level since June 2020. Consumer credit rose by £1.5 billion, driven by a £1.2 billion increase in credit card borrowing, the largest such jump since 2004. The data underscores the effects of rising interest rates and the cost-of-living crisis.

site_title: ‘Overboarding’: why it has become a hot issue for companies
summary: Corporate boards are facing pressure from shareholders to limit the number of directorships held by executives, as "overboarding" has become a growing issue. Despite numerical limits, directors argue that these are arbitrary and do not account for individual time management and expertise sharing. The lack of nuance in assessing board positions has led to unease among directors, with some declining offers of board seats or chairs to avoid investor wrath. The issue is particularly pressing in a heightened regulatory environment and amid global crises, where boards need to provide greater support to companies.

images.alt_text: Singapore should not be a laggard when it comes to corporate governance practices such as the disclosure of executive remuneration, but should move the needle, said June Sim, head of Listing Compliance, SGX RegCo. (PHOTO: BT)

site_title: Blackstone offers backstop to lure University of California in redemption-stricken Reit
summary: Blackstone has secured a $4 billion investment from the University of California in its unlisted real estate income trust (Breit) to backstop investor redemptions. UC Investments will hold its investment for at least six years in exchange for $1 billion of Blackstone's own investment. The deal aims to stabilize Breit, which has seen significant investor redemptions due to market turmoil. Blackstone will receive 5% of profits above a 11.25% annualized return threshold, and UC Investments will pay management fees of 12.5% of profits and 1.25% of total investment.

images.alt_text: The US$68 billion Blackstone Real Estate Income Trust (Breit) has been grappling with an increase in investors pulling money, particularly from Asia
The withdrawals are the highest since the fund was established in January of 2021.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Grab observes "continued and steady demand" for food delivery since Singapore's reopening last year. Demand for food delivery remains higher than pre-pandemic levels, according to food delivery platforms and F&B players. Leverage ratios for Singapore-listed real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) Kore and Prime US Reit are expected to remain below 45%. Telecoms provider Comba Telecom closed its debut on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) at S$0.255, roughly on par with its Hong Kong shares.

site_title: Nexus Venture eyes US$700m fund to bet on India, US tech startups: sources
summary: Nexus Venture Partners, a Mumbai-based venture capital firm, is in talks to raise a $700 million fund to invest in Indian and US-based technology startups. The new fund will be its seventh and will expand the firm's assets under management to over $2 billion. The firm plans to invest in early-stage funding rounds of Indian internet and technology startups, as well as US-based software firms. Nexus believes investing in US software firms will provide stability, while betting on India's rapidly growing tech sector. The fund's close is expected within two months.

images.alt_text: iPhones on display at the new Apple Inc. store, due to open to the public on Thursday, in the Knightsbridge district of London, UK, on Tuesday, July 26, 2022. Apple is set to report earnings this week against the backdrop of an economic downturn and a plan to slow hiring. Photographer: Hollie Adams/Bloomberg

site_title: Ditching concrete for earth to build a cleaner future
summary: Climate change has sparked renewed interest in using earth as a building material, swapping polluting concrete for a cleaner alternative. Earth, or rammed earth construction, has been used for centuries and can reduce reliance on concrete, which accounts for 8% of global CO2 emissions. The technique involves compacting certain soils into molds to create building blocks or walls, layer by layer. Earth has high thermal capacity, is fireproof, non-toxic, and can be recycled, but it also has its weaknesses, such as being prone to flooding and requiring specialized builders. Several countries, including Austria and France, are experimenting with earth-based building materials, and advocates say it could help reduce the environmental impact of construction.

site_title: Hong Kong’s retail sales post surprise drop in November
summary: Hong Kong's retail sales unexpectedly dropped 5.3% in November, the largest decline in eight months, as the city struggled to recover from pandemic-era controls and a slowing global economy. The sales volume fell short of economists' expectations of a 3.3% rise, with a government spokesman citing "softened" retail business. The drop may be due to Hong Kong's reopening of its international border, with economists attributing the decline to outbound travel by foreigners and Hong Kong residents.

images.alt_text: The return of mainland visitors would be a major boost to Hong Kong’s battered economy.

site_title: Walmart gets US$1b tax bill for PhonePe’s move to India
summary: Walmart and its shareholders will pay nearly $1 billion in tax after PhonePe, a digital payment company majority-owned by Walmart, relocated its headquarters to India. The relocation triggered a hefty charge due to PhonePe's pre-money valuation of $12 billion and increased share prices for investors, including Tiger Global Management. The tax bill of approximately $1.3 billion stems from the re-domiciliation and valuation increase, affecting existing shareholders.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A mobile phone showing an image of Indian online retailer Flipkart is seen in front of a Walmart Inc logo displayed in this illustration picture taken July 14, 2021. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: US auto sales to fall in 2022, GM set to reclaim top spot from Toyota
summary: US auto sales are expected to decline 8% in 2022 to 13.9 million units, due to inventory shortages caused by material costs and chip shortages. Toyota Motor's sales are forecast to fall 9% and the company will cede its top US sales spot to General Motors, which is expected to rise 2.3% in 2022. Industry observers warn that price hikes and rising interest rates may impact new vehicle sales in 2023, prompting automakers to incentivize buyers.

site_title: Airlines slam ‘knee-jerk’ Covid test plan for Chinese travellers
summary: The International Air Transport Association (IATA) has criticized China's plans to introduce Covid tests and other measures for passengers arriving from China, calling them a "knee-jerk" response that has proven ineffective in stemming the pandemic. IATA director general Willie Walsh stated that travel restrictions only delay the peak of new waves of coronavirus by a few days, harming economies and jobs. The European Union is considering similar measures, which may include masks and pre-flight testing requirements, despite the potential to strangle off international connectivity.

site_title: Evergreen Marine, Hyundai Oilbank staff get up to 52-months bonus
summary: Evergreen Marine and Hyundai Oilbank rewarded their staff with bonuses worth 10-52 months of salary in 2022, driven by the global shipping industry's upturn due to the pandemic-induced e-commerce boom. Evergreen Marine posted a net profit of NT$304.4 billion, while Hyundai Oilbank's operating profit jumped 226% year on year. The bonuses were part of a banner year for the companies, with freight rates remaining elevated and profits reaching record levels.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek

site_title: India awards mobility firms 30 billion rupee in e-bus contracts
summary: India has awarded 30 billion rupees in e-bus contracts to three mobility firms, Switch Mobility, JBM Auto, and PMI Electro Mobility, as part of the country's plan to deploy 50,000 e-buses over four to five years. The prices of the e-buses are 25-30% higher than the last bids in April last year due to payment risks and lack of government subsidy. The companies will supply 2,600, 1,781, and 2,080 e-buses respectively, with the exact quantities to be confirmed by Friday.

site_title: The best of Singapore Art Week
summary: Singapore Art Week 2023 kicked off on January 6, featuring over 180 events. Notable highlights include a solo show by 90-year-old fine art photographer Chua Soo Bin, magical realist painter Khairulddin Wahab's debut at Cuturi Gallery, and the high-end art fair Art SG featuring international galleries. The week-long event also includes minimalist artworks by Donald Judd and Sol Lewitt, as well as a showcase of local artists' works.

site_title: Singapore stocks post muted performance; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,242.46, down 0.1% or 3.34 points, amid mixed regional market performance. The Hang Seng Index led the "risk on" momentum, driven by Ant Group's approval to increase registered capital, while the Bank of Japan's unscheduled bond purchases dampened sentiment. DFI Retail Group was the top performer, gaining 2.8%, while Yangzijiang Shipbuilding fell 6.3%.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
Executive director and senior vice president of Comba Telecom Huo Xinru said that the company is investing in research and development in its 5G offerings to remain competitive.
Jack Ma has maintained a low profile since Ant’s IPO was halted.
The selling came on the heels of the BOJ’s move in December to double the cap on the benchmark yield and hints at expectations for a further change in policy settings.

site_title: Citi cuts India current account deficit forecast to below 3% of GDP
summary: Citi has lowered its forecast for India's current account deficit (CAD) to 2.9% of gross domestic product (GDP) for the current fiscal year, citing growth in services exports and lower oil prices. This is a reduction from its earlier estimate of 3.9% of GDP. The brokerage also revised its CAD forecast for fiscal 2023-24 to 2.2% of GDP, driven by the expected fall in oil prices, which could weigh down the CAD by 0.9%.

images.alt_text: Workers make glass bangles at a workshop in Firozabad, India, Oct 12, 2022. India's manufacturing purchasing managers’ index, compiled by S&P Global, rose to 57.8 in December from November’s 55.7, better than a Reuters poll median forecast for 54.3.
India government’s subsidy Bill for food, fuel and fertiliser was 3.01 trillion rupees during April-November, nearly exhausting the 2022/23 budgeted amount of 3.18 trillion rupees.

site_title: Food inflation climbs to a record high in British shops
summary: British food inflation reached a record high of 13.3% in December, according to the British Retail Consortium. This marks an acceleration from 12.4% in November, with fresh food prices rising 15% from the previous year. Despite overall shop price inflation dipping to 7.3%, retailers warn that prices may increase again from April as government support on energy bills expires. Experts predict a bleak start to the year for consumers, with rising food prices and energy bills taking a toll on household budgets.

site_title: Petrobras investors tank shares as Lula makes populist strategy shift
summary: Brazilian President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva has shifted Petrobras' strategy to a more populist approach, pledging to shield consumers from sharp fuel-price swings and increase investments in refining projects. This move has led to a 11% drop in Petrobras' New York shares, as investors worry about eroding profits and dividends. Lula's plan to extend a fuel-tax holiday and set a national reference price for refined products is expected to cost the company billions, raising concerns about its financial stability.

images.alt_text: Brazil's new President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva (centre), accompanied by his wife First Lady Rosangela "Janja" da Silva (second from right),  after his inauguration ceremony at the National Congress, in Brasilia, on Jan 1, 2023.
Overall, the number of board seats held by the state is unchanged, and the balance of power between the government and market shareholders in Petrobras was not modified.

site_title: Indonesia to start crypto exchange ahead of regulatory shift
summary: Indonesia plans to launch a cryptocurrency exchange this year, ahead of a regulatory shift that will transfer power over digital assets to the Financial Services Authority (FSA). The country has issued a white paper on its digital currency and passed a law recognizing cryptocurrency and digital assets as regulated financial securities. The move follows a significant increase in crypto investors in Indonesia, with 16 million investors in the first 11 months of 2023, and a shrinking trading value to 300 trillion rupiah. The FSA will assume regulatory power over the assets in two years.

site_title: UOBKH strengthens internal controls in response to SGX ban
summary: UOB Kay Hian (UOBKH) has strengthened its internal controls in response to a Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) ban, which prohibits the brokerage firm from acting as an issue manager or full sponsor for new IPO and RTO submissions. UOBKH will work with an external party to implement recommendations raised by SGX RegCo to ensure effective remedial measures. The ban was announced on Dec 27 following actions taken against UOBKH by the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS).

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek

SGX RegCo said on Tuesday (Dec 27) after market close that it is barring UOBKH from undertaking new mandates to act as an issue manager or full sponsor for IPO adn RTO submissions on the local bourse.

site_title: Japan to tighten Covid border controls for travellers from China
summary: Japan is tightening its COVID-19 border controls for travelers from China, with Prime Minister Fumio Kishida announcing that direct flights from China will require negative coronavirus tests before boarding. The measures, effective Sunday, follow a surge in infections among Chinese visitors and similar restrictions by other countries. Japan's health ministry reported 53 of 56 international travelers who tested positive for COVID-19 on arrival were from China, compared to 26 on Monday. The decision has been met with criticism from Beijing, which described the curbs as "discriminatory".

images.alt_text: Travellers at Hong Kong International Airport. The US, Japan and some other countries are requiring travellers from China to show a negative test before allowing them to enter.

site_title: Coral bleaching causing ‘unnecessary’ fish fights
summary: Researchers studying 38 species of butterflyfish found that mass coral bleaching is causing fish to expend energy on unnecessary fights, potentially threatening their survival. The bleaching event, triggered by climate change, diminished the fish's food source, leading to increased competition for other types of coral. This resulted in a 28% decrease in successful dispute resolutions among butterflyfish, with 3,700 observed encounters. The study warns that the fish may struggle to adapt to the changes, with potential knock-on effects on other species and the food chain.

images.alt_text: Cryogenically frozen coral can be stored and later reintroduced to the wild but the current process requires sophisticated equipment including lasers.

site_title: Prime residential prices to moderate in 2023 despite shrinking stock: Knight Frank
summary: Knight Frank predicts prime residential prices will moderate in 2023 despite a shrinking inventory of homes. In 2022, sales of non-landed luxury homes rose 5.7% year-over-year to S$2,495 per square foot, while landed luxury homes saw a 43.8% decline in sales value. The consultancy expects market activity to remain subdued in 2023, with prices growing at a more moderate pace, driven by larger-sized units in prime areas and returning foreign homebuyers.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim
This house on 17,905 sq ft of land in Tanglin Hill and completed in 1997 is currently on the market with an asking price of S$52 million or S$2,904 psf.
Huttons Asia estimates that overall supply of new condominiums will pick up in 2023 to around 10,000 to 12,000 units spread over 40 launches.

GCB land prices have continued to soar in 2022, rising 8.9 per cent between H1 21 and H1 22, to average S$1,839 per square foot (psf) according to JLL. This reflects a recovery of 25.3 per cent from the Covid trough of S$1,468 psf in H2 20.

site_title: Swiss inflation slows to 2.8% before likely jump in January
summary: Switzerland's inflation slowed to 2.8% in December, below the 3% median forecast and the 2% ceiling set by the Swiss National Bank. This reprieve is expected to be short-lived due to rising electricity and health insurance costs, which will likely trigger a surge in inflation this month. The Swiss National Bank has already raised interest rates by 175 basis points and is likely to hike again in March. Consumer prices have averaged 2.8% in 2022, with core inflation accelerating to 2%.

site_title: Australia braces for supply chain hit from China’s Covid surge
summary: Australia is bracing for a "substantial impact" on its global supply chains due to China's surge in Covid-19 cases. The country's economy, heavily reliant on trade with China, is monitoring the situation closely. Treasurer Jim Chalmers expects a significant effect on global supply chains and the economy, but predicts Australia's economy will buck the global trend and avoid a recession. The Reserve Bank of Australia has signaled further interest rate hikes to combat rising inflation.

site_title: Senior Philippine police officers urged to resign to 'cleanse' force
summary: Philippines' Secretary of Interior Benjamin Abalos Jr urged around 300 top-ranking police officers, including colonels and generals, to resign due to their involvement in narcotics. The move aims to "cleanse" the corruption-tainted police force. The probe found a "handful" of officers involved in the illegal drug trade, prompting Abalos to offer "courtesy" resignations. The anti-narcotics campaign has been ongoing since former president Rodrigo Duterte and his successor Ferdinand Marcos Jr. launched it.

images.alt_text: Rights groups say Duterte created a climate of impunity that led to an estimated tens of thousands of deaths at the hands of police, hitmen and vigilantes, even without proof that victims were involved in drugs.

site_title: Malaysia to tighten Covid screening for all arrivals, PM says
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim announced that the country will tighten Covid-19 screening rules for all foreign arrivals, prioritizing people's health over the economy. The move comes amid concerns about the outbreak in China. The government will test wastewater samples from flights arriving from China and will not discriminate against any country. This decision follows similar measures taken by other countries to prevent a potential resurgence of the virus.

site_title: China’s pledge to lift consumption sparks debate on cash handouts
summary: China's policymakers aim to boost consumption in 2023, but have yet to provide specific details on measures to achieve this goal. Unlike in the US and other countries, China is focusing on supporting businesses rather than providing direct cash handouts to consumers. Government-linked economists recommend targeting job creation and supporting vulnerable groups, while others propose distributing cash to low- and middle-income households as an interim measure. The goal is to increase household incomes and boost consumption, but experts caution that indirect implications could arise from such measures.

images.alt_text: Market pundits say 2023 is shaping up to be a better year  now that authorities have put economic revival back as a top priority, ramped up efforts to salvage an ailing property sector and signalled more support for private enterprise
People buy street food in a shopping district as China returns to work despite continuing Covid-19 outbreaks in Beijing, China, Jan 3, 2023.

site_title: Panasonic to stop making rice cookers in Japan after six decades
summary: Panasonic will stop producing rice cookers in Japan after 67 years, transferring production to Hangzhou, China by June 2023. The move is due to declining rice consumption in Japan and cost savings, as the country's shrinking population and changing lifestyle habits have reduced domestic demand. The production transfer aims to improve efficiency and profitability, as Panasonic seeks to adapt to changing market conditions.

site_title: Eurozone recession may not be as deep as expected: PMI
summary: The eurozone's business activity contracted less than initially thought in December, with S&P Global's PMI rising to 49.3, above a preliminary estimate of 48.8. This suggests the recession may not be as deep as expected, with demand declining for a sixth straight month at a shallower pace. Price pressures eased, with the output prices index dropping to 61.0, and the services sector's PMI climbing to within a whisker of the breakeven point. The data suggests the eurozone economy may contract, but not as severely as initially anticipated.

images.alt_text: Lending to businesses in the 19-country euro area expanded by 8.4 per cent in November.

site_title: Pele gets resting place in world's tallest vertical cemetery
summary: Brazilian football legend Pele has been given a unique and exceptional final resting place in the world's tallest vertical cemetery, the Memorial Ecumenical Cemetery in Santos, Brazil. The cemetery, which holds the Guinness World Record for the tallest cemetery, features a 24-hour restaurant, chapel, and other amenities, and Pele's 200 sq m mausoleum will be decorated like a football stadium, complete with artificial turf and gilded images from his career. Pele, 82, had purchased the mausoleum 19 years ago, stating it gave him a feeling of "spiritual peace and tranquillity".

images.alt_text: The Vila Belmiro Stadium where the wake for late Brazilian soccer legend Pele will be held, Santos, Sao Paulo, Brazil, Jan 1, 2023.
A spokesperson for Fifa said the flags at its headquarters had been lowered following the death of Pele “as a symbol of mourning and respect.”
Pele had been undergoing chemotherapy since he had a tumour removed from his colon in September 2021.
Riding on Pele’s appeal, the market for soccer expanded rapidly, making the sport – and especially its quadrennial contest – the delight of advertisers as much as audiences.

epa10387314 A fire engine carrying the coffin with Pele leads the funeral procession in Santos, Brazil, 03 January 2023. Brazilian soccer legend Pele, born Edson Arantes do Nascimento, died on 29 December 2022 at the age of 82.  EPA-EFE/Antonio Lacerda

site_title: Japan’s PM Kishida, central bank governor pressure firms for higher pay
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida and Central Bank Governor Haruhiko Kuroda urged companies to hike salaries to exceed inflation rates, aiming to sustain the economy's recovery. Kuroda emphasized the need for wage growth to meet the 2% inflation target, while Kishida hopes to create an economic structure with annual wage increases. The comments come ahead of annual spring wage negotiations, which could impact the Bank of Japan's stimulus efforts.

site_title: Kore, Prime US Reit unlikely to hit gearing limit even as US office assets face waning valuations
summary: Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit and Prime US Reit, two Singapore-listed real estate investment trusts with US office assets, are unlikely to hit their gearing limits despite declining US office valuations. Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit's leverage is at 37.5% and Prime US Reit's is at 38.7%, both below the 40% threshold. Analysts predict these Reits' interest coverage ratios will remain stable, unlike Manulife US Reit, which has hit 49% due to a 10.9% drop in portfolio valuation.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
The lobby of Figueroa, Manulife US Reit's 35-storey class A office building in Los Angeles. It makes up 44 per cent of the overall portfolio's valuation decline.
RHB Research analyst Vijay Natarajan notes that Manulife US Reit is trading at a more than 40 per cent discount to its marked-down book value.

site_title: The next stage of the hot Cold War
summary: The global energy landscape is shifting as Russia's economic decline accelerates, driven by Western sanctions and a sharp decline in demand for its fossil fuels.
