Russia's invasion of Ukraine and subsequent economic downturn have reduced its oil exports, with the International Energy Agency predicting a 40% decrease by 2023-24. To mitigate this, Western countries must focus on reducing demand for oil and increasing alternative energy sources, particularly renewable energy. Accelerated investments in these areas are crucial to reduce the world's reliance on Russia and its allies, and to limit the economic impact of Russian aggression.

images.alt_text: The US-China contest will accelerate in the coming decades and become the biggest challenge for Singapore companies.
January marks the 75th anniversary of the creation of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT), the forerunner of the World Trade Organisation.

site_title: China resumes residential real estate funds in further support
summary: China has resumed approvals for private equity funds to raise money for residential property developments, as the country steps up efforts to boost its real estate sector. The move comes after the government rolled out 16-point measures in November to address the property slump, which persists despite the measures. New home sales dropped 30.8% in December, and the number of private equity property funds decreased 14% in 2021. The move aims to improve the balance sheet of systemically important developers and counter the economic downturn.

site_title: India’s services growth at 6-month high on robust demand: PMI
summary: India's services industry experienced a 6-month high in growth, with the S&P Global India services PMI rising to 58.5 in December from 56.4 in November, defying expectations of a decline. The industry's activity increased amid robust demand, despite higher costs, including energy, food, staff, and transportation expenses. This marks the 17th consecutive month of growth, the longest stretch since June 2013.

images.alt_text: Workers make glass bangles at a workshop in Firozabad, India, Oct 12, 2022. India's manufacturing purchasing managers’ index, compiled by S&P Global, rose to 57.8 in December from November’s 55.7, better than a Reuters poll median forecast for 54.3.

site_title: Hong Kong-listed Comba Telecom closes SGX debut at S$0.255, roughly on par with HK shares
summary: Comba Telecom, a Hong Kong-listed telecommunications solutions provider, made its debut on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) with its shares closing at S$0.255, roughly on par with its Hong Kong shares. The company has not engaged in any equity fundraising activities in Singapore and has a market share of about a quarter in China's 5G base station installations. Comba aims to remain competitive by investing in research and development and improving productivity, with a focus on Asia, particularly India and China, where 5G deployments are expected to increase.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
The exchange will also establish a program in its securities market to support the liquidity of renminbi counters and reduce price discrepancies between the two counters, HKEX said.
SGX welcomed 11 new listings in 2022. The companies raised a total of S$580.3 million, according to bourse data.
Singapore, Malaysia, Thailand, Indonesia and the Philippines collectively saw 149 IPO listings in 2022, versus 132 recorded in 2021.

site_title: Oil’s new year slump deepens as demand concerns tick up a notch
summary: Oil prices slumped 4.2% on January 3, the largest drop since November, to near $76 a barrel, amid deteriorating demand outlook and predictions of a US recession. China's Covid-19 resurgence and milder winter weather are easing concerns of an energy crunch. The US Federal Reserve's rate hike to quell inflation is also cited as a factor.

images.alt_text: Brent futures for March delivery fell US$3.81, or 4.4 per cent, to US$82.10 a barrel, the largest daily decline in more than three months.

site_title: China to increase support for ‘too-big-to-fail’ property developers
summary: China plans to provide support to "too-big-to-fail" property developers amid a persistent property downturn, with measures including equity financing, loans, and real estate investment trusts. The Financial Stability and Development Committee has instructed regulators to identify eligible developers with reliable financial statements and no major violations. This support comes as China's home sales continue to slump, with a 31% drop in December from the previous year. The move underscores Beijing's stance of backing the strongest developers and leaving smaller ones behind, as the government seeks to stabilize the economy.

images.alt_text: People buy street food in a shopping district as China returns to work despite continuing Covid-19 outbreaks in Beijing, China, Jan 3, 2023.
China’s local governments, especially those in less-developed regions such as Guizhou, are struggling to meet debt obligations in an economy hit by Covid and a property downturn.
Languang has slashed about 90 per cent of its workforce since early 2021 and reported an accrued loss of 11.7 billion yuan as of the third quarter of last year.

site_title: BT subscribers get exclusive discount for Feb 18 property outlook seminar
summary: BT subscribers can register for the exclusive "Opportunities Amidst Volatility" seminar on Feb 18, featuring a panel discussion on Singapore's property market. The event, moderated by BT senior correspondent Leslie Yee, will include experts from Propnex, Edmund Tie & Company, and NUS Business School. Subscribers can pre-register for $15, while the general public can buy tickets for $40. The seminar will cover topics such as finding relative value in the residential market and the impact of megatrends on property prices.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan
The Property Insights newsletter will be produced by deputy news editor Michelle Low and senior correspondent Leslie Yee.

site_title: Philippines’ oldest bank hit with transaction errors; banking services go offline
summary: The Bank of the Philippine Islands (BPI), the Philippines' oldest bank, experienced a technical glitch causing double postings of debit transactions from December 30 to December 31. The bank's internet and mobile banking services went offline, prompting the central bank to order BPI to reverse the errors. BPI has identified the root cause and committed to reversing the transactions, with the central bank instructing the bank to submit a timeline for the reversal. Similar incidents have occurred at BPI in the past, and the bank has assured clients that their accounts are safe and secure.

images.alt_text: ``A Bank of the Phlippine Islands signage along kalayaan Avenue, in Quezon City, Philippines, Wednesday, Nov 18, 2009.XXX Metropolitan Bank & Trust Co. in Manila, the Philippines, on Wednesday, Nov. 18, 2009. Metropolitan Bank & Trust Co., the No. 2 Philippine bank by assets, rose to a 22-month high after CitisecOnline.com signaled it may raise its earnings forecast on the stock, citing a 49 percent rise in third-quarter profit. Photographer: Nana Buxani/Bloomberg

site_title: Appetite for food delivery dips after Singapore’s reopening, but still above pre-pandemic levels
summary: Singapore's food delivery demand has dipped since reopening, but remains above pre-pandemic levels. A Deliveroo survey found 60% of Singaporeans use food delivery services more regularly now than before. Foodpanda also reported steady demand and a consistent number of new restaurants added to the platform. Despite this, the demand is still lower than before the pandemic, indicating a gradual recovery.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
Deliveroo's Singapore general manager Jason Parke said that the company is focused on profitable growth.
Acquiring taxis could also be a means for Grab to reduce the impact of new regulations for platform workers.

site_title: Global hedge funds plan 2023 around inflation risk
summary: Global hedge funds are preparing for a mild global recession and persistent inflation in 2023, with many expecting a decline in equities. Key investment strategies include commodities, inflation-linked bonds, and corporate credit, while equities are seen as a risk-averse asset. Hedge funds are also focusing on macro-driven strategies that exploit volatility, with some expecting a mild global recession. Returns are expected to be lower than in previous years, with some hedge funds reporting losses of 6.5% in 2022.

images.alt_text: Better days may lie ahead for 60/40 stock/bond portfolios.
The selling came on the heels of the BOJ’s move in December to double the cap on the benchmark yield and hints at expectations for a further change in policy settings.
The SSB opened on Tuesday furnishing lower interest rates than the recent yields on Singapore Treasury bills and fixed deposit.

site_title: Biden to welcome Japan’s Kishida to White House on Jan 13
summary: US President Joe Biden will host Japan Prime Minister Fumio Kishida at the White House on Jan 13 to discuss North Korea, Ukraine, and the Indo-Pacific region. The two leaders will focus on maintaining peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait and addressing regional and global issues. This meeting aims to strengthen bilateral ties and cooperation on pressing global issues.

images.alt_text: Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida speaks during a joint news conference with U.S. President Joe Biden after their bilateral meeting at Akasaka Palace in Tokyo, Japan, May 23, 2022. REUTERS/Jonathan Ernst

site_title: Manhattan home prices slip 5.5% in first decline since mid-2020
summary: Manhattan home prices dropped 5.5% in the fourth quarter to a median of $1.1 million, the first year-over-year decline since 2020. The slowdown is attributed to tight inventory, with 6,523 homes on the market, and high mortgage rates, which led to a 55% share of all-cash buyers. Experts predict a modest decline in pricing over the year, with prices still 10% above the 2019 median.

images.alt_text: The Commerce Department said on Tuesday (Jan 3) that construction spending climbed 0.2 per cent in November after falling 0.2 per cent in October.

site_title: Iron ore slips as China Covid surge spurs volatility
summary: Iron ore futures declined 0.4% on China's Dalian Commodity Exchange to 846.50 yuan (S$164.5) a tonne, amid concerns over the weak real estate market and rising Covid cases. Despite optimism around China's reopening, Citi analysts expect underlying steel consumption to remain weak for 3-6 months, citing job security and consumer confidence challenges. Iron ore prices have risen 47% this week, with projections of further stimulus announcements and re-stocking expected to drive prices to US$130 a tonne.

images.alt_text: Global gas markets were roiled this year after Russia cut supplies to Europe and a major pipeline was damaged amid the war in Ukraine.

site_title: Asia: Markets rise again as traders consider China reopening
summary: Asian markets rose on Wednesday, despite a drop on Wall Street, as investors weighed China's reopening moves against surging Covid cases and recession concerns. China's shift out of zero-Covid has been widely welcomed, but the rapid lifting of restrictions has led to a surge in cases, affecting economic activity. Hong Kong and Shanghai rose, with analysts predicting a positive long-term outlook despite short-term pain. Traders will monitor the release of Federal Reserve minutes, which may provide clues about policymakers' plans, and are also keeping an eye on the global economy, which is expected to contract this year.

site_title: Has China “peaked” ?
summary: China's economic growth may not necessarily translate to increased global power, as the US maintains several long-term advantages, including geography, energy resources, financial power, demographic strength, and technological leadership. Despite China's expanding military capabilities and soft power, it remains behind the US on military and soft-power indices, and its economic power is smaller when considering US allies. The US holds a strong hand, but complacency or hysteria about China's rise could lead to miscalculations, making it essential for the US to maintain its external alliances and domestic openness.

images.alt_text: Joseph S Nye

An Electric Multiple Unit high-speed train for a rail link project part of China's Belt and Road Initiative is parked at Tegalluar train depot in Bandung, West Java province, Indonesia, October 13, 2022. REUTERS/Yuddy Cahya Budiman

site_title: Brokers’ take: CGS-CIMB lowers Japfa target price to S$0.42 post-distribution
summary: Brokerage CGS-CIMB lowered its target price for Japfa to S$0.42 after the distribution of its dairy business AustAsia Group. The new target is based on an eight times FY2024 price-to-earnings ratio, considering Japfa's remaining animal protein businesses. The firm reiterated an "add" call on Japfa, citing potential long-term benefits for shareholders who hold onto AustAsia shares. Japfa's shares rose 6.4% following the announcement, while AustAsia's shares declined 6.1% on its first day of trading. Analysts attribute Japfa's valuation to the African swine fever affecting its animal protein business.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
印尼佳发公司希望掌握新兴亚洲市场快速发展的牛奶行业。 （印尼佳发公司提供）

site_title: Gold prices flat as traders brace for US Fed minutes
summary: Gold prices remained flat at $1,838.69 per ounce as traders awaited US Federal Reserve minutes from its December policy meeting, which could indicate the central bank's tightening path. The minutes are due at 1900 GMT, following a 50-basis-point rate hike in December. Rising interest rates are seen as a deterrent to gold, considered a hedge against inflation. Meanwhile, China's factory activity shrunk in December due to Covid-19 disruptions, and British manufacturers reported a sharp fall in activity.

images.alt_text: Gold is considered a hedge against inflation and economic uncertainties, but higher interest rates increase the opportunity cost of holding gold as it pays no interest.

site_title: Global funds sell record amount of Japan bonds on BOJ pivot bets
summary: Global investors sold a record 4.86 trillion yen (S$49.9 billion) of Japanese bonds in the final days of 2022, with non-resident investors pulling out the largest amount ever. The BOJ's move to double the cap on the benchmark yield in December fueled speculation of a policy pivot, prompting money managers to bet on a shift. The BOJ responded to the selling by buying a record 17 trillion yen of bonds, and announced additional unscheduled bond-buying operations on January 4. Economists expect the BOJ to continue buying bonds to cap rising yields.

site_title: Canada grants record permanent residency permits in 2022
summary: Canada granted a record 437,000 permanent residency permits in 2022, exceeding its target of 431,645. This marks the largest annual intake in Canadian history. Immigration is key to addressing labor market shortages, with 100% of Canada's labor force growth attributed to immigration. By 2036, immigrants will account for up to 30% of the population, up from 20.7% in 2011. The government aims to welcome 1.45 million new permanent residents by 2025-end to boost the economy and support an aging population.

images.alt_text: Despite a recent heyday, Canada's real estate market has cooled for sellers as mortgage rates followed the Bank of Canada’s aggressive monetary policy in a bid to rein in inflation.

site_title: Ex-Nato chief urges democracies to unite during Taiwan visit
summary: NATO's former chief Anders Fogh Rasmussen urged democracies to unite in resisting "advancing autocracies" during a visit to Taiwan, warning that China's growing military pressure poses a threat to the self-ruled democracy. Rasmussen emphasized the importance of Taiwan's right to exist in freedom and peace, and to decide its own future. He also highlighted the need for the world's democracies to work together to counter the threat of autocracies, which he believes could create respect in Beijing and other capitals of authoritarian nations.

site_title: Tokyo Gas unit nears US$4.6b deal to buy US natgas producer: sources
summary: Tokyo Gas is in advanced talks to buy US natural gas producer Rockcliff Energy from private equity firm Quantum Energy Partners for approximately $4.6 billion, including debt. This deal would be Tokyo Gas' latest move to secure gas in friendly jurisdictions, following Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The all-cash deal with Houston-based TG Natural Resources is set to be announced this month, pending funding arrangements from banks and private credit providers. The acquisition would significantly increase TG Natural Resources' operations, producing over 1 billion cubic feet of natural gas per day.

images.alt_text: Gas storage across Europe is 84 per cent full, far above the five-year seasonal norm of 70 per cent and Germany is expected to produce near-record wind power, curbing the need for gas to produce electricity.

site_title: ARA H-Trust to acquire Colorado hotel property for US$29m
summary: ARA US Hospitality Trust is set to acquire a 119-room Hilton-branded hotel property in Colorado Springs, US, for US$29 million. The acquisition, expected to be completed in Q1 2023, will be funded by cash from the sale of five Hyatt Place properties in Q3 2022. The hotel property has a consistent demand base and outperforms similar properties in the area, with a RevPAR of US$137. The acquisition is expected to be yield accretive, with a pro forma impact on the distribution per stapled security of 0.784 US cents.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
The rise in net property income and gross revenue comes as the stapled group sees “strong recovery momentum” in its second and third quarters of 2022, the managers said.
Hyatt Place Pittsburgh Cranberry in Pennsylvania is among the 4 properties to be divested by ARA US Hospitality Trust.
ARA H-Trust to sell Chicago hotel asset for US$7.75m

site_title: Singapore shares dip slightly at Wednesday’s open; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore shares declined 0.1% at the open on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) falling to 3,241.8 points. Losers outnumbered gainers 67 to 43, with Quantum Health and CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust heavily traded. Local banks opened on a positive note, with UOB flat, DBS gaining 0.1%, and OCBC rising 0.3%. The decline follows Wall Street losses the previous day, with European shares rising as large-cap pharmaceutical companies boosted the Stoxx 600 index.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
ARA Hospitality US Trust's portfolio comprises Hyatt Place and Hyatt House hotels.

site_title: Jack Ma’s Ant Group wins approval for 10.5b yuan capital plan
summary: Chinese regulators approved Ant Group's plan to raise 10.5 billion yuan (S$1.5 billion) for its consumer unit, a key step in the government-ordered overhaul of the financial technology firm. The plan will lift Ant's capital to 18.5 billion yuan, with the consumer unit controlling half of the shares. This move signals progress in Ant's regulatory rectification and allows the unit to handle 1.1 trillion yuan of loans. The approval comes after a crackdown on Ant's business following its halted IPO in 2020, and it paves the way for Ant to meet regulatory requirements.

images.alt_text: A comeback of Jack Ma’s Ant Group listing would potentially be the most high-profile IPO, globally.
Angel Zhao, president of Ant’s international business group, says e-wallets are a “valuable and effective” channel for digital marketing.

site_title: China urges ‘final victory’ over Covid as global concern mounts over spread
summary: China has stopped requiring inbound travelers to quarantine from January 8, as the country dismantles its "zero-Covid" policy. Despite official reports of only 5,258 deaths, health experts predict at least one million deaths in China this year due to the virus. The government has played down concerns, while the World Health Organization (WHO) is meeting with Chinese scientists to discuss data on the outbreak. The move has raised concerns about the spread of the virus globally, with many countries imposing pre-departure Covid testing for travelers from China.

images.alt_text: All international arrivals in New Zealand are asked to test if they become symptomatic and the country provides free tests at the airport.
China has seen a soaring number of Covid illnesses since it abruptly ended a policy of zero cases following rare public protests over sweeping lockdowns.

site_title: US: Stocks give up gains to end lower on investor caution
summary: US stocks ended lower on Tuesday, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index dropping 0.4% and 0.8% respectively. Investors remain cautious due to recession fears and interest rate hikes, despite a brief rebound. The Dow Jones Industrial Average ended flat. Tech stocks like Tesla and Apple fell after missing delivery targets. Market sentiment is uncertain ahead of the Federal Reserve's meeting minutes and key jobs data due on Friday.

site_title: Experts sceptical that China travel curbs will be effective
summary: Experts say international travel curbs on China are unlikely to effectively contain the spread of Covid, citing a surging variant in the US that may pose a larger threat. Despite over a dozen countries imposing testing requirements, China has branded the restrictions "unacceptable" and vowed to take countermeasures. The EU's health agency has deemed the measures "unjustified" given Europe's high levels of immunity from vaccination and prior infection.

images.alt_text: While nobody knows the true extent of fatalities, it’s clear funeral homes in China major cities are already at capacity – and some experts warn that the worst is yet to come.
Travellers at Hong Kong International Airport. The US, Japan and some other countries are requiring travellers from China to show a negative test before allowing them to enter.
China has seen a soaring number of Covid illnesses since it abruptly ended a policy of zero cases following rare public protests over sweeping lockdowns.

site_title: Microsoft hopes OpenAI’s chatbot will make Bing smarter
summary: Microsoft plans to add OpenAI's ChatGPT chatbot to its Bing search engine in a bid to compete with Google, with a potential release in the next several months. The more conversational and contextual replies aim to provide better-quality answers beyond links, potentially winning over search users. Microsoft has been testing ChatGPT for several months, and while accuracy and speed are still being weighed, the chatbot's ability to summarize publicly available data has made it a credible alternative to Google search.

images.alt_text: The Microsoft deal is also facing scrutiny outside the United States, with the European Union saying it would decide by Mar 23, 2023, whether to clear or block the deal.

site_title: New Zealand won’t require Chinese arrivals to show Covid-19 test
summary: New Zealand has announced it will no longer require Chinese arrivals to produce a negative Covid-19 test, citing a public health risk assessment that deemed visitors from China as minimal contributors to the country's cases. This decision comes as other countries, including the US, UK, and Australia, have implemented similar measures due to concerns over China's outbreak. New Zealand will instead ask some travellers from China to do voluntary tests and trial wastewater testing on international flights. The move has been criticized by Chinese state media as discriminatory.

images.alt_text: The Reserve Bank has signalled further hikes are likely this year.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Ara H-Trust, Comba Telecom, EC World Reit
summary: Ara Hospitality US Trust plans to acquire a 119-room Hilton-branded hotel in Colorado Springs, US, for $29 million. The acquisition is expected to be yield accretive and will be funded using net proceeds from the sale of five Hyatt Place properties. Comba Telecom will make its trading debut on the Singapore Exchange, and EC World Reit has confirmed it can operate as a going concern, with its manager expecting existing bank loans to be repaid or refinanced before any default.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu

site_title: More US consumers want EVs but prices are a concern: Deloitte survey
summary: US consumers increasingly want to buy electric vehicles (EVs), but concerns about rising prices hinder adoption. A Deloitte survey found nearly 70% of prospective EV buyers in the US expect to pay less than $50,000, with affordability being the top concern. Despite high EV prices, EV purchase intent is up 3% year-over-year, while internal combustion engine purchase intent dropped to 62%. Consumers prefer upfront payments for connected technologies over subscription plans, highlighting a challenge for manufacturers looking to monetize the mobility experience.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Visitors wearing face masks check a China-made Tesla Model Y sport utility vehicle (SUV) at the electric vehicle maker's showroom in Beijing, China January 5, 2021. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang/File Photo

site_title: Internet providers warn against EU plans to make Big Tech cover telcos costs
summary: European Internet Exchange Association warns that proposed EU laws requiring Big Tech companies to cover telcos' network costs could reduce internet quality and create systemic weaknesses in critical infrastructure. The proposal, known as "fair share" payments, has been pushed by telecom operators, but critics argue it undermines net neutrality rules and could lead to platforms routing services via non-EU ISPs, compromising quality and security for European users.

images.alt_text: US tech giants including Meta, Microsoft, Twitter and Snap have purged more than 150,000 staff, according to Layoff.fyi, which tracks technology job losses.

site_title: Amazon secures US$8b term loan
summary: Amazon has secured an $8 billion unsecured term loan from certain lenders, which will mature in 364 days and be used for general corporate purposes. The move comes as the company braces for slower growth due to soaring inflation and reduced consumer spending. Amazon has been using various financing options to support capital expenditures, debt repayments, and working capital needs amid the uncertain macroeconomic environment.

images.alt_text: The move comes as chief executive Andy Jassy doubles down on Amazon’s streaming ambitions.

site_title: Japan’s Dec factory activity posts sharpest fall in more than two years: PMI
summary: Japan's factory activity declined in December at the sharpest pace in 26 months, with the manufacturing purchasing managers' index (PMI) at 48.9. This marks the second month below the 50-line separating contraction from expansion. The downturn was largely due to a weak demand environment both internationally and domestically. Input price inflation cooled to a 15-month low, but future output expectations hit a low since May, indicating a gloomy outlook for Japan's manufacturing sector in early 2023.

site_title: Foxconn to use Nvidia chips to build self-driving vehicle platforms
summary: Foxconn, a Taiwanese electronics manufacturer, has partnered with Nvidia to develop autonomous vehicle platforms. The partnership will see Foxconn manufacturing electronic control units (ECUs) based on Nvidia's Drive Orin chip for the global automotive market. The move aims to overcome production challenges and capitalize on a $300 billion market opportunity. Foxconn, which already manufactures electric vehicles for Lordstown Motors and Fisker, plans to use Nvidia's technology to scale its efforts and eventually produce cars for Tesla.

images.alt_text: The factory’s speedy bounce-back bodes well for the production of Apple’s marquee product in the run-up to the Lunar New Year shopping season.

site_title: Singapore Savings Bond opens for February issuance with interest rates under 3%
summary: The Singapore Savings Bond (SSB) for retail investors has opened for the February issuance with interest rates under 3%. The 10-year bond offers rates of 2.84% for the first year and 2.97% for the 10-year average, lower than its recent tranches. The rates are adjusted to prevent inverted yield curves, with the December bond yield curve being the ceiling. Demand for the SSB is expected to fall due to higher interest rates offered by other market products, such as Treasury bills and fixed deposits.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
The Monetary Authority of Singapore received S$909.7 million in applications for the latest Singapore Savings Bonds.

site_title: Sam Bankman-Fried pleads not guilty in FTX fraud case; October trial set
summary: Sam Bankman-Fried pleaded not guilty to eight criminal counts, including wire fraud and money laundering conspiracy, in the FTX fraud case. The 30-year-old ex-mogul faces up to 115 years in prison if convicted. Prosecutors have secured hundreds of thousands of documents and have two former associates cooperating with them. US District Judge Lewis Kaplan set an October trial date, which could last four weeks, after Bankman-Fried was extradited from the Bahamas.

images.alt_text: FTX disputed SCB’s calculations, saying its digital assets seized in November were worth just US$296 million and not US$3.5 billion.

Ex-billionaire founder Sam Bankman-Fried last year showed off his clean bill of health from auditors, tweeting that FTX and its US arm had “passed US GAAP audits”, even as he and his inner circle allegedly engaged in elaborate fraud and misuse of customer funds.

site_title: Crypto starts year with low trading volume after 2022 downturn
summary: Cryptocurrencies began the year with low trading volumes, following a dismal 2022 marked by industry scandals and meltdowns. Trading volumes on Binance are at lows since last summer, and Bitcoin's volatility has declined sharply, falling to 0.7% for a seven-day reading. Bitcoin fell 64% in 2022, its second-worst annual performance on record, and institutional investors have largely withdrawn from the market, with JPMorgan Asset Management stating that "crypto is effectively nonexistent" for most large investors.

images.alt_text: The Federal Reserve, Federal Deposit Insurance and the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency on Tuesday detailed concerns with the volatile asset class.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars wrongfooted by US dollar rally, bonds fare better
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars fell against the US dollar after a sharp rally in the US currency, with the Aussie closing at US$0.6739 and the kiwi at US$0.6259. The decline was partly due to a low German inflation reading and concerns over Chinese demand for commodities. However, bond markets benefited from the slowdown in inflation, with Australian 10-year yields dropping 10 basis points to 3.94%. Analysts expect further declines in inflation and interest rates, potentially leading to a reversal of policy tightening.

site_title: 5 Questions with John Tan, angel investor and edtech founder
summary: Angel investor and edtech founder John Tan shares his journey, reflecting on his entry into technology and discovering his life's purpose. Tan, who has invested in startups like Ninja Van and Chope, believes the current education system is "absurd" and disconnected from the real world. He advocates for a more personalized approach to learning, focusing on skills like critical thinking, collaboration, and problem-solving. Tan's edtech company, Doyobi, aims to equip children with the skills to thrive in a rapidly changing world. He advises his younger self to be skeptical of others' definitions of success and to pursue a sense of purpose.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

site_title: Chaos as US House adjourns without choosing speaker
summary: The US House of Representatives adjourned without electing a speaker, with Kevin McCarthy falling short in a third vote after 20 Republicans rejected his bid. McCarthy needed a simple majority to become the top legislator, but far-right rebels blocked his path. The deadlock could further deepen internal divisions within the Republican party and put McCarthy's career at risk. Lawmakers agreed to adjourn until Wednesday, with no clear candidate emerging to claim the speaker's gavel.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden leaving the White House in Washington, DC, on Dec 27, 2022, for the New Year holidays. Biden can now boast of a stronger legislative record in less than two years than either President Barack Obama or President Bill Clinton achieved in eight.
The exchange of pleasantries indicates that US Secretary of State Antony Blinken is still set to visit Beijing soon to follow up on a November summit between Joe Biden and Xi Jinping.
Workers in the clean room for silicon semiconductor wafer manufacture at the Newport Wafer Fab, owned by Nexperia Holding BV, in Newport, UK, August 2022.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise on Big Pharma boost, German inflation slows
summary: European shares rose 1.2% on Tuesday, closing at its highest level in nearly three weeks, driven by a boost from large-cap pharmaceutical companies. Germany's inflation slowed for the second month in a row, easing concerns over price pressures. The European healthcare index gained 1.8%, with Novo Nordisk, AstraZeneca, and Novartis rising 2.8%. Analysts expect Europe's pharmaceutical sector to maintain its premium despite recessionary concerns.

images.alt_text: Rate-sensitive technology stocks, among the worst-performing shares last year, rose 1.6 per cent on the day, despite more hawkish signals from the European Central Bank.

site_title: Sam Bankman-Fried asks judge to keep his bail guarantors secret
summary: Sam Bankman-Fried, the founder of FTX, has asked a US judge to keep the identities of two people who will help secure his $250 million bail package confidential to protect them from public scrutiny and potential harassment. The judge granted the request, allowing the identities of the sureties to remain secret, following a filing by Bankman-Fried's lawyers on January 3. A trial date for Bankman-Fried, who pleaded not guilty to eight criminal charges, has been set for October 2.

images.alt_text: Sam Bankman-Fried, co-founder of FTX Cryptocurrency Derivatives Exchange, departs from court in New York, US, on Tuesday, Jan. 3, 2022. Bankman-Fried pleaded not guilty to criminal charges Tuesday and is set to face a trial in October, a courtroom showdown likely to be one of the highest-profile white-collar fraud cases in recent years. Photographer: Stephanie Keith/Bloomberg

site_title: Ex-CFO pleads guilty to stealing from SPACs to trade meme stocks, cryptocurrencies
summary: A former CFO of multiple SPACs, Cooper Morgenthau, pleaded guilty to wire fraud for embezzling over $5 million, losing most of it trading meme stocks and cryptocurrencies. Morgenthau faces a 6-7.25 year prison sentence and agreed to forfeit $5.11 million and pay restitution. He stole from African Gold Acquisition Corp, raising $4.7 million from investors in another SPAC to cover losses, but lost most of it through crypto trading. Morgenthau breached the trust of investors and will be sentenced on April 25.

site_title: Sunak sets out priorities for Britain, responds to critics
summary: British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak will outline his priorities for 2023 in a speech, aiming to reassure his Conservative Party that he can lead them to the next election. Sunak, who became prime minister after Liz Truss's brief tenure, faces criticism over the country's economic and social issues, including a strike by thousands of workers, a health service crisis, and high inflation. He plans to focus on education, aiming to ensure all English school pupils study maths to age 18 to improve numeracy rates. The speech comes as the Conservative Party struggles to regain momentum ahead of the 2024 election.

images.alt_text: There is now growing support across the political spectrum, even within Rishi Sunak’s UK government, for a closer economic relationship with the EU.
Rishi Sunak’s response has been to hold the line against what he sees as inflation-busting pay raises.

site_title: Inflation won’t stop 2023 auto sales growth amid chip recovery
summary: US auto sales are expected to rebound in 2023 despite inflation and rising interest rates, with a projected growth of over 1 million vehicles to around 15 million units. The industry is recovering from two years of semiconductor shortages and supply problems, with consumers still in demand for vehicles. Automakers plan to offset rising interest rates by cutting prices, and the industry's shift towards building high-margin trucks and SUVs is expected to continue. Fleet sales are also expected to increase due to the Inflation Reduction Act's tax break for electric work trucks.

images.alt_text: In early November, Toyota cut its global production target for the fiscal year through March while sticking with a conservative profit outlook because of chip shortages.

site_title: China developer’s drastic action highlights battle for survival
summary: China's property developer Languang has slashed 90% of its workforce and reported a loss of $2.3 billion amid a sector-wide struggle for survival. The company, which has been selling off assets, is seeking a bailout from larger real estate companies or investors. China's government has rolled out a 16-point plan to ease liquidity issues in the sector, but smaller builders like Languang continue to face challenges. The sector's turmoil has led to widespread job losses, with many staff abandoning the industry altogether. Languang's chairman Yang Wuzheng hopes for a policy trough and is exploring restructuring options, including a complete overhaul of the company.

images.alt_text: After nearly two years of trouble, 2023 is likely to see a shakeout in the Chinese property sector that will help identify winners and losers.

site_title: Thailand expects 5 million Chinese tourists this year in post-Covid rebound
summary: Thailand expects around 5 million Chinese tourists to visit this year, about half the number recorded before the COVID-19 pandemic. This rebound is seen as a boost to the country's economy and tourism sector, with the government targeting 25 million foreign tourist arrivals in 2023. However, some experts are cautious, citing limited flight options and higher travel costs, which may impact the number of Chinese tourists. This comes after the lifting of COVID-19 curbs last year, when Thailand saw a quick rebound in tourism with 11 million foreign visitors in 2019.

images.alt_text: Some 11.5 million Chinese visitors went to places like Bangkok, Phuket, Pattaya and Chiang Mai in 2019.

site_title: US bank watchdogs issue joint warning on crypto activities
summary: US bank regulators, including the Federal Reserve, Federal Deposit Insurance, and the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, have issued a joint warning to lenders about the risks associated with cryptocurrency activities. The warning comes after the collapse of FTX, citing risks such as fraud, scams, and exposure to vulnerabilities in the crypto-asset sector. Regulators emphasize the importance of preventing risks from migrating to the banking system and will continue to monitor and regulate crypto-related activities.

images.alt_text: Ex-billionaire founder Sam Bankman-Fried last year showed off his clean bill of health from auditors, tweeting that FTX and its US arm had “passed US GAAP audits”, even as he and his inner circle allegedly engaged in elaborate fraud and misuse of customer funds.

site_title: Apple’s slide topples last stock in US$2t club
summary: Apple's market value fell below $2 trillion after a 3.7% drop on Tuesday, marking the latest casualty in the tech stock rout. Concerns about iPhone supply in the holiday quarter, coupled with investors' loss of faith in a reprieve from higher interest rates, contributed to the decline. The stock's slide ends Apple's reign as the last company to sport a $2 trillion valuation, following Microsoft and Saudi Aramco's retreat in 2022.

images.alt_text: Recent weakness has come as production halts in a major iPhone plant in China contribute to a supply shortfall of Apple’s flagship product.

site_title: Govt financing vehicle in China’s Guizhou region extends debt by 20 years
summary: China's local governments in the Guizhou region, struggling to meet debt obligations due to the Covid-19 pandemic and property downturn, have extended the maturity of bank loans worth 15.6 billion yuan (S$3 billion) by 20 years. This move comes after China's Cabinet allowed local government financing vehicles to delay debt payments and undergo debt restructuring. The debt extension aims to alleviate financial pressure on the region's local governments, which are facing significant challenges in meeting their debt obligations.

site_title: US says Covid tests for China travellers based ‘on science’
summary: The US has reaffirmed its requirement for COVID-19 tests for travelers from China, citing "very public health concerns" due to the surge of cases and lack of transparency on data from the Chinese government. This move comes after China denounced the measures as "unacceptable." The US is prepared to share its COVID-19 vaccines with China, which has promoted its own less effective vaccines internationally. The requirement for negative COVID-19 tests for air passengers two years and older to enter the US will take effect on January 6, 2023.

site_title: Fear of global gas crisis eased by warm start to winter
summary: A warmer-than-expected start to winter is easing fears of a global natural gas crisis, with gas storage across Europe at 84% full and Germany expected to produce near-record wind power, reducing the need for gas to produce electricity. Gas futures are plummeting due to reduced fuel consumption and a weaker outlook. The risk of extreme market tightness is considered low, with governments and utilities having rebuilt inventories and milder weather across North Asia reducing competition for liquefied natural gas cargoes.

images.alt_text: Global gas markets were roiled this year after Russia cut supplies to Europe and a major pipeline was damaged amid the war in Ukraine.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher on first trading day of 2023
summary: US stocks opened higher on the first trading day of 2023, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 1.65 points, or 0.15%, to 33,148.90. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained, with the S&P 500 up 13.79 points, or 0.36%, and the Nasdaq Composite up 95.58 points, or 0.91%. The market's gains come ahead of key economic data and the Federal Reserve's meeting minutes, which may provide insight into future interest rate hikes.

site_title: France signals flexibility in face of pension reform resistance
summary: France's Prime Minister Elisabeth Borne signaled flexibility on the government's plan to raise the retirement age to 65, part of a contentious pension reform project proposed by President Emmanuel Macron. The plan, aimed at balancing the pension system by 2030, could be adjusted to include "other solutions" to achieve its target, Borne said. The full plan details will be unveiled on January 10, and talks with unions will continue, despite a majority of French people opposing the reform, with 54% of respondents in a poll saying they are against it.

images.alt_text: A banner for the Force Ouvriere (FO), the Totalenergies Carling’s trade unionists, hangs at the entrance to the petrochemical site of Carling, north-eastern France on Sept27, 2022, as workers demand an increase in wages, an unwinding of profit-sharing, the resumption in hiring.

site_title: China vows to hit back at nations imposing Covid travel curbs
summary: China has vowed to retaliate against nations imposing COVID-19 travel restrictions, calling them "political goals" with a lack of scientific basis. Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Mao Ning stated that China will take measures based on reciprocity, without naming specific countries. The US, Japan, and Taiwan have implemented restrictions, including requiring negative tests for travelers from China, amid concerns about new virus strains. China has ended its strict COVID Zero strategy, which made entering the country difficult, and will strengthen communication with the international community to combat COVID.

images.alt_text: Analysts say that China is entering the "most dangerous weeks of the pandemic", with economic activity depressed nationwide.

site_title: ShareInvestor merges with InvestingNote; group aims for IPO in 3 years
summary: ShareInvestor, a financial media and technology company, has merged with InvestingNote in a deal valued at over S$30 million. The merged entity aims to grow across South-east Asia and list in three years. The merger will expand ShareInvestor's market data and investor education segments to Thailand and Indonesia, aligning with the company's plans to expand its presence in the region.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Invest Fair, an annual investment event organised by ShareInvestor, is set to return as a physical event for the first time since the Covid-19 pandemic.
Speakers (L to R) Matthew Henshaw, Marcus Ng, Jermyn Wong, Geoff Howie and Ryan Huang were speaking about investing in the STI during not so straight forward times.

site_title: Bodies pile up in China as Covid surge overwhelms crematoriums
summary: China's Covid-19 surge has overwhelmed crematoriums, with funeral homes in major cities reaching capacity. Experts warn the worst is yet to come, estimating a potential 25,000 daily Covid deaths in January. The government has acknowledged only about a dozen Covid deaths since abandoning strict pandemic controls in December. Funeral homes have implemented online booking systems, but families often face long waits and exorbitant costs for cremation services. A grey economy has emerged, with middlemen offering same-day cremation services for high fees, as desperate families seek alternatives to traditional funeral services.

images.alt_text: The weeks leading up to Chinese New Year will be an important window for assessing how widespread the rebound in mobility is, as hundreds of millions of Chinese are set to return to their hometowns.
Travellers at Hong Kong International Airport. The US, Japan and some other countries are requiring travellers from China to show a negative test before allowing them to enter.

site_title: Oil dives 4%, trade choppy on worries about China, global economy
summary: Oil prices plummeted 4% in volatile trade on Tuesday, driven by weak demand data from China, a gloomy economic outlook, and a stronger US dollar. Brent futures fell $3.81 to $82.10 a barrel, the largest daily decline in over three months. The decline was attributed to concerns over China's Covid-19 situation, recession fears, and a rise in export quotas for refined oil products. The IMF warned that the global economy is slowing simultaneously, making 2023 tougher than 2022.

images.alt_text: While a jump in year-end holiday travel and Russia’s ban on crude and oil product sales has supported crude, tighter supply will be offset next year by declining fuel consumption due to a deteriorating economic environment, says CMC markets analyst Leon Li.

site_title: Data breaches and ransomware: Prepared or paying?
summary: Cyber threats, particularly ransomware, are expected to remain high in 2023 due to their lucrative nature and ease of execution. Sophisticated hacker groups, such as the Desorden Group, are targeting companies in Asia with vulnerabilities that can be easily exploited. To avoid breaches, companies must prioritize cyber hygiene, implement effective security measures, and maintain a clear visibility of their cyber assets. Automation can help mitigate growing ransomware risks, but companies often fall back to minimal compliance obligations, adopting a "box-ticking" mindset rather than a proactive security program.

images.alt_text: Financial institutions filed 1,489 incidents related to ransomware in 2021, up from 487 the year before.
The cybercrime situation could turn even more dire. Evidence is mounting that some ransomware gangs are linked to and protected by enemy governments, such as those of Russia or Iran.
A strategic approach to cybersecurity is circular and iterative, and importantly — informed by data.

site_title: Huge crowds bid soccer star Pele farewell in Santos
summary: Brazilian soccer star Pele, who died at 82 after battling colon cancer, was bid farewell by a massive crowd of 230,000 mourners in Santos, where he lived for most of his life. President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva attended the 24-hour memorial service and praised Pele as "incomparable" as a soccer player and human being. A private burial was held in a procession outside Pele's home, with crowds lining the streets to applaud. Celebrities and authorities, including FIFA President Gianni Infantino, paid their respects to the three-time World Cup winner.

images.alt_text: The Vila Belmiro Stadium where the wake for late Brazilian soccer legend Pele will be held, Santos, Sao Paulo, Brazil, Jan 1, 2023.

site_title: US construction spending rebounds in November
summary: US construction spending rebounded 0.2% in November after a 0.2% decline in October, exceeding economists' expectations. Non-residential structures saw a 1.7% gain, while single-family homebuilding fell 2.9% due to higher mortgage rates. Residential construction outlays decreased 0.5%, with multi-family housing projects increasing 2.4%. The Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes continue to impact the housing market, with average 30-year fixed mortgage rates reaching 6.42% last week.

site_title: China raises fuel export quotas to spur refinery output
summary: China has raised its 2023 fuel export quotas by nearly half to 18.99 million tonnes, up 46% from last year, to spur refinery output and capture strong export profits amid slow domestic demand. The increased quotas, released in the first batch, aim to encourage refiners to process more crude and maintain record fuel exports. State-run refiners were granted 18.73 million tonnes of permits, while privately-controlled Zhejiang Petrochemical received the remainder. The move may help mitigate the impact of possible cuts in Russian diesel exports when EU sanctions take effect in February.

site_title: Court rules against underwriter in China's first interbank bond fraud case
summary: A Chinese court has ruled against an underwriter and two intermediaries in the country's first interbank bond fraud case. Bluestone Asset Management sued Industrial Bank and others after the issuer, Dalian Machine Tool Group, defaulted on a bond worth 500 million yuan (S$97.3 million). The court found the underwriter and intermediaries responsible for up to 20% of the loss. The ruling aims to protect investors and the bond market, but Bluestone criticized the penalty as inadequate and unfair.

images.alt_text: People buy street food in a shopping district as China returns to work despite continuing Covid-19 outbreaks in Beijing, China, Jan 3, 2023.

site_title: Indian state-run companies to remain exempt from public shareholding norms
summary: The Indian government has decided to exempt state-run companies from the minimum public shareholding (MPS) norm, allowing them to maintain a 100% public ownership. The exemption will be valid for a "specified period" and applies to IDBI Bank, which is currently being sold a 60.7% stake. This move aims to encourage investors to buy stakes in government companies, as part of the government's privatisation drive.

site_title: Euro slides as German inflation eases
summary: The euro slid 1.3% against the US dollar, its lowest level since December 12, as German inflation eased in December, indicating national inflation may have slowed for a second month. The dollar rose to a two-week high amid focus on the Federal Reserve's minutes from the December meeting. The euro's decline is attributed to weaker-than-expected German inflation data, which may not deter the ECB from pursuing an aggressive tightening policy. The dollar index rose 1.1% to a two-week high, while the yen strengthened against the dollar, and sterling fell 1% against the US dollar.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. Dollar banknotes are seen in this illustration taken July 17, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: On workers’ safety, tone is set at the top
summary: Singapore saw a rise in workplace fatalities in 2022, with 46 reported cases, the highest since 2016. The Ministry of Manpower has been pushing for greater accountability from top executives, introducing a new code of practice that emphasizes the importance of workplace safety and sets clear roles and responsibilities. Listed companies, which are also required to report on ESG metrics, are urged to prioritize workplace safety to avoid scrutiny from investors. The authorities have also imposed a "heightened safety" period, with serious lapses potentially resulting in companies being unable to employ new foreign employees for up to three months.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
With about two months left in the year, the 40 workplace deaths so far already surpass the full-year counts of 37 in 2021 and 39 in 2019.
Workers at a construction site with worksite safety banners at Short Street on Sep 15, 2022.

site_title: China’s finance minister reiterates plan for fiscal expansion
summary: China's Finance Minister Liu Kun reiterated plans for fiscal expansion to aid economic recovery, citing risks including demand contraction and supply disruptions. The government aims to boost investment in more areas, increase transfer payments to less-developed regions, and prevent systemic risks from government debt, which remains below 60% of GDP. Liu vowed to maintain sufficient fiscal spending on Covid controls and transform local government financing-platform companies in a market-oriented way. The scope for further fiscal stimulus is shrinking due to local finance stress and unsustainable debt burdens.

site_title: Singapore PMI resumes downward trend, slides deeper into contraction
summary: Singapore's Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) fell to 49.7 in December, marking the fourth consecutive month of contraction in overall factory activity. The electronics sector also contracted, with a 0.3 point drop to 48.9, its fifth consecutive contraction since August 2022. Experts attribute the decline to slowing electronics demand and escalating cost pressure, with further downside expected in the first quarter of 2023. Global uncertainties, including geopolitical developments and high inflation, are also weighing on the manufacturing sector.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan
Part of the weak outlook for Singapore's overall manufacturing sector is due to semiconductors, which contribute about a third of Singapore’s electronics output.

site_title: Reinsurers hike rates, exclude Russia and Ukraine: brokers
summary: Reinsurers are hiking rates by as much as 200% on key business lines, excluding risks in Russia, Ukraine, and Belarus, due to losses from the Ukraine conflict and natural catastrophes like Hurricane Ian. This increase is expected to be passed on to corporate clients, making insurance more expensive and harder to buy. The exclusions are making it difficult for insurers to find cover for these countries, further increasing the risk of reduced insurance availability.

images.alt_text: Tokyo wants to ensure Japan will continue to import LNG from the Sakhalin-2 project in Russia.

Reinsurers, who insure the insurers, typically renew their 12-month contracts with insurance clients on Jan 1, giving them the first opportunity to scale back exposure since the war in Ukraine started.

site_title: More people ride the subway in China’s biggest cities as Covid starts to peak
summary: China's Covid cases have started to peak in some urban areas, with nearly a dozen major cities reporting recoveries in subway use. The rebound in mobility is expected to be assessed during the weeks leading up to Chinese New Year, as hundreds of millions of Chinese return to their hometowns. Although people are moving around, spending remains muted, with the national box office and tourism revenue down from last year. China's economic growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

images.alt_text: Traffic congestion levels across 15 major cities in China rebounded nearly 60 per cent by Wednesday from a week ago.
Subway trains in Beijing and Shanghai are packed as residents commute to work.

site_title: These are the climate numbers to watch in 2023
summary: The world is expected to continue warming in 2023, with global temperatures potentially ranking as the fifth or sixth hottest on record, 1.15 degrees Celsius above the 1850-1900 average. Record emissions of greenhouse gases, particularly from fossil fuels, rose 1% last year, exceeding 2019 levels. This trend is concerning, as scientists warn that temperatures may breach the Paris Agreement's 1.5-degree limit within a decade. Meanwhile, investment in renewable energy and electric cars has grown, but progress in climate diplomacy and national emissions reductions remains slow.

site_title: Japan’s business owners can’t find successors; one man gave his away
summary: Japan's business owners, particularly in rural areas, are struggling to find successors as the country's aging population and shrinking workforce exacerbate the issue. Nearly 60% of businesses report having no plan for succession, with many owners too old to continue or employees uninterested in taking over. One man, Hidekazu Yokoyama, gave away his thriving logistics business in Hokkaido, Japan's northern island, after failing to find a suitable successor. The government is launching public relations campaigns and offering subsidies to help ageing owners find buyers, but the challenges remain, threatening the survival of vital businesses in rural areas.

images.alt_text: Japan’s aged care market remains stable, said the CEO of PLife Reit's manager.

site_title: Startups spring from ashes of Big Tech purge
summary: US tech giants such as Meta, Microsoft, Twitter, and Snap have purged over 150,000 staff, creating a wave of entrepreneurs emerging from the ashes of mass job losses in Silicon Valley. Despite a 33% decline in overall venture capital financing, early-stage funding for startups remained robust, with $37.4 billion raised in angel or seed rounds. Initiatives such as Day One Ventures' "Funded, not Fired" program are investing in startups founded by laid-off tech employees, highlighting opportunities for innovation in areas like gaming and AI.

site_title: UK factories face tough 2023 after December weakness
summary: UK manufacturing activity fell to its lowest since May 2009 in December, with the S&P Global/CIPS UK manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) dropping to 45.3 from 46.5 in November. This reflects a sharp decline in new orders and ongoing job cuts, starting the year on a weak note.

site_title: How investing in quality securities stands you in good stead
summary: In the current economic environment of elevated inflation and recession expectations, investing in quality securities is expected to be rewarding. Quality investing involves buying companies with durable long-term profitability, minimal solvency and financial risk, and high earnings quality. The MSCI USA Quality Index has delivered strong performance over the past three months and has outperformed the broader market over the past 20 years. As the US economy is headed for a recession, investors are advised to take on more exposure to the quality factor, with examples of high-quality companies including Microsoft, Visa, and Apple.

images.alt_text: The 60/40 portfolio is a great starting point for  long-term multi-asset investment.
Better days may lie ahead for 60/40 stock/bond portfolios.

site_title: Hong Kong to raise up to US$5b in green bonds: sources
summary: Hong Kong's government plans to raise up to US$5 billion through green bond issuance, consisting of US$3 billion in US dollars, €1 billion in euros, and approximately ¥5 billion in offshore yuan. The bonds will be issued in tranches of three, five, and 10 years, with a possible 30-year bond. The deal is being managed by eight investment banks and seven mandated banks, with books opening on January 4. The move aims to capitalize on the current favorable market conditions and stabilize inflation.

images.alt_text: Recovery in ESG bond issuance seen in 2023 as rates stabilise, inflation subsides
Harnessing green financing to push the boundaries of innovation

site_title: German unemployment falls in December
summary: German unemployment decreased by 13,000 in December to 2.52 million, according to the Federal Labour Office. The seasonally adjusted jobless rate remained stable at 5.5%. Analysts had expected a rise of 15,000. The labour market was moderately affected by the war in Ukraine last year, but the consequences were manageable, according to Labour Office head Andrea Nahles.

site_title: Bonds to stage comeback as hedge for stocks
summary: A survey of 610 respondents found that 60% are betting on stocks and bonds moving in opposite directions in 2023, potentially restoring a 20-year-old relationship between the two asset classes. Respondents are moderately bullish on bonds, expecting a 10-year yield to dip to 3.5% by year-end. The S&P 500 is projected to gain around 4% in 2023, and 23% of professional investors expect to increase their stock holdings in the next month, while 28% plan to decrease them.

images.alt_text: Bear market

site_title: Global shares rise as investors kick off 2023 in risk-on mode
summary: Global shares rose 0.2% on Tuesday, defying a stronger dollar, as investors shifted to riskier assets amid concerns over China's Covid-19 resurgence and its potential impact on the economy. European stocks, particularly energy and healthcare sectors, led the gains. Analysts expect interest rates to peak at 5% in the US and 4.5% in Britain, but markets are pricing in rate cuts for late 2023. The Bank of Japan's surprise bond yield hike has boosted the yen, while central banks are concerned about rising wages and excess cyclicality.

images.alt_text: Quality investing is defined as buying companies with durable long-term profitability, minimal solvency and financial risk, and high earnings quality. The investments are defensive and more resilient in times of market stress.

site_title: EY’s Budget 2023 wish list prioritises business growth and innovation, upskilling, sustainability
summary: EY's Budget 2023 wish list prioritizes business growth and innovation, upskilling, sustainability, and addressing global uncertainties. The firm proposes tax measures, such as enhanced M&A schemes, increased R&D tax deductions, and a 300% tax deduction for small and medium enterprises. Additionally, EY suggests extending tax relief for working mothers, foreign maid levies, and permanent tax deductions for approved donations. The proposals align with the six pillars of Singapore's Forward Singapore roadmap, aiming to support the nation's social compact and prepare for potential challenges and opportunities.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
DPM and Minister for Finance, Lawrence Wong, will make a round-up speech to address queries and feedback from Members of Parliament about a week or so after the Budget statement's delivery.
The government is looking at additional measures in this year’s budget to help Singaporeans cope with rising prices and inflation, said DPM Lawrence Wong.

site_title: Macau casinos deal themselves a tough hand with big non-gaming investment pledges
summary: Macau's casinos face a challenging future as they begin new 10-year licenses, with a government mandate to diversify away from gaming revenue. The non-gaming sector must grow to over 30% of overall gaming revenue in the next decade, up from 5% before the pandemic. The industry has been decimated by Covid-19 restrictions, leading to a record-low annual performance in 2022, and casino operators face increased government oversight and control. With industry net debt surging, casinos must adapt to a new era of regulation and growth expectations.

images.alt_text: China's reopening in January, and Macau’s own moves to scrap quarantine for overseas arrivals, paves the way for a major rebound for casinos in 2023.
Previous attempts by Macau to diversify have been unsuccessful.

site_title: EC World Reit able to operate as going concern: Reit manager
summary: EC World Real Estate Investment Trust (Reit) is able to operate as a going concern, its board said, after divesting some assets and expecting existing bank loans to be repaid or refinanced. The Reit's operations remain stable and profitable, and the proceeds of the proposed divestment will be sufficient to make a mandatory repayment. Approximately 83% of lenders have internally approved the repayment plan, with the remaining lenders in the process of obtaining approval.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Dasin Retail Trust is the only China-focused S-Reit to register a gain in unit price after China on Dec 7 announced the nationwide loosening of Covid restrictions.
EC World Reit's manager said lenders are in the process of obtaining the relevant internal approval for the repayment plan.
The latest proposal is on the back of delays to divestment plans of two Chinese logistics assets, to the tune of some 2.03 billion yuan (S$392.7 million).

site_title: Frustrations abound as delays in condo completions persist post-pandemic
summary: Delays in condo completions persist post-pandemic, with only 5,103 private homes completed in the first nine months of 2022, down from an estimated pipeline supply of 11,247 in Q4 2021. Many developers are experiencing delays due to pandemic-related issues, causing frustration among buyers who are unable to collect their keys. The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) estimates 17,276 private residential units will be launched in 2023, but actual completions may be lower due to ongoing delays.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim

Generic photograph of construction workers working on a construction site next to Bartley Road East on Oct 04, 2022.
