site_title: RWS launches inaugural football clinic with former Manchester United player
summary: Former Manchester United player Mikael Silvestre led a charity football clinic at Resorts World Sentosa, training 30 children from families in need. The clinic, in collaboration with the People's Association and SportCares, aimed to help vulnerable children gain confidence through sports. The event provided a platform for the children to engage in social interactions and teamwork, with Silvestre teaching defending and technical skills such as motor coordination and ball control. The clinic was a dream come true for many, including Andrew Lim, who had his son participate and learn new football tricks.

images.alt_text: Vivien Ang

"Life happens, and there is a danger that some may feel like it is a chore. So the aim for us is to work with companies and education institutions to sensitise people to the needs of others," says Soh.

site_title: Brazil’s Lula: president to pariah and back
summary: Brazil's Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, 77, made a stunning comeback as president, defeating far-right incumbent Jair Bolsonaro in a bitter election. Lula, a former blue-collar hero and president from 2003-2010, was a political pariah after being jailed in a corruption scandal, but had his convictions overturned by the Supreme Court. He took office for a third term, vowing to end the "nightmare" that had lasted for years, and thanked the Brazilian people for their faith in him. Lula's return to power marks a significant shift in Latin America's politics and comes after a tumultuous period in his life, including throat cancer and the loss of his wife.

site_title: A tale of two Chinas
summary: China's e-commerce sector is experiencing a slowdown, with top-line growth significantly declining. The sector's golden period is over, and valuations need to reset to mature stock valuations. Despite President Xi Jinping's focus on "common prosperity" and economic development, fears of a return to Maoism are unwarranted. Xi's views on common prosperity and economic growth are expected to remain largely unchanged, with economic achievements defining the success or failure of China's new leadership. The sector's decline is partly due to regulatory crackdowns and the end of the growth stock era, with valuations expected to decline further.

images.alt_text: The Hang Seng Tech Index has surged about 50 per cent since an October trough.
New restrictions limit the fees and operating times of private tutoring services for primary and middle school students.

site_title: South Korea, US eye exercises using nuclear assets: President Yoon
summary: South Korea and the US are discussing joint planning and exercises using US nuclear assets to counter North Korea's growing nuclear and missile threats. According to South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol, the joint planning would aim to effectively implement the US "extended deterrence" policy. This comes amid North Korea's recent missile tests and leader Kim Jong Un's calls for developing new intercontinental ballistic missiles and a larger nuclear arsenal. Yoon emphasized the importance of maintaining the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons.

site_title: The trouble with dividend yields
summary: Investors often focus on dividend yields, but this fixation can lead to poor investment decisions. Author Yong Jun Yuan shares his experience of investing in Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) shares in 2017, purchasing them at S$2.75 each despite not fully understanding the investment. He notes that hyperfixation on yields can lead to overlooking other important factors in investment decisions. This article highlights the importance of considering multiple factors in investing, rather than relying solely on dividend yields.

Is a recession coming or not?
Why do some investments need guardrails? Wealth editor Genevieve Cua has insights.

site_title: Indonesia’s Dec inflation inches up to 5.51% y-o-y
summary: Indonesia's inflation rose to 5.51% in December, exceeding the central bank's target range for the seventh consecutive month. The increase was driven by higher prices of fuel, air fares, house rents, and foodstuff. Despite this, the annual core inflation rate remained at 3.36%, within the target range. The central bank had predicted December inflation would not exceed 5.4%. This marks the end of a rate hike cycle initiated by Bank Indonesia to combat inflation.

site_title: Magnitude 5.4 earthquake strikes northern California
summary: A 5.4-magnitude earthquake struck 15km south-east of California's Rio Dell region, Humboldt County, on Sunday. The earthquake, at a depth of 27.8km, occurred in an area still recovering from a 6.4-magnitude earthquake last month. The California Department of Transportation closed State Route 211 at Fernbridge for safety inspections following the tremor. The region was previously affected by the December 20 quake, which left thousands without running water and electricity, and injured at least a dozen people.

site_title: Philippines’ main airport scrambles to restore normalcy after power cut
summary: The Philippines' main airport, Ninoy Aquino International Airport, was severely disrupted after a New Year's power outage, causing 300 flights to be cancelled or delayed. The outage, which affected the airport's air traffic control, was attributed to a failure of primary and secondary power supplies. The airport has introduced its own power system but experienced a power surge after being connected to the regular commercial electricity, shutting down equipment, including radar and communications. The airport is expected to take 72 hours to normalize operations, with long queues and delayed rebooking for passengers.

images.alt_text: Flight departures and arrivals in Manila will be rescheduled, and passengers are advised to await instructions from the airlines.

site_title: Xi warns of tough Covid fight with China economy on back foot
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping acknowledged the challenges in the country's fight against COVID-19, urging patience as the nation enters a new phase of Covid control. Despite a persistent property market slump and sluggish consumer demand, Xi said the economy expanded at least 4.4% in 2022, exceeding 120 trillion yuan. Economists forecast a faster and stronger rebound later in 2023, with growth projected to pick up to 4.8% for the year. Xi's speech came after data showed economic activity contracting in December, and the government pledged to support domestic demand and maintain effective growth of credit.

images.alt_text: New Year revelries appeared to be mostly unaffected as people celebrated the end of 2022 and the turn into 2023.
The return of mainland visitors would be a major boost to Hong Kong’s battered economy.
Dasin Retail Trust is the only China-focused S-Reit to register a gain in unit price after China on Dec 7 announced the nationwide loosening of Covid restrictions.

site_title: Boeing shares jump most in 40 years as Airbus retains the crown
summary: Boeing shares surged 57% in the final quarter of 2022, adding $42 billion to its market value, making it the largest quarterly gain in 40 years. This came after executives outlined a plan to turn the company around after four years of turmoil. Despite this, Airbus retained its position as the world's biggest planemaker, delivering 565 jets in 2022 compared to Boeing's 411. Airbus also had more orders, with 825 compared to Boeing's 576, but Boeing's sales were still ahead due to a 200-jet sale to United Airlines.

site_title: Macau casinos seek brighter outlook after worst year since 2004
summary: Macau's casinos reported their worst year since 2004, with gross gaming revenue declining 51% in 2022 to 42.2 billion patacas. However, analysts predict a 195% growth in 2023 due to China's reopening and Macau's removal of quarantine for overseas arrivals. The recent loosening of pandemic curbs is fueling optimism for a long-awaited revival in the industry. Despite short-term headwinds, investors are bullish on the sector, pushing casino stocks to their best annual performance since 2017.

site_title: China names Wang Yi to lead foreign policy
summary: China's ruling Communist Party has named 69-year-old Wang Yi to lead the nation's foreign policy after his promotion to the 24-member Politburo following last year's party congress. Wang will focus on building stable foreign relations based on peaceful coexistence and balanced development. He plans to deepen mutual trust with Russia, establish guidelines for China-US relations, and correct course in the bilateral relationship. Wang's appointment comes after Yang Jiechi's retirement from the top decision-making body, despite being older than the retirement age of 68.

site_title: Media is transforming; journalism education needs to change too
summary: The media industry is undergoing significant changes, driven by digital transformation, and journalism education needs to adapt to provide students with a career head start. Current media and journalism programs lack a culture shift towards developing audience-centric, product thinking mindsets and digital product management capabilities. To address this, media schools should update their curricula to include skills such as design thinking, data analysis, communication, and leadership, as well as courses on product development, digital marketing, and the subscription economy. This will prepare students for emerging roles in the newsroom and expand their employment options in the media and digital economy.

images.alt_text: Chan Cheow Pong
Making change work is harder than change itself
While news is still our core, the new structure places audience strategy and product development as equally important elements and co-dependent with quality journalism.

Retaining talent in the newsroom goes beyond attractive pay and hours, to creating an environment that nurtures passion for journalism.
Cross-functional BT stakeholders collaborating at a product design workshop in September 2022

site_title: Hong Kong eyeing Jan 8 to resume cross-border travel with mainland China
summary: Hong Kong plans to resume quarantine-free travel with mainland China as early as January 8, according to Chief Secretary Eric Chan Kwok-ki. The move aims to boost Hong Kong's battered economy, which has been impacted by three years of restricted travel due to COVID-19. Quotas will be set to limit the number of people traveling between the city and mainland China, and travellers are advised to take PCR tests and be COVID-negative. China has also announced it will stop requiring inbound travellers to go into quarantine on the same date.

images.alt_text: Offshore yuan (CNH) deposits stood at about 6 per cent of the city’s total banking deposits, according to data released by the Hong Kong Monetary Authority on Friday (Dec 30).

site_title: Over 5,000 new private residential units set to be launched in H1 2023
summary: Over 5,000 new private residential units are set to be launched in Singapore in the first half of 2023, with half of these units expected to be located in city fringe areas. Six projects, including Sceneca Residence and The Botany at Dairy Farm, are slated for a Q1 launch and will yield around 2,700 units. Developers are expecting strong demand for these projects, with prices ranging from S$1,996 to S$2,069 per square foot. This is in line with the overall resilience of the private property market, which is expected to stay strong in 2023.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim
Huttons Asia estimates that overall supply of new condominiums will pick up in 2023 to around 10,000 to 12,000 units spread over 40 launches.

The Lentor Modern condominium is one of many new launches this year that commanded psf prices of above S$2,100.

site_title: Croatia switches to euro, enters borderless Europe club
summary: Croatia officially switched to the euro on January 1, 2023, becoming the 20th member of the eurozone and the 27th member of the passport-free Schengen zone. The adoption of the euro is expected to provide economic stability and lower borrowing conditions, particularly amid soaring inflation. However, some Croatians express concerns that the switch may lead to higher prices and a loss of control over their economy. The move is seen as a significant milestone in Croatia's integration into Europe, with experts predicting a boost to the country's tourism industry.

images.alt_text: A cash tray holding British pound banknotes and coins in the UK. From its October low of 1.03 against the US dollar, the pound has rallied by about 17 per cent to 1.21 as of Dec 27.
A commercial clean vehicle, the guidance says, “is made by a qualified manufacturer”.

site_title: Apac Realty sees advantage in its ‘ultimate agent training’ and a super-app to help with analytics
summary: Apac Realty CEO Marcus Chu expects resilience in the property market in 2023, citing the high home ownership rate of 88.9% in Singapore. To improve sales, the company is investing in its "Ultimate Agent Training" and developing a super-app to aid with analytics, aiming to boost agent skills in closing property deals.

images.alt_text: Total revenue for the first three quarters of the year fell 3 per cent year-on-year to S$527.5 million from S$543.8 million, said Apac Realty, which holds the ERA regional master franchise rights

Apac Realty, which holds the regional master franchise rights for ERA Realty, reported earnings of S$23.9 million for the first three quarters of 2022, down 8.5 per cent from S$26.1 million last year.

site_title: Canada bans most foreigners from buying homes
summary: Canada has implemented a two-year ban on foreigners buying residential properties, aiming to make more homes available to locals facing a housing crunch. The ban applies to city dwellings, excluding recreational properties, and was proposed by Prime Minister Justin Trudeau in 2021. While the ban does not address the root issue of underused and vacant housing, it follows major markets such as Vancouver and Toronto introducing taxes on non-residents and empty homes. The Canadian Real Estate Association reports a 5% drop in average home prices since 2022.

images.alt_text: To bring the housing sector in check, Beijing introduced the so-called three red lines in 2020 to halt borrowing by developers unless they meet rigid financial targets and imposed lending limits on banks.

site_title: Toyota’s Indian unit warns of a possible customer data breach
summary: Toyota Kirloskar Motor, the Indian unit of Toyota, has notified authorities of a possible data breach that may have exposed personal information of some customers on the internet. The incident was reported by a service provider, but the company did not disclose the size of the breach or the number of customers affected. This is the second data breach reported by Toyota Motor in India, following an incident at Toyota Motor's T-Connect service that leaked 296,000 pieces of customer information last October. Toyota India is investigating the incident.

site_title: Final farewell for Pele, Brazil’s football ‘King’
summary: Brazil bid farewell to football legend Pele, known as the "King" of football, with a 24-hour public wake at his former team Santos' stadium, Vila Belmiro. The wake began on Monday with fans gathering to pay tribute to the 82-year-old, who died on December 29 after a long battle with cancer. A procession will follow, passing Pele's mother's house, before ending at a cemetery in Santos, where he will be interred in a special mausoleum. Tributes poured in from around the world, with Pele's legacy hailed as "eternal" by the sporting world.

images.alt_text: Argentina won their first World Cup trophy since 1986 by beating France in a penalty shootout in the final in Qatar on Dec 18, 2022.
Riding on Pele’s appeal, the market for soccer expanded rapidly, making the sport – and especially its quadrennial contest – the delight of advertisers as much as audiences.
A spokesperson for Fifa said the flags at its headquarters had been lowered following the death of Pele “as a symbol of mourning and respect.”

site_title: GIC is most active state-owned investor for fourth year running: report
summary: Singapore's Government Investment Corporation (GIC) remained the most active state-owned investor for the fourth consecutive year in 2022, completing 72 deals worth $40.3 billion, a 17% increase from the previous year. Over half of the capital invested was in real estate, with a bias towards logistics. Global sovereign wealth fund tracker reported $261.1 billion invested in 747 deals, a 13.6% increase from 2021.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
Investors large and small are scrambling to adjust portfolios and philosophies undermined by the simultaneous cratering of equity and bond markets.

The Public Investment Fund (PIF) tower, centre, in the King Abdullah Financial District (KAFD) in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia. The PIF plans to buy about US$250 million in Saudi Tabreed, the local venture of United Arab Emirates-listed National Central Cooling.

site_title: Navigating the minefield that is gift-giving at the workplace
summary: Gift-giving at the workplace can be stressful, especially for those who don't enjoy it. According to the article, it's essential to give gifts to colleagues only if you want to, and put thought into it when you do. The author suggests that this approach can help avoid awkwardness and stress, especially for introverted or busy individuals. By being mindful of your own preferences and boundaries, you can navigate the minefield of workplace gift-giving with ease.

site_title: Why stock markets, including Singapore’s, should boom in 2023
summary: Ken Fisher predicts a strong recovery for the Straits Times Index (STI) and global stocks in 2023, driven by easing inflation, falling interest rates, and positive signs from Hong Kong and China's reopenings. Despite global recession fears, most economic data is mixed, and no clear sign of a global recession is present. Historically, losing categories in global bear markets bounce highest in bull markets' first thirds, making a recovery likely. Fisher recommends positioning for a "great and hugely unexpected" recovery year, focusing on consumer discretionary companies, hard-hit tech stocks, and companies with strong export and tourism growth.

images.alt_text: The time to be optimistic and greedy is when others are pessimistic and fearful.
US wheat prices, which spiked following Russia's first attacks on Ukraine, have fallen 31.8 per cent from their March highs.
An oil pump jack in a field near Calgary, Alberta, Canada. Higher oil prices are among a cocktail of worries keeping investors pessimistic and priming the market for a rebound.

site_title: Regulatory, economic uncertainties muddy 2023 demand outlook for ESG funds
summary: Regulatory and economic uncertainties are casting doubt on the demand outlook for Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) funds in 2023. Despite keen interest in sustainable investing, concerns about regulations and macroeconomic conditions are affecting investor appetite. This follows a dismal 2022 for ESG funds in Asia, where net fund inflows plummeted after years of growth. Experts attribute the uncertainty to ongoing sustainability goals, sustainable product launches, and transition finance market developments.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
At present, China’s green funds only operate within broad investment guidelines that came into effect in 2018 and do not have a mandatory labelling regime.
Forestry, agriculture and other environmental assets are among the investments in one of two natural capital funds, managed by Climate Asset Management.

A plan by Europe’s markets watchdog, ESMA, to set quantifiable ESG and sustainable investing standards is forcing portfolio managers to rethink how they design and market an ESG fund class known as Article 8.
Clean-energy stocks have been among the few standouts in the US market this year.

site_title: Keppel forging ahead with transformation plan, asset monetisation efforts
summary: Keppel Corp, a Singapore conglomerate, is undergoing significant transformations, including simplifying its business and asset monetization efforts. The company aims to become a "global asset manager and operator" with capabilities in urban development, energy, and environment. In 2022, Keppel made significant progress in divesting its logistics business and announced S$2.8 billion in investments. The company expects to exceed its target of monetizing S$3 billion to S$5 billion by end-2023, with a focus on unlocking capital for growth and rewarding shareholders.

Terms of the proposed deal to merge Sembmarine and Keppel O&M were revised in October.

site_title: Vietnam startup Airlios poised to launch South-east Asia’s first flying car
summary: Vietnam-based startup Airlios is poised to launch South-east Asia's first electric flying car, an autonomous personal flying vehicle that can rise 10 meters within 10 seconds and travel at 100 km per hour. The prototype has flown 33 km in 20 minutes and has been tested for over 100 hours. Airlios aims to localise 80% of its eVTOL production in Vietnam by 2028 and plans to offer the flying car at a competitive price of US$81,000. Regulatory approval and certification are still pending, but the company is targeting institutional customers initially before expanding to the private market.

images.alt_text: Benchmark prices of lithium batteries in China are still about twice as high as the start of 2022, despite declining this month.
BYD’s decision to hike pricing is an interesting move in the face of slowing consumer purchases.
On Tuesday, Tesla was hit by an 11 per cent slump on fresh concerns about a production halt at its Shanghai.
Exports of electric passenger vehicles accounted for more than half of the total car shipments for two months in a row.

site_title: German finance minister sees 2023 inflation at 7%
summary: German Finance Minister Christian Lindner expects 2023 inflation to drop to 7% and continue falling in 2024 and beyond, but notes high energy prices will remain a challenge. He advocates for an "unbiased" energy policy, considering domestic fracking, nuclear energy, and renewables. The target remains 2% inflation, a priority for the European Central Bank and the German government.

site_title: South Korea's president vows 'export first' policy as December exports fall
summary: South Korea's president, Yoon Suk-yeol, vowed to prioritize exports in 2023, following a 9.5% decline in December exports. The country's full-year exports rose 6.1% to $683.9 billion, but imports grew 18.9% to $731.2 billion, resulting in a record trade deficit of $47.2 billion. The decline marks the third consecutive month of falls, clouding the outlook for the global economy, which is facing a slowdown. The government plans to provide policy support to exporters to avoid a decline in 2023.

images.alt_text: Energy Minister Lee Chang-yang said the Korea Electric Power Corp is expected to post a deficit of more than 30 trillion won (S$31.9 billion) this year, after a 6 trillion won deficit last year.

site_title: BT Money Hacks: Fractional property investing for the win (Ep 134)
summary: Correspondent Howie Lim discusses fractional property investing with Keith Ong from RealVantage, exploring alternative investing options for those looking to enter the real estate market. With property prices remaining high, investors are seeking alternative paths, such as fractional property investing, which allows individuals to invest in a portion of a property. Keith Ong shares insights on which sectors are now accessible through fractional property investing, offering a potential solution for those looking to diversify their portfolios.

site_title: Over S$1 million lost to phishing scams involving fake buyers on Carousell in December
summary: Singapore Police Force reported that scammers posing as buyers on online marketplace Carousell cheated victims out of over S$1 million in December 2022, with at least 1,115 victims affected. This was a significant increase from the first 11 months of 2022, where there were 975 victims with reported losses of over S$938,000. Investigations showed that a majority of reports involved unauthorized overseas PayNow transfers.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
The findings come amid a flurry of security incidents in cryptocurrency and as financial losses from cryptocurrency-related hacks totalled US$1.9 billion in the first 7 months of this year.
The metaverse became a tech buzzword in 2021, with companies and investors betting that virtual world environments will grow in popularity and mark a new stage in the internet’s development.

site_title: More and better data needed to elevate social sector
summary: The social sector lags behind the private and public sectors in data-driven decision-making, despite the world becoming more data-driven. A 2021 report found that the lack of accessible data about the charity sector results in poorer policies from the government. Singapore, in particular, is behind in social sector data, with charity watchers like Charity Guidepoint being the first of its kind. To improve, data needs to be produced and made accessible, capacity builders must parse and produce second-order data, and social sector organizations must want and push for data analysis and decision-making. A $100 million investment could help elevate social sector data and make a quantum difference in philanthropic efforts.

site_title: Evergrande misses overhaul proposal deadline amid creditor talks
summary: Evergrande Group, the world's most indebted developer, has missed its self-imposed deadline to release offshore debt-restructuring plans, disappointing creditors. The company, with 1.97 trillion yuan (S$380 billion) of liabilities, is facing a winding-up lawsuit in Hong Kong and is at the center of China's property crisis. The delay has broader implications for China's US$58 trillion financial system, potentially sparking financial contagion and curbing growth in the world's second-largest economy. Evergrande's fate could be among the country's biggest restructuring efforts.

site_title: China state media seek to reassure public over Covid-19
summary: China's Covid-19 outbreak appears to be under control, despite a surge in cases, as the country enters a "new phase" after relaxing strict zero-Covid restrictions. State media reassured the public that the situation is being managed effectively, with increased production of medicines and antigen test kits. However, concerns remain about the accuracy of case and mortality data, and the health of the economy. China reported one new Covid-19 death on December 31, bringing the accumulated official death toll to 5,249. Authorities have rejected claims of underreporting fatalities, but international scrutiny continues.

images.alt_text: “With China’s lack of population immunity against Covid-19 there is the possibility that a new variant of concern could emerge,” Nordlund says.

site_title: Bullion gearing up to rally in 2023
summary: Gold prices are expected to rally in 2023 due to inflation concerns, recession fears, and a weakening dollar. Central banks have been buying gold at record rates, pushing prices to test historic support zones. A potential reverse head and shoulders formation is forming, with target levels of $1,890 and $1,940 per ounce. If gold continues to hover around $1,800, 2022 will be the second straight negative year for yellow metal prices, but it still outperformed other assets in 2022.

images.alt_text: Despite the stronger than expected demand for crude oil, supply pressures and news of a positive re-opening of China’s borders have shifted market focus to global recessionary fears that taper demand for the commodity instead.

site_title: Bank of Korea chief sees more conflict between goals
summary: South Korea's Bank of Korea Governor Rhee Chang-yong warned that 2023 will be a year of increased conflict between policy goals due to growing uncertainty from inflation, economic growth, and financial stability. The recent aggressive policy tightening's effects are expected to manifest, with factors such as a cooling real estate market and the ongoing war in Ukraine contributing to uncertainty. The governor emphasized the need for a sophisticated policy mix to address these challenges.

site_title: China home prices fall at faster pace in December: private survey
summary: China's home prices fell 0.08% in December, marking the sixth consecutive month of decline, according to a private survey. This follows a 0.06% drop in November. The decline reflects weak demand amid rising Covid-19 cases, despite government support measures. The property market crisis worsened in 2022, with home prices, sales, and investment all falling. Experts predict the housing market will stabilize gradually in 2023, with room for policy easing.

images.alt_text: To bring the housing sector in check, Beijing introduced the so-called three red lines in 2020 to halt borrowing by developers unless they meet rigid financial targets and imposed lending limits on banks.

site_title: The hottest place to network is an ice bath
summary: Firms are using unconventional networking methods, such as ice baths, sound baths, and IV infusions, to entertain clients and boost team morale. The practice is seen as a way to promote wellness and relaxation, and can be a unique selling point for companies. Executives at Daring Foods, a plant-based chicken company, used an ice bath to address internal challenges, citing an increase in endorphins and improved team dynamics. This trend is becoming increasingly popular across the US, with companies using alternative wellness practices to foster connections and drive business growth.

images.alt_text: Crochet is a skill set that could easily be monetised, but profit margins would be nonexistent.

site_title: Philippines restores air traffic control after power outage
summary: The Philippines restored air traffic control operations after a power outage forced the closure of the country's airspace, cancelling or diverting over 280 local flights and affecting 56,000 passengers. The Air Traffic Management Center at the Ninoy Aquino International Airport resumed normal operations on Sunday after a power outage earlier in the day, with equipment restoration still ongoing. Flight departures and arrivals were rescheduled, and passengers were advised to await instructions from airlines.

images.alt_text: Chinese tourists will no longer need to quarantine on return home starting Jan 8.
Coast guard personnel evacuating a resident from a flooded house in Plaridel, Misamis Occidental province, Philippines, Dec 26, 2022.

site_title: World welcomes 2023 and leaves a stormy year behind
summary: The world bid farewell to 2022 and welcomed 2023 with mixed celebrations. Despite the ongoing conflict in Ukraine, many countries held New Year's Eve festivities, with London's mayor branding it the biggest in Europe. Fireworks displays were cancelled in some cities due to weather conditions or economic constraints, while others, such as Sydney, kicked off the celebrations with record-breaking displays. Meanwhile, in Ukraine, people gathered in private to celebrate, with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy urging for victory in the conflict. The year 2023 marks a return to post-Covid normality in Asia and a focus on meeting climate challenges.

images.alt_text: Sng wears a peach shirt and off-white suit by Celine, as well as a  B.Zero1 pendant chain necklace, B.Zero1 rings, B.Zero1 bangle and Octo Finissimo Chronograph GMT watch, all by Bulgari.

site_title: Tesla stock had the worst year ever. That doesn’t make it cheap
summary: Tesla's stock has dropped 65% in 2022, but individual investors are buying up shares due to its high valuation. Despite this, concerns remain about the company's short-term outlook, including rising costs, competitive threats, and recession risks. Tesla's shares trade at a higher valuation relative to expected earnings than most major tech giants, but analysts are cautious about its growth prospects. Despite this, some analysts remain bullish on the stock, with Morgan Stanley's Adam Jonas predicting a potential doubling of the stock price in 2023.

images.alt_text: In an effort to clear inventory, Tesla offered a rare US$7,500 discount to US customers who took delivery of a new Model 3 or Model Y at the end of the year, along with 10,000 miles of free Supercharging.

site_title: China stock investors eye better 2023 after US$3.9 trillion rout
summary: China stock investors are optimistic about 2023 after authorities shifted focus to economic revival, property sector support, and private enterprise encouragement. The Hang Seng China Enterprises Index suffered a third consecutive year of declines, but experts expect a better year ahead, citing attractive valuations and reduced US-China tensions. However, challenges from a messy Covid exit, lingering debt issues, and a looming global recession remain, with market volatility expected to persist.

images.alt_text: With a drop of more than 20 per cent in 2022, the MSCI All-Country World Index is on track for its worst performance since the 2008 crisis.

site_title: UK’s problems won’t go away in new year, Sunak tells Britons
summary: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak acknowledged that the country's problems won't disappear in 2023, despite making tough decisions to control borrowing and debt. He vowed to continue supporting Ukraine in its fight against Russia, following a tumultuous year marked by an unprecedented pandemic and the UK's third prime minister change in 2022. The Labour Party criticized the government for its handling of public sector strikes, with shadow chancellor Rachel Reeves accusing the Tories of sabotaging the UK economy, leading to a surge in opinion polls against the Conservatives.

images.alt_text: “There are no plans to re-introduce Covid-19 testing or additional requirements for arrivals into the UK,” the spokesperson said when asked about a Telegraph report which said the government will consider curbs for arrivals from China.

site_title: Australia home prices fall further as rate hikes weigh on market
summary: Australia's housing market declined further in January, with the median price in Sydney dropping below A$1 million for the first time in almost three years. The national Home Value Index fell 1% and is now down 8.9% from its April 2022 peak, the largest and fastest fall since 1980. CoreLogic attributes the decline to the Reserve Bank's aggressive interest rate hikes to cool inflation. Experts expect house prices to stabilize once rates peak, but until then, Australians are likely to delay major financial decisions due to concerns over household finances and the economy.

images.alt_text: Prices are down 5.3 per cent last year, marking the largest calendar year decline since 2008, during the global financial crisis, when home values fell 6.4 per cent.

site_title: Beware crypto billionaires boasting of audits
summary: Ex-billionaire Sam Bankman-Fried's FTX and its US arm passed US GAAP audits, despite allegedly engaging in elaborate fraud and misuse of customer funds. This raises concerns about the credibility of audit reports in the cryptocurrency industry, which is largely offshore and patchily-regulated. Regulators, including Wall Street's top regulator, are warning investors to be wary of how crypto firms promote the work of accounting firms, and are considering enforcement actions.

site_title: South Korea considers early easing of Covid visa curbs on travellers from China
summary: South Korea is considering lifting its Covid visa restrictions on Chinese visitors earlier than scheduled if the number of infections in China remains manageable. Prime Minister Han Duck-soo suggested lifting the restrictions before the end of February, citing the need to ease travel and tourism sectors hit by the pandemic. The move comes after China suspended issuing short-term visas to South Korean visitors in response to Seoul's decision. This could benefit Korean Air, which lost 20-25% of its passenger and cargo business due to the pandemic, and duty-free shops that rely on Chinese tourists.

images.alt_text: China had stopped issuing visas to Japanese nationals from Jan 10 after Tokyo started requiring people arriving from the mainland to test before travel and upon landing.

site_title: US dollar climbs before Fed decision, but set for fourth monthly drop
summary: The US dollar index rose 0.25% on Tuesday ahead of the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision, but is set for its fourth consecutive monthly drop. The dollar index was up 0.25% at 102.5, but down 0.9% for the month. The Fed is expected to raise interest rates by 25 basis points on Wednesday, followed by the European Central Bank and Bank of England on Thursday. Analysts predict further tightening, but some expect a pause, which could impact the dollar's value.

site_title: Asia: Markets fluctuate ahead of Federal Reserve meeting
summary: Asian markets remained flat on Tuesday ahead of the Federal Reserve's policy decision, as investors waited for the announcement of another interest rate hike. Despite data showing a bounce in Chinese economic activity, the markets remained cautious due to recession concerns. The Fed is expected to raise borrowing costs by 25 basis points, marking a slowdown in its monetary tightening campaign. Markets in Hong Kong, Tokyo, Shanghai, Wellington, Taipei, Manila, and Jakarta fell, while data failed to excite investors. The decision is due on Wednesday.

images.alt_text: Shanghai rallied as it resumed trading, while Tokyo, Taipei, Jakarta and Wellington also rose, though Hong Kong, Sydney, Seoul, Singapore and Manila slipped on Monday.

site_title: Japan Inc strives to lure skilled workers as inflation, labour crunch bite
summary: Japan Inc is offering inflation allowances to combat rising prices and a labor crunch, with about a quarter of firms offering or planning to offer such allowances. Major firms, including Toyota, are negotiating with in-house unions to set wages for the coming fiscal year, with some aiming to offset cost-push inflation. As annual labor talks wrap up in mid-March, momentum is growing for firms to offer pay hikes to cushion consumer inflation, which hit a 41-year high of 4% in December.

images.alt_text: “We will take further steps towards ‘life with corona’ and make steady progress on returning to normality in homes, schools, workplaces, neighbourhoods and all facets of life.” Japan Prime Minister Fumio Kishida said.
A pedestrian walks in front of the Bank of Japan (BoJ) head office building in Tokyo on April 27, 2022. (Photo by Kazuhiro NOGI / AFP)

site_title: What’s gone at Twitter? A data centre, janitors, some toilet paper
summary: Elon Musk has implemented cost-cutting measures at Twitter, including shutting down a data centre, stopping rent payments, and cutting janitorial and security services. The move, aimed at stabilizing the company's finances, has led to concerns about server disruption and employee welfare. Twitter managers have been instructed to justify individual costs using the "zero-based budgeting" tactic, and employees have reported difficulties, including missed rent payments and bringing their own toilet paper.

images.alt_text: Clockwise from top left: Elon Musk, Jeff Bezos, Changpeng Zhao and Mark Zuckerberg alone saw some US$392 billion erased from their cumulative net worth.
At the peak of the outage, at about 0035 GMT, DownDetector said more than 10,000 people reported problems with the platform.
Hordes of Twitter users, and employees, have left the social media network in the wake of Elon Musk's entry and shakeup of the platform.

The layoffs and departures of a high-ranking leader comes as regulators around the globe question Twitter’s content moderation work and protection of user data after Musk cut the staff from more than 7,000 to under 2,000.

site_title: US House panel to vote next month on possible TikTok ban
summary: The US House Foreign Affairs Committee plans to vote next month on a bill that would give the White House the authority to ban TikTok over US national security concerns. The measure, proposed by Representative Michael McCaul, aims to address concerns that the Chinese-owned app provides a "back door" into US phones. This effort comes after previous attempts by the Trump administration to block TikTok were unsuccessful, and follows a bipartisan bill introduced by Senator Marco Rubio in December.

images.alt_text: A spokesman for the European Commission said the meetings could be expected to cover issues such as the protection of personal data by online platforms such as TikTok and the implementation of the EU’s Digital Services Act.
The job cuts represent a small percentage of ByteDance’s workforce, the report said.

site_title: Bill Ackman says Hindenburg's Adani report 'highly credible'
summary: US short-seller Hindenburg Research released a report accusing Adani Group of improper use of offshore tax havens, leading to a US$10.73 billion loss in market capitalization for the conglomerate's seven listed companies. Billionaire investor Bill Ackman found the report "highly credible and extremely well researched" and has a history of taking on pyramid schemes, including Herbalife. Adani Group has vowed to take "remedial and punitive action" against Hindenburg, while Hindenburg has threatened to demand documents in a potential US lawsuit.

images.alt_text: Hindenburg vs Adani: The short seller taking on Asia’s richest person

site_title: Pharrell Williams-backed surf park to tap US$121m of bonds
summary: Pharrell Williams-backed surf park, The Wave, plans to raise US$121 million through unrated revenue bonds for its 4-acre development in Virginia Beach, Virginia. The bonds are part of a US$330 million project, the largest public-private partnership in the city's history. The Wave is the centerpiece of the Atlantic Park development, which will feature various attractions and amenities. The project aims to capitalize on the city's growing tourist industry, despite muni deals funding tourist attractions having a checkered past. The bonds are expected to be sold in two parts, with proceeds funding The Wave's construction.

images.alt_text: Fifa has long managed a loan portfolio, targeting short-term bonds predominantly in government or public debt.

site_title: Brazil open door to breaking foreign coach taboo
summary: Brazil is considering breaking the taboo of hiring a foreign coach, following the departure of Tite, who led the team to a World Cup quarterfinal exit. The Brazilian Football Confederation (CBF) president, Ednaldo Rodrigues, has yet to find a local replacement. Luiz Felipe Scolari, a 2002 World Cup-winning coach, notes that Brazil used to produce more coaches than now, highlighting the need for change. This move could mark a significant shift in the country's coaching landscape and pave the way for a foreign coach to lead the Selecao.

images.alt_text: epa10387314 A fire engine carrying the coffin with Pele leads the funeral procession in Santos, Brazil, 03 January 2023. Brazilian soccer legend Pele, born Edson Arantes do Nascimento, died on 29 December 2022 at the age of 82.  EPA-EFE/Antonio Lacerda

Soccer Football - FIFA World Cup Qatar 2022 - Final - Argentina v France - Lusail Stadium, Lusail, Qatar - December 18, 2022
Argentina's Lionel Messi and teammates celebrate winning the World Cup REUTERS/Peter Cziborra     TPX IMAGES OF THE DAY

site_title: China junk dollar bond prices swing from record low to longest winning streak
summary: Chinese junk dollar bonds experienced a record 12-week winning streak, with prices surging to a 1-year high of $0.787, rebounding from a record low of $0.493 in November 2022. The reversal is attributed to government support for the ailing property sector and the scrapping of zero-Covid policies, boosting economic prospects. Analysts expect further gains, citing a "light" investor position and wide trading spreads. However, volatility remains a concern, and not a suitable trade for everyone.

images.alt_text: Chinese policymakers have sought to boost infrastructure spending to shore up the Covid-ravaged economy.

site_title: Key inflation gauge cools further, paving way for smaller Fed rate hike
summary: The personal consumption expenditures core price index, excluding food and energy, rose 4.4% in December from a year earlier, the slowest annual pace in over a year. The overall gauge climbed 5% year-over-year, still above the Federal Reserve's 2% goal, but both were the slowest paces since late 2021. Consumer spending fell, and inflation eased, paving the way for policymakers to scale back interest-rate hikes. The Fed's preferred inflation measure, core price index, was up 0.3% from a month earlier.

images.alt_text: Over the year as a whole, as measured from the fourth quarter a year earlier, US GDP grew 1 per cent, down sharply from 5.7 per cent growth in 2021.

site_title: Malaysia’s mid-tier firms investing and expanding with more confidence
summary: Malaysia's mid-tier companies are expanding production capacity and moving towards higher-value-added sectors, driven by greater political stability. According to Callum Chen, president of the Malaysian Consortium of Mid-Tier Companies, the country's growth is slower compared to other regional countries, and staying in their comfort zone could lead to stagnation. This shift aims to address labour shortages, rising costs, and regional competition.

images.alt_text: While the ringgit is expected to consolidate in the near-term, Fitch Solutions analysts noted some broader upsides in a report on Friday (Jan 6).

site_title: The humbling of Goldman Sachs
summary: Goldman Sachs, known for its exceptional image, has recently faced significant setbacks. Since October, the firm has made a U-turn on its consumer bank plan, booked its worst quarterly result in a decade, and attracted a Federal Reserve probe. This marks a reversal from its previous commitment to build a big consumer bank and highlights the challenges of reforming a firm trapped by its own mythology. The recent struggles demonstrate a shift in power in global finance, underscoring the difficulties Goldman faces in adapting to changing market conditions.

images.alt_text: Julian Salisbury, chief investment officer of asset and wealth management at Goldman Sachs, says the Wall Street giant plans to divest its positions over the next few years and replace some of those funds on its balance sheet with outside capital.
Goldman posted the biggest loss in the S&P 500 and its longtime rival was the biggest winner in midday trading on Tuesday.

site_title: Stripe hires JPMorgan, Goldman Sachs to explore liquidity raise
summary: Stripe, a world's most valuable startup, hires JPMorgan Chase & Co and Goldman Sachs to explore liquidity raise options, including a direct listing or private market capital raise. The move aims to raise funds for veteran employees with expiring restricted stock units before an economic downturn. Following a significant valuation drop due to slowing online spending, Stripe has cut over 1,000 jobs and reduced its internal valuation multiple times to US$63 billion. The company has also secured a major win with Amazon expanding its use of Stripe's core payments platform.

images.alt_text: Stripe in November cut its headcount by about 14 per cent, saying that the payments startup had overhired and grew operating costs too quickly.

site_title: Mezze and more at Ummi Beirut
summary: Ummi Beirut, a Lebanese restaurant at InterContinental Singapore's Robertson Quay, offers a culinary tour of the country. The menu features a variety of traditional dishes, including mezze platters, lentil salad, tabbouleh, batata harra, and kibbeh. While authenticity is ensured by a chef from Beirut, prices are steep, with individual dishes ranging from $20 to $40. The restaurant's plush interiors and friendly service make it an accessible introduction to Lebanese cuisine, but some dishes may be considered overpriced. Overall, Ummi Beirut scores 6.5 out of 10.

images.alt_text: Assorted dim sum at Jia He Grand.

site_title: Your friendly neighbourhood No Sleep Club
summary: No Sleep Club, a modern communal bar on Keong Saik Road, aims to provide a relaxed atmosphere with a modern vibe. Co-founded by Juan Yi Jun, the bar serves a mix of cocktails and food, including a signature NSC Gin & Tonic inspired by childhood memories. The bar has been open for dinner since late 2019, but plans to restore morning service. With a focus on communal dining and a diverse menu, No Sleep Club seeks to cater to a wide range of customers, offering a unique experience in Singapore's nightlife scene.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng
In a nod to the historical plantations in the neighbourhood, The Bar at 15 Stamford's signature cocktail Plantation 1840 features rum, pineapple juice, and sugarcane.
In Full Bloom, one of the signature cocktails at botanic-themed Ginger.Lily, is served in a clear infuser that displays a mix of fruit and herbs.

site_title: Fashion retailer H&M’s Q4 operating profit tumbles more than expected
summary: H&M's operating profit for its Q4 (September-November) fell 87% to 821 million kronor (S$105 million), exceeding analyst expectations of 3.67 billion kronor. The drop was attributed to soaring costs and weakening consumer confidence. The Swedish fashion retailer's stock plummeted 7.9%.

images.alt_text: British retailers are battling against weak consumer demand as prices hit a fresh record high this month, with brands increasingly having to pass costs on to consumers.

Third-quarter net sales at the Swedish group were up 3 per cent from a year earlier at 57.5 billion kronor (S$7.6 billion), short of the 5 per cent which analysts polled by Refinitiv had forecast for the June-August quarter.
Swedish fashion retailer H&M says its Russian business accounted for about 4 per cent of its 199 billion kronor (S$26.7 million) in sales during the last financial year.
H&M and rival brick-and-mortar retailers have seen a rebound in sales as consumers refresh wardrobes for work and special events after 2 years spent mostly stuck at home.
Although it was open earlier this month, the 3-storey building in downtown Shanghai was on Friday (Jun 24) boarded up with its H&M signage gone.

site_title: From Seoul to London, Tottenham’s Son Heung-min exudes global appeal
summary: South Korean footballer Son Heung-min, captain of Tottenham Hotspur and the South Korean national team, has solidified his global appeal through his achievements on and off the pitch. With 108 international appearances, including a World Cup appearance, Son has become a seven-time Asian Footballer of the Year and the first Asian to win the Golden Boot. He recently became AIA Singapore's first brand ambassador, aiming to promote holistic wellness in three key aspects. Despite Tottenham's current fifth-place position in the English Premier League, Son is focused on the future, looking to improve and inspire young footballers.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

Manchester City's Kevin De Bruyne in action earlier this month.  The team generated total revenue of 731 million euros (S$1.04 billion), followed by Real Madrid (714 million euros) and Liverpool (702 million euros) in Deloitte's Football Money League rankings.
