site_title: Brokers’ take: Analysts positive on MLT acquisition plans, but wary of near-term forex weakness
summary: Analysts remain optimistic about Mapletree Logistics Trust's (MLT) acquisition plans, but are cautious about near-term forex weakness and rising borrowing costs, which could weigh on distributable income growth. OCBC Investment Research and Citi analyst Brandon Lee warn that improved acquisitions outlook may be offset by near-term forex weakness, potentially denting the Reit's share price.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
For the latest nine-month period, MLT’s gross revenue grew 11.3 per cent to S$551.7 million.
Mapletree Logistics Trust's manager said that capital released from the divestments will give it flexibility to pursue investment opportunities of modern assets.
The last time there were no S-Reit IPOs was in 2008 and 2009, in the aftermath of the Global Financial Crisis.
The proposed sale price of 3 Changi South Lane represents a 39.2 per cent premium to the property’s latest valuation of S$15.8 million as at Oct 1.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What happened today
summary: Rising interest rates may boost local lenders' earnings, as higher margins could offset cost pressures. Analysts expect banks and consumer sectors to perform well in Q4 earnings. The infrastructure sector is gaining traction as investors seek stable returns. Wealthy foreigners buying Singapore properties may be avoiding family offices to circumvent financial disincentives. High-interest-rate environment is unlikely to hinder innovation, but may require correction of valuations and regulation. A US$1.1 billion nickel scam case involving Ng Yu Zhi is set to be heard by the High Court, with a possible 20-year imprisonment if convicted.

images.alt_text: Hospitality S-Reits such as CapitaLand Ascott Trust are expected to ride on the tailwinds of the return of Chinese tourists.
The latest NODX print comes after Singapore’s manufacturing Purchasing Managers’ Index resumed its downward trajectory in December, dipping 0.1 point to 49.7.
Consumer sentiments on overall inflation are mixed, with some 41 per cent of those surveyed expecting inflation to decrease while 45 per cent feel that it would increase.

site_title: Nelson Loh, Singaporean linked to Newcastle United takeover bid, remanded for another week
summary: Nelson Loh, a 43-year-old Singaporean co-founder of Novena Global Healthcare Group, has been remanded in prison for another week. Loh faces forgery charges for allegedly forging financial statements in 2019, which he used to obtain S$18 million in bank loans. His employee, Michael Wong, also appeared in court and had his bail application denied. The case remains under investigation, and both men have been in prison for over a year after being wanted by the police since 2020.

images.alt_text: (Pictured) Nelson Loh, co-founder of Novena Global Healthcare Group, and his employee Michael Wong have been arrested and charged, the police said on Monday.
Ng Yu Zhi was declared bankrupt last month on the application of the liquidators of his companies.

site_title: Do AI-generated works infringe copyright?
summary: The use of AI-generated works and data mining for training AI models raises questions about copyright infringement. Under the Singapore Copyright Act, data mining for training AI models may be deemed "fair use" if it meets certain conditions, but the outcome is uncertain. AI-generated works may infringe on copyrights if they reproduce or are substantially similar to copyrighted works. Artists and creators should document their process to prove originality, and users of AI software should exercise prudence to avoid infringement. The issue remains unclear, with liability potentially falling on users or the owner/operator of the AI system, and the debate also touches on ethical considerations.

images.alt_text: Businesses often view intellectual property in a legal context or as a cost centre rather than as assets that are core to business strategy, growth and ultimate enterprise value.
Interactions among avatars in the metaverse could result in breaches of the law, as in the real world.
NFTs: Are they art or artifice?

INTEL on Tuesday (May 10) launched a new chip called Gaudi2 focused on artificial intelligence computing, as the chip manufacturer makes a bigger push into the AI chip market currently dominated by Nvidia.

site_title: Billions still exposed to toxic trans fat: WHO
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) reports that five billion people remain exposed to toxic trans fat, despite efforts to eliminate it by 2023. Trans fat is linked to 500,000 premature deaths from coronary heart disease annually. While 43 countries have implemented best-practice policies, many countries, including nine with high coronary heart disease deaths, are not taking action. The WHO calls for urgent action from these countries, emphasizing the cost-effectiveness and health benefits of eliminating trans fat.

images.alt_text: India shipped 5 million eggs to Malaysia in December, and will ship 10 million in January and up to 15 million in February.

site_title: Australia jobs take surprise dip in Dec, but unemployment stays low
summary: Australia's job market experienced a surprise decline in December, with a net employment drop of 14,600 from November, missing forecasts for an increase of 22,500. Despite this, the jobless rate remained at 3.5%, near a 48-year low. Full-time employment rose 17,600 jobs, while total job gains for the year stood at 452,000. The tight labor market is expected to influence the Reserve Bank of Australia's decision to raise interest rates, with a 60% probability of a quarter-point hike.

images.alt_text: The Westpac-Melbourne Institute index of consumer sentiment released on Tuesday rose 5.0 per cent in January, the largest monthly gain since April 2021.

site_title: Singapore stocks snap 2-day losing streak; STI rises 0.3%
summary: Singapore stocks ended a two-day losing streak with a 0.3% gain, bringing the Straits Times Index (STI) to 3,289.55 points. SIA's share price rose 0.9% to S$5.88, despite brokerage CGS-CIMB downgrading its call from "add" to "hold" due to decreased upside potential. Analysts suggest a possible turning point for global equity fund flows, with inflows picking up in China, Asia, and Japan, while US equity inflows slow.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek

site_title: Chinese heritage restaurants hold on to tradition
summary: A handful of old-school Chinese restaurants in Singapore, such as Cheng Hoo Thian, Plum Village, and Lai Wah, are defying the challenges of the F&B industry by staying true to their traditional culinary roots. Despite the pandemic and rising costs, these family-run eateries continue to thrive, thanks to their loyal customer base and dedication to preserving heritage recipes. Owners like Jimmy Koh and Lai Fak Nian are committed to teaching their children and younger staff members the art of traditional Chinese cooking, ensuring the continuation of these beloved eateries.

images.alt_text: Yue Bai's minimalist interiors.

site_title: Battle for the board
summary: Singapore-listed companies face varying degrees of success in boardroom challenges, with some cases resulting in the removal of incumbent directors and others failing. The Companies Act provides rules for shareholder requisitions, but its application can be complex and contentious. Recent cases, such as Kitchen Culture and Allied Technologies, have seen success, but others, like Metech and QT Vascular, have failed. Regulators, such as the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (ACRA), may play a greater role in overseeing boardroom challenges to prevent protracted delays and promote fairness. An independent oversight body could also help resolve disputes and minimize harm to minority shareholders.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim

Poggenpohl showroom by Kitchen Culture. Ooway Group became a substantial shareholder of Kitchen Culture in 2020, after it sold 30 per cent of its subsidiary Ooway Technology to Kitchen Culture in exchange for 90 million shares – around 21.2 per cent – of Kitchen Culture.

The latest requisition letter referred to the company’s announcement on Nov 6 in relation to another requisition letter dated Nov 4 from Ng Eng Tiong, who is seeking an EGM to remove the company’s chief executive officer.

site_title: Suntec Reit’s H2 DPU falls 9.7% to S$0.04074 as financing costs rise
summary: Suntec Reit's second-half distribution per unit (DPU) fell 9.7% to S$0.04074 due to higher interest expense, resulting in a 27.8% rise in finance costs. Despite a 16.9% increase in gross revenue to S$223.7 million, distributable income dropped 9% to S$117.3 million. The Reit's manager expects higher interest rates, weaker exchange rates, and higher energy costs to impact distributions significantly in the near term, with potential divestment of mature assets to strengthen the balance sheet.

images.alt_text: RHB Research downgrades its call on Suntec Real Estate Investment Trust (Reit) to “neutral” from “buy” amid slowing growth and rising rates in the technology sector.
Suntec Reit's gross revenue and net property income rose in Q3 on stronger operational performance.
The manager of Suntec Reit says its stronger operational performance was weighed down by interest rate and exchange rate pressures.

site_title: 🍊 Dealing with difficult CNY conversations
summary: During Chinese New Year (CNY), relatives may ask intrusive and judgmental questions, triggering insecurities. Experts suggest setting personal boundaries, keeping responses short and general, and using humor as a deflection tactic. However, these tactics may not address underlying issues. It's essential to reflect on perception bias and consider why such questions make you anxious. By developing self-awareness and a stronger sense of identity, you can become less affected by others' opinions, making CNY a more enjoyable experience.

images.alt_text: Chloe Lim

site_title: Bank of Japan keeps yield control policy unchanged, dollar surges
summary: The Bank of Japan maintained its ultra-low interest rates, including a 0.5% cap for the 10-year bond yield, in a unanimous decision defying market expectations of a policy change. This decision follows the central bank's surprise move last month to double the yield band, which has failed to correct market distortions. The move sent the dollar surging nearly 2% against the yen, its largest one-day percentage jump since June 17. The BOJ has faced pressure to address rising inflation and wage expectations, but chose to keep its yield control policy unchanged.

images.alt_text: The bank advised on US$3.42 billion in equity capital market deals last year across the Asia Pacific.
Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida is greeted by US President Joe Biden as he arrives at the White House in Washington, US, Jan 13, 2023.

site_title: Jia He Grand serves dressed-up Cantonese fare at friendly prices
summary: Jia He Grand, a new Chinese restaurant in Singapore, offers respectable cooking at friendly prices, with a focus on traditional Cantonese dishes. Located near Farrer Park Hospital, the restaurant serves dim sum and appetizers with a variety of options, including siew mai, har kau, and xiao long pau. The combination platter and braised pig tendon and sea cucumber dishes are standouts, with the crispy rice noodles doused in eggy gravy also impressing. Mango pudding flambe is a disappointing finale, but overall, Jia He Grand is a worthwhile visit for those seeking authentic Chinese cuisine in a convenient location.

images.alt_text: Thirty9's modern rustic interiors.

site_title: BlackRock’s Fink says ESG narrative has become ugly, personal
summary: BlackRock CEO Larry Fink stated that the ESG (Environmental, Social, and Governance) investing narrative has become "ugly" and is causing "huge polarization." Fink claims attacks on the firm are now personal, with some on the right criticizing its policies for harming the fossil-fuel industry and others on the left arguing it is not doing enough to address climate change. To counter this, BlackRock has increased lobbying efforts and investments in US political campaigns. Fink plans to write a letter to business leaders focusing on the concept of hope to change the narrative.

site_title: India’s Infosys Q3 profit beats estimates
summary: Infosys, India's No 2 IT services firm, reported a quarterly profit of 65.86 billion rupees (S$1 billion), beating estimates of 65 billion rupees. The company's strong deal pipeline helped it overcome a challenging macro environment, with consolidated net profit increasing from 58.09 billion rupees a year ago. The results are a positive sign for the IT sector despite global economic uncertainty.

site_title: Adani to give 10% discount in India’s biggest follow-on offer
summary: Gautam Adani's flagship company, Adani Enterprises, will offer a 10% discount to large investors in India's biggest follow-on share sale, aiming to raise $3.2 billion. Retail investors will be allowed to pay in tranches, potentially with a 50% upfront payment and two instalments. The sale will help Adani meet goals of broadening his investor base, repaying debt, and winning over mom-and-pop investors, amid concerns over his empire's thin trading stocks.

images.alt_text: View of Mount Carmel city and port of Haifa in northern Israel. The sale of one Israel’s main seaports marks the culmination of a nearly two-decade reform of an underperforming sector plagued for years by labour strikes.
“As a part of the company’s business growth strategy, we continue to evaluate various viable options,” an Adani Group representative said.

site_title: Pitching Picasso to the masses: Artex plans exchange for artwork
summary: A new art exchange, Artex, plans to list its first painting in the first half of 2023, allowing investors to buy shares of artwork alongside stocks and bonds. The platform, co-founded by a Liechtenstein prince and investment bankers, aims to make art more accessible and regulated. Artex will list works by famous artists, including Picasso, and will have a secondary market with real-time prices and brokers. The platform's success is uncertain, with some experts questioning the value of art as an investment and the risk of thin liquidity.

images.alt_text: While sticking with the familiar, such as Singapore-listed stocks, is sensible, it can be good to become knowledgeable about other markets.
Blockchain has promised much but delivered little.
It’s the latest lawsuit to target celebrities for their promotions of digital financial products.

site_title: Can craft beer companies rescue malt liquor’s reputation?
summary: Craft breweries are attempting to revamp the reputation of malt liquor, a style often associated with low-quality, high-alcohol beers. Companies like Virginia Beer, Barrel Brothers Brewing, and Samuel Adams are releasing malt liquors with unique flavor profiles and higher ABVs, aiming to appeal to craft beer fans. While some see this as a way to "make a hip" product, others worry about cultural appropriation. As the category experiences declining sales, these efforts may help malt liquor shed its negative image and attract new consumers.

site_title: Dwayne “The Rock” Johnson’s Zoa Energy drink plots major marketing push
summary: Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson's energy drink brand Zoa is set to triple its marketing spending in 2023, aiming to increase brand visibility and drive growth. The brand has revamped its packaging and will launch pop-up shops, contests, and influencer programs. Johnson will be heavily involved in promoting the brand, which has broken $100 million in retail sales in its first full year and is available at 50,000 distribution points. The company expects triple-digit percentage growth in 2023 and is eyeing international expansion.

site_title: Goldman Sachs misses profit estimates on dealmaking slump
summary: Goldman Sachs reported a 69% drop in fourth-quarter profit to $1.19 billion, or $3.32 per share, due to heavy losses in its consumer business and a 48% slump in investment banking fees. The bank's investment banking unit was hit by dealmaking activity stalls, while its trading business was boosted by market volatility. Overall net revenue fell 16% to $10.6 billion. The bank's consumer unit reported a 10-month loss of $1.2 billion, and its platform solutions unit reported a pre-tax loss of $778 million.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo for Goldman Sachs at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, New York, U.S., November 17, 2021. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly/File Photo

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Friday; STI up 0.7%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.7% on Friday, driven by overnight gains in US and European markets. The Straits Times Index (STI) gained 21.47 points to 3,289.25. Gainers outnumbered losers 91 to 28, with top performers including Genting Singapore, Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, and Lendlease Reit. Local banks UOB, DBS, and OCBC also saw gains, following overnight increases in US stocks.

images.alt_text: UOB has priced S$850 million in 5.25 per cent perpetual capital securities. The perps will be issued under UOB’s US$30 billion global medium term note programme, and are intended to qualify as additional Tier 1 capital.

site_title: The Last of Us – a new test for video game adaptations
summary: The HBO series "The Last of Us" has broken the curse of video game adaptations, with a 97% positive review score on Rotten Tomatoes and predicted to be the streaming world's first success of 2023. The nine-episode series, developed by Neil Druckmann and Craig Mazin, remains faithful to the original game and follows the unlikely duo of Joel and Ellie in a post-apocalyptic America. The stakes are high for HBO Max, which has raised its US subscription fee in anticipation of the series' success, and analysts predict that the show's success hinges on its ability to tell a compelling character story apart from the game.

site_title: ExxonMobil dismissed own global warming forecast: study
summary: A study published in Science found that ExxonMobil's own scientists accurately predicted global warming from fossil fuels as far back as the late 1970s, but the company publicly downplayed climate change despite the predictions. Researchers analyzed 32 internal documents and 72 peer-reviewed publications, finding that ExxonMobil's projections closely tracked subsequent observed temperature increases. The study's findings support long-held accusations that ExxonMobil knew about the threat of global warming decades ago, despite publicly denying it.

images.alt_text: The EU's windfall profits tax is “counter-productive,” discourages investments and undermines investor confidence, ExxonMobil spokesperson Casey Norton said on Wednesday.
Exxon will continue to supply finished lubricants and chemical products in Thailand through a new company to be formed.

site_title: Tesla files for US$776m expansion of Texas gigafactory
summary: Tesla has filed for a $776 million expansion of its Texas gigafactory, marking one of its largest investment drives since setting up a $5.5 billion facility in Germany. The expansion will add five new facilities, including a cell test lab, at its Austin site. The move comes as Tesla faces production and logistics challenges at its Shanghai hub and growing demand concerns. The company's fourth-quarter deliveries fell short of market estimates, and it is expected to host an investor day on March 1 to disclose plans for expansion and capital allocation.

images.alt_text: China’s decision to end a more than decade-long subsidy for EV purchases has forced automakers, including Tesla, to deepen discounts to maintain sales, as demand eases in the world’s largest car market.
The waiting time for orders of the rear-wheel-drive and long-range versions of Model Y were a week longer on Monday than on Friday.

site_title: Pharma companies say new drug price law leaves them in limbo
summary: US pharmaceutical companies are in limbo due to the Inflation Reduction Act, which allows the government to negotiate prices for some drugs and charge rebates for price hikes. The uncertainty of future revenue has led to a chilling effect on deals and investment, with executives citing concerns about the impact on innovation and development of new products. The law's structure, which allows price negotiations after 9-13 years, may encourage companies to wait to bring new drugs to market, potentially delaying treatment for patients.

images.alt_text: Pfizer chief executive Albert Bourla said that talks with China on future pricing for antiviral drug Paxlovid had broken off after China had asked for a lower price than Pfizer is charging for most lower middle income countries.
Clovis says it has liabilities of between US$500 million and US$1 billion.

site_title: Why you shouldn’t put all your money in T-bills and SSBs (answer: you won’t beat inflation)
summary: Investors in Singapore are attracted to T-bills and SSBs due to their high yields, but experts caution against putting all money into these assets. With interest rates rising to combat inflation, yields on T-bills and SSBs are below the inflation rate, making them less attractive. Experts recommend diversifying investments and allocating 60% to equities and 40% to bonds to beat inflation. While bonds are nearly risk-free, they may not keep pace with inflation, and investors should consider other assets like equities and ETFs to form a balanced portfolio.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
The last time yields were at the 4 per cent level was in 1989.
T-bills can be purchased by anyone above the age of 18, even non-Singapore residents. They can also be purchased by institutions.
Although interest rates have risen significant on an absolute basis, investors should also take into account relative return.

site_title: The power of two
summary: Two high-end watch collaborations have emerged in 2023, combining Swiss luxury with Japanese streetwear. Franck Muller and #FR2 have collaborated on a limited edition timepiece, the #FR2NCK Muller Vanguard, featuring a unique carbon and glass fibre composite case and Super-Luminova details. Meanwhile, Bell & Ross and Alain Silberstein have teamed up to reimagine the BR-03, resulting in three watches: Klub 22, Krono 22, and Marine 22, each priced between $6,100 and $9,300.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan
Audemars Piguet's Limited Edition Royal Oak Selfwinding 34mm in Black Ceramic in Collaboration with Carolina Bucci .

site_title: Stripe cuts internal valuation by 11%: The Information
summary: Stripe has cut the internal value of its shares by about 11%, valuing the company at $63 billion, according to a report. This is the third time Stripe has reduced its valuation since June, with a total reduction of about 40% in the past six months. The move comes as the company adjusts to growing operating costs and overhiring, following a 14% headcount cut in November.

site_title: Indonesia president says ‘strongly regrets’ past rights violations in country
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo acknowledged "gross human rights violations" in his country's past, including the 1965 bloodshed that killed at least 500,000 people and jailed a million or more suspected of being communists. The president expressed regret for 11 incidents spanning 1965-2003, including student protests and violence against the Chinese community. He vowed to restore the rights of victims "fairly and wisely" without negating judicial resolving, but critics say acknowledgement and expression of regret are insufficient without cases being legally resolved and perpetrators tried.

images.alt_text: When asked about an upcoming reshuffle, Indonesia's President Joko Widodo confirmed he was planning a Cabinet shake-up.

site_title: Australia trade surplus tops forecasts at A$13.2b in November
summary: Australia's trade surplus widened to A$13.2 billion in November, exceeding forecasts of A$10.5 billion. Imports dropped 1.5% due to a decline in consumption and capital goods, while exports slipped 0.4% mainly due to a sharp fall in liquefied natural gas exports. The surplus rise offset a dip in iron ore earnings. The Australian Bureau of Statistics reported the figures on Thursday, showing a significant improvement in the country's trade balance.

site_title: A Kyoto state of zen
summary: Roku Kyoto, a luxury resort in Kyoto, Japan, offers a serene and modern experience blending ancient heritage and contemporary design. The resort, named after the three mountains of Takagamine, is set amidst lush greenery and features a stunning Japanese garden. With its unique blend of traditional craftsmanship and modern amenities, Roku Kyoto provides a tranquil retreat for travelers. The resort's culinary offerings, led by chef Akira Taniguchi, showcase seasonal ingredients and artistic presentation, while its spa and cultural experiences cater to those seeking relaxation and immersion in Japanese culture.

images.alt_text:
syluxeoman13 - oman FH8A2254

credit stefanie yuen thio

site_title: Seven in 10 Singapore fund managers see 10-20% upside to Asian equities in 2023
summary: Singapore fund managers are optimistic about Asian equities in 2023, with 7 in 10 expecting a 10-20% recovery in the MSCI AC Asia Ex Japan Index. About half believe Asian credit yields will drop 50-100 basis points. The optimism stems from attractive valuations and China's relaxation of Covid-19 policies, which fund managers see as a "light in the gloomy" global recession outlook. The survey also found growing appetite for fixed income strategies and ESG investments, but caution about emerging market local currency bonds and margin erosion.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting
Equity hedge funds, where the bulk of the industry’s roughly US$3.7 trillion in assets are invested, however fared worse with a 10.4 per cent loss.
Credit Suisse has said that it is set to report a loss of up to 1.5 billion francs for the final three months of 2022, partly on the back of historic outflows of client funds.
Malaysia's tourism-related stocks have gained buying interest as analysts expect the Chinese tourists will catalyse the country's economy.

site_title: Creator of memories
summary: Renowned interior designer Tony Chi, who stepped down from his eponymous studio four years ago, is still as busy as ever. Chi believes design should be subtle and in the background, allowing a space to feel intimate and personal. He emphasizes the importance of living essentials, such as home etiquette, taste, and curated items, in creating a sense of hospitality. Chi's studio has designed luxury hotels for brands like Rosewood and Mandarin Oriental, and he has recently received the Lifetime Achievement Award from the Interior Design Confederation Singapore. He is now focusing on creating private residences, only for clients who view their property as a treasure to pass on to the next generation.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang
Creating a lasting legacy

site_title: Bountiful blessings for Chinese New Year
summary: PARKROYAL COLLECTION Marina Bay in Singapore celebrates Chinese New Year with its signature creations. Chef Edward Chong's "Harvest Yusheng" Lo Hei platter features a nitrogen-frozen rose, abalone, kanpachi, and organic fruits. This unique dish adds drama to the traditional Chinese New Year yusheng tossing, promoting a healthy and prosperous start to the year.

images.alt_text: yi by Jereme Leung $188 Set Menu

site_title: Heritage cuisine with a modern touch
summary: Chef Jereme Leung of Singapore's yì restaurant creates Chinese New Year menus showcasing ingredients from different Chinese provinces, blending tradition with modernity. The restaurant's philosophy features unique and seasonal ingredients, such as yellow pepper paste from Hainan and five-year aged turnip from Guangdong. Leung draws inspiration from his childhood memories of working in his mother's family restaurants, where every condiment was made in-house. He looks forward to celebrating the year of the water rabbit with his family and hopes to introduce lesser-known ingredients to guests.

images.alt_text: yi by Jereme Leung $188 Set Menu

site_title: Luka Zhang Lei: Beauty & brains
summary: Singapore model Luka Zhang Lei has made a name for herself in the fashion world with her striking features and androgynous style. However, few know that she is also a PhD graduate from Nanyang Technological University's School of Humanities, with a dissertation on working-class literature. Zhang balances her modeling career with her love for literature and social sciences, citing influences like Maxim Gorky and Anton Chekhov. When asked about her future, she expresses a desire to pursue academia, saying "Trust the trail of tears / and learn to live."

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
Sng wears a peach shirt and off-white suit by Celine, as well as a  B.Zero1 pendant chain necklace, B.Zero1 rings, B.Zero1 bangle and Octo Finissimo Chronograph GMT watch, all by Bulgari.
JJ Lin feeling festive at the Little Social., a private Peranakan home dining space. He wears a knitted pullover and denim jeans by Louis Vuitton.

site_title: Volkswagen Group sales down 7% in 2022 despite stronger second half
summary: Volkswagen Group reported a 7% decline in vehicle deliveries to 8.3 million in 2022, despite a 12% increase in the second half. The company's first-half output dropped by over 20% due to supply chain disruptions from the Ukraine war and COVID-19 lockdowns in China. Volkswagen remains Europe's top battery-electric vehicle maker, with all-electric sales up 26%. The company is confident about 2023 despite a weakening macroeconomic environment and ongoing supply chain shortages.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A technician cleans a Volkswagen logo at the production line for electric car models of the Volkswagen Group, in Zwickau, Germany, April 26, 2022. REUTERS/Matthias Rietschel/File Photo

site_title: Most Japan households predict higher prices, keeps pressure on BOJ
summary: Japan households' inflation expectations rose to 85% in December, with a 9.7% forecast for price increases in one year. This increase, coupled with rising food and fuel costs, suggests conditions may be ripe for the Bank of Japan to phase out its stimulus program. Core consumer prices rose 4% in December, exceeding the BOJ's 2% target for a seventh straight month. The BOJ is expected to upgrade its inflation forecasts at a rate review next week, supporting the conviction that domestic demand will sustainably keep inflation around 2% in coming years.

images.alt_text: A woman chooses products at a drug store in Tokyo, Japan January 10, 2023. REUTERS/Issei Kato

site_title: Show goes on at Palestinian theatres overcoming obstacles
summary: Palestinian theatres continue to operate despite Israeli raids and gunfights in the Jenin refugee camp, where a 16-year-old girl was killed in December. The Freedom Theatre, directed by Mustafa Sheta, held a show despite the tension, with actors taking the stage as planned. Despite obstacles, Palestinian artists emphasize the importance of continuing to create and deliver art to people, particularly in areas where freedom of expression is threatened. Other theatres in Jerusalem and the West Bank face similar challenges, including reduced audiences and economic strain.

images.alt_text: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has sought to calm concerns about the fate of civil rights and diplomacy since his bloc of nationalist and religious parties secured a Parliamentary majority in a Nov 1 election.

site_title: Tan Chong expects unrealised loss of HK$222 million in FY22
summary: Tan Chong International expects an unrealised loss of HK$222 million (S$37.9 million) for FY22 due to share price changes of its listed investments. This is an increase from the HK$170 million loss in the same period last year. The company's final results announcement will be made before the end of March 2023.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan

site_title: Singapore’s unemployment rates stay low in November: MOM
summary: Singapore's unemployment rate remained steady at 1.9% in November, mirroring pre-pandemic levels, according to the Ministry of Manpower (MOM). Resident unemployment was 2.8%, with 65,700 unemployed residents, mostly citizens. MOM expects the unemployment situation to hold steady due to the tight labour market, with short-term fluctuations likely to be frictional.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
In addition to easing manpower shortages by filling lower-wage roles, foreign talent are also sought after to take up top positions and transfer knowledge and resources to Singaporeans.
The number of job vacancies fell to 108,200 in September. Meanwhile, the ratio of job vacancies to unemployed persons also decreased to 2.20.

site_title: SPH Media advertiser rates pegged to third-party data sources, not circulation data
summary: SPH Media, the publisher of several Singaporean newspapers, has clarified that its advertising packages are based on reach and readership data from independent third-party research agencies, not circulation data. The company collected data through a survey panel representative of the Singapore population and verified it through GfK. This follows a review of internal processes in March 2022, which found inconsistencies in circulation data resulting in a 10-12% discrepancy. The clarification aims to provide transparency on the company's media rates and advertising packages.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
The inconsistencies led to a 10 to 12 per cent discrepancy in circulation figures.

site_title: Strong 7.6-magnitude quake hits off Indonesia: USGS
summary: A 7.6-magnitude earthquake struck off Indonesia's Tanimbar Islands Region and East Timor, 427km south of Ambon island, at a depth of 95km. The quake was felt on islands of Timor, Maluku, and Papua, with some aftershocks reported at a magnitude of 5.5. Although there were no reports of damage or victims, the Indonesian geophysics agency initially warned of a potential tsunami, which was later lifted. The quake was also felt in Darwin, Australia, where at least 1,000 people reported it.

site_title: Macron presses ahead with pension reform as French discontent swells
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron's government plans to unveil a pension reform overhaul, aiming to raise the retirement age to 64 or 65 from 62, amid growing social discontent over the cost of living. The reform, necessary to balance the pension system's finances, faces opposition from trade unions, including the CFDT, which has threatened protests. Macron's government aims to balance the accounts without raising taxes or cutting pensions, but the passage through parliament will be challenging, with Macron lacking a working majority.

images.alt_text: A banner for the Force Ouvriere (FO), the Totalenergies Carling’s trade unionists, hangs at the entrance to the petrochemical site of Carling, north-eastern France on Sept27, 2022, as workers demand an increase in wages, an unwinding of profit-sharing, the resumption in hiring.

site_title: Salesforce aims to cut costs by US$3b to US$5b: Fortune
summary: Salesforce aims to cut costs by $3 billion to $5 billion through restructuring, following the announcement of 10% job cuts and office closures. CEO Marc Benioff stated that real estate will be a major focus, with the company looking to reduce its space. The cost-cutting measures come as the company navigates an economic slowdown and rapid pandemic hiring. Benioff also hinted at potential further layoffs, citing lack of productivity from new account executives. The move is part of the broader trend of big tech firms cutting jobs in preparation for a potential recession.

images.alt_text: Amazon.com’s layoffs will now include more than 18,000 roles as part of a workforce reduction it previously disclosed.
The reductions will cost Salesforce US$1.4 billion to US$2.1 billion, the company said.
Microsoft launched its emissions tracking platform in June, and has recently announced a new carbon offset tracing service.

site_title: AP Strategic unit proposes to sell China hotel assets for 80m yuan
summary: AP Strategic's subsidiary, Grand Canal Culture Tourism Group, plans to sell its stake in a China hotel management company for 80 million yuan, expecting net proceeds of 70.4 million yuan. The sale will help repay term loans and settle existing creditors. The hotel, Anatole by Landison Hotel Huzhou, has 113 rooms and a lease term expiring in 2056. The deal is subject to shareholder approval and follows a trading suspension lifted by AP Strategic.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

APS said the new consideration was arrived after an arm’s length negotiation and after agreeing to take into account an independent valuation of Catapult Venture, which is to be completed before the acquisition.

site_title: India central banker sees inflation, debt as risks in region
summary: Reserve Bank of India Governor Shaktikanta Das warns that sustained price pressures and rising debt in South Asia pose risks to economic growth, emphasizing the need to prioritize price stability. He calls for multilateral cooperation and deep structural reforms, highlighting the importance of IMF's role in capacity building. Das also suggests strengthening energy cooperation to boost resilience against external shocks and accelerating the transition to a green economy.

site_title: Chinese rush to renew passports as Covid border curbs lifted
summary: China dropped its Covid border controls on Sunday, allowing its 1.4 billion residents to travel abroad for the first time in three years. Long queues formed outside immigration offices in Beijing as people rushed to renew their passports. The move is seen as a significant step in China's dismantling of its "zero-Covid" regime, which began last month following historic protests. While domestic travel is expected to recover, outbound travel is still limited due to flight shortages and travel restrictions from other countries, with some nations requiring negative Covid tests from Chinese visitors.

images.alt_text: The immediate impact of China's border reopneing is a surge of overseas Chinese returning home, many of whom have not seen family for years.

site_title: Apac IPOs most resilient in 2022; tech and energy groups lead large issuances: EY
summary: The Asia-Pacific (Apac) IPO market was the most resilient in 2022, with a 26% decline in IPO volume and 31% decline in size, compared to a 50% decline globally. Tech and energy groups led large issuances, with renewable energy, electric vehicles, and green hydrogen driving energy IPOs. Chinese electric vehicle startup Nio was among the largest IPO issuances. However, the Asean market faces headwinds due to global inflation and interest rate hikes, and EY expects conditions to improve with reduced Covid-19 restrictions and positive market sentiment.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
Tech IPOs in the region has tapered off after a flurry of listings from Grab to Blibli, as exiting via public markets aren't as attractive to investors as in the past.
SGX welcomed 11 new listings in 2022. The companies raised a total of S$580.3 million, according to bourse data.

site_title: BT Future of Finance: Why digital-only banking (Ep 4)
summary: Digital-only banking is the future of finance, despite misconceptions surrounding it. Dwaipayan Sadhu, CEO of Trust Bank, discusses the benefits of digital banks, including increased efficiency, reduced costs, and improved customer experience. Digital banks are particularly relevant in Singapore, where they can address risk and fraud concerns. The industry is also exploring new developments, such as digital banking in wealth management. Ultimately, true digitalization is required to transform the banking sector, according to Sadhu.

images.alt_text: Transforming financial services will be the key to future proofing, according to Shayan Hazir, CDO, HSBC.
Heng Koon How from UOB discusses blockchain shock waves.
“And we all know happy employees mean happy customers!” - Serene Koh, OCBC Bank.

site_title: Bed Bath & Beyond warns it may go out of business
summary: Bed Bath & Beyond has warned it may go out of business, citing years of management missteps and a dysfunctional corporate culture that failed to compete with Amazon.com. The company has begun preparations for a bankruptcy filing, citing "substantial doubt" about its ability to stay in business. Bed Bath & Beyond expects to report a net loss of about $386 million for the third quarter, a 40% increase from the previous year. The company may try to restructure its debts or sell assets, but its shares have fallen 30% and its bonds have plummeted to new lows.

images.alt_text: Sheng Siong disclosed its China operations - all in Kunming - contributed 2.6 per cent of total revenue of S$333.5 million for Q3FY2022.

site_title: Volvo Cars’ sales rise in December, but down for 2022 amid supply chain headwinds
summary: Volvo Cars reported a 13% year-over-year increase in December car sales to 72,663 units, despite a 12% decline in full-year sales to 615,121 due to supply chain headwinds caused by lockdowns in China and component shortages. Despite the challenges, demand for Volvo Cars remained robust, with fully electric vehicles accounting for 20% of December sales, unchanged from the previous month.

site_title: Malaysia aims to finalise review of 5G rollout this quarter
summary: Malaysia aims to finalize its review of the 5G mobile services contract by this quarter, with Communications Minister Fahmi Fadzil stating that the government has concerns over contractual obligations and the speed of the network rollout. The review is being conducted by the government and state-run Digital Nasional (DNB), which is rolling out the 5G network with Swedish telecom major Ericsson. As of November 30, DNB had rolled out 2,575 5G towers, exceeding its forecast of 3,433 towers by the period.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's single wholesale network has reached 33.2 per cent of populated areas as at Sep 30 this year.

site_title: BlackRock, Citigroup among firms named fossil-fuel boycotters by Kentucky
summary: Kentucky Treasurer Allison Ball has named 11 financial institutions, including BlackRock, Citigroup, and JPMorgan Chase, as "hostile" to the fossil fuel industry due to their alleged boycotts. The firms will be required to divest from state entities within a year, except for certain exceptions. The move follows a similar strategy by Republican-led states and aims to counter liberal-leaning financial practices. The institutions have denied boycotting energy companies and claim their business practices align with Kentucky law.

images.alt_text: BlackRock sold about 1.2 million Keppel shares on Dec 12.

site_title: Poised Cantonese cooking with a healthy slant at Yue Bai
summary: Yue Bai, a new Cantonese restaurant in Singapore, offers a refreshing twist on traditional Chinese cuisine with a focus on healthy ingredients. Chef Lee Hongwei's creations, such as seven-flavored deep-fried burdock and pan-fried organic purple rice cakes, showcase his skill in turning medicinal foods into addictive snacks. The restaurant's menu also features hearty double-boiled soups, braised duck and sea cucumber, and egg-fried rice with cod fillet, all made with care and attention to detail. With its minimalist interiors and elegant cooking style, Yue Bai is a unique find in the crowded Singapore dining scene.

images.alt_text: Asia Grand's new interiors at Fairmont Singapore.

site_title: Japfa’s dairy spin-off AustAsia looks to double its revenue over five years
summary: AustAsia Group, Japfa's China dairy unit, aims to double its revenue over the next five years. The company's growth will primarily come from its dairy business, with a significant opportunity in the beef market. AustAsia recently completed its initial public offering (IPO) in Hong Kong, raising HK$99.3 million, but its shares have fallen 6.3% below the offer price. Despite the IPO's challenges, AustAsia's CEO Edgar Collins believes the listing will allow the company to "grow the business strategically" and maintain its independence.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi

“With the distribution and the listing of AustAsia shares, Japfa shareholders will now participate in two leading agri-food businesses, each with a clear focus, strategy and financial flexibility to grow further in their respective dynamic markets in Asia," said Tan Yong Nang, chief executive officer of Japfa.
印尼佳发公司希望掌握新兴亚洲市场快速发展的牛奶行业。 （印尼佳发公司提供）
Tan Yong Nang, chief executive officer of Japfa. The group posted a 59 per cent drop in net profit for 9M FY2022, despite recording higher revenue.
ST Engineering, one of the companies with the highest gearing ratios in H1, acquired a US-based transportation solutions provider called TransCore.

In a bourse filing on Friday (Oct 14) by Japfa's chief executive Tan Yong Nang, the company warned that there is no assurance that the proposed distribution or listing would materialise at all in due course.

site_title: Economists hopeful China’s reopening may cushion Singapore’s slowdown
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to experience modest growth in 2023, despite a global economic slowdown, with a forecast of 3.8% in 2022. China's border reopening may cushion the impact, particularly in the services sector, which could see a sustained recovery due to increased air travel and tourism. However, concerns about new Covid-19 variants from China may limit the upside risk. Domestic firms and consumers will still face elevated inflation and cost pressures, but the local job market is likely to remain generally supported.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
A general view shows the city skyline in Singapore on December 1, 2022. (Photo by Roslan RAHMAN / AFP)

site_title: Korean heritage in modern design
summary: South Korean architect Teo Yang aims to preserve the country's heritage in modern design. A graduate of the School of the Art Institute in Chicago and ArtCenter College of Design in Pasadena, Yang worked abroad before returning to Seoul in 2009. He incorporates traditional Korean aesthetics into his designs, often using hanok, traditional Korean houses, as a platform to showcase cultural heritage. Yang's work includes the interior refurbishments of two national museums in South Korea, and he has been appointed creative director for the Craft Trend Fair and Seoul Beauty Travel Week.

images.alt_text:
avluxedesign13 - Teo Yang Portrait

Credit: Teo Yang Studio

site_title: A House divided gives rise to debt ceiling jitters
summary: US House Republicans failed to elect Kevin McCarthy as speaker for the 10th time, amid divisions among hard-liners. This setback raises concerns about the upcoming debt ceiling, with Goldman Sachs' chief political economist Alec Phillips warning of increased market volatility and a potential sell-off in Treasury securities. The debt limit deadline later this year is expected to lead to a disruptive standoff, underscoring the risks of a US default.

site_title: Hidetoshi Nakata: making his mark from soccer to sake
summary: Former Japanese football legend Hidetoshi Nakata is shifting his focus from sports to promoting Japanese craftsmanship globally. Since 2009, he has traveled 110 countries and all 47 prefectures to learn about heritage traditions such as sake brewing and tea growing. Nakata founded the Japan Craft Sake Company in 2015, which introduces premium craft sake brands to a global audience through modern methods and blockchain technology. He also launched a luxury tea brand, Hanaahu, and aims to protect independent farmers and promote farm-based industries. Nakata believes stepping out of his comfort zone is key to his success and emphasizes the importance of travel and understanding different cultures.

site_title: A fabulous Chinese New Year
summary: Bulgari has unveiled its stunning Chinese New Year collection, featuring iconic and awe-inspiring pieces with auspicious red accents. The collection includes the Serpenti Viper Special Edition pendant necklace, Exclusive Edition bags, and a watch with dark pink alligator straps. Bulgari's B.zero1 jewellery collection, including rings, bangles, and necklaces, is also available, showcasing the brand's classic and confident designs.

images.alt_text:
ckluxebulgari13 - Reporter to caption

Credit: greenplastic soldiers

site_title: Italian food that counts at Thirty9
summary: Thirty9, a Mediterranean-themed Italian restaurant in Singapore, offers a reliable yet unexciting dining experience. The restaurant boasts modern rustic interiors and serves a range of dishes, including pizza, pasta, and seafood. Standout options include Burratina, Polpo, and Genovese pizza, which showcase the chef's knack for dressings and sauces. Prices are mid-high, with main courses ranging from S$28 to S$48. The restaurant's desserts are underwhelming, but the overall experience is palatable and comfortable. Rating: 6.5.

images.alt_text:
jedining12 - Thirty9 interiors

Credit: Jaime Ee

site_title: Ayden Sng: Embracing Chinese culture
summary: Actor Ayden Sng, known for his roles in Channel 8 and meWatch dramas, is a self-proclaimed Sinophile who celebrates Chinese New Year with great enthusiasm. Born into a family of Chinese culture, Sng learned Mandarin and erhu music at a young age, which helped him master his craft as an actor. He hopes to continue improving his acting skills and is currently working with an acting coach. Sng also has a deep appreciation for fashion, which he shares with his love for Chinese culture. This year's Chinese New Year celebration will be special for him as he reunites with his family and friends.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Raising a glass or two to the city that wears the crown
summary: New York and London are considered two of the world's best cities for wine, according to Eric Asimov. Unlike wine-making regions, these cities had to look far and wide for wine, making them great for discovering a wide variety of wines. Asimov visited London and discovered that great wine lists can be found in many types of restaurants, from casual eateries to Michelin-starred establishments. He highlights 12 places to try excellent wine, including The Drapers Arms, Hunan, Brat, and Noble Rot. Asimov notes that the key to great wine is not just the wine itself, but also the expertise and passion of the people who serve it.

images.alt_text: Diners toast at Brat in the Shoreditch neighborhood, in London, Dec. 28, 2022. ItÕs one of the worldÕs best cities for wine and you can find terrific lists in pubs, bars and all sorts of restaurants in almost any neighborhood. (Peter Flude/The New York Times)
